column2: Gen. J.W. Denver, California, Gen. C.L. Fitzhugh U.S.A.; Judge J.W. Clough, Oregon; and G. A. Henderson and son, Washington, are at the Metropolitan Hotel.
The first case tried was one of grand larceny, alleged to have been committed by John Simmons, an intelligent young man of not over 25 years of age.
Miss Neeley, of Mockville, N.C., shot a negro woman through the heart on the 2d inst., while the latter was engaged in a controversy with her master.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. A reckless bachelor, in blue satin waistcoat and red neck-tie, stands no chance in such a piece as "Still Waters Run Deep." The play, in its purpose and effect, is a glorification of dull husbands. John Mildway, the hero, wades quietly on the stilts of prudence to heights which fiery indiscretion in vain attempts to scale.

The new street-cleaning contractors have evidently not had a fair show. They have been expected to do wonders without material, and as the Hebrews of old were compelled to make bricks without straw, they are expected to keep the streets clean without men, tools, horses and carts, and this, too, in the face of ...

ARREST OF A SKILLFUL COUNTERFEITER SEIZURE OF MONEY, DIES, Yesterday Detectives ELDER and McCORD, THOMAS SAMPSON, of the Sub-Treasury Department, and Deputy-Marshall YOUNG, arrested JERRY COWSDEN, an experienced counterfeiter, at Guttenberg, N.J., while in the act of printing counterfeit 50 cent fractional currency.

The great practical measures of public policy which are now being acted on by the administration are those relating to (1) the principles and forms of reconstruction; (2) the question of negro suffrage; (3) the treatment of chief and prominent rebels.

NIBLO'S GARDEN. BOUCICAULT'S spectacular drama of "Arrah-na-pogue," of which we have heard so much, was produced here last evening, and received with favor, warming once or twice into enthusiasm, by an audience that was crowded in every part of the house. The drama is constructed with all Mr.
The royal mail steamship Persia, Capt. LOTT, which left Liverpool at 1 o'clock on the afternoon of the 1st, and Queenstown on the 2d of July, arrived here yesterday.

There has been an extensive fire in Mobile. Loss $10,000.
The Trade Convention reassembled this morning, and the balance of the committees were appointed.
The finds were quiet but steady. Consols on the 30th June closed at 90%@90 1/8 for both money and account.
By the stemship Eagle, Capt. LAWRENCE, arrived this morning, we have dates to 8th inst., at 1 P.M.

The contractors for cleaning the streets commenced work in earnest yesterday. In the Eighteenth Ward, at an early hour, about a dozen carts made their appearance, and the ashes and garbage, which have been accumulating for many day's past, were removed. Quite a strong police force had been detailed to protect the laborers, and two or three disturbances occurred during the day.
The Weekly returns of the Bank of France show an increase in the cash in hand of 15,250,000 francs, making the total bullion 20,500,000 sterling, a sum higher than has been touched for several years.

The New-York and New-Haven Railroads Company vs. Robert Schuyler and others. An injunction herein was personally served. The decree expressly modifies these orders in the manner therein setforth. This is in effect a continuation of those orders in the modified form. The judgement not extending but limiting

Major-Gen. HOWARD, Commissioner of the Bureau of Refugees, Freedman and Abandoned Lands, has issued a circular to assistant commissioners and other officers, saying no fixed rates of wagon will be prescribed for a district, but in order to regulate fair wages in given individualcases,the agent should bear in mind the minimum rates for his own guidance.
The following order, which has been in abeyance for some loss in order to positively define the geographical boundaries of the several departments, is officially promulgated to-day:

The First Maine Battery, numbering 122 men, and under the command of Capt. E.D. HALEY, arrived yesterday morning at 6 o'clock, and after remaining at the Battery all day, left by the Fall River line at 6 P.M., for Augusta,, Me., to be mustered out and paid off. The following officers accompany the battery : Capt. E.D. HALEY, First Lieuts. JOHN S. Snow and John GUINGs, Second Lieuts. MICHAEL MOONEY and E. FESSENDEN.
At the opening of the court His Honor charged the jury in regard to the case of Alexander Ward, reported yesterday. A verdict was returned of guilty, and the prisoner remanded for sentence.
The English steamship Comvay has brought news from Vera Cruz, which port it left on the 1st instant.

On Tuesday morning early the steamer Eagle arrived from New-York. Before entering the harbor, and at sunrise, she fired a salute of thirteen guns in honor of the day, and dressed the ship. During the forenoon Capt. LAWRENCE called on Gen. DE MARINA and obtained permission to fire a salute at noon of thirty-six guns, and at sunset another of thirteen guns.
Receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last: 8,272 bbls. Flour, 87,978 bushels Wheat, 28,964 bushels Corn, 41,878 bushels Oats, 10 pkgs. Provisions, and 151 bbls. Whisky.

The failure of the negotiations between the Italian Government and the Pope was the leading theme in Italy. The Opinione, of Florence, had stated that the Pope rejected the demand that the bishops should be required to take the oath of allegiance to the King of Italy, but had he consented to order them to yield obedience to the laws and to the State.

SPECIAL MEETING. The board met at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the President, JAMES M. McLEAN, Esq., in the chair. Commissioner FARR, replying to a query which the TIMES had put, said that this meeting had been called to enable the board to finish any incomplete work that might be on hand, this being the last Wednesday previous to the August vacation.
Hugh O'Brien was tried on an indictment for commiting rape upon Ellen Slatterly on the 14th of May.
The following letter from Ex-President BUCHANAN was read on the Fourth of July, at the celebration of the day by the Democrats of Harrisburgh,

Very few have any idea of the public charitable institutions situated on Blackwell's and Randall's Islands; but a glance at the last yearly report of the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections shows that over a hundred thousand people received relief at the hands of the commissioners.

The steamship Morning Star, Capt. HORATIO NELSON, arrived at this port this forenoon. The Morning Star left Greytown, Nic., July 5, with 772 passengers, who left San Francisco by the Moses Taylor on the 13th of June. July 10, lat. 28 deg. 10 min. N., long. 79 deg. 38 min. W., passed a large bark-rigged screw steamer bound north; also brig D.M. Jobson, of Boston, and a bark showing Spanish colors.

The Court met this morning at the usual hour, and the jury were brought in from the hotel. The room, as usual, was excessively crowded, a great number of ladies being present. Miss HARRIS entered the courtroom at 10:15 o'clock, lenaing on the arm of Mr. BRADLEY. Mr. BRADLEY announced that the testimony for the defence had closed yesterday evening.
The reports of the Transit Committee were taken up.

A.W. Heye et al. vs. The Ship Cordillera. The libelants having agreed with the ship to take 350 tierces of lard to Liverpool, sent it alongside the ship in a lighter. Two of the tierces fell from the slings and were injured. The testimony was conflicting as to whether it was in custody of the ship, or by whose carelessness if any, the accident occurred.

The Adjutant-Generals in convention to-day make reports showing the number of troops furnished by the following States: Maine, 66,669; killed and died 22,573; Vermont, 34,490; Connecticut, 54,468: Rhode Island, 25,355; West Virginia, 29,010; Massachusetts, 153,706; New-Hampshire, 33,258; Kansas, 21,948; Pennsylvania, 566,000; Iowa, 72,355.

Dr. NICHOLS, Superintendent of the Government Insane Asylum, was recalled to-day by the prosecution in the Mary Harris case. He had yesterday expressed the opinion that at certain periods between the time that she was crossed in love and the killing of N.K. BURROUGHS, she was insane; and he now entered into explanations on that subject, repeating that the homicide was of insane violence.

The speediest and most economical means of traveling to Europe has at length become the prevailing topic among our leading city merchants, and it is insisted that the expected successful laying of the great Atlantic wire should be hailed on this side by the immediate formation of a steamship company that shall eclipse all former attempts, and completely outstrip all present competitors.

The steamers Illinois and Empire City, which sailed with the Texas Expedition, arrived here last night via New-Orleans, with a number of refugees and discharged troops from Louisiana regiments. They sailed for New-York to-day.
The street-cleaners who refuse to work under the contractors, held another meeting at No. 76 Princestreet, yesterday. Mr. MICHAEL MOONEY presided.

A meeting to discuss the question of negro suffrage and reconstruction was held at the Metropolitan Hall last evening, D. HUDSON in the chair. The hall was about half filled, with an audience representing all political parties.
The body of an unknown man, about 28 years old, was found in the water near Fort Hamilton yesterday.

The Central Park Commissioners announce that if the weather is fine there will be music on the Mall, at the Park, this (Saturday) afternoon, commencing at 4 o'clock, by the Central Park Band, under the leadership of H.B. DODWORTH.

In the Plasterers' Convention, the manner in which ornamental work is done in certain cities by men not in the trade, was discussed at considerable length. A motion was unanimously carried that after the 1st of January next no plasterer work for bosses "who shall not put up their own ornaments."
Mr. J.A. BOWER, of Chicago, from the Committee on Commerce, made a report commending to the consideration of the Legislative bodies of the States and the nation the following subjects;
At a festival given to Gens. SHERMAN and COX, yesterday, at Columbus, Gen. SHERMAN, being enthusiastically called upon to make a speech, came forward and with much reluctance did so.

The Cincinnati Commercial publishes an installment of Gen. ROSECRANS' testimony before the Committee on the Conduct of the War. It discloses a lamentable lack of harmony between him and Gen. HALLECK. The following, relative to the battle of Chickamauga, is of interest:

About two hundred carts were employed yesterday in removing ashes and garbage, and in some of the wards the streets were being swept. In many of the up-town wards the laborers are using their own carts, and from present appearances it may be inferred that the combination against the contractors will soon be broken up.

Hon. Michael Hahn, La.; Hon. A. Boody, New-York; J.N. McCullough, Pittsburgh; Hon. J.W. Morkley, Philadelphia; Clark W. Thompson, St. Paul; Col. H.L. Robinson, Washington, and Hon. James H. Lucas, St. Louis, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.
The President to-day pardoned seventy-five persons; none of any prominence. Large numbers of applications for pardons continue to be received.

The Macon Telegraph says all the jewelry belonging to the citizens, which was sent off on the approach of the federals and was afterward captured near Athens, has been turned over and will be in Macon in a few days; and the gold captured from the Central Railroad Company last April, has been returned by the military authorities.

To Mrs. Major-Gen. Wm.T. Sherman: DEAR MADAM: We, the undersigned, Catholic clergymen, in response to your circular in behalf of the Northwestern Sanitary Fair, do ourselves the honor of remitting herewith five hundred and seven dollars ($507,) subscribed by ourselves and others at our solicitation' and a list of whose names we inclose.
Antonio Castro, a Spaniard, indicted for grand larceny on complaint of Francisco Blass, was acquitted.

A writer to the Chicago Republican offers a new explanation of that affair, received from Mr. CAMERON himself at an interview soon after it occurred. He says:
Confiscation has commenced in Richmond, and there is already a vast amount of feeling being manifested on the subject by the rich men of the city.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 56. In obedience to General Orders, No. 118, dated War Department, June 27, 1865, the undersigned assumes command of the Department of the East, embracing the New-England States. NewYork and New-Jersey; Headquarters at New-York City.

The Art Committee of the Union League Club of this city having written to Mr. BRIGHT requesting him to sit for his portrait, to be painted by an American artist, in England, for the club, the following note from Mr. BRIGHT was read at the last meeting of the club:

The day was gloriously fine and the knowledge that all three of the horses entered for the purse would positively start, with the probability of an exciting trot, induced a large attendance, among whom the fashionable lady residents at the Springs were in full force, giving light and brilliancy to the gay scene. The track was in the finest possible order, and all the arrangements of the most affluent description.

There has seldom, if ever, been so ruinous a defeat of any political organization, in the history of constitutional government, as the rout of the Unconditional Peace Party in 1864. The whole concern was overthrown horse, foot and artillery. Tve Chicago cabal was utterly demolished; and the disjecta membra of their retinue are to-day "lying round loose," no one having the courage or the inclination to gather them together.

The exercises of the week will begin on Sunday evening, with a discourse from Rev. ORVILLE DEWEY, D.D., to be preached at the request of the graduating class of the Divinity Schools. Tuesday forenoon the class will read its dissertations; the last performance of its members before entering upon the active duties of their profession. In the afternoon, we suppose, the Alumni of the school hold their meeting and listen to an address.

The First New-Hampshire Cavalry arrived yesterday afternoon by the New-Jersey Railroad, landing at foot of Cortlandt-street at about 2 o'clock. Marching quietly down to the Battery Barracks, the men took dinner, and at 4 o'clock the command took special steamer for New-London, as they could not be carried by the boats of the regular route. The First expect to reach Concord, N.H., this evening or tomorrow morning.

In the case of Henry Hastings, who was, on Monday, convicted of burglary committed at No. 21 Warren-street, May 11, the counsel for the prisoner moved for a new trial on the merits. The motion was denied, and the prisoner was sentenced to two years' imprisonment in the State Prison.

The following beautiful and pathetic ballad is from Mr. GEORGE MACDONALD'S recent book, Alec Forbes, of Howglen, a work characterized by the Spectator as a "Scotch pastoral, without any of the foolish idealism of ordinary pastorals, but full of the broad sunny nature and deep humanity of the imaginative Scotch literature:"
The Attorney-General of Virginia has written the following letter in reply to inquiries made of him by LITTLETON TAZEWELL, JOHN H. GILMER and others:

Gen. LOGAN has issued another important order. The whole of the gallant Army of the Tennessee is to be mustered out immediately. Let there be no more grumbling among the veteran soldiers. In a few days the camps which so thickly dot the earth in the vicinity of our city will disappear, and the brave boys in blue will be en route for their respective homes.

SYLVIA ANN HOWLAND who died a short time since in New-Bedford, Mass., left an estate valued at two and a half millions. One million is bequeathed to public and private charities. The Mercury says: "The sum of $20,0000 is given to the Orphan's Home, ....

BERRGER, the necessi ty for a new loan was admitted by the Chamber, uponthe government entering into an engagement to receive the instalments of the loan in four years, alalthough the loan for 250,000,000f, would be issued in its entirety.

A telegram from Florence says: It is asserted that the Minister for Foreign Affairs addressed a circular on the 30th ult. to the diplomatic agents of Italy abroad, in which he gave a history of the negotiations with Rome.

Between 11 and 12 o'clock Saturday forenoon a steam-boiler exploded in Messrs. NOLEN STEERS' steam saw-mill, on the northwest corner of Fiftyfourth-street and Second-avenue, and PATRICK COLLINS, the fireman, who was in the engine-room was buried in the ruins of the shed wherein the boiler stood. It is supposed that he was instantly killed.
In his farewell address to the people of Georgia, which we published yesterday, Gov. BROWN uses words which are both timely and wise when he says:

In the case of Henry Hastings, who was, on Monday, convicted of burglary committed at No. 21 Warren-street, May 11, the counsel for the prisoner moved for a new trial on the merits. The motion was denied, and the prisoner was sentenced to two years' imprisonment in the State Prison.

We were very sorry to learn that the Federal soldiers had committed depredations on the plantations on Red River. Gentlemen have informed us that the soldiers left the steamers and entered the premises of Messrs. TEMPLEMAN, HUTCHINSON and others, and robbed the smoke-house, and were rude to the ladies. These were no petty thefts, but wholesale robberies.

The Berlin Staats-Anzeiger publishes an account of the conversation which took place on June 1, 1864, between Herr VON BISMARK and the Duke of AuGUSTENBURG. By order of the King, this conversation was immediately afterward committed to writing by Herr BISMARK, who had on that occasion developed to the Duke of AUGUSTENBURG the demands of Prussia. On Monday, July 4, Lord RAVENSWORTH gave notice that in the first session of the ensuing Parliament he should bring in a bill to alter and amend the Roman Catholic oath, enacted by GEORGE IV, if the government would take up the question, he would willingly leave it in their hands.

Those who visited Morrisania, on Saturday, to witness the first match this season between these clubs, and the first appearance of the Excelsior nine of 1865 in a match, were not only gratified spectators of a very interesting contest, but also of the most attractive attendance of the fair sex seen at a match this season.
JAY COOKE Co. report the subscriptions to the Seven-Thirty Loan on Saturday at $10,331,700, including the following:

The Quebec News of Saturday says: "The hotels in this city are beginning to be crowded with American visitors. One party of fifty will arrive by the Europa this morning, and take up their quarters at the St. Louis Hotel. Most of these visitors will do the Saguenay before they return westward, taking passage on the steamer Magnet, or on the Arctic, which leaves to-morrow morning for Tadousac, returning on Monday forenoon.

During the opening period of the war, while the prices of all kinds of merchandise and an abundant supply of raw material was on hand, the manufacture of cotton was one of the most prosperous in this country. Until this stock was used up, the mill-owners found an ample demand for every pound of yarn or cloth they could produce, at war prices.

The Fourth Vermont Regiment left for Burlington Saturday morning. The First NewHampshire Cavalry and Seventh Rhode Island Regiment arrived Saturday afternoon, departing almost immediately for their several destinations. The One Hundred and Fifty-second New-York also arrived and left Saturday night. Yesterday afternoon the Seventeenth New-York, Second Rhode Island, Eleventh and Fifty-eighth Massachusetts and Seventeenth Vermont, arrived in this city from Washington. All of them, except the Seventeenth New-York, left for their respective States last night.

It is natural and right that New-Yorkers should be proud of their city; that they should boast of its wealth, of its size and its rapid increase, of its commercial enterprise and importance. These are legitimate objects of pride.

The members of the stock company and other persons, numbering about fifty, recently employed at Barnum's Museum, held a meeting on Saturday morning at No. 93 Canal-street. Among the gentlemen present were CHARLES FOX, JOHN BRIDGMAN, and Mr. HARRISON, the comic singer.

A recent number of the TIMES contains an able and interesting article (signed "H.," I think) on the application of the Monroe doctrine to Mexico. In that article the writer endeavors to make it appear that the Monroe doctrine does not apply to French occupation of Mexico, because: 1. That the Monroe doctrine is defensive.
JAY COOKE Co. report the subscriptions to the Seven-thirty loan to-day at $5,663,500, including the following:

Gen. CONNOR will start from here with the left column of the Powder River Indian Expedition within the next ten days. The right column, nearly 2,000 strong, is now well up the Louis Fork. The centre column will leave from the camp near this place and strike through the Black Hill country. Supply depots will be established on Powder River.
A heavy storm set in here yesterday afternoon, causinq the most extensive flood known in these parts since the year 1811.

Gen. McDOWELL, in accordance with instructions from the War Department, has issued an order requiring all men arriving in San Francisco, known to have been in the rebel army, to take the oath of allegiance.
The One Hundred and Fifty-ninth New-York Volunteers left Hilton Head for Syracuse.

A dispatch from Secretary SEWARD to Sir FREDERICK BRUCE, which had not been previously given to the public, was laid before the British Parliament on the 3d inst. That dispatch we publish to-day in another column. It cannot be said to present the relations of the two governments in any new or more unfavorable light to the public, on either side of the Atlantic.
The Inman steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at 4 o'clock on the afternoon of the 5th and Queenstown on the 6th of July, arrived here yesterday morning.

By the Alpha we have the statement of Capt. HART, of the bark Meteor. He searched a day and a half for the unfortunate passengers by the ship Wm. Nelson, the wreck of which was scattered for miles over the water.
Mr. BIGELOW, the American Minister at Paris, gave a fete on the Fourth of July, which was largely attended.
The British Parliament was prorogued to-day, and dissolution immediately followed.

GENERAL ORDERS NO. 55. Pursuant to General Orders No. 118, current series, War Department, Major-Gen. DIX hereby transfers to Major-Gen. JOSEPH HOOKER, of the army, the command of the Department of the East.

In the House of Lords on the 5th, the Lord Chancellor announced his resignation in an appropriate valedictory address. He stated that he had repeatedly expressed his desire to resign in consequence of the unjust charges which had been brought against him, but that Lord PAL, MERSTON and his colleagues had dissuaded him from doing so.
GENERAL ORDERS NO. 1. 1. In obedience to General Orders, No. 118, current series, from AdjutantGeneral's office, Maj.-Gen. MEADE assumes command of the Military Division of the Atlantic.

The city, during the whole of yesterday, was filled with returning troops, on their homeward way to be finally discharged and paid off. Broadway, from early morning until late in the evening, resounded with the crash and swell of martial music; and as the different regiments passed to and fro from the steamers to the Battery Barracks or the New York State Agency, they were received with marked attention, if not enthusiasm.

A single sentence in this morning's TIMES serves to awaken many memories of the past, and revive remembrances of men and parties long since crumbled or forgotten. Thus it reads: "Died, on Sunday morning, July 16, at her late residence, Washington Heights, madam ELIZA B. JUMEL, in the 92d year of her age."
Lieut. G. HAWK, Third Pennsylvania Artillery, has been appointed Superintendent of tde Freedmen's Affairs for this Military District.

The screw-steamer Nyack, 7 guns, which was built at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, in 1863, will sail in a few hours for the Pacific station, and service in those waters. Once out there, in all probability she will never return to the Atlantic sea-coast. She will touch, en route, at St. Thomas, Bahia, Rio Janeiro, Montevideo, and one or more ports on the west coast of South America.

The NEW-YORK TIMES is slaughtering the butchers and milkmen, whom it charges with keeping up the price of meat and milk. These people make all the money they can, but they can no more control the prices of the articles they deal in than they can reverse the movements of the tides, or make the trunk of a tree grow into the earth instead of out of it.

The New-Bedford (Mass.) Standard says: "Workmen are busily engaged in scraping the iron sides of the Georgia, preparatory to painting her; caulkers are at work upon her decks, and her cabins are being thoroughly cleaned. She will leave this port shortly for New-York, and will probably find her way back to her former Liverpool owners. She brought only $42,000, and it is said her engines are worth over $30,000."

It is well known that the cable of the NewYork, Newfoundland and London Telegraph Company across the Gulf St. Lawrence was by some means injured early in June last, since when messages from all Newfoundland have been sent from Cape Ray to Arfu Bay, or Sidney, by sailing vessels, and from thence by telegraph here.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 9 A.M. of the 8th and Queenstown on the afternoon of the 9th inst., arrived at Halifax at 5:30 P.M. to-day. She has 51 passengers for Halifax and 66 for Boston.

GENERAL ORDERS, N o. 30. 1. To prevent the recurrence of outrages on the persons of colored people by their former owners, and other evil-disposed persons, it is hereby ordered that the Superintendent of Freedmen of this district will bring all such cases coming to his knowledge before the Provost-Marshal in the form of a charge, and the Provost-Marshal will try the case in the manner prescribed for Field Officers' courts in the army.

The new steam fire engine ordered by the commissioners from the Amoskeag Works will probably arrive in the city to-day. It will be known as Metropolitan No 1. It is a very powerful engine, having the capacity to play four large streams of water at the same time. It will be drawn by two horses, and will be taken care of by experienced men.
Bishop POTTER, of Pennsylvania, died since his arrival here a few days ago. His body has been embalmed, and will be returned to the East.

The Commercial Chronicle takes up the subject of house-building, and the great want of houses in New-York for business people of small incomes, and mechanics and others with limited wages, upon which we have frequently written of late.

The Indian Bureau has received information from Gen. HERRON stating that recently a grand council was held in the Chickasaw Country, at which twenty tribes of Indians were represented. These Indians took part in the late rebellion, and now, like their Southern white neighbors, want a restoration of their forfeited rights and priviliges. They have agreed to call in representatives to another grand council, which will probably be held at Fort Smith early in August.

DODGE, were arrested in the town of Haverhill by Constable J. BURNHAM of that town, upon suspicion of having stolen government bonds from parties then unknown. Considerable excitement exists here in regard to an affray which occurred last night on the corner of Main and Water streets, resulting in the death of THOS. DE MOTT.
Brig.-Gen. MANN left Norfolk this morning for Suffolk, Va., to review the troops stationed at that post.

Much has been said by the Western press, of late, concerning the log cabin once occupied by ABRAHAM LINCOLN on the prairies of Illinois. The veritable fabric has at last reached our city, and is on exhibition on the parade-ground of the Common. It is some twenty feet square, and of the most primitive pattern, being constructed entirely of logs placed together in the same manner in which a child would construct a "cob house."

HOW WORKMEN ARE EMPLOYED AND WHAT THEY DO. An interesting state of facts was developed yesterday before United States Commissioner NEWTON in relation to operations in the Navy-yard. Some time since JOHN MAXON, JOHN R. MARSDEN, WM. McDERMOTT and FRANCIS RILEY were arrested on the charge of defrauding the government by carrying off several thousand dollars worth of manufactured material. They all occupy prominent positions in the mechanical departments of the yard.

Lord BROUGHAM recently said in Parliament that he wished to correct a misapprehension which some of his friends from the United States had told him might have an unfortunate result in lessening the influence, such as it might be, of that earnest remonstrance which he had addressed to the United States, imploring them to exercise moderation and mercy in the hour of their great victory.

On Thursday, July 6, about 7 o'clock, a steam boiler at the coal mine of Mr. WILLIAM REEVES, near Reed's Station, on the Belleville and East St. Louis, Mo., Railroad, exploded, causing the death of the engineer, named WILLIAM KENICKER, in the most horrible manner.

The return of Midsummer has brought a recurrence of its annual festal days to the ancient university established in this place. The two white days, as they may be called, of the college year, are class-day and commencement. The former occurs in the middle of June, and was celebrated about a month ago.

All of these commands, except the One Hundred and Sixty-ninth, are city regiments. We append histories of three of them.

THe graduating exercises of the male department of this school were held yesterday. The assembly room was beautifully decorated with the "Red, White and Blue," and crowded with the friends of the school. The City Superindendent presented the diplomas to the graduating class.

Yesterday was another exceedingly pleasant day, the sun shone brightly and a welcome breeze cooled the atmosphere. Every train swelled the volume of visitors, and the hotels begin to swarm with pleasure-seekers. Of course, in such fine weather, as may well be imagined, everybody was out doors as much as possible, and there was to be seen a constant stream of pedestrians in the different promenades, and a goodly display of teams on the "rides."

The position now taken by the public men of Kentucky and the altered tone of public sentiment in that State, give good assurance that the Constitutional Amendment will be adopted there when next it comes before the Legislature. The revolution in the South involves a prodigious change, and it will require, at the very least, a generation to complete it. We never expect to see the South entirely clear of the old theories of the subordination of the races, and of the doctrines of State sovereignty, until those who are now upon the stage give place to those born in the new era.

Interesting ceremonies took place at Harvard College to-day in commemoration of the patriotism of her sons. Harvard contributed 495 of her graduates to uphold the standard of the country, of whom 96 were either killed in battle or died from the effects of wounds or disease.

United States District-Attorney DICKINSON received information on Thursday last that the Portugese bark Dahomey, lying in the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn, was fitting out as a slaver. It was alleged that the vessel had sailed from Cuba with a cargo for NewYork; on her arrival part of her cargo was sold, but the balance, consisting of timber, rice, rum, and other articles used by slavers, was kept in the vessel.

WHERE ARE THE CORONERS? For the last three days the body of a drowned man has been lying in the water near the barge office. A few weeks ago a woman's body was left there for about the same time. Surely our four coroners should be able to attend to these cases promptly. A dead body soon becomes a mass of disease-creating matter at this season of the year.

COTTON Sales of week 4,500 bales, including 7,500 to speculators and 10,500 to importers. The market has been dull, with a decline of d. on American and Surats; other descriptions were irregular. Sales, to-day, (Friday,) 8,000 bales; market closing firmer at unchanged rates. The authorized quotations are: Middling Upland, 19d.; Middling Upland. Orleans, 19 d.; Middling Upland. Texas, 19d. The stock of Cotton in port amounts to 361,000 bales, including 29,500 bales of American.

SAD CASE OF DESTITUTION. A family consisting of a mother and four children, named OULD, residing corner of Graham-avenue and Powers-street, Eastern Division, were yesterday discovered by Officer COLGAN of the Forty-sixth Precinct, suffering the horrors of famine and disease. The father of the family, a German named JOSEPH OULD, was some time since in business for himself, but failed.

A dispatch from Mobile, dated the 22d instant, says that Bishop ANDREWS has issued a notice to the Episcopal Church, requesting the annual Conferences to hold sessions this Fall to elect delegates to a general Conference, commencing in April next. He also requests the churches to meet in Columbus, Ga., for consultation at an early day.

The great issue before the voters of Kentucky, to be decided at the election of Aug. 7, is the constitutional amendment. In view of this election, an energetic canvass of the State is now going forward. The Unionists are sanguine that a sufficient number of pro-amendment men will be elected to the coming Legislature to insure the success of an enactment that shall make Kentucky, by her own emphatic verdict, henceforth and forever free.

There were no returning regiments arriving during yesterday, but several are expected during the present and early part of next week. SINGULAR CASE OF ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. A man named EDWARD DEADAN was discovered in Washington Park about 3 o'clock yesterday morning lying on the grass and laboring under great pain. His groans had attracted the attention of some citizens in the neighborhood who went to his relief. They found him bleeding profusely and soon ascertained that he had been stabbed.
The jewelry-store of J.M. FREEMAN, on Mainstreet, Norfolk, was broken open last night and robbed of all its watches and valuable jewelry. Loss upward of $2,000.

On Wednesday afternoon, Officers VERMILYEA and HARRIS arrested PATRICK BURNS, alias "Piper Burns," and BARTHOLOMEW O' CONNER, on suspicion of having been concerned in the murder of JAMES SMITH, at the foot of East Fifty-fifth-street, on Tuesday night. The prisoners proved their innocence, and the Coroner discharged them.

M. Eloin who passed through this city nearly two months since as the special Embassador from Emperor Maximillian to France, returned here per steamer Scotia, and is stopping at the Brevoort House. It is expected that he will resume his journey to Mexico as soon as possible.

COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED. On Wednesday night an effort was made to pass a large number of counterfeit $10 bills on the Thompson Bank of Thompson, Conn. The police soon learned the fact, and gave storekeepers notice, and the villains were foiled in the attempt. The bills are welt executed and calculated to deceive good judges of money in the evening. SALOMON P. STODDARD, a lawyer, was arrested by Officer KELLY, of the Twentieth Precint; ...

Shortly before 12 o'clock on Wednesday night a fire was discovered in the large frame building No. 262 West Fifty-first-street, occupied by MYER MORANGE as a flock factory. The fire broke out in the drying-room, and owing to the inflammable materials with which the building was stored, the premises were soon enveloped in flames and reduced to ruins.

The beautiful steam-yacht Clara Clarita, from New-York for Aspy Bay, with Engineer EVERETT'S party on board, arrived here yesterday. The yacht has proved herself an excellent sea-boat, and no better could have been procured in the United States for the peculiar service in which she is now temporarily engaged. The company are under great obligations to Mr. JEROME for kindly placing her at their disposal for this important expedition.

Dispatches from Fort Laramie report that a thousand Indians recently attacked a small outpost of the telegraph company at Platte Bridge, but after two days the redskins were defeated with heavy loss. On the white side two men were killed and a number wounded.
GENERAL ORDERS No. 1: The Military Division of the Southwest, which was created for special purposes, is discontinued.

A highly interesting and very important case of slander was before a Pittsburgh court recently. A gentleman had charged a lady with calling him a "bastard," and she had, accordingly, been arrested. The lady averred that the charge was false, as she only said he was a "dastard." The two words are so similar in sound that the Judge decided that he could not tell which was used. The lady was therefore discharged.

PARKER SNOW, whose name is well known in connection with the expedition sent out from England by Lady FRANKLIN in search of her husband, the renowned navigator, Sir JOHN FRANKLIN, and his crew, and also by his published works regarding explorations in the Antartic Ocean, lectured, by invitation, before the Travelers' Club, at their rooms, corner West Fourteenth-street and Fifth-avenue, last evening. The great race between the Yale and Harvard College Boat Clubs, for the championship, came off to-day, and resulted in the victory of the former. The time was: Yale, 17 minutes 42 seconds; Harvard, 18 minutes 10 seconds. The distance rowed was three miles.

We hear from various points on the Mississippi River, as New-Orleans, Vicksburgh, Memphis and Cairo, of the great activity in steamboating and general commerce that now exists there. The busy times before the war are revived on the great river. Steamboats are plenty as ever, and equally fast, and somewhat less explosive.

With the disbandment of our gigantic military and naval force, on the one hand, and the immense increase in public revenues from internal taxation and import duties, on the other hand, it is now definitely seen that the day of great expenditures has passed away, and the day of great revenues has fairly begun.

We are favored to-day with a communication from a gentleman who is an advocate of high prices. He undertakes to show us that neither the milk speculators in the city, nor the dairymen in the country, are overpaid. Ten cents a quart he considers a reasonable price, and so forth. This outspoken advocate of extortion is fitly answered by two correspondents, whose letters we place side by side with his.
The following from LEE to MOSBY was captured last Spring by one of our officers, and shows that the horrible atrocities committed by guerrillas had the approval of the former:

AN ESCAPED CONVICT RETURNED TO BLACKWELL'S ISLAND. On Monday evening the Eighteenth Ward Police arrested PATRICK BURNS, alias "Piper" BURNS, on suspicion of having killed JAMES SMITH, at the foot of East Fifty-fifth-street, on Tuesday evening. Yesterday Coroner COLLINS discharged BURNS, the prisoner having proved his innocence of that charge. He was immediately re-arrested, however, the police having learned that he was an escaped convict.

In the case of the murder of JAMES TAYLOR, who was assaulted and mortally wounded while returning from the Fenian picnic in Jones' Wood on Tuesday evening, the Coroner's Jury yesterday rendered a verdict that he came to his death by wounds received at the hands of JOHN BURNS, FREDERICK HOOKER boing an accessory before the fact. BURNS has not yet been arrested.

Despite the tropical weather the mercury high up in the nineties all day long Saratoga has had a first-class sensation to-day, occasioned by the arrival of that military chieftain Lieut.-Gen. U.S. GRANT, Commander of the armies of the United States in the field. He reached the depot in a special train from Albany at about 7 o'clock this evening, accompanied by three officers of his personal staff and several citizens.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. About 4 o'clock yesterday morning, a man named RICHARD O'BRIEN, while under the influence of liquor jumped into the river at the Paterson Dock, Jersey City, with a view of drowning himself. A private watchman gave the alarm and O'BRIEN was rescued much exhausted. He was conveyed to the Station-house, and is still under the care of a physician.

One of the phenomena of great wars is the proof they afford of the immense latent force and capacity for exertion in the human character. Hedged round by social ties, governed by a host of conventionalisms, the human animal is usually of orderly and peace-loving proclivities content to pass from the schoolhouse and the play-ground to the countingroom, the store, the manufactory or the farm.

SUSPICIONS OF FOUL PLAY. On Wednesday morning last, about 4 o'clock, Capt. JAMES PEABODY, of Chelsea, a watchman in the Navy-yard, left the gate near the Chelsea bridge to go to his home. Since then nothing has been heard of him. Capt. PEABODY is an old and highly respected citizen of Chelsea, very regular and domestic in his habits and it is feared he has met with foul play.

Among these undiscriminating persons are not a few of the subdued rebels we cannot say repenting rebels, for, according to their story, they have done nothing to repent of.

The Capitol mentions a couple of large coffee kettles which have been presented to the Wisconsin State Historical Society by Company A, Sixteenth Wisconsin Volunteer Infantry. These kettles traveled "from Atlanta to the sea," and so around to Washington, making, on an average, forty gallons per day, and leaving many a black spot on the sacred soil of Georgia and the Carolinas.

The official report of the negotiations between home and the Italian Government has been published, and unlike official reports in general, it is a terse, straightforward document, and gives us some valuable information, and furnishes us with sufficient data on which to form a judgment. To begin with, it sets the question at rest as to whether the King or the Pope made the first overtures.

We are all suffering here with intense heat of the weather. But, notwithstanding it is July, business appears to be quite active. As yet there are no signs of yellow fever, and the impression prevails that we shall escape that scourge this season. The continual political strifes to which Mexico has been a prey for so many years, have greatly undermined the social intercourse of the people. Party spirit was carried even to the domestic circle, separating friends and relations, and, sometimes, parents and children.

One of the most important practical matters for America is good sanitary legislation, especially bearing on the evils of over-crowding and the removal of conditions, promoting disease in our large cities. England is evidently far in advance of us in this important particular, and I propose, in this letter, to give a brief summary of the most valuable points in the acts of Parliament and local acts, directed to sanitary reform.

Old SANTA ANNA is out again with a revolutionary manifesto to the Mexicans. Whenever his native land is in an extremity of misfortune, or whenever its fortunes begin to brighten, he springs to the front, sword in hand, and rushes, as the case may be, upon those whom he considers the authors of its ruin, or upon those who are attempting to rescue it from destruction. It seems to make comparatively little odds to him.

During the four years of war, the cultivation of the great Southern staples cotton and tobacco, as also rice and sugar was almost entirely stopped, and wheat and corn took their place. We hope to see the cultivation of the old staples renewed, in even more than its former magnitude, in the coming year.

Neither the city of Richmond north County of Henrico has ever represented the sentiment of Virginia in the business of elections. As they voted, so did not the State at large ever vote. Virginia always voted in direct opposition to the vote of Richmond and Henrico.

Every emigrant from the United States held carnival this year on our national birth-day. Where two or three met together they did no work and kept Sabbath. The solitary pilgrim in barbarous lands halted and camped in remembrance of freedom. The gay world of Americans at Paris congregated in the Pre Catilan, and the travelers among the Alps came down in the valley to Geneva and kept high festival for "Auld lang Syne."

To-day Lient.-Gen. GRANT has been the guest of the City of Boston. After breakfasting with his family at the Revere House, he was met by Mayor LINCOLN and Aldermen CLAPP and GARFIELD, and soon after 9 o'clock, carriages were taken for the Charlestown Navy-yard.

Yesterday was a gala day among our returned veterans. The day was devoted to the formal reception of the Forty-sixth, Fifty-first and One Hundred and Thirty-first New-York City Regiments, and the entire proceedings passed off remarkably well. The day was fine and the men in excellent spirits; and the veterans evinced the greatest interest in the ceremonies gotten up for their edification and honor.

Gen. GRANT and party arrived at 3:42 P.M. He was received by the City Government and a large escort of military and citizens, by whom he was conducted to the Preble House after passing through several of the principal streets. The concourse of citizens which lined the streets was immense, and the General was greeted with enthusiasm.

The Magenta has arrived with New-Orleans dates to the 25th, the Seventh Minnesota and a portion of the Sixth Minnesota Infantry, and the Second Massachusetts Battery. The major portion of the Sixth Minnesota previously arrived on another steamer.

It is rumored in ministerial circles in Madrid that the Spanish Representative in Chili will be dismissed on account to the late negotiations he conducted with Chili.

The inquest in the case of Mr. JOSEPH VAN DOREN, who was shot by JAMES F. ORAM, on Saturday last, and almost instantly killed, was concluded yesterday. The jury brought in a verdict in accordance with the facts of the case. The prisoner said, in reply to to the questions of the Coroner, that whatever he had done was done in self-defence. He was then committed to the Tombs.

The American Republic was not founded for the purpose of progagating republicanism throughout the world by the sword. Citizen GENET AND Gov. KOSSUTH both held that it was; but neither of the individuals was a citizen of America, and each of them had a purpose to subserve by the realization of the doctrines which, at different periods, they proclaimed.

Gov. PARSONS, in his address to the people of Alabama, a few days since, declared that one hundred and twenty-two thousand men of that State were engaged in the war, and that of this number seventy thousand are dead or disabled. This is an extraordinary statement; and, if it be true, it gives us a new conception of the desperateness with which the Confederate cause was defended.

Last month the committee on procuring volunteers, of which Mr. ORISON BLUNT is chairman, put forth an elaborate report of their operations, giving the cost per man of every volunteer procured, and also the grand total of expenses, amounting to $10,594,391.68.
The weekly returns of the Bank of France show a decrease in specie of 4,700,000 france.
An Imperial decree had been issued relieving Count PALEY of the Governorship of Hungary.
The rebellion had one of its great roots at the North in those elements of the great city populations whose law is lawlessness, whose order is disorder.

Gov. SMITH has appointed Dr. GEO. NICHOLSON, of Northfield, late Surgeon of the Thirteenth Vermont Regiment, Secretary of State, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the decease of Hon. GEORGE W. BAILEY, of Montpelier.

How different are the dog-days this year from last! This year they encounter us in the weak, piping times of peace of peace so well established already, that last year's story of doubt and anxiety, of blood and desolation, seems like an ugly vision that has passed.
The steamship Blackstone, Capt. COFFIN, from New-Orleans 19th, was towed into Hampton Roads last night.

St. Thomas' (Episcopal) Church, situated on the corner of Broadway and Houston-street, has been sold to a large clothing-house in Broadway for the sum of $175,000. The building is not to be removed until May, 1866, when the site will be occupied as a store.

The U.S. steamer Wando, Acting Master F. T. KING, commanding, from Port Royal, arrived yesterday evening. She reports no sickness at that port. The order of the Secretary of the Navy for retrenchment was being strictly carried out there, and rumor has it that all the vessels of the squadron are to go North, with the exception of the flagship Malvern, storeship New-Hampshire and two tugs.

Peter Jaurekhe et al. vs. The Brigantine S.G. Troop. This was an application by seamen to be made co-libelants. The libel was filed to enforce a bottomry bond; process was issued in the cause and the vessel arrested, and on the return of the process, no one appearing, the default of all persons interested.

Six hundred and twenty-six members elected to the House of Commons show 353 Liberals and 273 Conservatives. The Liberal gains will reach 24. The South Lancashire election resulted in the success of GLADSTONE; but his two colleagues are Conservatives.

The Fifty-seventh Massachusetts, Lieut.-Col. J.M. TUCKER, commanding, and the Twenty-ninth Massachusetts, Lieut.-Col. CHARLES D. BROWN, commanding, arrived here to-night from Washington, and were escorted to the Battery Barracks by Col. HOWE, Military State Agent, where they were well provided with a hot supper.

The R.M. steamship Asia, Capt. MOODIE, which left Liverpool at 9 A.M. of the 22d, and Queenstown the next day, arrived at Halifax at 5:30 this (Tuesday) afternoon. She has 24 Halifax and 97 Boston passengers.

It is anticipated that fully 10,000 people will be present, and therefore those desiring good seats should go early and take their camp-stools with them.

Spaulding: Having had occasion to examine with some attention the question of the duty of assessors, in valuing the shares of the national banks for the purposes of individual taxation under State or municipal authority, and knowing your interest in the question, I forward to you the result of my examination. In the Congressional election in this State today, CAMPBELL, Opposition, carried the city by 231 majority. It is now expected that he will carry the district by 2,000 majority.

Although the heat was most oppressive yesterday, the thermometrical indications were not so high as was generally supposed. About 2 P.M., while the sun was shining brightly and no clouds visible, a brisk shower fell, cooling the air considerably, and between 5 and 6 o'clock a heavy thunder storm burst over the city, the rain falling in torrents.

Detective TILLEY, of the Third Precinct, yesterday arrested a young Cuban, named MANUEL DE OLIVER, on a charge of robbing boarding-houses. ALBERT L. STARKWEATHER, the son of the murdered woman and brother of the murdered girl in Oakland, was brought to Hartford jail early last evening. The British packet arrived yesterday, bringing the great news that the rebellion had suddenly caved in, and that nearly all the rebel chiefs were prisoners. This has opened the eyes of many here to the fact that they had long overlooked, viz: that they are the unswerving friends of the United States Government and always admired President LINCOLN. They surrender, just as their friends in the South have done.

The frigate Congress was raised to-day. At 8:30 A.M. the pumps were set to work; at 10 o'clock the frigate commenced to rise, and at noon about six feet of her hull was above the water. She was deeply imbedded in the sand, and could not be removed from its banks until high water, which will be about 6 o'clock this evening.

Commencement at the University of Vermont comes late in the season of college festivals, but is never forgotten by the old friends and alumni of the institution. Those who have visited Burlington once, wish to come again, and those who have spent four happy years here, never lose their affection for the beautiful lake, the grand mountains, the enchanting views from College Hill, and all the charms of this queen city of the Green Mountains.

Mr.HENRY POWERS, of No.121 East Twentieth-street, made complaint against JOHN RYAN, of No. 250 Mott-street, and that person was apprehended by Policeman GILBERT, of the Fourth Ward. The affidavit against RYAN recites that recently he and the complainant drank to excess in a lager-bier saloon, and went thence to a pier on the East River, where POWERS fell asleep and was robbed by RYAN of $1,227.

In the steamship Bellona, Capt. DIXON, just arrived at this port, were two steerage passengers, concerning whom a thrilling incident is related. JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME COURT OF NEW-JERSEY. A dispatch from Somerville, received yesterday, brings us the painful intelligence of the death of Hon. GEO. H. BROWN, one of the Associate Justices of the Supreme Court. The dispatch announces that the funeral will take place to-day, but does not give the date of his death.

John McGuckean vs. Augusta Moore.--In the month of March last the plaintiff deosited $4,500 with the defendant for safe keeping. Some time afterward, when he demanded his money back, she refused to comply with the request, whereupon McGuckean obtained an order of arrest against her, and she was arrested by the Sheriff.

This fine regiment arrived in this city at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening, in the steamer Cossack, from Fortress Monroe. The regiment, was organized in October, 1861, and since that time has been actively engaged in the field. It has borne upon its rolls over 3,000 names. The casualties of 1864 were: officers, 7 killed and 13 wounded, and 4 missing in action; enlisted men, 69 killed, 203 wounded, and 126 missing in action.

On Friday, after an illness of only a few hours, departed this life Capt. PERCIVAL DRAYTON, U.S.N., an officer universally respected and esteemed. He entered the naval service as a midshipman on the 1st of December, 1827, and was ordered to the frigate Hudson. In 1831 he was sent to the Naval School at NewYork, and after a year of study he was ordered to join the Mediterranean squadron.

LAUNCH POSTPONED.--A new Sound steamer, called the Old Colony, was to have been launched at 8 o'clock Saturday morning, but owing to the heat having melted the grease on the ways she would not go off, and the launch was postpond until to-day.
The results of the municipal elections known up to July 24, are very favorable to the government. Nearly every where the whole municipality have been reelected.

The late civil war has left the State in an exhausted condition. Its capital has been necessarily impoverished and its resources crippled. The future depends much upon the efforts which are now made for recuperation. Every assistance, therefore, should be extended to these efforts, and every obstacle, if possible, removed.

Among the new occupations or pursuits that have recently sprung up here is that of the pardon broker, or advocate. Those who come here to obtain the Executive clemency, especially such as have some money to spend, are soon beset by the "runners" of pardon advocates.

The weather to-day has bordered upon that supposed to be perpetual in the infernal regions. Without any further circumlocution, it has been very hot all day. Hot! the word fails to convey a correct idea of the condition of the atmosphere. Shadrack Co. could not stand it without grumbling. Just before dark, however, the atmosphere was cooled by a smart shower.

The Prussians are certainly the most patient and enduring people in the world. One half the indignities which they have meekly borne would have driven any other nation into revolution. During the last three years Parliamentary government has been contemptuously kicked aside by the king and his obsequious minister, who have ruled the country in exact opposition to the views of Parliament.

Yeserday morning the first great step in this important undertaking was accomplished by hauling on land the massive shore and up the cliffs at the southwestern extremity of this island, and there successfully laying it from the Caroline out into deep water to a distance of 25 miles at sea. By nearly a fortnight the time has been overpassed when this should have been completed.

ALBERT A. CHESBROUGH, of No. 304 West Seventeenth-street, appeared, and with his wife, accused HENRY DEPEW, alias George Smith, of having stolen a portion of the woman's clothing. The facts of the case proved to be substantially as follows: Some years ago, the woman in question had been made the legal wedded wife of the prisoner, who after marriage, upon conviction of crime, was sentenced to two years' imprisonment.

Private THOMAS HALLAHAN, of No. 37 Washingtonstreet, was robbed of $300 while serving as a private in the First Delaware Infantry, when that regiment was on march near Fredericksburgh, and JOHN DEYGER, having been accused of the theft, fled and was nowhere again seen by HALLAHAN until yesterday, when he was captured in Howard-street. He was taken to Jefferson Market, and there held by Justice LEDWITH to be handed over to Maj. Gen. HOOKER.

You see, according to Gen. PALMER'S estimate, that over 165,000 Kentucky slaves have been directly and indirectly, for self-defence, freed by government enactment. Of the 65,000 remaining, I reckon, at least 15,000 to 20,000 have escaped from the State. perhaps most via Louisville. Not 50,000 stay-at-home and at all serviceable slaves are left, and they, says the Auditor, are not worth $50 a piece.

The shore end of the cable was landed this morning successfully, the weather being beautiful.

A dispatch from Queenstown per steamship City of Boston, dated July 27, states that the steamship Great Eastern was, on that morning, three hundred miles out at sea, paying out the cable successfully. The signals were good, and the weather fine.

We are again called upon to record another tragedy on the East Side. As ever, gin was the author of the crime, but not as usual, the murderer and the murdered are brothers, and the homicide was committed in their own bedchamber, in presence of a third person, and under their mother's roof.

The Ninth Connecticut Battalion, 385 men and officers, under command of Lieut.-Col. J.S. HEALEY, arrived yesterday at noon from Savannah, in the ocean steamer J.R. Spaulding. The command landed at Pier No.36 North River, and marched down Broadway to the Battery for dinner and rest. The Ninth Connecticut was specially noticeable for the great number of pets brought home by the men.

An evening paper contains an article on "the national debt," taking ground that when we provide for the interest (about $140,000,000 per annum,) and add ten millions to the yearly tax for liquidation, the sum will be sufficient to extinguish the debt. It adds to this sensible view the following:

DEAR SIR: Since leaving New-York several weeks ago, I have been informed that some persons there have not returned stock dividends as part of their incomes for the last year, which information is confirmed by noticing in the published list of incomes that several are much less than I supposed, from what I knew of their affairs, and in some of these cases I know the parties had very large dividends in stock.

The first race of the day was for the Travers Stakes, for which seven horses were entered. It was won by Mr. MOORE'S Maiden, Oleata coming in second, Sarah K. third, Richmond fourth, Gilda fifth, Baltimore sixth, and Vandal Colt seventh. The race was a severe one and well contested, Maiden winning by three parts of a lengths. Time, three minutes eighteen and a half seconds.

A brief telegram, which may have escaped the notice of many readers, was published the other day, to the effect that one of the oil-wells on Pithole Creek, Venango County, had taken fire and burned several persons three quite severely. The well, it was added, continued to burn, in spite of all attempts to extinguish the flames.

At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning the centre building of the three which comprise the St. Charles Hotel, at No.648 Broadway, fell, and is now a mass of ruins. Mr. KNIGHT, landlord of the hotel when it was known as the Sewell House, was buried under the mass; but policemen and members of the Fire Insurance Patrol took him out, happily, alive, but with a fractured shoulder-blade and serious internal injuries.
As our readers will remember, the brigade of Gen. LOPEZ left our city last Saturday, at 10 o'clock A.M., having on guard a convoy destined for Monterey.
Maj.-Gen. HOOKER is out of town and his command devolves upon Maj.-Gen. J.J. PECK of this department.

Great as were the anticipations indulged in concerning this meeting, they were fully realized at the inauguration to-day. By the middle of the week all the hotels were filled to overflowing, and even outside rooms to sleep in were at a premium. The rush on Saturday night was terrific, and it was repeated on Monday morning when the early trains came in from New-York, Albany and the East.

The Brokers' Circular reports the sales of Cotton in the Liverpool market, for the week ending with Thursday, at 49,000 bales, of which 7,500 were taken on speculation, and 10,000 for export. The market had been dull, and prices were d. lower for American, and d.@ d. lower for other descriptions.

MURDEROUS ASSAULT ON A WOMAN WITH A HATCHET. Between 5 and 6 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a returned soldier named PETER WINN, residing in a tenement building known as the barracks, in Canal-street, Jersey City, became involved in a quarrel with his wife, and while laboring under great excitement seized a claw-headed hatchet and dealt the woman a murderous blow on the top of her head, cutting a fearful gash and laying the skull bare.

The Old Colony is one of the finest of our Sound steamers, and in all her appointments will probably have no equal in this country.

The vote in this city for Congress is as follows: Rousseau, Administration, 4,502; Mallory, 1,789; Mundy, 121. The election of Rousseau, from the Fifth District, is conceded.

Kings County is in tribulation. Brooklyn has come to grief. Williamsburgh sits in sackcloth and ashes. Mr. CHARLES W. CHESHIRE, one of the Supervisors of the county a man of unstained repute, of unblemished character, of political power and social distinction has been tried by a court-martial, convicted of malfeasance in office, sentenced to six months' imprisonment in the Albany Penitentiary, and mulcted in the sum of $2,000.

DOMESTIC SERIOUSLY BURNED. A domestic in the employ of Mr. MARSH, of No. 159 West Fortyfourth-street, whose Christian name only is reported as ANN, attempted to add fuel to a fire by pouring alcohol thereon. The vessel whence she poured the inflammable liquid burst, and, covered with burning alcohol, ANN flew to the rear yard, where Mr. MARSH speedily enveloped her in a carpet. Her attending physicians do not regard her injuries as necessarily mortal.

It would be wrong to deny that the idea of raising all or the quarter part of the Government revenue by an impost on all commodities sold, in market, store, or on private premises, has taken hold of some of our best minds; and that it has attractions which insure it support in influential quarters, if not general acceptance. It has the charms of great simplicity and impartiality at first sight.

The following letter from Gen. BENNETT, commanding this post, was addressed to JOHN E. CAREW, Esq., in reply to an application made to the military authorities for the surrender of the jail. Mr. CAREW is Sheriff of this district, and proposed to resume his official functions under the recent proclamation of Gov. PERRY.

In 1854, when account was taken of the weights of mail matter passing through the New-York Postoffice, it was found to be eighteen tons daily, nine tons coming into the office and nine going out. Now thirty-five tons are received daily, and an equal amount is sent away, making seventy tons handled every twenty-four hours.

There is, perhaps, nothing of which the Southern States to-day are in greater want than an adequate supply of agricultural implements. Their past system of labor has been such as to forbid the introduction of those improvements which have become of universal use in the Northern States. Where labor is performed by slaves, labor-saving machines find but a sorry market.

FELLOW-CITIZENS: To be permitted once more to stand upon Texas soil and thus address you fills me with emotion. I well remember when, and under what circumstances, I last addressed a public audience in this city. It was in November, 1860, when organized rebellion was first beginning.
Senators FOSTER, DOOLITTLE and ROSS, Committee to investigate Indian affairs, through NewMexico and Colorado, have returned from the Plains.

Agreeable to a call issued to that effect, a meeting of the contributors to the Hancock Recruiting Fund was held yesterday afternoon, at the office of Col. GEO. BLISS, Jr., No. 45 William-street. The purpose of the meeting was to determine upon the final disposition of the balance still in the hands of the Treasurer of the fund. A very slim attendance was present.

The Times' City of Mexico correspondent of the 11th ult. says, that the French organs state that they will require 100,000 more men to destroy the bands of Jaurists. The rising of the people daily takes larger dimensions. Reports of French successes are unfounded.

WILLIAM JONES, who is better known as Jack Sheppard, having recently escaped, with a confederate, from Sing Sing Prison, was recaptured in this city, yesterday, by Detective Officers FARLEY and TIEMANN.

Last week a destructive flood swept over Franklin, Johnson County, Md., doing an immense amount of damage. Many people living in the lowlands awoke to find their domicils entirely surrounded by water, and their fields of corn and wheat flooded and ruined by the sweeping deluge. The amount of damage to crops alone in Johnson County, may be reckoned by hundreds of thousands of dollars. The town of Franklin was a seagirt body of land.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 6 Frequent complaints are made to the military authorities at this post of outrages upon private and public rights, committed by the numerous gangs of cotton thieves who infest the country.

Cotton is quiet. Sales 2,000 bales, at 42c.@ 44c. Sugar active; fair to fully fair 14c.@14 c. Freights declining: 1c.@1 c.

At the convention of colored people of Tennessee, held for this State, to-day, Mr. NELSON WALKER was elected chairman. He stated the objects of the meeting to be to petition the Legislature, and send a delegation to Washington asking the privilege of the elective franchise, and to lay their grievances before the people of the State.
The number of oaths of amnesty taken at the Provost-Marshal's office in Houston numbered 4,000 up to 3 P.M. on the 24th.

The grand stand was densely crowded, a large proportion of the occupants being superbly dressed ladies, who appeared to enter thoroughly into the enjoyment of the sport, and the brilliant scene presented.
THE PRESIDENT'S HEALTH. The President is in good health, and this afternoon spent some time in riding out.

The recognition by the new Ministry of the right of the Cortes to interfere in colonial affairs, which was disputed by the late Minister, has given great satisfaction here, which is augmented by the declaration of the new Colonial Secretary that he intends boldly to look all questions in the face, without being frightened at the word "innovation," although not wishing to place in peril public or private interests.

The regular quarterly meeting of the Shipowners' Association of the City of New-York, was held yesterday afternoon, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, Mr. J.H. FROTHINGHAM, President of the association, in the chair.
The regular afternoon session took place yesterday, at Firemen's Hall. Present, Commissioners ENGS, BOOTH and BROWN.

We know of nothing in connection with the new condition of the South so significant as the desire of the freedmen to learn to read and write, and the quickness with which they obtain this power. There can be no mistake about this, for it is the universal testimony of all the teachers sent out by the Freedmen's Association, and is abundantly confirmed by the reports of our military officers. It is a tremendous fact.

The Funds, on the 28th, were steady. Consols slightly improved, closing at 90 1/8.

Messrs. DERBY MILLER, of No. 5 Sprucestreet, have just published "The Life, Public Services and State Papers of ABRAHAM LINCOLN," by H.J. RAYMOND. It is an octavo volume of over 800 pages, and contains all of Mr. LINCOLN'S State papers, with his speeches, addresses, messages, letters, and proclamations. The text, from the pen of Mr. RAYMOND, connects them in their proper order, and succinctly details the circumstances under which they were issued or made.

A brief Queenstown telegram received by the Cuba relieves the pressure of public expectation in regard to the fate of the cable, and brings with it a disappointment which will be universally and deeply felt.

The safe in the office of HOWARD Co.'s Express, in this village, was entered on the night of the 25th of July, and thirty United States 7-30 notes of $50 each, numbered from 163,737 to 163,766, and ninety United States 7-30 notes of last issue, of $100 each, numbered from 259,828 to 259,917, were stolen therefrom which have not yet been recovered.
Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, per steamer City of New-York, close on Saturday at 1:30 P.M.; for the German States, via Hamburg, per steamer New-York, at 10:30 A.M. of same day.

An extensive fire occurred at Galveston on the 2d inst., involving heavy loss. It was doubtless the design of the parties to burn the town. The transactions of villains in Galveston were never before equaled.
His Excellency Gov. Fenton dined at the Astor House, yesterday, and proceeded to Albany in the evening train.

Speaking of the trial of CHAMP FERGUSON, the Nashville Times Press says: "Would it not be better to hang, or burn, or fry to death in petroleum, that horrid monster CHAMP FERGUSON, and take the remainder of the evidence afterward? Enough testimony has already been taken to hang a regiment of villains. CHAMP is a concentrated example of the wickedness of the rebellion. He is a monster redeemed by no semblance of virtue."
The royal mail steamship Cuba which left Liverpool at noon on the 29th, and Queenstown on the evening of the 30th July, arrived here yesterday morning.

There were very heavy rains throughout Wisconsin and Minnesota last night and to-day. In many sections the grain crop is badly damaged.

The highly important order directed to Gen. SHERIDAN by the War Department, to "cause to be mustered out of service all volunteer white troops cavalry, infantry and artillery serving in the Department of Texas, that can be dispensed with," is doubtless by this time in the way of actual execution. The order was issued by the Secretary of War on the 1st instant, and reached Gen. SHERIDAN at New-Orleans, by telegraph, on the same day.

BENEFIT OF MISS KATE REIGNOLDS. At the Broadway Theatre Miss KATE REIGNOLDS takes her farewell benefit this evening. Her engagement here has been an entire success, nothing resulting therefrom save continued pleasure, profit and popularity. Holding her in no way responsible for the outrageous interpolations of senseless gags, we urge her claims for a full house, and trust she will go hence with pleasant memories.

Russell Sturges vs. The Steamship Florida. This was a libel for salvage. The libel alleged that on Dec. 14, 1858, the steaming Achilles, owned by the libelant, rendered salvage services to the Florida which had, in a dense fog, run upon a point of land in the harbor of New-York and was in a perilous position, there exposed to the violence of the winds and the waves.

A MOROCCO FACTORY AND GLASS-HOUSE DESTROYED LOSS ABOUT $150,000 ONE FIREMAN INJURED. About 12:30 o'clock yesterday, a fire broke out in the morocco factory of THOMAS SHEVILL, situated at the corner of Kent-avenue and Taylor-street, Williamsburgh. The fire spread with great rapidity, and, notwithstanding that the firemen from both districts were promptly on hand, it was found impossible to stay the progress of the flames, and the factory, with its contents, was entirely destroyed.
The Union State Convention met here to-day at 10 o'clock. The attendance was large, with a full representation from the whole State.

On Wednesday last the late Sir E.P. TACHE, Premier of Canada, was buried at his residence, St. Thomas, with all the honors due to a man of his position, both military, political and social. As a soldier, he was brave; as a politician, he was, what I am sorry to say is a rare thing among us now, honest; and as a private member of society, he was a gentleman.

By the arrival here yesterday of the steamship Saladin, from Rio Janeiro, we have news from the River Plate to June 29, which gives an account of a severe naval engagement between the Brazilian fleet and eight Paraguayan steamers and eight floating batteries. The greatest bravery was displayed on both sides, and the slaughter fearful. The victory is claimed by the Brazilians.
William Schaffer, indicted for grand larceny, was tried on the charge of stealing two dogs from a mulatto dog doctor named H. Gardner, residing at No. 22 Thompson-street.

The interest in the Saratoga racing meeting continues on the increase, and bids fair to culminate in a perfect blaze of triumph. More general and well-merited enthusiasm has prevailed hitherto at this meeting than at any that has previously taken place on this continent. It is little to be wondered at, for the sport has been affluently ample in quantity and admirable in quality.

A great calm has succeeded the storm of war. There is no stir, either North or South. Even the election canvasses, in the few States where they are going on, are conducted languidly. Politicians are at a loss to get up any issues which can produce excitement, or even interest. Nothing serious is urged against the administration. All are placid, if not complacent; acquiescent, if not satisfied. The public mind everywhere seeks quiet.

The case recently decided in the English Court of Chancery, involving the question of the right of the United States to property in England, claimed to have belonged to the rebel government, is a very interesting one, not only in itself, but because it may be the pioneer of many cases, varying in circumstances, but coming under the same principle.

The Institute met this morning at 9 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by the venerable Ex-Pres- ident of Yale College, Rev. JEREMIAH DAY, LL.D., who is now ninety-five years of age, and still interested in attending the meetings of this Institute.

The races to-day were not witnessed by so large a concourse of people as on the previous days of the week. There are as many people in town as two days ago, but late hours and a satiated curiosity has depleted the track visitors, who substitute Congress water, a late breakfast and a short nap before dinner.

There was a large sale of government vessels this morning at the navy-yard. A number of steamers, tugs and sailing-vessels, for which government has no further use, were sold at auction by order of government.

The Stonewall still remains in port. We are expecting soon to see a United States vessel come after her. The Oneida, that happened in last Saturday, we thought came with that purpose; and on Sunday afternoon, when the United States steamship Fort Morgan came into port, with an Admiral's pennant flying at the main, we thought surely that the rain would leave during the week.

The tax on tobacco, snuff or cigars accrues when they are sold, consumed or removed for consumption or sale, or removed from the place of manufacture. A removal from the factory to the store or warehouse of the manufacturer is not such a removal as renders the goods liable to be assessed for the tax thereon, since the ordinary storerooms connected with the manufactory are included as a part of the place of manufacture.
The steamer Costa Rica reached Aspinwall on the afternoon of the 26th, and the Sacramento, with her passengers and mails, sailed hence for San Francisco on the evening of the 27th.

The act of June 30, 1864, as amended by the act of March 3, 1865, imposes a tax on all photographs or other sun pictures, either ad valorem, under the 94th section, or a stamp duty under scedule C, section 170.

Rev. Dr. THOS. J. CONANT, who has translated the Bible from the original for the Baptist Union, has just finished the final revision of the New Testament. The book will shortly be published in elegant style, quarto form. The compilation of so grand an enterprise is an era in the history of books not only, but in the "book of books."
Arrived last night, the United States Mail steamship Fung Skuey; J.B. HILDRETH, Commander, from New-Orleans Aug. 5, with United States mail, merchandise and passengers, to H.B. CROMWELL Co.

JOHN H. EARL, formerly a clerk in the Phenix Bank, but recently employed by SMITH, MARTIN Co., of Broad-street, brokers, having been arrested for complicity with HENRY B. JENKINS in the Phenix Bank defalcation, committed suicide yesterday morning in the Twenty-ninth-street Police-station. He was a widower, aged about 30, and dwelt in New-Jersey.
A collision occurred between the steamboats Pewabic and Meteor, at 6 o'clock on Wednesday reopening six miles from shore.

Michael Finerty, one of the Bowery short boys, was charged with committing a very grave assault on John Hall, hitting him from behind with a stone. At seven o'clock on Sunday evening witness said he was standing talking to a lady in the Bowery, when the prisoner, with two others, came up and struck him on the back of the neck with a rock. It was about two o'clock. Witness never saw the man before.
The professional duties of Mr. C.A. SEWARD requiring his personal attention, he has relinquished his position of Acting Assistant Secretary of State, and returned to New-York.

REMOVALS AND REAPPOINTMENTS IN THE CROTON AQUEDUCT DEPARTARTMENT. The Croton Aqueduct Board have appointed WM.S. KING Register, vice THOS. B. TAPPEN removed. Ex-Alderman WALSH has been appointed Clerk to the President of the board, vice JOHN McCAULEY removed. Mr. TAPPEN formerly held the office of Assistant Commissioner of the Croton Board, but was removed in 1862 to make way for the present incumbent, and was subsequently appointed Register.

Our dates from the national capital are to the 29th ultimo. All remains quiet in the interior of the country; poverty reigns supreme; prosperity don't seem to make its abode in that direction; public revenues are in the worst of conditions; crops of grain and potatoes are failing in the States of Cundinamarca, Bogota and Tolima; trade is dull, and the election for President keeps every one in an excited, unquiet state.

South Bend, Ind., was visited on Wednesday night with a fierce and devastating tornado. Its track was about two hundred yards wide. It commenced a mile east of Notre Dame College, and swept through the centre of the town, and to a distance of ten miles. Roofs and chimnies of many substantial structures were struck off, and many frame building ruined.
