At about 3 o'clock yesterday morning an incendiary fire consumed Mr. JAMES HINES' stable, at No. 47 Lewis-street, and the flames, spreading thence, entered the seven stables adjoining, belonging to Messrs. ROBERT MURRAY, JOHN MUNDIGAN, JOHN HINES, J. FARRELL, R. PATTERSON, D.PATTERSON and T. BLACK, and these also were destroyed. Messrs. D. PATTERSON, FARRELL and HINES each lost a horse. Next in importance to the great business of restoring the Southern States to their normal relations, is the duty of remodeling the revenue system, which alone gives security to our national debt. The steamer W. Whilden arrived from Richmond to-day, bound to Baltimore, with the Thirteenth Ohio Regiment in command of Col. S.R. CLARK. They are to be mustered out of service.

Austria proposed arrangements for the settlement of the question of the Duchies. She will consent to the acquisition of Kiel, the acquisition of Rendsburg, and further territorial acquisition by Prussia, provided she receives a corresponding acquisition of territory on the Silesian frontier. Austria also approves conditionally of the Grand Duke of Oldenburg as the future Duke of Schleswig Holstein.

I was much surprised on reaching Nashville the other day, to find the city and surroundings panting, not from the effect of severe heat merely, but of actual drouth. Kentucky, and the region north of the Ohio, had been visited with frequent and gushing rains, during all the season, amounting in some instances to floods, but here no rain had fallen since the 19th of July.

Saratoga has taken a slight emetic, and yet is full. The racing week closed last night, and a large proportion of the people who came to assist on the turf have taken their departure. A few with more money than they brought here a large majority with less. I asked a genial landlord who he thought had made the most money on the races. His answer was prompt and sensible: "The hotel proprietors."

To-day, at noon, BURDETT, JONES Co., auctioneers, will sell, at the Navy-yard in Brooklyn, a number of vessels which have been in the naval service, and for which the Navy Department have no further use. The Dictator arrived at 4:55. The race from Portsmouth was a well-contested fifty mile run. The Agamenticus made the distance in five hours and ten minutes, at a rate of nearly ten knots an hour. The Dictator was a mile and a half behind her when they arrived at Portland, and should have an allowance of seventeen minutes for the stoppage of her machinery on account of the heating of the crank pin.

MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG GIRL? SHE RETURNS HOME AND ENDS HER LIFE BY TAKING POISON.?On Wednesday morning last, ELLEN OWENS, 16 years of age, an intelligent, prepossessing girl, who resided with her sister, Mrs. F. COLLEY, in Willow-street, Hoboken, disappeared from her home, and although inquiries were made in every direction, no tidings of her whereabouts could be obtained until about 8 o'clock on Sunday evening. Mr. COOLEY,

is up for New-Orleans in Messrs. H.B. CROMWELL Co.'s line, and will sail on Wednesday, Aug. 16. Her general dimensions are 251 feet on deck, 34 feet 8 inches breadth of beam, 16 feet 4 inches depth of hold; draws 15 feet of water when loaded, and is 1,480 tons burthen, old measurement.
The Jenny Lind, with a cargo of rum, molasses and tropical fruits, arrived from the West Indies to-day. This is the first commercial arrival here from that quarter since the war.

The President has appointed Hon. PRESTON KING, of Ogdensburgh, Collector of this Port. This announcement, yesterday, took the city by surprise, both as regards the removal of Mr. DRAPER, and the appointment of Mr. KING, very little having been heard on the subject.

The old frigate Congress was raised at an early hour this morning, and started for Norfolk. While off Sewall's Point she got aground, and additional steam power was applied, but she got off with the flood tide, proceeded up the Elizabeth River, and at 11 o'clock this morning she was at Baker's Landing, Norfolk.
The steamer Pauline Corsall, from New-Orleans on the 9th, has arrived, with 125 bales of cotton for Cairo and 111 bales for St. Louis.

Receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last, 15 bbls. Ashes, 3,677 bbls. Flour, 150 bbls. and 400 bags Corn Meal, 58,674 bushels Wheat, 69,046 bushels Corn, 400 bushels Barley, 24,555 bushels Oats, 2,720 bushels Malt, 1,573 pkgs. Provisions, and 100 bbls. Whisky.

The government agent sent out to give Christian burial to the thousands of our soldiers murdered at Andersonville, writes to Washington in favor of preserving the prisonpen as a monument of the wickedness of the rebellion. This recommendation raises a serious question. There can be no good reasons for saving this memorial of the fiendishness of the Richmond Government that will not apply with equal force to many others.

Mr. JOHN N. WYKOFF, of No. 131 Pearl-street, is now busily engaged in testing a newly invented pro cess for saving gold and silver while extracting the precious metal from the ore. From a cursory examination of the process we are satisfied that it is destined to prove the great desideratum so long sought for by mining companies.
The trial of Capt. WERTZ was to have commenced to-day, but has been further postponed until to-morrow.

Maj.-Gen. ALFRED HOWE TERRY, commanding the Department of Virginia, has received his promotion from the War Department as a Major-General in the regular army of the United States by brevet. This promotion, while most flattering to the recipient, is universally acknowledged to be highly deserved.

ARREST OF A.W. NATHANS, THE BOUNTY-BROKER, BY ONE OF HIS VICTIMS. A.W. NATHANS, the bounty-broker, who figured so conspicuously in the Second District Provost Marshal's office, and on whose testimony Supervisor CHESHIRE was convicted of accepting presents and sentenced to the Penitentiary, ...

Delegates to the National Teachers' Association are arriving here by every train. It is expected that by to-morrow the largest representation of educators that ever assembled on any occasion in this country will be present to participate in the proceedings of the convention.

We have hoped almost against hope that some good fortune would ultimately bring through the great Atlantic cable. That hope is gone. We have news direct from the fleet as late as the 6th instant, by an arrival at Heart's Content, (name of mockery!) whereby we learn that the cable broke on the 2d, the day the signals to Valentia failed.

The Military Commission, with Gen. UNDERWOOD as President and Col. CHAPMAN as Judge-Advocate, convened in Washington for the trial of WERTZ, the Andersonville jailor, has entered upon its task. The simple charge of "violation of the laws of war" is accompanied by a horrid army of specifications, a catalogue of atrocities which humanity shudders to lay to the account of any one man.
The Board met at 2 o'clock, P.M., yesterday Mr. TWEED in the chair. A resolution was offered appropriating $70,000 for the defrayment of expenses incurred in taking the Census.
Of the present condition of Fayetteville, and how the people of that town brought it on themselves, the Wilmington Herald of the 8th says:

Robert Booth, aged 28, was charged with assaulting an unknown woman, with intent to pick her pocket. George Witten, the witness, said that last Wednesday he saw the prisoner insert his hand into two women's pockets, but he got nothing. Amos Stokey said he followed the prisoner through the market for about twents minutes, and during that time he saw him put his hand in five or six pockets. Guilty, Penitentiary six months.

Hon. Gideon Welles, Secretary of the Navy: SIR: The action of the Bureau of Steam Engineering in regard to my contract for the engine of the Algonquin, makes it necessary for me to ask for your decision, in order that a case may be made on record for appeal, if need be, or for such other action as the ends of justice may require.

SEIZURE OF THE TOWN. Everybody has wondered why the police authorities so long tolerated the sale throughout the city of a libidinous hebdomadal known as The Town. It appears, first, that the police required time to ascertain precisely where the sheat was printed, and, secondly, no citizen took it upon himself to prefer a complaint upon which they could proceed, without fear of being tripped by shrewd and well-paid counsel.

The average price of government animals sold in Richmond up to this time having been found to be considerably less than that obtained for animals of similar quality in the Northern cities, the Quartermaster-General has ordered the discontinuance of sales here. This order was received here on last Thursday by Col. WILLIAM L. JAMES, Chief Quartermaster of the Department of Virginia, who immediately stopped the sales then about to take place.

The Democratic State Convention met at 10:30 this morning. PAUL S. MERRILL, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, called the convention to order, nominating Hon. E.F. PILLSBURY, of Farmington, temporary chairman.

Major DICK McCANN, formerly of the rebel army, who made himself conspicuous as a cavalry leader in this State, was arrested yesterday on a charge of having been a member of the court-martial which hung several Union citizens at Knoxville during the war. He will be taken to Knoxville to stand trial.

J.L. PENNINGTON, editor of the Raleigh Progress, who is standing up manfully for the Union, and who knows more of the secret designs of the rebel leaders than any other man in North Carolina, and who has been making important disclosures of their evil intentions, is a candidate for a seat in the coming State Convention.

A terrible and fatal accident took place, about 11 o'clock this morning, on the Housatonic Railroad, three miles and a half from the depot in this city, by which a number of lives were lost, and a large number of persons injured some fatally, others slightly. Early this morning an extra train going up started on its trip about 8 o'clock.

A frightful railroad disaster occurred this morning on the Housatonic River Railroad. The morning freight train going up the Housatonic Railroad became disabled several miles above Bridgeport, and the 10:30 train following found it on the track, and hitched on and backed toward Bridgeport with it.

We are gratified to learn that the dangerous thoroughfare, corner of Fulton and Broadway, has received due attention at the hands of tho Police Commissioners. Two more patrolmen have been stationed there, and the public may now have some chance of a safe crossing during the heat of the day. The additional force ought to be still further augmented, to insure perfect safety to pedestrians.

We have already referred to the action of the Navy Department in regard to the war steamer Algonquin, built for the service by P. S. FORBES, Esq., under a special contract to make her engine equal in power and economy to that of the other vessels of a similar character built by the department.

The recent disasters at sea, caused by the burning of the ship Wm. Nelson and the steamer Glasgow, have again directed public attention to the condition of the appliances on board passenger vessels for extinguishing fires, and otherwise guarding against the fearful sacrifice of human life, so liable on these not unfrequent occasions.

Some weeks since we alluded to a very distressing case that had occurred at the Tombs. A poor woman, leaving her fire children at home one of the little ones being a nursing babe went to a neighboring grocery to make some purchases. The proprietor of the store suspected her of a design to steal his cabbages, and caused her arrest on suspicion.
The propeller Triton sailed for Hilton Head yesterday, and soon after passing outside of Cape Henry, her machinery became disabled, and she was towed back, arriving here this morning.

RAYMOND'S forthcoming History of Mr. LINCOLN'S Administration of the abortive attempt to institute negotiations for Peace, made in July, 1864, through correspondence at Niagara Falls, omitting only the already printed letters there interchanged and the manifesto thereupon put forth by the Confederates concerned. Most of the documents herewith given are new to the public. And now for the requisite explanatory comments.
The government removes to Ottawa next month, when Parliament closes. The buildings are now being finished, and will be ready for occupation in a month.

THE STEAMSHIP TWILIGHT. This vessel is up for Wilmington, N.C., by the well-known firm of Messrs. LIVINGSTON, FOX CO., for which port she will sail on the 19th inst. She has just been finished, and her construction reflects credit upon her builders, as she is a craft well calculated to give satisfaction on her proposed route of service, possessing speed, strength of hull and a variety of elegance of finish in her passenger department.

The President has made the following appointments: Newton Edwards, to be Governor and ex-officio Superintendent of Indian Affairs at Dakotah Territory, and Edward B. Taylor to be Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Northern Superintendency. Maj.-Gen. Curtis, Brig.-Gen. H.H. Sibley, Henry W. Reid and Oran Guernsey have been appointed commissioners to negotiate under the instructions of the Secretary of the Interior a treaty or treaties with the several tribes of Sioux and Cheyenne Indians.

Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday, on the body of MALACHI COUGHLIN, who died from the effects of wounds received on Sunday morning, as it is alleged, at the hands of EMMERICH SCHNEIDER. We publish the most important testimony taken before the Coroner's jury, together with a statement of the accused in regard to the affair.

It is important in a hundred ways, that a large crop of cotton be planted in the Southern States next Spring. It is important to the North and to the South, to all the business interests and to the general well-being of the United States. It is important that this country maintain its ascendency as the chief cotton producing country of the world, and retain the dominancy it formerly held in the markets of Europe.

Receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last, 16 bbls. Ashes, 6,115 bbls. Flour, 425 bbls. and 600 bags Corn Meal, 42,063 bushels Wheat, 46,583 bushels Corn, 10,055 bushels Oats, 11,973 bushels Malt, 903 pkgs. Provisions, and 45 bbls. Whisky.

The steamer Thomas Collyer ran into an old wreck in the James River, near Richmond, yesterday, doing some damage. She left for Baltimore last evening, for repairs. Her pumps were sufficient to keep her clear of water.
The funeral of the Consul-General of Prussia, Mr. JOHN W. SCHMIDT, took place at Grace Church at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

We have had a dull and quiet week, with scarcely anything to break the monotony of thought. No murders, riots, "Mary Harris" cases, or other touching and startling occurrences, which seem so much to form the passion of the age. Everything is quiet and serene, with hardly a ripple to disturb the current of events.
Wm. Tucker, aged 23, a native of Boston, was charged with robbing Catherine Stackpole under very peculiar circumstances.
It was a slow, military train which brought me here from Nashville. You have no conception, unless you have experience, as to what process of locomotion traveling on a military railroad is.

The announcement of an accident to the cable which was telegraphed from Valentia at midday on Wednesday, coupled with the long silence since then, and other collateral circumstances, if possible, still more grave, all justify the fears which are now entertained as to the present success of this great undertaking. Up to midday on Wednesday the signals received were singularly distinct, and the insulation as nearly perfect as electrical insulation ever can be.

With the exercise of much patience, the endurance of many discomforts, and the expenditure of no inconsiderable amount of greenbacks, I have reached this point. In such a trip one must of necessity receive some new impressions, and the one most firmly fixed upon my mind is that government cannot run a railroad to the satisfaction of the traveling public.

The Department of Agriculture has just completed its tables showing the condition of the crops on the 1st day of August, as reported by its correspondents. At that time the harvest had not been secured; but from the correspondence since then it is believed that the wheat crop had not received additional injury, excepting, perhaps, in Wisconsin and Minnesota, where the rains have extended since the 1st of August.

The Thirty-ninth Regiment Illinois Volunteers has relieved the Thirteenth New-York Heavy Artillery, at this place. The former regiment, with the One Hundred and Fourth Pennsylvanai Volunteers, garrison the city, and the fortifications extending around the city. The authority of the city police has been superseded by the military, but the Mayor's and other civil courts are still open for the trial of all cases...
The U.S. steamer Catalpa, HOWORTH, Port Royal and Charleston, via Fortress Monroe, 36 hours, arrived yesterday morning.
U.S. steamer Catalpa, (4.) Howorth, Port Royal and Charleston, via Fortress Monroe 36 hours. Steamship Yazoo, Couch, Norfolk 24 hours, with mdse. and passengers to G. Heineken Palmore.

The recent defalcation in the Phenix Bank has called forth, as such things always do, a good deal of discussion about ways and means of prevention, and one has suggested one plan and another another, all pointing to some new device of checks and balances which shall of itself disclose any misapplication of the funds of a corporation.

The British war-steamers Terrible and Galatia arrived at St. Johns, N.F., at 9 o'clock on Tuesday evening, the 15th inst.

The investigation into the cause of the explosion on board the steamboat Arrow, on the 5th inst., whereby several persons lost their lives, was resumed before Coroner LYNCH yesterday morning, about 11 o'clock.

The question relating to direct or indirect taxation has been prolific of almost endless disputes in days gone by, but is effectually put at rest by the necessities of our present situation, and consequently needs comparatively little discussion. We have not been left a choice in the matter, but must resort to both, the only points to be settled being to what extent and on what commodities.

The Southern States undoubtedly offer very tempting fields to young men of energy and enterprise; fields, in some respects, more tempting than any which the West ever offered. The pioneer work is done. The general features of the country are known.

The Union State Convention met in the House of Representatives at noon to-day. The convention was called to order by Gen. CAMERON, the Chairman of the State Central Committee. Hon. JOHN CESSNA was elected temporary President.

THE POLICE COURTS. MEYERS is alleged to have been one of a gang of four outlaws, who first knocked WEIRICH to the pavement.

Raymond: RESPECTED FRIEND: In your issue of Aug. 8 is a description, by "Traveler," of the Shakers their dress, ages, manner of worship, personal appearance, , , together with what purports to be a report of the discourse of an elder, at the public meeting, to "their gay world's people" who were in attendance as spectators.

It is curious to note the little interest taken by the American public in the late attempt to lay the Atlantic Telegraph cable, as contrasted with that excited by the previous effort. Then every stage was watched with the closest attention; every temporary disappointment saddened all hearts, every successful advance was hailed with delight.
The shock of an earthquake was felt here this morning, shaking buildings, tumbling down chimneys, upsetting loose articles, and an iron safe establishment was thrown over.

Just one year ago the first State Billiard Tournament was held in Connecticut; and on that occasion Mr. GERSHOM B. HUBBELL, a fine amateur billiardplayer, succeeded in vanquishing all competitors, and was awarded the champion's cue. Since that event Mr. HUBBELL has been called on four times to prove his right of title, and on each occasion has vindicated himself handsomely.

"A good Captain makes good officers, and good officers make good men," is an adage familiar to the ear of the merchant sailor. That it is true is unquestionably the fact, and it is established by an acquaintance with what we have seen in our experience among men of the sea.

A GIRL SEVEN YEARS OF AGE ABDUCTED TO NEW-YORK. Yesterday afternoon, a man 30 years of age, giving his name as J.K. BARKER, and who claims to be a naval officer, was brought to the Police-station in Jersey City, on a change of having abducted a child named MARY E. KENNEY, 7 years of age, from her home at the foot of Bergen Hill, near Christs' farm, and attempted to outrage her person.

The whaling bark Pearl, of New-London, while on the passage from Honolulu to the Arctic Ocean, was destroyed by the pirate Shenandoah.

The hearing in the case of PETER R. MUMFORD, who is alleged to have defrauded Messrs. GREENLEAF, NORRIS Co., of Exchangeplace, of $28,200, by means of worthless checks, was resumed at the Tombs, yesterday, before Justice DOWLING, Mr. AUGUSTUS W. GREENLEAF was the only witness examined, but his evidence was not of great importance. The case was adjourned to August 30, at 10 A.M., and in the meantime MUMFORD was remanded to the Tombs.

The hearing in the case of Mr. CORNELIUS WARD, for Messrs. GREENLEAF, NORRIS Co., against PETER R. MUMFORD, for defrauding that firm of $28,200 by drawing his check for that sum on the Mechanics' Bank when he had no sufficient deposits therein, was resumed yesterday morning in the Private Trial Chamber at the Tombs, before Justice DOWLING, Messrs. MILLIKEN and JENKINS appeared for the prosecution, and Messrs. RODMAN and SOMMERS for MUMFORD.

INCENDIARY FIRE.--About 8:30 o'clock last night, the stable of EDMUND WALL, corner of North Seventh and Fourth streets, E. D., was discovered to be on fire, but the flames were extinguished with slight loss. The fire was kindled in the manger during the temporary absence of the stable-boy. The same place was fired once or twice before.
Major-Gen. HOOKER, who has recently made a partial tour of the Department of the East, has returned to the city, and relieved Major-Gen. PECK, who had command during his absence.

Several counterfeit one dollar United States notes were recently presented at the Treasurer's office for redemption, but were readily detected by the experts in that bureau. There were numerous counterfeit fifties, but none, so far as is known, of the denominations of one thousand, five hundred and two dollars. All others are counterfeited.

Rev. Dr. SEHON, after an absence at the South for some time, has returned, and is on his way to Washington in search of Pardon. He talks like a man of sense, and admits that he did not act like a man of sense when he joined in with the rebellion. The Doctor is thoroughly subjugated, and intends to make a good citizen from this out.

The special military commission, of which Major-Gen. WALLACE is President, met this morning for the first time, in accordance with the order of the War Department. Judge-Advocate Gen. HOLT was absent. The commission, in secret session, merely organized and adjourned till Monday. Prisoners other than Capt. WERTZ, may be tried before it. The charges and specifications against him will not be made known until his arraignment.

The Commercial Advertiser replies to the arguments recently advanced in this journal against the proposed tax on sales. At the outset it concedes that a rate of two per cent., instead of one, on all commodities sold would be requisite; and, further, that this would probably amount to eight, ten or twelve per cent. of an increase of price to the consumer, through intermediate profits.

THE BURNING OF MRS. CUSICK. Mrs. ELLEN CUSICK, of No. 60 Baxter-street, who was alleged to have been burned by her husband, JAMES CUSICK, setting fire to her clothing, on Sunday night, died at the New-York Hospital yesterday. Coroner GOVER held an inquest on the body. It appeared from the testimony that the woman was grossly intoxicated at the time of the accident, and set fire to her clothing. The Coroner discharged CUSICK from custody.

ITALIAN OPERA. The sounds of saw and hammer, the smells of paint and turpentine, fill the Academy of Music. Preparations extensive, and of the most elaborate nature, are making for the approaching season, and ere long the graceful baton of MARETZEK will wave in front of the lights, and to the inspiring orchestral harmonies, the superb array of artists, whose names and fame have been given in the TIMES, will make melodious the vast expanse.

The Canadian customs returns to June 30 of the present year, just issued, show that there was imported during the year merchandise valued at $44,500,000, of which $21,000,000 came from Great Britain and $19,500,000 from the United States. There is a falling off of $417,000 in customs receipts as compared with the corresponding period of the previous year.

The Palladium says that about 7 o'clock last night, the evening train from New-London ran over a cow, three miles this side of Branford, and the baggage, mail and first passenger cars were thrown from the track.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE OF A WOMAN. A lady named AMELIA DECKER, residing in Dean-street, near Flatbush-avenue, attempted suicide yesterday afternoon by swallowing a dose of arsenic. Her situation being discovered in time, a physician was called in, and by application of the stomach-pump the poison was extracted. She was last evening in a fair way of recovery. Jealousy is alleged to have been the cause.

Our advices by the Persia indicate the amicable settlement of the dispute between the two leading Powers of Germany, which for some time threatened to culminate in open rupture. It is now stated that a complete understanding has been reached in the principal points in dispute, and that the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia were to have a friendly confab to decide upon a division of the spoils.

The Times City of Mexico correspondent, of the 21st ult., writes that the Estafette, the French organ, says that but two courses are left open; that France should assume the protectorate of Mexico, (as it admits the empire is an entire failure,) and declare it one of its provinces, or their country must be absorbed by the United States. Mexican independence, it says, is impossible.

The examination of Dr. BATES was resumed before the Wirz Military Commission yesterday morning. It was with reference to the condition of the prisoners at Andersonville. According to his narration the scurvy was next to rottenness, with which many of the men suffered. Many starved to death because of the paucity and unwholesomeness of the rations, and in consequence of gangrene there were frequent amputations and reamputations of limbs.

This is the last number of the Index. Many, we doubt not, will Sympathize with the regret we feel in making the announcement. We deem it our duty to set forth why the publication of the Index is stopped, also to say a few words of farewell.

With profound sorrow we announce the death in Brooklyn, on yesterday morning of Dr. FRANKLIN TUTHILL, who for several years prior to 1860 was an associate editor of this journal. Dr. TUTHILL was born in Suffolk County, L.I., on the 3d of April, 1822. He entered Amherst College at the early age of 14 years and graduated four years thereafter.

In another column we print the farewell address to its readers contained in the last number of the London Index. That publication having, on the fall of the Confederacy, bravely attempted to retain its position in the literary world, though with a programme more suited to the changed attitude of its constituents, finds itself unable to do so, and, like them, surrenders unconditionally.

We suppose that the mustering out of the negro troops will now be in order. Thus far, while the white soldiers have been disbanded, until three-fourths of the entire force have been sent to their homes, the colored military element has been retained intact. There are about a hundred thousand of them in service, which is about equal, we suppose, to the number of white troops yet on the rolls.

Col. JOSEPH J. MORRISON, Commanding Sixteenth Regiment New-York Heavy Artillery, has been breveted Brigadier-General of Volunteers, to date March 15, 1865. Col. MORRISON'S distinguished service as Captain of a light battery well-known in North Cerolina, both by rebel and Union troops, as Morrison's battery, received the commendation of his superior officer and secured his selection as Colonel to raise a heavy artillery regiment.

An accident of the most appalling nature occurred about noon yesterday on the Oil Creek Railroad, one mile west of the Titusville depot, and nearly opposite the Driving Park. The express train due here from Corry at 11:45 collided with a freight train going west out of time, causing a perfect demolition of locomotive, tender, express and baggage cars, the instantaneous death of six passengers, and the serious injury of a number of others.

In referring in yesterday's TIMES to the Buffalo Spiritualist trial, we left untouched some points of interest, bearing on the interpretation of the Internal Revenue Act. The 79th section of that act, which is the provision in relation to licenses, provides among other things that "jugglers shall pay for each license $20;" and adds that "every person who performs by sleight-of-hand shall be regarded as a juggler under this section."

Prussia is to rule in Schleswig, Austria in Holstein, until the future of the Duchies has been decided on.

OCEAN YACHT RACE. An ocean race is to come off on the 11th between the Fleetwing, owned by Mr. GEORGE A. OSGOOD, and the Henrietta, owned by Mr. JAMES G. BENNETT, Jr., two of the largest yachts in the United States. It will be the first ocean race this side of the Atlantic.

The annual convention of Wool manufacturers was held on Wednesday, in Philadelphia. Mr. JOSEPH L. HAYES, of Boston, Secretary of the association, read, an address upon the origin and progress of the woolen manufactures of the world. In the United States, he said that there had been a great increase in the num- ber of mills. By the census of 1860, there were in the country 3,319 sets of machinery.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday. It was resolved to appoint a committee of five to draw up a recommendation to Congress, to permit ten per cent. of the duties on foreign goods to be paid in legaltender notes. A committee was appointed to invite Mr. JOHN BRIGHT, M.P., to visit this country, and the Chamber then adjourned.

A rule of the Metropolitan Police Department forbids application, by any person connected with the department, for contributions for any object whatever. Therefore the NEW-YORK TIMES has ventured to make an appeal in behalf of the family of the Metropolitan Policeman who was recently murdered on his post.

There are two hundred and fifty thousand freedmen in Louisiana. The census of 1860 gave a slave population of about three hundred thousand. This number has been reduced by various causes. Among them may be noted sickness, emigration back to the States where they were born, and enlistment into the army.

Once again the sons of old Brown gather themselves together from all the country to celebrate another anniversary, and renew the scenes of their youth. The day dawned auspiciously, and at an early hour the graduates scaled the lofty hill on which the colleges stand. The dry weather had caused the leaves of the trees to wither and fade, and the grass to lose its verdancy; but the memories evoked were fresh and cheerful.

After making a good Sabbath day's journey, the commissioners and party, en route for the grand Indian council at Fort Smith, arrived at the un-Sabbath place of Fort Scott last evening. THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER AT THE "HUNDRED STEPS." Coroner HANLEY, of Hudson City, held an inquest on Saturday upon the body of the unknown man, dressed in the garb of a sailor, who was found on Friday lying in a clump of briars, about twenty feet from the foot of the "hundred steps" leading up Bergen Hill to Washington Village.

The conventional commercial year commences in this city on Sept. 1. In the palmy days of our former prosperity it was customary at this period for the daily papers to give an annual review of the NewOrleans markets, entering into all the principal details of their movement throughout the year, and accompanying the report with such general information and reflections as were suggested by the occasion.
The necrology of Brown University for the year 1865 shows that 25 graduates have deceased, of whom 8 were clergymen, 11 lawyers, 1 a teacher, and 2 engaged in commercial pursuits.

Detective CORWIN arrested WM. L. MAYHEW, on Friday night, on the charge of obtaining money under false pretences. His mode of operations was to call on some business firm, and representing his name to be the same as that of the party he came in contact with, generally ingratiated himself into their favor, when he would order some work to be done. He thus called on a number of carpenters, masons, gas-fitters, ,....

The One Hundred and Sixty-Fifth New-York Volunteers, Second Duryee's Zouaves, 300 men, who have been confined for the past two months in Fort Sumter, Charleston Harbor, have been mustered out. The regiment left Charleston on the morning of the 6th, and arrived at this port on the evening of the 9th. The regiment has been honorably discharged, and their arms restored to them.

The first ocean yacht race which has ever taken place in America is now in progress, between the yachts Henrietta and Fleetwing. They started yesterday morning from the lightship off Sandy Hook, on their way to Cape May, the prize to be a valuable cup. The Henrietta is a fore-and-aft rigged yacht, over two hundred tons burden.

The fourth day's sale (yesterday's) went off with decidedly more liveliness than that of any previous day. Indeed, the sale is evidently and decidedly successful. About a third more buyers are present than have usually attended the sales, and the rates commanded by standard books and meritorious light literature are unexpectedly high.

A NEW BAPTIST CHURCH. The dedication of the Fifty-third-street Baptist Church, near Seventhavenue, took place on Sunday. The sermon in the morning was preached by Rev. J.W. HOLMAN, Several appropriate hymns were executed in fine style by the choir at various times during the service.

Those who remember his aspirations in the United States Senate, some ten or fifteen years ago, may be glad to hear the pitch of his pipe at the present hour.

The English brigantine Carrie, from Liverpool, with iron, for Baltimore, is here, wind-bound. The Captain (WILLIAMS) is very ill from an attack of paralysis.

Even a traveler's observation can assure him that Austrian Italy is by no means in a happy condition at this time. Glorious as Venice is, she wears a frown even to the stranger's eye. The people look moody. There is no sort of friendly relation between them and the Austrians.

We publish to-day another article, in the form of correspondence, descriptive of iron mining and manufacturing in the Highlands of New-Jersey and this State. The examination of that country by our correspondent is doubtless by much the most thorough ever made by any member of the newspaper press, he having journeyed about 150 miles on foot to gather the facts from trustworthy sources.

At about 7 o'clock on Monday evening the fires in the Algonquin's furnaces were lighted, and before 9 o'clock the wheels were revolving in fine style. It is fair to say that the Algonquin can get up steam in a very few minutes, owing to a peculiarity of her boilers and the arrangement of the heating surface.

On Saturday, the 9th inst., a collision took place on the Saratoga Railroad, some two miles south of Moreau Station, between two freight trains. It appears that the two trains were proceeding along close together, the first one having a passenger-car attached. The leading train was going at a very slow rate of speed, while the hindmost one was coming at a rapid pace. The result of the collision was a complete smash.

Mr. PETER HAMILL, a Catholic priest, and a resident of Newburyport, Mass., was brought to Bellevue Hospital, yesterday, suffering from incised wounds in his throat of a very serious character. It appears that HAMILL took passage on the train at Boston, and had with him four trunks, which were checked through to this city.

FIRE AND DESTRUCTION OF LIVE STOCK AT BOWRONVILLE.--On Tuesday night the barn of Mr. R. S. SPURGE, Howard-avenue, near Jefferson-street, was fired by incendiaries and entirely consumed. A valuable five-year-old stallion and a milch cow were lost in the conflagration. The stallion was valued at $1,500, and the barn and stock at about $1,000. A few months since the residence of Mr. SPURGE was also fired and destroyed near the same place.

PAREPA IN BROOKLYN. -- The ticket office at the Academy of Music has been liberally patronized by those who propose attending Mr. BATEMAN's concert to-night in Brooklyn. Mlle. PAREPA, and her distinguished companions, will more than repay the good people of our sister city who hear them. Since the days of LIND there have been no such concerts. THEODORE THOMAS leads the orchestra.

The Prisoner WIRZ is suffering from a severe degree of nervous prostration. He has been growing more and more nervous as the trial has proceeded, and at every rectial of some additional act of revolting cruelty, he suffers increased agony of mind. He has more feeling than appears from his expressionless countenance.

The Twenty-fifth Annual Fair of the Now-York State Agricultural Society was opened here this morning,and will continue until sundown on Friday. The exhibition is held in a sixty-eight acre lot, near the north bounds of the city, on the estate of Hon. JOHN BUTTERFIELD, and is situated about two miles from the Central Railroad Depot. It is readily reached by the horse cars, which run from Utica to New-Hartford.

A MAN FOUND DROWNED--SUSPICION OF VIOLENCE. Yesterday morning the body of LOUIs BARN STOFF, a German milkman who lived in Ludlow-street, was found floating in the dock at Pier No. 24 East River, under circumstances which led to the belief that he had died by violence.
We have received by telegraph news of the arrival of the American steamer Mankattan at Vera Cruz yesterday, but her mails will not reach here until to-morrow--till after this leaves.
At a Union County Convention held at Horseheads to-day, LUTHER CALDWELL, ISRAEL MCDANOLDS and TRACKY BEADLE were chosen delegates to the State Convention.

BEES.--Mr. QUINBY, as well as all other apiarians among our readers who have made bee keeping a specialty, will be interested in learning that a swarm issued yesterday (Sept. 13) on Staten Island. It was a "second swarm." The owner was not on hand, and ...

SURGEON.--The London News of the Week contains a singular statement respecting the late Dr. BARRY, who must be well remembered by many of our readers, as holding the place of Inspector of Hospitals in this city, a few years ago.

The annnual fair of the State Agricultural Society, in spite of the inclement weather, has thus far been a perfect success. The grounds are the best ever used by the Society, and the accommodations unsurpassed. The total number of entries is 2,100.

I read with much interest in the TIMES of the 7th inst., the letter of the New-York correspondent of the London Times, and your comments upon it. But it seems to me that even the most intelligent Englishmen are either wilfully or stupidly blind in regard to the relations they bear us.
William Van Brunt and John Myers, jointly indicted for burglary in the third degree, were tried for entering the saloon at the Roosevelt-street Ferry, on the 27th of August.

Yesterday morning, near 2 o'clock, Mr. PHILIPALLEN, a young man about 32 years of age, attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat with a razor, at his residence, No. 163 Gold-street, Brooklyn. It appears that Mr. ALLEN has been laboring under temporary derangement of mind for several days past, and...

The Wirz Military Commission reassembled this morning. Col. CHIPMAN read a note addressed to him by GEO. WEST, Captain and Military Superintendent of the Old Capitol Prison, dated to-day, inclosing a communication from Dr. FORD,Surgeon of the Post, relating to the condition of Capt. WIRZ, in which he states that "The prisoner is somewhat better, but is unable to leave his room to-day."

FIRE IN FULTON-STREET. Between 7 and 8 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in Mr. W. VANDEWATER'S carpenter's shop, on the fifth floor of No. 105 Fulton-street. The flames were soon extinguished, with slight damage by fire. Mr. W. SCHLINGLOFF'S paper-box manufactory, on the third and fourth...

Halsey vs. Cohen; in this case the defendant having failed to appear under the within order it may be enforced and an attachment issued; defend- ant to be held to bail in $300. Pearl vs. Robitchek; order settled. Woodbury vs. Seguine; motion grant- ed. See opinion.

Since the Grand Jury, just one week ago today, brought in the twelve indictments against EDWARD B. KETCHUM, the room in which the Court of General Sessions is held has been daily filled to its utmost capacity, while the vigilant and efficient officers who guard the entrance have, from necessity, had to deny admission to many persons desirous of witnessing the proceedings.

CONDITION OF CAPT. WIRZ ANOTHER POSTPONEMENT. WIRZ is still suffering severe physical prostration. When the court convened this morning report was made of his condition, and in order to give him rest and freedom from excitement, an adjournment was made until Monday next.

The third and last day of the National Horse Fair has been a greater success than yesterday. The attendance was very large, and the show of horses excellent. There were three entries for the five mile trot, viz.; Frank Vernon, Henry Clay and Stonewall Jackson. The first prize was $800 and the second $200.

When JENKINS was called on to plead to the indictments, his counsel, Ex-Judge STEWART, said he would put in a plea of not guilty, with the privilege of interposing a demurrer, to which the District-Attorney replied that he would give notice that if the demurrer was put in, he would move for judgment in case it was decided against the prisoner.

The following charges against Corporation Counsel DEVELIN have been laid before the Governor, in common with those against Comptroller BRENNAN and City Inspector BOOLE, which have already been published:

Our Police Justices have never been distinguished for clearness of judgment, or for a particularly fearless discharge of their duties; but in the following case which came up lately at the Tombs Police Court, the acting magistrate appears to have been utterly befogged, permitting a scoundrel to escape, while his innocent victim was made to suffer what to a refined and delicate woman was worse than any punishment that could be devised.

All the principal counties in the interior of the State have elected Union members to the Legislature. Two or three small counties have gone Democratic; but as a whole the Union party has not lost anything.
The good things of this world have each their appointed mission.

THE RECENT ALLEGED WIFE MURDER. Coroner BARRETT continued the investigation yester- day afternoon, into the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. LAURA MILLS, the wife of FRANKLIN MILLS, residing at No. 32 Fulton-street. The evidence showed that the husband came home about 11 o'clock on Monday night, instead of 1 o'clock as stated by himself. The barkeeper of the American Hotel, which nearly adjoins the Eagle office,...

The English party arrived this morning and proceeded to the Lindall Hotel, where rooms had been reserved for them. A steamboat excursion in the river, witnessing the capacity and efficiency of the steam fire engines, a drive to the Botanical Gardens Of HENRY SHAW, at Lower Grove, and other prominent points about the city, have been the order of the day.

Yesterday and to-day the President granted-fifty-nine pardons, distributed as follows: North Carolina 18, Virginia 27, Mississippi 12, Alabama 1, and South Carolina 1. The Pardon business has not only increased the duties of the President and the Attorney-General, but those also of the Secretary of State and some of his subordinate officers.

The steamship Asia arrived yesterday at Hallfax, with two days later intelligence from Europe. The directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable Company have unanimously accepted the offer of the Telegraph Construction Company to manufacture and lay down a new cable and complete the present one so as to have two perfect cables between Ireland and Newfoundland next Summer.

It may be considered impertinent for one as obscure as myself to criticise, or even differ, with the veteran ex-editor of the Evening Journal; but as the party to which we both belong allows considerable "individuality" to its members, I venture to refer to his article in your paper of yesterday, the 14th.
A meeting of the Board of Commissioners was held last evening at Firemen's Hall. A large number of firemen were present.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The subscription for Mr. MARETZEK'S coming season of Italian opera opened yesterday, and the sale, we are happy to say, was unusually large. Although this result was not wholly unexpected, it is still gratifying in view of the fact, that the unexpected temperature of the Fall season has enabled the fashionable world to prolong its stay in the country.

We made inquiry on Tuesday why we never heard of the detection and arrest of some of the numerous counterfeiters who are destroying faith in our currency by the circulation of bad bills of different denominations. We suppose an answer was furnished to our inquiry by the Associated...

The new and beautiful synagogue of the Congregation Bnai Jeshurun, the oldest but one in this city, was yesterday consecrated, according to the Jewish custom. This congregation is the wealthiest and most influential of the Israelitish faith in our...
It will be seen by the following statement that the Quarantine regulations at this port are so far modified as to permit vessels to discharge cargo at Brooklyn wharves:

It is stated that in consequence of the spread of Fenianism the number of regiments in the South of Ireland is to be increased. The report that Mr. BRIGHT is to visit America on official invitation is pronounced to be without foundation.

By the news from Europe this morning, it will be seen the British Government are becoming go alarmed at the progress of Fenianism in Ireland, that they have determined to increase the military force stationed in that portion of the United Kingdom.

The convention which our government is now holding with the Indian tribes of the great Western plains, seems already to have had a good effect. We have had no "Indian outrages" reported of late, and the telegraph line is working from the Missouri River to California. At the latest dates, no representatives from the wild tribes had made their appearance; but the civilized delegates agree to bring the savages to fair terms.

The number of cases of domestic difficulty seems to be on the increase. At this session of the court there were eight complaints of wives against husbands, for assault and battery. The first case of this nature called was...

An accident occurred on the Camden and Amboy branch road, at Princeton, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, between the train krown as the Adams Express Washington fast freight line, coming from Washington, and the train running from Kensington at midnight.

Certain philoso phers have advanced the idea that our little planet is gradually narrowing its orbit and will ultimately drop into the flery body of the sun and disappear like a snow-ball in Mount Vesuvius. The past fortnight has furnished reasonable evidence of the correctness of this theory, with the alarming addition that the circle is narrowing with fearful rapidity.

Just now, when so much is being said about sanitary matters, crowded tenements, cleanliness and education of the masses, it will, doubtless, surprise many of our readers to be informed that there exists, among what is considered an intelligent and respectable class of our foreign population, a spirit of opposition to educational measures of reform.

A telegram was received by the President today from Columbia, S.C., stating that the State Convention assembled yesterday, the 13th inst. One hundred members were present. It is regarded as the ablest body every convened in that State.

The following officers have been appointed from the Third Pennsylvania Artillery as Assistant Superintendents of the Freedmen's Bureau: Capt. J.B. BISPHANE, for Elizabeth City County; Lieut. JAMES DARLING, for New-Kent County; Lieut. FRANK MARTIN, for Charles City County; Lieut. MARSHALL, for James City County; Lieut. J.W. KAYE, for York County.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news.

EDWARD B. KETCHUM and HENRY B. JENKINS were arraigned yesterday before the Court of General Sessions, the first for forgery and the latter for embezzlement and grand larceny. They both pleaded not guilty. Their trials were set down for the first Monday in the October Term.
Receipts of Produce since our last: 6,846 bbls. Flour, 157 bbls. and 126 bags Corn Meal, 20,954 bush . Wheat, 37,800 bush. Corn, 9,077 bush. Barley, 763 pkgs. Provisions, and 35 bbls. Whisky.

The weather has been so very changeable lately that it has been a task of some difficulty to decide what toilettes are most suitable; but, as our leaders of fashion are either traveling or preparing to do so, the materials made up for them have been what are called...

Count WALEWSKI tendered his resignation as a Senator, and it was accepted. The Emperor had received M. MON, the new Spanish Ambassador. He said he attached great value to seeing France and Spain advancing together, and the French Government would always be found ready to strenghten the bonds and unite the two countries.

The steamship Asia, Capt. MOODIE, from Liverpool at 4 o'clock on the afternoon of the 2d, via Queenstown on the 3d inst., arrived here at 2 o'clock this morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received. She has 52 passengers for this port and 98 for Boston.

Clearances will hereafter be made for all ports of Texas. The collector has commenced to refund the 1 per cent. per pound shipping fee on cotton, and 3 cents merchandise fee heretofore erroneously collected.
The following is the result of the elections held last evening for delegates to the Union State Convention, which meets at Syracuse on Wednesday next (Sept. 20) to nominate State officers:

The Illinois State Agricultural Fair is now under full headway in this city. It is located on the race course of the "Chicago Driving Park Association," about three miles south of the centre of the city. The exhibition is decidedly successful in all its departments. I shall not attempt anything like a full description, for the task would be a long one, and the space it would occupy would have to be counted by columns.

The fair closed this afternoon, and nearly every article on exhibition has been removed from the ground. The total receipts will reach $12,000; about $600 more than was received here two years ago, and $3,000 less than the receipts at Rochestor last year.

The people of Connecticut are soon to decide whether they will strike tho word "white" out of that clause in their State Constitution which prescribes the qualifications of voters. The Democratic party have taken ground against it: the Union party in its favor.

Four days of coal-burning, paddle-turning, cross-firing and objecting has passed, and the Algonquin and Winooski have ceased to work their engines. We are enabled now, we believe, to give our readers the plan which is to govern this peculiar and not uninteresting test between two vessels, each the exponent of a principle which eath designer claims to be the only true one.

It ever managers have occasion to bestow their orisons on the gentleman known as "the Clerk of the Weather," the powers that be of Hoboken owe him a debt of gratitude which they can never repay, for their meeting has been gotten through in the midst of uninterrupted sunshine, for Old Sol has persisted in exhibiting himself in a blaze of glory throughout.

There is unquestionably some little extravagance on the part of many in their estimates of the civil and military celebrities of this war. It is not true that any man was indispensable to its success, as WASHINGTON and FRANKLIN were indispensable to the success of the Revolution.

We publish this morning an interesting account of the commercial activity by which the opening of the Fall season in this city has been thus far marked. It seems to be wholly without precedent. Contrary to the fears and expectations of very many persons, our merchants are selling goods of all kinds in quanties and values far beyond those of any other season.

The application for an injunction to restrain the Assessor and Collector of the Thirty-second District from collecting revenue in certain cases, has been decided by Judge NELSON. The application was based on a decision previously rendered in favor of the applicants in supposed test cases submitted for the purpose.

The board met at noon yesterday, Mr. TWEED in the chair. Mr. PURDY moved that the special order of business (the report of the Committee on Annual Taxes in relation to the Tax Levy for the year 1865) be taken up.

The Greenport, L.I., Watchman says: At about 9 A.M. of Sunday last the schooner Catherine Willcor, of Lubec. Me., was proceeding down the Sound, and while becalmed abreast of that port, about eight miles off shore, the captain and a young man, seventeen years of age, named PETER JOHNSON, belonging at Robinston, Me., formerly a soldier, and who was now working his passage home, stripped off their clothing and jumped overboard for a swim.

The American Union Commission continues active in its work of regeneration and assistance at the South. From the following report of the Richmond Agent, which has just been received at the parent office, in this city, much of interest can be gathered by our readers. It is evident that the commission is doing a great work, and one to which the government and particularly the War Department, is lending every assistance possible.

The public loudly demand that a stop be put to the slaughters by rail which daily darken our pages, and bring merited disgrace upon the country. One of the wisest of ancient legislators declared that that country was best governed in which a wrong done to the meanest citizen was considered and treated as an injury to the community of which he was a unit.

The New-Orleans Times' City of Mexico correspondence, of the 11th, says that the news from the United States causes great agitation among the Imperialists in the State, and extreme anxiety among the most zealous adherents of MAXIMILIAN. They are discouraged and every one seems to feel the increasing despondence.

The London Daily News narrates, in a recent number, a singular difficulty, or rather series of difficulties, which occurred at the dedication of the Church of St. Michael and All Angels in that city. We are informed that the first cause of offence to the officiating Bishop, Dr. TAFT, was the appearance of the altar, which was decorated with four handsome bouquets, which latter he desired should be removed.

There is scarcely a more pressing necessity experienced by humanity than that of mental occupation. The brain must be found work, which is at once its aliment and its safety. As in the bodily system, the unsupplied stomach preys upon itself, so in the system of the mind, idleness means corrosion and utter destruction.
The mails of the Asia reached this city yesterday, and furnish the following additional details of news. The dates are to the 2d inst., inclusive.

The obsequies of Rev. PETER HAMILL, the unfortunate Catholic priest who, while laboring under insanity, inflicted wounds on his throat from the effects of which he died, on Friday, at Bellevue Hospital, were observed at St. Stephen's Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday morning.

In giving, some time since, an account of the dockyards of Great Britain and comparing them with our own, we alluded to the private ship and machinery building establishments of England as superior to any in the world.
The first rain of the season fell in the southern counties of the State yesterday, doing considerable damage to the unharvested grain.

To those Kentuckians who petition Gen. PALMER for relief from the burden of a "population that will not labor, but simply exist as a nuisance," he says there is but one course which can relieve them, and whereby they can have this cooperation, viz.: To assure the colored people of their freedom, abondon the scheme of expelling them from the State, and gain or regain their confidence.

Capt. WIRZ is now privileged to see his wife, she having obtained a pass from the War Department permitting her to visit him. The spiritual advisers, Fathers HAMILTON and WHELAN, of whom he seeks spiritual comfort, have not yet called upon him, WIRZ to-day was somewhat in better health. He is incessantly occupied with his case, frequently being engaged in writing until midnight.

The Tribune editorial of the 12th inst., does inustice to the Secretary of State in the matter of the Sumter and Pickens expeditions. A comparsion of dates will prove this.
Receipts of Produce since our last: 3,434 bbls. Flour, 7,777 bushels Wheat, 8,500 bushels Barley, 213 bushels Oats, 165 pkgs. Provisions, and 30 bbls. Whisky.
The steamer City of Richmond broke her machinery as she was leaving Richmond yesterday. Her passengers were transferred to the Magenta and arrived here in season for the Baltimore boats.

Between 12 and 1 o'clock Saturday morning Mrs. MARY LADDING, who was momentarily insane, leaped from a second-story window at No. 145 Worthstreet, and sustained a compound fracture of the skull, from which she died three hours subsequently. She was a native of Ireland, 68 years of age....JOHN MACDONALD, who sustained painful injuries from falling from a wagon on the 31st ult., died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday morning.

By the British steamer we have this morning a very amusing report of a meeting of Confederate bondholders in London. These sagacious and far-sighted capitalists have come to the conclusion that it is time for them "to inquire into the circumstances under which the loan was contracted." We should think it was quite time to inquire. It has been usual for lenders of money to make such inquiries a ...

Count EULENBURG, who killed Prince ALFRED'S cook, and was in consequence ordered to keep his room while the inquiry was going on, had been allowed to join his regiment, now manoeuvering in the neighborhood of Bonn.

Mrs. JULIA DEAN HAYNE, assisted by Manager PORTER's troupe from Idaho, is playing four nights a week in the Salt Lake Theatre, to densely crowded houses. She has already appeared in "Camile," "The Stranger," "The Jealous Wife," "Griseldis," "The Hunchback," and "Leah."
Overtures for peace have been received from the Rajah of Bhootan, and the war is not likely to be resumed.

is seldom written of prisoners who enter the portals of the East Side Court; but on Saturday such commitment was ordered in the case of WILLIAM JOST, a Bowery statue, who had snatched a wallet, containing $108, from the hands of Mr. EDWARD GRIFFITH, of NO. 834 Broadway, while that gentleman was payivg for refreshments in a Bowery saloon, near Grandstreet.
The Inman steamer City of Boston, Capt. KENNEDY, which left Liverpool at 4 o'clock on the afternoon of the 6th, and Queenstown on the 7th inst., arrived here last evening.

The sloop-of-war Portsmouth, after an extended cruise in the Gulf, has returned to New-York, been put out of commission, and is now being loaded with ordnance stores. As soon as she is stowed she will be towed to an anchorage off Ellis' Island and securely moored.

The Executive Committee of the Merchants' Committee appointed for the relief of the colored people who suffered from the riots in this city in July, 1863, met on Friday afternoon at the office of Mr. JOSEPH B. COLLINS, No. 40 Wall-street. Mr. D. McKENZIE, the chairman of the committee, presided; and Mr. JONATHAN STURGIS, Treasurer, Messrs. JACKSON G. SCHULTZ, GEORGE C. COLLINS, A.R. WETMORE, and EDWARD CROMWELL were present.
A Paris letter says there is no prospect of a reconciliation between the Emperor and Prince NAPOLEON.
The board met at noon Saturday, Mr. TWEED in the chair.

A certain military officer of the olden time is known in history to have "marched up the hill with 40,000 men then marched down again." He does not seem to have accomplished much. Undoubtedly he returned to the spot from which he marched; and Con. FISE and "company" have done equally well. It isn't every one who can do it, however, in these times of the smashing business on the various railway lines.

At the managers' meeting, held day before yesterday, in the Bible Rooms, Rev. Dr. ARMITAGE, President, occupied the chair. A letter was read from Rev. Dr. TAYLOR, Secretary of the Southern Missionary Board, asking the Union to assist in printing and circulating the Scriptures in China. Dr. MASON writes on behalf of Karen Scripture distribution, and begs the Uuion to renew its labors for the nations in India ...

The most destructive fire that ever occurred in Maine swept through this city this morning. The entire business portion of the city, extending from the passenger bridge to Winthrop-street, and from the river to above the railroad track, is a smoking mass of ruins.

The national organizations of the churches were the first to split. It seems now as if they would be the last to unite again. Not one of the four largest denominations, which dissolved North and South before the rebellion, have yet made the first movement toward a new junction. Nor, indeed, is there the least sign yet of such a disposition, unless it be among the newspapers of the Old-School Presbyterians.

COTTON The market has been buoyant, but closed somewhat quieter. All qualities have advanced to a trifling extent. The sales for two days have amounted to 40,000 bales, including 19,000 bales to speculators and exporters.

Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, flames burst from a window in Messrs. COE LAWRENCE'S United States Bonded Warehouse on Cherry, Water and East streets, near Grand. The building was one of the largest in the city, having a frontage of two hundred and forty feet on Cherry-street, and about one hundred feet frontage on the river side.
The steamers Northern Light, from New-York, and Sheridan, from Boston, have arrived.

On Tuesday last the American Institute opened the doors of the old Palace Gardens on Fourteenth-street, and invited the people to an exhibition of American industry. The war being finished, peace has resumed its leadership as of old, directing the onward march of art and science and homelier effort in industrial pursuits, some of the grand results of which are brought before the people only at such times and by such fairs as this.
The Wirz Military Commission reassembled this morning.
The weather in the morning was very chilly. In the afternoon there was a cold, drizzling rain, with a strong easterly wind.

Solicitor for the Navy Department, was given yesterday, in the private examination chamber at Jofferson Market Police Court, before Justice DODGE, the examination being conducted by Mr. JOHN GRAHAM, counsel for Mr. PORTER.

On Saturday, at 2 o'clock,the Atlantic Mail Steamship Company was consolidated with the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, the latter paying $4,500,000 for the ships and appurtenances of the former. This consolidation forms the largest steamship company on this continent, and is destined to wield a most powerful influence on our commercial relations with the world.
Our new City Hall was dedicated to-day, with appropriate exercises. Speeches were made by the Mayor and other dignitaries.

Whoever has observed the enormous increase of houses devoted to the sale of WOOLEN GOODS in our great cities, since the commencement of the war, or the natural, but perhaps more surprising growth in the number of woolen factories among the valleys of New-England since the same epoch, cannot have failed to see that cotton is no longer regal in the great world of merchandise.

The Justice confessos himself unused to the scenes that he witnesses in his new field usefulness, and he already sighs for the close of the week restore him to Jefferson Market, where he may occasionally see among the prisoners a countenance that has not been ruined by debauchery and violence.
The steamer City of Richmond broke her machinery, as she was leaving Richmond, yesterday. Her passengers were transferred to the steamer Magenta, and arrived here in time for the Baltimore boats.
A special correspondent of Saunders' Newsletter gives the following account of the present "Social aspect of the South of Ireland:"

Trade, during the week, has been moderately active. With an unusually light stock of Eastern goods, and the non-arrival of two or three ships over-due, prices of leading staples tend upward. Oils, candles, provisions, case goods, starch, soap, coffee and chemicals have advanced; but the higher prices and unsettled condition of affairs in the East checks speculation.

Upon suggestions of corruption among the paymasters in the Department of Missouri, the government recently sent an inspector to that department to investigate the facts. The inspector returned home last Saturday, having in custody Paymaster.

The annual meeting of the Grand Lodge of Independent Order of Odd Fellows of the United States took place this morning in the hall on North Gaystreet, Grand Sire ISAAC M. VEITCH presiding. The Algonguin and Winooski are ready in the engine department for trial, but the wheels were not quite prepared yesterday to begin work. They have been altered so that the dip of the wheels will be about twenty-four inches, the paddle-floats being seven inches on the face. Just at midnight last night Mr. THOMAS McGRATH, of No. 111 South-street, discovered smoke issuing from a window in the third story of the American Rice Mills, at No. 156 South-street. He immediately gave the alarm, and the firemen were promptly brought out; but before they reached the spot the flames had burst from the third, fourth and fifth story windows, and it was clear that the entire structure must be consumed.

"Is the gutters froze, Billy," rejoined the parent. "Werry hard, father. they is," was the response, "Ah!" sighed the old gentlemen, "put up the coal two pence a pail, Billy. God help the poor!"

In the lecture-room of the Mercantile Library a large audience gathered last evening, to do honor to the memory of the German Gen. SCHEMMELFINNIG, who recently died from disease contracted while in the discharge of active duty in the field. Those present were mainly Germans, a large number being ladies. The proceedings were interesting and impressive in character, and were gotten up under the immediate auspices of the "Unionbund," or German Union League.

Fort Pulaski, with its frowning parapets lined with the savage dogs of war, is at present a place of considerable interest, containing within its battered, war-begrimed, historic walls, several distinguished prisoners of the late Confederate States. Among the prominent men now confined there are Gov. MAGRATH, of South Carolina; G.A. TRENHOLM, late Secretary of the Treasury of the defunct Confederacy; D.L. YULEE, of Florida; Secretary SEDDON, Judge CAMPBELL, Gen. MERCER, and others.

The Secretary of War is no popularity hunter, and has an invincible repugnance to being lionized. The five-hour test was completed shortly after 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon, and at 4 o'clock the fires were hauled from the furnaces of both vessels; twelve hundred pounds of wood were served out with which to start new fires, and all the coal and ashes in the fire rooms was hoisted out and weighed.

FIRES. Between 12 and 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, a fire broke out in the oil refinery of Mr. CHRISTOPHER, corner of Ferris and Sullivan streets. In the attempt to extinguish the flames the watchman, WM. COOPER, was severly burned.

The Thirteenth and Sixteenth New-York cavalry, forming the Third Provisional Cavalry, arrived in this city yesterday from Washington. At 10 o'clock today they will have a parade and reception. The following is a list of the officers:

The fourth of the matches for $5,000 each came off at the Fashion Course on Saturday, and created the customary excitement among the immediate patrons of the trotting turf. Saturday is a bad day to attract a crowd, added to which the morning was low ering and threatened rain, hence many who would otherwise have been present deferred their intention, doubtful if the race would come off, consequently the attendance was more select than numerous.

Charges of malfeasance in office have been preferred against myself and other City Officials. They were presented to the Governor, who appointed the 26th instant to receive our answers or defense. I would have addressed you in regard to them at an earlier day ...

Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER has renewed his regular ministrations at Plymouth Church, and yesterday availed himself, morning and evening, of the opportunity to instruct his people, and an immense audience of outsiders, in the way they should go, politically and morally, on the great questions of the day; assuming that, sooner or later, the entire people of this country will become participants in the discussion of negro suffrage.
The visit to this country of the great English capitalists appears not to have been a mere affair of sentiment or pleasure, so far as concerns the principal purpose they had in view.

The Concord National Bank, of Concord, Mass., was entered between half-past 1 and 2 o'clock to day, while the cashier was at dinner, and the safe robbed of $300,000, consisting of United States bonds and money.

A ministerial journal of Berlin says that the payment of indemnity to Austria for the Duchy of Lauenburg will be made for the present from the King of Prussia's privy purse, and that the occupation of Lauenburg will take place without delay. The further settlement of its position toward the Prussian Crown is postponed.
The regular tri-weekly session of the Board of Fire Commissioners was held yesterday afternoon, at Firemen's Hall. Present Messrs. PINCKNEY, ENGS, BROWN AND ABBE.

SHALL A SOLDIER OF THE UNION FILL A PAUPER'S GRAVE? An old soldier of the Union, named JOHN ROGERS, who was honorably discharged, on account of sickness, some months before the close of the war, died on Saturday, after a lingering and painful illness, leaving a wife and three children wholly destitute.

Boston is now moving in the same direction. The Directors of the American Steamship Company have felt justified in undertaking to construct the first two steamers of the Boston and Liverpool line. The State Trades Assembly met in this city today, Mr. STEVENS, Vice-President, presiding.
