The Belfast and Angelica Plank-road Company, Respondents, vs. C.T. Chamberlain et al., Apellants. Planklroad companies formed under the act of May 7, 1847, and the acts amending the same, under the act of March 28, 1854, do not forfeit their powers and franchises by any act or omissions not willful or malicious on their part.
The base ball game between the Atlantic Club, of Brooklyn, N.Y., and the Lowell Club, to-day, was witnessed by five thousand persons. It was a handsome game.

Steamship Gov. Bailey, Doyle, New-Orleans 10 ds,, in ballast to E.A. Hussey Co. 19th inst., lat. 27.17, lon. 70.30, spoke schr. Mary Mankin, from Galveston for NewYork, 18 ds. out; same day, lat. 28, lon. 79 22, bark Northwood, bound N.

The London Times has an editorial strongly denouncing the continued wanton and vindictive depre dations of the Shenandoah, and sharing in the indignation of America against her. It says that Capt. WADDELL is acting on his own responsibility, and unless he can clearly show he had no knowledge of what was known to everybody else in the same latitude, he has no claim to mercy.

From the City Inspector's report for the past weak it appears that 507 deaths occurred in the city during that time 115 men, 103 women, 153 boys and 136 girls, being a decrease of 63 from the number reported in the previous week, and an increase of 10 over the number reported in the corresponding period of 1864. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows:
The Moniteur says that the great powers have removed all difficulties relating to the Treaty for the navigation of the Danube. The treaty will be signed shortly.

ASSAULTING A NEW-YORK POLICEMAN. On the 14th inst., Policeman BENJAMIN DEVOY, of the Seventh Precinct, New-York, and who resides at No. 62 Remsen-street, E.D., was crossing to New-York in one of the ferry-boats plying to Grand-street, when he found it necessary to take into custody a passenger named JAMES DORSEY, whose residence is at No. 159 Worthstreet, New-York.

The bonds on the rebel Cotton Loan declined one per cent., we see, after that famous meeting of Confederate bondholders at the London Tavern, at which was urged so pathetically the bounden duty of the United States, upon international and moral grounds, to assume the Confederate debt. The reason for this fall is stated to be that "the proceedings at the meeting afforded little ground of hope to the bondholders."

Shortly after the conviction of Friary for the murder of Harry Lazarus, two of the murderer's friends were indicted as accessories to the murder after the fact. One of these men, George MacDonald, pleaded guilty to the indictment; the other, one William Clark, was placed on trial yesterday for the offence with which he stands charged.

The following note comes to us in a mysterious way; its contents are pregnant with odorific gratitude and sarcasm. Sympathizing with the troubles of the fair writer, we respectfully doff our cady before His Honor, and urge his early attention to this boneboiling business, which in a new sense is here developed as a nuisance:

The funeral of Capt. CHARLES H. MARSHALL will take place this afternoon, at the Fourteenth-street Presbyterian Church, corner of Second-avenue, at 3 o'clock. The ceremonies will be attended by the Loyal League Club, the Maine Society, the Chamber of Commerce, and other bodies with which the deceased was associated. Yesterday each of these societies passed resolutions in memory of their departed friend.
The steamship Moravian, from Liverpool on the 14th, via Londonderry on the 15th inst., arrived this morning. Her dates are five days later than those already received.

The funds generally are steady. Consols are without material fluctuation. There is rather more demand for discount, but rates are unchanged. The ROTHSCHILDS have introduced the new Brazilian five per cent. loan for 5,000,000 sterling in the London market. The subscription price is 74, payable in installments extending over twelve months.

FENIANS ON A RAMPAGE. Three young men named MICHAEL DONLIN, JOHN JONES and MARTIN HENLEY, arrested by Officers RAMSEY and ROSE, were taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday morning, charged with having on Sunday evening conducted themselves in a very disorderly manner in one of the Jersey City and Hoboken cars. It was alleged that the prisoners, while intoxicated, entered one of the cars with cigars in their mouths.
Sir MORTON PETO arrived here this evening with his friends, and is staying at the Weddell House.

On Sunday afternoon F.G.H. BEHRENDS, a young German of 27 years, committed suicide at No. 169 Eldridge-street, by taking poison. Little is known of the young man beyond the fact that he took lodgings about three weeks ago at the place where he committed suicide, and, not having found employment, had been quite intemperate and misanthropic. Dr. JOHN BEACH made a post-mortem investigation, but was unable to ascertain what poison the suicide had taken.
The official government journal of San Salvador, El Constitucional, of the 31st of August, has been received in this city. It contains the particulars of the execution of Ex-President BARRIOS.

The propeller Buckeye, of the Northern Transportation line, left here on Saturday evening with passengers and merchandise for Toledo, when about 4 A.M. on Sunday, she struck a sunken rock near Crossiver light, in the St. Lawrence River, a mile above Oak Point, and sunk in seventy feet of water. The passengers were aroused, but hardly had time to realize their peril when the boat slid from the rock and sank.
At Montevideo, Aug. 11, ship Wm. Woodbury, for West Coast, waiting for a crew.
Gen. CURTISS, Col. KYLER and Mr. GUERNSEY, of the commission to make a treaty of peace with the Northwestern tribes, have reached Sioux City, where they were joined by Gen. SIBLEY and Surgeon WOOD.

The following extract, which has just been published, is from the late President LINCOLN'S letter to Gen. WADSWORTH, who fell in the battle of the Wilderness. The letter, which is of a private character, is to be sent to Gen. WADSWORTH'S family.

The four-oared boat race of five miles, two and a half miles out, and two and a half miles back, for $1,000 aside, and the championship, which has created no little excitement among amateur oarsmen and sporting men, for some time past, took place yesterday, opposite Sing Sing.

Hannah Day, a washerwoman, was charged with stealing a considerable amount of clothing from her mistress, Ellen McDonald, who had employed her to do a day's washing and to come next day and do the ironing. It was impossible to say who was the thief the cook or the washerwoman; hence the latter was discharged.

A number of prominent officials and other citizens of New-York are in attendance at the Executive Chamber to-day, to attend the investigation of the charges preferred against the Mayor, Comptroller, City Inspector, Recorder and Corporation Counsel.
The following speech was made at the Buffalo banquet by Sir MORTON PETO:

Several hackmen were yesterday brought before the court on writs of habeas corpus. They alleged in their petitions that they had been illegally arrested by the order of Capt. Petty, of the Fifth Precinct Police.

The distinguished English capitalist, HANDEL COSSHAM, of Bristol, who comes to this country stamped as the friend of JOHN BRIGHT, was received last evening by the members of the Union League Club, before whom he made a very interesting and impressive address, in a somewhat desultory manner, on his impressions of America, her institutions, resources, wealth and general progress.

The funeral services of the late Capt. CHAS. H. MARSHALL, took place, agreeable to previous notice, yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock, at the Fourteenthstreet Presbyterian Church, corner Second-avenue.

Among the witnesses examined in the WIRZ trial to-day was JOHN B. JONES, formerly editor of the Madisonian, the official organ of President JOHN TYLER in Washington. During the late rebellion JONES was employed in the War Department at Richmond.
The regular correspondent of the London Times writes from Newport:

Gen. Aug. V. Kautz, U.S. Army; Capt. W.R. Boggs, U.S. Navy; Hon. Edmund Rice, St. Paul's, Minn.; Hon. R. Yates, Illinois; Hon. Peter Kellogg. New-Orleans; Prof. Vincent, England; Judge L. Trimble, Kentucky, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.
The Wirz military commission reassembled to- day.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The opera of "Il Poliuto" will be given here to-night, with a cast which we are sure will be acceptable to the public. It embraces the names of three favorites Mme. CAROZZI-ZUCCHI, Signor MASSIMILLIANI and Signor BELLINI. It is unnecessary to say a word more.

The Royal Mail Steamship Cuba, Capt. STONE, which left Liverpool at 8:30 on the morning of the 16th, and Queenstown on the 17th, arrived at this port this afternoon at 4 o'clock. She has 82 passengers for Halifax and 113 for Boston.
To-day, at noon, an auction sale of vessels will take place at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. We give a brief sketch of each vessel's history and their general dimensions:

The Fall campaign of the Union men of Jersey City was inaugurated on Monday night by a meeting of the Central Marcus L. Ward Club, at Cooper Hall, which was filled by a highly respectable audience. The President, Alderman J.W. PANGBORN, occupied the chair. The proceedings were opened with a song by Master G.C.B. HALLOWAY, entitled "The Squirming Copperhead," to the air of "Dixie's Land."

QUIET IN THE WHITE HOUSE. The executive mansion was closod to visitors today, and the President had a quiet day. Among the very few persons granted an audience were a delegation from Louisiana, who are looking after the reconstruction of that State.

SIR: In obedience to your order of the 26th July for the competitive trials of the machinery of the steamers Wincoski and Algonquin, to test the relative economy of fuel and power, we would state, that the trial commenced on Friday, 22d inst., and we respectfully make the following report:

The city is full of Masons from all parts of the State. The Grand Commandery of the State of NewYork are holding their annual session here. A large number of the oldest and most influential members of the order are present. Some important business pertaining to the order was transacted yesterday.

It was announced that twenty vessels would be sold at the Navy-yard yesterday, but seven were withdrawn, leaving only thirteen, which were sold at high prices. The following are the names, prices brought and firms who purchased them:

The Wirz Military Commission reassembled to-day.

Under the direction of the Quartermarter's Department, the removal of a large amount of ammunition, comprising ordnance store and 200 barrels of powder from the storehouse on the wharves at Portsmouth, Va., was commenced to-day, to relieve the inhabitants of all apprehensions of the possibility of any explosion.

It must be confessed that the French nation, while it occasionally makes a mistaken conquest, (as in the case of Mexico,) and seems scarcely able to regulate its public affairs without leaning upon the strong arm of despotism, has yet a fine and excelling touch in some other things.

Counterfiet "fives" on the First National Bank of Indianapolis, Ind., and on the First National Bank of Washington, D. C., were circulated here today. They are the first yet seen, and are well calculated to deceive.
Intelligence has been received from Hayti to the 9th of September.

At noon the New-York City officials, under charges of malfeasance in office, with their counsel, being present in the Executive Chamber, Gov. FENTON said he had given the question of jurisdiction careful consideration, and his Secretary would read the conclusions he had come to upon the subject.

The work of reorganizing the Fire Department of this city, on the basis laid down by the new Fire Law, is now materially progressing toward completion. The Board of Metropolitan Fire Commissioners have kept on their steady course of reorganization, on the basis laid down by the board, and are now considerably more than half done.

Richmond and Predericksburgh papers of today have been received. The majority of the forty odd candidates for Congress in Virginia appear to be remarkably outspoken in the avowal of their opinions. The Fredericksburgh Ledger gives an abstract of the views of the candidates from the Fredericksburgh district, of whom there are three, Messrs. CHRISTIAN, DOUGLASS and CURTIS, and all of whom addressed a meeting at Lancaster Court-house.

The Albany Argus says: We were mistaken in stating yesterday that the Supreme Court, at General Term, in this district, were of the opinion that the shares of stock in the National Banks were not taxable under our State law as personal property. The decision was made without deliberation, and only proforma, for the purpose of obtaining the judgement of the Court of Appeals, and no opinion was written.

The present week is by far the most successful of the Fair of the American Institute. New features are added daily, and as the entire mass of machinery on exhibition is in perpetual motion, it cannot fail to render a visit to the rooms both entertaining and instructive. The visit of Major-Gen. HOOKER and his staff was the occasion of a grand demonstration.

A general meeting of the citizens of Paramus, Bergen County, N.J., was held at Union Hall, on Tuesday night, at which much enthusiasm was manifested. There were about twenty-five hundred people present, many of them from the surrounding country. The fair sex was well represented. The National Glee Club was in attendance, and delighted the audience with its melody.

The power of rendering gunpowder explosive or non-explosive at will has long been supposed to be impossible, but a process of obtaining this desirable result has at last been discovered so simple and effectual that the only wonder is no one ever thought of it before.
At Manzanilla, Sept. 2, brigs Arostook, Lord, for NewYork in 2 ds.; Hancock, Norton, for Boston next day Camilla, (Br.,) for New-York in 12 ds.

A meeting of the backers of the Turners and their adherents was held at 4 P. M. yesterday, at the house of ANDREW BRUMACHER. A crowd of ruffians were in attendance to carry out any hint of the MILLER and HASTINGS party, and Jack's friends being in the minority, as one to fifty, were glad to save their bacon at the expense of the money.

The Harbor Police yesterday brought up thirty-three of the crew of the ship Calhoun, who are charged by the Captain with mutiny. It appeared from the complaint, that on the 21st of September there was a quarrel between the cook and some of the crew. The boatswain interfered to protect the cook, and a joint assault was made on them.

The eighty-second convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York, held its first session yesterday morning in the Church of St. John, in Varick-street. At an early hour the church was well filled by prominent members of the denomination, cleaical and lay, while the galleries were occupied by ladies and other spectators.

The Fenians are putting Ireland in such a ferment, that the British Government is becoming concerned lest serious trouble come from it. At Police Trials, yesterday, before Commissioners ACTON and McMURRAY, one hundred and seven charges were preferred against officers of various grades. The number of complainants and witnesses was far greater than usual, and twice during the day the Trial Chamber seemed too small to accommodate them.

In obedience to the Proclamation of Provisional Governor PERRY, the delegates of the people of South Carolina assembled at noon to-day in State Convention for the purpose of repealing the Ordinance of Secession and remodeling the State Constitution.

Richmond and Petersburgh papers of to-day have been received.
On motion, Judge B.D. Silliman, DistrictAttorney, Wm. J. Huff, Esq., and Richard N. Harrington, of New-York, were admitted to practice as attorneys and counselors of the court.

"Dice, the Gipsey Queen," a deformed negrees, that until recently had been exhibited throughout the country by circus companies and others, died yesterday, at No. 310 Broome-street, at the age of 45 years.

Mary Maury was tried yesterday for an alleged larceny of money. The complainant testified that he was standing on the sidewalk in Mulberry-street on the 12th of this month, when the prisoner came along and snatched from his hand a pocket-book containing $180. Complainant was sure he lost his money, but not so sure that prisoner took it. The identification not being complete, the jury rendered a verdict of not guilty.

There is no doubt that the action of the Democratic Convention at Albany took the Administration party in this State wholly by surprise. They were not quite prepared, even with all their knowledge of the utter unscrupulousness of the Democratic leaders, for so sudden a repudiation of evey principle they had maintained, and for the adoption of every principle they had denounced and branded for the four years previous.

The Wirz Military Commission reassembled today.

Anne Larkins vs. Frederick J. King. At 10 o'clock yesterday morning the examination of witnesses in this case was resumed before Justice BARNARD. The plaintiff in the action wishes to have it distinctly understood that her name is not Lorkings, nor Lorking, nor Lorkin, but that it is Larkins. The interest which for the last two days has been exhibited in this case, very materially subsided yesterday.

The Convention of Evangelical Christians met here yesterday, and permanently organized by choosing Chief-Justice CHASE, of Washington, for President, with a number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries, Addresses during the day were delivered by Drs. KIRK, BUDDINGTON, CLARK and others, discussing the objects of the convention.
Rev. J.H. McCarthy, Providence, R.I., is at the St. James.
HENRY GRINNELL, Esq., has received a letter which Mr. HALL wrote to Capt. CHAPEL to be forwarded to Mr. GRINNELL, from which we are permitted to extract:

The Board of Metropolitan Fire Commissioners met yesterday in regular afternoon session. Present Messrs. PINCKNEY and BROWN.
The Eighteenth New-York Cavalry have arrived here en route home.

The convention met at the usual morning hour, and put through a small amount of unimportant business, when Mr. Dox, of Northern Alabama, offered the following resolutions, which, on his own motion, were laid over until to-morrow:

The examination, commenced yesterday morning in the alleged mutinous conduct of thirty-one men employed as seamen on the ship Calhoun, attracted a large crowd of the friends of the accused parties. The crew were all brought into court ironed, and, although a rough-looking lot, they appeared to be above the average in intelligence. The charge against them was refusing to do duty and mutinous conduct. The Captain of the Calhoun was the first witness called.
The convention of the State of Alabama met this morning at 10 o'clock, and after prayer and the reading of the minutes, went into the trensaction of the following business:
Hon. DAVID G. BURNETT has arrived here from Texas, en route to Washington, with a large petition praying for the pardon of JEFFERSON DAVIS.
Gens. HOWARD and STRONG, Col. ORLANDO BROWN, and several other officers of the Freedmen's Bureau, arrived to-day from Richmond. They are inspecting this department.
The steamer Corsica has arrived from Havana, via Nassau, 25th.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. An Unusually equal and creditable performance of "Lucrezia Borgia" was given here, last evening, to another full and fashionable audience. We have rarely heard an old opera create so much genuine applause from a house which, while warm in appreciating the music, was singularly cold toward the singers. The caste was as follows: Lucrezia Borgia, Mme. ZUCCHI; Orsini, Miss A. PHILLIPS; Genarro, Sig. IRFRE; Duke Alfonso, Sig. ANTONUCCI.

Mayor KENNEDY left for Washington to-day on a pilgrimage in regard to the Jackson Railroad and to attend to some other matters.

The Alabama State Convention to-day debated the election ordinance, and finally agreed that all State elections should be left to the people, and that the first election should take place on the first Monday in November.

Late advices from the Lackawanna Valley are to the effect that the men have resumed work, from Carbondale down to Pittston, which takes in the area where operations had been suspended. Below the borough of Wilkesbarre nothing was done for several months in the early part of the season, owing to damages on the canal, the coal thereabouts being shipped to Havre de Grace and Baltimore, but since July the ordinary activity has prevailed thereabouts.

The wills of the following-named persons have just been admitted to probate: Joseph Colgate, Adeline Matilda Bulkley, John Miller, Conrad Hartig, Joseph W. Kellogg, Charles Tappell, John Ridley, F. A. Kupfer, John B. Hagany, M. Donnelly.

Sandwich Island dates of the 2d inst. are received. No later news from the pirate Shenandoah had reached the Islands, which was regarded as favorable to the safety of forty vessels in the Ochotsk Sea.
The convention met this morning, all the members being present. Prayer was uttered and the minutes were read, and at 12:30 the body proceeded to business.

Elijah W. Carpenter vs. the Steamer Island City. This was a libel for a collision. The libelant was the owner of the schooner Peri, which was sunk by a collision with the steamer in Hell Gate. The District Court held that the collision was occasioned by the schooner's own fault, and dismissed the libel, and from this decree the libelant appealed to this Court.

All through the Park, and more especially the Mall and Ramble, were large and ever-moving crowds, listening to the music and enjoying the beauties of the scene.

The World publishes the following letter from Hon. A. H. STEPHENS, written very soon after President LINCOLN'S first election, to GEO. T. CURTIS, Esq., then of Boston:...

Mr. CHARLES COLTON, of Vandam-street, an employe of Messrs. J.B. W.W. CORNELL, died at the New-York Hospital on Friday morning, an iron beam having fallen on one of his legs on Thursday of last week, at the new court-house. He was a native of Ireland, aged 38 years.

The Jewish day of atonement Yom Kippur Which ended at sunset on Saturday, is one of the most important and generally respected of the fasts prescribed for observance among the Israelies.

After continual backing and filling since the 30th of May last, the Kavanagh party have finally secured all their primary points, and yesterday afternoon it was mutually agreed that the first game should be played as above stated. This game is 250 points up, the three-ball French carom game, on a second-sized standard American carom table, with 25-16 inch balls.
A committee of twelve two from each judicial district was appointed to divide the State into four Congressional represeatative districts.

The President has received a letter from Virginians in Albemarle County, Va., in which they ask his counsel concerning the casting of their votes for candidates for the next Congress; all their candidates having been conservative men before the war and opposed to secession, but some of whom countenanced the Southern cause during the rebellion to such an extent as to prohibit them from taking the oath prescribed by Congress in 1862.

The fiasco of the Brothers DAVENPORT is the talk of the town. Never was fiasco more complete, more terrible. For more than a year these famous American mediums have been filling the columns of the London papers with the details of their astounding feats, until all the intelligent and reading world of Paris was in a fever to see them. The field was, therefore, prepared, and the harvest waited to be gathered.

The occupation of a Doctor of Medicine is not a life which is generally desired. Submit the question of the choice of a profession to a class in our public schools, and you would certainly find in it more aspirants for the bar than for the surgery, and possibly more for the pulpit than the bar. The reason for this is obvious.

GEN. PALMER AND GOV. BRAMLETTE. A statement appeared in one of the New-York papers of the 29th ult., in substance, that Maj.-Gen. PALMER is to be removed from the command of the Department of Kentucky. This statement is incorrect. It is true, however, that Hon. GREEN CLAY SMITH, aided by Gov. BRAMLETTE, has made an effort to accomplish this end, and have filed statements in the War Department.

Austria has a curious and difficult task before her. She is to restore self-government to Hungary, and yet retain the supremacy of Austria. We are glad to note that in the Congressional canvass of Virginia there is a general disposition to leave the field exclusively to candidates who can take the stringent Congressional oath that they have never participated in the rebellion. Out of the eight Congressional districts, five have candidates running who can all meet the Congressional requirement.

In the Supreme Court, yesterday, an important opinion was delivered by Justice BARNARD, in the case of the New-York hackmen who were arrested about ten days ago for an alleged violation of the corporation ordinances, in leaving their coaches, crowding on the piers and boats, and forcing themselves into railroad cars just arrived, for the purpose of importuning passengers.

A meeting of the Union General Committee was held last evening at the headquarters, corner Twenty-third-street and Broadway, President JAMES KELLY in the chair. Gen. BARNUM and Mr. CORBETT, of Syracuse, were present, and invited to take seats upon the platform.

SEWELL WORTLEY, of Lynchburgh, Superintendent of the Quartermaster's office, under Capt. ALBERGER, and JOHN ODELL, one of BAKER'S detectives, severally testified as to their looking down through a hole on the movements of Gen. BRISCOE in the room below, where the money was deposited. The latter subsequently searched Gen. BRISCOE, and found the missing treasure in his private office. The money and bullion, and the money bags and packages, were identified by this witness.

The twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society, which opened Wednesday morning, at the Fashion Course, Flushing, and continued yesterday, has proved quite a success. The unpropitious state of the weather undoubtedly kept many from attending, and detracted somewhat from the general interest of the occasion. Yet the attendance on Wednesday was not less than 8,000 people, and Thursday 12,000 probably visited the fair grounds.

The writer of this, not desiring to make any arrangement but that which would be agreeable to the managers of the fair, did, before going to any expense, consult with, and did receive their consent and approval, they then seeming desirous to encourage me or any other enterprising persons.

The Mozart Democracy. seem to be front in the field with their local nominations, their county ticket being evidently made up for the purpose of forestalling Tammany Hall.

A great mass meeting of negroes and freedmen was held at Edgefield, Tenn., on the 5th, six thousand persons being present. An address was made by Brig.-Gen. FISK. He rejoiced that the negroes of Tennessee were free as God intended them to be. He told them that they must prove themselves entitled to freedom by industry, sobriety and integrity. His duty was to see that they discharge their duties.
After the North Carolina State Convention had organized, GOV. HOLDEN sent in the following message:

The Central Park Commissioners announce that if the weather is fine, there will be music on the mall at 3 o'clock to-day, by the Central Park Band, under the leadership of H.B. DODWORTH. Owing to the lateness of the season, Wednesday afternoon concerts on the lake are discontinued.

Patrick Walsh was placed on trial for stealing $400 from August Radika, an emigrant. It appeared that there was a mistake as to the identity of the prisoner, he being an Irishman, while the person who took the money was Dutch, and talked Dutch to the complainant.

We are glad to see that the Chamber of Commerce has taken up the subject of a City Post-office. Its call upon the Postmaster-General and upon Congress, to provide a decent building for this branch of the public service, will meet with an emphatic response.
The Steamer Constitution sailed to-day for Panama, with $1,112,000 in treasure for New-York, and $342,000 for England.

Colorado, as well as Connecticut, has just given its decision against negro suffrage. This circumstance has led a cotemporary, possessed of very extreme views on the question of negro voting, to take ground against the admission of Colorado into the Union, for which application will be made at the forthcoming session of Congress.

The Wirz Military Commission reassembled this morning. Augustus Kleich, of the Eighth Pennsylvania Cavalry, testified that he was taken as a prisoner to Andersonville; Capt. Wirz was sick in August, and continued so for a month; meanwhile, Lieut. Davis was in command; he never heard or saw Capt. Wirz shoot or injure a man.
The Fall Meeting of this association commences at their private grounds at Paterson of Tuesday next, and promises in all respects to be a success.

In the Legislature to-day Mr. WINES, of Montgomery County, presented a memorial from the citizens of his county, requesting that measures be adopted to relieve the financial embarrassment of the people.

This court, more than any other in the country, indicates the increase or decrease of offences of a minor character. In the course of the year there are from five to six thousand offenders arranged to plead for assault and battery, larceny, and other misdemeanors.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 38. The Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States has established a form of prayer to be used for "the President of the United States and all in Civil Authority." During the continuance of the late wicked and groundless rebellion, the prayer was changed to one for the President of the confenerate states, and so altered was used in the Protestant Episcopal Churches of the Diocese of Alabama.

The Binghampton (N.Y.) Republican relates the singular case of SEYMOUR BUTTS, of Windsor, Broome County, who has been deranged on the subject of snakes. He imagined himself to be in great danger from them, and was seized with the idea that if he are food the snakes would cause his death.

CLARKE, the comedian, from playing the celebrated piece entitled "Our American Cousin" was argued before Judge MONCRIEF in the Superior Court. The Judge peremptorily refused to grant any injunction, as in his opinion there was no possible ground for claiming one.

Nearly all Eastern goods are still advancing. Large transactions are taking place, partly on speculation, in Eastern whisky, candles, mackerel, soap, etc., at higher prices. Coal oil sells at $1.70 per gallon, mackerel at $3 a kit and $11 a half barrel. Whisky is $1.75@$1.80 a gallon. The market is entirely bare of Eastern products in first hands. Wheat has advanced to two cents a pound. Flour sells at $6.25 per barrel.

On Saturday evening the much-talked of at least in New-Jersey discussion between Maj.-Gen. KILPATRICK and Hon. A.J. ROGERS, came off in front of the Court-house, Newark, N.J. The challenge for the discussion emanated from Mr. ROGERS, who offered to meet Gen. KILPATRICK three times a week until election, to discuss the issue of the present campaign in New-Jersey. It was promptly accepted, and the meeting on Saturday evening was the first of the series.

A young artist named BARTLETT, but a few months since a simple marble-cutter, has produced a choice head and bust, which he calls the Yankee Girl, and which is causing quite a sensation in artistic circles. As a work pure and simple it is in some respects deficient, but as the first work of an uneducated hand, it is miraculous. BARTLETT'S studio is the Mason Hamlin Building, next to the Metropolitian Hotel.

The Moniteur, alluding to the reported speedy evacuation of Rome, says that no doubt should exist relative to the intentions of the French Government. So soon as France shall consider the proper moment to have arrived, she will, in concert with the Pontifical Government, adopt necessary measures for the commencement of the evacuation of Rome, in order that the withdrawal of the French troops may be completed within an appointed period.
The Democratic organs profess to be very confident of success in the coming election. But their confidence is based wholly on presumed or predicted divisions in the ranks of the Administration Party.

A divorce suit of considerable interest came up yesterday, before Justice INGRAHAM, in the Supreme Court. In September, 1864, the plaintiff, GABRIELLA SELTZER, wife of ALEXANDER SELTZEE, obtained a decree of absolute divorce from her husband on the ground of adultery.
The steamship North American, from Liver pool on the 28th, via Londonderry on the 29th of September, arrived of this point at 4 o'clock this morn ing. She has 31 cabin and 347 steerage passengers.

A dispatch from Brussels says: "The Nord publishes a telegram from Paris, which says: "The text of Earl RUSSELL'S circular upon the Gastein treaty, published by the Independence Belge, is an invention, the object of which was to create the belief that a good understanding existed between the English and French cabinets. The circular of M. DROUYN DE LHUYS is alone authentic."

Highway robberies in this section are becoming of almost daily occurrence. The scenes of operation are on the roads leading to Titusville or Shaffer, and the parties are so numerous and bold that it is not safe to travel the roads alone.

At 12.45 o'clock to-day the severest earthquake ever felt here frightened almost the entire population of the city out of their houses into the streets. During half a minute there were two tremendous shocks, which caused buildings to rock to and fro in a manner altogether alarming.

Pennsylvania and Ohio held their elections yesterday. In the former State the contest was quite tame, there being no prominent officer to be chosen, the highest being AuditorGeneral, who is at best a mere clerk.

On the night of the 19th of March last, the ship William Tell, under the command of Capt. WM. W. FRENCH, was within about twenty miles of Pernambuco. It was the mate's watch on deck. The Captain was sleeping in his cot in the cabin.

WM. HOGAN, aged 15, was charged with lifting two pieces of cassimere cloth from the door of the store of MORRIS MICHAEL, in Thirty-seventh-street. He was seen taking the goods, but he ran so fast that he could not be caught.

The government has had Detective ARMSTRONG for two weeks hunting out a gang of counterfeiters of American silver. ARMSTRONG arrived here last night, having arrested five wealthy farmers, who are represented to have for forty years been maufacturing bogus silver, near Stirling.

The pupils of the Institution of the Deaf and Dumb, with their officers and teachers, will visit the Fair of the American Institute on Thursday, the 12th inst., at 1 o'clock, having received a gratuitous invitation from the Board of Managers. An interesting exhibition may be expected from the pupils on the platform, showing their acquirements in useful knowledge in the arts and sciences.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S opera of "I Puritani" was given here last evening to an unsually brilliant house, brilliant we mean for Tuesday, the least popular of the opera off nights. The distribution was excellent, and the performance in consequence was exceedingly well balanced and satisfactory. Miss KELLOGG'S Elvira is well known.

In Philadelphia, McMICHAEL'S majority for Mayor is 5,109; HARTRANFT'S, for Auditor-General, 7,692; CAMPBELL'S, for Surveyor-General, 7,750. All the Union city ticket is elected. Two Union Senators, fifteen Union and three Democratic Assemblymen elected. MANN, the Union candidate for District-At torney, has 8,000 majority.

To-day's session has proved itself, by far, the most important one of the five that have preceded. The business of the day was devoted almost exclusively to the consideration of the report of the Committee on Consecration of Bishops, and more especially to that portion of the report which concurred in the acceptance of Bishop WILMER as the elected and consecrated Bishop of the Diocese of Alabama. The debate was warm and discursive.

Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at the NewYork Hospital yesterday over the body of Dr. FRANK B. WILLIAMS, late assistant surgeon of the Fourth New-York Artillery Regiment, who died from the effects of a dose of morphine. It is said that deceased had recently drank to excess.

The General Convention of the Episcopal Church reassembled at 10 o'clock this morning. The Committee on New Dioceses recommended the passage of a resolution ratifying the division of the Diocese of Pennsylvania into two new dioceses, and the said division to take effect on the 1st of November, 1865.

At a regular monthly meeting of the Union League Club, held at the Club-house on Thursday evening, Oct. 12, 1865, the follwing preamble and resolutions, offered by GEORGE W. BLUNT, were ununimously adopted:

Yesterday was indeed a gala occasion at the Fair of the American institute. Early in the morning, crowds, many hundreds, of people who had learned from the TIMES and other journals of the anticipated visit of the deaf and dumb children to the fair, thronged the building. We have never, save on one or two evenings, saw the large halls so densely packed as at this time.

The steamer Cumbra, from Savannah on the 7th inst., has arrived here. The steamer ldaho, from New-York, arrived at Savannah Sunday morning at 8 o'clock. The steamer America, from New-York for Savannah, arrived off Tybee Island on Sunday at noon.

A dispatch from Washington announces that Lieut.-Gen. GRANT has returned to the capital, and that he will now take measures for the reduction of the army to a standard required only for the ordinary condition of the country, in times of tranquillity at home and abroad.
The Wirz Military Commission reassembled today. Mr. Schade, counsel for the prisoner, read from the letter book of Capt. Wirz the following:

We print this morning an important order by the Lieutenant-General, which will very speedily muster out of service nearly all the volunteer army. He has assigned the artillery for the most part to the forts of the Northern States; the forts of the Southern seaboard, with two or three exceptions, are to be in charge of colored troops.

The Democratic nominations in Kings County and Brooklyn are identical with the suggestions made in the TIMES several weeks since, commencing with the name of MARTIN KALBFLEISCH for Mayor. In this county the Democracy have in former years been bit terly divided. The regulars and nationals and citizens and soreheads have fought each other with a zeal that in a better cause would have merited success.

The following important order from Gen. GRANT, assigning several regiments of the regular army to frontier duty, mustering out all the volunteer cavalry east of the Mississippi, and garrisoning the sea-coast forts south of Fortress Monrce with colored troops, has been issued by the War Department.

The Woman's Central Association of Relief has closed its mission. Of the many benevolent organizations developed by the necessities of the war, this has been one eminently useful, invariably successful, always judicious and never selfish. It was begun in April, 1861, and in June of the same year it book voluntarily a position subordinate to the Sanitary...

Prof. LOWE and his balloon were at the great Fair last night; so were about three thousand pushing, jostling, curious people; so were half a dozen young women, who pounded unmercifully every piano in the hall, and made the roof weary with the echoes of their thumps.

SUSPICIOUS CHARACTERS. Detectives McWILLIAMS and NUGENT arrested two young men, named TENNENT McCORMIC and JOHN CONNELLY, charged with being rather suspicious characters. They have been charged with loitering around the ferry and railroad depots with bad intentions. The Recorder committed them to the County Jail, the former for 60 and the latter for 30 days.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. A spirited and excellent performance of "Martha" was enjoyed here last evening by a brilliant and overflowing audience. The cast was all that could be desired for this gay and graceful work. Miss KELLOGG is certainly a charming Martha. She invests the part with much vivacity, and sings the music with perfect facility.

Mount Hood, Oregon, has been in a state of eruption since Sept. 23, which it is supposed had some connection with the recent earthquake in California, although the central part of this State only felt the shock.

The many private courtesies extended to Sir MORTON PETO and his fellow travelers by our citizens, are occasionally varied by demonstrations of a more public character, by which they are informed more thoroughly and minutely of the workings of our institutions and the customs of our country.
The reported majorities in the sixteen counties sent to-day, compared with the vote of 1862, shows a Union gain of 4,930.

Chief-Justice CHASE is now the guest of JAY COOKE, Esq., at his beautiful residence on Gibraltar, Put-in-Bay Island, Lake Erie, luxuriating in the magnificent vineyards in that locality, and whiling away the time, a la old IZAAK WALTON, catching black bass. Miss RANSOM, the well-known artist of Cleveland, is also at Put-in-Bay Island, making sketches for some large paintings of the beautiful scenery about the bay and islands, which have been ordered by JAY COOKE.
The Wirz Military Commission reassembled this morning.
The General Convention of the Episcopal Church reassembled to-day. The collect for the burial service was read in reference to the death of Rev. LOT JONES of New-York.

The insolence with which the Democratic leaders in this State claim the support of President JOHNSON is simply astounding. We are pretty well hardened to all sorts of misrepresentation at the hands of Democratic partisans, but this caps the climax.

The following counties are reported. The comparisons are with 1862, when the Democrats had 3,524 majority in the State. We think some of the figures for this year are poor guess-work, but we give them as they come. ED. TIMES.

EIGHTH WARD DIVERSIONS. Late last evening a drunken dispute occurred between HENRY GERKEN and his mother, ANNA GERKEN, in her disreputable house on the southwest corner of Prince and Mercer streets, and in a scuffle young GERKEN'S pistol, which was in his coat pocket, was discharged, and he was wounded in the left leg.
The Wirz Military Commission reassembled this morning.

An accident happened to the day express train going east, between here and Lancaster, this afternoon. Four cars were thrown from the track. Eight persons were killed, and two slightly injured. The only one of the dead recognized up to this time is the wife of J.P. BARR, Esq., of Pittsburgh. The accident was occasioned by a broken rail.

The Presbyterian Synod of Kentucky has been in session three days. No action has been taken on any proposition as yet. The regular officers have been elected.

The fire in this city originated accidentally, at about 11 o'clock, in a boat-shop at the head of Lewis Wharf, at the foot of Main-street, and owing to a low tide, a scarcity of water, a deficient fire apparatus, and a fresh wind, soon scattered the flames, and in a short time the buildings on and near the wharf were consumed.

On Friday night a party of Irishmen tarried late over their cups in PETER MATTHEWS' bar-room, at No. 9 James-slip, a place which is familiarly known as Slaughter-house Point, and at about 3 o,clock yesterday morning, the company having drunk themselves into fighting humor, the subject of Fenianism was introduced. MONTGOMERY, ALA.,Saturday, Sept. 30, 1865. The Reconstruction Convention of the State of Alabama met on Tuesday, Sept. 12, 1865, and by acclamation Gov. FITZPATRICK was made permanent President.

Patrick Dunning was tried on an indictment for robbery, but the case proving to be only assault and battery he was convicted of that offence. The affair took place near Avenue A, the prisoner, complainant, Francis Graham and some others being out on a spree, and getting pretty drunk, the prisoner knocked down one of his companions, He was remanded for sentence.

Major-Gen. Geo. B. McClellan is expected to arrive in this city from Europe in about three weeks. W. Bartlett and wife, of Cleveland, are stopping at the St. James Hotel, in this city. Mr. Bartlett, as auditor of the Cleveland Erie Railroad, has strongly identified himself with the railroad interests of this country.

Corporal JOHN SHEPHERD, of the Thirty-eighth United States Colored Regiment, was hung this morning at Camp Hamilton, for rape committed last April near Richmond.

RAMMING lived about half an hour after receiving the wound. The steamer Yosemite burst her boiler at Riovesta, on her downward trip from Sacramento, last night. The upper works forward were completely wrecked. Thirteen persons are known to be killed, forty or fifty wounded, and others are missing.

On Saturday, a number of our Fire Companies left for Philadelphia to take part in the grand parade in that city to-day. Preparations for departure were commenced at an early hour in the morning, and at about noon the several companies proceeded to the foot of Cortlandt-street to take the cars for the Quaker City. The steamship Nova Scotian, from Liverpool, at 2:30 P. M. of the 5th, and Londonderry on the 6th, inst., passed this point this evening.

Our Washington correspondent says: "The last disgraceful scene in the WIRZ trial took place yesterday. Mr. BAKER, the prisoner's counsel, an obsceue pettifogger, who foisted himself into the case for personal notoriety, was all but ejected from the court for his contumacious conduct. It was not until a motion to pitch him out had been made and seconded that he subsided. The evidence was then closed...

The record of testimony in the Wirz trial makes 5,000 foolscap pages, divided into seventy parts, and contains between three and four hundred objections and rulings of the court. One hundred and sixty witnesses were examined on both sides, several of whom were individually on the stand for two days for examination in chief and cross-examination.

The speech of Secretary McCULLOCH to his old neighbors at Fort Wayne will attract the attention due to the important financial position which this gentleman occupies. We believe it will be well received throughout the country. It should give renewed assurance to all conservative and prudent people that the blame will not be with the Administration at Washington if our finances are not gradually but surely consolidated, and the currency improved...

An accident happened to the day express train going east, between here and Lancaster, this afternoon. Four cars were thrown from the track. Eight persons were killed, and two slightly injured. The only one of the dead recognized up to this time is the wife of J.P. BARR, Esq., of Pittsburgh. The accident was occasioned by a broken rail.

My last was dated at New-Orleans, and my return trip was made by Mobile and Pensacola. The few hours at my disposal in Mobile were spent in looking about the city.

The undersigned passengers on the New-Orleans steamship North Star, on her trip from NewOrleans to New-York, Oct. 7-15, 1865, as a means of testifying their high regard for the officers of said steamship, do adopt the following resolutions:
The exhibitors of artificial legs are in luck. Their little show of Saturday night was productive of such good results that they resolved to leg it again last night.

We had the pleasure of a call from Dr. J. DELL ORTO, from whom we are glad to learn that steps are being taken to introduce a colony of Polish immigrants into Texas. Col. SMOLINSKI has bought large quantities of lands in the counties of Freestone and Anderson, for the above purpose.

A few influential ladies of this city and vicinity, interested in the very excellent Ursuline Convent at Morrisania, have entered with great zeal into the project of forming a church organization in connection with the convent.

JULES DORN, WM. KRIPPENSTAPPEL, and other substantial Louisvillians have organized a "Kentucky Land Association," to assist and protect all those who may intend to settle in our State, and to obtain for them suitable property at fair prices.

QUEENS COUNTY NOMINATIONS.--The following nominations have been made by the opposing political parties of Queens County: Democratic.--For County Judge, JOHN J. ARMSTRONG; Surrogate, WILLIAM H. ONDERDONK; District-Attorney, BENJAMIN W. DOWNING; Superintendent of the Poor, WILLIAM W. CURTIS; Coroners, LEONARD A. SEAMAN...
The storm has abated, and a fleet of vessels detained by weather, proceeded to sea this morning.
The General Convention of the Episcopal Church reassembled this morning.
THE OLD BOWERY. Last night, for the first time, we believe, was produced. "The Spirit King," a melodrama of the most startling kind, said to be translated from the German of "Der Alpenkonig."

A trial of some interest to policemen was concluded yesterday in the Marine Court, before Judge HEARNE and a jury. The parties were S.G. ADAMS, a staff officer in the United States Army, plaintiff, and Capt. CAFFRY, of the Fifteenth Precinct, Metropolitan Police, defendant.

Shortly after the Stamford train (which leaves New-York at 6:30 P.M.) had passed over the bridge at this place last night, the bridge was discovered to be on fire between the draw and the west end, supposed to be ignited by fire dropped from the locomotive. Efforts were made to check the flame by pails ...

We have received several numbers of the Mexican Times, an English newspaper, recently established in the City of Mexico by a rebel refugee. Judging from the specimens before us, we think news must be a scarce article in MAXIMILLIAN'S capital.

An informal meeting of the Fenian Congress was held to-day, at the Assembly Buildings, About six hundred delegates were present. The Chairman delivered an address, but the Congress will not be organized for business until to-morrow.
Lieut. Col. HOGG, Second New-York Artillery, has been restored to the rank of which he was temporarily deprived, and Gov. FENTON has addreseed him the following flattering letter:

The Sunday morning murder at No. 872 Hudson-street, details of which were published in yesterday morning's TIMES, was investigated by Coroner COLLIN, yesterday afternoon, at the Greenwich-street Police-station.

The grand parade of the Philadelphia Fire Department to-day is one of the most imposing and splendid pageants ever presented in this country. The procession is composed of twenty-two divisions, each numbering from four to six companies, making, in all over one hundred and fourteen, including over thirty visiting companies.
The following official returns are received: Cambria County--Davis, Democrat, 759 majority Denton, Democrat, 831 majority.

ANOTHER COTTON WAREHOUSE CONSUMED. Near 11 o'clock last night, fire was discovered on the second floor of Messrs. HARRISON OSBREY'S storehouse, at Nos. 3 and 5 Bridge-street, and the alarm was promptly sounded; but before the firemen could get their streams on, the interior of the buildings was a mass of flames.

FOUND DROWNED UNDER MYSTERIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES. Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a returned soldier, named THOMAS LARKINS, whose body was found floating in the Morris Canal Basin on Sunday morning.
The yachts that rendezvous here are all at anchor in the Horse Shoe. It is blowing a heavy northwest gale, and it is supposed they can't get out, as they are all on the lee shore.

The Union Republican Judiciary Convention met last evening at headquarters, corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, Mr. EDGAR KETCHUM, in the chair. After the roll of delegates from the various Assembly districts had been called, the Chairman announced that the meeting was ready to proceed to business.
Let no reader of this morning's TIMES, who is entitled to a vote, hesitate one moment to have his name registered.

The Constitutional Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning, pursuant to adjournment. Several members who were absent yesterday at the passage of the new ordinance declaring the secession ordinance to be null and void, , were allowed to record their votes, which they did in its favor.

It is pleasant to talk of the new ships of the New-York and Hamburg line; of the rapid increase of the international Liverpool line of WILLIAMS GUION; of the great success of the Cunard and of the Inman lines, and of the prosperity of the Bremen and recently-introduced French lines.
These clubs played their return game at Hoboken yesterday, and it proved to be quite interesting contest, the victory remaining with the St. George second eleven by a score of 107 to 83.

A recent tour through Virginia, and into North Carolina as far as Raleigh, has satisfied me that the waste of war has not been by any means so great as is generally imagined, and that it is far from being irreparable.
The convention met at 10 o'clock A.M., and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. CAAVEN, of the Methodist Church.

Among the amnesty oaths just filed at the State Department is that of ROBERT E. LEE, subscribed to on the 2d inst. That all the world may know what this man promises for the future, we give the oath entire. It is the same oath required from "any other man:"
A number of drafted men who had run off, but returned since the end of the war, have been tried by a court-martial at Detroit.
BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. The board met yesterday afternoon, but did very little business of general importance.

Boston is a knowing town. We are sagely apprised therefrom that on the 19th instant there will be an eclipse of the sun "partially visible in Boston." We are sorry for the Athenians; it is quite too bad that an eclipse should be to the only partially visible.
The people of this State are asked to elect the Democratic ticket, because the Democratic party will support President JOHNSON. They are referred to the resolutions passed at Albany for the proof.

It is perhaps hardly worth while to "rush into print" on so small a matter, but for the sake of those who read without thinking, I submit that your respected correspondent, the "Veteran Observer," has hardly made out his point against me.
A large sale of hospital stores, which have accumulated here in immense quantities during the war, took place here to-day. Piles of bed stuffs, blankets, sheets, tables, , were disposed of.

The decision in the case of Irene McCready, charged with keeping a disorderly house in East Fourteenth-street, was rendered yesterday morning. The motion of counsel was to remit the papers back to the magistrate for further examination. The motion is denied. The court holds that if the papers were to be sent back to the committing magistrate he might refuse to reopen the case.
The following paper, substantially, was offered at the Kentucky Presbyterian Synod last Thursday, by Rev. Dr. ROBERT J. BRECKINRIDGE:

The Democratic leaders make a great deal of noise about State rights. They affect to believe that the Republican party means to destroy them, and to convert the government into a consolidated unitary rule. It is an easy string for them to harp upon, for it has been long familiar to them.

Services of thanksgiving were held at St. Luke's Church this morning at 10 o'clock. A large congregation was assembled.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The performances here last evening were truly of a gala character. They commenced with singular promptness at 8 o'clock, and terminated toward midnight. During this rather long session there was a concert of nine vocal and instrumental pieces without counting encores and the entire opera of "Lucretia Borgia." It is safe to say that either of these attractions would have filled the house. The combination sufficed to produce a jam.

Walter W. Hurd vs. John Kelly, Sheriff of the City and County of New-York. This interesting case was tried yesterday in the Supreme Court before Mr. Justice SUTHERLAND and a jury. It involves some points of law and some questions of fact, of interest to laymen as well as to lawyers.

The Democracy are very desirous in this campaign, as they have been heretofore, to keep out of the sight of the people the real question involved, and to go off upon side issues, and matters which will not be affected either way by the result.

A writ of habeas corpus, on the petition of JOHN HIPKISS, Jr., was granted yesterday by Justice INGRAHAM, of the Supreme Court, against Mr. JOHN A. KENNEDY, Superintendent of the Metropolitan Police. The petition alleges that MICHAEL B. CLINE was lately in the custody of a guard in the City of Richmond, Va., for an alleged debt; that he escaped the guard, and came to this city, where he was arrested.

Dispatches from Danville say it is believed there that Rev. B.A. DAVIS, Methodist Minister of Patrick County, is elected to Congress in the Fifth District. His antecedents are unknown here. STURDEVANT, elected Mayor of Richmond in July, has resigned.

An adjourned meeting of the Republican City Convention was held on Monday evening, to nominate a candidate for Collector of Taxes, in place of Gen E. L. MOLINEAUX, who was previously nominated, but who declined to stand.

INCREASED POST-OFFICE ACCOMMODATIONS. Yesterday, the postage-stamp department of the General Post-office was removed to the Nassau-street side of the building, a part of the space on Nassau-street that was formerly used as an entrance to the registered letter department, and a part that was assigned to the ladies department, now comprising the new stamp-office.

Tho second great ocean yacht race of the season, between the yachts Palmer and Henrietta, was decided yesterday afternoon, the latter vessel being declared victorious. The yachts sailed from the buoy off Sandy Hook at 1l:45 on Monday morning, a strong north westerly wind blowing at the time, and the sea being so rough that it was impossible for the guests on the steamtug to board the Palmer.

The grievance now, as it has been for years, of American shipowners and shipmasters is that we have no apprentice system in our merchant service, and are entirely dependent upon foreign nations for our supply of seamen.
At the Fenian Congress to-day, reports from the Committees on Credentials, Permanent Organization and Rules and Regulations, were received.

Sir MORTON PETO and his party called on the President this morning and were received most cordially. These English gentleman appeared to be somewhat embarrassed in the presence of the President probably more surprised than embarrassed all owing. doubtless, to the extreme democratic surroundings and quiet, unostentatious deportment observable at the White House, so different from the appearance at the European courts with which the visitors are familiar.
The ship-carpenters in the Charlestown Navyyard have sent two delegates to Washington, to investigate the late order reducing their wages, and petition for its withdrawal.

It has often been noticed by American travelers, on returning to this country, that the "machinery of life" does not work easily. The discomforts of existence for 4 the upper classes are far greater here than in Europe.
The General Convention of the Episcopal Church assembled at noon to-day.

Robert T. Liddle vs. Uzal Cory et al. This was a motion for an attachment for an alleged violation of an injunction. An action was brought to recover damages for an infringement of a patent belonging to the plaintiff for an improvement in air-heating furnaces designated as Liddle's Gas Tight Furnaces. A judgment in favor of the plaintiff was taken in it by agreement, and an injunction was issued forbidding further infringement of the patent.

During the first week of October very heavy rains and high winds were experienced almost all over the island. In Cienfuegos there was almost a hurricane; business suspended; no newspaper issued for a week, and the inhabitants shut themselves up in their houses. In Matanzas it rained almost unceasingly for a week, with high winds.

In the list of "English victims to the rebel loan," published by the American papers, one name appears which all Europe will read with amazement. Is it possible that there can be any ground whatever for the allegation that the Right Hon. WILLIAM E. GLADSTONE, Chancellor of the Exchequer, was among the Englishmen who advanced money toward the support of the Confederate rebellion?

The following report of Capt. J.M. MOORE, A.Q.M., who was sent to Andersonville, Georgia, to mark the graves of Union prisoners for future identification, contains valuable information, in which the people are interested, and will, doubtless, be appreciated by the relatives and friends of those who have given their lives to their country:
The Wirz Military Commission reassembled today.

The European mail, yesterday, brought various denials on the part of gentlemen whose names were appended to the subscription for the Confederate cotton loan. The telegraph had previously intimated the fact of these denials having been made. Mr.BERESFORD HOPE, of the Saturday Review, puts his protest in very explicit terms. He says he never held a farthing of the loan.

The members of the Board of Corporators of the National Military and Naval Asylum for the relief of the totally disabled officers and men of the Volunteer forces of the United States met to-day, at the Smithsonian Institute, when it was again found that there was not a quorum, only 23 persons responding to their names, whereas 51 are required to constitute a quorum of the one hundred members.
The schooner Red Jacket, from Savannah, for Boston, has arrived here with two men sick. One man died on board this morning, of fever.
The General Convention of the Episcopal Church reassembled this morning.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second Parepa evening was marred, but not spoilt by the weather. So far as the house was concerned, there was hardly anything to be desired. The seats and boxes were occupied, and a fringe of "standers" filled up the passages. But the particular and vexatious action of the weather was manifested in the case of Mlle. PAREPA, whose cold not being benefited by the humidity of the atmosphere, became unmanageable.

As fitted up for human habitation, the American continent was not adapted to nurse a race of "bog-trotters." Its suns are too bright; its winds are too dry, as they come whistling over the Pacific coast range, the Sierra Nevada, the Wahsatch and the Rocky Mountains, to mingle with those from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic.

Preparations for the execution of the guerrilla, CHAMP FERGUSSON, are being rapidly completed. The execution will be conducted by Gen. SHAFER, commandant of the post of Nashville, at the penitentiary outside the city. FERGUSSON'S wife and daughter were expected here to-day to visit him for the last time.
Max Maretzek vs. Wm. Cauldwell and Horace P. Whitney. This was an action of libel, commenced by the plaintiff against the defendants, and was called yesterday in its regular order on the calendar.
The United States District Court, Judge C.F. FREGG presiding, commenced its session to-day. A large number of indictments for conspiracy and treason were disposed of.

At the second October meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a memorial was read from the Male Principals' Association, infoming the board that the keeping of a record of corporeal punishments would consume time which the principals could more profitably devote to other matters.
The Board of Fire Commissioners met again yesterday. On account of the sickness of Commissioner PINCKNEY, Commissioner ENGS was appointed Chairman pro tem.

Yesterday was one of unusual excitement at the fair. Many supposing it to be the last availed themselves of the opportunity to look at the very many articles of interest and of value. The exhibitors were in a frantic state of expectation, and dogged the footsteps of the managers and committeemen, anxious for an inkling of the results of their deliberations.

The recent presentation, in the Episcopal Convention at Philadelphia, of a communication appealing to Americans for support of a part of the Italian priesthood in their efforts to assimilate their state to that of the Episcopal clergy, is the first recognition we have seen in this country of a most interesting and important fact in the social and intellectual revolution of new Italy.

WHEELAN, a prominent Irish-American journalist, made his appearance, having just returned from a tour in Ireland, during which he was intimately connected with Irish Fenians, and informed himself of their plans. He reports the organization as powerful and under skillful leaders.
The Bank of France, on the 5th inst., raised its rate of discount from three to four per cent.

Unlike many of its Democratic cotemporaries, it did not profess to be for the war, and at the same time oppose all the means for effectually carrying on the war. To the Editor of the Albang Evening Journal: SIR: I have noticed several allusions in your paper to a transaction which occurred at Vicksburgh while I was in command at that place, in which it is alleged that the government was extensively swindled.
A bill permitting negro testimony to be allowed in courts, was passed in the Senate to-day, by a vote of 9 to 10.
COTTON Sales to-day, 20,000 bales, including 10,000 bales to speculators and exporters. The market is buoyant at an advance of d. The advance in the Bank rate was too late to affect the market.
The October elections have resulted highly satisfactorily better, on the whole, than we hoped. The will tend to the encouragement of our friends for the contest next month.

Late English papers have contained elaborate accounts of a new torpedo of American invention, said to possess wonderful destructive properties. Several tests of its efficacy have been made, and with such successful results that the discoverer, instead of being blown up by the Admiralty authorities as an impostor, actually succeeded in blowing up a condemned vessel-of war in that very limited period described somewhat vaguely by Mr. Richard Swiveller as something less than no time."

In the Matter of the Application of Michael B. Cline for a Discharge from Arrest.--This case, which has produced considerable excitement in certain circles, was thoroughly investigated yesterday, and at the conclusion the prisoner was discharged.
The bark Aden, from Hakodadi, Japan, Sept. 15, arrived at Victoria, British Colombia, on the 8th inst.
The trial of George W. Wagner for killing his wife Mary Wagner on the 22d of July, at No. 516 Broome-street, was commenced yesterday.

The most successful exhibition ever given by the American Institute in this city, closed last night after five weeks of unprecedented popularity and success. Of the fourteen hundred articles on exhibition at the fair, but comparatively few were unworthy of the prominence given them, while very many were of signal interest and conspicuous usefulness to the American people. The fair was gracefully inaugurated...

The thirty-sixth annual fair of the American Institute closed on Thursday evening, being a complete success. The list of premiums in the horticultural department was published in yesterday's TIMES; the remainder of the list will not be ready until today. About three hundred medals of gold, silver and bronze, and a large number of diplomas, will be awarded.

Col. Chipman this morning read his argument on the part of the prosecution in the Wirz trial. The Fifth-sixth Regiment New-York Veteran Volunteers, under command of Lieut.-Col. SMITH, arrived in this city yesterday by United States transport Empire City, from Hilton Head. S.C. This Regiment was organized in September, 1861, at Newburgh, Orange County, New-York, by Brigadier-General then Colonel VAN WYCK.

FIRE. The stable of ADOLPH ECKSTEIN, in Vanderbilt, near Park-avenue, was dostroyed by fire on Thursday evening. It was occupied by MICHAEL CONNOLLY. The entire loss is about $200, upon which there is no insurance. The flames extended to the paint-shop of WM. H. KINKAID, in the rear, which way damaged to the extent of $200; no insurance. A dwelling house adjoining the stable, owned by JOSEPH KELLY, was somewhat damaged. Loss about $100; insured.

The Legislature has indorsed the course of Hon. WM. L. SHARKEY by electing him United States Senator, to fill the unexpired term of JEFF. DAVIS, commencing March 4, 1863, by an overwhelming majority 100 to 26 over FULTON ANDERSON. There was no election to fill the unexpired term of ALBERT G. BROWN.

WEDELL PHILLIPS has opened upon President JOHNSON in the same way as his old philippics against President LINCOLN. The cause of his wrath, this time, is that President JOHNSON does not force negro suffrage upon the South. There is no measure to the tirade which this "sin of omission" evokes from this reveller in contumely.
The board met, pursuant to adjourment, in their chamber, No. 16 City Hall.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC. On Monday next Mr. MARETZEK brings out a novelty in the opera of "Crispino e la Comare." There will be no matinee to-day owing to the Philharmonic rehearsal.

It being generally known that rooms had been taken in a prominent hotel, yesterday, for Mr. STEPHENS and his party, quite a gathering of the curious and wonder-loving was in waiting at the hour of the arrival of the party last evening, and the numbers increased up to 10 o'clock, the sight-seekers, hoping to get a good view of Mr. STEPHENS. He was only visible, however, as he passed from the vehicle into the hotel.

We have nothing of local interest. The State, so far as we know, is quiet, nothing having been heard form Gen. OLARTE, at Chiriqui, or his object in taking the State troops there, after his victory over CALANCHA at Santiago.

Gen. TURNER, Commanding the District of Henrico, issued general orders this afternoon permitting the organization of the city government of Richmond, the objectionable officers, Messrs. STURDEVANT, JOHNSON and BIGGER having filed declensions to the Offices to which they were elected.

Quite a sensation has been created in mercantile circles by the absconding of the junior member of an extensive firm on South Broadway, consisting of father and son. The son has for his wife a young woman that he had married in a Western city, who has proved to be of the most gay and volatile disposition.

I have little news at this juncture to communicate, beyond the fast approaching meeting of the Legislature, which is summoned for the 10th inst., "to meet and proceed to business," and there are rumors that our sapient legislators intend increasing taxation. Everything is done in this unfortunate country to in crease the misery and distress of the people, but no one cares to remove her out of the slough of poverty and ruin.

Two MEN SHOT BY BURGLARS. Two Private watchmen, named GEORGE C. HAAS and FRANCIS BUCKMASTER, in the employ of GEORGE V. DE MOTT, at Hudson City, were shot about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, by two unknown burglars, who succeeded in making their escape. It appears that while the watchmen were patroling their beat they met two unknown men carrying a bundle at the corner of Cottage-street and Bergen-avenue.

On the 16th of September last a meeting of sol diers and loyal citizens was held in Fredericksburgh to take preliminary steps toward erecting a monument to perpetuate the memory of the thousands of Union heroes who laid down their lives in this vicinity that the nation might live.

It is to be regretted that full report was not published of the debate in the North Carolina State Convention upon the ordinance declaring null and void the previous ordinance of secession. It would have afforded the most satisfactory evidence to the whole country of the thorough loyalty of the dominant party in the convention, and, as I believe, in the State. I never saw men more in earnest than the speakers representing the majority.
MY DEAR GENERAL: I hasten to send many thanks to you for your more than kind letter of the 14th inst., just received.
One by one the newspapers of virginia, extinguished by the war, are reappearing in the literary firmament, like stars as the clouds pass by.

Yesterday forenoon JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-street, a bar-keeper, was shot at the corner of Cortlandt and Washington streets by EDWARD L. McWILLIAMS, a Detective officer of the Jersey City Police, and almost instantly killed.

EXTENSIVE BURGLARY AT FLUSHING, L.I. A SAFE BLOWN OPEN AND $8,000 STOLEN Some time after 12 o'clock on Friday night, the office of the Flushing Railroad Company was entered by burglars, the safe blown open, and $8,000 abstracted.

THANKSGIVING. This morning the members of both Houses met at St. Luke's Church, to hold special service of... thanksgiving to God for restoration of peace, and the supremacy of the National Government. A large congregation was assembled, and the services were impressive.

The Wirz Military Commission reassembled to-day.

Message No. 24 was received from the House of Bishops stating that they concurred in the action of the House of clerical and lay deputies, with reference to foreign missionary bishops, passed yesterday.
The Merchants' Exchange, of this city, has received the following to-day:

Yesterday forenoon Detective Officer EDWARD L. McWILLIAMS, of Jersey City, shot JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-Street, near the intersection of Cortlandt and Washington streets where he was employed as bar-keeper. Officer McWILLIAMS at once surrendered to Policemen an DALLY, and was taken to the Liberty-street. Police-station, and JOHNSON was removed to the New-York Hospital, where he died.

MOVEMENTS OF THE POLICE. The appointments and transfers by the Police Commissioners, for the week ending yesterday were as follows: APPOINTMENTS Chas, H. Williamson to Third Precinet, Chas. W. Buck to Twenty-first, Patrick Conneil to Eighth.

BRIGHAM and company returned on Friday from their trip southward. Considerable display of flags, banners, processions, etc. are common in the settlements during these tours of exhortation and observation, and I presume the city felt itself rather backward in such recognitional displays, so on Friday the flags and the bands and some of the militia and other citizens were out to meet BRIGHAM and welcome his return to the city.
DEAR SIR: I received a few days since from Gen. THOMAS JORDAN the proof-sheets of an article entitled "Jefferson Davis," which is to appear in the Oct. number of your magazine.

When the Wirz Military Commission reassembled on Saturday, Judge-Advocate CHIPMAN proceeded to read his agruments on charge second, alleging murder in violation of the laws and customs of war, treating the subject under four heads, as follows: First The various cases of death resulting from mutilation by hounds. Second Those resulting from confinement in the stocks and the chain-gang.
Messrs. CLAY and MITCHEL, at sundown yesterday, were transferred to their new quarters in Carroll Hall.

An independent man was defined by CANNING, we believe, to be a man who cannot be depended upon. That seems to be the Democratic notion of President JOHNSON'S independence. Because he forms his own judgments and adopts his own methods, it is imagined that the party which raised him to power cannot rely upon him, and that any day he may rush into the Democratic embrace. It is a most foolish mistake.

Of all the many religious bodies in our midst the Sabbath schools connected with the Methodist Episcopal churches present the most enjoyable features. Hearty, whole-souled singing, familiar, interesting addresses are the normal pastimes of each Sundays's session, and the result is that the benches are always well filled and the scholars never forget the lessons learned.
Two colored regiments arrived here to-day, from the South. Seven hundred and seventy bales of cotton for St. Louis arrived here to-day.

Policeman VAN CLEEF, of the Eighth Ward, apprehended JAMES B. JORDAN, young Georgian, and against him appeared Mr. ROBERT K. GAD, of No. 20 Varick-steet, and Messrs. LEWIS O. HARRISON and EDWARD W. BURDICK, of No. 107 Wooster-street, and complained that the prisoner, who had been their fellow border, had stolen garments of the value of $300. JORDAN was committed for trial on his own confession.

The obsequies in honor of the late Gen. WEIGHT and wife, lost with the steamer Brother Jonathan, and whose bodies were recovered from the ocean, were observed at Calvary Church to-day. The military escorted the remains to the steamer for Sacramento, where they will be finally interred. It is believed that the Legislature will appropriate funds for the erection of a suitable monument.

The secretary announced that the vote in the "Provincial System Canon," taken on Saturday, was as follows: Clerical ayes, 19; nays, 5; divided, 2. Lay ayes, 10; nays, 6; divided, 1.

William H. Mc Vickar vs. Augustus W. Greenleaf et al. A few days ago, the plaintiff commenced a suit by summons, and obtained an order for the examination of E.B. Ketchum, the defaulter. The latter is not technically disabled, and probably will not be for several days, from giving testimony in civil actions.
The Board of Fire Commissioners held their usual afternoon session yesterday. A large number of communications on a variety of matters were received and appropriately referred.
