The semi-official Berlin Journal says that thehonorable and cordial reception given Count BISMARCK by the Emperor NAPOLEON at Biarritz, and the observations of the Emperor upon pending questions, are guarantees for the unaltered continuance of the friendly relations between France and Prussia. It has no doubt that the Emperor NAPOLEON has resolved to continue the disinterested policy he has hitherto pursued relative to the Duchies,

The interesting anniversary exercises of the National Sunday-school Union of the Methodist Epis copal Church, came to a fitting and interesting close last evening by the usual anniversary meeting of the society. The celebration was held in St. Paul's Church, in the Fourth-avenue, and the meeting was attended by a large congregation of those interested in the progress of the Union. Hon. MOSES F. ODELL presided.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. VERDI'S Opera of "II Trovatore" was given here last ovening to a very good house. We have recently spoken of the performance, and need add nothing on the present occasion, except that the favorite morceaux were received with the customary favor.

Arrests for Fenianism continued in Ireland. Among those arrested was a passenger by the steamship Helvetia, which sought to pass Queenstown without putting in to land her passengers. The reason given for this was the bad state of the weather. She was compelled, however, by the authorities to do so, and a strict search was instituted among her passengers.

We learn, by way of Havana, that MAXIMILIAN issued a proclamation on the 2d inst., in which the departuie of JUAREZ from Mexican territory is officially announced. The proclamation also threatens severe measures against parties in arms against the Imperial Government. All who harbor guerrillas, or supply them with money, provisions or information, are to be summarily dealt with. The voyage of MAXIMILIAN to Yucatan, previously announced, will take place during November.
Important diplomatic correspondence between Mr. ADAMS, the American Minister, and Earl RUSSELL, is published in the London Gazette of the 11th inst.

We have to-day a brief abstract of a correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Lord RusSELL, on the subject of the depredations committed upon our commerce the Shenandoah and other Confederate cruisers. We do not perceive that there is anything either novel or startling in this correspondence. And why it should have been given to the British public, through the Official Gazette, at this particular time, is not at all apparent.

The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on the 12th, via Londonderry on the 13th inst., arrived off this point en route to Quebec at 6 o'clock this morning. She was boarded by the news-boat of the Associated Press and the following summary of her news obtained, which is five days later.
We have received later news from Vera Cruz by the arrival of the French steamer La France, which is rather interesting.

DENIO, C.J. The appeals in these three Cases were heard together, and the general question in each is, whether the shares of the stockholders in the banking association created under the acts of Congress which provide for the creation of national banks can be subjected to taxation by State authorities.
The Minister of Police at Warsaw has intimated that the state of siege in Poland will be raised at the opening of the new year.

Gov. HAMILTON, of Texas, has officially made known the statements necessary to be made to accompany a petition to President JOHNSON for pardon. He says that all applications for pardon will require his indorsement.
A meeting of the Atlantic Telegraph Company has authorized an increase of capital by one hundred and sixty thousand shares, of 5 each.

Secretary SEWARD arrived in this city day before yesterday from Auburn, where he had been spending several days. He has been the guest of R. M. BLATCHFORD, Esq., and leaves, with Mr. FREDERICK SEWARD, this morning, at half-past eleven o'clock for Washington. Both these gentlemen have been greatly benefited in health by their excursion.

The following list comprises the names of all the applicants for pardon now on file in the Attorney General's office, which come under any of the exceptions except that known as the "twenty thonsand clause."

A correspondent in Southampton, County of Bruce, sends to a Toronto paper the following: "The body of a woman, well-dressed, has been found on the beach of the Indian Reserve, north of this village, at a point about six miles distant.

Receipts of produce since our last: 9 bbls. Ashes, 21,096 bbls. Flour, 200 bbls. Corn Meal, 21,900 bushels Wheat, 163,658 bushels Corn, 150 bushels Rye, 52,390 bushels Oats, 35,378 bushels Barley, 9,250 bushels Malt, 136 pkgs. Provisions, and 174 bbls. Whisky.

The United States vs. Eleven Cases of Photographic Paper. This was an action brought to forfeit the goods for fraudulent undervaluation. The goods were imported from Berlin in October, 1863, by A. Hurtzell, the claimant in the cause.
The General Convention of the Episcopal Church reassembled to-day.

From every quarter of the State we have intelligence highly favorable to the success of the Union ticket. The canvass is less zealous than usual, but it is still active, resolute and effective. The candidates and the principles of the party alike commend themselves to popular favor.

Last evening, at DELMONICO'S fine establishment in Fourteenth-street, Mr. ROBERT H. BERDELL, President of the Erie Railway Company, gave a sumptuous complimentary entertainment to the English railway gentlemen now in this country, to which pleasant meeting he had invited the representatives of the neighboring New-York and Pennsylvania, and the distant Western roads, so far as they could be found in the city, as well as his colleagues of the Erie Road.

The Austrian (press) law, says the D bats, appears to admit of very mild gradations in the punishments it applies to press offences. The New Free Press, a journal of Vienna, was accused of having excited the citizens to a disobedience of the laws, in inviting the deputies of the country to concert, as to the consequences of the new policy of the Maylath Belcredi ministry.
We have been looking with some interest for the action of the Legislature of the State of Mississippi upon the question of ratifying the Constitutional Amendment prohibiting slavery.

The People on the Relation of Elizabeth Graff vs. The New-York Juvenile Asylum. This case came on for argument yesterday, before Hon. Judge CARDOZO, at Special Term. The facts are exceedingly interesting, and the questions of law involved are considered highly important.

On Saturday afternoon an Italian committee, composed of Prof. ACHILLE MAGNI, HENRY FARDELLA, who formerly distinguished himself as General in the Union army, and Mr. THEODORE MANARA, all residents of New-York, gained an introduction to President JOHNSON, in order to present to his Excellency a petition, sent to Prof. A. MAGNI by the committee in Milan. This gentleman, after introducing his honorable colleagues, explained to the President the object of their interview as follows:

FIRE ON BARREN ISLAND LOSS $10,000. About 4 o'clock, on Monday, the large fish-oil factory on Barren Island, belonging to J.W. SMITH, of Hempstead, and WILLIAM CRYSTAL, of New-York, was fired by an incendiary and entirely consumed.
Last night the several Democratic Senatorial Conventions of this city met to make nominations. The result was as follows:

The Convention of United States Assessors met in the Assembly Chamber this evening, at 7 o'clock. About sixty assessors are in attendance from the States of New-York, Massachusetts, New-Hampshire, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania and Ohio, and additional delegates will arrive tomorrow morning.

ROBBERIES. Between 6 and 7 o'clock on Monday evening the residence of ABRAHAM ROSE, Jr., No. 193 Grand-street, Jersey City, was entered by thieves while the family were at tea, and robbed of a gold watch and chain, diamond ring, gold mounted hair chain, and other articles valued at about $400....
Mr. WEED closes a long and ill-natured letter in the TIMES with a point of startling and dramatic interest. He says that he met Comptroller ROBINSON, who actually offered his hand to him.

Announcements of new publications continue to appear, numerous, in proportion to the late quiet among the trade, as far as the production of novelties was concerned for in the supply of the staple articles of commerce the whole year has been most actively and profitably employed by publishers.

John Guest vs. John Hear. Plaintiff, on Sunday evening, went into defendant's grocery store, corner of Thirtieth-street and Ninth-avenue, for some beer. Defendant's dog, being then unchained, seized the plaintiff by the leg and bit him quite severely. The dog was shown to be vicious and to have once before bitten a man's arm.
The steamer Majestic, from Shreveport, with 650 bales of cotton, was burned yesterday at Point Coup e. The fire commenced in the hold. Nothing was saved, though no lives were lost.

ELEVENTH WARD DIVERSIONS. Learning last evening that a party of Eleventh Ward "sportsmen" had arranged a hostile encounter of canine animals in the cellar of DONAVAN YOUNG'S liquor-store, at No. 75 Willett-street, Capt. ULMAN sent Policeman BERRIMAN thither, in civilian attire, with instructions to take a place in the pit as a spectator, and at the proper moment give a section of policemen in attendance a signal.

A Montreal correspondent of Le Canadien imparts the following paragraph: "The children of JEFFERSON DAVIS have been for some time in Canada, as is well Known. The two boys are just now in Chambly, and about to enter Lennoxville College. The young girl, nine years of age, is a pupil at the convent of the Sacred Heart, Sault-au-Recollets.

This action was brought to recover for the loss of liquors at Whitehall, in this State. The liquors were delivered to the defendants as common carriers at Whitehall, and while there in defendant's possession were stolen, the barrels having been tapped and the liquors taken therefrom.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The new opera of "Crispino e la Comare" was produced here last evening with complete success. The artists who took part in the performance were in excellent voice, and everything except the mise-en-scene was good, The opera has been hastily produced, and very badly put on the stage.
This case was continued yesterday, a great deal of interest being manifested in it, the court-room being crowded to repletion.

The steamers Algonquin and Winooski are still running on their ninety-six-hour test. The engines of both vessels were started at 5 o'clock P.M. Monday. Each vessel received 3,200 pounds of coal to start with, and are continuing to receive 1,600 pounds every hour, which is the given quantity that each vessel is allowed.

In pursuance of the theory conveyed in the old adage that honor should be given to whom honor is due, we are pleased to place on record that to the ingenuity and energy of Col. WILLIAM R. NEVINS is due the fact that from 250 to 3,000 barrels of flour were daily turned into most excellent bread for our soldiers in the field.
The Louisville papers of Saturday give the particulars of the execution of the guerrilla H.C. MAGRUDER. The Democrat says:

Richmond papers of this morning state that the ring which was stolen from the body of Col. DAHLGREEN by cutting off the finger, has been recovered. It was found in the possession of Dr. SAUNDERS, at Loretta, Essex County.
Lieut.-Gov. Wm. Bross, Ill.; Gen. J.A. Logan, Ill.; Hou. J. Ewing, Penn.; and Gen. Lew Wallace, Ind., are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

In South America matters look very gloomy. Chili is in a sad state of perplexity owing to the pres ence of the Spanish fleet and the demands of the Spanish Government, which there is every reason to believe will be resisted by force; for an accession to such demands would doubtless lead to a revolution. Business in Valparaiso is very dull, but there is a good demand for shipping.

The steamship New-York arrived at Aspinwall on the morning of the 10th inst., after a fine run out of seven days and sixteen hours. As the steamer Constitution was a day behind her time from San Francisco the New-York will not get away until late this evening.
The Panama Star and Herald says: "We have received files of the Australasian, Melbourne, to Aug. 11, containing dates from Auckland, New-Zealand, to Aug. 1, and Nelson, New-Zealand, to Aug. 3.

The American Bible Union held its sixteenth annual meeting yesterday morning, in the Broomestreet Baptist Church. A large attendance was present, and the exercises were full of interest. Rev. THOMAS ARMITAGE, D.D., President of the Union, presided. The annual report was read by Rev. CHAS.

Yesterday, by order of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, 31,800 tons Pittston coal were sold at public auction by Messrs. BURDETT, JONES Co., at the salesrooms No. 111 Broadway. The coal is deliverable at Newburgh, the freight thence to this city being 70 cents per ton.

The Union League Club, last evening, received with generous hospitalities and cordial welcome, Sir S. MORTON PETO, and his traveling friends, the English railway capitalists. At an early hour the club rooms were crowded with a gathering of our leading citizens, members of the club and otherwise.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of "Crispino e la Comare" took place last evening. We may safely say of it that it was throughly enjoyed by an audience that did not display any prepared familiarity with the pet pieces, but picked them out with promiscuous discretion and the most perfect of appreciation.

An initial meeting of the new American Christian Commission, designed to succeed and take the place made vacant by the old Commission, which achieved so much good during the war, was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the American and Foreign Missions Society, Bible House.
Schooner Thomas Page, from Roanoke Island, was wrecked on Rum Cay--no date. Crew saved and taken to Hassan.

Gen. BANKS spoke this evening in the Town Hall, Maiden, to an immense audience. Much interest was manifested in what he might say, as it was generally understood he would reply to the attack made upon him last week by WENDELL PHILLIPS in the lecture " The South Victorious."
Information has been received at this place that the propeller C.C. Leary, is in Hatteras Inlet, in a disabled condition.

The bonds are of the denominations $10, $20, $50, $100 and $500, of varied general arrangement, admirable in design, and of elaborate execution. One allegorical vignette of exclusive and fitting character is prominent upon all. The verbal matter in form is as follows:

We surrender a very large portion of our available space this morning to the correspondence between Earl RUSSELL and Mr. ADAMS concerning the responsibility of Great Britain for losses inflicted upon our commerce by privateers, built, equipped and fitted out in British ports and sailing under the rebel flag. The subject is one which affects, in its discussion and result, the question of war and peace between England and the United States.

We hope there will be neither doubt nor delay, in any Southern State, in the ratification of the Constitutional Amendment by which slavery is to be forever prohibited. This can only be done, in accordance with the resolution of Congress, by the State Legislatures, some of which are already in session.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

The Christian public will be interested to know that the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Missionary Association is now in session at Mr. BEECHER'S church in Brooklyn. Yesterday afternoon a very small audience assembled in the lecture room of the church and shivered in unison while the venerable secretaries and committeemen read severally their reports.

On Wenesday evening, agreeably to previous announcement, the President and members of the Union League Club, of this city, held a special festival in honor of the English Railway Capitalists, who have been traveling through the country the past month.
Sixty tons of coal were sent to Hatteras to-day for the propeller C.C. Leary.

The Executive Committee of the Prison Association held their stated monthly meeting at their office, No. 38 Bible House, in Wednesday evening, Prof. THEODORE W. DWIGHT in the chair. This was the first meeting since June, and the reports covered a period of four months.

Advices have been received through JUAREZ'S official journal, from El Passo to the 16th of September, confirming the reports of the fixing the seat of government there; also a letter from one of his staff to a Mexican officer here, saying that JUAREZ is confident that the French will have to leave Mexico and let the people settle their own difficulties.

At 11 A.M. yesterday our reporter visited the Algonquin and Winooski, and found the engines of each vessel working with their usual ease. The Winooski appeared to be gaining on her rival, while the Algonquin seemed to be getting tired. On examining the logs of both vessels, we found the counter of the Winooski to be 59,328; that of the Algonquin, 60,566? making 1,238 revolutions in favor of the latter vessel.
GOV. PERRY'S message was read before the Legislature to-day.

Fifty million dollars of Treasury and compound interest notes, and certificates of indebtedness, have been converted into fivetwenty six per cent, gold-bearing bonds, under the funding proposals of Sept. 29, from...

A Washington dispatch to the Philadelphia Ledger says: "The notice issued by the State Department, some time since, calling for the presentation of claims against foreign governments has been quite freely responded to, and Mr. SEWARD will no doubt give these matters his attention soon after his return.
McVickar vs. Greenleaf et al. Yesterday was the time appointed, by order of the court, for the examination of Ketchum the alleged forger, in the action above entitled.

At the opening of the court this morning, Hon. Daniel S. Dickinson, United States District-Attorney, moved the court that Henry S. Foote, Ex-Senator of the defunct Confederacy, be admitted to the bar as counsellor of the Supreme Court of the United States ,

The steamship Africa, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool at 3:30 o'clock on the afternoon of the 4th, via Queenstown on the l5th inst., arrived here at 7:30 o'clock this morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

Steamships Moro Castle, Adams, Havana, Spofford, Tileston Co.; E.B. Souder, Lockwood. Charleston, Livingston, Fox Co.; Hunter, Rogers, Savannah, L.L. Jones; Fairbanks, Powell, Wilmington, C.H. Pierson.
The commission held their adjourned meeting yesterday morning, to settle upon the location of the central office and the appointment of an executive committee.

The American Bible Union held their second and concluding session yesterday. The principal business transacted was the adoption of committee reports, especially that relating to the issue of the new and revised edition of the New Testament. Sir MORTON PETO visited the meeting and made a short address.

The great match stallion trot between those rival stallion champions of the trotting turf George Wilkes, whilom known as Fillingham, and the new aspirant for trotting honors, Commodore Vanderbilt, came off at the Union Course, Long Island, yesterday.
The piano-forte, which has had almost exclusive favor as a drawing-room instrument, is finding a rival in the cabinet organ, recently introduced, and which is receiving much favor in musical circles.

A meeting of the Committee of the Board of Councilmen on Railroad was held, yesterday morning, in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, Mr. McGRATH in the chair, to take action on a petition of residents of Washington and Greenwich streets in relation to the removal of the railroad tracks in those streets south of Chambers-street.

E COMPANY, THIRTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT. A very pleasant company assembled last evening to do justice to a very elegant entertainment tendered to the members of Company E, Thirty-seventh Regiment, National Guard, by its newly elected Captain, ERNEST DES MARETS, and Lieuts. WHELAN and BRUNTON. The occasion was one of unmarried pleasure and enjoyment.

The most important office to be chosen at the coming election is the State Comptroller. And the present financial condition of the State, and the necessity of watching with incessant vigilance every thing relating to its debt and expenditure, render it more than ever important that the incumbent of the office should be the very best man to be found in the State.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The successful opera, "Crispino o'la Comare", will be repeated here to-night for the third time.

The World is undoubtedly quite right in assuming that "our government has no present intention to interrupt amicable relations with England." It has no intention to do so now, nor at any future time, unless the obstinate and arrogant refusal of the British Government either to redress the wrongs we have suffered at her hands, or to submit the questions in dispute to a fair and just arbitration, should leave us no alternative.

The American Bible Union continued its sessions yesterday, in the Broome-street Baptist Church. The attendance was not so large as on Wednesday. The day's proceedings were, however, enlivened by the visit of Sir S. MORTON PETO, who made a few remarks. The Moderator, Rev. Dr. ARMITAGE, presided.

DISTRESSING ACCIDENT. Coroner LYNCH held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a daughter of Mr. ALEXANDER MATTHEWS, residing in the Town of New Lots, who came to her death in the following manner: Herself and mother arose about 6 o'clock

At an extraordinary meeting of the stockholders of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, held in London on the 12th inst., the resolutions adopted at the meeting in August were rescinded, and it was unanimously resolved to increase the capital to two million sterling, by the creation of one hundred and sixty thousand new shares at 5 each, such shares having a preferential dividend of five per cent.
When I read the beautiful speech of Mr. SEWARD, at Auburn, and the tribute which he paid to his associates in public life, I could not help asking: "Who shall perform the office for him?"
The following rules in relation to making up the calendar, dispensing with the usual notice of trial and note of issue, have been adopted, viz.:

Since May last, by the gun-boat James Adger we have had no arrivals from Central and South America, and nothing of much moment has transpired on the Isthmus. The State is quiet, with the exception of the usual weekly "scares" got up in Panama of reported revolts and invasions, which we have become so accustomed to that we only laugh at them.

Among the distinguished visitors at Police Trials, before Commissioners ACTON, BERGEN and McMURRAY, on Wednesday, were Major-Gen. JOHN C. ROBINSON, commander of the Northwestern Department of New-York, and Capt. JOHN McMURRAY, Chief of the Commissary Department of Northwestern New-York.

The colored people of Missouri, through a State Executive Committee, have issued an address to the people of that State, asking for such laws as will give them the right to vote. They ask it as essential to the security and enjoyment of the rights conferred upon them by emancipation, as true and loyal citizens of the United States, and as men who have defended and maintained the government in the field of battle.
Richmond papers say that the City Council on Wednesday adopted an ordinance repealing at once all existing ordinances relating to negro slaves.

We find the following official decisions of our somewhat notorious Attorney-General in the Rochester Daily American. It will be observed that the facility with which opposite conclusions are reached, from the same premises, is not less remarkable than some other of the feats of this remarkable personage:

A meeting of the Commissioners of Health was held yesterday, at which were present the Mayor, the City Inspector, the Presidents of the Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen, Dr. Sayre, Dr. Swinburne, Dr. Murphy, Dr. Walser, and also, by special invitation, Mayor Cleveland, of Jersey City; Dr. Jones, Health Officer of Brooklyn; and Mr. Cobb, Quarantine Commissioner.

The nineteenth annual meeting of the American Missionary Society was continued yesterday at Plymouth Church Lecture-room, beginning at the early hour of 8 A.M. Prayers were in order until 9 o'clock, by which time quite a pleasant little audience had assembled in the spacious hall, and the regular stated session was opened.

Gentleman of the Senate and House of Representatives: The people of the State of Mississippi, at the recent election, called me to the chief executive office of the State. In obedience to that call I appear before you to-day for the purpose of taking the oath prescribed by the constitution for the incumbent of that office.

James B. Ediman et al. vs. The Brig David Caroline. This was an appeal by the libelants from a decree of the District Court of the Southern District, against them. The facts sufficiently appear in the decision.

MACON, Ga., Sunday, Oct. 15, 1865. I have just returned hither from a visit to some of the large plantations in Southwestern Georgia, the principal cotton and grain-growing district of the State, and was much gratified to find the contentment and prosperity of the negroes, and the kind and trustful relations which subsist between them and their late masters. In very few instances have they left their old homes.
The Masons of the North are about to receive a distinguished committee from the capital of South Carolina.
At the opening of the Court the prisoner George Wagner, was placed at the bar, attended by his counsel.

Hon. Henry J. Raymond, Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: My attention has been called to the following extract from an editorial of the NEW-YORK TIMES, which was republished in the Richmond Whig, of Oct. 10, with a view to operate on the Congressional election then ponding in Virginia:

Earl RUSSELL, in the last of his letters to Mr, ADAMS, takes occasion to congratulate him upon the close of the war, and especially upon the abolition of slavery. Upon this last point he says that the British nation have always looked with the deepest abhorrence upon slavery, and that "the efforts by which the United States Government and Congress have shaken it off, have, therefore, the warmest sympathise of the people of these Kingdoms."

SIR: In the issue of the New-York TIMES of this date, under the head of "Naval Intelligence," I find a letter signed by E.N. DICKERSON, containing statements which are false, both in fact and inference, in regard to his stoppage of the engine of the Algonquin, thereby preventing the completion of the competitive trial of her machinery with that of the Winooski.

The offer of the new loan for the Republic of Mexico is reported in a very favorable state of progress. These having charge of the affair state the receipt of letters from bankers and others, who desire further information on the subject.
These garnished head lines, in large capitals, adorn the World. They display both the poverty of the Democratic party and its taste.
The board held their adjourned meeting yesterday morning. Present a full board. A number of communications were read and referred.
The wills of the following-named persons have been admitted during the week, ending Oct. 28:

The Cotton market is active; sales, to-day, 8,200 bales, at 64c. 66c. for Midding; sales for the last three days, 8,200 bales. The stock on hand is 117,000 bales.

We publish, this morning, a letter from Hon. A.H.H. STUART, member of Congress elect from the Charlotteville District, Virginia, in reply to our article counseling the people of Virginia not to elect representatives who could not swear, according to law, that they had never participated in the rebellion. Mr. STUART denies that he ever participated in the rebellion, inasmuch as he "neither sought nor held any public position during the war."

The London papers apparently assume that the United States will jump at Lord RUSSELL'S proposal of a commission for the settlement of pending differences between the two nations. When they come to consider the circumstances of the case, they will find occasion to modify this rather hasty conclusion.
The story about a collier having inherited the Drummond estate, near Swansea, and 8,000 a year is denied.

A prize suit of considerable interest was tried in the Admiralty Court of tho United States at this place, in September, Judges DAVIS and TREAT presiding. It was a suit for the recovery of 935 bales of cotton captured by a detachment of gunboats from Commodore PORTER'S Red River expedition, and commanded by Capt. FOSTER.
Mr. ANDERSON, of Chatham, introduced a resolution to appoint a committee of five to memorialize the President for the release Of JEFFERSON DAVIS.

With a grand flourish of trumpets the Kings County Democratic Committee announced a grand ratification meeting at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn last night. Maj-Gen. SLOCUM, Maj.-Gen. BLAIR, JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., Hon. S.S. COX, and a host of other notables, were positively advertised to speak, while a New-York morning journal grandly announced that Maj.-Gens. LOGAN and KILPATRICK would likewise address the meeting.

Rarely in the history of politics, here and hereabouts, have the opposing parties permitted the day of election to draw so near, the nominations being yet incomplete, the organizations remaining so undefined, the plan of campaign so entirely unrevealed.
GIDEON JONES YOUNG, an opium-eater, died at Believue Hospital, and Coroner COLLIN was summoned, yesterday, to hold an inquest.

Whereas it has pleased Almighty God, during the year which is new coming to an end, to relieve our beloved country from the fearful scourge of civil war, and to permit us to secure the blessings of peace, unity ard harmony, with a great enlargement of civil liberty; and ...

The philosopher who shall hereafter describe this age will especially entitle it "the age of wealth." Not only has the great increase in the production of gold raised apparent values the world over, and thus made living seemingly more expensive in all countries, but the vastly augmented productiveness of all labor in the most civilized communities has brought about in the last decade an immense increase of wealth.

Commissioner ORTON, the accomplished Chief of the Internal Revenue Bureau at Washington, resigned his position last Wednesday to enter upon the discharge of the duties of President of the United States Telegraph Company, to which position he was recently elected.

The case of Major DE VERE, of the British Royal Engineers, who was deliberately shot by JOHN CURRIE, a sapper under his command, was lately commented on in this paper in an article under the heading of "Military Morality."

At the trial of three noted female shop-lifters and first-class pickpockets, Margaret Scott, alias Mag. Moran, Mary J. Williams, alias Mrs. Allen Taylor, Mary Boice, alias Mrs. Jack Boyce, quite a scene ensued when they were asked to plead to the charge of stealing a piece cf cassimere cloth, the property of Frank W. Richmond. The scene is best described by giving it as it occurred. The clerk asks if they are guilty.

?A letter from Wiesbaden, in the Cologne Gazette, gives some curious details relative to the discussion which has just taken place in the Chamber on the subject of the diplomatic representatives of Nassau abroad.
Joseph B. Van Deusen et al. vs. Joseph Eneas. This was an action on a contract for building a steam propeller.

The mysteries of American finance are becoming gradually clear. It is now confessed, and there is no discredit in the confession, that the authorities of the Federal Treasury were afraid to reveal the whole truth while the war continued, and the issue remained uncertain.

The Georgia State Convention transacted no business of importance in its morning session to-day.

Dates from Honolulu to the 30th of September are received. The Honolulu Advertiser publishes a list of ninetytive whalers, composing the Arctic fleet, nearly all American. Thirty-three of these had been burned or bonded by the Shenandoah, and sixty-two remained to be heard from.
Parties have for several days past been exploring the subterranean passages under this city.

We have been making our final studies of the mining business of the Pacific States here among the mines and mills of the famous Mariposa estate of Col. FREMONT. And the occasion is a proper one to sum up my various notes and observations in California on that subject, and so far as possible represent the state of the business in the whole region west of the Rocky Mountains.

There is now on exhibition at the jewelry-store of Messrs. BROWNE SPAULDING, under the Metropolitan Hotel, a curious medal, formerly the property of the famous Indian Chief RED JACKET, and now belonging to one of his descendants, Col. PARKER, of Gen. GRANT'S staff.

Yesterday being the last day of the October term of the Court of General Sessions, and the time designated for Edward B. Ketchum to withdraw his plea of not guilty and put in one of guilty, he was brought up for that purpose. He was attended by his counsel, Ex-Judge Allen and Mr. Morris Ketchum.
Hon. KENNETH RAYNER, of North Carolina, has publislied a letter of marked interest on the condition and necessities of the Southern States.

Owing to the recent rain-sterm, very few sited the Central Park yesterday, though those who did, found the walke in admirable condition, being firm and pleasant to the feet. The day, during the forenoon and the earlier hours of the afternoon, was charming, there being neither heat nor dust to annoy the visitors, while the modulated warmth of the October sun made it both delightful and agreeable.

It will be recollected that at the municipal election in this city last July certain parties were elected to important posts who were inimical to the military authorities, and were not allowed to qualify.

Gov. JOHNSON, of Georgia, has been officially informed by the Secretary of State that the President cannot recognize the people of any State as having resumed the relations of loyalty to the Union that admits as legal obligations debts created in their name to promote the war of the rebellion.
The Norfolk Post this morning gives the particulars of the disaster to the steamship North Star, in the gale off Hatteras on the night of the 24th inst.

In the Circuit Court, Part II., of this city, during the October term, there were three separate panels of jurors summoned, and out of them about one hundred non-attending jurors have been fined by the court $25 each.

In these days when placards meet the eye at every turn, reminding us that this or that man is the "regular candidate" for some office or other, we have found it interesting to read some statements which we have noticed in the English papers, regarding election expenses, at the late Parliamentary elections.

BEDFORD BROWN, formerly a United States Senator, offers himself as a candidate for Congress in the Fifth District of North Carolina. He declares himself honestly anxious to aid in the work of restoration. In his address he says: "During the entire war, I have no doubt, if the freedom of opinion had not been suppressed, that North Carolina was, at all times, in favor of an honorable settlement of the question.

Yesterday morning another appalling steamboat disaster occurred on the North River, resulting in the death of ten, and the serious scalding and maiming of seventeen persons. The fifty-seventh anniversary of the New-York Bible and Prayer Book Society was held yesterday evening, at Trinity Chapel, in Twenty-sixth-street, near Broadway. This society, as the name indicates, is connected with the Episcopal Church of this State, and is fostered for the extension of the ritual of service of that church.

The Richmond Bulletin makes this statement regarding the lands of which Gen. WISE was so anxious to recover possession: Gen. TERRY decided that he, as military commandant of the department, could not take the lands of Gen. WISE from the Freedmen's Bureau, which had possession of them as "abandoned lands." The Secretary of War confirmed this decision of Gen. TERRY.

FIRES. About 8 o'clock, Saturday evening, Mr. T.R. AGNEW'S grocery, at No. 260 Greenwich-street, was damaged to the extent of about $10,000 by fire, which was kindled by a lighted match carelessly thrown into a lot of waste paper. The building, which may be repaired for $500, is insured for $10,000 by the Star Company.
The steamer Palmetto arrived to-day from Pliver Bay on the 23d of September.

Although the new opera of "Crispino o la Comare" has achieved a very marked and decided success, it will for the present only be repeated once more to-morrow night. It is withdrawn in accordance with Mr. MARETZEK'S well-known and publicly approved policy of giving the greatest amount of variety to his programmes, and also to make room for other revivals and novelties.

The accident which happened yesterday to the splendid North River steamer St. John, and by which ten persons lost their lives and seventeen were injured, is one as inexplicable as it is appalling. The boat was considered, like her consort, the Dean Richmond, not only a magnificent specimen of naval architecture, but a vessel every way thoroughly and perfectly appointed, especially in the matter of her machinery.

SUSPICION OF FOUL PLAY.--ANTOINETTE JUDSON, a young colored woman, left her place and friends in New-Haven, on the 9th ult., by the 10 o'clock train, for New-York, by arrangement to live in the family of a well-known clergyman in this city. Instead of taking the accommodation train, on which she was to meet him at Milford, she by mistake went with the express train, which starts about the same time, and so missed him altogether.

An article in the Nation on the much-vexed subject of "Servants" makes the excellent suggestion of a higher kind of "intelligence office," similar to one recently started in London, which shall be supported solely by the ladies. The present intelligence offices are, for all practical purposes, utterly useless to families.

The sudden removal of the British Premier from human affairs will probably facilitate the peaceful settlement of our difficulties with England. Though not in direct charge of the Foreign Department, beyond all doubt he had a large part in the practical shaping of its policy. That policy never more unmistakably bore his personal impress, even during the long years when he was the Foreign Secretary.

Mr. H. M. CHAFFEE, one of the officers of the Black Eagle, has just forwarded to our navel reporter a letter written by Capt. C. F. HALL on the eve of the departure of that vessel from the Arctic regions. This is the last letter which he wrote, and as it is probably the last that will be received from him till next Fall, it becomes valuable as well as interesting.
The Inman steamer City of Boston, Capt. KENNEDY, which left Liverpool at 10:30 on the morning of the 18th, and Queenstown on the 19th of October, arrived here yesterday morning.

The rites of Christian burial were to-day performed over the ashes of the lamented Col. ULRIC DAHLGREN, at the church of Rev. Dr. SUNDERLAND, on Four-and-a-half-street. Aside from the military honors paid to the memory of the deceased, the outpouring of the people, including the President, Cabinet, and many other distinguished persons, besides hundreds of ladies, notwithstanding the severest storm of the season, attested how deeply the memory of the brave young soldier is regarded.

Arrived, ship Ne Plus Ultra, after a long passage, from New-York. She experienced calms and head winds during the greater part of the voyage. This will account for the delay in making the trip, she was forty-five days off Cape Horn.

The income of the National Treasury from internal revenue, during the month of October, amounted to $30,457,983, making a total of $124,178,403 received from this source in the first four months of the current fiscal year, commencing with July 1, or equal to a yearly aggregate of about three hundred and seventythree million dollars.

At Derby, Conn., last Thursday, WILLIS BLAKE was pouring powder from a twenty Pound keg, which he held under his arm, about half full, into a seam blast, which had been blown out a few minutes previvious, when the powder ignited with a terrible explosion, and Mr. BLAKE gracefully alighted in a pool of water not far distant, which saved him a horrible death from burning, as his clothes were all on fire.

The General Conference of the Mormon community commenced Oct. 6, and concluded on the 9th. The result of the elections of Tuesday adds to the evidences, furnished so abundantly throughout the last five years, of the steady adherence of the people to the principles and policy sanctioned by their deliberate judgment. In 1860 they pronounced their verdict against the political domination and the territorial extension of slavery, by the election of President LINCOLN.

We beg the World not to make itself too unhappy over the result of the State election. President JOHNSON is not deposed, nor is his policy overthrown by that catastrophe. Both, on the contrary, are more firmly established than ever before. If the World will possess its soul in patience a little while, it will be satisfied that this is so.

Col. TAYLOR and Rev. Mr. REED, of the Indian Commission, sent to treat with the tribes of the Northwest, arrived at Fort Randall, Dacotah, on the 5th, on the steamer Calypso. The other members of the commission have gone home overland. The commission have concluded treaties with nine tribes of the Sioux nation, and a treaty stipulating for peace among the Indians themselves as well as with the government.

Nearly all the Colonels of the different city regiments of the State National Guard, visited Inspector-Gen. BATCHELDER yesterday at his office, No. 644 Broadway, agreeably to appointment. FIRE AND ACCIDENT.--About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a fire broke out in the cooper shop of JOSEPH THOMPSON, Sackett-street, near Van Bruntstreet, caused by one of the employes burning some shavings to season a barrel. The flames soon spread through the building, causing damage to the amount of $1,000. Insured in the Hamilton and Phenix Companies for the full amount.

SMITH, of No. 97 Sixth-avenue. Young GIBSON had been stopping with Mr. SMITH, and, while walking in the street, stole money from SMITH'S pocket.

Yesterday morning, as the Alexandria Railroad train was backing on the Pennsylvania-avenue, where the city railway crosses the Alexandria track, it came in contact with a city passenger-car, striking it in the rear, and throwing it entirely off the track. Miss MARION HUTTON, of Philadelphia, who is a clerk in the Treasury Department, and C.J. RIDDLE, the conductor, were seriously injured, and Mr. BAYNE, agent of Adams Express Company, and others, slightly injured.

The Georgia Convention has terminated its labors. I think it would have been better had it never have met. As far as I can see the people of Georgia seem to be loyal and in good spirits, but the convention gave no proof of this. To commence with, the convention was unwieldy--301 members. Alabama had one hundred.

The Tribune reprobates in very emphatic terms the nomination of any Union candidate for Mayor in the approaching election. Whether it may ultimately prove to be wise or not, this advice seems to us decidedly premature.

The recent accident on the New-Jersey Railroad, at Newark, N.J., continued to excite much interest in that city yesterday. The boy, JAMES BRITT, who lost an eye and was otherwise injured about the head, died at 11:48 o'clock yesterday.

Judge SWAN has declared the action of the Legislature, in abolishing the Cotton Court, unconstitutional, Gov. HUMPHREYS vetoed the bill, but the legislature passed it over his veto. The Legislature had adopted a memorial to President JOHNSON, praying him to remove the Federal troops from the State.

About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, two disguised men entered the office of the "What Cheer House," where only one clerk was in charge. They knocked him senseless by a blow on the head, took a key from his pocket, opened the safe and robbed it of twenty thousand dollars in gold. The robbers then escaped unmolested, and no track of them has yet been discovered.

Since the last mail left for New-York there have been no arrivals from the Central American republics. The steamer Guatemala, due here on the 30th of October, met with an accident to her machinery when about 300 miles from here. She will probably be towed down by the Salvador, due here on the 15th inst. We shall then have one month's later news.

The New-York branch of the American Temperance Alliance and Band of Hope, hold its regular half-yearly meeting Saturday afternoon, in the large hall of the Cooper Institute. The meeting was largely attended by the youthful members of the Alliance, the hall being crowded to suffocation by a host of juventles, numbering over three thousand.

The Tammany City Convention held an adjourned meeting yesterday afternoon at Tammany Hall. The result of the session was the nomination of Recorder JOHN. T. HOFFMAN for Mayor, and RICHARD O'GORMAN for Corporation Counsel. Both nominations were made by acclamation, scarcely any opposition being offered. Both gentlemen have accepted the nominations.

Between two and three hundred of the male members of St. George's Church assembled at the chapel, Monday evening, to make arrangements for the future, and to raise funds for a new church. A few ladies were also present.

A meeting in aid of the South was held last night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at which perhaps five hundred persons attended, a number which would have been multiplied many times had the night been pleasant.

A mass meeting of the Tobacco trade of the United States was held yesterday at the Cooper Institute for the purpose of organizing a movement looking toward removing the tax on manufactured tobacco and placing it entirely on the leaf, as it leaves the hands of the grower.

The Citizens' Association have presented the names of JOHN HECKER for Mayor, and RICHARD O'GORMAN for Corporation Counsel. The former is a Republican, the latter a Democrat, but both are heartily in favor of the reform which the Association aims at. Neither desires and concealment of his political views, nor seeks to belittle or apologize for them. We hope Mr. HECKER may be nominated by the Republicans.--Tribune.

By order of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, Mr. JOHN H. DRAPER disposed of 25,000 tons of Scranton coal at auction yesterday. The coal is deliverable at Elizabethport, N.J., the freight thence being 75 cents per ton.

The bill conferring certain civil rights upon freedmen passed the House to-day, with a substitute for the fourth section. Freedmen are allowed to testify and be witnesses when a party to the record, but not in cases exclusively between white men, by a vote of 56 to 30.

The Montreal Gazette says that militia of that city is to be recruited to the full strength of the battalions. The English Workingmen's Benefit Society purpose organizing themselves into two strong companies. It is also purposed to organize an engineer battalion, the nucleus of which will be the two fine companies now commanded by Capts. FORSYTH and KENNEDY, and the other companies of which will be raised from the Grand Trunk workmen.

A WOMAN ROBBED IN THE STREET.--Yesterday afternoon as Mrs. CHARLOTTE BLAKE, residing in Bergen, was passing through the tunnel under the New-Jersey Railroad, at Brunswick-street, Jersey City, she was approached, as is alleged, by a young man named WM. ERWIN, who snatched a pocket-book from her hand and ran into a building near by. Soon after, ERWIN came out into the street again, and was arrested by Officer GREADY.

A dispatch from San Francisco says that the State has suffered excessively during the past week from a severe rain-storm. Communication with the interior, except by water and telegraph, is cut off. The Central Pacific Railroad has suffered severely by the caving in of embankments.

The discharge of Capt. WADDELL and his crew by the British authorities was unconditional, and not restricted by parole as first reported. We should not be too quick in construing this to be an unfriendly act of the new Cabinet.
Gen. Wm. Irving, Albany; Hon. G.W. Tiff, Buffalo; Hon. J.M. Cook, Saratoga; and Gen. Sweeney H. Lee are at the Astor House.

SALE OF GOVERNMENT PROPERTY.--A large quantity of government property was sold at auction yesterday by Messrs. WILMERDINGS MOUNT. The attendance at the sale was large but the prices realized were considered low.

To-day has been fixed on by the authorities and the Commanding-General of the First Division, as the one on which the celebration of Evacuation Day shall take place, although to-morrow is really the anniversary.

Mr. NORMAN WIARD, of this city, has just concluded some very interesting experiments on board of the steamboat St. John, of the People's Line of Steamers. By permission and the request of the owners of the line, he inserted a number of thermomters in the port boiler (the one which exploded) for the purpose of ascertaining the different temperatures in the interior of the same.

Last evening, a meeting was held at the Church of the Puritans, in Union-square, for public discussion on the "responsibility, power and duty of Congress in the matter of justice to the rebel States and our colored citizens." The meeting was very slimly attended, and there were some signs of an adjournment.

The National Intelligencer lends its powerful aid to the promotion of that division in the ranks of the administration party from which its enemies hope so much. It makes the recent speech of Mr. COLFAX the occasion for remarking that "the time has come to throw away disguises" and for demanding that "gentlemen range themselves fairly and squarely under their banners."

The unfortunate man who won the elephant in a raffle, and the astonished French lady, whose affectionate son, fighting in Algeria, sent her the New Year's present of a dromedary, were less embarrassed than England, when a few days ago the Shenandoah steamed into the Mersey, and placed herself under the guardian care of one of Her Majesty's gunboats.

There were no convictions in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, and only two cases were tried. JOHN FOUNTAIN, a colored individual, accused of stealing a quantity of clothing from a lady residing at No. 59 Thompson-street, was acquitted, owing to the failure of proof.

The Crane Court-Martial has closed and the arguments delivered on both sides. The decision has not been made public by the court, though in military circles it is believed that Col. CRANE has fully vindicated his course in every particular.

Aumack, et al. vs. The Steamship Creole.--This libel is filed to recover damages for the sinking of the schooner John Aumack by the steamer Creole, and exceptions are filed upon the ground that the libel does not set forth with sufficient fullness and certainty the facts and circumstances attending the collision.

John T. McMahon, a tall, stalwart Irishman, aged about 20, respectably dressed, appeared to answer the charge of an unprovoked assault on Mr. Joseph Shadock, who is in the employ of the American Watch Company.

The Matamoras Ranchero say that the Liberals are in force eight miles from that city. A skirmish had taken place, resulting in the killing of one Imperialist and the capture of three others by the Liberals.

The Union Convention for the nomination of candidates for the offices of Mayor and Corporation Counsel, to be voted for at the ensuing election, was held last evening at the headquarters corner of Twenty-third-street and Broadway. Aside from the delegates, of which a full representation from each district was present, a numerous concourse assembled, and much interest in the action of the convention was manifested.

The New-York TIMES--just the day before the assembling of the Union Mayoralty Convention--asserts for the first time that Mr. HECKER is no Republican--voted for McCLELLAN and SEYMOUR last Fall, We do not know how he voted last Fall, but he surely was a Free-Soiler and Land Reformer in earlier years, and we presumed was still so. But this--as we said some days since--has no relevancy to the issue now pending.
TWELFTH ALDERMANIC DISTRICT.--The Republican Nominating Convention in this district met last evening and adjourned to this evening.

The parade of the First Division, New-York State National Guard, yesterday, in celebration of Evacuation Day, was a magnificent and imposing display of our city military. Fully ten thousand men were in line, and the appearance of the troops was very creditable to the respective commanders.

The President is required by the constitution to give to Congress "information of the state of the Union, and recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient." This duty has never been so momentous as it will be on the occasion of the opening of the new Congress, now near at hand.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There was another excellent house at the Academy last night, when "La Sonnambula" was given in a truly excellent manner. We have never heard Sig. IRFRE to better advantage than in the part of Elvino, and he fully deserved the great applause after the andante of the duet in the first act. He sang with truly artistic taste, and showed his fine high notes to great advantage.

The Constitutional Convention has, to-day, closed its session and consummated its work in a manner highly creditable to the State, and, I think, satisfactory to the government. The "sober second thought," under the influence of Gov. MARVIN, and the desire to have no further controversy with the General Government, has secured a fundamental law free from all objections, save some of a trivial and unimportant character.

The Raleigh, N. C., Standard, of Wednesday contains the following highly important intelligence: Gov. HOLDEN has received the following telegram from President JOHNSON, which is laid before the public for their information:

President JOHNSON has sent a telegraphic message to Gov. HOLDEN, of North Carolina, under date of Nov. 27, expressive of his great disappointment in the result of the late elections in that State, as tending seriously to retard the work of reconstruction.

The President will decide to-morrow as to the mode of sending his message to the leading newspapers for publication on the day of the reading in Congress. Thus Alabama has passed, a resoluition that the amendment be adopted, "with the understanding that it does not confer upon Congress the power to legislate upon the political status of freedmen in this State."

MISS RUSHTON'S NEW-YORK THEATRE.--This pleasant little establishment opened for the season on Saturday evening. The house was so densely crowded that much personal discomfort prevailed--the rightful owners of seats being deprived of them by hardy invaders, who barely held the policemen in terror.

A collision occurred between two passenger trains on the Stonington Railroad, eight miles from this city, this afternoon. Both locomotives and several cars were disabled. One passenger (a colored man) had his leg crushed. There were no other serious casualties.

The Ohio Legislature assembles to-morrow. GOV. ANDERSON'S message is very lengthy and devoted principally to State affairs. The institutions of the State are represented to be in a flourishing condition. The total receipts of the State from all sources during the fiscal year were $13,190,000 against $8,600,000 in 1864.

A Conflict of authority between the civil and military authorities occurred at Danbridge, past Tennessee, under the following circumstances: A party of soldiers, under order, killed the guerrilla THORN, HILL some months ago. These men, under an not of Congress, were tired, acquitted and discharged by court material.

A large number of Sonators and members have already arrived, and canvasing has been active at the Delevan and Congress Hall for the part twenty-four hours. The candidate or Speaker of the Assembly in the Union Caucus, to-morrow night, will be INMAN TREMAIN, of Albany, and GEO, H. HOPKINN of Wyeming.

The steamer Atlantic, which arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, brings news from Chili of the highest importance. On the 28th of November the Chilian man-of-war Esmeralda captured the Spanish gunboat Covadonga off Papudo, having on board the Spanish Admiral's correspondence. The engagement lasted about half an hour,

THE STRONG DIVORCE CASE.--The people of this city have been compelled to listen to the private history of the STRONG and STEVENS families each day during five long weeks. Through the entire catalogue of entire ran the thread of a case whose immodest generalities were only paralleled by its disgusting details.

Rumors have been in circulation for some days past that one of our city officials had appropriated the funds of the city to his own use, but neither the name of the party or the amount appropriated was made public.

Our thoughts for the New Year are inevitably mingled with our recollections of the Old. It is impossible to attempt a forecast of the future without remembering what we have suffered and achieved in the past.

The insurance on the steamer Commonwealth and her fittings was about $80,000. She was a capacious and staunch boat, built about eleven years ago, at an expense of $200,000, and has been running on the Stonington route four on five years. The depot was not of much value, but the loss by burning of freight in the cars and on board the steamer was very large.

The steamer Golden Age, (query, Golden City ?) sailed for Panama to-day, taking $1,014,901 treasure, of which $800,000 is for New-York. The overland mail, with New-York dates to Dec, 9, has arrived.

Francis George Shaw, Esq., President N. F. R. A., No. 70 John-street, New-York; MY DEAR SIR : I have obtained from, Gen. HOWARD a table, hereto appended, showing the precise number of freed people-men, women and children-depended upon the government for food, and his estimate of the number likely to become dependent during the winter.

THE NEW YEAR. New-York's day promises to be well observed here to-morrow, if the weather permits. Almost since before Christmas we have had nothing but snow, rain and mud. The president will receive from 11 A. M. until 2 P. M. and a large crowed is anticipated at the White House.

Scarcely a month Passes we are called on to announce one or more new ocean steamers added to the lined plying between Europe and America, Boston is about to establish a line direct to Liverpool, Philadelphia is against the subject, and efforts are being made to make Norfolk the terminus of another traneatlantic line.

The board met Saturday afternoon, Mr. JAMES HAYES in the chair. A resolution appointing a Sergeant-at-Arms for the Mayor's office, with a salary of $1,500 a year, was concurred in. Mr. EDWIN M. HAGGERTY offered his resignation as a member of the board, which was accepted.

As Mrs. NETTIE CLINE, residing at No. 375 Bleecker-street, was passing through Fourth-street on Friday afternoon, about dusk, a young mail named HENRY WILSON came up behind the lady, and, as he passed her, snatched form her hand a pocket-book containing $6 20, running off with his booty.

FRANCE AND BELGIUM.-It would seem from the comments in the journals, both European and American, that the impression has been widely prevalent that LOUIS NAPOLEAN would take immediate occasion of the death of King LEOPOLD to seize upon Belgium;

The progressive or liberal Italians propose to improve the financial condition of the nation by suppressing the religious orders and assuming the salaries of the regular clergy. There are 84 of these establishments, of which 80 possess property to the amount of $8,000,000. The monasteries contain 15,494 clerical and 4,466 lay members, who are men, and nearly 26,000 women.

During the past week the firs meeting has taken place in Boston of the "Association for the Promotion of Social Science." Papers have been presented, and addresses delivered, and discussions held on some of the great questions of society--on the treatment of crime, education, the isolation of the insane, sanitary legislation and science, competitive examinations, national resources, and similar subjects.

A PERIL OF THE YEAR.--In congratulating the country at the close of the year over the happy stoppage of the scourge of war which took place in its earlier months, we must not lose sight of the fact that there is danger of our suffering in the present year from the scourge of pestilence,

THE NEW RUMORS ABOUT MEXICO.--These who claim to possess the knowledge that Mr. SEWARD'S voyage will extend as far as Vera Cruz, connect the circumstance with the rumor that the French Emperor has proposed to withdraw his troops from Mexico if the United States Government will agree not to interfere with MAXIMILIAN thereafter.

A fire occurred this morning in MATHEWSON ALLEN'S large block, on Broad, Dorrance, Eddy and Middle streets, occupied chiefly by manufacturing jewelers. The third and fourth stories of the west end were badly burnt, and much damage was done in nearly three stories by water.

From the Washington Chronicle. The TIMES is a splendid property, chiefly owned and entirely controlled by Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, Representative in Congress from one of the New-York City districts, To him it owes its origin, its growth, its circulation, its commanding influence and its present unchallenged superiority. What renders the alternation more hazardous is the fact that there is no increase in price with the increase in size.

Doth boards of the Common Council for 1866 will convene at noon to-day, pursuant to law, and organize by the election of Presidents and clerks, The Mayor will send in his message, and, in view of the fact of its being New-Year's day, both boards will doubtless adjourn without transacting any further business.

The following statistics will be found interesting: The ecclesiastical establishment in Mexico consists of one Archbishop, eight Bishops and about 10,000 clergy of all orders. It is the richest Church established in the world. Its landed, property, mortgages and rents are estimated to be worth about $150,000,000;

The news from the Pacific this morning is of more than ordinary importance. While Franco, England and Spain have been exchanging notes on the question of a peaceable settlement of the difficulties between the lastnamed Power and Chili, events have transpired, almost within sight of Valparaiso, which change the situation from one of passive warfare to active hostilities.

The end of the Strong-Stevens case is as remarkable as its trail. The jury were discharged yesterday morning by Judge GARVIN, after a five weeks' trial and forty-five hours of deliberation. We give a sketch of their transactions from 12 M. on Friday until 9 A. M. on Sunday, at which time they were discharged.

A safe containing $80,000 was stolen last night from the office of Major ELLIS, Paymaster of the army. Two orderlies are missing, and are supposed to be the guilty parties, Of the amount in the safe $28,000 belonged to the government; the remainder was the private property of Major ELLIS.

Rain has been hero all day, but the temperaturo is mild for the season. The colored people assembled on masse this fore. noon at the First African Church, to celebrate their deliverance from slavery. Several addresses were made.

The official trial of the motive, turret, blowing and pumping engines of the light-draught monitor Cohoes took place yesterday at the Continental Iron Works dock, Greenpoint, L. I. Commodore C. RINGGOLD, accompanied by his staft, and Chief-Engineers LONG, ALBERT and PURSE were present to test here steam powers while lying at the dock.

The new bark B. Sewall, of Richmond, Maine was driven ashore on the coast the 26th inst., twelve miles west of Galveston, Capt. F. A. HUSSEY, wife and daughter, reached here safely, after twelve hours' exposure in the boat. The ship was pounding hard when he left. The mate and crew have not been heard from, but are probably safe.

A very destructive fire broke out here at I o'clock this morning in Chesnut-street. The building No. 607 Chesnut-street, occupied by Harden's Express Company, Nos. 603 and 605 by ROCKHILL WILSON, wholesale clothiers, and No. 603 by PERRY Co., clothiers, were almost entirely destroyed.

THE SNOW IN THE STREETS.--Is it true that there is an ordinance requiring occupiers of houses to sweep their sidewalks after a fall of snow? For the last three days the condition of the streets in this respect has been simply disgraceful, and if a sudden frost should convert the vile slush into ice, walking will bo positively dangerous. Will not some official.

THE STATE LEGISLATURE.--There is good opportunity, and we are glad to say there are good hopes for the State Legislature which just assembled. It can signalize the session in such a way as to command the highest possible respect.

A goodly number of colored people held a jubilee meeting last evening at the Cooper Institute, to celebrate the anniversary of the issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation. Mr. GARNET, of Washington, an eloquent colored clergyman, delivered an eloquent address on "The Freedmen of the South,"

Consul TRURSTON to-day received instractions that the Government of the United States will not permit any more cottle to enter the States from Canada. This prohibition creates intense feeling not only among Canadians shout out from American markets, but among United States traders.

A MAN SHOT BY A POLICEMAN.--About an hour after dusk, on Sunday evening, Sergeant WILSON, Roundsman TOWNE and Officer MULLEN, of the Fourth Precinct, were passing through Chathamsquare, when their attention was attracted by an altercation between several men in respect to a horse.

The Governor's Message to the State Legislature includes, and perhaps necessarily, a brief historical review of the national situation, in addition to the usual summing up of the State record for the year. In this respect it ought to have much more than the value of a document merely devoted to local interests.

NEW YEAR'S DAY.--We had to indulge in some remarks the other day upon the state of things in Petersburg on Christmas, as represented in the papers of that place. The population generally, it seemed, got drunk upon that festive day.

NEW-YEAR'S DAY RECEPTIONS. Notwithstanding the disagreeable condition of the weather from the recent snow and rain, the first New-Year's reception of President JOHNSON was largely attended. The doors of the Executive Mansion were at 11 o'clock this morning opened to the Foreign Minister and their attaches, some of them displaying their glittering badges of distinction.

In the Union Senatorial Caucus, JAMES TERWILLIGER was nominated for Clerk, Capt. ARTHUR HOTCHERS for Sergeant-at-Arms, SANDERS WILSON for Postmaster, and H. B. YOUNG for Doorkeeper; FRANK M. JONES, NATHANIEL SAXTON and AUGUST WAGNER, Assistant Doorkeepers. The Chairman, Senator FOLGER, appointed as a Canuus Committee Messrs. Low, CORNELL and LENT. The caucus then adjourned.

The celebration by the Negroes to-day passed off with perfect order and propriefy. Large delegations were present from the surrounding country. All the civil officers in the State appointed by the Provisional Governor, including the magistrates, mayors and conmissioners of towns, judges and all others, comprising the whole machinery of the government, have ceased to exercise any authority, their terms of office having come to an end by the Provisional Governor vacating his office.

The Eighty-ninth session of the New-York Legislature begun yesterday. In the Senate, Lieut. Gov. ALVORD presided, and delivered an appropriate address. All but one of the Senators were present. Mr. TERWILLIGER was reappointed Clerk, and immediately read the Governor's Message.

The Congress reassembled yesterday morning at Clinton Hall, about five hundred members being present. The session was strictly private, but it was ascertained that Mr. PATRICK CORBETT, of Syracuse, was unanimously elected Speaker.

CAPTURE OF BURGLARS. --About 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning, Office HALLET, of the Forty-seventh Precinct, captured a burglar while in the act of leaving the carpenter-ship of Mr. DOUGHTY, corner of Fourth-street and Norman-avenue, Greenpoint. Several implements generally used by the fraternity were found in his possession.

WINTER GARDEN.--Mr. EDWIN BOOTH made his reappearance here last night in the character of Hamlet. He received the applause which he had a right to expect from a genial, honest and appreciative audience. When the second scene of the first act opened, and Mr. BOOTH was discovered, the applause extended from the parquette to the dome.

The Legislature of This State has at last adjourned, after having agent several weeks in what may very properly be considered a useless expenditure of time, money and talent. With the exception of some few unimportant acts, its has done nothing which is likely to stand the test of the scathing revision which Congress will give its proceedings.

Friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend. The remains will be taken to Auburn. N. Y., for burial.

Mr. ANDREWS gave notice of a bill to create the Metropolitan Sanitary District and Board of Health. Mr. EZRA CORNELL introduced at bill which amends the banking law of 1899, by declaring that the franchies or privilege of banking under said act shall be deemed personal property, and be liable to taxation to an amount not exceeding the capital stock.

Arrived steamship Star of the Union, from New-York. The President of the Southern Pacific Railway has issued a notice requiring all applications for recognition of stock to be made in March, except those from Texas, which must be sent in by the 1st of April, on be forever debarred from doing so.

Gen. PALMER addressed four thousand colored people in the open air yesterday. He congratulated the audience that slavery was ended forever in the United States, and that the colored people, having ceased to be slaves, had no longer any interests which separated them from the mass of the American people.

A PERPETUAL HORROR. If any visitor from the country who, in his desire to see the elephant, would experience a few sensations of the horrible we advise a visit to a few of those popular man-traps called ferry-bridges. The spectacle exhibited all day long at these places is simply terrific, but especially so at these periods of the day when the crowds going to our returning from business create most pressure.

BARD on Tuesday, and while in the house the visitor was invited by a lady living up stairs to go to her rooms, which he did, accompanied by Mrs. RHODES, who left upon the mantelpiece of her front parlor a gold watch, valued at $80, and a pocketbook containing $10, looking her door as they left the room,

Between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday morning, the boiler of the steamer Neptune, then lying off the spit buoy at Sandy Hook, exploded, and by the explosion two persons are supposed to have been killed instantaneously or drowned, Five of the employes of the boat were severely but, happily, not mortally scalded. The boat filled and sauk immediately after the explosion.

The Massachusetts Legislature met to-day, The House elected Mr. JAMES A. STONE, of Charlestown, Speaker, giving him 123 votes, against 117 for Mr. HARVEY JEWELL, of Boston. The Senate chose Mr. JOSEPH A. POND President, by an unanimous vote. GOV. BULLOOK will not, probably, deliver his message till Saturday.

The Britannia, which arrived here yesterday morning, sailed from Glasgow Dec. 19, with 20 cabin and 212 steerage passengers, and had throughout the passage very heavy westerly gates. On the 22d, white have to under close reeled main mizzen top-sails during a terrific gale, with immenses, shipped large quantities of water, stove two boats and lost two others, had wheel-house stove in, and received other slight damages.

Advices by Santa Fc by coach say that intensely cold weather prevails on the plains. The snow-bound trains had lost nearly all their animals. Several teamsters were severely frozen, some fatally. Eleven men were pleked up along the route in a helpless condition, and taken to Fort Dodge for treatment.

A destructive fire, and the largest which ever occurred in this village, broke out in the four-story building on Gelty Square, in the centre of the business portion of the village, owned by Hon. Wm. RADFORD, about 1 o'clock this morning, which, in a few hours, was entirely destroyed.

The impression has been so widely prevalent in the Southern States for the last three months, that there would be extensive insurrectionary manifestations among the blacks during the holiday season at the close of the year, that the passing away of the holidays without any disturbance of the peace anywhere, will tend to reassure the white population as to the future.

The Daily Champion to-day publishes an accurate statement of the amount of freight shipped from here across the Plains for the past year. Twenty-seven firms and individual freighters are engaged in this trade.

Efforts are to be made by the Quartermaster's Department to raise the gunboat Smith Briggs, such by the rebels nearly two years ago, during an attach on Smithville. If the messages which proceed annually from the Mayors of our city serve no other purpose, they do those of reminding us of how well the art of "how not to do it" is understood and carried out in our midst, and of a perpetual accusation of incompetence, blundering and neglect on the part of many officials.

PRIZE-MONEY.-Wo are glad to see that our gallant tars are at last getting some considerable share of the prize-money due to their captures during the war. Nine millions of dollars have already boon paid out in sums ranging from a quarter of a dollar to nearly one hundred thousand dollars.

At last "your own" has reached again the shooting grounds where so many fanciful correspondents are supposed to shoot the beautiful, fat canards expedited hence to the New-York market, to be greedily devoured and digested by an eager public.

The statistics of crime exhibited by this Report, published in another part of this paper, are not calculated to make a nervous man feel comfortable. He is admonished that as bad as the matter was in 1864, it was last year even worse. In the city of New-York there were 68, 873 arrests for offences last year.

PHILLIPS AGAIN FURIOUS,--WENDELL PHILLIPS still continues, and probably will forever continue, in ill humor with the President and with the everything done by the "powers that be." In his speech in Boston on New-Year's Day, he exclaimed that "President JOHNSON, in attempting to lecture colored citizens, had reached the height of impudence."

TO THE GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK : The Board of Metropolitan Police, in accordance with the 39th section of chapter 403 of the laws of 1864, respectfully transmit their Annual Report for the year 1865, "upon the condition of the Metropolitan Police."

The sudden disappearance of Mr. HUBBELL, the Cashier of the Mississquoi Bank, Sheldon, VT., at last accounted for. He turns out to be a defaulter in a large sun. The amount is stated as high as $75,000. He embezzlements began yours ago, but have been so covered by false entries and false footings, as to clude observation until yesterday.

Further news has been received from San Domingo, reporting another revolution there under very peculiar circumstances. The last news was that CADRAL, had peacefully succeeded to PIMENTAL. On the 10th of October, a party of insurgents entered Azua and proclaimed BAEZ as the President.

Both House adjourned till Tuesday next, and most of the members have gone home. Nothing of special public interest has transpired at the State capital. RIGHT HOURS A DAY'S WORK.
