The steamship Hermann, from Southampton Dec. 20, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing three days' later advices. The English Press continues to comment favorably on the President's message, the general tone of which was much more pacific than had been expected. Secretary McGULLOCH'S report made a very favorable impression.

GOV. ANDREW to-day delivered a lengthy valedictory address to the two branches of the Legislature, in which he ventures the opinion that the Government of the United States ought to require the people of those States late in rebellion to reform their constitutions by First--Guaranteeing to the people of color, now the wards of the nation, their civil rights, as men and women, on an equality with the white population, by amendments irrespealable in terms;

THE MURDER ON THE SCHOONER "JOHN BOYNTON."--Coroner LYNCH commenced an inquest yesterday, upon the body of ROBERT MITCHELL, mate of the schooner John Roynton, who was killed by a river thief off Riker's Island, on the night of the 30th of December, 1865. The Captain, NATHAN A. REED, JOSEPH MALONEY, a sailor, and Dr. ANDREW J. WILLETTS, were examined.

Advices from Fort Yuma, Arizona, state that large numbers of Mexican refugees were assembling in that territory preparatory to marching into Sonora. Reinforced by the Cowpax Indians, nearly 200 Apaches had entered the Mexican town of Somerita and plundered the merchants in a most merciless manner.

The Richmond Enquirer commenting upon an article condemnatory of the stay laws, which appeared in our columns some days since, says: "But we misapprehended the effect of these laws upon foreign creditors, and overlooked the fact that the Federal courts are open for the recovery of debts due the North, notwithstanding the passage of stay laws."

MEXICO--OFFICIAL CORRESPONDENCE. There has just been issued from the Public Printing Bureau, the Message of the President here before transmitted to the Senate in response to a resolution asking for information on the subject of a decrec of the so called Emperor of Mexico, of the 9d of October last.

Gov. CONY was inauguarted to-day and delivered his message to the Legislature. Referring to the military history of the State during the rebellion, he says that Maine furnished 71,558 men, being more than one-tenth of her population. Five regiments and one battalion of infantry still remain in the service.

The Congress reassembled in secret session yesterday morning, Mr. CORBETT, of Syracuse, presiding. It was noticeable that the doorkeepers were not in uniform, though as strict as ever in preventing those who had not passes from entering.

BAPSFORD.--At Fordham, on Tuesday, Jan. 2, of consumption, WILLIAM B. BASSFORD, in the 53d year of his age. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Friday, the 6th inst., from the residence of Mr. Thomas Bassford, at Fordham, at 11 1/2 o'clock A. M. The remains will be taken to Greenwood, Carriages will be in waiting at the 26th-st. depot H. R. R. at 1 1/2 P. M.

One of the most remarkable incidents of the late war was the influence exerted on European opinion by such men as BRIGHT, STUART MILL, and Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH, of England, and MONTALEMBERT and HENRY MOREAU, of France. In unofficial positions, with no weapon but the truth, these men were a power paramount to that of all others.

Mr. LABAU introduced a bill amending the Metropolitan Police Act, which practically embraces Richmond County within the Metropolitan Police District, and provides for a force of twenty-five policemen and two Sergeants of Police in said county. Mr. ANDREWS introduced a bill to create a Metropolitan Sanitary District and Board of Health, which is substantially the New-York Health Bill of last year.

As I Write a letter for the supplemental mail, I see gaily Seating in the harbor the grand old banner, the "Stars and Stripes." It is a feast to the eyes, especially when I remember that it floats over the fineal passenger steamer that was ever in these waters, La Porleha, from New-York, built for this river.

The Steamship Hermann, from Southampton on Dec. 20, arrived here yesterday morning with three days later from Europe. The Louisiana, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool Dec. 17. The City of Baltimore, from New-York, arrived at Queenstown Dec. 18.

THE FAR WEST.--The great growth of the overland trade with our far Western territories is well shown by a telegraphic statement from the Kansas town of Atchison, the place from which the greater part of the goods is transported to the mining regions of the Rocky Mountains.

The newspapers of Louisiana are filled with advertisements of plantations for sale, mostly by the Sheriff. Christmas Day passed off quietly and pleasantly in the interior. Immigration of Swiss and Germana in expected in Mississippi from Ohio.

Soon after 12 o'clock last night, the steamship Fairfax, of the Atlantic Steamship Line, lying at G-street wharf, was discovered to be on fire in the vicinity of the boiler, and efforts were at once made to suppress the flames. This was, however, unsuccessful, as shortly after 1 o'clock the bow and stern were enveloped with fire.

FATAL ACCIDENTS ON CITY RAILROAD CARS.--Coroner GOVER held an Inquest yesterday, at the Ninth President Station-house, on the body of THOS, KENNEDY, aged 6 years, who was run over and instantly killed by car No. 12 of the Bleecker-street line, on Wednesday night, at the corner of Jane and Hudson streets.

THE GENERAL BURST.--The following is a partial list of the steam-boiler explosions for the last week or two. To make the list complete we should probably exhaust more space than we have at our disposal.

DOGS.--The Wool-Growers' Association of the State of Ohio, at its recent convention, determined to urge upon the government that a tax be levied on dogs sufficient either to raise a considerable revenue for the government, or materially diminish the number of dogs, of both.

THE REASSEMBLING OF CONGRESS. Both Houses of Congress assembled to-day at the usual hour, and notwithstanding a call of the roll would have shown that there was not a quorum present, yet opportunity was given for the presentation of such resolutions and bills as might be presented.

The Nashville Times of the 20th says: It is remarkable that Mississppi should manifest so malignant and unrelenting a hostility to the negroes. Of all the Southern States she has most cause to be grateful to that people for their humanity, forbearance and subordination, for they had always been harshly treated, and when the whites enlisted in the rebel army, they were largely in the majority.

SELF ASSERTION--There are two New-England Senators who have propounded, since the 4th of December last, measures sufficient to keep the wisest assembly the world has over known in deliberation for at least a hundred years, with just as much chance of a solution at the end of the century as at the beginning.
CRIMINAIS BUT NOT GUERRILLAS.--We notice in the Missouri papers accounts of various local criminal outrages, which are designated as guerrilla atrocities. We hope not to hear this world used more;

There is no especial excitement to chronicle in our city of a public character. Times are dull business is dull, and people generally are waiting for something to "turn up." The event of the week in financial circles has been the failure and assignment of W. H. CROSBY, of Opera House fame. His liabilities are large, supposed to be nearly half a million.

A Nashville letter says: "For some weeks past there has been a marked diminution in the amount of crime committed in this city and vicinity. This is owing, doubtless, to the more efficient police system which has been organized, and the determination to visit the heaviest penalties of the law upon offenders. Numbers of the ruffians have gone to try their fortunes in other fields.

FELIX DELGADO, Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Territory of New-Mexico, reports that the Indian affairs in that Territory are not improving. All the Apaches on the reservation have left, and troops are now in pursuit of them.

EVERY SATURDAY.--If Messrs. TICKNOR FIELDS will only start a daily paper in Boston, or bay but one of these already established, their literary conquests will be complete. Not satisfied with publishing a quarterly and two monthlies they have just commenced the issue of a weekly, Every Saturday by by name. It differs from their other periodicals in being entirely made up of selections from the foreign periodicals.

EDITORIAL CHANGE, --Col. W. HOLLOWAY has retired from the Indianapolis Journal, which be has done so much to build up and establish in a prominent position among the able journals of the West. Though young, he has proved himself a journalist of great tact and ability, as he is a man of remarkable energy and force.

Mails for Europe, via Southampton and Hamburg, Saxonia, will close to-day, at 10 A. M.: via Queenstown, per steamer City of Washington, at the same hour. Mails for Cuba, per steamer Liberty, close to-day at 2 P. M.

The Times' Brownsville correspondent, under date of Dec. 80, has the following: "Gen. r. CLAY CRAWFORD has arrived at Browleville, with an appointment as General in the Mexican Republican army, and authority to recruitan American division for the Republican services under his command. Gen. CRAWPORD has established a recruiting office in Brownsville and at other places in Texas, and enlistments were already progressing rapidly.

The annual ball and military reunion of the Seventy-first Regiment, National Guard, (American Guard,) was hold at the Academy of Music last night. The occasion was rendered a brilliant one by the attendance of many of the shining lights of the First Division, beside several whose names were carved at the point of the sword during the war.

Gov. WELLS, of Louisiana, has voted two bills passed by the Legislature. One of these was to pay T. BERMUDEZ, formerly Judge of the Second District Court of New-Orleans $1,041 65 for services rendered from April 1, to June 14, 1862.

But few houses have been built in New-England during the past four years of war and high prices, and the result now is a general scarcity, which has become so pressing that the procurement of a decent domicile by the homeless is almost an impossibility.

THE MONROE DOCTRINE.--Extensive preparations have been made for a mass meeting to take place at the Cooper Institute this evening. Prominent statesmen will be present to give their views upon the matter of Republicanism is Monarchy on the American Continent, and there will be, without doubt, such a popular gathering as only New-York City when thoroughly in earnest, can display.

LEVY.

In the Senate yesterday Mr. SUMNER offered a number of petitions from colored people asking security for civil rights, the right of suffrage, Pettions were presented opposing the renewal of the Reciprocity Treaty. Two Bostonians petitioned for indemnity for a ship destroyed by the Alabama.

MINING IN NEVADA--THE SILVER HILL MILL--This neat little mill, which is owned by the Silver Hill Mining Company of New-York, is situated in the Fourth Ward, of Austin. The mill has been erected under the management of Mr. CHANDLER, Superintendent of the Company.

An exchange of pistol shots took place to-day in the hall of the Capitol between HENRY RIVES POLLARD, of the Examiner, and NAT. TYLER and WILLIAM P. COLEMAN, of the Enquirer. Six shots were fired Without damage, except knocking off half a tassel on the case of the marble statue of WASHINGTON.

THE CITY CARS AT NIGHT.--We must believe that the Superintendents of several of the city railroads are entirely ignorant of the extent to which the privilege of riding in the cars is extended--at night particularly--to persons in a beastly state of intoxication.

The progress of the work on the American-Russian Telegraph is most satisfactory. The reports of the Superintendent and his party, who have just returned from the summer's work, are very favorable. The route has nearly all been determined. A number of doubtful geographical questions of much importance to the location have been solved.

This distinguished Presbyterian elergyman, who died at Winchester, Va., a few days ago, was born near Martinsburgh, in 1814. His first sermon was preached in Dr. CHALMERS' chapel in Edinburgh.

THE PROPER DIAMETER OF CRINOLINE.--The question of the proper diameter of a lady's skirt has recently received an authoritative decision--not a decision by the laws of taste, nor in a court of fashion, by which these matters have been usually determined, but a regular judicial determination in a court of law in England.

It was mentioned in yesterday's Democrat that Miss HEATON, a beautiful young lady, had committed suicide by taking poison. Since thus Coroner O'RELLY has held an inquest on the lady, and it was ascertained that the poison was taken for the purpose of producing an abortion, and not with the intention of committing suicide.

The Chicago butter merchants have been vitimized to the amount of over sixteen thousand dollars by one of their number, J. E. BURNHAM by name. Mr. CHARLES BARRETT, who is well known in the trade, a few days since intrusted BURNHAM with the sum of $6,000, with which he was to purchase butter, and render an account of the expenditure of the funds.

The steamship Moravian arrived at Portland yesterday morning with two days late news from Europe. Her mails reached this city at a late hour last night. The political news is not very important. American Securities had experienced a decided advance, in consequence of increased confidence inspired by the President's Message.

A woman named MARY WATTS was found with her throat out on the floor of her residence, in Germantown, at 7 o'clock this morning. The murder is supposed to have been committed by burglars, as the house was stripped of much valuable property.

GENERAL ORDERS NO. 40.--Armed resistance to the authority at the United unions having been put down the President, on the 20th day of May last, issued his Proclamation of Amnesty, that armed resistance having ceased in all quarters, he invited these lately in rebellion to reconstruct and restore ?? authority, thus proclaiming the ?? of our government toward all, no matter how criminal or how deserving of punishment.

GERARD HALLOCK. GERARD HALLOCK, the voleran editor of the Journal of Commerce, formerly one of our most respected and enterprising Journalists, died at New-Haven, Conn., on Thursday last. One of the kindest-hearted men, generous to a fault, fond of doing good, Mr. HALLOCK was ever the suggester and promoter of benevolence. His long life was devoted to enterprise in the right direction,

The Akron (Ohio) papers announce the death by accident, of JAMES BROWN, a notorious counterfeiter, who resided in that portion of the State for a number of years. The accident occurred at Peninsular. While pushing a coal-boat into a lock, Brown lost his balance, fell from the "running board," by which he broke his arm, fractured his skull, and sustained internal injuries which terminated in death on the following day.

THE COMMITTEE ON RECONSTRUCTION. The Joint Committee on Reconstruction held their first meeting yesterday morning, in one of the Senate committee rooms, and organized by the election of Senator FESSENDEN, who is Chairman of the Senate branch of the committee; as Chairman of deliberations of the Joint Committee.

The steamship Zodiac, which arrived at this port last evening from Savannah, brought on at portion of the crew of the steamship Indian River, which went ashore at the mouth of the Indian River. No lives lost. The crew comprised a colony of 60 odd men, in charge of Mr. THOMAS D. CAULDVIELD. They went out for the purpose of settling at that point, and putting up fish, turtles, , for Northern markets.

The press of France has received the Message of President JOHNSON in quite as friendly a way as it was received by the press of England; and the President's treatment of the Franco-Mexican question is discussed in as conciliatory a spirit in Paris as his treatment of the Anglo-American question was discussed in England.

The Wilmington (N. C.) Journal of the 16th announces the death of JAMES FULTON, Esq., its senior editor. It says: Mr. FULTON was known by nearly every person in this city and throughout the State, and none knew him but to respect, esteem and love him.

If any tax-earning and taxpaying citizen, who has thoroughly imbibed that document, does not dream fitfully of Sodom and Gomorrah, and involuntarily look for a summons to serve on a vigilance committee, he must be of most unimpressible composition.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I wish to suggest an important improvement, the adoption of which cannot fail to be attended with beneficial results to our whole people. It is the issue of what may be styled a "dimo currency," in place of the so-called fractional currency now in use.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I wish to make a few remarks on an article on this subject in the TIMES of last week. As it is convenient, in order to judge on one's views on this subject, that his general views should be known, I promise that I am in favor of free trade, and would abolish the tariff immediately; nd, in general, I think indirect taxes impolitic.

Having an hour to spare, the other day, we turned over the brief minutes of the Common Council for some of the closing sessions of 1865. Much to our surprise we found that a grand new boulevard has been ordered to be made from the corner of Ann-street and Broadway to Fulton Ferry.

The managers of the telegraph are evidently anxious to prepare the public mind for something stupendous in the matter of reciprocity. Dispatch follows dispatch, bidding 'the busy world of Washington to prepare for the advent of notable diplomatists.

PAREPA, Mr. J. LEVY and Herr Rosa to be heard once more in that establishment. These excellent artists have just come back from a highly successful trin in the West and the East.

The late freshets having swept away the bridges at Resaca, at Etowah, and over the Chattahoochee, travel over the road between Chattanooga and Atlanta is much interrupted. Probably sixty days will elapse before all the bridges are up again.

THE COLORED TROOPS--INTERESTING STATISTICS.--The report of A. A. General W. W. FOSTER, chief of the bureau for colored troops, shows that during the war 186,057 negroes were placed in the army. Of this number 68,178 were lost from various causes.

Never in his most vigorous health did Dr. CUMMINGS appear more beautiful and attractive physically than now, as he lies in the perfect tranquillity of death, robed in the graceful vestments of his office, mourned by thousands of his weeping flock, and guarded by the watchful eyes of his dearest professional and social friends.

Cotton is dull and declining; sales, 2,500 bales; 49c.@50c. for Middling. Gold, 142 1/2. Sterling Exchange, 52 1/2. The Picayune learns from a gentleman lately from the interior of the State that the freedmen positively refuse to make new contracts, go to work or leave the plantations.

The temperature yesterday was something quite unusual for this city. Soon after midnight on Saturday the cold rapidly increased, and kept on increasing until a late hour last evening. We usually consider anywhere from 25 to 15 degrees above zero to be right smart Winter weather, but yesterday the mercury ran down as far as ten degrees below zero;

RAPHAEL ??, late commander of the Alabama, arrived here in the 10:20 New-York train last night, in charge of Lieut, LYMAN P. FRENCH and Sergis. CASSIDY and JONES, United States Marines, and was at one taken to file Navy-Yard, where he was placed temporarily in a room hastily fitted up in the dispensary building, over which a guard was placed.

CONWAY.--On Sunday, Jan. 7, JOHN CONWAY, aged 47 years. His friends and the friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral, from his late residence. No. 861 2d-av., corner 51st-st., on Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock His remains will be taken to St. Bridget's Church, corner 8th-st. and Avenue B, where a requiem mass will be offered up for the repose of his soul, and from thence to Calvary Cemetery for interment.

ABOUT THE SOUTH.-Some of the Southern papers seem to be offended that the Northern press has so much to say about everything in the Southern States. Not only the governmental relations of the Southern States, and its phases of political thought, are perpetually discussed, but its local questions of social economy, its labor difficulties, its legislation, and everything that is done or left undone, said or unsaid, felt or left unfelt.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--THE BATEMAN CONCERTS,--Notwithstanding the severity of the temperature last evening there was a fashionable attendance at the second of the Bateman concerts; sufficient every way to demonstrate that had the weather been only moderately good the Academy would again have been taxed to its utmost capacity.

The semi-centennial anniversary of the battle of New-Orleans was celebrated last evening at Tammany Hall with something more than regal splendor.. Never since the Autumn of Tammany began was there such a mighty gathering of the Sachems and their devoted followers; and the day is in the dim and distant past when Tammany could boast-as she could last night--having within her walls not one, but many, dear to their country and illustious for all time.

THE MISSISQUOI (VT.) BANK--HEAVY DEFALCATIONS OF THE MISSING CASHIER--SUSPENSION OF THE BANK.--A report that the disappearance of Mr. HUBBELL had been explained by the discovery of a heavy deficiency in the funds of the bank of which he was cashier, reached us on Wednesday last; but in view of all the circumstances, we chose to withhold it for fuller and more authentic information.

The American and Foeign Joint Stock Company, an asociation of colored capitalists, held it annual meeting last night at Hope Chapel. The attendance was large, the audience consisting of both white and colored persons. The company, though young, is in a a flourishing condition, and its capital is constantly increasing, a large number of shares having been taken last night.

Probably no public testimonial of professional and social or general respect for the memory of a deceased citizen has at any time been attended with such absolute discomfort and positive pain as was that which, with one accord, the public yesterday extended to the friends and co-laborers of the late Dr.CUMMINGS, at St. Stephen's church, in Twenty-eighthstreet.

COOPER, clothier, were burned out and lost most of their goods. LINSLEY SON were insured $2,500; COOPER was not insured. There was an insurance on the building of $2,000.

A year since Congress passed an enabling act for the admission of Colorado as a State. The vote of the people being against a State, no advantage was taken of the act. A short time since a vote was obtained for the State, and the different official positions filled. As a general result the personas elected to office are men of integrity and capacity.

The telegraph yesterday morning gave a brief account of the heavy robbery of the Adams Express car on the New-Haven Railroad on Saturday evening. The New-Haven Journal of yesterday gives full particulars. The safe which was stolen contained over half a million dollars in bonds, specie and government securities.

The Rensselaer Iron Works, Hon. JOHN A. GRISWOLD and Messrs. CORNINGS WINSLOW, proprietors, are an immense institution. They were built in 1845 by Messrs. PETER A. BURDEN, CANNON SCHUYLER, and others, and the first work they did was to make the rails for the Saratoga and Whitehall Railroad.

A SAFE BLOWN OPEN BY BURGLARS.-Yesterday morning, the porter employed by Mr. HANS REES, a leather dealer, doing business at No. 37 Ferry-street, discovered that the store had been entered by burglars during the interval between Saturday night and Monday morning. On further examination it was found that the office safe had been blown open and $3,000 worth of United States bonds abstracted.

D., for many months past has missed various articles of household furniture, carpets, pictures, , but never reported the facts to the police. Recently her son was arrested for larceny, found guilty before Justice DAILEY, and sentenced to the Penitentiary.

GRABBED AN OVERCOAT.--JOHN GARRY, doing business at No. 444 Hudson-street, made complaint against THOMAS GRAY and CHESTER TORRENCE for stealing a new overcoat valued at $45. The accused were arrested by Officer DAPKE, of tho Twenty-eighth Precinct. The prisoners entered complainant's store on the 8th inst., and expressed a wish to purchase an overcoat.

COAL.--As a matter of course, coal has shot up in price during the last three days, and the poor are forced to pay two or three cents more per bushel while this dreadful weather lasts. Only close observers among the poor know how hard this has been upon them, and how many of them have been compelled by it to shiver in their apartments without fire.

The contest among the chess players continued yesterday, at the rooms of the New-York Chess Club, in Room No. 35 University Buildings, and, as on the opening day, a large gathering of experts in this fascinating and intellectual game, were present. Two matches were played yesterday by Messrs. GRAVES and MARTINEZ, of the second class, each gentleman winning a game.

The annual pew renting at Plymouth Church has become a feature of Brooklyn city life. Every year the entire church is thrown open to the public, the seats revert to the Board of Trustees, the genial pastor opens the meeting-auction with prayer, makes a few appropriate remarks, gets everybody in good humor, introduces Brother PILLSBURY, who has sold the Pews in this way since the commencement, and then the work goes on.

The captain of the packet ship Neptune, which arrived in the Lower Bay yesterday, makes the follow ing report: The ship Neptune, PEABODY, Liverpool, Nov. 18, merchandise and 180 passengers, to C. H. MARSHALL Co.; all well--no deaths. Was nine days in the Channel, with very heavy weather from the westward.

BECK.--On Tuesday, Jan. 9, RACHAEL W., eldest daughter of Wm. and Ann E. Beck, in the 20th year of his age. Notice of the funeral hereafter. BUCKHOUT.--At Morrisania, on Saturday, Jan. 6, of acute hydrocephalus, FRANK WEBB, only son of Henry and Sarah E. Buckout, aged 11 months. The remains were interred in St. John's Cemetery, Yonkers.

The President is apparently under a tutelage which ought to be altogether irresistible. The other day we had the presiding officer of a New-Hampshire Convention assuring the assembled politicians of that State that "he did not believe President JOHNSON would go over to the embraces of a political party which for four years upheld robellion."

The board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, No. 16 City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members : Councilmen Flynn, Long, Keenan, Robinson, O'Brien, Kenny, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, Kellogg, White, Mackay, Tyng, Halloran, Roberts, Thomas, Hottrick, Pullman, Imiav--23.

TENNEBSEE COTTON.--We judge from what we have heard that one of the largest cottonproducing States in the Union this year will be Tennessee. In the first place, the native industry of that State, white and colored, is in better condition than that of most other States for the resumption of activity.
Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, (Union,) presented the petition of the clerks in the State Department for an increase of pay. The petition was referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

This Board met at noon, yesterday, and organized by the election of Mr. HENRY SMITH (Republican) as President, and the reflection of Mr. JOSEPH YOUNG as Clerk, Mr. SELMES as Deputy Clerk, Mr. WOODWARD as Assistant Clerk, and Mr. EUGENE DURNIN as Sergeant at Arms.

HASTY LEGISLATION REBUKED. The House of Representatives was again the scene of much interest to-day. A very considerable amount of business was done, and the result, as predicted of the hasty legislation of the first days of the session, was made manifest.

This board hold a special meeting at 2 P. M. yesterday, President BRICE in the chair. The committee were discharged, and on motion of Mr. RYERS the rules of the board for 1865 were adopted as the rules of this board. Mr. VARNUM offered the following resolution:

BROADWAY THEATRE.--The return of Mr. JOHN E. OWENS to this establishment is an event of unquestionable interest to its patrons, which, when Solon Shingle is in question, means the entire community.
This spell of Arctic weather should remind our citizens, if anything ever could, of the sufferings and wants of tens of thousands of poor among us. There is no enemy that the poor fear, like cold.

An immense audience assembled in Crosby's Opera House yesterday, to witness the funeral ceremonies of the gallant dead of the Chicago batteries. There were nineteen bodies in all. The meeting was presided over by CHARLES BANDOLPH, Esq., President of the Board of Trade, and was most eloquently and feelingly addressed by Rev. Dr. TIFFANY.

Within the past twelve hours New-ork has become thawed out. The cold snap which commenced on Sunday afternoon may be said to have spent itself about noon on Tuesday, when the temperature had risen to 22 degrees above zero. It may be safely asserted that forty-eight hours of severe weather were never experienced in this latitude since the settlement of the country.

The following order was received a few days since at the Headquarters of the Military Division of Tennessee : WAR DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON, Dec. 20, 1865. [Extract.] SPECIAL ORDERS, No. 659.--10.--By direction of the President, Major THOMAS W. SWEENEY, Tenth United States Infantry, Brevet Colonel United States Army.

The inaugural address of Gov. Cox is limited to a declaration of the general principles that govern affairs, and to a statement of the political problem to be worked out--but it does not lay down any specific measures for the accomplishment of these objects.

The steamship Canada, from Liverpool Dec. 23 and Queenstown Dec. 24, arrived yesterday at Halifax, after a long and stormy voyage. She brings two days' later intelligence. The steamship City of London, which put into Halifax three days ago short of coal, arrived at this city last might. Her advices were anticipated.

The following is the regular weekly report of the Sanitary Company of the Metropolitan Police for the first week in the new year: CETRAL DEPARTMENT OF THE METROPOLITAN POLICE, NO. 300 Mulberry street. NEW-YORK, Jan. 8, 1866. Too the Honorable the Board of Police:

The Kansas Legislature will meet at Topeka to-day, Gov. CRAWFORD'S message recommends the removal of the various Indian tribes of the State to the Indian Territory, and that patents be issued to those having settled homes, thereby enabling them to dispose of their lands, if they desire to do so, and move with the others; and if not, that then their land may be held subject to taxation, like that of other settlers.

The New-Jorsey Legislature meets to-day. Caucuses were hold by both parties this morning. The Republicans made the following nominations: For President of the Senate, JAS. M. SCOVEL, of Camden; Secretary, E. R. BORDEN, of Mercer; Assistant Secretary, EDWARD DOBBINS, of Essex; Engrossing Clerk, Capt. VANDERVER, of Essex.
GEN. PILLOW.--There seems to be no prominent man in the Southern States who is doing more for the solution of the industrial problem than Gen. PILLOW.

DEATH OF DR. THOMAS W. BLATCHFORD.--In the death of Dr. BLATCHFORD, the City of Troy loses an eminent physician and an eminently good citizen. Aside from his devotion to patients for forty years, Dr. BLTCHEORD contributed valuable professional knowledge in various published works.

By neglecting his military duties proper, Major SWEENY has subjected himself to the disgrace of a formal dismissal from the United States service. Major SWEENY'S record, as a soldier in the United States Army and as an officer of considerable rank in the national volunteer army is reported on all hands to be exceedingly honorable.

A large sale of old navy cannon will take place at the Navy-yard to-day, at noon, and will be continued at the same hour to-morrow. The lot lying in tile Navy-yard consists of 126 guns, weighing 942,947 lbs.--that on the Hospital-grounds 214 guns, weighing 1,349,86 lbs.--that at the ordnance dock 162 guns, weighing 929,654 lbs., and on the North Carolina, Vermont, Octorora, Oneida, Pequot, 40 guns, weighing 288,729 lbs. Total, 542 guns;

THE SUICIDAL MANIA.--The not insignificant subject of suicide was discussed by the County Medical Society on Monday night, and some excellent, though not new views, werepresented as to the medical diagnosis and treatment of the suicidal mania.

The river is falling, and is six and a half feet deep on the shoals. The cotton market is dull. A negro soldier attempted to shoot the City Marshal to-day, near the scene of the late fire, and the affair nearly resulted in a riot. The negro was arrested, and the case will be investigated by the ProvostMarshal.

The inaugural address of Gov. Marshall was delivered before both houses of the Legislature this forenoon. Gov. MARSHALL in reviewing the trade and property of the State gives the following figures: The receipts of the treasury for the fiscal year end. ing December 1, 1865, $395,590 08; and expenditures, 416,318 00.

WORK FOR THE IDLE.--The class of Wealthy persons among us whose disinclination to undertake any political or other public responsibility on the score of its distastefulness to their nervous sensibility, have frequently opportunities which they might embrace without self-derogation.

Statistics, liKe texts from Scripture, are available on every occasion, No sectary was over so mad that he could not refer to scraps from Holy Writ in support of his doctrines; and in politics no cause was ever so desperate that figures might not be found to establish its identification with patriotic purposes.

The large brick block opposite the depot, and a wooden building adjoining, were destroyed by fire this evening. Loss about $100,000; insured for $50,000. CHESTER KINGSLEY, a member of Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, was injured by falling through a sky. light while working on the building.

The public sympathies were painfully startled yesterday with the announcement at the head of this article. With that announcement deep sorrow passed over the city. None who knew ROBERT B. MINTURN--and there are few indeed among us to whom his person or his character were unknown--received the intelligence emotionless.

The steamship Canada, Capt. INGLES, from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 23d, via Queenstown on the 24th of December, arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received. The Canada has 16 passengers for this port and 25 for Boston.

Meessrs. HOLLIDAY Co., distillers, of Martland, are being tried at the Assizes here to-day, charged with swindling the government out of $180,000, by smuggling whisky into the United States. A large fire occurred in Sarnia last night. The Toronto Leader states there is groat dissatisfaction among the volunteers, owing to the meanness of the government in neglecting to clothe them.

Senator WOOD appeared in his seat and took the oath of office. Mr. H. C. MURPHY gave notice of a bill relative to security given by trustees and providing for their removal. Mr. ANDREWS gave notice of a bill to extend the powers of the Five Points House of Industry.

The Adams Express Company, an institution that has faithfully served the people of this country for a great many years has, as our readers know, suffered several very great losses, but has never yet been the instrument of damage to any one.

A fire broke out hero this morning in WENHALL'S extensive carriage and car factory. Three buildings were burned and others wore seriously damaged. There being no water for the engines, the car-shop was saved by snow-balling it.

Last evening the members of the Union League Club assembled at their Rooms in Union-square to give expression to their sorrow at the loss sustained by them and by the community in the death of their late associate and first President, ROBERT B. MINTURN. The Vice-President, CHARLES BUTLER, Esq., presided.

An order from the department headquartore will be promulgated to-morrow, mustering out a large number ot regiments doing duty in Texas. The list has not yet been made known, but it. Is believed it will include about 12,000 troops, all but three regiments.

Accounts in the Louisinna country papers represent that the freedmen are indisposed to male any contracts for labor. They refuse to make any agreements whatever with the planters, unless they can he employed near the largo towns. They are expecting something extraordinary to turn up.

Not many weeks ago we took occasion to warn our readers not to respond to the appeals of individuals on behalf of the freedmen. Our advice has been republished and strongly indorsed by the official organ of the National Freedmen's Relief Association.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Mr. TOM TAYLOR"S dramatization of Miss BRADDON'S novel, named, after the hero, "Henry Dunbar," was produced here last evening, with a success which will justify its repetition on many ensuing evenings. The situations are powerful, and the best one (in the third act) is certainly unexpected by those who have not enjoyed the privilege of reading the novel.

The House of Representatives is working out of its false position, if we may assume that in adopting Mr. STEVENS' resolution with startling unanimity, it placed itself in a false position. The ground thus lost waspartially recovered on Mr. RAYMOND'S resolution affecting Tennessee.

A STRANGE WEDDING.--The St. Louis Democrat says that a few days ago CHARLES MORITZ, a returned soldier, being anxious to marry and settle down, offered an acquaintance $50 provided he procured him a person of whom he might make a wife. The bargain was struck and MORITZ'S friend and a few others determined to work a practical joke on the bachelor.

By order of H. A, WISE, Chief of Bureau of Ordnance, a large lot of old and unserviceable navy cannon was disposed of at public auction, under the superintendence of Capt. MULLANY, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, yesterday.

With the appointment of the standing committees, which are sent you to-day, by telegraph, both Houses of the Legislature are placed in working order. There is, as usual, considerable growling over the list, various members being of opinion that they are not placed in as high a position as their abilities deserve, but generally the committees seem to be very well formed.

MEDICAL COLLEGE AND HOSPITAL FOR WOMEN AND CHILDREN.--A literary and musical entertainment for the benefit of the Medical College and Hospital for Women and Children, at No. 252 West Twenty-sixth-street, will be given this evening, at the residence of Mrs. Dr. LOSIER, No. 361 West Thirty-fourthstreet.

The time for the reception of applications for space at the Pris Universal Exposition has been extended from the 1st of January to the let of March next. Our producers, mechanics and artisans will have further opportunity to send in their applications for space to the agent in Now-York, before the closing of the books.

We make the following extracts from' the reportt of Canal Commissioner SKINNER, recently transmitted to the Legislature: REMOVING BENCHES. Much benefit has arisen to the canals by the removal of the small portion of the benches on the eastern division.

POISONED BY THE USE OF MUSTY FLOUR.-Information was lodged with the Health Officer yesterday, to the effect that an entire family, residing at No. 586 Columbia-street, had been poisoned by the use of musty flour, bought at a neighboring grocery-store. The victims, five in number, were taken sick with dysentery; two recovered, one child died, and two are still down with the sickness.

TRIAL, FOR MURDER.-JOHN MATTHEWS, who was indicted for the murder of JOHN KEEVY, by shooting, was placed on trial in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. The alleged offence was committed on the 18th of September, 1865, in a grocery store, corner of Classon-avenue and Butler-street.

At 5 o'clock last evening, THOMAS BOESE, who holds office as clerk during the pleasure of the board, having taken the chair, Commissioner HITCHMAN moved that, for the purpose of organization, Commissioner FARR be made Chairman.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Congress passed an act in March, 1865, that all officers, thou in service, below the rank of BrigadierGeneral, who remained in service until the close of the war, and were honorably discharged, should receive three months' extra pay.

The Collector of Internal Revenue has seized 257 boxes of cigars from New-York, because of fraudulent government stamps thereon. Rev. JOSEPH FISHER, one of the most eminent clergymen of the diocese of Kentucky, had his skull fractured,by a slung-shot on Monday evening, and has been insensible ever since.

In steamship Quarter City, from Charleston--M. Bogatchi, H. M. Crane, Capt. Richardson, J. H. Fisher, J. R. Richardson, Jr., L. T. Brien, M. Vaynard, John Wallace, Wm. McNeil, L. T. Huey, U. S. BECK.--On Tuesday, Jan. 9, RACHAEL W., eldest daughter of Wm. and Ann E. Beck, in the 20th year of her age. The funeral service will be held at the residence of her parents, No. 235 West 16th-st. this (Thursday) evening at 7 1/2 o'clock. Her remains will be interred at Goodwill Church, Montgomery, Orange County, N. Y.

Tho first number of the National Temperance Advocate, a new paper to be published under the auspices of the National Temporance Society and Publication House, has boon received, and we are glad to find it such a promising sheet and in every war worthy of the great and important interests it is intended to promote and advance.

From the St. Louis Republican. About 9 o'clock yesterday morning, a large bull, which had become separated from a herd on the other side of the river, stepped forth on the ice and made for the city of St. Louis, waking straightforward with a dignified mien, and a look very much like that of a Numidian lion.

Hon. PETER CONE, for many years a State Senator, and a prominent citizen of Bullock County, died at his home on the 6th inst. The steamship Julia, from Boston, for Rio Janeiro, put into Fernandina, Fla, the 6th inst., for coal.
President JUAREZ and Gen. NEORETE arrived at San Antonio from El Paso, on the 1st inst. The Galveston Bulletin notices that a number of United States troops are passing en route to the Rio Grande.

The execution, by hanging, of MORRIS ELLSWORTH, at Newark, yesterday, was one of the most remarkable events in the annals of American jurisprudence, and many years must pass before the parties connected with the scene officially, or as simple spectators, will recover from its effects-mental or moral.

A very pleasant dinner was given yesterday by the New-York agents of the North German Lloyd on board of their splendid new steamship Hermann, in honor of her first and very successful voyage. The Hermann is one of the best vessels of her class afloat, substantially constructed and fitted up with everything necessary to insure the safety and convenience of passengers. The ship ia divided into five bulk.

LONGSTREET, OWEN CO. advertise in the columns of the St. Louie Republican that they will be glad to do any business as cotton factors or general commission merchants with which their friends may intrust them. The Republican says: "The firm is composed. Individually, of Gen. JAMES LONGSTREET and W. M. and E. OWEN.

MEETING OF THE NEW-YORK CARMEN.--Quite a large meeting of the New-York carmen was held last evening, at TAYLOR'S Hotel, Jersey City, to take into consideration certain proposals made by the agents of the Empire Transportation Company.

Yesterday, shortly after noon, three men residing at Connor's Creek, about five miles out on the Gratiot road, came to this city, having in their custody one JOHN HANLY alias COOPER, who had, about 12 o'clock on that day, murdered his own sister in cold blood, having almost literally chopped her to pieces with an ax.

During the war of secession LOUIS NAPOLEON exhibited no great anxiety to secure the recognition of the so-called Mexican Empire by our government. The subject was hinted at once or twice, but from what we have heard we judge that MAXIMILIAN was more anxious than his master about the matter.
In the ship Zeno murder case, the mate was sentenced by the jury to be hung. The Judges sustained the action of the jury. The cook's confession implicates the mate and the boy on board the vessel.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: The report in the DAILY TIMES of the last annual festivities of this society, is suggestive of a few thoughts upon the design of this most excellent institution.
A mooting of citizens from different parts of the State was held here to-day, for the purpose of discussing the feasibility of constructing a railroad from Oswego to Jersey City.

JOHN MOREHOUSE, Captain of the steamship City of London, reports: "Left Liverpool Dec. 20; when about four miles north of Queenstown, discovered a steamer on shore flying signals of distress: went as close to her as we could prudently, and found her to be the Ibis, belonging to the Cork and Liverpool line.

We have been looking at the rough map appended to the Ann-street widening resolution, and will try to give the reader an idea of what is proposed. Starting from Ann-street we measure 103 feet along Park-row, then out in so as to take all the lots up to the Express Offico, running back on the regular lot boundary about a hundred feet,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You have published many unjust attacks on coal-dealers, but none so bad as that on page No. 4 in this morning's paper. Some dealers may have done as you charge, but not all. I have not raised my prices since the cold spell. My prices ore $12 per ton, 65 cents per bushel.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. Act No. 12 amends and enlarges the scope of the Vagrant Act of 1855. It adopts the same definition of vagrancy as in the old act, and provides that any person charged with vagrancy shall be arrested on the warrant of any Judge or Justice of the Peace;

A fire broke out this morning in the clothing store of J. L. ANDREE, on Carroll-street, and destroyed all the buildings from Pattinson's market, on Carrollstreet, to Hitchcock's market, on Lake-street. The buildings were all of wood and of little value.

This relic of barbarism, this invention of dishonest legislators, still disgraces our code. We had hoped that the Legislature, at its recent session, would have abolished it forever. Failing therein, we hope, at its reassembling, that one of its first acts will be to repeal this odious enactment instanter and in toto.

In the Senate yesterday a petition was presented from the colored citizens of Savannah, asking for the right of suffrage. A resolution was passed to print 6,000 instead of 10,000 copies of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT'S report.

The Fisk Freedman's school was dedicated yesterday. Speeches were made by Gen. FISK, Gov. BROWNLOW and others. It is intended to be a free high school for colored children, with accommodations for 1,000 to 1,500 pupils.

Petitions were presented to confirm the grant of the Brooklyn Common Council to the Metropolitan Railway, and to amend the act for the collection of damages caused by railroad accidents.

The contract in progress of negotiation between the Atlantic and Great Western Railroad Company and the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company has been finally agreed upon, and goes into effect immediately.

SKATING IN THE SUNSHINE.--THE BALL UP EVERYWHERE.--The genial temperature of yesterday, with the universal "ball up" which met the skater's view on every car-top, left nothing to be longed for by the lovers of this healthy recreation.

FIRE IN ANN-STREET.--At 9:40 o'clock last night, a fire broke out in the basement of premises No. 79 Ann-street, occupied by W. TWIBLE as a packing-box manufactory. Damage to stock about $300, by fire and water.

CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN GOV. WORTH AND PRESIDENT JOHNSON. The North Carolina papers publish the following: GOV. WORTH TO THE PRESIDENT. STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA, EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 2, 1866. To His Excellency Andrew Johnson, President of the United States:

THE PRESIDENT'S POLICY. The chief feature of the morning was the consideration by Mr. DAVIS, of New-York, of a series of well and cautiously-drawn series of resolutions indorsing the President's policy. Mr. WASHBURNE, in his customary spirit, immediately referred the resolutions to the Joint Committee on Reconstruction, but the Speaker, not having surrendered his prerogative ?? presiding officer, begged to differ with Mr. WASHBURNE, as they gave rise to debate.

The citizens of New-Haven have lately made the discovery that the treasury of their Orphan Asylum is nearly empty, and they have set themselves to work with a will to replenish it. On Monday evening next a promenade concert will be given, which bids fair to fully accomplish the desired object.

BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. By Mr. ANDREWS--The Rochester Arsenal Bill. By Mr. FOLGER-For an Assistant District Attorney in Niagara County. By Mr. FOLGER--To amend the Metropolitan Police Act by providing for patrolmen in Richmond County. Also for admitting to bail parties arrested in Brooklyn on Saturday nights.
The new bill creating a "Metropolitan Sanitary District and Board of Health " for NewYork and Brooklyn, is now before the committee of the Senate.

GLAR--THE POLICEMAN SHOT.-Another of the many conflicts between the burglars and police of the Ea crn Distriet took place shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning, in which, as usual, the burglar came off triumphantly. In this encounter one Metropolitan was shot. and a private watchman had a leg broken while searching for the assailant.

THE RUSS-DAYTON TRAGEDY.--Coroner LYNCH yesterday held an inquest upon the body of WILLIAM H. RUSS, who died at the City Hospital on the 3d. of January inst., from the effects of injuries inflicted by himself.

Whenever the original promoters of the Reciproeity Treaty were hard pressed for argument they fell back upon the alleged advantages of the St. Lawrence route to the ocean. On that theme their eloquence and rhetoric were inexhaustible.

The tug S. C. Hall, from Philadelphia, bound to Galveston, put in here to coal She reports that the schooner Retribution, ashore on Hatteras Inlet, had four of her crew frozen to death while hanging on the vigging, and two pilots are supposed to have been washed off and drowned.

THEATRE FRANCAIS.--The singing members of the French company gave a pleasant operatic enter. tainment at the Academy on Wednesday evening, when portions of HALEVY's opera of " L'Eclair," and the charming operetta of " Les Noces de Jeannette," by VICTOR MASSE, were given.

Gov. SWANN submitted his message to the extra session of the Maryland Legislature to-day at noon. After expressing gratithde to Almighty God for the protecting arm which has been extended over the State during the rebellion, and for the overwhelming triumph of free principles in the conflict, which has so recently terminated, in the restoration of peace within our borders, the Governor proceeds at some length to discuss State and National affairs.

TERRIBLE ACCIDENT BY SCALDING.--On Wednesday evening a terrible accident occurred at the distillery of Mr. JACOB B. HANSELING, on Elm-street, near Garrison-street, Newark, which it is thought will result fatally. Mr. HANESLING was showing the premises to an acquaintance, and while doing so passed through a room on the level of the floor of which wore several vats filled with boiling liquor.

The steamer Gen. Barnes, from New-York for Alexandria, stopped by ice in the Potomac, arrived this morning. The steamer Leo, from Savannah for New-York, arrived to-day, short of coal. She encountered heavy weather. The ice in the Elizabeth River is fast breaking up. The James River is still closed above City Point.

THE DEATH PUNISHEMENT.--The execution at Newark on Wednesday of MORRIS ELLSWORTH, convicted of murder under what many would consider extenuating circumstances, suggests a comparison between the carrying out of the criminal laws in New-Jersey and other States and our own.

A fox-hunt is suggestive of scarlet coats, buckskin small clothes, and white-topped boots, include ing, of course, high-bred horses. A fox chase, however, hereabouts entirely dispenses with these accessories.

Among the distinguished visitors at Trial Chamber, on Wednesday, were Senator J. McLEOD MURPHY and Police Justice JOSEPH DOWLING. The trials-118 in-number-were entertaining as usual, notwithstanding the dark side of the docket was more sombre than on any previous trial day within the memory of the Board of Commissioners.

The mails by the Canada reached this city at 1:20 o'clock this morning. We lay before our readers the important diplomatic correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Earl CLARENDON in regard to the pirate Shenandoah.

SUPREME COURT--CIRCUIT--PART I.--JAN. 11 Before Justice Joseph F. Barnard and a. Jury. William Twomley vs. Jeronimus S. Underhill--This action was brought to recover the sum of $10,000 damages for injuries alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff by reason of the illegal and hasty acts of the defendant under the following circumstances. The plaintiff was a rigger and as such was in the defendant's employ.

About 2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in Mr. LORRELL HARDING'S store on Court-street, two doors east of the American Hotel, and before the flames were extinguished totally destroyed three stores, owned respectively by L. HARDING, HORTON BROTHERS and R. II. HALL CO.

CHEERFUL.--Mark Tapley, as our readers will recollect, was a character whose cheeriness under difficulties and in the midst of doubts and uncertainties 'and troubles was worthy of all praise and imitation, and he has been universally accepted as a model in this respect. But he was a character of fiction.

OUR COMMERCIAL CONDITION.--The annual circular of the Mercantile Agency presents a variety of interesting and most satisfactory figures and statements bearing upon the commercial condition of the country.

THE RECIPROCITY TREATY. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, (Union,) presented the petition of citizens of Michian against the renewal of the Reciprocity Treaty, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce. PETITION FOR UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE. Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, (Union,) presented the petition of the Colored Baptist Convention, asking for universal suffrage, which was referred to the Committee on Reconstruction.

The object of the maintenance of large standing armies by the governments of Europe is to protect monarchs against each other's ambitions and against their own subjects. In this fortunate country, the government is neither in peril from neighboring powers nor from its own citizens.

A call has boon issued for a meeting, at 3 o'clock on Monday afternoon, at POWERS' Hotel, in Park-row, of property owners interested in the suddenly-developed project of widening Ann and Fulton-streets.

We have received the following communication from a thoroughly responsible resident of the Twelfth Ward. It details a scheme for filling a vacancy in the Board of Trustees, without the necessity of consulting the people, which has the merit at least of ingenuity.

BUCKHOUT.--At her father's residence, Sing Sing, on Wednesday evening Jan 10, CORNELIA A. wife of Alfred Bucknout, and daughter of Adrian k. Hoffman. M.D. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from St. Paul's Ohurch, Sing Sing, on Saturday, at 12 o'clock.

One of the most shocking cases of shameful and criminal neglect by a ship's surgeon has just been made public, by which a female emigrant was compelled to endure the severest sufferings, and her life, in all probability, was imperiled.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. CHANDLER presented a petition from citizens of Michigan, against the renewal of the Reciprocity treaty. Mr. SUMNER presented a petition in favor of universal suffrage. Mr. FESSENDEN called up the bill to authorize the Secretary of the Treasury to appoint Assisant Assessors of Internal Revenue.

Now that the skating season has fairly and emphatically set In; that the ice is in most excellent condition, and that the ball is likely to be permanently up ?? slight sketch of the origin and progress of the sport of skating may not be without interest.

LUCY RUSHTON'S NEW-YORK THEATRE.--The "Lady of Lyons" was played here last evening to an audience that was more respectable in applause than numbers. The business of hunting in old settled and civilized countries was once respectable; but that was a long time ago. For half a century the grand battues of British centaurs, with horns and hounds, against the fast-fading. remnant of the fox and hare tribes have been fit and well-improved subjects for ridicule.

The Royal mail steamer Scoha, Capt. JUDKINS, which left Liverpool at 8:30 on the morning of the 30th, and Queenstown on the evening of the 31st December, arrived here yesterday morning. The steamship North American left Liverpool for Portland on the evening of Dec. 28, and Londonderry the 29th.

The third annual meeting of the New-York State Cheesemakers' Association adjourned this evening after a successful and largely attended session of two days. The name of the association was changed to " The American Dairymen's Association," to include the delegates from half a dozen States and the Canadas, who were present.

BENJAMIN B. MARSCHALL and AUGUST FRICE, recently convicted of the murder of a German named FORSTER, at Boyd Hill, near this city, a short time since, were executed to-day. MARSCHALL made a confession before the trial implicating FRICKE, who, although the testimony against him was conclusive, persisted in declaring his innocence to the last, calling on MARSCHALL on the scaffold to clear him of the charge.

MORE LOGIC.--We quoted into our columns the other day the statement that certain "radical" members of Congress, disliking Secretary MCCULLOCH'S views upon negro suffrage, had therefore determined to oppose his financial measures. This seemed ridiculous enough, but not too ridiculous to be credited by those who have made a study of the actions and motives of certain public men.

COURT OF CLAIMS. Chief-Justice Casey presiding. Thomas W. Pierce vs. The United States.This noted case, so important in its consequences to the government, both in respect to its treasury and its established usages, yesterday came on for hearing on its merits, and will likely consume a couple of days in the trial.

THE EMIGRANT-SHIP HORROR.--Mrs. MARY A. GILROY, the unfortunate steerage passenger on board the emigrant ship Neptune, who suffered so terribly from neglect and exposure, while suffering the pains of premature childbirth, a full account of which ap peared in yesterday's TIMES, died yesterday morning at the New-York Hospital from the effects of said neglect, superadded to the natural consequences of her condition.

THE CHIVALRY STILL RAMPANT, AND AGAIN WHIPPED.-We learn that our correspondent in Richmond has been visited with the dire vengeance of Mr. HENRY RIVES POLLARD, who undertook a small whipping operation, but the valiant son of chivalry was instantly disarmed, and was receiving a bit of merited punishment when some of his friends came to the rescue, and saved what there was left of him. Gov. BROWNLOW to-day sent to the. Legislature a message urging the Legislature to make provision for keeping up the State Penitentiary, and warning the members that embarrassment and trouble will come from the delay. He also urged the importance of the establishment of .a branch penitentiary at Knoxville and Memphis,

The Legislature convened on Wednesday, and elected Hon. H. D. BARROW Speaker and E. W. YOUNG Chief Clerk, The Senate elected F. M. STEWART Chief Clerk. Gov. FAIRCHILD delivered his message this afternoon, It is a very able document, and a complete review of the affairs of the State for the past year, which are represented to be in an excellent condition. The State debt is only $2,664,553.

ELIJAH F. PURDY, who for many years--the biblical three score and ten-lived a simple unpretending life among us, was yesterday conveyed, with great pomp and ceremony by his late associates and friends, to the City Hall, where his remains were laid in state until this morning.

The correspondence which has passed between Mr. ADAMS and Lord CLARENDON on the subject of our claims against the Queen's Government, owes its interest, possibly, in part to the intervening changes in the British Ministry, as well as to the subject immediately discussed.

The Senate Committee on Municipal Affairs have set down the Metropolitan Health Bill for its first hearning on Tuesday afternoon next. It is too soon to get a fair view of the course to be taken by the opposition this Winter, but it seems certain that they are already much disheartened.

NOTE.--The custom of printing over and over again the State and politics of Senators and Representatives seems to be superfluous, since the public are by this time pretty well acquainted with the facts. We therefore omit the localty and designation of Union men, but shall in all imprtant movements specify the Democrats, omitting only their States.--ED. TIMES.

The steamship Scotia arrived at this port yesterday morning, with' seven days' later intelligence from Europe. The Fenian excitement is England had received a fresh impulse from the circumstance that several regiments of English troops had been dispatched in haste to Ireland. Military movements indicated either great danger or remarkable credulity on the part of the authorities.

CABNETT CHANGES.-To enliven the current dullness, the quidnuncs have been at work lately reconstructing the Cabinet. All the present members were to go out but two; only one out of the whole was going out; and precisely one half of the members were going out, while the other half remained in.

TAX ON COTTON.-The proposition made in Congress by Mr. MOORHEAD to increase the internal revenue tax upon Southern cotton from two to ten cents per pound is one which should not be sanctioned. It would be extremely damaging to the national interests.

THE UNITARIANS.--We understand that the "council of ten" of the National Unitarian Conference meets in Boston next week, and at that time the date and place of holding the next session of the conference will be agreed upon. It is quite improbable that the gathering of the national body will be held in New-York this year.

By way of San Francisco we have news from Acapulco to the 5th inst. The steamer Gibson, which was disabled, has left for New-York, convoyed by the steamer E. C. Knight. The steamers Albemarle and Niagara, previously reported ice-bound, have arrived from Richmond and sailed for New-York.

On the 17th of October, 1855, a treaty was made with the Blackfeet Indian Nation (A. CUMMING and ISAAC I. STEVENS acting as Commissioners on the part of the United States.) by which nearly the whole of what is now Montana was given over to their exclusive use, the northern portion for a dwelling place, and part south of the Muscle-Shell River for a hunting ground.

ScoTT, late commanding the United States steamer Saginaw, at Acapulco on the 5th inst., after three weeks' sickness from fever. Mining stocks are a shade better. The bill to enlarge the Freedmen's Bureau, as amended by the Judiciary Committee, has been presented by Mr. TRUMBTH to the Senate. It provides for the continuance of the bureau, and its extension to all parts of the United States were freedmen may be. To-day the last scene in the terrible Boydhill tragedy was enacted. The murderers, FRECKE and MANSOHALA, have paid penalty of their crimes, and the curtain falls. They were recently convicted of the murder of a German named FOERSTER at Boyd's Hill, near this city. Throughout the whole of last night and up to the time of his execution this morning, FRECKE walked the narrow limits of his cell.

The two thieves arrested at Norwalk on Tuesday had a partial hearing on Wednesday, and wore required to give bonds in the sum of $25,000 each for appearance next Saturday at Norwalk, to undergo a lull examination.

NO DANGER OF TOO MUCH COTTON.--The Montgomery (Ala.) Ledger expresses the opinion, that so far from the cotton crop being likely to prove a failure this year the only danger is that there will be an over crop.

Quite an exciting election was held to-day by the Corn and Flour Exchange for a Board of Directors. The regular ticket, composed exclusively of Union men, was defeated, and the opposition ticket, made up of gentlemen of opposite sympathies, was elected by a large majority.

Nothing could more completely illustrate the utter helplessness of the taxpayers of this city against any raid that organized self-interest may make upon them than the proceedings (reported in another column) of the meeting held yesterday to oppose, or at least to look into, the plan for the widening of Ann-street, the destruction of the block between William and Gold, and the tearing down of the United States Hotel.

COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert and Justices Hoyt and Voorbles. The Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, sitting in the superb room prepared for it in the new County Court-house, yesterday took up the case of GONZALES, who stands charged with the murder of a Cuban named OTERO, in the Park of Brooklyn City, last November. In the Senate yesterday a bill was introduced to provide for the examination of army officers before a competent board, for the purpose of weeding out incapables. Referred to the Military Committee. Mr. WILSON'S bill to fix the strength of the peace military establishment was called up and recommitted. A petition in favor of a protective tariff was offered.

The brig Neva, of Machias, Me., TALBOT, muster, from New-York, bound to Jacksonville, Fla., was wrecked on the South Breaker of St. John's Bar on the 8th inst. Miss WALL and a child, passengers, the Captain, first mate, pilot and two seamen were lost. The brig now lies on the beach twelve miles south of the bar.

A few days ago our reporter visited the ironclad depot on the Delaware, and saw the vessels laid up there. It is not long since the vessels were removed from a point near the Navy-yard to the socalled channel at the back of League Island.

Prof. BRUNNOW, an American citizen by adoption, has been appointed Astronomer Royal for Ireland and Professor of Astronomy in Trinity College, Dublin, in place of Sir Wm. HAMILTON, deceased. This appointment is one of the highest in the Astronomical world. It is the more honorable as it is probably the first instance of a foreigner receiving an appointment of this kind in the United Kingdom.

Brownsville accounts say that the recently surprised Liberals were captured through the treachery of one of their number. They were en route to Fenerldo with thirteen wagons.

There is before the Legislature of this State a bill giving power to undermine Broadway for the purpose of creating an underground railway, and another to carry a railroad, by a light viaduct, above the street traffic.

McCHEISTIE, late Assistant Surgeon of the Ninth Indiana Cavalry, was engaged to a widow lady in Liberty, Ind., and pending the marriage she intrusted considerable funds with him. The Message of President JOHNSON has been read with greater interest than any preceding document from Washington. Bankers, merchants, manufacturers, and diplomats and ministers at the Diet have been for days on the qui vive to see this important Message. Some timid men were looking for a warlike, threatening document, which would embroil us at once in a war with England and France.

The Academy of Music was last evening crowded to repletion with a fashionable and brilliantly dressed assemblage of the friends and patrons of the Roman Catholic Asylum, who gathered for the double purpose of adding to the funds of a worthy and beneficent institution and the enjoyment of a few hours of social pleasure in the mazy dance.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--The board met yesterday afternoon, the President, A. M. BLISS, Esq., in the chair. Considerable business was transacted. Alderman FISHER moved that the contract for removing offal from the city for 1866 be made for one year.

GEN. CRAWFORD AGAIN.--We have no doubt that the government has sent orders to Gen. SHERIDAN, who commands the military department in which Texas is located, to take prompt and effective care of the "Gen. CRAWFORD" who has lately begun to figure on the Rio Grande as some sort of a filibuster, and who seems determined to get this country into trouble if it be in his power.

The Liverpool and New-Orleans Steamship Line are building new vessels, to make trips in eighteen days. The agent of the French TransAtlantic Steamship Company is here, and has obtained ample wharfage facilities to connect New-Orleans with St. Nazaire.

WHAT SHALL WE TAX ?--A delegation of Northwestern distillers and whisky dealers are in Washington for the purpose of urging upon Congress the reduction of the tax upon whisky. There have been a hundred, if not a thousand, propositions before Congress, during its present session, for reducing or abolishing the taxes upon various articles.

THE EQUALIZATION OF BOUNTIES. Gen. SCHENCK, Chairman of the House Military Committee, recently addressed a letter to the Secretary of War, asking for information concerning the amount that would probably be required to equalize the bounties of all volunteers during the rebellion.

"SMILING AT GRIEF."--A "Southern gentleman who owns the soul of a knight and a genius of the highest order"--so he is described by the Mobile Register--but who is "ready to fly from a land darkened by the power of New-England superstition."

The great hope, in an economical view, for the Southern States, is the gradual creation of a class corresponding to our Northern and Western farmers or freeholders. It is well known that the ruling class at the South has always been the planting class, holding large estates, while the balance to them consisted mainly of whites, who were uneducated and not well off, and who were in consequence the tools of their superiors.

Orders were received yesterday from the War Department to discharge all employee in the various government departments in this district who had been in any way connected with the rebel service. In accordance with these instructions the Commanding General immediately dismissed all such-about 25 in number-giving them short notice to leave the place.

The inquest in this case was resumed yesterday morning, before Coroner GOVER. JACOB DALE, steward of the ship Neptune, testified at considerable length to facts going to show that proper care and attention had been given to deceased by himself and by the doctor.

WOOD's THEATRE.-At intervals only too short, Mr. THOMAS DE WALDEN maddens the community with a new play. Critics on such occasions rush from the theater in dismay. They have been known to stand bareheaded in the street imprecating this reckless dramatist, and madly cursing the destiny that made it necessary they should write about him.

A very serious accident occurred to the Stonington steamboat Plymouth Rock at an early hour yesterday morning, when on her way from Stonington to this city. It appears that the steamer left Stonington at 10 o'clock on Monday night, having on board 160 cabin passengers and 40 in the steerage, some of the latter having been but recently rescued from the ship Gratitude.

THE REPUBLICAN CAUCUS. The Republican members held an adjourned meeting at the Capital to-night to receive the report of the committee heretofore appointed to mature a plan in order to reconcile conflicting viewe on a bill for the extension of negro suffrage in the District of Columbia.

Mr. Low gave notice of a bill to facilitate the construction of the New-York and Oswego Midland Railroad, allowing towns to tale stock, exempting the company from taxation for a certain time, and authorzing the Commissioners of highways to grant the right of way.

The State Military Association met at the City Hall at 2 o'clock P. M. to-day. About 70 members were present, who represented 60 regiments located in nearly every section of the State. The President, Col. F. A. CONKLING, in the chair, referred to the present condition of the country as favorable to the more complete organization of the National Guard, and hoped the deliberations of the association would tend to promote that end.

A QUEER AFFAIR. CHARLES RILEY, (colored,) an inmate of the Soldiers' Home, in Howard-street, and a returned soldier, made the following queer complaint against EMIL STARKE, also an inmate of the home. He stated that on the 18th of December last, he accompanied STARKE to the New-Haven Railroad Depot, For the purpose of assisting him in loading a wagon.
PAY OF NAVAL OFFICERS. Mr. MORGAN presented the memorial of the New-York Chamber of Commerce asking for an increase of the pay of naval officers; referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs.

The extreme course talon by the New-England members at the very opening of the session has so taken by surprise the conservative section of the Republican party that it has been thrown into some confusion, and it will probably not be until after the Christmas recess that it reforms itself into a powerful organlzation.
MARCUS L. WARD was inaugurated as Governor of New-Jersey to-day. There was a great rush at the State-house. Everybody is pleased with the inaugural address.

As the previous diatribes of the Evening Post about Mexico meet with no response in the policy of the government or the feeling of the people, it has taken to the outrageous course of urging Fillibustering expeditions from the United States against the Imperial Power established in Mexico.

A CLAIM AGAINST THE GOVERNMENT KILLED.A case tried in the Supreme Court yesterday disposed of a question which has been considered a good deal by the owners of vessels which were chartered by the government during the rebellion.

JURY CHALLENGES.--The privilege of jury challenges seems likely to pats into some contempt from the strained interpretation of the law which has been often adopted of late. We judge that the intention of the challenge is not so much to secureignorant jurors as to exclude those whose prejudice for or against a prisoner, implies a determination to convict or release him.

At the opening of court yesterday morning, an immense crowd made a rush for the doorway, and in less than five minutes the entire audience-room, below and in the gallery, was packed full; no ladies present.

ANOTHER STATE ADDED TO THE UNION.--The inauguration of MARCUS L. WARD as Governor of New-Jersey, which event took place yesterday at Trenton, completes the necessary formalities for the restoration of that State to the Union.

The Senate Committee on Municipal Affairs held a meeting this evening to consider the Metropolitan Health Bill, at which the members of the House Committee on Public Health were present by invitation.

GOV. STONE, Of Iowa, was inaugurated for his second term on Thursday. Referring to the President's reconstruction policy he says: "While I could have desired him to go further than he has, I cannot withhold my cordial approval of the acts he has already done in the exercise of his constitutional powers.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON reported his bill for the reorganization of the army on a peace basis. There are to be 5 regiments of artillery, 12 of cavalry, 55 of infantry. Mr. CHANDLER'S resolution for the recall of our Minister to Great Britain was brought up, and after some debate was laid on the table by 25 to 12.
A Warrant is out to-night for POLLARD, issued on an affidavit from BROOKS, given to-day at the instigation of prominent officials and citizens who desire to meet the question of security of life.

In the Senate, yesterday, the credentials of WILLIAM A. GRAHAM, Senator elect from North Carolina, were presented and ordered to lie upon the table. A remonstrance was presented against arming the militia of Alabama.

Quite a pleasant little affair came off last evening at the Riding Academy, corner of Sixth-avenue and Twenty-sixth. Some forty or so of the habitues of the establishment, male and female, appeared in the arena in fancy dress and masked.

The steamer Richmond is now being loaded with cotton for New-Orleans, being the first shipment made to that port. Cotton has an upward tendency. Quotations are from 40c.@43c., 42c. being the ruling figure. Re. ceipts 385 bales; sold 289; shipments 254.

We learn from our special Washington dispatch of last evening that at the Republican caucus of Monday night there was a majority of two to one in favor of qualified, as opposed the 1 to universal, negro suffrage.

BOYD--On Tuesday, Jan. 16, of Bright's disease of the kidneys, SARAH ELIZA, eldest daughter of James and Sarah Boyd, in the 22d year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her parents, No. 97 Henry-st, on Friday at 11/9 o'clock. DENMAN.-Suddenly, on Tuesday, Jan. 16, ASAHELA.. DENMAN . in the 61st rear of his age.

NENATOR DOOLITTLE'S SPEECH. Senator DOOLITTLE'S speech in the Senate this afternoon was listened to by the Senate and an immense audience with marked attention. It is pronounced one of the ablest arguments delivered in the Senate this session, and a conclusive answer to the speech of Mr. HOWE on his resolution recommending the establishment of provisional governments for the Southern States.

The Matamoras Ranchero, of the 5th inst., contains the following highly important and exciting intelligence: Several officers and men crossed from Clarksville, Texas, and took up quarters apparently for the night. Shortly after midnight the guards at the ferry and along the river were surprised, and disarmed by this party.

The conservative organ, in an article on re-ciprocity to-day, says that the proposition to place the Canadian tariff on the same footing as that of the United States is impossible; would be displeasing to the home government, and probably would not be allowed.

A bill has been presented to the House by Mr. JENCKS, of Rhode Island, which we fear is too good and too much in advance of our civilization to pass as yet, but which hereafter may, in some of its features, become law. We allude to the bill for instituting public "competitive examinations" for our public officers.
