The House to-day had its annual spasm over Red-books. The Committee on Expenditures reported in favor of forty copies of the Legislative Manual for each member and five for the reporters. Upon this the debate sprang up, consuming some two hours of time.

Mails for Europe, via Hamburg, per steamer Borussia, close on Saturday, at 10:30 A. M.; via Falmouth and Havre, per steamer Arago, same day, at 1 P. M.; via Queenstown, per steamer City of Baltimore, at 10:30 A. M.

Gen. WOODS, commanding in Alabama, has issued an order allowing the churches to be reopened and the ministers to resume their duties. Mr. HACKET has arrived. (Gov. WELLS has returned to-day from Alexandria:
A fire, at 5 o'clock this morning, destroyed the boiler-shop of MERRICK'S foundry, corner of Fifth and Washington streets, The loss will not exceed $15,000.

A GREENPOINT GIRL ON A MISHONARY ENTERPRISE.--A girl named ANNIE ROBINSON, ten years and a half old, was missed from the residence of her parents, in Eagle-street, near Liberty, Greenpoint, on Wednesday, the 10th inst., and her parents entertained the most serious apprehensions in regard to her safety, fearing that she had been kidnapped;

OLYMPIC THEATEE.-It is seldom that so good a drama as "St. Marc" is presented to the public, and rarely that any drama is placed on the stage with equal warmth and completeness. The expressions warmth, is justified by the scenery, which at this theatre is peculiarly, and as in this case felicitously warm.

The Secretary of War has addressed the following letter to the Chairman of the Committee on Appropriations: WAR DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON CITY, Dec. 15, 1865. SIR: The Surgeon-General has applied for the assignment of the property known as Ford's Theatre for the deposit and safe-keeping of the records relating to soldiers discharged for disability incurred in the service...

KINGS COUNTY OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert and Justices Hovt and Voorhles. The third day of the trial of GONZALES for the murder of OTERO, found an increased crowd in atCendauce, a perfect multitude of men thronging the malls, corridors and room itself.

The New-York State Temperance Society com menced its first annual session in this city to-day at the First Baptist Church, Vice-President SAMUEL MORRISo, of Catskill, in the chair. J. C. GALLUP, of Oneida County, was chosen Sccretary. The morning session was devoted to preliminary business.

The forty-ninth annual meeting of the American Colonization Society was hold last night. It was not so largely attended as the meetings have been for several years past, but a number of old and timehonored leaders were among the auditors. The report states that the balance in the Treasury at the commencement of the year was $1,523 33.

In the quaint old town of Frankfort-on-the. Main many of the houses rest upon caryatids of all periods, styles, sexes and ages. On the market-place some disdainful Hercules supports a six-storied house upon one shoulder, while with the arm that is free he dares the gaping public.

BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. To amend the act for widening South Seventh-street, Brooklyn. To alter the Commissioners' map of the Ninth Ward Brooklyn. BILLS NOTICED. By Mr. FOLGER--Requiring County Treasurers to give bonds in certain cases. By Mr. GODDARD--To equalize the bounties to volunteers.

Last evening, at No. 548 Broadway, next door to TIFFANY Co.'s establishment, was inaugurated the sale of one of the finest collections of oil-paintings ever yet made in this country. Messrs. HENRY LEEDS MINOR, by order of the heirs and assignees of the estate,

Brooklyn has taken another step in advance. Her increase in size and importance has been manifesting itself in various ways. She has within a few years secured for herself a theatre, an Academy of Music, and a Court-house.

This board held a special meeting yesterday--President BRICE in the chair. The following resolutions by Mr. LEOW was called up: Resolved, That the Comptroller be and hereby is authorized to take the necessary measures to collect from the necessary measure to collect from the United States Government the balance unpaid of the amount expended in the years 1861 and 1862.

The Gazette's Nashville dispatch says that during the debate on the bill granting civil rights to negroes in the House yesterday, a fierce altercation took place between Messrs. STEEL and ABNELL. The He was given and returned.. The House adjourned in great confusion.

JOHN BELL has broken his long silence on political subjects by writing a series of public letters upon national politics. Those who know the character of Mr. BELL's mind, as displayed during his long public career, will find these letters to be precisely what they might have anticipated, considering his fortunes and misfortunes during the past five years.

SHOOTING AFFRAY.--About 8:20 o'clock last evening a man named JOHN DEGUAN came to the Seventeenth Precinct, Police-station, and surrendered himself to the Sergeant in charge. Mr. DEGUAN stated that he had been visiting some friends at No. 306 East Twelfth-street, and white there he was violently assaulted by JAMES CASSIDY and others.

TIME SUFFRAGE BILL PASSED. The contest on the Negro, Suffrage Bill to-day in the House, the votes on the various propositions, and the final passage of the bill as it was originally reported by the Judiciary Committee, occurred just as predicted in my dispatches of last evening. The first motion was to lay on the table, which was lost by a strict party vote--46 to 123.

The House Committee on Claims, through its chairman, Hon. COLUMBUS DELANO, will to-morrow offer a resolution instructing this Committee, until otherwise ordered, to reject all claims referred to them for examination by citizens of any of the States lately in rebellion, growing out of the destruction or appropriation of or damage to property by the army or navy while engaged in suppressing the rebellion.

CANAL EXPENDITURES.--The resolutions of Mr. LITTLEJOHN, in the Assembly, calling for information about the expenditures upon the State canals, is seasonable and searching. The enormous sums required to keep the canals in repair during the year 1865 has awakened general solicitude. Either the system is bad or it is badly administered.

Emmons, Willard Sayles, Mrs. Sarah Harby Ale, Villiet J. Chantegrel, Mark Oganriteh, W. Jacobs, John S. Thompson, John Barrett, John Brady, and 53 U. S. colored troops.

The eighteenth annual report of the State Prison Inspectors was presented to the Senate on Saturday. It shows the number of convicts in the several prisons: Sing Sing, 784 males, 159 females; Auburn, 515; Clinton, 338; Asylum, 73; total, 1,869. During the year 1,187 were received, 1,028 discharged, 17 escaped, 81 died, 10-were transferred to the asylum.

There was a debate in the House of Representatives to-day on the bill granting civil rights to negroes. In the morning Messrs. RICHARDS, of Shelby, and FREEMAN and HAYWOOD spoke in favor the bill. Both made good speeches. In the afternoon, Mr. STEIGALD, of Perry and Decatur, made a speech in opposition.

I am sure your readers who have lived in the midst of a real rebellion--one that is now fairly ranked as the greatest civil war that history records from the very beginning of the world--must smile in contempt when they hear the Jamaica emeute spoken of as a rebellion, and a great rebellion, too.

The members of the Philadelphia Sketch Club, tic gave, last evening, private exhibition of a collection gr of paintings, new on view at Messrs. SEITZ NOELLE'S Gallery, No. 625 Broadway. There was, as unusual on such occasions, a very large attendance, and the ladies were the only works of art attentively examined.

To the Editor of the New-York Time: January, 1866, will have to stand as the coldest month for many years, and the Winter of 1885-66 as that in which the coldest weather occurred, though it may not be the coldest Winter, for the month of December, 1865, was unusually mild.

THE KOHNSTAMM CASE.--The grounds upon which a pardon for SOLOMON KOHNSTAMM is urged are quite inconsistent with the facts in his case. The assumption that he was unjustly committed is wholly unauthorized. That he was widely known as a merchant, and much esteemed socially, is true.

If the question of reconstruction were always approached in the spirit which pervades the speech of Mr. Senator DOOLITTLE, we might hope for a speedy and satisfactory adjustment of existing difficulties.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As one of the sufferers by the contemplated opening of New Broadway, permit me to thank you for the part you have taken in opposition to it. But have you not misapprehended the spirit and action of the meeting held at Powers' Hotel on Monday afternoon ?

At last we have reached Puebla. What roads! But to begin at the beginning. The first thing we are advised to do before starting was to empty our pockets of the few straggling pieces of gold in our possession. The guerrillas, or rather the ladrones, were the dread and the talk of all the Mexicans and old settlers. They are always prepared to be robbed.

SHOOTING AFFRAY IN FIRST-AVENUE.--Last night three Mackerelville roughs entered the lagerbier saloon of FREDERICK SCHEPELER, No. 180 First avenue, and drank several glasses of lager-bier, but refused to pay. SCHEPELER, incensed at this conduct, remonstrated with the fellows, when one of them, named JOHN DUGAN, of No. 198 East Eleventh-street, endeavored to strike him.

In the Senate yesterday it was voted to distribute 500 copies of the Madison papers among various libraries and departments. The House bill to extend the time for the withdrawal of bonded goods was reported without amendment. A bill was reported to authorize the construction of a telegraph to the West Indies.

THE PARIS EXHIBITION. Mr. MORGAN presented the resolutions of the New-York Chamber of Commerce, recommending that Congress take such action in relation to the Paris Exposition in April, 1867, as will give the United States a favorable opportunity for competing with other nations at that exhibition. They were referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

While the Congressmen elected from the Southern States are waiting in Washington for a decision upon their claims--while the affairs of the South, and the best mode of dealing with them, are being daily debated in the National Legislature, discussed in the public newspapers, and talked of all over the country--it becomes a question of interest

LEGISLATURE REPORTING.--The perfection of all reporting is to express facts in the briefest possible form--to tell precisely the thing said or done in the fewest words that will convey the meaning. We should like to impress this system upon congressional and legislative reporters, to induce them to give us something for our enormous expenses for telegrams.

To the Editor of the Boston Advertiser: Agreeably to your request, I send you a few facts connected with my recent visit to Washington. I spent four days, and almost nights, in explaining to members of Congress my draft of a national system of education for the United States. The memorial to Congress from my native town of Medford had brought the subject before the House of Repreentattves.

New-Haven has had a truly grand promenade concert; successful in every feature, and reflecting great credit on its managers. The object, so worthy and so directly appealing to our hearts and purses at this time-the replenishment of the treasury of the Orphan Asylum--brought many to Music Hall who would, perchance, have faltered at the suggestion of going to a "ball."

MR. WEHLI'S MATINEE.--Mr. WEHLI'S first matinee at Wallack's Theatre on Wednesday last hardly attracted the attention which it deserved. The attendance was poor, but it included many excellent people whose applause is worth having, and whose approbation indeed is a success in itself. When the entertainments are better known, they will, we are sure, become popular.

C., ( and whose address is Box No. 110 Wilmington Post-office,) the following list of the paroled ;prisoners and discharged soldiers who sailed from that port in the ill-fated steamship Gen. MORE CLAIMANTS FOR ESTATES IN ENGLAND.--Recently several members of the Tryon family held a meeting in Irving Hall, for the purpose of deciding on the proper measures to be taken to get possession of a certain estate in England known as Bulwyck Park, Northamptonshire, of which the Tryon family believe themselves to be the rightful claimants.

One of the most horrible acts of murder and robbery took place yesterday which has been perpetrated In this community for many months. Mr. DARWIN STEWART, son of Mr. E. PINCKNEY STEWART, who was formerly a well-known citizen and lawyer here, was shot by a negro, dressed in the uniform of a soldier, yesterday morning, about 10 o'clock, three miles from town on the Hernando road.

In the Senate, this morning, Senator ANDREWS, Chairman of the Committee on Municipal Affairs, reported the Metropolitan Health Bill, which was referred to the 'Committee of the Whole. The bill will now be printed, and will probably come up for discussion as soon as Monday next. It is said that BEN WOOD, whose seat has been vacant nearly the whole time, will take the floor in opposition to this measure.

COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert and Justice, Hoyt and Voorhies. The final scones in the Otero murder trial were presented yesterday afternoon. Promptly at the hour of 10 the court opened its session and the evidence for the defence was begun.

The one hundred Germans who lately left this city for New-Orleans, in search of agricultural employment, have made the following engagement with A Louisiana planter: Their wages for the first year are to be $150, in addition to which they are to be supplied with food, medicines and medical attendance, comfortable quarters and blankets. Their clothing and other wants they are to supply themselves.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have just read in the Cincinnati Commmercial your notice of Col. HOLLOWAY'S retirement from the Indianapolis Journal, which does injustice to the real editor, Hon. HENRY C. NEWCOMB. Mr. HOLLOWAY may be, and doubtless is, a very energetic young man, but his editorial connection with the Journal consisted of writing occasional notices of amusements in that city.

The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her parents, No. 97 Henry-st., on Friday at 1 1/2 o'clock. BEENY.-On Friday, Jan. 19, SARAH A., wife of Stephen Beeny, in the 47th year ot her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, Bedford-av., near Myrtle, Brooklyn, on Sunday, Jan. 21. at2 P. M.. without further invitation.

The trial of Gen. MERCER, late of the Confedrate Army, charged with murder, in shooting se?? Union soldiers who had joined the rebel army, for desertion, was finished to-day. The testimony was favorable for MERCER, and it is believed that he with be acquitted.

Gen. HOOD has returned from his Northerntrip. The planters in Lafayette, Vermillion and Colcasien Parishes, West Louisiana, had opened a system of planting on a small scale. The cattle interest in that section is very large and valuable, and, requiring but few hands, begins to attract more attention than before the war.

In the covered play-ground of the Five Points House of Industry there was an amusing and instructive entertainment last evening, got up for the children by the teachers and their friends. At one end of the playground a stage was erected furnished in proper fashion with wings and drop-curtain.

At a meeting of the property-holders of Mill Creek Bottom, a resolution was adopted appointing a committee to petition the Legislature to empower the City of Cincinnati to condemn all the overflowed lands of Mill Creek Bottom for the use of the city.
The Civil Code, which is proposed by the Code Commissioners to the Legislature for adoption, is a book of some seven hundred pages, aiming to be a body of the law upon the matters of which it treats.

The steamship Nova Sotian, Capt. WYLIE, which left Liverpool at 12:0 P. M. on the 4th inst., and Greencastle on the 5th inst., arrived at this port at 6 o'clock this evening. The steamships Hibernian from Portland, and City of Dublin from New-York, reached Liverpool at noon on the 3d.

FIRE IN A LOCK-FACTORY.-Shortly after 9 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the third story of the building owned by Mr. B. T. BENTON in Ad. ams, near John street. The fire, it appears, originted between the floor and celling, and the flames soot enveloped the upper portion, which is occupied by the Excelsior Lock Manufacturing Company.

SUFFERING ON THE PLAINS.--Throughout this section of the country the weather has been remarkably mild during the entire Winter months. On the plains, however, there has been intense suffering, resulting in the loss of property and life. SHERIDAN will likely proceed immediately from New-Orleans to the Rio Grande, in order by his personal presence and authority to keep the difficulty from spreading.

The New-Orleans Times of Jan. 11 published the following: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Jan. 1, 1866. Maj.Gen. Godfrey Weitzel, Commanding District Rio Grande and Twenty-fith Army Corps: GENERAL: Information has just reached me that a number of soldiers belonging to the army of Mexico, were this morning captured in battle by the soldiers of the (so-called) Emperor of Mexico, and that, by orders of the traitor MEJIA, they are to be shot to death early to-morrow morning.

The Eagle Flouring Mill, with 10,000 sacka of flour and 2,000 bushels of wheat, was burned last night. The mill was owned by Messrs. CARGILL, and was valued at $25,000. It was uninsured. The stock was owned by Messrs. FLOYD CO., and was insured in Hartford companies.

MARTHA GRINDER, the poisoner, was executed to-day. She made a confession admitting the murder of MARY C. CARUTHERS and JANE C. BUCHANAN, but denied the other charges of poisoning brought against her. Contrary to general expectation, her department on the scaffold was calm and collected.

SENATOR SHERMAN. -- The severe contest which has been in progress in Ohio for a year past for the United States Senatorship, has terminated by the election, or rather the reelection, of JOHN SHERMAN. His opponent was Gen. SCHENCK, who is a member of the present, as he was of the last, House of Representatives.

KINGS COUNTY OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert and Justices Hoyt and Voorhies. The trial of PELLICIER an alleged accomplice of GONZALES, the murderer of Senor Otero, was commenced yesterday in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge GILBERT, of the Supreme Bench.

The vote of the House on the question of negro suffrage within the District of Columbia has probably been invested with more importance than was due to it. The pith of the bill lay solely in the declaration that persons residing in the District should not be disqualified from voting on account of their complexion.

About 9:30 o'clock last night a fire was discovered in the cotton and storage warehouse of MILLER CONGER, situated at Nos. 248 and 249 South-street, between Pike and Rutger streets, and extending into Water-street, occupying Nos. 483 and 485. The firemen were speedily bn the ground, and about 10 o'clock six or eight streams were playing on the burning building.

Not withstanding the close of the war and the recent reductions of the workingg force in the Brooklyn Navy-yard, considerable activity is yet observable there. The old ships that were built before the rebeltion, and a large number of those that were so signally serviceable during the war, employ many workmen in repairing, altering and refitting, and many other Workmen are employed in building new ships to replane those that have been condemned or sold.

DEATH OF COL. JUDAH.--Brevet Col. HENRY M. JUDAH, Fourth United states Infantry, commanding the military post at Plattsburh, N. Y., died suddenly, of heart disease, at Fouquett Hotel, at 2 o'clock on Sunday afternoon. Col. JUDAH was graduated at West Point in 1843, and was a class mate of Lieut.-Geu. GRANT, GRANT ranking 21st and JUDAU 35th in a class of 39.

FATAL FALL.--An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY, at the New-York Hospital, on the body of MICHAEL HERNAN, whose death was caused by injuries received in falling down stairs. From the testimony offered before the jury it would appear that HERNAN, who resided at No. 218 Cherry-street, was on the 12th inst., in the liquor store of JOHN WALSH, in .. Market-slip.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Freedmen's and Union Commission on Friday shipped sixty boxes of clothing and school books for the South, for the benefit of the suffering refugees and freedmen. These goods, mostly partly-worn clothing, valued at five thousand dollars, were all contributed by the benevolent public.

The Canadian Trade Review professes to know that the United States Government have consented to renew the Reciprocity Treaty if Canada will raise the provincial excise duties to the American standard, ad. mit certain manufactures free, and enlarge the canals, the United:States bearing part of the expense, the whole matter to be arranged by the respective Legislatures without a treaty.

During the year 1864, when the cause of the Union imperatively demanded a large increase of our army, and the retention of the vast number of disciplined soldiers whose terms of enlistment were about to expire, vigorous efforts were made to meet the President's calls for troops without recourse to the unpopular resort of drafting..

The following is a correct version of the attempt to assassinate Hon. STEPHEN G. FIELD, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. Last Saturday morning, while the Judge was at his table writing, his mail was brought in, and contained a small package about four inches square and one and a half inches high.

At 7:30 o'clock the Hon. JAMES F. LEGATE called the meeting to order and nominated Judge T. C. SEARS as Chairman. The following gentlemen were nominated and elected as Vice-Presidents: M. W. Delalhay, James F. Legate, John Kerr, E. H. Gruber, W. F. Cloud, Thomas Carney, J. W. Morris, .D. R. Anthony and A. M. Clark; and Joseph Clark, W. B. Hutchinson, J. S. Coulter, L. Sousman and L. A LETTER FROM GOV. MORTON, OF INDIANA. -- Col. HOLLOWAY received on yesterday a letter from Gov. MORTON, dated Dec, 22, and written on shipboard, when nine days out from New-York. The voyage had been very stormy to that time, and the Governor had been confined to his bed nearly all the time, after the first day. Col. HOLLOWAY has kindly furnished us the following extract from the letter:

The installation of MARCUS L. WARD in the gubernatorial chair of New-Jersey, which took place yesterday at Trenton, was quite properly made the occasion of ;very considerable military and civic display on the part of the friends of the incoming administration. For these ceremonies have, in a certain way, a national interest, like the election which preceded them, and made them possible.

The Asia, at Halirax, and the New- York and Hansa at this port, bring additional but not very important advices from Europe. The Asia's news is two days later than that received by the Nova Scotian. Paris papers have little to say upon the Emperor's speech, which, it is asserted, contained nothing of political importance.
By the proceedings in Congress a few days ago it will be seen that a bill to establish a uniform system of bankruptcy throughout the United States was referred to the Select Committee.

Some very interesting figures regarding the operations of the cotton mills in Massachusetts for the year ending May 1,1865, have just been collected by the clerks employed by the State to secure its industrial statistics. In the eleven manufacturing counties there were during the time named 214 mills, [running 1,913, 750 spindles, consuming 46,630,250 pounds of cotton of the gross value of $49,683,919.

At trials, on Wednesday, the conspicuous feature was the bitter night of the 8th instant-a night in which the patrolmen throughout the city took the risk of fine for violation of the rules in entering dwellings and other places to warm their extremities.

Strangers complain of the lack of information as to the means of egress and ingress from and to the metropolis. The great event of the last month in this section of the country was the election of CORNELIUS COLE to the United States Senate for six years, to succeed Gen. JAMES A. McDOUGAL.

A RAILROAD RILL. A joint resolution extending the time for the completion of the Burlington and Missouri River Railroad, was passed. PENSIONS. Mr. LANE, of Indiana, called up the bill authorizing the President instead of the Secretary of the Interior to appoint pension agents, and name the boundaries. of pension districts.

A late steamer from Europe brings news that the British Government has resolved on a very considerable reduction in its military establishment, which reduction (to omit details) will amount, in the aggregate, to about 17,000 officers and men in the infantry, and one full regiment of cavalry.

Before Commissioner Osborn. The case of Martin, the alleged hotel burner, came up, by adjournment, before Commissoner OsBORN yesterday. Assistant United States District-Attorney Courtney tested the case for the government.

Major-Gen. HUMPHREYS and corps of assistants, accompanied by two engineers in the employ of the State, have gone up the river on a boat chartered for the purpose, and will make a careful personal examination into the condition of the levees in this State.

THE ALLEGED ROBBERY BY SPIRITS.--MRS. CUTLER AGAIN ON THE STAND.--A further hearing, in the matter of the robbery of ELIZA J. CUTLER, of No. 283 South Fifth-strect, E. D., took place-before Justice DAILEY on Saturday.. This ldy, it will be remembered, was robbed of furniture and money to such an extent that she was reduced. from comparative affluence to absolute poverty, and she attributed the robbery to spirits.

The royal mail steamship Asia, from Liverpool on Saturday, Jan. 6, via Qucenstown Jan. 7, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. The Inman steamer City of New- York, Capt. LEITCH, which left Liverpool at noon on the 3d, and Queenstown on the 4th of January, arrived at this port last evening.

The fire last night proved more disastrous than was at first supposed. The wind commenced blowing freshly, and fanned the flames after they had been nearly subdued, causing the total destruction of the building occupied by H. UTLEY, pianos and piano goods, and ACTMAN Co., clothing house. The building was owned by Mr. UTLEY, and cost $25,000.

FREEDMEN IN FLORIDA. Col. OSRORNE, Assistant Commissioner of the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, , for the District of Florida, has submitted a plan to Major-Gen. HOWARD for the consideration of the government for colonizing freedmen in Florida.

The guilty soul of Mrs. GRINDER has been sent to the judgment bar of God. At exactly 1:15 o'clock this afternoon the Judge's sentence, that she be hung by the neck until she be dead, was executed. The scene was a sad, solemn and deeply impressive one. The only person present who seemed to be not in the least affected was the murderess herself.

PROPOSED REUNION OF THE TWO VIRGNIAS.The Legislature of Virginia has taken the first step toward attempting the restoration of the ancient boundaries of the Old Dominionthat is to say, the boundaries it had before the opening of the war, when West Virginia, by the will of its people and the authority of Congress, was constituted a separate State.

HOUSES, RENTS AND RAILROADS.--The crowded condition of New-York and the enormous rents of houses are not because of the want of room on the little island of Manhattan, or the want of capital that could be invested in housebuilding.

ANNIN.--At Plainfield, N. J., on Saturday, Jan. 20, MAGGIE, daughter of Sarah E. and the late Joseph Annin, aged 8 years. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her mother, on Monday, 22d at 2 o'clock P. M.

EXCURSION TO THE SOUTHERN STATES. The House Committee on Freedmen's Affairs or a portion of the members will shortly visit some of the Southern States. The Orange and Alexandria Railroad Company has tendered to them the use of a special train from Washington to Lynchburgh.

Some facts have recently been brought to our notice, which throw much light on the practice of the Engineering Bureau in attempting to bolster up its defective machinery. It seems that last Autumn Mr. ISHERWOOD caused a statement to be published in the Army Navy Journal concerning the performance of the Nyack--fitted with his engine...

Political parties at the North, as viewed from a Southern standpoint, are divided into four classes. First--The conservative Republicans, under the lead of Mr. SEWARD; second, the radical Republicans, the followers of Mr. SUMNER and Mr. THADSAUS STEVENS; third, the mass of the old Democratic party, and fourth, the radical Democrats, like Mr. LONG of OHIO, and Mr. BEN. WOOD, of New-York.

FOUND DEAD IN A TUNNNEL.-During Saturday afternoon WILLAM TROY, an employee of the Harrlem Railroad Company, discovered the dead body of HUGE SELLEY, a flagman, lying on the trek near Ninety-second-street, terribly mangled. It is supposed that deceased was knocked down and crushed by a passing train. The deceased was 55 years of age, a native of Ireland, and leaves a family.

Intense excitement was caused in Memphis on the 13th inst., by the killing of GARRETT COLWELL, by a negro soldier. COLWELL had been arrested for stealing a carpet-sack from a freedman. COLWELL was permitted, with another prisoner, under guard, to go after bonds. Some excitement was raised, when the other prisoner escaped.

The steamship Asia, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 6th, via Queenstown on the 7th inst., arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

The object of the Democratic members of the House in refusing to postpone or to refer for the purpose of amending the District of Columbia Suffrage Bill, does not admit of misapprehension. He that runneth may read it, and he that hath no understanding may comprehend it fully. But its rectitude or expediency is not nearly so apparent.

The opera will be with us once more next week. The season of twenty-four nights-it will be seen by an advertisement elsewhere-commences on Thursday, Feb. 1. It will be devoted mainly to revivals. The extensive repertoire of the past and previous seasons enables Mr. MARETZEK to give unusual variety to his programmes.

The Legislature has now been in session about one week. The Democrats, having a slight majority in both houses, secured the organization. A contest is still going on with reference to the seat of Gen. HEATH, (Republican,) editor of the Omaha Republican, and military commander of the Eastern Division of Nebraska.

From the Charlotte, N. C., Times. Rumors are going the round of the public press, to the effect that these useful and necessary institutions are in an unsound and insolvent condition. It gives us great pleasure to lay before our numerous readers an authenticated and official denial of this report of " Broken Banks."

A dispassionate French -journalist, in. an article which we published yesterday, has put the argument for and against the continued occupancy of Mexico, in a more practical form than we have yet seen it. The Moniteur's latest defence of the actual situation, it will be remembered, was characterized by more than ordinary frankness. Said the official organ:

WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY.--Mr. E CORNELL, in the Senate, and Judge SELDEN, in the Assembly, have introduced bills to legalize certain proceedings of the directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company. The object is to authorize the company to issue three millions of preferred stock, with a guaranteed dividend of eight per cent.

Several of our citizens taking advantage of Gov. PATTON's presence in our midst, solicited the pleasure of hearing him publicly in regard to matters of State, to which His Excellency promptly responded by delivering one of his practical, honest speeches. We were present and listened with unfeigned pleasure to every word uttered,

Official news from El Paso, Mexico, up to the 22d of December, has been received here. The French marched in great force against the city of Chihuahua, and the Mexican Government had to abandon it. On the 9th President JUAREZ left Chihuahua with his Cabinet and his army, and came to El Paso. arriving there on the 18th.

THE EXECUTION OF WOMEN.--The fact of the execution of Mrs. GRINDER on Friday last, at Pittsburgh, by the order of and under the direction of a civil court, is, we suppose, in large measure due to the example set, a half year ago, by a military court, in the execution of Mrs. SURRATT.

To the Editor of the Utica Morning Herata: The comet discovered by Mr. TITTLE at Washington on the 5th inst., was observed here last night. It is a dim, globular object, apparently without nucleug. From two observations kindly communicated by the Washington observer, and the one made here, I have computed elements which show that the comet already is moving rapidly from the earth,

The snows and suns and drizzling rains of last week committed sad havoc with our streets, our clothing and our health. But a few days ago and tens of thousands of happy children, waking from a sound and healthful sleep, made the house resound with gladsome cries because of the falling snow, with its promise of sliding, driving, rolling and balling;

As our readers are aware, the bill establishing universal negro suffrage in the District of Columbia, passed the House of Representatives on Thursday last by a vote of 116 ayes to 54 nays. It will probably also pass the Senate by a decided majority.

Brownsville accounts of the 15th inst. give an Important and correct statement of the capture of Bagdad, which is as follows: A party of one hundred and twenty-three, mostly colored soldiers, belonging to the One Hundred and Eighteenth United States Colored Infantry, under command of Col. REED, crossed the Rio Grande at Clarkesville, and divided into three squads.

The Galveston Bulletin of the 5th inst. says that an engineer and pontoon train were embarking thence for the Pro Grande. Only 377 names were registered in Galveston as voters. The San Antonio Express states that 1,728 voters were registered in Bexar County.

Randolph, of Elizabeth, N. J. BASSETT--RICHARDS.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, Jan. 18 By Rev. H. S. Carpenter, ALLEN L. BASSETT and Mrs. ANNIE S. RICHARDS, all of the above-named place.

We suppose from all we hear and read that the idea is all but universally prevalent that the cholera will be in the'United States with the coming Spring. The impression is based partly on the course taken by the disease from the Orient through Europe last year, and partly on the fact that it actually reached our harbor last Fall, where it remained "anchored" for some time.

Another ice-boat race came off here to-day. The distance sailed was sixteen miles and return, the boats going to Newburgh. The Una arrived at Newburgh ahead on the down trip and came in ahead on her return. The run from Newburgh to New Hamburgh, a distance of eight miles, was made in the unprecedented time of seven minutes. Four boats were entered-the Una, Minnehaha, Icicle and Snowflake.

CHARLES LINDAUER being sworn,

CANADIAN BENEVOLENT SOCIETY BALL.--Last evening the tenth annual ball of the Canadian Benevolent Society took place at the Jones' Assembly Rooms, No. 656 Broadway. The order of dancing presented a very tasteful selection, and the order and grace which characterized tile movements of the " light fantastic toe " reflected credit upon the Floor Committee. There were about two hundred couples present.

A SAFE CASE FROM TROY.-The office safe belonging to Messrs. ROY Co., in West Troy, was blown open by burglars during the night of the 8th inst., and $13,000 in Treasury notes taken therefrom. After securing their plunder the thieves made good their escape, and nothing more was heard of them until Sunday night,

RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE WAR.--The Richmond Enquirer, in commenting upon some recent remarks in this journal, belabors Mr. SEWARD as the responsible party in bringing upon the country the late rebellion and war.

Mails for Europe, via Liverpool, per steamer Scotia, close to-morrow at 9:30 A. M.; via Portland, per steamer North American, at 1:30 P. M., on Friday. Mails for Havana and Mexico, per steamer Manhattan, close to-day at2 P. M.; for Havana per steamer Eagle, close to-morrow at the same hour.

The steamer Colorado has sailed for Panama with $995,260 in treasure, of which $934,074 goes to New-York. The overland mall, with New-York dates to the 23d, arrived last night. The ship Dreadnought, Capt. CUSHING, has arrived from New-York.

The Senate met at 7 P. M. The President presented from the Secretary of State the preliminary report of the State census of 1865. Which was referred to the Appointment Committee. Mr. LA BAN gave notice of a bill to incorporate the village of Edgewater, Richmond County.

An order has been promulgated mustering out twenty-two regiments in Texas. The White troops will be paid off at their respective state rendezvous; most of the others at New-Orleans. The Vote in Texas for the convension was quite small. the delegate selected are mostly of the conservative stamp.

We are not surprised to hear that peremptory orders have been sent by the government to Gen. SHERIDAN to take instant steps to enforce the laws against CRAWFORD and his fillibusters, who are attempting to get our country into difficulty on the Rio Grande.

DODWORTH'S HALL.--Mme, FANNY RAYMOND RITTER will give an exceedingly interesting concert at this establishment to-night, assisted by Mr. S. B. MILLS, Mr. THEODORE THOMAS, Mr. FRED. BERGNER and Mr. J. NOSENTHAL.

This board met at 2 P. M. yesterday in their own chamber, which has been thoroughly renovated since the commencement of the year. The reporters' table has been placed at the extremity of the chamber and behind a huge column, so that seeing and hearing are matters of difficulty.

The passage unanimously by the House, this evening, of Mr. LITTLEJOHN'S quarantine resolutions, is an indication that something will be accomplished by the present Legislature in the matter of providing suitable quarantine accommodations.

Col. WHITTLESEY, Assistant Commissioner of the Bureau of Refugee, Freedmen and Abandoned Lands in North Carolina, reports that so generally have the freedmen sought employment and obtained it that the demand for laborers cannot be easily supplied.

RECONSTRUCTION. An foreshadowed in the TIMES' dispatches of last Friday, the Joint Committee on Reconstruction today made their first report simultaneously in both branches of Congress. In the House, Mr. STEVENS reported back the constititutional amendment in regard to the basis of representation referred to that committee fortnight since, by Mr. BLAINE, of Maine, somewhat changed in phrase, but embracing precisely the same idea.

The thirty-seventh annual ball in aid of the New-York Fire Department Charity Fund, came off last night at the Academy. It was a grand and genuine success, the entire building being crowded with the throng of beauty and fashion, while the fiber was kept almost constantly vibrating with the busy feet of the dancers.
The following is the eloquent speech of Hon. H. C. DEMING, of Connecticut, delivered in the House of Representatives Jan. 19, a telegraphic abstract of which was published in Saturday's TIMES:

A fire occurred this morning in the Rectifying House of S. M. SPENCER, in this city, caused by the bursting of a still, containing sixty-five barrels of highwines. The building was saved by the exertions of the firemen. Loss about $12,000, which is covered by insurance.

Decidedly the heaviest snow-storm that has occurred in this part of Oregon for many years, has prevailed for two days past. It snowed all day Tuesday and rained most of the time yesterday. During the night the storm continued and it has been snowing uninterruptedly to-day.

Mr. WILSON has introduced into the Senate a bill to restrict the fees of the famous guild known as "claim agents." The majority of these persons have usually hitherto adopted no standard of compensation for their services--except the rather fluctuating one of "get all you can." As it has been found that, in thus creating "a law unto themselves," their clients get very badly fleeced,

In the Senate, to-day, the Free-school Bill was defeated by 9 to 8. The bill is virtually dead. Cotton is dull and receipts light; prices 41c. to 43c. for Middlings. The Nashville Blood Horse Association offers a stake to be run during the Spring meeting of sweepstakes for all ages, three mile heats, $1,000 entrance, $500 forfeit, $2,000 to be added by the proprietor;
The examination of Messrs. George W. MatBell and William Mackollar, proprietors of the Nation. al Police Gazette, was commenced before Justice DowLING, at the Tombs Police Oourt, yesterday afternoon.

It would seem from the recent communication of the Secretary of the Treasury to the House of Representatives, that his views are not favorable to any change of the law of shipping which shall allow those vessels which were put by their owners under foreign flags during the rebellion to receive again their former position as American vessels.

That sturdy and sterling friend of America, of free institutions and of reform, JOHN BRIGHT, has, according to the latest English news, made another great speech on the reform question in England, at Rochdale.

KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert, Judge Dikeman and Justices Hayt and Veerhies. The trial of Salvador Pellicier was continued yesterday before Judge GILBERT, in the presence of a vast crowd of spectators. In estimating the tone and temper of the Southern people it is unfair to consider them as a unit. We see on the one hand, from the pens of Southern writers, rose-colored pictures of a new prosperity, based on enterprise, industry and education, and destined to excel all the prestige of the past.

BABCOCK.--In Brooklyn, on Seventh Day, First Month, 26th, at the residence of her brother, Heary Babcock, ELIZABETH BABCOCK, aged 69 years. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at Friends Meeting-house, Schermerhorn, near Boerum-st., Brooklyn, on Third Day, 23d, afternoon, at 2 o'clock without further invitation. BOWNE.--In Brooklyn, on Monday evening, Jan. 22, CATHERINE BOWNE, widow of Rodman Bowne, in the 66th year of her age.

A meeting of the Commissioners of Health was held yesterday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, at the Mayor's office, His Honor, the Mayor, presiding. Dr. SAYRE, the Resident Physician, stated that information had been obtained by the last arrival from Gaudaloupe, that the cholera was introduced there by a trunk containing clothing of two persons who had died of the disease while on the passage from Marseilles,

The existing disorder in tile anthracite coal regions, says a Harrisburgh correspondent of a Philadelphia paper, calls loudly for some remedy. Murders and robberies are so frequent, that unless preventive measures are soon taken, it will be impossible for parties having legitimate interests to trust their lives in certain sections.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. FESSENDEN reported a joint resolution proposing an amendment of the Constitution of the United States, to regulate the apportionment of Representatives and direct taxes. A petition from Boston merchants was presented, praying for protection against the operation of Southern stay-laws. The bill in relation to the qualifications of jurors was called up.

This board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. BRICE, President, in the chair. A remonstrance by Mr. DALY, of the Citizens' Association, against the adoption of a resolution to pay the City Inspector $9,650 for expenses incurred in the late investigations before the Governor and Senatorial Committee, was received and laid over.

The report of the Commission appointed by the Provisional Governor in pursuance of the resolution of the convention to frame laws for the government of the freedmen, read in the House of Commons to-day, provides among many other things that freedmen shall testify in cases whenever the rights of property or person shall be directly concerned, either criminally or civilly.

SIGMA PHI.--The Sigma Phi Club of the City of New-York held their annual reunion and supper on Monday evening, at the Maison Doree. The club is composed of the graduate members of the various chapters of the Sigma Phi Society, one of the oldest of the college secret societies, who have become residents of the metropolis and its vicinity.

On Tuesday evening the Brothers senior prize debate took place at the Brothers in Unity Hall. The judge were S. E. BALDWIN, Esq., TRACY PECK, Esq., and Prof. PACKARD. Question--"Was the effect of Monastacism on the Middle Ages beneficial?" The first prize of $20 was awarded to E. Y. Hincks, Bridgeport; the second, of $15, to Edmund Coffin, Irvington, N. Y.:

THE WAY TO DO IT.--The New York organ of the modern Democratic heel-and-shinbone school of politics furnishes the following little hint of a process by which its party might be won over to the old-fashioned Democratic doctrines of "liberty, equality and fraternity :"

After the troublous vicissitudes of last week, the pleasant sunshine and exhilarating breeze of the past two days came to us trebly welcomed. There were few if any grumblers if the north wind was a little rude, and pleasant smiles blossomed in the wrinkles under parti-colored noses.

Rev. SAMUEL OSGOOD, D. D., delivered avery eloquent and ably-written lecture before the Historical Society last evening. The subject was "Washington in the Nineteenth Century." He said that WASHINGTON lived to see sixty-seven birthdays, and when sixty-seven are added to 1799--the year in which he died--we had 1866, and February 22, 1866, will close the cycle of days in his second life.

A dispatch from Colfax says: "We have experienced the heaviest rain-storm here that we have had sinee the Winter of 1862" A snow-slide had also occurred near there, burying: a house ten feet deep and killing one man. Advice from other sections of the interior represent that the creeks are flooded and the roads impassable.

On Sunday night an attempt was made to burn the town at 9 o'clock, a house and barn were set on fire, and an hour later Chase's block, in the centre of the town, was fired and burned down; also, DEYFOS furniture and liquor store, and the new bathing-house of FLKTCHER.

THE DEBATE IN THE HOUSE. This afternoon's session in the House was one of more than ordinary confusion, with a smart seasoning of excitement and disorder, sometimes amounting to turbulence. It was all about the proposed amendment to the constitution, reported yesterday by the Joint Committee on Reconstruction.

RELIEF OF SEAMEN. Mr. GRIMES introduced a bill to amend the act for the relief of seamen and others on the books of vessels lost or wrecked at sea, which allows compensation to officers of the navy and Marine Corps for personal effects lost in action with the enemy, not to exceed one month's sea pay; provided that no loss prior to April, 1861, shall be paid.

KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert and Justices Hoytard Voorhles. The case of PELLICIER, alias Salvader, who is charged jointly with GONZALES (convicted) of the murder of OTERO, becomes daily more intricate in its meanderings, more complex in its situations. The trial yesterday was characterized by most remarkable developments on the part of the prosecution, and by a theory of defence as bold as it was ingenious.

The joint resolution in regard to the Constitutional Amendment was discussed in the Senate today, and passed by a vote of 13 yeas against 8 nays. The Senate has thus reversed the vote by which the bill was lost last year. Mr. SCOVEL, President of the Senate, made an able speech, which was much applauded in favor of the amendment.

BLAIR.--At Nassan, New-Providence, on Saturday, Dec. 23, of consumption, MILTON L. BLAIR, of Scranton Penn., in the 30th year of his age. BANKER,--At Hyde Park, N. Y., on Monday, Jan. 22, of typhoid pneumonia, WILLIAM BANKER, in the 67th year of his age. EVANS.--On Monday, Jan. 22, JOANNA H., wife of Thomas W. Evans, of Nashville, Tenn., and daughter of the late David La Tourette, aged 30 years.

HAWKESWORTH-ZEBLEY,--On Tuesday, Jan. 23, at the Church of the Holy Trinity, by Rev. Stephen H. Tyng, Jr., JAMES ALLEYNE HAWKESWORTH and Miss ELLA D. ZEBLEY, daughter of John F. Zebley, Esq., all of this city. No cards. Wilmington, Del., and Philadelphia papers please copy.

A largely attended meeting of the Montreal Board of Trade was held to-day to consider Hon. JOHN YOUNG'S resolution as to the necessity of constructing a canal communication between the St..Lawrence and Lake Champlain. The Presidents of the Quebec and Toronto Boards of Trade were present.

In the Senate yesterday a bill was introduced to amend the act for the relief of seaman and others on the books of vessels lost at sea. A bill was reported to restrict the expenses of collecting soldiers' claims.

Mr. LA BAU presented the petition for the removal of the railroad tracks in Thompson-street. BILLS NOTICED. Mr. SUTHERLAND-For the incorporation of the village of White Plains. Mr. E. CORNELL--For a ship canal from Lake Ontario to Cayuga Lake.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read with much interest the editorial and other remarks in your paper relative to equalizing the bounties of our now citizen soldiers, and while I would not wish our treasury to be still further embarrassed by the addition of any unnecessary expenditure, yet I do feel that justice should be done our soldiers.

He has to restore peace after a civil war unexampled in its magnitude and almost unexampled in the strength and bitterness of the angry passions it evoked.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: when the war first broke out hundreds of thousands of volunteers sprang to arms at the call of the government, but as the conflict continued longer Than was expected, and our armies needed reinforcements, the ranks could no longer be filled by voluntary enlistment, and hence Congress was compelled to pass the Conscription Law.

The steamship Meteor, which was built in Boston by Mr. FORBES and others, with a view to being used in the pursuit of the pirate Alabama, and was paid for by Boston merchants, has been lying at this port for some time. She is represented to be a rapid sailer, and well adapted for the purposes of a privateer, her speed being set down at eighteen miles an hour,

BOORMAN.--On Wednesday morning; Jan. 24, JAMES BOORMAN in the 83d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at 10o'clock on Saturday morning; the 27th inst., at the Mercer-st. Presbyterian Church, between Waverley-place and Clinton-place, without further invitation.

The case of ROBERT SCHUYLER et al. vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad, otherwise known in the New-York courts as the Omnibus suit, was decided in December by the Court of Errors of NewYork, the court of the last resort in that State, in favor of the plaintiffs. The Judges awarded to the plaintiffs judgment and costs to the amount of $900,000.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL reported without amendment the bill in relation to the Court of Claims. Mr. GRIMES reported the bill to amend the act for the relief of seamen and others, with amendments, one of which guards against payment for costs accruing through the negligence or fraud of the officers making application.

In opposition to the memorial recently placed before the public as coming from the Union citizens of Tennessee, a call has been issued to all citizens who are favorable to the speedy restoration of the State to its proper position of equality and influence in the Union, to hold a mass meeting on WASHINGTON'S Birthday, the 22d of February, to secure this desired end.

The Council Grove Democrat of the 11th says that Col. J. H. LEAVENWORTH. United States Indian Agent for the Kiowas, Camanches and Apaches, and Col. J. H. DODD, Agent for the Navajos, arrived here on Sunday last, just in from the Plains, both looking well and enjoying tolerably good health. They departed yesterday for the City of Leavenworth.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--SHERIDAN'S admirable comedy of "The Rivals " was played superbly here last evening. We doubt if the cast has ever been stronger. Mr. ROBINSON'S Captain Absolute is one of those quiet, gentlemanly performances which we look for only in the proprietor of this theatre, but gladly welcome in any one else. The stage presence of the gentleman is unexceptionable.

The course of the debate on the constitutional amendment now before the House indicates such a diversity of sentiment as may lead to the defeat of the whole measure. As reported by the Joint Committee on Reconstruction, it provides that if any restrictions re placed by any State upon suffrage, on account of race or color, all of such race or color are excluded from being represented.

The impression made upon the visitor to the exhibition of paintings by the Philadelphia Sketch Club at the Derby Gallery, is one of disappointment rather than of pleasure, however modest may be his expectations before entering. True, there are in the collection a number of good paintings, and a few of more than passing merit.

QUARTERLY MEETING OF FRIENDS.--The customary quarterly meeting of the (orthodox) Friends or Quakers residing within the limits of the Westbury District, (the meetings alternating between Westbury, L. I., and this city,) occurred at the Friends' meetinghouse in Twentieth-street on Wednesday morning.

To the Honorable, the General Assembly of North Carolina: GENTLEMEN: Being duly notified by a dispatch from the President of the United States of the discontinuance of the provisional government, Gov. HOLDEN turned over to me, on the 28th of December last, the great seal of the State and other State effects in the Capitol, and I entered upon the discharge of my duties as Civil Governor.

The House has been occupied nearly the whole of its session to-day in the discussion of the imporb ant question of expelling reporters of the press fromy the floor. I chronicle the fact that it may go to the constituents of the gentlemen that the day for which each member is paid the sum of $3, has been spent in a crusade against the press.

PETITION OF THE OFFICERS FOR AN INCREASE OF PAY. A petition will shortly be presented to Congress by the officers of the revenue service, asking that their rate of pay be increased to an equality with the pay of officers of the same rank in the navy.

For some months past the officials of the Ncw-York and Erie Railroad have been satisfied that their road was infested by a gang of thieves, whose operations for nearly eight months have been the source of constant annoyance. These robberies seem to have been carried out in the most systematic manner, and despite the vigilance of the officials and the active measures initiated by them,

The English who sympathized with those who fought in America for the preservation, or, as it has sometimes been called, the restoration of the Union, cannot understand how any party in the North should oppose itself to the completion of a work that has cost so much. If the Union is not to be restored, one would say that much blood has been shed and much treasure spent in vain.

ALLEN was duly elected and is entitled to a seat in the Board of Education, The gentleman sent in his and other affidavits at the first meeting of the board, showing the trick whereby he was wrongfully counted out; and a committee was appointed to make inquiry and report to the board.

Some time ago we called the attention of persons who had made purchases of wearing apparel in Canada to a decision of the United States District Court in Michigan, which established that going to Canada for the purpose of making such purchase was an attempt to evade the revenue laws, and that goods thus purchased and brought across the line were subject to forfeiture unless the duties were paid on them.

THE MISSTATEMENTS OF EARLY'S LETTER. The following is the letter of Gen. SHERIDAN which appeared in the New-Orleans Crescent, of Jan. 12, as reported by telegraph: HEADQUARTERS MILITARY DIVISION OF THE GULF, NEW-ORLEANS, La., JAN. 8, 1866. To the Editors of the New-Orleans Daily Crescent:

The Alexandria Democrat, of the 6th inst., prints the following extract from a private letter of Gen. SHERMAN to a friend in Rapides Parish: I have seen several numbers of the Louisiana Democral, in one of which I met a common mistake which I have observed before, attributing to BRAGG and BEAUREGARD my appointment as Superintendent of the State Seminary in 1860.

ARREST OF ALLEGED COTTON THIEVES.--Two truck drivers named SAMUEL TUCKER and LEWIS HORSMAN, in the employ of LAREW WOOLEY, No. 126 Water-street, New-York, were arrested yesterday by Capt. DAVIS and Officer SCHACK, of the Hoboken Police, on a charge of stealing cotton.

A meeting was held yesterday at the store of SAMUEL, RAYNOR Co., No. 115 William-street, to take action relative to the bill now before Congress permitting the Postmaster-General to sell stamped envelopes at the cost of the stamp impressed thereon. The meeting was attended by about twenty of the largest dealers and manufacturers in this city.

A rumor was set afloat yesterday that the alleged privateer Meteor had been allowed to proceed to sea, the order of the court to hold her having been revoked. This story was soon discovered to be without any foundation in fact, by United States Marshal MURRAY, who stated that his officers were still on board the vessel, and that they must remain there until she was released by the regular process of law.

IN THIRTIETH-STREET. At 10 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the four-story tenement building situate in the rear of No. 219 East Thirtieth-street. The fire was caused by the plumber who was repairing water pipes. The first floor and basement was occupied by JAMES FITHICHT as a stable, and he lost two valuable cows; which were burned to death.

An inquest was held yesterday at the NewYork Hospital by Coroner WILDEY, on the body of MARTIN HALEY, a fireman on board the steamer Man hattan, who died during Tuesday night from the effects of a wound received at the hands of HENRY CURWIN, the second mate, as already reported in the TIMES of yesterday.

It is earnestly to be hoped that our inventors, machinists and manufacturers are busily making their preparations for an exhibition of their products in the grand French exposition of 1867. We trust no American's eye will be pained by another such ludicrous exhibition of clocks, buggies, India-rubber shoes and Yankee "gim-cracks," as adorned the great English exhibition of 1851, though even there a few most useful machines redeemed our reputation.

THE RIKER'S ISLAND MURDER-INVESTIOATION BEFORE CORONER LYNCH AND A JURY.--Coroner LYNCH resumed the investigation, yesterday after. noon, into the circumstances attending the murder of ROBERT MITCHELL, the mate of the schooner John Boynton, who was shot through the heart by a river thief on the night of the 30th December last, while the vessel was anchored off Riker's Island.

BURGLARY IN THE FIFTEENTH WARD. Mr. CORNELUS D. EARLE, who resides at No. 91 West Eleventh-street, stated that at an early hour yesterday morning his premises were entered by burglars. It appears that about 1:30 o'clock the servant girl, DOLORES SANCHES, who sleeps in the basement, heard a man moving about the house and saw some one scratch a match on the wall.

COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Gilbert and Justices Hoyt and Voorhles. The famous Otero case is ended, and but the final fall of the curtain yet remains. The confederates GONZALES and SALVADOR, alias Pellicier, lie in the Rings County Jail, convicted murderers, and on Saturday the Court will sentence them to a speedy and an ignominious death upon the scaffold.

Shortly before 9 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the Atlantic White Lead Works, occupying nearly the entire block bounded by Gold and Marshall streets, Hudson-avenue and the river, and resuiting in the destruction of an immense amount of property. One portion of the premises is occupied for the manufacture of white lead and paints, and the other part for the manufacture of linseed oil.

I have not been swift to rush into print with garbled statements of what the President said to Senator Smith and Representative Jones, (as retailed by them on the avenues,) concerning his relations to Congress, and the existing differences of policy. I have thought it more respectful at once to the President and to my readers to say nothing till I could speak advisedly.

FOOT-BRIDGES OVER STREETS. - While the question of city travel is being discussed by the State Legislature, would it not be well to give a thought to the necessity for footbridges, by which our streets could be crossed at dangerous points? The mere mention of such ought to induce some member to bring forward a bill on the subject.

ODELL--McLEAN.--On Wednesday, Jan. 24, at the residence of the bride's mother, by Rev. W. H. Pendleton, Mr. HENRY ODELL and Miss MIMA McLEAN, both of this city.

The inauguration of Gov. BOREMAN, of West Virginia, took place on the 16th inst. The Wheeling Intelligencer gives the following sketch of the message: The Governor begins by an allusion to the overthrow of the rebellion as Having taken place since his last message, and says it is cause not only of congratulation among ourselves, but of gratitude to Almighty God.

A very moderate snowfall lengthens the through journey in our up-town cars from one hour and twenty minutes to over three hours. The distance from the City Hall to Harlem is about seven miles. The existing companies do their best, The overtaxed horses likewise do their best; but two miles an hour or a little over is surely slow travel, even in a snowstorm.

THE HOMICIDE IN THE EIGHTH WARD, BROOKLYN--INVESTIGATION BEFORE CORONEB LYNCH AND A JURY.--Croner LYNCH resumed the investigation yesterday afternoon into the circumstances attending the death of JOHN MCDNALD, who was injured in a fight near the corner of Fifth-avenue and Eighthstreet, on the 16th inst., from the effects of which he died at his residence in Van Brunt, near Sullivanstreet, on the morning of the 23d inst.

JAMES BOORMAN, Esq., one of our wealthiest and most respected citizens, died in this city on the 24th inst., at the advanced aged of eighty-one, Mr. BOORMAN was born in Kent, England, in 1783, and came to this country in 1795.
Gen. R. C. CRAWFORD was arrested last night by Col. YOUNG, Chief of Gen. SHERIDAN'S scouts, on board the steamer Conlinental, bound for NewYork.
The brig Roseway, from Pernambuco, has arrived here. She makes the following report: Saw going into Pernambuco, Dec. 22, the United States iron-clad Monadnock, in company with two convoys.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I notice an article in the TIMES of to-day, in which it is intimated that the Board of Education, through the connivance of the clerk, was paying, or intended to pay, for advertising its proceedings in the Transcript, although the board by resolution prohibited such advertising after Dec. 31, 1865.

At present there is no danger of a flood at Sacramento, but the present storm may bring it on. Gen. STEELE, successor of the late Gen. WRIGHT in command of the Columbia Department, arrived at Sacramento yesterday. The steamer Pacific, from Portland, has arrived, bringing $419,709 in treasure.
BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. Requiring County Treasurers to give bonds to the State. For the better equalization of assessment and taxation. To submit the question of a new constitution to the people.

AN APPROPRIATION TO PAY THE ADJUDICATED REWARD ASKED FOR. Pursuant to the recommendation and request of the General-in-Chieg, thirty-seven delegates, notwithstanding the insufferably cold weather, with proxies of 124 veterans, who desired their names to be attached to all the proceedings, assembled at the City Hall, in the city of Albany, on the 9th of January, 1866.
