Massachusetts. on the other hand.

The pupils of Old Public School No. 14, (now No. 13,) who were taught by the venerable LEONARD HAZELTINE between the years 1834 and 1850, and are known as class No. 9, gave their honored teached a fine banquet last evening at the Steuben House, in the Seventeenth Ward, within a stone's throw of the old school-house. The cloth having been removed, Mr.

The schooner E. C. Johnson is ashore at Ship Shoals, and will be a total wreck. The Board of Survey have recommended the tearing down of fifty-six buildings on Old Point. Steamer Empire City, from Alexandria, has arrived with the Fifth United States cavalry for Charleston. The Fifty-eighth Pennsylvania was mustered out, and left for home to-night.
MISERY AND DIRT.--If no other strong reason existed for the immediate establishment of a through railway line in our city, the horrible condition of the streets would furnish a sufficient one.

In the Senate this morning there was considerable discussion over the subject of quarantine for the port of New-York, pending Mr. LITTLEJOHN'S resolution on that subject, heretofore printed in the TIMES, calling upon the general government for aid in the erection of suitable quarantine structures. Senator WHITE favored applying once more to Now-Jersey to obtain leave to use Sandy Hook and Horseshoe Bay for quarantine purposes.

A BETTER OBSEVANCE OF THE SABBATH.--A public meeting, by cooperation of all the churches, was held last evening in the Wayne-street Reformed Dutch Church, Jersey City, in behalf of the better observance of the Sabbath, at which lion. B. F. RANDOLHH presided. The proceedings were commenced by prayer by BENJ. IMBRIE, and reading of Scriptures by Dr. MATTISON.

FLOUR firm. WHEAT steady at $1 23 1/4 for No. WINES inactive. PROVISIONS dull. MESS PORK declined 25c. @50c.; sales at $26@$26 25 for city; $22 50 for country packed; ordinary mess in fair request at $25. PICKLED MEATS inactive; sales trilling. BULK SHOULDERS--Fair inquiry at 10 3/4c.@11 1/2c. for loose and packed, respectively. GREEN MEATS--Nothing doing. LARD steady at 17c.@17 1/2c.
We have been requested to publish the following correspondence: NEW-YORK, Jan 22, 1866. To Hon. Schuyler Colfax, Speaker of the House of Representatives, Washington, D. C.:

CHINESE AND JAPANESE PAPER.--At a meeting of the section of the Association for the Advancement of Science and Art, for Agriculture, Statistics and Physical Geography, held at the Cooper Institute last evening, Dr. MACGOWAN, the well-known traveler in Eastern Asia, gave a very interesting and instructive description of the method of preparing paper in China and Japan.

The steamship Hibernian at Portland, and the City of Boston at this port, yesterday, brought five days later news from Europe. The London Times and other journals have attributed the pressure in the money market to heavy exports to America on credit. Letters are published from commercial men refuting such argument, and showing that remittances have been most prompt, and that heavy cotton receipts are set off against British exports.

WINTER GARDEN.--Ruy Blas (in VICTOR HuGO'S play of the name) can hardly be regarded as one of Mr. EDWIN BOOTH's best impersonations. It is, however, a picturesque and effective effort, culminsting in a single scene of great power, which, on Wednesday afternoon, was very ably rendered by Mr. BOOTH and all the artists engaged in it.

"The previous question" undoubtedly has its uses in legislative warfare. It forms a check upon garrulity and factiousness, and is not seldom essential to the legitimate progress of public business. It frustrates the quirks with which an ingenious and desperate minority sometimes endeavor to effect a purpose otherwise unattainable, and enables a majority to overcome obstacles to the expression of the popular will.

A new counterfeit bill of the National Currency has made its appearance in this city. Its denomination is a twenty on the First National Bank of Indianapolis, Ind. The paper is stiff and hard and darker colored than the genuine.

The centenary of American Methodism was celebrated last night in St. Pail's Methodist Episcopal Church, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twentysocond-street, with fitting ceremonials and exercises. The church was crowded at an early hour, a large proportion of the audience being ladies and clergymen. At 7:20 o'clock the organist performed a congratulatoryy voluntary which attracted much comment;

The thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society was held to-day. EDMUND QUINCEY, the President, in the chair. Among the resolutions offered was one to dissolve the society which gave rise to a long discussion, in which WM. LLOYD GARRISON presented an exposition of his views.

Rev. JOHN BARRETT KERFOOT, Bishop elect of the new diocese of Pittsburgh of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was consecrated to-day in Trinity Church, in the presence of a large congregation. Bishop HOPKINS, of Vermont, presided, assisted by Bishops McILVAINE, of Ohio, WHITTINGTON, of Maryland, WILLIAMS, of Connecticut, TALBOR, of Indians, CLARKSON, of Nebraska, CONE, of Western Pennsylvania. The service were deeply impressive.

On the 15th December last, as we learn by advices received by ship White Wing, from Venezuela, the city of Caracas was visited by two shocks of earthquake. The first and most severe one was about 5, and the second about 9 P. M. The shocks were very strong and marked in character, and seemed to proceed from southeast to northwest. No very material damage was caused, though several walls in houses were cracked.

The steamship Hibernian, Capt. DUTTON, from Liverpool at 2:30 o'clock, on the afternoon of the 11th, via Londonderry on the 12th inst., arrived at Portland at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning, bringing 286 passengers. Her dates are five days later. The Inman steamer City of Boston, Capt. KENNEDY, which loft Liverpool at 1 o'clock on the afternoon of the 10th and Queenstown on the 11th of January, arrived here yesterday morning.

NEW STABLE FASTENING.--We have been shown an invention of a novel character, which will doubtless cone into general use and be efficient in saving valuable property in times of conflagration. It is a method of fastening horses in their stalls without taking any knots in the halter, rope or strap, and which fastening may be instantaneously east loose.

It appears that at the last charter election in this city there were three candidates in the field for the office of School Commissioner for the Seventh School District--HORATIO P. ALLEN, JAMES B. BRADY, and FREDERICK A. SMYTHE; that on the night of election the figures given of the votes in the Seventh Election District of the Twenty-second Ward were:

The board met pursuant to adjournment. Present--Aldermen Moore, Coman McBrien, Flynn Gedney, Reilly, Loew, Varnum, O'Brien, McGinnis, Van. Voorhis. The President being absent at roll-call, Alderman Moore moved that Alderman Flynn take the chair. Which was carried. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

The long-anticipated and much talked-of Light Guard ball came off last night at the Academy of Music, and the affair was, as usual, a grand success. The decorations were superb in their character and novel in their design, the music was charming and the company select and brilliant. In fact, it was the Light Guard ball, and as such was in every way a delighful and magnificent tete.
Some of the leading British journals are engaged in the task of accounting for the decrease of bullion in the Bank of England, which has led to the serious advance in the bank rate of discount.

Mr. DIXON reported the bill relative to the sale of postage-stamps and stamped envelopes on credit, with an amendment limiting its operation to the 30th of June, 1868. He asked for the printing of an explanatory letter of the Postmaster-General, which was ordered.

The Senate passed a bill to-day authorizing railroad connection between Winchester and Strasburgh. Several bills regulating the status of the freedmen, conferring various rights and privileges on the colored people, were also passed.

The writ of habeas corpus, case reported in the TIMES of Thursday, whereby Major-Gen. Hooker was commanded to have the body of Chas. H. Coles in the Supreme Court together with the cause of his detention, came up again yesterday afternoon before Mr. Justice Sutherland. The prisoner was not in court, neither was Gen. Hooker.

As Officer STELLGES, Of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, was on duty in Clark-street at an early hour yesterday morning, he noticed two men driving a horse and wagon, and observing that they were acting in a suspicious manner, he followed them, and saw them stop at a stable on the corner of Clark and Broome streets.

We observe with satisfaction that "General" R. CLAY CRAWFORD, the renowned commander of the "American Division" of the Liberal army of Mexico, is cooling his martial ardor in the casemates of Fort Jackson, below New-Orleans.

Much damage has been done to the interior of the State by floods. A freshet occurred at Stockton which was very severe in its effects. By timely and energetic efforts immense damage to property at Sacramento by the flood was prevented.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: In your report of Dr. ARMITAGE'S remarks before the Baptist Sunday-school Convention yesterday you say: "He dissented from the views of Baptista who retain their membership of the American Bible Union, because that Union had published works which inculcated principles antagonistic to the Baptist faith." Here is an important error.

While the Southern section of our country is organizing itself and being organizedwhile one State after another is doing all that is possible to resume position in the Unionthat other vast section of our country which, in general terms, lies West of the Missouri River, is also actively engaged in political organization and material development.
A man named BUCHANAN murdered his wife in Indianapolis yesterday. A difficulty between two prisoners in the Indianapolis jail last night, resulted in the fatal stabbing of one of the party.

The North American Review. No. CCX. January, (Boston: TICKNOR FIELDS.) This venerable periodical sustains in its current number the character, good sense and solid information earned by more than half a century's experience. Indeed, a somewhat larger infusion of light literature would make a more readable miscellany;

Hon. FERGUSON BLAIR, the newly-appointed member of the government, has been elected without opposition. He made a speech yesterday, saying that intelligence had been received from Washington that the prohibition in regard to the cattle trade was to be removed immediately.

A FAST CAREEB QUICKLY ENDED.--The Fillibustering career of "Gen. CRAWFORD" has been particularly short and not particularly brilliant. He has made a great sputtering, and attracted some attention toward himself;
The following telegrams has just been received here by Senator SUMNER, of Massachusetts: DENVER CITY, Colorado, Territory, Thursday, Jan. 25, 1866. Hon. Charles Summer, Washington:

Mr. THOMAS MURPHY presented the petition of the chief and assistant enrolling officers, appointed by the Governor in 1862, to enroll the militia, for payment of their claims. BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. By Mr. FOLGER-To amend the Revised Statutes relative to limited partnerships.

THE DEBATE IN THE HOUSE. The continuation of the debate on the constitutional amendment, to-day, developed to new features of moment. When the subject came up in the regular order, Mr. STEVENS suggested that it be the understanding that the debate should be continued through to-day and Monday, and the vote taken on Tuesday.

ERIE RAILROAD.-About 8 o'clock yesterday morning, a smash-up occurred to Express train No. 4, on the New-York and Erie Railway, due in Jersey City at 1 P.M., resulting in the death of a man and horse, and, as is reported, serious injury to six or eight persons, beside the destruction of cars. The accident occurred at Masthope Station, on the Delaware division, about 30 miles west of Port Jervis.

The steamer Stars and Stripes, Capt. HOLMESM, six days from Havana, arrived here to-day with a cargo of 1,000 boxes of sugar and 138 thousand cigars. The United States steamer De Soto arrived at Havana on the 20th, with Hon. Wm. H. SEWARD and family on board.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-The admirers of Mr. JAMES M. WEHLI, and their numbers, already strong, are rapidly on the increase, will certainly be glad to hear that the farewell matinee at this house on Wednesday last was not a distracting occasion of a positive leave-taking.
There was a large Fenian meeting at St. James Hall this evening. Hon A. M. CLAPP, Gen.

FIRE IN BROADWAY.--Shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire was discovered in the subcellar of premises No. 625 Broadway, owned and occupied by WHEELER WILSON, sewing-machine manufacturers, being caused, it is supposed, by a box of papers taking fire from a gas jet.

CHAPMAN--HAMILTON.-On Thursday, Jan. 25, at Trinity Church, West Troy, N. Y., by Rev. Philander K. Cady, Rev. EDGAR T. CHAPMAN, Rector of St. Mark's Church, Green Island, and KATHERINE A., second daughter of the late David Hamilton, Esq., of Watervliet. DAIY--MOORE.-In Brooklyn, on Thursday, Jan. 25, at the residence of the bride's parents, by Rev. Alfred H. Partridge, HENRY DAILY, Jr., Esq., of New-York, and Miss LIZZIE HUTCHINSON MOORE, daughter of Wm. A. Moore.

The Royal Mail steamship Java, which left Liverpool at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 13th, and Queenstown on the evening of the l4th January, arrived at this port last evening. The steamship St. George, from New-York, arrived at Greenock on the 18th. The steamships Etna and Cuba, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool on the morning of the 13th.

In the House to-day, Mr. LYONS, of New-York, obtained the floor, and spoke at some length concerning the New-York Court-house, giving a history of the structure from the time when in 1860 the sum of $100,000, was put in the tax levy for the purpose of building a Court-house, till the present time, when he declared that the enormous sum of $2,300,000 had been expended.

One of the pleasantest and most noticeable facts that presents itself to almost every Northern man going South, is the willingness exhibited on the part of the Southern people to listen to arguments and suggestions. That wonderful arrogance and disdain; so conspicuous before the war, are changed into an eagerness to obtain information upon points that they have never satisfactorily understood, and a readiness to confess their mistaken views.

Advices from Mexico to the 5th inst., tate that the Liberal Gen. CARONA holds a position within forty miles of Mazatlan. Although a strong force o French was at the latter place CARONA remained undisturbed. He does not attack, knowing that he could not hold the place if he took it.

The schooner Mary Jane, during a heavy gale on the 10th inst., went ashore at Bagdad. No lives were lost. The vessel was a total loss. The freight was partly saved. Both were insured. The steamer Dora Martin, from Shreveport for New-Orleans, struck a snag, and sunk, in Red River. She had 600 bales of cotton on board. The boat is a total loss. The principal part of her cargo will be saved.
THE HARBORS OF OHIO. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, introduced a bill to provide for the improvement of certain harbors in the State of Ohio, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce.

The steamship Java reached this port last evening, bringing intelligence to the 14th. The general situation of affairs was unchanged. The London Times continued its attack upon American credit, and had drawn forth indignant replies from merchants and the papers. The intelligence from Spain shows a very unsettled state of affairs, with no change of importance In favor of either party. Gen.

The good people of this city were wondering, a day or two since, how it was that for a week past they had been compelled to slide down glaciers of snow, or climb up mountains of mud, or wade through filthy rivers of slush. They had often so wondered before, but their last experience was, and may again be, more horrible and disgusting than can be expressed in ordinary language.

UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE. Before Commissioner Osborn. Commissioner OSBORN has given the following decision in the case of William Frankle, charged with selling counterfeit United States internal revenue cigar stamps:

The prodigious accumulation of wealth during the last ten years in Great Britain, under the favorable working of an almost untrammeled trade with the whole world, and the busy industry of the people, is producing its natural effect. The savings of the British people are poured into every country.

Special dispatches in the morning papers record numerous losses of life by murder and accident. On Friday last a man named GREEN was shot and instantly killed at Granada, Miss., by some unknown person. The night following a man named TELL was shot dead at the same place.

The small-pox is spreading among the negroes in the interior of the State. Accounts from the parishes continue to come in to the effect that the planters find the greatest difficulty in contracting for labor with the freedmen, notwithstanding that the highest wages are offered them to go to work.

A most ingenious and successful robbery was committed yesterday morning in Carmine-street, when $3,000 in United States Treasury and National Bank bills were taken from a bank porter by a man dressed in police uniform, the regularly detailed officer on duty unconsciously assisting in the robbery. THE CAREER OF AN ALLEGED FEMALE SWINDLER.--A woman named ELIZABETH NILES, but who, as occasion requires, assumed the names of Boyle, Mills and Miles, has for a long time been preying upon the benevolent citizens of Brooklyn, by making collections of money, clothing, or anything else which she could procure, under the pretence that she was engaged in the philanthropic work of assisting needy families who have nothing wherewith to keep body and soul together.

From Honolulu letters, published in the San Francisco Bulletin, of the 9th ult., we gather the fol. lowing: "A Great amount of excitement had been created in Honolulu on account of the abduction of a native girl by a Capt. THOMAS B. BANHAM, formerly a Lieutenant in the British navy.

Republican, who gives the following account of a strange discovery made near Waynesburgh a short time since, vouches for its truth: "Some lime since as Surveyor J. L. MCCONNELL Was passing down Smith Creek, about one mile from town, his attention was arrested by some characters on a stone at the roadside.

JAN. 27--In steamship Erin, for Liverpool--Mr. and Mrs. Maury, New-Orleans; Mr. George Cooke, Mrs. C.P. Hill, Miss P. Hill, Mr. James S. Blair, Master Blair, Mrs. E. Burke and infant, Capt. S.P. Selby, Mr. Thomas Pierce, Mr. John Holley, Mr. C.O. Larey, Mrs. Dr. John L. Roberts, Miss Augusta J. Smith, New-York; Mr. and Mrs. F. Gavdiol, Messrs. Richard, Napoleon and Gustave bavdiol, Calfiornia; G. Clements, wife and two children, New-York, and others in steerage.

The bill introduced into the Assembly on Wednesday authorizes the construction ot a surface and elevated road from the South Ferry to the Central Park, to pass through blocks and across streets in the most feasible and direct route. The cars on the surface road to stop in the centre of blocks--on the elevated track (to be operated by steam) to stop at Fulton, Canal, Fourteenth, Thirty-fourth, and Fourty-fourth-streets.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : It is with feelings of great pleasure that I'notice your persistent efforts to relieve our overburdened population by railways-that is, the proposed tunnel and aerial roads. I know, Mr. Editor, there is no room for any argument as to the great benefit that would secrue from this enterprise. An axiom needs no investigation.

To-day we are called upon to record another of those horrible murders, now too common, the shocking details of which create a shudder in the community, and give rise to a general feeling of insecurity. Yesterday morning, as two boys were playing in the race track grounds, in the northeast part of the city, they started a rabbit.

We desire to call attention to a communication in respect to the proposed Civil Code, which appears on our second page this morning. The subject, as the writer says, is one of more importance than anything before the Legislature, and a discussion of it by a careful hand cannot fail to be useful and of interest to all who have any care for the matter.

Not long since the father, mother and three sisters of Col. JULIAN ALLIEN, a merchant of NewYork, arrived from Poland. One son, MICHAEL MEYENDORFF, the half-brother of Col. A., remains an exile in Siberia, "alone and a banished man." Efforts, however, are being made to procure his release, that be may join his kindred in this country.

SEMI-ANNUAL EXAMINATION ON AT MANHATTAN COLLEGE.-The students of this establishment passed through the ordeal of a half-yearly examination on Wednesday of last week. The anticipation of the trial was for them a strong incentive to close application. during the first term of the yearly session, and the result quite. satisfied the college faculty and the other. gentlemen who assisted.

Tho Galveston News urges the sending of special Treasury detectives to Texas to investigate into alleged gross fraudulent cotton transactions by the government agents. The Jefferson, Marion County, Texas, newspaper charges the government cotton agents with downright barefaced stealing and oppression.

NOTICES. By Mr. VAN VALKENBURG-To fix the rate of are on the Albany and West Stockbridge Railroad at three cents per mile. By Mr. CURTISS--To incorporate the Brooklyn Groera' Association. By Mr. VEEDER-To increase the salary of the Kings county Treasurer. BILLS INTRODUOED.

After a winter of extraordinary mildness up to the 10th of January, we have a fall of snow which has suspended railway and telegraphic communication, and lay a foot deep level and three feet in drifts at the Crystal Palace, though only four or five inches in the streets of the metropolis. We are now likely to hare a few weeks of the cold weather so confidently predieted.

The report of Gen. BATCHELLER, Inspectorgeneral of the State, has been received. It furnishes the public with a comprehensive and authentic state. ment of the effective resources of the State, and the condition and value of the military property as it as present exists. This report is one of the most interesting and instructive documents yet presented to the Legislature.

The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House nothing was done beyond speech-making in Committee of the Whole upon the question of reconstruction. Mr. GREEN CLAY SMITH, Ot Kentucky, Mr. BAKER, of Illinois; and Mr. BROOMALL, of Pennsylvania, were the principal participants.

The New-Orleans Price Currenl reviews the reports from the different Southern States on the labor question, and shows the urgent necessity of the Freedmen's Bureau throughout the South taking energetic measures to make the freedmen keep their contracts for work, if it is desired. to raise even a moderate crop of cotton.

We understand, says the memphis Argas, that anumber of" German laborers have been employed on the cotton farms in the neighboring Miississippi bottom, on the other side of the river, and that so far they perform remarkably well. Picking cotton, we are told, comes pretty hard to them, but they show a most commendable ambition to improve, and are progressing finely.

All Americans who happened to visit Rome last year will remember Miss STRBBINS' beautfull statue of " Joseph," which was then generally admitted to be one of the most perfect works of art to be seen in any of the numerous studios of the Elernal City.

ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. Yesterday morning about 6:15 o'clock, as the Cincinnati express train of the Hudson River Railroad was on its way to this city, when about a mile this side of Croton, it encountered an obstruction of an unavoidable character. It appears that more than half the cars composing the train had passed the spot which furnished the cause of the disaster.

CBAFT.--On Thursday, Jan. 25,.at Titusville, Penn. of congestion of the brain, MILTON O. CRAFT, of.Glen Cove, L. I., in the 37th year of his age. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to at tend the funeral from his late residence, on Monday, the 29th inst., at 12 o'clock. Boats leave James-slip and 34thst. Ferries for Long Island Railroad at 9 A. M.; return train from Glenhead at 3:50 P..M.

CIRCULAR OF COMMISSIONER ROLLINS. The following circular, respecting the cancellation of adhesive internal revenue stamps, has just been published: TREASURY DEPARTMENT, OFFICE OF INTERNAL REVENUE, WASHINGTON, jan. 16, 1866.

A convict named JAMES LEE leaped from a railroad train on the 12th inst., while on his way to State Prison from Cleveland, in charge of the Sheriff. LEE was heavily ironed, and the train was going at great speed; but he leaped, striking on his head, inflicting a dreadful wound on his forehead.

Sydney, Australia, advices of Nov. 11, state that public affairs still remain in a disturbed state. There had been an extensive strike by the workmen on the Western Railroad, but it was quieted down and they resumed work. Rain had finally commenced to fall, doing great benefit to the country.

The civil code which has been reported by the commissioners to the Legislature is paramount in importance to any other subject now pending before it. It may be anticipated that so great a change of our laws will not be accomplished without serious opposition.
PUNISHMENT OF AN EDITOR.--The following is the sentence of the court-martial on the case of the editor of the Charlotte (N. C.) Times:

The history of Spain is one long record of insurrections and discord. Wars of succession and of political parties have been her bane and her curse. Two opposing principles--that of despotism and bigotry on one side, and of liberalism and progress on the otherhave distracted her people and retarded her growth for hundreds of years.

To the Members of the Army of the Tennessee: As the arnues were being brokon up in July last, I was chosen, in connection with others, to secure funds and build a monument to perpetuate the memory of the lamented major-Gen. MCPHERSON. The faces of the troops were already turned homeward, and but little could then be done din raising money.

DEAR SIR: Allow me to address to you the following remarks on a subject which deserves the close and earnest attention of Congress: The amendment of the constitution, now before the House of Representatives, proposed by the Committee on Reconstruction, retains the words of the constitution, article 1., section 2: "Representatives and direct taxes shall be apportioned among the several States which may be included within this Union, according to their respective numbers."

THE NEW-YORK INFIRMMARY FOR WOMEN AND CHILDREN, AND WOMAN'S MEDICAL COLLEGE.-This excellent institution, now in the thirteenth year of its existence, has just held its anniversary for the election of trustees at the Infirmary, No. 126 Second-avenue. During the past six years 32,000 patients have been treated by the Infirmary with highly satisfactory results.

From All the Year Round. John:Beadle was an honest man, with a large family and a small shop. It was not a ful circumstance in John's position that, his family kept on enlarging the shop obstinately maintained its contracted dimensions; that, while there seemed to be no bounds to the race of Beadle the business which maintained them was strictly limited.

Private information received here from the City of Mexico, from a reliable source, is to the effect that the French troops will not be withdrawn until the Emperor MAXIMILIAN is declared free from American intervention. It is declared that MAXIMILIAN will certainly not give any position in the Mexican Army to any Ex-Confederate commanders.

FACTS ABOUT PEAT.-Mr. T. H. LEAVITT has compiled a pamphlet giving a full description of the nature and method of preparing solidified peat, for use as fuel. The subject is of great interest, and must command attention. There are large deposits of peat in many of the States, and these will supply immense quanties of fuel of a very superior character.

LETTER FROM EX-PRESIDENT BURNET, OF TEXAS. The New-Orleans Picayune publishes a batch of documents furnished it by Judge DAVID E. BurNET, of Texas, who visited Washington recently to intercede for the pardon of JEFF. DAVIS. The follow. ing letter gives the result of his mission: NEW-ORLEANS, Thursday, Jan. 11.

The Philadelplia Press gives the following sketch of " REUTER'S Express." It is to be hoped that the facts given are more accurate than the statement made toward the close of the article regarding the partisanship of the dispatches. No poor scapegoat at Queenstown should be allowed to run off with the responsibility for the perversions of truth which were always to be bound in the telegrams REUTER reg. ularly furnished the foreign press.

The trial of Gen. BAKER before the Criminal Court had developed some interesting facts in relation to the detective system and pardon brokerage. It appears from the testimony of Lieut. HINE that last July he was detailed by the 'Assistant Secretary of War, and placed at the disposal of Gen. BAKER, and directed to act under his orders.

FATAL OCCURRENCE IN BUCKINGHAM, PENN.--A BOY SHOT BY HIS BROTHER.--On Wednesday of last week, a small boy, named FRANKLIN WHITCRAFT, aged about seven years, was shot and instantly killed by the discharge of a gun in the hands of his eldest brother, BENJAKIN WHITCRFT, about fourteen years of age.

B. M. steamships Princess Royal, Pelorus, Leopard; H. L. M. steamships Guer.

The steamer before reported ashore, near Plymouth, Mass., is the Wyandotte, Capt. SHERWOOD, of the Metropolitan Line, which left this port Wednesday morning for New-York. During the heavy storm of Thursday night she sprang a leak, when twenty miles east of Cape Cod, and was compelled to return for a harbor.

The pen of the historian is sometimes profane. The voice of the orator may become vicious. And when the ancient landmarks and floodgates of social life are attacked by either, humanity mourns. What sorrow then must bedew the visage of every Scot who hears that his time-honored bagpipes, drone, chanter, bellows and al , are not Scotch The skirl and the growl are not the proper companions of the claymore and the kilt.

SOLDIERS' BOUNTIES.-There is no danger of the so-called "bill to equalize bounties" passing Congress. It is not called for by justice nor by our disbanded soldiers. It would be an outrage upon both. Those interested in our national credit and our national debt-being the whole people-need not fear it.

At the annual meeting of the Union League Club held at the Club house, in the City of New-York, on the 18th day of January, 1866, the following resolutions were unanimously adopted: Resolved, That we regard the early passage of a law., establishing an improved and efficient sanitary system for the City of New-York and its vicinity, as the most important and pressing subject which can engage the present Legislature.

The gaieties of the present season in this city surpass in extent and magnificence those of all previous years. The public balls, entertainments and receptions; the concerts and the theatres; the skating " carnivals," and the displays at Central Park, exhibit a more general lavishness in expenditure;...

The pleasant and elegantly frescoed hall of the Liederkranz Society was well filled last night by the guests and friends of the Association, on the occasion of the third social concert and reunion given there this season.

ADAMS.--At Albany, on Friday, Jan. 26, of apoplexy, ROBERT SAGE ADAMS, in the 1st year of his age. Funeral on Monday, 29th inst. at 2 P.M. BOGART.--After a ?? off Sunday morning, Jan. 28, at Jamaios, L. L, GEORGE BOGART, aged 47 years.

Humboldt papers give glowing accounts of discoveries of diamonds, gold and silver in Idaho. AMOS PHINEAS Co., extensive lumber dealers of this city, have failed. Their liabilities are reported at $400,000. Notwithstanding the water in the river?? Saramento Was nearly twenty-three feet above low-water mark, the levee still held back the food.

All the intelligence from France points to the probability of a peaceful solution of the Mexican question at no distant day. To expect a summary, immediate and unexplained withdrawal of the French troops, were to assume a spirit of humiliation for which there is no precedent in the history of the French nation.

For the first time this season on Saturday and on the day before the sleigh-riding and skate-loving community may be said to have enjoyed themselves to the utmost limit of their capacity in that direction. Neither was it too cold for the full enjoyment of a drive, nor yet mild enough to poll the surface of the ice for the pupils in podography.

A fatal affray occurred on Gravier-street yesterday, in which H. L. NEWBURY was killed and Capt. OLDHAM severely wounded. The young man who shot NEWBURY surrendered. The schooner Neptune, hence for Rio Janeiro, with 45 passengers, was lost on the 10th off the Cuban coast. The passengers and crew were saved, and brought here on the Guiding Star.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a recent investigation of the First Ward, Mr. DUPUY, the indefatigable Visitor in that distriet, reports of an underground room which quiet equals, in its fearful condition of fifth and overcrowding, those described so graphically of late by the Police Commissioners.

The following is the statement of the engineer of the train which met with the accident on the Hudson River Railroad on Saturday: "I was engineer of the train that ran over a broken rail on the Hudson River Railroad on Saturday. My train at the time was running at the rate of 26 miles the hour.

Last evening a large and attentive congregation assembled in the Reformed Dutch Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-first-street. The object of the meeting was to aid the Women's Union Missionary Society of America. The Rev. Dr. MUHLENBERG opened the exercises by reading the sixty-second chapter of Isaiah and offering prayer.

Rev. Dr. SPRING'S Half Centary Palpit Reminiscences, which I have read with all the interest that his long and faithful ministry, his pure life and great usefulness, awaken and inspire, sets my own memory at work.

The telegraph gives us the substance of a free talk by President JOHNSON with a distinguished Senator upon the great questions just now claiming attention. If this report is correct, (and we have no reason to doubt it,) the President looks with disfavor upon the thousand and one patches sought to be forced upon the constitution by the legal doctors in the Capitol.

The public mind was shocked a few days since by an account of the sufferings of a poor emigrant woman who was ruthlessly left to die after her confinement, unattended and alone, amid the foulness and discomforts of the steerage of a passenger ship at the wharves of our city.

ARRESTED FOR PASSING BONUS MONEY.--Two young men, giving their games as THOMAS LOVETT and JAMES PHAIR, and hailing from New-York, were arrested at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Officer GREEN, of the Forty-sixth Precinct, for attempting to pass worthless bills at the saloon of THEODORE BLANK, corner of Montrose-avenue and Leonard-street.

The same policy of reconstruction and restoration which is now being so successfully and constitutionally carried out by President JOHNSON in South and North Carolina, Virginia, Alabama, Florida, Mississippi and Texas, it will be remembered, was inaugurated by the lamented Mr. LINCOLN, in the States of Tennessee, Arkansas and Louisiana, some time before his decease.

The following is the substance of a conversawhich took place to-day between the President and a distinguished Senator. The President said that he doubted the propriety at this time of making any further amendments to the constitution.

We have received copies of the Matamoros Ranchero, of the 6th and 7th, containing full accounts of the occurrences at Bagdad. Those contained in the paper of the 6th have already been published; those of the 7th are fully confirmatory of them. The Ranchero says on its Spanish side that it has taken pains to sift all the information received and give only that which is most reliable.

The house of Mr. JAMES McNULTY, corner of Middagh and Fulton streets, was feloniously entered on Saturday night, through the hall door, (which had been left unlocked,) and a suit of clothes, $300 in bills and a gold watch, in all valued at $450, was taken away. The money and clothing were stolen from the room in which Mr. McNULTY was sleeping.

SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS.--Nos. 8, 9, 44, 47, 56, 59, 64, 88, 107, 120, 154, 171, 172, 186. SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM.--Adjourned to Feb. 3, at 11 A. M., to render decisions. SUPERIOR COURT--TRIAL TERM--Part I.--Adjourned without day. Part II.--Adjourned for the term. The Special Term of this court will be continued the present week, by Justice McCunn.

From the Matamoras Ranchero of the 1st inst. further details of the capture of Bagdad were received, with the additiond report that Gen. CANALES, of the Liberal army, had counseled his men to accept no aid, or in any way to affiliate with the Yankee flllibusters. The previous representations of the lawless and freebooter character Of the Bagdad affair are confirmed.

FIRES IN BROADWAY.--At 7 o'clock last evenings fire occurred in the apartments of JOHN SCHAUSS, on the third floor of the three-story and basement building No. 636 Broadway, which was caused by the overheating of a stove, and spread, during the absence of the occupants, to the floor below, which is occupied by BARRON FORTUNE as a fashionable club house. SCHAUSS' loss by fire and water is $50,

A CITY INSPECTOR OF RAILROADS.--The Common Council has again revived the question of appointing an Inspector of City Railroads, at a salary of $3,000 a year. The roads in question, no doubt, need inspection. But no one has any faith in the Council's providing for such inspection by a salaried man at $3,000 a year, or at any other sum.

Three soldiers of the Seventeenth Maine Regiment have been under trial for the murder of a barkeeper named CARDLES, in November last. No evidence existed against them.

The French Exposition of 1867 is beginning to attract attention. The action of Congress, although dilatory and unappreciative, is nevertheless as far advanced as might be expected from a legislative body as yet imperfectly informed as to the character and importance of this Exposition.

The venerable President of Union College breathed his last at an early hour yesterday morning. This event occasional intimations through the press have prepared the public to receive any time for several years past.

THE DOCTORS AND THE HEALTH BILL.--The homeopathic physicians of this city are somewhat exercised on the question of securing the appointment of one of their number as a member of the Health Commission provided for by the City Health Bill now before the State Legislature, and they hold a meeting last night to take action on the subject.

The steamship South America, which left Rio Janiro Jan. 3, via Bahia, Pernambuco, Para and St. Thomas, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. Among her passengers is Gen. WOOD, agent of the Southern Brazil emigration-enterprize. The war between Brazil and Paraguay was still going on with vigor.

Advices from Yreka say that the weather up the coast during the past fortnight has been the most severe ever known. The snow on Scott Mountain is from twelve to fifteen feet deep. No mail had been received for twelve days. The telegraph line was broken in a hundred places. Communication with Washington Territory over the mountains is nearly broken off. and the telegraph line in the Territory is almost totally destroyed.

DARRAS' very popular work entitled "A General History of the Catholic Church, from the commencement of the Christian era to the present time."

Since my last announcing the visit and departure of the Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD and party in the De Soto little of importance has transpired. On the 17th the steamer Caravilla arrived at Santiago de Cuba, from Kingston, Jamaica. The new Governor of Jamaica arrived there on the 6th, and was sworn in at Spanish Town. He is also President of the Committee of Investigation on the late rebellion.

GOV. CURTIN'S message was communicated to the Legislature to-day. The financial report shows an improvement in the condition of the treasury since Nov. 90, 1860, of over $3,500,000, notwithstanding the large expenditures for military purposes.

Ex-Gov. ROLLIN died hero to-day, suddenly Both houses of the Legislature adjourned to-day in honor of his memory. The Mississippi is falling. The great Morganza Levee, in the Parish of Point Coupee, will be repaired in about ten days sufficient to keep the water out. German laborers and families are arriving at that parish under contracts to labor on the plantations. .

Long before the hour had arrived for the opening of the court this morning, every available seat, and all the standing room were occupied by an intensely curious assemblage of the elite of this thriving town. Ladies were particularly numerous, and of course, occupied the seats, for gentlemen are always ready to accommodate them.

In Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON introduced an important bill for the reorganization of the volunteer militia of the country under the general government, instead of the present separate State system. It was referred to the Military Committee. The Post-office Committee were asked to report as to the expediency of building or hiring telegraph lines along the principal mail routes, in effect making the telegraph a branch of the postal service.

Collector MONTAGUE has been removed from office, and J. M. TOMENEY appointed Acting Collector. Mr. MONTAGUE's removal was caused by his connection with certain transactions for which DEXTER, late special agent of the Treasury Department, is now on trial before a military commission.

The steamer Missouri exploded her boilers at 2 o'clock this morning at the mouth of Green River. The wreck floated down and sunk a mile and a half above Evansville, Indiana. Her officers and crew inumbered about one hundred. A report from New-burgh says only twenty survivors were taken off, including the wounded.

THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT. The final disposition made to-day of the constitutional amendment in the House was in exact accordance with the intimation given in my dispatches of last evening, viz., its recommitial to the joint committee without instructions. That disposition affords a pretty good index of the change which has taken place in the feelings of the House on the general subject of reconstruction.

Reference was made in our columns several weeks ago to the progress of an organization under the name of the American Bureau of Mines. The organization is now complete, and as the object is one of a public character, its purposes and aims ought to be as extensively known as possible.

Somebody has been at work stirring up the United States Senatorial question again in this State, and you may expect to receive a telegraphic announcement that a resolution has been introduced in the Virginia Senate for the purpose of nullifying the Underwood and Segar election, and preparing for a new choice. The scheming of the different cliques in the State is amusing, and at the same time perplexing.

The notorious JACK SHEPARD, Jr., as he styles himself, again escaped from the Sing Sing prison at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon. Ho dressed himself in citizen's clothes, and seized a horse and sleigh standing in the prison yard, belonging to Mr. BOWEN, of the shoe manufactory, and drove leisurely through the village, taking the route toward Pleasantville on the Harlem Railroad.

THE DIRTY STREETS.--As we write, the weather has broken and the streets are covered once more with a filthy slush of melted snow and mud. We have seen a few men armed with shovels, but very few, and these appear, from their purposeless efforts, to be wholly unused to the work of street-cleaning, so that the presumption Is that there is not an organized force trained to meet emergencies of the kind now existing.

CLEAN STREETS.--We observed a very old and very lean graybeard engaged in sweeping one of the crossings of Broadway a day or two ago, and around his hat he had a handbill, with some such legend as this printed upon it: "TheIndependent Patent Street-sweeping Company." The old chap plied his broom vigorously, and did his work well.

The Galveston Bulletin of the 12th inst. gives an account of.a desperate attempt of negro prisoners in the county jail to escape. The Sheriff attempted to put some of them in irons, when they attacked him with brick-bats. A guard of the Forty-eighth Ohio Volunteer Infantry was then called upon to put the negroes down, and the latter attacked them violently with bricks and other missiles.

FIRES ON RAILWAY TRAINS.--It seems almost incredible that cars in motion should be destroyed by fire in spite of all efforts to extinguish the flames, but frequent occurrences of the kind attest the fact. The latest instance occurred on the Erie Road on Sunday night, when the car belonging to the United States Express Company was entirely consumed,

SUFFRAGE FOR WOMEN. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, said--I present, with great pleasure, the petition of one hundred and twenty-four beautiful, intelligent and accomplished ladies of the City of Lawrence, Kansas, praying for an amendment to the constitution that shall prohibit the several States from disfranchising any of their citizens on the ground of sex. As the petition is very brief, I ask that the gallant Senate will hear it read.
The jury in the Starkweather murder trial returned a verdict this morning of guilty of murder in the first degree. They were out only nineteen minutes. The prisoner was remanded for sentence.

The Speaker stated the regular order of business to be the consideration of the following joint resolution, reported by the Joint Committee on Reconstruction: Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, (two-thirds of both Houses concurring,)

PASSAGE OF THE AMENDMENT. The Joint Committee on Reconstruction fulfilled my prophecy of last night in regard to their probable action of the recommittal of the constitutional amendment with more promptness than was generally expected. Before the morning hour had expired Mr. STEVENS reported the amendment again, modified by striking out the words "direct taxes,"

A telegram from London, C. W., says it is understood that a dispatch from the frontier was received last night by the military authorities, containing news justifying the placing of extra guards on duty, and calling for extraordinary vigilance for some important event. A despatch went over the wires to Ottawa yesterday purporting to give information of a collection of Fenians on the western frontier.

The report on reciprocity which has just emanated from the Treasury Department, and of which we had a very imperfect synopsis by telegraph, is a paper of far broader scope than we had anticipated. Instead of being merely a digest of former treaties, or a summary of the mutual benefits accruing from the Convention of 1854, we find that the report of Mr. MCCULLOCH'S agent takes a survey of the whole domain of international policy.

The steamship New-York, from Southampton Jan. 18, arrived at this port last evening with four days' later news from Europe. The London Star says It has authentic information that the French Emperor is ready to withdraw his troops from Mexico as soon as he can be assured of the safety of MAXIMILIAN from American intervention.

The grand assembling of the warlike tribes of Erin for the forcible expulsion of the Saxon from that sacred isle--a gathering that was to have eclipsed in power and renown the somtewhat famous array led by Agamemnon against Troy--is still further postponed; or, rather, a change of tactics has been made,

Orders were received at headquarters in this city this morning, from Washington, ordering the closing up of business and the discontinuance of Elmira as a military post. The military establishment. as at present constituted, consists of the following departments and officers: Post Headquarters, Col. KUSSEROW in command. Quartermaster's Office, under charge of Capt DANA, Commissary Department, in charge of Capt. SAPPINGTON.

THE RISING RENTS.--Some of the large business houses on Broadway are complaining of the threatened rise of rents for their premises during the coming year. They talk as vigorously as the poorer folks in other parts of the city, and demur as stringently to the curtailment of their profits from this cause as other people do to the curtailment of the necessaries of their existence by it.

The Stlamer Miami, which exploded on the Arkansas River, had about 250 passengers on board, among 'whom were 91 men of Company Thirteen of the Thirteenth United States Cavalry. The accident occurred at 7 o'clock in the evening, just after supper, and while the passengers were assembled in conversation around the stoves in the hall.

The Legislature of Maryland to-day appropriated $8,000, making in all $15,000 appropriated, to complete the work of enclosing, grading and ornamenting the Antietam Cemetery, which will be ready early in the Spring, to receive the bodies of the he roes who fell in that memorable battle. Their re mains, to the number of 8,000, are now buried in the mountains, roadsides and fields in that region.

ANNAN.--Suddenly, on Monday evening, Jan. 29. Gen. THEDORUS ANNAN, aged 62 years and 1 month. His relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral at the Presbyterian Church of Fishkill, on Friday, at 2 o'clock P. M. No Further notice. Poughkeepsie papers please copy. BLYDENBURGH.--In Brooklyn, On Wednesday, Jan. 31. RICHARD FLOYD BLYDENBURGH, son of the late Richard F. Blydenburgh, in the 30th year of his age.

THE FINANCE BILL. The bill introduced by Representative MORRILL, from the Committee on Ways and Means, to-day, provides as follows: First-That the act entitled "An act to provide Ways and means to support the government," approved March 3, 18665, shall be extended and construed to authorize the Secretary of the Treasury,

Offical news has been received here up to the 5th of January, from El Paso, the residence of the Mexican government. Gen. IGNACIA MEJIA, one of defenders of Puebla, has been appointed Secretary of War in President JUAREZ' Cabinet. The French have not made another attempt to attack El Paso. Gen. FERRAGO's division was close by, and the place is looked upon as entirely safe.

THE NEW ANNOUNCEMENT FROM FRANCE.-Statements come to us from France more positive and definite than ever that the Emperor is making preparations to withdraw his troops from Mexico. By the Africa, whose telegraphic news we give this morning, we have it stated on the authority of the Paris Presse,

The crew of the clipper-ship White Swallow, just arrived from New-York, have been arrested for mutiny while off the coast of South America. Advices from Honolulu to the 6th state that much trouble exists with the coolies, who are setting all rules and regulations at defiance, The U. S. steamer Lancaster loft Honolulu on the 6th for a cruise to Hilo,

ELTING--OVERTON.--On Wednesday, Jan. 31, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Peter Stryker, EVERETT ELTING and Miss EMMA J. OVERTON, daughter of R. C. Overton, all of this city. No cards. GOSLING--LA GRANGE.--On Thursday, Feb. 1, by his Honor Mayor Hoffman, J. LAFAYETTE GOSLING and SOPHIE S. LA GRANGE, all of this city. No cards.

The condition of the country at present awakens a wide and searching interest in the future of our mineral lands. They are real wealth, but like any other land, only so when combined with intelligent labor. The labor they require, however, differs in quality from any other, and the responsibilities of the chiefs are in some respects singular.

The steamship Africa, Capt. HOCKLEY, left Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 29th, Queenstown the evening of the 21st, and arrived at Halifax at 12:30 P. M., Feb. 1. She has 18 passengers for Halifax and 47 for Boston. The steamship City of Cork also left Liverpool the 29th for New-York.

INCENDIARY FIRES.--On Wednesday night and early yesterday morning three incendiary fires took place in the Eastern District, involving a loss of about $3,000. At 10 o'clock the barn and coach-house owned by HENRY BEDELL, and occupied by Mr. BACKUS, near the Penny Bridge, Meeker-avenue, was consumed. Loss on building, $1,000; on stock, $200....Shortly

Cattle are in ligh supply. Beef offerings, $5 75 a head. The week opened with a strong market, owing to short supply, the severe weather keeping several lots back, including 200 head detained on the Ohio by ice. Sales at an advance of 3/4c. The rates obtained do not show this improvement the quality of the cattle not being equal to last week's receipts.

Mr. THADDEUS STEVENS and his radical friends are not unlikely to overshoot their mark. Their fiery zeal will in due time defeat itself, and bring upon their own heads the punishment with which they threaten others. For all this agitation in Congress, this piling up of amendments to the constitution,

The first five-night season of a series of dramatic performances, under the auspices of the Ama tour Dramatic Club, is now very agreeably in progress at Mr. JEROME's elegant theatre in Twenty-sixth. street. A few weeks since it was stated that Mr. JEROME had given the use of his theatre for a short time to JUIGNET DRIVET's excellent French troupe, pending the completion of their house in Fourteenth. street,

Mr. PIERSON presented a petition asking that Dr. E, R. SQUIBB be appointed Health Commissioner for Brooklyn. Also, for a Belgian pavement in Kentavenue, Brooklyn. BILLS REPORTED. By Mr. Low-To facilitate the construction of the New-York and Oswego Midland Railroad. Mr. WILLIAMS presented a minority report against the same.

A fire broke out here about 4 o'clock this morning, which destroyed twenty-four buildings in the centre of the town, among which were the post-office, Lamberton House, Stanford's Theatre Building, and the Masonic building just completed. The loss is estimated at half a million of dollars, about one-half of which is covered by insurance, principally in Eastern companies.

SUICIDE OF AN UNKNOWN MAN.--Yesterday afternoon tan unknown man, who was laboring under an attack of delirium tremens, while in transit across the East River on a South Brooklyn ferry-boat, attempted to walk overboard as the boat neared the slip on the New-York side, but waa seized by a passenger, though he ultimately succeeded in breaking away, and sprang into the river.

MEXICO A PARADISE.--The country will doubtless be surprised at the announcement, but it is nevertheless our duty to state the fact, that MAURY, the great, the irrepressible MAURY, M. F.-in other words Deep-Sea-Current MAURY--has a brother.

An eulogium on the late VALENTINE MOTT, M.D., L. L. D., was delivered last evening by Dr. GUNNING S. BED FORD, before the New --York County Medical Society, at Cliuton Hail, Astor -- place, and the speaker was attentively listened to by a large and apperciative audience mainly composed of the medical profession of this city.

BURCHARD.--On Tuesday, Jan. 30. CHARLES BURCHARD, in the 91st year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this day, (Friday,) Feb. 2, at 10 1/2 o' clock A.M., at his late residence, Rockville Centre, L. L. The remains will be taken to Greenwood. BABCOCK.--Suddenly, on Sunday, Jan. 28, JOHN H. BABCOCK, aged 41 years and 6 months.

We published recently, entire, an authentic copy of the proposed amendment to the School law of this city. The features particularly worthy of note in the sections published are as follows: 1. The colored schools are, by the provisions of the proposed amendment, placed directly under the control of the Board of Education.

HOTEL "DEAD-HEADS.--We heard, some time ago, that a number of the leading hotelkeepers had determined to expel all deadheads" from their respective houses--that they were to be refused lodgings, rooms or gratuities of any kind, and were to be thrown entirely upon their own resources.

The lecture of Major-Gen. O. O. HOWARD in Music Hall this evening, delivered under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association, was attended by a large and appreciative audience. Gov. BULLOCK presided, and introduced the General in his usual eloquent style.

A meeting of capitalists and merchants was held in this city, at the rooms of the Board of Trade, to consider the interests of the Northern Prcific Railroad. Speeches were made by Edward S. Toby, who presided; Ex-Gov. Smith, of Vermont, the new President of the company;

INTIMATION.--Mr. STEPHEN H. BRANCH has found a prone imitator in the Tribune, which has adopted that gentleman's device of printing a black list of public men consigned to political death. The prototype in this ingenious business had more courge than his follower.

SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS.--Held by Justice SUTHERLAND. No. 171. SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM.--Adjourned to Saturday, Feb. 3, at 11 A. M., to render decisions. SUPERIOR COURT--TRIAL TERM.--Both parts adjourned to Monday next. COMMON PLEAS.--Both parts adjourned for the term. The Special Term will be held by Judge BRADY.

Our Washington dispatches, a few days since, mentioned the reception by President JOHNSON of a manifesto or protest against the imprisonment or trial of RAPHAEL SEMMES. The complete document is now before us, and we give it entire. It is in SEMMES' own handwriting, and is got up with great care.

THE SECRETARY OF STATE.--A writer in the Post has discovered a wonderful reason for the warm reception given to Secretary SEWARD in Havana. It is "explained by the fact that these were demonstrations in favor of the kidnapping of Col. ARGUELLES. There can be no other explanation."

THE TWO VIRGINIAS.--If the people of Eastern Virginia are as anxious as their resolutions and actions would seem to show, to secure reunion with what was once the Western section of their State, we can tell them a better plan for paving the way to bring it about than by the appointment of Commissioners to the West Virginia Legislature. Let them exhibit a spirit somewhat less sectional and bitter, somewhat more

On Tuesday evening the New-York City Mission held their monthly meeting in the Brick Presbyterian church, A. R. WETMORE, Esq., presiding. Rev. GEORGE J. MINGINS, lately appointed Superintendent of Missions, referring to his early missionary work in Philadelphia and his more recent connection with the grand operations of the United States Christian commission, said there is no greater field for philanthropic effort than that we find at our own doors.

The steamer Atlanta, from Aspinwal, Jan. 23, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings later intelligence from South America. Hon. F. HASSAWREK, United States Minister to Ecuador, was a passenger on the Atlantic, having obtained leave of absence from his post.

The steamship Africa, from Liverpool Jan. 20, via Queenstown Jan. 21, reached Halifax yesterday. It is announced, on the authority of the Paris Press, that Baron SALLARD left Paris on the 15th ult., to arrange with MAXIMILIAN for the speedy return of the French troops from Mexico.

This board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, the President, Mr. BRICK, in the chair. Mr. VARNUM presented a resolution requesting the Committee on Streets to inquire into the expediency of adopting a plan of renumbering the streets somewhat resembling that adopted in Philadelphia. Mr. ELY said the plan was being put in practice as fast as possible.

The board met pursuant to adjournment. Present--John Brice, Esq., President, in the chair; Aldermen Moore, Coman, Norlon, Flynn, shannon, Gedney, Ely, Ryers, Reilly, Loew, Masterson, Varnum, O'Brien, McGinnts, Van Voorhis. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

The Senate bill ordering an election of parochial officers in all parishes on the second Monday in March, passed the House to-day. The House Judiciary Committee have reported adversely to all bills and plans looking to a "stay law." The Ouachita River commenced rising again on the 27th, but cotton was coming into Monroe from the back country.

The readers of the Tribune, accustomed as they are to its vagaries, must have been struck to find that journal advocating a PARTISAN Board of Health: "The Health Bill, as reported, is a scheme to increase the power and patronage of the little band of wireworkers in our city who are distinctively

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. MARETZEK'S season opened last evening. The house was crowded to its greatest capacity. There was not a seat to be had, long before the performance commenced. People contented themselves with the back ranges, and listened to a performance which in every leading respect was admirable.

The U. S. steamer Narcissus, from Pensacola for New-York, was lost during a storm on Egmont Key, (entrance to Tampa Bay, Fla.,) with all on board, about thirty souls. The U. S. tug Althea left Pensacola in company with the Narcissus, and arrived safely at Key West. One body was washed ashore from the Narcissus, but could not be recognized.

History, or tradition, informs us of a youthful genius who suggested to his father that, instead of asking the regular blessing at breakfast, time would be economized by blessing the pork in barrel. An Assembly genius, taking that idea, proposes, instead of legislating for this city in detail, to comprehend all its wants and woes in a single enactment.

IN THE BALANCE DRY DOCK. At about 5:15 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the Balance Dry Dock, at the foot of Rutgersstreet, East River, which was promptly subdued by the efforts of the officers and crew of the United States steamer Catawba, Capt. HILL, which at the first alarm steamed over from the Navy-yard. The loss is estimated at $1,500, and covered by insurance.

In Committee of the Whole in the House today, a bill was considered to increase the compensation of the various clerks in the State departments of government, appropriating $27,000 for that purpose. The increase is to be for the calendar year commencing Jan. 1, 1866, and is on the following scale; On all salaries under $1,500, an increase of 85 per cent.; all salaries of $1,600 and less than $2,000,

SOCIATION.--A public meeting was held yesterday afternoon in the Baptist Church, Grove-street, Jersey City, for the purpose of organizing a County Temperance Association, as an auxiliary to the State Temperance Association recently organized at New-Brunswick. Rev. W. H. PARMLY presided, and Rev. J. W. CUSTIS acted as Secretary. A constitution, prepared by a committee previously appointed,...

SLAVERY IN CUBA AND BRAZIL.--If our emancipated negroes throughout the South prove by their conduct during the coming Summer that they can carry on the operations of industry faithfully and profitably as freemen, the fact will exercise an immense influence upon slavery in Cuba and Brazil.

The show may be said to have opened this morning; that is, if the presence of the Hen. P. T. BARNUM, the great showman, within the bar may lend that character to the court-room. But no, Mr. BARNUM merely stepped in, in common with the other curiosity-seekers, to see what was going on. The court-room was again crowded.

BERGER.--In this city, on Thursday, Feb. 1, FRANCIS ELVI BERGER, M. D., in the 77th year of his age. His friends and the friends of the family, and the medical faculty, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral services at the Church of the Ascension corner of 5thav. and 10th-st., on Monday afternoon, the 5th inst., at 3 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation.

The steamer Sierra Nevada, so long fast on a rock up the coast, arrived to-day from Portland. Tile overland mail, with New-York dates of Jan. 3 has arrived. The sailors of the ship White Swallow, arrested here for mutiny, state that their action was occasioned by the brutal treatment received from their officers, and was adopted for self-protection.

SUPERIOR COURT--SPECIAL TERM.--FEB. 2. By Justice McGunn. A. W. Lord vs. Edward Ingraham; motion granted. Anna Vernon vs. Jacob Little; order granted. Lebbens Chapman vs. L. J. Moore, order granted. Clement Heerdt vs. Henry A. Whitmore:

The New-Albany Ledger says that the steamer Charmer went to the wreck of the steamer Missouri, on Tuesday morning, and succeeded in getting the safe and books, Mr. MALL, clerk of the Missouri, has gone to Evansville to obtain possession of them, and will be able to make out a complete list of the lost.

MARINE COURT. Before Judge M. G. Gross In the case of Franz Schief vs. Martin Stubb, Captain of the schooner Coral Isle, the testimony in which case is too indecent for publication. Judge GROSS, yesterday, delivered the following OPINION: The action was brought by plaintiff against the defendant for an alleged assault and battery. The plaintiff was cook on board the Coral Isle, of which vessel the defendant was the Captain.

THE CIVIL RIGHTS BILL. The Civil Rights Bill which passed the Senate today is generally regarded as one of the most important before this Congress. Its first section provides that all persons born in the United States, and not subject to any foreign power or tribal authority, excluding Indians, are hereby declared to be citizens of the United States.

IN CROSBY-ST. A few minutes before 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire was discovered at No. 129 Crosbystreet, occupied by GRORGE A. BALDWIN, as a carriagemanufactory, originating in the second floor of the rear building, known as the wood-shop.

We see in the columns of a morning cotemporary a story of the proprietor of a shop or store having raised his rent at one sweep from $15,000 to $50,000 a year. The lessee was offered the privilege, in the first instance, of renewing his lease for a certain term at $40,000.

MOVEMENTS OF POPULATION.--There are no statistics attainable that give any approximate idea of the extent to which migration into the Southern States is now going on. There are several large companies in this city engaged in the work of forwarding to that region the foreign immigrants to our shores.

THE WAR ENDED--PEACE DECLARED.--During the last five years the country has passed through a terrible civil war, but, thank God! that it is over, no more to return. The great issues involved have been solved, ?? to be opened. But during that time that has not been the only war that has vexed the nation.

IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION.--We see it stated in a Mobile journal that a large property owner--a Southerner apparently-in Alabama has been appointed an agent of the Freedmen's Bureau. We do not learn what wore the particulars of the appointment.

The following important letter has been written by Major-Gen. SHERMAN to the President, giving the origin and history of his famous "Special field Order, No. 15," which gave the freedmen possessory titles to the Sea Islands of South Carolina and Georgia: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2, 1866. To Andrew Johnson, President of the United States: SIR: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt last evening of your letter of Feb. 1 and in compliance

The House of Representatives has passed the resolution to amend the Constitution of the United States changing the basis of representation. Hitherto that basis has been the whole number of free persons and three-fifths of all others. This gave the slaveholding States a representation of all their free persons, and about 2,400,000 in addition thereto--assuming their slaves to number 4,000,000.

MATINEE AT THE NEW-YORK CIRCUS,--One of those popular and enjoyable semi-weekly reunions will take place to-day, at 2:30 o'clock, at the "family resort." on Fourteenth-street, opposite the Academy of Music. Mr. JAMES ROBINSON, who is generally considered the champion rider of the world, will ride his emotional act, in which he will introduce his tiny pet equestrian, Master CLARENOE, Mr. LEVI J. NORTH, Mme, LOUISE TOURNAIRE, and the whole of the company, will appear.

To the Senate of the United States: In answer to the resolution of the Senate of the 30th ultimo, requesting the President, if not incompatible with the public interests, to communicate to the Senate a copy of the late report ot Major-Gen. SHERMAN upon the condition of the States in his department, in which he has lately made a tour of inspection.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--The board met yesterday afternoon, Supervisor TALBOT, the President, in the chair. The special business to appoint two additional assessors in the county towns was brought up, and argued at length, when the subject was laid upon the table until next meeting. Gen. CROOKE presented a petition in favor of making a macademised road from Brooklyn to Calvary Cemetery in Flatbush.

The first annual meeting of the club. for the year 1866 was held, last evening, at DELMONICO'S, Fourteenth-street and Fifth-avenue, for the election of officers and the transaction of other business of the association. Before proceeding to the election,

FAR WESTERN RAILROADS.--The people of Texas are being "stirred up" at present about the construction of a railroad which it is proposed to run nearly due north from the Gulf of Mexico, at Galveston, as high as St. Joseph, in Missouri, at which point it will have connection with the great Eastern lines.

PROFESSOR BLOT'S LECTURES ON COOKING.-Professor BLOT purposes to give a course of lectures on cooking, in the lecture-room of the Brooklyn Institute, Washington-street, near Concord, so soon as he can form his classes. The lectures will be delivered on Tuesday and Fridays, at 1 P. M. Subscription lists are now open at No. 10 Front-street, Brooklyn, and on Wednesdays and Thursdays at the institute.

LOSSES OF LOYALISTS.--One of the preposterous schemes which have got before Congress somewhat analogous to the claims of compensation for the emancipation of slaves, or to the bill for equalizing bounties, is the measure for reimbursing the losses by the war of the loyal citizens of the South.

The following message from the President was received by the House to-day: To the Senate and House of Representatives: Believing the commercial interests of our country would be promoted by a formal recognition of the independence of the Dominican Republic, while such a recognition would be in entire conformity with the settled policy of the United States,

The latest news from the United States declares that Gen. LOGAN has declined to accept the position of Plenipotentiary to the Juarist government, which was offered him by the Washington Cabinet. Had any other person been designated to occupy that position, we should have inquired whether His Excellency the Plelipotentiary, would have proceeded to meet face to face the lawful President of the Mexican Republic.

A large party of invited guests embarked yesterday on board the revenue cutter Cuyahoga, Capt. JOHN FAUNCE commanding, to witness the trial of Messrs. BROWN LENT'S life-saving tackle, to disengage boats from davit tackles instantaneously, when the vessel is under full speed. The Pacific Mail Steamship Company, Canard Line, National Line, Bremen Line and several of our prominent steam lines were represented by their Captains and chief officers.

ALLERTON--JUDD.--At Kent, Conn., on Thursday, Feb. 1. by Rev. E. Srudder, GEO. W. ALLERTON. Jr. of New-York, and LIZZIE R., youngest daughter of Wm. M. JUDD, Esq., of the former place. No cards.. ANDERSON--CORNISH.--On Thursday, Feb. 1, at the residence of the bride's parents,

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER offered a bill to abolish in the late rebel States legal and political distinctions based upon class or color, and declaring all persons equal before the law, both in the court-room and at the ballot-box. He gave notice that this bill, presented in conformance to the second section of the amendment abolishing slavery, would be pressed as a substitute for the amendment which has just passed the House.

There is a paper published semi-occasionally at Athens, Georgia, known as the Cullivator. Under the guise of instructing its readers in the proper method of cultivating the soil, it does its utmost to keep alive and intensify the hostility between the North and South.
