Below will be found a corrected list of fire-signals, alarm-stations and locations adapted to the shore city, and which went into operation on the ??. The stations and locations practically represent shall fire-districts. The signals are made or the lower bells, or on the fire engine-house or police station-house gongs, by strokes corresponding with the numbers of the stations.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Among the various propositions submitted to the Legislature, having in view the relief of Broadway and the rapid transportation of passengers and freight from the business centres of the city to the suburbs. I am convinced there is not one having so many qualities to commend it to popular favor as that submitted to the Assembly by Mr. BRANDRETH.

The board met pursuant to adjournment, in their chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Councilmen Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, O'Brien, Kenney, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, white, Mackay, Kellogg, Tyng. Thomas, Halloran. Roberts, Pullman, Hettrick, Imlay--22.

The usual quiet of our camp was broken today by the arrival of three employes of the Butterfield overland Dispatch Company, with the report that the Indians were again on the war-path. Since the depredations committed on the line west of here in November, it has been comparatively quiet, and although there have been small parties of Indians seen from time to time, it was the universal belief that they had left this neighborhood.

At an early hour this morning, the ladies' gallery and the bench gallery were occupied by ladies, as anxious as ever to witness the progress of the trial of the more anxious CLARK. It has been suggested that the attractive personal appearance of the prisoner is the magnetic powers by which so much of the local beauty of Bridgeport is drawn hither.

Senator MURPHY will soon introduce a bill to authorize the formation of a Pneumatic Dispatch Company in the City of New-York. The following gentlemen are named in the bill as directors, viz.: Elias P. Needham, Wm. A. Guest, Asa P. Robinson, Thomas Rigney, Ephraim Searls, George M. Mason, Hugh B. Wilson, Wm. C. Edeston, James P. Robinson and John Sessions.

A disturbance occurred over a game of cards last night, at a free concert saloon on Mulberry-street, kept by an Italian named ANTONIO WHITE, between the proprietor and another Italian named LE JANG. This morning, about 9 o'clock, WHITE saw LE JANG in ROGGONI'S barber-shop, under the City Hotel, and applying an epithet to him, challenged him to come out on the sidewalk.

BILLS REPORTED. To amend the charter of the Phoenix Fire Insurance Company. Providing for the restoration of securities held by insurance departments deposited by life insurance companies organized in other States. The annual report of the trustees of the Cooper Union, for the advancement of science, was received and ordered to be printed.

MEDICAL REGIMEN IN OUR HARBOR.--The report of the Commissioners of Quarantine, which has been transmitted to our State Logislature, is a document which will attract more than ordinary attention this year, from the fact that the subject of quarantine is again being extensively discussed in connection with the threatened visitation of cholera.

The Health Bill came down from the Senate to the House this morning, and was referred to the Committee on Public Health, of which Dr. CONGDON, of Tompkins, is Chairman. That committee has already had the subject under consideration, and will report as soon as Wednesday or Thursday of next week.

DIVORCES IN CONNEOTICUT.--The Legislature, at its last session, passed an act requiring the clerks of the superior courts, in each county, to make a return to the State librarian of the number of divorces granted since Jan, 1, A. D. 1860, with the causes for which the same were granted. This information is to be used by the librarian in his annual report on registration. He has not received returns from all the counties.

THE SEIZURE OF THE STEAMERS JAMESTOWN AND YORKTOWN. In the Virginia House of Delegates, Jan. 25, a report from the Committee on Claims, in regard to the claims of the Virginia and New-York Steamship Company against the State for the seizure and loss of the steamers Jamestown and Yorktown, was presented, and, at the request of the committee, was ordered to be printed.

ACCIDENT AT THE FULTON FERRY.--As the five o'clock boat for Brooklyn of the Fulton-street line was leaving her landing on this side the river last evening, a boy about twelve years of age, who resides in Brooklyn, in attempting to jump on board the boat when she was already some two feet from the dock, fell into the water between the boat and the landing.

DIAMOND PIN ROBBERY. CATHARINE SIMMONS, alias, Mary Ann Wheeler, who is well known to the police as an old offender, residing at No. 272 Bleecker-street, entered the store of HERMAN MARCUS, No. 22 John-street, in company with a boy named GEORGE GARRISON, aged 16 years,

Gen. WEITZEL has written a letter to the Adjutant-General of the Department of Texas, reviewing at length the protest of the merchants and foreign Consuls at Matamoras. He makes counter charges and asserts that they were greatly instrumental in aiding the Confederates during the war with arms, ammunition and other necessaries of war.

Assistant Seoretary CHANDLER and Hon. HARVEY M. WALTERS have arrved here. Mr. CHANDLER has removed R. V. MONTAGUE from the Collectorship of Customs for Mobile, on account of his connection in certain transactions with T. C. A. DEXTER, late special cotton agent. J. M. TOMINY is now acting as Collector.

From All the Year Round. The "good ship " Promised Land really deqerved that praise. She was now, had made only one voyage, in a remarkably short space of time, was copper-fastened, two hundred tons burden, was of course registered At at Lloyd's, and was now loading at the St. Winifred's Docks.

Gen. Mowers, commanding the sub-district of Galveston and Houston, passed through this city today, on route home, previous to being mustered out of the service. Large invoices of goods, imported from England by the way of Havana, have arrived at Galveston, and been sent into the interior.

The sales at auction of paintings and other works of art which have taken place in the city this Winter are without precedent in number and importance in its history, and it would appear that the end is not yet. The eagerness with which the works of artists, known and unknown, have been bought up is only less surprising than the prices obtained for pictures of ordinary merit only.

Mayor Hoffman has determined to put down a certain class of auctioneers doing business in this city in violation of the laws, and against whom frequent complaints of fraud are made. Yesterday morning, a man named Zano Burnham, who resides and does business at No. 44 West 16th street, was arrested by order of the Mayor on a charge of violating the State laws relating to auctioneers and auction sales. The law reads as follows:

ORDER IN RESPECT TO DESEITERS. In conseqilence of the large number of desertions from the regular army during the past few months, Gen. GRANT has issued an order calling on Commanders of departments and regiments to take the most stringent measures for checking the evil, and to cause inspections to be made to discover and remove the cause.

Whatever grounds for grumbling skaters may have had in the unsettled state of the weather in the earlier portion of the season, surely they can well afford to forget their disappointments in the all-appreciable present. There never was a week since ice was first invented so well disposed by day and night to those who enjoy the happy games upon it.
Ex-Gen. and Ex-Gov. Wms., the hero of Roanoke, lately made a public address in Richmond, nominally in behalf of the very worthy charity in that city known as the Female Orphan Asylum.

If one must judge the tone of the people of Misissippi by the acts of her Legislature, which, indeed, would be a most natural conclusion, an opinion would prevail that Mississippians had failed to appreclate that magnanimity which has been extended them by the very party who had all to do with their defeat.

The Senate is not in session to-day. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. WASHINGTON, Saturday, Feb. 8. LAKE ERIE HARBORS. Mr. SPALDING introduced a bill, which was retorred to the Committee on Commerce, providing for the repair and improvement of the harbors of Cleveland and Fairport, on Lake Erie.

REMARKS OF MR. DARLION, OF NEW-YORK, IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. Mr. DARLING--Mr. Speaker, I do not intend to occupy the time of the louse on the bill now under consideration with any extended remarks, but a few practical ideas have suggested themselves to my mind which I thought I would embrace the very first opportunity to lay before them for their consideration.

HOUSES TO LET AND FOR SALE.--We would caution our readers against giving way to a feeling of panic on the subject of houses and rents. There are a large number of dwellings for sale in various localities. These will not be sold in the majority of cases, and will be offered to tenants in a month or so.

Chief Justice Chase presiding. G. Clarence Churchill, impleaded, , vs. The City of Utica.--This is one of the New-York bank tax cases, coming to this court from the Court of Appeals of the State of New-York, where was affirmed a judgment of the General Term of the Supreme Court, holding that the State could tax the stock of the National Banks in the hands of private owners as personal property.

The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House, a bill was introduced providing for the repair and improvement of certain harbors on Lake Erie; referred to the Committee on Commerce. The bill making appropriations for the Legislative, Executive and Judicial Departments of the governmant, for the year ending June 30, 1867, was made the special order for Monday.

Under all forms of government, whether national or local, republican or monarchical, the personal character and public actions of those in authority have much influence over the moral growth of the masses, or their decadence in wisdom and virtue.

The Secretary of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Col. PALMER, has just received from San Francisco the detailed report of Col. BULKLEY, the Engineer-in-Chief of the Russian Telegraph Expedition. The Rochester Union is permitted to publish the report as a matter of great interest to the stockholders and to the public, looking with anxiety to the progress of the work of uniting by telegraph the two continents.

A late number of the London Engineer gives us the unexpected information that the English Admiralty are about to commence the construction of a large iron turret-ship, from their "own plans." It is pretty plain what "own plans" means.

At 8:40 o'clock last evening, Officer CAMP, of the Sixteenth Precinct, discovered flames issuing from the, two-story brick building, occupied as a depot and stables by the Fulton Ferry and Bleecker-street line of cars. He at once gave an alarm, when Metopolitan Engine Company No. 3 quickly arrived and stretched a line of hose, being soon joined by several other companies.

In yesterday's Journal we announced that our neighbor, lion. JOHN G. DAVIS, had an attack of paralysis and was not expected to recover. He rallied, not with standing, on Wednesday night, and oven at 6 o'clock yesterday morning hopes wore entertained of his recovery, He had another attack, however, after that hour, aud before 7 o'clock he expired.
The report of the special commission on our revenue system is the most important financial document which has appeared for a long time, and is in our view remarkably able and progressive.

The present alleged scarcity of dwellings suitable for occupation by families in moderate circumstances naturally recalls a subject which a few years ago was much discussed. The idea of association for procuring homes has been realized in many States to a considerable extent, but not, we believe, of late years.

The time is that of holiday, and the accessories are favorable. The amount of snow already fallen is popularly accounted unprecedented here at this season of the year, and there is still no sign of a diminution of the flaky supply. As a consequence, the sleighing is magnificent, and is taken advantage of largely.

SOUTERN LANDS.--There are plenty of cotton plantations still to be purchased and leased in the Southern States. One Northern company offers for sale at this moment five hundred plantations located in all the States from Maryland to the Mississippi River, and also in Texas.

Mr. JAMES R. SPALDING, one of the editors of the NEW-YORK TIMES, who had taken a trip to NewOrleans for the benefit of his health, was, on his return, we regret to hear, struck with paralysis. Mr. SPALDING being unable to speak when removed from the vessel on Wednesday evening, was driven about to several hotels, the proprietors of which, not knowing him, refused to take him in.

WOMAN AND HER RIGHTS.--Wherever Progress may have been born and cradled, there can be no question of the fact that its permanent place of residence is the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and its favorite domicil the yellow-domed State-house on Beacon-streot Hill.

We translate from the Paris Journal des Debats, of the 19th ult., a very powerful article on the policy, the prospects, and the future of the Mexican Expedition. The article is from the pen of M. ST. M. GIRARDIN, and presents a comprehensive, clear, and pointed review of the situation in Mexico, especially in relation to its bearing on a good understanding between France and the United States.

At 8 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in Oswego, in the upper story of the dry goods store of MORRIS PLACE, on the west side of First-street, and before the flames could be checked the entire building was destroyed, together with the property adjoining. It was occupied as follows: Morris Place, dry goods: THOMAS MOORE, dry goods; ALLEN BURCHARD, leather and findings;

That which may be termed the civil war diplomatic correspondence of the government, now lies before us in eight massive volumes. The years 1861 and 1862 are represented by a volume each. 1863 needed two volumes. But 1864 required four. Practically the diplomacy of war ended with this last year.

Very well; there is no other restric.

The Steamer W. R. Carter exploded her boilers at 3 o'clock this morning, at island No. 98. A large number of lives were lost. The boat and cargo are a total loss. The following are known to be lost: Mrs. Dr. RICHARDSON and three children, of New-Orleans; Mrs. GIBBONS; Mrs. WOLF; Mrs. RICE, of Cincinnati; Mrs. OSTERMAN, of Texas; Mrs. NOOSE; Mrs. MORRIS, of Columbus, and Mrs. HOWLAND. Many others were scalded and otherwise injured.

The order of Gen. SICKLES relating to the industrial relations of negroes and their employers is in the main a practical and just exposition of the reciprocal duties of the two classes. We publish the order in full, that our readers may see that there is a golden mean in this as in every other theory or system of administration.

IN CHTHAM-SQUARE. Near 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered by the patrolman on duty in the promises occupied by ARMSTRONG Co., No. 206 Chatham-street. An alarm was at once given, but owing to the inflammable nature of the contents, the flames spread with rapidity, occasioning considerable loss. Messrs. ARMSTRONG Co.'s loss is about $2,000; insured.

Mr. MARETZEK'S three performances--the "African," "Crispino" and "Norma"--have inauguarated the Spring season in the most brilliant and successful way, and this, too, despite the fact that dancing is so much in vogue that the fashionable world has double duty to perform. The matinee on Saturday drew a magnificent audience, and the performance was in every way creditable and excellent.

THE IRREPRESSIBLE LAIRD.--A trustworthy Liverpool journal announces that LAIRD, M. P., is at his old business of rambuilding, this time for the belligerents on the Pacific. His Confederate ventures paid him so handsomely that he thinks Chili a fairfield for speculation, while the conflict between that power and Spain shall continue.

Although the snows of Winter are still upon us, and the vernal Spring is yet some distance off, the great business houses and manufactories of the city are making the most active and extensive preparations for the Spring trade, and canvassing its prospects with the greatest eagerness. Within ten days...

To justify their continued warfare upon the South, the radicals find it necessary to allege the existence of a hostile, unmanageable spirit among the people lately in rebellion, and of a disposition to bear unjustly and even cruelly upon the colored population. Both allegations are essential to the Radical programme.

A letter has been received here from San Domingo, giving the substance of a conversation held there on the 14th of January, between Secretary SEWARD and President BAEZ at the National palace. The Cabinet of Dominica were present. The respectability of the source whence the information came entitles it to credibility.

The wonderful prosperity of the British Empire is a subject of perpetual glorification, mingled with the continual grumbling, which is the charactertstic and privilege of that curious specimen of humanity-the British subject. "Our wealth," says the Quarterly Review, "is overflowing, our commercial prospects unclouded, save by the excess of our own activity, and nothing seems likely to disturb either the peace of Europe or the profound contentment which this island is enjoying."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: No more important measure can come before the Legislature this season, or perhaps at any time, than the new bill creating a reformed sanitary administration for New-York and Brooklyn. On the success of that measure, on its powers if passed, will depend probably more human lives than on any measure which has occupied the attention of the New-York Legislature for many a year.

MITCHELL BAILEY Co.'s knitting-factory at Oriskany, N. Y., was destroyed by fire Jan. 31. The Utica Herald says: An accident occurred during the burning of the building which in its results, considering the circumstances, was truly astonishing. A female operative, whose name we were unable to learn, being at work in the room where the fire originated, suddenly found herself cut off by the flames from the stairway leading below.

When Secretary SEWARD was in San Domingo, on his late trip to the West Indies, he was entertained at the national palace by President BAEZ of the Dominican Republic, and had a long conversation with him upon the recognition of that government by the United States. President BAEZ was anxious to bring about such recognition, and Mr. SEWARD told him (unofficially) that he did not doubt that such a result was near at band.

The following is a statement of the names of the sufferers, and amounts of losses sustained by the fire at Oswego: On buildings owned by Mrs. MILLER, loss $18,000; insurance $12,000. E. P. JONES' building, loss $1,500; fully insured. On the Buckhart Building, loss $500; fully insured. MORRIS PLACE, dry goods,

The weather yesterday was cold and boisterous, and snow fell to the depth of two feet during the day and previous night. The trains on the Oswego and Rome and the Oswego and Syracuso Railroads are all detained by the snow.

About 7:30 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered on the second floor of No. 77 Rutgers-slip, occupied by NELSON BAKER as a sail left. Loss on stock estimated at $1,000; covered by insurance. The building is owned by JOSEPH HITCHCOCK, and is damaged to the extent of $500; insured. The origin of the fire is unknown.

Files of Havana papers have boon received to the 28th of January. The papers contain elaborate accounts received by the way of Vera Cruz of the affair at Bagdad; but the accounts contain no further facts than have already been made known here.

The House held a session of only an hour in length this morning, and passed a number of bills, a bare quorum being present. The Senate meets at 7 1/2 o'clock this evening. Mr. LITTLEJOHN gave notice of a bill to incorporate the Niagara Ship Canal Company.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Without entering into an argument to explain the reason why, it may be ?? stated, that the naval battles of the future, on the result of which important issues will depend, so far as regards attacks on the ports of an enemy, or defending, harbors, , against his attacks, will be fought with iron-clad vessels.

The examination into the charge of libel preferred by A. T. STEWART against Mr. GEORGE KNAPP, one of the editors and proprietors of the Missouri Daily Republican, and Mr. RICHARD J. COLBURN, New-York correspondent of the same journal, was continued yesterday morning. Mr. COLBURN, having already waived an examination, he was admitted to bail, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

SILK ROBBERY. Detectives FARLEY and EUSTACE arrested EDWARD DRUM and MICHAEL L. DOYLE, on suspicion of having committed the theft of eleven pieces of silk, valued at $800, the property of FERDINAND MENSSING, No, 140 Duane-st. The silk, it appears, had passed through the Custom-house though the owner never obtained his goods.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. DOOLITTEE desired to record his vote in favor of the Civil Rights Bill, he not having been present when the vote was taken. Mr. CHANDLER reported the House bill preventing the issue of registers to vessels that changed their registry during the war. The bill was ordered over for the present.

The Archaeological Academy of Belgium have organized an international congress in conjunction with the French Archaeological Society, which is to take place at Antwerp next month. The following questions, among others, will be discussed at the meeting:

By Mr. Low-To amend the charter of the New-York Pier and Warehouse Company. By Mr. C. G. CORNELL--To incorporate the American Transit Company; also, for a railroad in Grand and other streets, New-York, and to regulate the fare thereon.

About 10 o'clock yesterday morning a collision occurred in Centre-street, near White, between a Fourth-avenue passenger car and a Harlem Railroad freight car, resulting in the demolition of the Fourthavenue car and the crushing to death of one of the horses attached to it. Fortunately the passengers were warned in time, and vacated the car before the collision occurred.

HEREWARD THE LAST OF THE ENGLISH. B. CHARLES KINGSLEY, author of "Two Years Ago," Boston: TICKNOR FIELDS. A novel by a clergyman and a Cambridge Professor of History, must be a book deserving some notice. "Hereward" will undoubtedly gratify a large circle of readers.

A MAN KILLED BY THE FALL OF A CEILING.-DANIEL McCARTY, a carpenter, JOHN McQUADE and two other men were at work on the 29th ult, making alterations on the promises Nos. 175 and 177 Firstavenue, occupied by W. D. GREGORY. As they were about taking down a false celling that was about falling it suddenly gave way, burying the workmen beneath the debris.

THE MACHINERY OF THE CHATTANOOGA.--The United States steam trigate Chattanooga, the hull of which was built by Messrs. CRAMP SONS, and the machinery by Messrs. MERRICK SONS, is about to make a trial trip, preparatory to which the machinery has been in motion for the past two days, and will be for a day or two longer.

Mr. DELANO (Adm. 0.) made an explanation, called forth by a remark of Mr. ROUSSEAU, and said he repudiated as utterly groundless the assertion that the States are dead. They live, and, by the blessing of God, they will live, as long as the United States shall live as a part and parcel of our common country. He was ready to admit the members from Arkan.

Our latest advices from Paris are to the 19th January, and as the Corps Legisltif were to meet on the 22d there was great interest manifested as to the speech which the Emperor was to pronounce on the occasion, or rather the interest was as to the position likely to be assumed by His Majesty on one question-the France-Mexican-American question.

AUSTIN.--At West Farms, on Saturday evening, Feb. 2, after a short illness, LAVINUS AUSTIN, (27 years in the employ of Ball, Black Co.,) aged 53 years and 6 months.

CLAIMS FOR TAXES COLLECTED IN ERROR.--It will be remembered that the courts decided some time time ago that no taxes could be collected on United States securities, and that consequently a very large portion of the taxes levied by the county on the assets of certain banks and insurance companies would have to be refunded.
The annual report of the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction for the year 1865, which has just been published, is replete with facts that should interest all classes of citizens,

The National Association of State School Superintendents meets in Washington to-day. It is composed of those who have have had the widest observation and largest experience in education in the different States. A prominent aim is to devise a feasible plan of free schools for the Southern States, to be introduced and sustained not by Congressional coercion, but by their own choice and support.

This board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, the President, Mr. BRICE, in the chair. A resolution was adopted directing the Coroners advertise descriptions of all unknown persons on whom inquests are held, in two daily papers. A resolution was presented by Mr. McGINNIS increasing the pay of inspectors of repairs to sidewalks, pumps, , from $2 to $3 per day.

The weather is unusually cold. The thermometer stands at 47 deg. above zero. The steamers Flag, Star of the Union and Fung Shuey have sailed for New-York. ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The cold snap had its effect on all places of amusement last evening, nor did the Academy of Music wholly escape. BELLINI'S charming opera of "I Puritani" drew a good and fashionable audience, but one which has often been excelled in numbers.

The Fire Department of the City of Brooklyn is one of the few volunteer associations against whose reputation we find no stain or blemish. Its officers are men of character and position, and its members mainly reputable citizens of probity and good standing,

In the Courier yesterday we detailed, by our special dispatches from Evansville, all we could glean of the terrible disaster to the steamer Missouri. The Dictator, Capt. DONALDSON, arrived here yesterday morning from the scene of the disaster, with all the survivors. The Missouri left New-Orleans last Tuesday week with a light freight, but full of passengers, the most of whom were discharged at Cairo.

The trial of CLARK, the young man charged with participation in the recent robbery of the Adams Express Company, was resumed this morning. The prisoner, being deemed too sick to leave his cell, was not in court. Atter consultation between counsel, it was decided to go on with the trial in the absence of CLARK.

Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Councilmen Keenan, Long, Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, O'Brien, Kenney, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, White, Mackay, Kellogg, Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Pullman, Hettrick, Imlay-23. THE STEVENS FACTION.--The full strength of the faction of confiscators in the House was yesterday brought out on the amendment to the Freedmen's Bureau Bill, moved by Mr. STEVENS. The amendment in question, summarily stated, was to declare the whole of the Southern States to be conquered territory, or more practically, to take everybody's property and give it to everybody else.

The steamship Matanzas sails for New-York to-morrow. The appointment of E. F. PARKER as Surveyor of this port gives universal satisfaction. The Times indorses him, saying that "he is one of the few thorroughly consistent Union men, and a man of great energy of character and business capacity."

BEOOKLYN CITY COURT--EFOBE JUDGE REYNOLDS AND SUPERVISORS BLOOM AND MAGGROTTY.--THOMAS ROPP was tried on the charge of entering the house of Mrs. CLAPP, No. 80 Henry-street, on the 5th of December last, with the intention to seal, but as he took nothing, and the proof being insufficient, he was acquitted...

Col. R. M. HALL was to assume command at Brazos on the 1st inst. The Austrian troops at Bagdad are commanded by Col. KADALICK. The Spanish Consul at Matamoras, with one of Gen. MEJIA'S officers, left for the City of Mexico on the 31st ult., on important business. Civil proceedings have been commenced by the the Texas State officers at Brownsville against the parties implicated in the Bagdad affair.

THE RACE BETWEEN THE ALGONQUIN AND WENOOSKI.--The race between these two gunboats was to have commenced yesterday morning, but it has been postponed in consequence of the ice in the river and the severe weather generally.
A stated meeting of the Historical Society was held last evening, and after the regular business had been disposed of, JonN T. AIKIN, Esq., read a very interesting paper on "The History of Liberty."

The State Temperance Association met at the First Presbyterian Church at Syracuse at 11 o'clock this morning. The morning session was called to order by Gan. SMITH, President, and Rev. OVID MINOR, of Herkimer, was made Secretary, pro tem. Adjourned to 2 o'clock this afternoon. About twenty delegates are present.

Mr. E. CORNELL reported bills to tax the franchise or business of banking. BILLS NOTICED. By Mr. E. CORNELL--TO provide for the reduction of capital stock of banking associations. By Mr. LENT--To increase the annual payments on the shares of the New-York Society Library and authorize the trustees to commute their annual dues. Also to provide for a police court in New-York.
Judge SHIPMAN'S decision quashing the indictments against BARNEY and others, which our readers will find in another column, is sufficiently startling.

To His Excellency, R. E. Fenton: SIR : I have the honor to invite your attention to the inclosed translation of a note of the l7th, from the Marquis DE MONTHOLM, the Minister of France accredited to this government, upon the subject of detention at New-York in quarantine of the steamship Europa, of the General Transatlantio Company's line, from Havre.

UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE. Petitions for universal suffrage were presented by Messrs. WILSON and POMKROY, and referred to the Committee on Reconstruction. THE TAX ON AGRICULTURAL IMPLEMENTS. Mr. SHERMAN presented the petition of citizens of Ohio, asking for a reduction of the tax on agricultural implements, which was referred to the Committee on Finance.

THE STREET CARS--FURIOUS DRIVING.--The practice of furious driving at points where city railroads intersect each other, needs some check. We have had several very serious collisions within the present week, growing out of this cause alone.

The Tribune has been holding various persons responsible, during two years, for defeating the Health Bill. Now it is at work to accomplish what it abused others for doing. Persons concerned for the public health prepared a bill designed, as far as practicable, to effect its objects.

DOCK AND RIVER THIEVES. Roundsman RUSHER, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, while on duty on Saturday morning, about daylight, saw a rowboat lying alongside of a canal-boat, in the slip near Pler No. 43 North River, and also noticed that the boat had a bale of cotton in tow.

THE FRENCH EXHIBITION.--The New-York Chamber of Commerce has just issued a report on the French Exhibition of 1867, which we think will attract general attention. It will be found at length in our paper this morning.

The steamship Palestine, Capt. MARTIN, from Liverpool the 23d ult, arrived here this afternoon. She is a freight steamer put on the Cunard line for an extra trip, and brings no malls or files of newspapers. A few newspapers were in the hands of passengers on board, the latest of which contain but few items of news.

Before Judge Shipman. The United States vs. William C. Barney, Beuinam Fabian and Reginald Chauncey.--The motion to quesh the indictment in these cases was yesterday morning decided by judge SHIPMAN, granting the motion. The following is his opinion:

We give news this morning, the most important, in some points of view, that we have published since the downfall of the Confederacy a year ago. The Emperor of the French has announced, in his speech before the legislative chambers, that preparations are being made to withdraw the French troops from Mexico;

In this city, on Tuesday, Feb. 6, GEORGE ARMSTRONG, aged 93 years. The relatives and friends of the family, and of his son, David, and sons-in-law. James Gregory and John Sutton, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from his late residence, No. 65 Pike-st., on Thursday, the 8th inst., at 2 P.M. , at 2 P.M.

THE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE AND THE HEATH BILL.---At its yesterday's meeting the Chamber of Commerce unanimously passed resolutions cordially approving of the Health Bill as it stands. And it will be interesting to a city contemporary to find that that particular clause of the bill which incorporates the Board of Metropolitan Police as the executive arm of the commission, has the fullest approval of the merchants of New-York.

The Georgia papers just received establish a fact which the telegraph failed to make clear--that Mr. A. H. STEPHENS and HERSCHEL V. JOHNSON were both elected to the United States Senate by the State Legislature-the former for the long and the latter for the short term.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"The African" was given last night to a very good house. "Faust" will be played to-night. Both these popular works will be withdrawn after the present week, other attractions being in readiness.

THE FREEDMEN'S BUREAU. The Freedmen's Bureau Bill came promptly up, today, under the previous question, and the votes on the several propositions were promptly taken. GREEN CLAY SMITH'S amendment, to except Kentucky, was rejected-ayes, 34; noes, 131.

ENTERTAINMENTS BY THE BLIND.--Several of the graduates of the New-York Institution for the Blind, are giving interesting miscellaneous entertainments every night this week at Clinton Hall. The exercises consist of reading by touch, explaining the use of the maps for the blind, singing, instrumental music, recitations of poems, original and selected.

Gov. WARD sent into the Senate this afternoon the following appointments: For Chancellor, A. 0. Zabriskie, vice Henry W. Greene, resigned; for Judges of the Supreme Court, Van Cleve Dalrymple, of Mercer, vice George H. Brown, deceased; David A. Depew, vice Daniel Haines, term expired; George A.

Last eveing Re. M. J. SPALDING, the Catholic Archbishop of Baltomore, and spiritual head of the Catholic Church in this country, delivered a lecture on "The Church the Civilizer of the Nations," at the Church of St. Stephen, in Twenty-eighth-street.

Mr. J. D. TOWNSEND, counsel for PELLOIEB, one of the convicted murderers of Senr OTERO, is Indefatigable in his efforts in behalf of his condemned client. He proposes, at the sitting of the General Term of the Kings County Supreme Court next week, to move for a new trial in PELLICIER'S case, and thinks that he can furnish evidence exculpating the unfortunate man.

Broadway, between Spring and Prince sts. THIS AFTERNOON at 3. EVENING at 71/2 o'clock. GRAND CIRCUS PERFORMANCE. PERFORMING THREE-HORNED BULL. The Romantic I rams of the SONS OF THE REPUBLIC. Giants, dwarfs, 100,000 curiosities.

We receive by the last arrival from Europe the important intelligence that the Emperor of France, in his speech of Jan. 22, to the Corps Legislatif, announced that arrangements were making for the withdrawal of French troops from Mexico. The Emperor expressed the hope that this would pacify the United States. This important declaration caused an immediate advance in American securities. No further details of news are given.

No one not familiar with the wants and evils of the city, can have an idea of the large number of entirely homeless men and women always drifting about our streets. It is they who especially fill up the vile cellars described recently with such graphic effect by the Police Commissioners.

The Union members of the Assembly held a cauous on the Health Bill this evening. Dr. RICHARDSON, of Essex County, was called to the chair. On motion, all reporters and others except Union members and officers of the House were excluded.
The Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting yesterday, JONATHAN STURGIS, Esq., in the chair, to indorse the Metropolitan Health Bill now before the Legislature.

INCENDIARY FIRE--FIVE HORSES DESTROYED--A FIREMEN'S FIGHT.--A fire was discovered in a frame building in Fourth-street, between North Third and Fourth, E. D., about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, and before it was extinguished damage to the amount of $3,500 resulted. The lower part of the building was occupied by DANIEL BUTLEr as a stable.

RATHE COSTLY--There is a telegram from New-Orleans, which says that there are forty thousand destitute persons in the State of Alabama, who will require an appropriation ot two million dollars per annum to sustain them. To what class do these forty thousand belong ? Are they black or white?

Broadway, between Spring and Prince sts. THIS AFTERNOON at 3. EVENING at 7 1/2 o'clock. GRAND CIRCUS PERFORMANCE. PERFORMING THREE-HORNED BULL. The Romantic Drama of the SONS OF THE REPUBLIC. Giants, dwarfs, 100,000 curiosities.

NEWS ENTERPRISE.--Twenty-four hours after the steamer Palestine had arrived at Boston, we were favored with a report of the Emperor's speech at the opening of the French Legislature. Such telegraphic enterprise deserves at least some special mention.

In steamship Java for Liverpool.--Thos. Grieve, Jas. L. Raymond, W. Schaus, E. Greef, Miss Perrin, W. Brown, J. E. Wolf, W. R. Wagstaff and friend, Mrs. Barbour and child, Jas. Vaughan, C. Rathbone, Mrs. Rathbone, Miss Sandford, Col. and Mrs. F. Townsend, Mr. and Mrs. Careager, Mr. Castillo, J. B. Hernandez, Lieut, s. Garcia. J. Philippe, Lord and Lady Edward Clinton and servant, J. Suoden and son, Mrs. Parsons,

The Union Legislature caucus has voted in favor of repealing the Specific Contract Law by a large majority; also favoring a postponement of the Congressional election until 1867. A dispatch from Portland says there is no communication with the upper Columbia owing to the ice blockade.

Officer O'CONNOR, of the Tenth Precinct, while on duty in Grand-street about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, saw a man driving a team of horses attached to a heavy truck, loaded with six large dry goods cases, the contents of which were evidently very heavy.

INTERESTING AND IMPORTANT.--The Tribune of yesterday says: "Prices are tending downward. We must return to specie payments." Things are coming right. The Tribune says so. How pleasant to know that " prices are tending downwards."

The Inman steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at noon on the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th of January, arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning. The steamers Helvetica and Tripoli loft Liverpool also on the 24th for New-York.

LEETE--LEETE.--In this city, on Wednesday, Feb. 7, at the residence of A. N. Leete, Esq., by Rev. E. P. Rogers, Hon. CALVIN M. LEETE and Miss LUCY M. LEETE, both of Guilford, Conn. LOTHROP--KELLY.--At St. Andrew's Church, Philadelphia, on Wednesday, Feb. 7, by Right Rev. Wm. Bacon Stevens, D. D., CHARLES B. LOTHROP and DEBORAH K. KELLY, grand-daughter of the late Henry Kahis, Esq.
We understand that the meeting of workingmen at Albany will not confine its attention to the question simply of an agitation in favor of the eight hours' limit of a day's labor.

When President McLEAN called the Board of Education to order, last evening, it was observed that nearly a full board was present, and an unusually large number of spectators filled the lobbies. The occasion for this uncommon interest in the Commissioners proceedings was undoubtedly the expected report of the "special committee upon the claims of HORATIO P. ALLEN to the seat "

THE CASE OF SCHOOL-COMMISSIONER ALLEN.-At the meeting of the Board of Education last evening, the committee of that body who had under consideration the contested election case of HORATIO P. ALLEN against JAMES B. BRADY, reported in favor of Mr. ALLEN, who was at once qualified for office and took the scat which Mr. BRAD has unjustly filled since the beginning of the year.
The State Medical Society reconvened this morning. The committee having in charge the New??

The Mexican Consulate has received an official communication from JUAREZ and the Minister of Foreign Relations, dated El Paso del Norto, Dec. 28. All the Generals commanding Liberal forces gave in their adherence, and approved the decree extending the term of JUAREZ' Presidency.

THE PROPOSED MORGUE AND ADVERTISING THE UNKNOWN DEAD.--The records of the Coroners' office show that nearly every year there are committed to paupers' graves the bodies of more than three hundred persons whose identity an inquest has failed to establish. This startling and shameful fact has resulted from two causes.

SERIOUS RESULT OF THE LAST FOURTH-AVENUE COLLISION.--Among the passengers in the small Fourth-avenue car which was smashed up by the cars of the New-Haven road on Monday last, was our wellknown fellow-citizen Gen. WARD B. BURNETT. The General was severely bruised about the head, neck and shoulders and sprained quite badly his wrist.

CHARGE OF GRAND LARCENY. Officer McCARTY, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, yesterday, arrested GUSTAVUS FRNAK, on a charge of grand larceny preferred by FREDERICK KOCHLER, residing at No. 106 West Twenty-fifth-street. The Complainant stated that on the 21st of June last, he went to the office of ALBERT FRANK, broker, doing business at No. 39 Exchange-place, for the purpose of buying gold.

A destructive fire occurred this morning on the east side of Main-street, between Washington and Poplar, by which seven buildings were destroyed. The fire originated in the dry goods store of BESTOFF SCHLINGER,on the north corner of Poplar-street, and rapidly spread to the buildings on the back side, including the four brick stores belonging to Mr. LEVI, but occupied by Mr. SCHLINOER, dry goods;

The City of Washington arrived at 1 o'clock this morning, bringing mails to the 24th ult. from Liverpool. The most important news is from France and Spain. The Emperor's speech, of which we had just a glimpse by the Palestine, we print in full, as reported in Galignani. Count WALEWSKI has taken his seat as President of the Corps Legislatif.

We are happy in the belief that the English holders of Confederate bonds are reasonably provided with that metallic material the possession of which constitutes, with the majority of mankind, the sum of human happiness. For we can laugh at them without being thought unkind, and need mingle with our mirth not one iota of pity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In Your paper of the 26th inst. I find a cotter our public debt, in which he argues, as many do, against placing our bonds in a foreign market. And he appeals to our national pride in support of his position, while at the same time he admits, as all must, that the bonds will be purchased abroad if it can be done on satisfactory terms.

THE RECIPROCITY TREATY. The reciprocity negotiations are for the present ended. The Canadian delegates presented to the Committee of Ways and Means a series of propositions insolving many changes in the financial system of the Provinces. The committee in return offered their terms. The difference between the two is so wide that all efforts to reconcile them have been abandoned.

The envelope manufactures throughout the country are naturally greatly exercised at the proposition of the Postmaster-General to manufacture and sell Stamped envelopes at the cost of the stamps on their face.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It has already been made public, to some extent, that when a portion of the Mercer emigration party sailed on the steamship Continental, for the Pacific coast, some were compelled, as it is alleged, by the most unjust action, to remain behind.

The Democratic State Convention assembled here to-day. Full delegations were present from all parts of the State. The convention is the largest held for many years. Hon. THOMAS H. BOND presided. Hon. JAMES E. ENGLISH, of New-Haven, was nominated for Governor by acclamation, as was also EPHRAIM L. HYDE, of Stafford, for Lieutenant-Governor.

The reported conversation with the President with a number of negro gentlemen, which is given in another column, does not present anything which throws new light upon the Executive policy. Mr. FREDERICK DOUGLASS naturally entertains an exalted view of the past services and the future destinies of his race.

An agent of the Freedmen's Bureau was recently murdered in his bed at Pontiac, Mississippi, by enemies of the government. Mobile Harbor is to be examined by an engineer officer with a view to facilitating commerce. The removal of piles and other obstructions in the passages to the forts comes within the scope of the examination.

SUPREME COURT CIRCUIT--PART I--No more civil cases will be called in this part during the term. The presiding Justice, G. G. BARNARD, will continue the Oyer and Serminer. CIRCUIT--Part II.--Held in the General Term room by Justice CLERKE.--Court opens at lO1/2 o'clock.-Nos. 628, 730, 764, 784, 804, 812, 816, 818, 824, 826, 828, 830, 832, 834, 840, 844, 850, 852, 856, 860.

The House had another spasm on the "retrenchment and reform" question this morning, and consumed much valuable time in discussing the question whether the Adjutant-General's report should be bound in muslin or printed without covers. D. P. WOOD, who is the especial champion of economy on the printing question, led off in the debate. J. L.

Ex-President BURNET has published a list of severe charges against Gen. GREGORY, in his administration of the Freedmen's Bureau. Gen. GREGORY says they are false, and demands a retraction or full proof. Colonies of Europeans are coming into Texas. Poles are settling on Trinity River, near Palestine.

NAPOLEON'S announcement of his purpose to recall his troops from Mexico not only removes any ground of quarrel with France, but enables Congress to discuss more intelligently the bill now before it for the establishment of a permanent standing army.

The first battalion drill of the Thirty-seventh Regiment N. C. S. N. Y., since the election of their new Colonel, W. H. FARRAR, was hold, last evening, at the State Arsenal in Seventh-avenue. The drill was a very tine one, as the members of the regiment turned out in full force, and the maneuvers of the command were witnessed by a largo and fashionably dressed assemblage of ladies and gentlemen.

On Monday afternoon last, a man name THOMAS KEARNEY, was run over in Elm-street, near Parl, by car No. 7, of the Bleecker-street line, as already reported in the TIMES. Yesterday the injured man died at the New-York Hospital, and an inquest was held on the body by Coroner COLLIN.

THE JUDICIAL SYSTEM. Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, introduced a bill in addition to the several acts, to establish and amend the judicial system of the United States, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee. It provides for ten Circuit Judges, as at present, (the amount of salary left in blank,) who shall take the following oath:

By the arrival of the Peruvian at Portland yesterday, we have one day's later news from Europe. The statement that Gen. PRIM had entered Portugal had not been confirmed, but was generally believed to be correct. The cattle disease was increasing in England, the number of cases in the weekly return exceeding ten thousand. It is reported that France,

BUTLER--VER VALEN.--At Haverstraw, N. Y., on Thursday, Feb. 8, by Rev. A. s. Freeman, WM. L. BUTLER, of New-York City, and MARIA A., daughter of Richard A. Ver Valen, of the former place. Buffalo papers please copy. COREN--BROOKE.--In Jersey City, on Wednesday, Feb. 7, at the First Congregational Tabernacle, by Rev. John Milten Holmes, Mr. ISAAC COHEN, of New-York, and Miss MARY JANE, eldest daughter of the late William Brooke.

The State Medical Society reconvened at 9:30 this morning. Resolutions were adopted declaring as the sense of the Society that the cholera may be mainly if not entirely prevented from becoming epidemic in any city, town or locally, by the adoption and enforcement of rigid hygenic measures;...

Petitions were presented for a Metropolitan Baggage Act and to incorporate the Workingmen's Union o: New-York. BILLS REPORTED FAVORABLY. To regulate taxes on lands taken, or to be taken, for Croton Aqueduct purposes. To increase the powers and duties of Courts of Special Sessions except in New-York and Albany.

A GRIM HOPE.--We heard a humble and complaisant Teuton grimly remark to his landlord the other day, while paying a rent he could ill afford, "Ha, ha! wait till the cholera comes, and then you'll give us cheaper rent!" The speaker seemed to be quite comforted with the thought that when the cholera had devoured thousands of our inhabitants, and

Hong Kong advice to the 16th of December state that the Northern banditti are still causing much trouble to the government, whose forces had been defeated and driven toward the Yellow River, where they had been cut off from communication, Trade in the provinces of Shantang and Honam was entirely destroyed by the banditti.

THE STOVER-PORTER CASE AGAIN.--The Mr. NEWMAN referred to, as a lawyer appearing for D. M. PORTER in the case of PORTER vs. STOVER, reported in the TIMES of the 6th inst., and who was severely censurged by Judge McCUNN for reading an indecent and unprofessional affidavit, was not Mr. CLEMENT D. NEWMAN.

The following is the text of Senator HARRIS' bill for the reorganization of the United States Judiciary: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress asembled, That on and after the Ist day of July, 1866, the Circuit Courts of the United States shall be abolished, and the several district courts of the United States shall, in addition to the authority

The deputation of negro representatives who waited on the President the other day seem to have been altogether disappointed at the result of their interview. They announced their intention of addressing the Executive on the subject of their political disabilities.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S "African" will be given here to-night for the last time--this week. The house will present the gorgeous and striking appearance which is elsewhere described in this paper--the decorations of the "Arion Ball" remaining to-night and to-morrow at the matinee, which our readers will remeber comences at 11 o'clock--the doors oepning at 10; opera "Crispino ola Comare."

Orders have been received here to immediately discontinue the military district of Wilmington. Brevet Brig.-Gen. GOFF, commanding, goes to the command of his regiment, the Thirty-seventh Colored. The headquarters of the Smithville military post will be retained here with a garrison of four companies, and the Twenty-eighth Michigan.

While the Health Bill is in progress through the Legislature, and before it is defeated or perverted, (if that is to be the event,) we desire to call public attention to some instructive facts in regard to it. A morning cotemporary has professed of late an extreme anxiety ot render our municipal offices non-partisan.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE ANNUAL ELECTION.-The annual election of officers for the American Institute took place last evening, at the rooms of the Institute. The result was the election of HORACE GREELEY for President, that gentleman having received 152 votes, against 127 cast for Gen. WM. HALL, tile former President. The Vice-Presidents elected were

Late advices from Japan state that the Ministers of the United States, Great Britain, France and Holland, to demand the opening of Hiogo, the chief port of the inland sea, had been successful. Mikado had ratified treaties entered into between the Tycoon and foreign Governments, admitting Japan into comity with other nations.

Senator HARRIS has modified the bill which he introduced some time since for a reorganization of the Federal Judiciary, and thus modified has again introduced it into the Senate. Our readers will find it at leangth in another column.

A WONDERFL TERRITORY. -- The enterprising Territory of Montana found an opportunity of gratuitously advertising itself on Wednesday to an extent nad in a style rarely equaled by any of its rivals. A number of its citizens thoght proper to make their appearance in the President's presence,

The two great German singing societies, the Arion and the Liederkranz, annually give each a ball at the Academy of Music, at which the good people of the fraternities meet on masque and have jolly good times. The ball of the Arion Society was given last night; that of the Liederkranz follows on Thursday of next week.

A man named H. HAYWARD, of the firm of HAYWARD Co., who have an office at No. 229 Broadway, has been brought efore the Mayor several times on charges of swindling. It appears that HAYWARD Co. operate in the following manner: They first send a circular, stating that they ahve received 50 cents for two certificates, the said certificates being inclosed in the letter.

A smash-up resulting in the death of one passenger, and the injury of eight or ten others took place on the Newark and Bloomfield Railroad yesterday morning. As the train which leaves Montclair at 7:30 A. M., was approaching the Bloomfield station, a bridge over which it was going, suddenly gave way. The engine had passed over in safety but

We the undersigned, passengers by the General Trans-Atlantic Company's steamship Europe, on her voyage from New-York to Havre, on the 5th of January, desire to express to Capt. DUCHESNE, and through him to the officers and men under his command, our lively sentiment of obligation and gratitude for their vigilant and effective services during the passage that is now approaching its end.

The effort to convert and pervert a measure which concerns the health of the Metropolis, and the lives of its citizens, into a party machine,...

The Steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool at 2:30 o'clock on the afternoon of the 25th, via London-derry on the 26th of January, arrived at Portland at 8:15 o'clock yesterday monring. Her dates are one da laterthan those already received. The steamship Fullon, from Havre Jan. 24, also arrived yesterday.

A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was hold yesterday afternoon, to receive the report of the Special Committee appointed to confer with the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund on the general subject of the improvement of piers, and also in reference to the sale or lease of piers to the New-York Pier and Warehouse Company. Mr. JONATHAN STURGES presided. There were only eight members present.

THURSDAY, Feb. 8. 1866-2 o'clock P. M. The Board met pursuant to adjournment, is their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Councilmen Keenan, Long, Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, Kenney, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, Mackay, Kellogg, Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Pullman, Hettrick, Imlay--21.

ANOTHER CONCERT AT ORANGE, N. J.--Encouraged by the extraordinary success of the soiree of chamber music, given a few weeks since in Orange by Messrs. MASON THOMAS, the Library Association of that place has arranged for a concert at Library Hall, next Tuesday evening, which will, if possible, be an improvement upon the Previous one.

Advices from Honolulu to the 24th of January, state that great damage had been done by a hurricane there. The United States steamer Lancaster arrived at Honolulu on the 19th of January. Lieut. CUSHING, while ashore at Hilo, was thrown from his horse and his collar-bone broken.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The experiment of an early matinee will be tried to-day by Mr. MARETZEK. The performance, instead of commencing at 1, begins at 11 o'clock--the doors opening an hour earlier. There are undoubtedly many visitors to the city who will be pleased with this change.

Arrived, steamer Cassandra, from Boston. Sailed steamers AEtna and Herman for Boston, and Matamoras for New-York. The steamer Marmion spoke the brig Valencia on the 29th ult., bound for Boston, out of provisions, with which the Marmion supplied her.

The investigation into the causes of the late accident on the Morris and Essex Railroad, near Bloomfield, N. J., which resulted in the death of Mr. MILTON B. HOLT, and the serious injury of several other persons, was commenced before Coroner G. SANDFORD, yesterday afternoon. The following gentlemen composed the jury:

The Mount Hope Insane Asylum case progreases slowly. The Court decided to-day in favor of the admissibility of the yearly reports of the Asylum as evidence, which has been earnestly opposed by the defence. To-day the prosecution again attempted to proceed with the examination of the witnesses.

Eight United States soldiers, convicted by court-martial held in this city, were to-day drummed out of the service to serve their various terms of imprisonment, which range from five to seven years. They were marched through the streets with drums beating. Four of them had their heads shaved,

ASPINWALL, tile chief founder of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, vouches freely for the entire accuracy of the statement that active measures are being taken by himself and others, to permanently establish an additional line of communication between New-York and San Francisco, via Panama. The business of the Legislature of a great country ought not to be lightly suspended, and should never be suspended for the mere purpose of " honoring " the servants of that Legislature, no matter how illustrious or how deserving the recipients of such "honors" may be.

BISHOP--ROAT.--On Thursday, Feb. 1, in the City of new-York, by Rev. J. N. Shaffer. JAMES S. BISHOP and Miss CHATTIE W. ROAT, both of Jersey City. A party composed of the representatives of the leading trades of Norfolk started this morning from there on a commercial tour through North Carolina, for the purpose of inquiring into the business prospects of the various counties.

Lord MONCK arrived in this City yesterday, (by the Australasian,) on his way to Canada, where he will at once resume his functions as Governor-General of the Provinces.

The Health Bill was reported to the House this morning by Dr. CONGDON, Chairman of the Committee on Public Health, and immediately there occurred one of the most exciting scenes that has been witnessed since the session began. The Committee have amended the bill so as to conform to the Jenkins resolution in the Union caucus, giving the Governor power to appoint Sanitary Commissioners.

Gen. WRIGHT arrived from Galveston on the 1st inst. Col. BROWN succeeds Gen. WEITZEL in command of the Rio Grande district. Col. J. G. PERKINS succeeds Gen. SMITH in the command of a division of the Twenty-fifth Corps. The United States Provost-Marshal is busy arresting and disarming all parties in Brownsville and its neighborhood.

The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at St. Andrew's Church, Richmond, Staten Island, on Saturday, Feb. 10, at 2 P. M., without further invitation. FREEDMEN'S BUREAU. Among the very first things that the House did today was to take up the Freedmen's Bureau Bill as it passed the Senate last night, and concur in the amendment which the Senate made to the House amendment, which strikes out the words which confine its operations to the States wherein the writ of habeas corpus was suspended on the 1st of February, 1866.

DEPOPULATION OF NEW-YORK.--Three of the leading journals of this city, in view of the enormity of rents and the famine prices of food, have urged all who can remove from New-York to do so. We should be slow to give such advice.

THE NEW SOUTH.--We learn from the New Orleans papers that the demand for labor there in every department of mechanics is such as to absorb the entire supply. Never, since the first settlement of New-Orleans, has it been greater than it now is.

THE TWENTY-SECOND OF FEBRUARY.--Isn't it about time for the true Union men of the City to make arrangements for a becoming celebration of Washington's Birthday. We have had but one WASHINGTON, and those who honor him as he ought to be honored should rejoice in the opportunity to perpetuate his memory, his services, and his virtues.--Express.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your reporter, in noting the evidence concerning the disaster on the Bloomfield Railroad, unintontionally conveys the impression that my opinion as to its cause was not clear: I would therefore say, emphatically, that I believe it was occasioned by the giving away of timbers decayed by long service and insufficient in strength, having been designed originally (some eleven years since) for trains much lighter than those now run.

We chronicled lately in our columns the formation of a new society which has a novel and most humane aim. Its object was to form an American branch' of an International Association for relieving and protecting the wounded, of whatever country, in time of war; or, in other words, an extension of the principles which inspired our American "Sanitary Commission" to the whole world.

The season of slush is with us once again. A month ago, when the patient public rose and fell among the bills and valleys of our streets and side walks, fording creeks in Nassau-street or William, leaping chasms in Fulton, or wading over firmer-bottomed Broadway, they dreamed, deluded souls! that the weather and the other party had done their worst.

THE LATE BRIG.-GEN. H. M. JUDAH. Brig.-Gen. HENRY M. JUDAH, United States Volunteers, and Brevet Colonel United States Army, died of heart disease at Fonquett's Hotel, Plattsburg, N. Y., on Sunday, January 14, at 2 o'clock P. M. His remains wore taken to Westport, Conn., for interment, and the funeral was attended at that place on Saturday, January 20, by a large number of the personal and military friends of the deceased.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to correct the misrepresentation of your Panama correspondent, in your paper of to-day, concerning the Nicaragua route and the detention of passengers. It is singularly incorrect in every particular. We do not carry one-half the number of passengers stated, not do they wade in mud round the portages at the Rapids--the river being full of water, which renders portages quite superfluous.

There is a tract of land at the mouth of the Paraguay River, not much larger than the State of Rhode Island, on which are gathering the armies of four nations, Paraguay has withdrawn all her troops to her own "sacred soil," and awaits attack. At the angle of her territory formed by the confluence, almost at a right-angle of the Paraguay and Parana Rivers, there are two points of powerful resistance.

Some days ago we urged that our city railroad companies should allow the regular detectives of the police force to ride free upon their cars, believing that to be the best mode of driving off the pickpockets who operate at hours when the cars are most crowded. Since then we have paid some further attention to the matter, and have had the benefit of the experience of others.

The mystery surrounding the robbery of the National Bank of Concord, Mass., on the 25th of September last has been partially revealed, through the untiring efforts of the detectives. A few days since two of the robbers were captured in another State, and $196,000 of the money recovered, being about two-thirds of the total amount stolen.

The murder was committed to obtain the money it was supposed Mr. RICHARDSON carried about his person for safe-keeping.

BUSINESS IN CHARLESTON.--Business of all kinds in this city is more lively than it was month ago, and the merchants are in better spirits. This change has taken place, too, before the heavy Spring trade has really commenced. Buyers from the country are coming in gradually, and although they do not make large purchases, they order sufficient quantities of goods of goods to give an air of life to the interior of stores and warehouses.

Among the subjects the discussion of which is of more consequence than many suppose, is that of the cultivation of a refined taste in matters of dress. The apparel not only indicates but often moulds the character. As it is vulgar and outre or the reverse, so will the wearer become an expositor of the same qualities personally, if he have not done so already.

Saturday was a hard day for the fiddlers, and eke the performers on wind instruments, among whom may be numbered several critics. DEATH OF CAPT. WAINWRIGHT SCOTT.--The last Pacific Mail steamer brought intelligence of the death, at Acapulco, on the 5th of January, of Capt. ROBERT WAINWRIGHT SCOTT, commander of the gunboat Saginaw. Capt, SCOTT left this port with his vessel on the 27th of August, the very picture of vigorous health.

The memorial services on the death of ABRAHAM LINCOLN took place to-day, strictly according to the programme agreed upon beforehand. The arrangements seemed to have been perfectly made, and were perfectly carried out.

THE NATIONAL PEACE.-We are glad to hear that the able soldier, Gen. WEITZEL, who has just been relieved from duty on our Mexican frontier, does not " consider the country watered by the Rio Grande worth going to war about." On this point we are in perfect accord with Gen. WEITZEL. In fact there are but few things in this mundane sphere worth going to war about.

SENATOR WADE.--Th alleged attempt to assassinate Senator WADE has had a curious addition made to its history by the publication in the Washington papers of a long letter from the gigantic and ferocious " man in gray" who who was accused of the attempt. His name is W. L. FLEMING, and he describes himself as a " humble person" and a " Yankee mechanic."

BARKER.--At New-Rochelle, on Sunday, Feb. 11, STEPHEN BARKER, son of J. D. Barker, aged 18 years and 5 months. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral on Wednesday, Feb. 14, at 11 o'clock, from the residence of his father, Upper New-Rochelle. Trains leave 27th-st. at 9:30 A. M. Carriages in waiting at depot. BILLS.--On Sunday, Feb. 11, ELIZABETH, wife of Orrin A. Bills. and daughter of Col. Geo. Smith.
Advices have been received from San Salvador to the 20th of January. The Legislative Corps of the Republic was in session at the capital. The country was quite free from political agitation.

The act amending the revenue laws of the State passed to a third reading in the House to-day. It requires every bank to pay a tax of one per cent. to the Commonwealth on each share of stock; and railroad, canal and transportation companies not liable to taxes on incomes, to pay a tax of three-quarters of one per cent. on their gross receipts.

No one can follow the more recent speeches in the House on Constitutional questions without noticing that the violence of the radical faction has spent its force. A reaction from such irrational vehemence as has characterized Mr. STEVENS' utterances might naturally be looked for, were there no conservative influences at work to make the temper of extreme partizans more sober.

Such a demonstration as that made at Cooper Institute, last night, has rarely been seen in NEW York City. At 7 o'clock the hall was literally packed; at a quarter after the square in front was occupied by thousands of eager, struggling, restless men and women, each striving to obtain an entrance to the place before them. The House, on the 6th, passed, by 47 to 37, a bill an horizing the refunding of money paid into the Stale Treasury on account of the sale of runaway slaves sold since Jan. 1, 1863, by order of Court.

In the Senate yesterday bills were introduced to repeal the act for a ferry between Sag Harbor, Greenpoint and Riverhead; to regulate the sale of passenger tickets on railroads; to prohibit the throwing of ashes and other substances in the streets and public places in New-York. CROTON AQUEDUCT AND GRADE OF EIGHTH-AVENUE. Senator C. G. CORNELL introduced a bill amending the law passed April 27, 1865, as follows: After the map establishing the grade of Eighth-avenue, from Fifty-ninth to Ninety-third-street, shall be duly certified, it shall be the duty of the Street Commissioner to fix the grades of the streets connecting therewith, so as to give convenient access to said avenue.

A GRAND PRIZE FRONT IN THE MUD.--For some weeks past the "fancy" have been greatly excited over a grand bruising match between TOM CHANDLER and PETE MAGUIRE, for $1,000 a side. The steamer Center Costa left Broadway wharf on Wednesday morning with a small, but very select party of principals and spectators, some 150 in all, bound for the field of blood, mud and glory, near Lakeville Landing. THE ALGONQUIN AND WINOOSKI.-A very false impression is given to the public by the paragraphs in the newspapers announcing a trial of speed between the steamers Algonquin and Winooski ;-and this is made still more unjust and unfair by the announcement yesterday, on the authority of Mr. ISHERWOOD, that the Algonquin had failed to make her appearance for the race.

The spirits in the haunted house at Philadelphia have been exercised, and the Rev. SAMUEL DURBOROW tells how it was done, as follows: The Rev. SAMUEL DURBOROW states that he read the accounts in the Inquirer of the haunted house, and called next door to said house, on one of his parishioners.

THE SECOND ANNUAL BALL OF THE NATIONAL TELEGRAPHIC UNION,--The second annual ball of the National Telegraphic Union will come off at Irving Hall on the 19th inst. The Committee of Arrange ments are sparing n pains of expense to make it one of the most agreeable and elegant affairs of the season. The floor will be under the management of Mr. JOHN OLTMAN, assisted by a number of other well-known telegraphers.

A MODEST REQUEST.-The managers of the City railways ask the Superintendent of Police to instruct policemen, whenever there is cause to arrest a railway conductor or driver en route, to accompany him to the depot of his line, on the plea that if either one of these employes is taken from his car, the car must be stopped then and there, and the line be choked in consequence.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--The Board held a meeting last evening and transacted considerable routine business. The President, Alderman BLISS, occupied the chair. A communication from the Mayor was presented, in which he calls attention to the fact that a number of contracts had not yet been awarded, and that the interests of the city were suffering thereby.

Dr. HUGHES, the murderer of TAMSEN PAYONS, was hanged at Cleveland, on Friday last. The Leader says: At twenty-five minutes to 1 o'clock, HUGHES, accompanied by the Sheriff and his Deputy, and Professor THOME, ascended the seaffold, with a firm step.

From the Mobile News. A gentleman of this city has received a letter from Capt. WADDELL, tormerly in command of the cruiser Shenundoab, dated Dec. 27, Waterloo, near Liverpool, from which we are permitted to make such extracts as may be of interest to the general public.

Tho United States steam cutter Powluxet, Capt. FENGAR, went ashore on the back side of Cape Cod this afternoon, in a thick fog. She was not considered in much danger, and was expected to come off at high water.

The Houston Telegraph of late date says that many of the planters declare that their hands never accomplished as much work before, were never more obedient or better disposed, and that, wind and weather favoring, they Will mike more cotton this year than they ever made in any one year before.

The closing exercises of the Eighth Ward evening school (male department) took place in the large hall of Grammar School No. 38, in Clark, near Broome-street, last evening. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, the attendance was good. In the absence of JOHN R. RUSSL, Esq., Chairman of the local Board, MATTHIAS CLARK, Esq., presided.

The House of Assembly will be called upon to act to-day on one of the most important matters ever brought before a New-York Legislature-a bill to promote the public health of New-York and Brooklyn. This bill comes at a time when there may stand but a few weeks between our present condition and the approach of cholera.

The Mount Hope conspiracy case was continued to-day. The defence objected to the admission of any evidence prior to 1865. The Court reserved its decision. The Court previously had decided to admit the declarations of a former Sister Superior as evidence in the case, its value to be subsequently determined by the Court.

The work in the yard has slacked off to a great extent since the close of the rebellion, which was followed by a large number of discharges from the mechanical and laboring departments. The force now employed numbers about 2,800 men, for whom there is, however, sufficient to do; no more being retained than can accomplish that which is required under the present peaceful aspect of affairs.

BURNS.--On Monday, Feb. 12, ALEXANDER BURNS, in the 54th year of his age. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at 1 o'clock P. Last evening, Washington Hall, Newark, N. J., was crowded to its utmost capacity with a highly, intelligent, respectable and enthusiastic audience, in support of a new railroad between Newark and this City, in view of the neglect on the part of the NewJersey Railroad Company to furnish proper accommodations for passengers going between the two cities. a Hon. JAMES M. QUIMBY presided, and stated the object of the meeting. JAMES E. GOLL, Esq., was Secretary.

The following resolutions were introduced into the House branch of the Maine Legislature to-day by Gen. SHEPUEY, of Portland, in relation to equality of civil and political rights: Resolved, That the grand result of a truly republican government can never be fully attained, until equality of civil and political rights be permanently secured irrespective of differences of race and color.

Wallack's Theatre has become of late the resort of many private, or rather semi-private associations, which shrink from the vast amplitudes of the academic state; and among the occasions which have rendered its daylight revelations memorable are the delightful semi-annuals of the students of Columbia College. yesterday, at ten A. M., one of these affairs was held.

The Republican State Convention, which meets in this city to-morrow, promises to be one of the largest and ablest Conventions which has assembled in Connecticut for years. The attendance at the caucus to-night is quite large, and a good feeling prevails. The Convention will indorse President JOHNSON, affirm their confidence in the patriotism of Congress, and reaffirm the doctrines and principles under which the party has fought for the past five years,

The Texas State Convention organized on Saturday. The Convention voted, by 66 to 11, that all the members should support the Constitution of the United States. A resolution that all who had not hither done so should take the amnesty oath was reconsidered.

In the hottest periods of partisanship the American people have seldom disregarded the impulses of patriotism. Their zeal for party leaders and party platforms is tempered by a devotion to their country. For that they are prepared to sacrifice everything. And unless that be the controlling consideration in party movements, and the paramount end of party effort, they promptly withhold the support which is essential to party success.

ASH WEDNESDAY.--To-day is the commencement of Lent, or the forty days fast, accompanied by penitential exercises prescribed by the Church. In the early ages, when public penance was imposed, it was customary on this day for the offender to stand outside the church covered with a coarse garment, with ashes sprinkled on his head, and listen to the lamentations of those within the sanctuary.
The Examiner office was closed at 9 o'clock this evening, by order of Gen. TERRY. The order is said to have emanated from Gen. GRANT.

CORPORATION DONATIONS.--We are glad to see that the Common Council have at length taken action upon the subject of donations to blind men. They have been rapidly increasing in number, and their total must have reached a very large addition to the city expenses.

Its statement that Mr. RAYMOND shaped the bill of four years ago, is inoorrect, as is also its statement that Mr. RAYMOND put his brother-in-law upon the committee which had charge of that bill.

The ship Hamlet, Capt. STEVENS, from Calenita for Boston. with a valuabale cargo of East India goods, went ashore during a thick fog, last night, o Nauset beach, at Orleans, Cape Cod, and will be a total loss. her back is broken and she is full of water. Crew saved. The Hamlet was 757 tons burden. She was built in 1851, and was owned by W. C. ROGERS Co.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S Opera of "Don Sebastian" was revived last night with complete success. The work possesses all the elements of popularity, and satisfies the eye as well as the ear. The ensembles, and tableaux are effective in both reaspects, particularly that at the end of the third act. Mr. MARETZEK'S chorus and orchestra are better now than they were last year.

THE CHOLERA CONFERENCE. The President, to-day, sent to each House of Congross a message, transmitting for their consideration a correspondence between the Secretary of State and the Minister of Prance accredited to this Government, and also other papers relative to the proposed international conference at Constaniinople, upon the subject of the cholera.

Gov. HAMILTON sent a message into the Texas State Convention to-day. It calls attention to the absolute requirement of the General Government touching the doctrine of absolute State sovereignty, the abolition of slavery, the right of the blacks to testify in courts of justice and to be protected in person and property, and the repudiation of the rebel debt.

Yesterday was St. Valentine's Day, as everybody knows or ought to know, and it may cheer the hearts of those who cling lovingly to ancient customs to know that the venerable Saint had at least the usual number of votaries at his shrine.

GERRIT SMITH has written a letter to Senator SUMNER bearing date Peterboro, Feb. 5. He says: I see that the House of Representatives approves, and by a very strong vote, the proposed Apportionment Amendment of the Constitution. I see, too, that nearly all the members, who are the most radical friends of freedom, are included in this vote; and that there is, therefore, no room in the case for questioning motives.
