The brig Vinoent, 74 days from London for Boston, with a general cargo of merchandise, struck on Sow-and-Pigs Ledge on Monday, at noon, during a thick fog, and bilged. She will probably prove a total loss, unless good weather prevails. All hands saved. A steamtug and lighter have gone from here to her assistance.

A commission has been appointed by Congress to select a site for a New-York Postoffice. The Commission consists of the Mayor of the City, Mr. Low, President of the Chamber of Commerce; Mr. A. J. SCHULTZ, and Postmaster KELLY--all unexceptionable men.

The gentleman from Arkansas, whose claim to a seat in the lower House of Congress was made the subject of a test vote on Tuesday, is known at home as Col. JAMES JOHNSON, of the First Arkansas Infantry. His case is one which deserves a better fate.

The speech from which we herewith print a few extracts was read In tile Tennessee House of Representatives on the 2d instant. Major LEWIS, now 83 years of age, is the senior member of that body. His great age and feeble voice precluded his delivering the address himself, and it was read for him by Mr. PORTLY, the member for Shelby.

The saying " Give an inch, and he'll take an ell," was never better exemplified than in the conduct of some of the City railroad companies. Practically, these corporations have been granted a fee simple, right, title and interest to the public thoroughfares.

Two FATAL BRNNING CASUALTIES.--At 9 O'clock last night a little girl named HATTIE PRATT was left by her mother sitting by a table, while she ran out on an errand. During her absence the child accidentally upset the kerosene oil lamp, her clothes catching fire from the explosion which followed. An alarm of fire was given.

In the Senate, yesterday, a petition for recognition from the Senators and Representatives elect from Tennessee, was referred to the Committee of Fifteen. Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from certain women of New-England for the abolition of sex in certain cases. It is but just to add that the Senator declined to indorse the proposition. Petitions of deputy assessors of internal revenue for increased pay were presented.

The Union State Convention, which met in this city to-day, was one of the largest, ablest and most harmonious Conventions which has assembled in this State for many years. The delegates numbered over four hundred, comprising a large number of the leading men in the State. Col. DEXTER R. WRIGHT, of New-Haven, was President of the Convention.

THE POSTAGE STAMP CREDIT BILL. The morning hour in the House to-day was entirely occupied with the discussion of the Postage Stamp Credit Bill. The features of the debate were the same as yesterday. The Radicals made an effort to lay the bill on the table, which failed by the decisive vote of 30 yeas to 108 nays. The bill was then postponed for two weeks.

The annual masquerade ball of the Liederkranz Society was given last night at the Academy of Music with entire success. For many years this festival has been held in high favor by the beat of our people, the purchasers of tickets being found in every circle of art and literature, bound by no national ties, confined by no hamperings of prejudice.

The case of Brig.-Gen. (?) COOLBAUGH, which was heard before Justice DOWLING at the Tombs Police Court yesterday, is of this remarkably bold and reckless kind.

After several vexations disappointments, adjournments, embankments and disembarkments, your reporter came on board this morning with a determination to remain until the race was either completed or abandoned.

The ship Herald of the Morning, from Shields, with a cargo of coal and chemicals, while entering this harbor during a southeast rain storm, last night, got ashore on False Spit, half a mile inside of Boston Light, staving a hole in her bottom. She remains in the same position this morning, ten feet of water in her hold.

Dates from the City of Mexico to the 27th of January are received. The Imperialists had gained a great success in the surrender to them of Papantla by the Liberal Gens. MURIAZ and ALALOE. The city, after the surrender, acknowledged the authority of the Empire. The principal officers are to go abroad if they wish to do so.

The bank at Liberty, Clay County, Mo., was robbed on Tuesday afternoon of $72,000, under the following circumstances: Twelve men entered the town about 2 o'clock, three of whom guarded the suburbs of the place. The other nine went to the Clay County Savings Association, seven of whom guarded the outside of the building, while the other two entered.

PENMANSHIP.--Mr. W. E. SHADER'S sytem of penmanship, published by APPLETON, deserves some notice from the common sense principles on which the author proceeds. Mr. SHADER belives that the worst method of teaching writing is to adopt that which proceeds on the fine, effeminate, angular, or zigzag system,

Honolulu dates to the 27th of January are received. The United States war ship Lancaster was still there. The officers were being extensively feted by the Hawalian authorities. There is no news of importance. The Victoria Chranicle announces the total loss of the American bark Mustang, Jan. 21. Bhe left San Franctsco on the 14th.

Mr. BROWN reported, without amendment, the bill to reimburse the State of Missouri for moneys expended for the United States in enrolling, equipping and provisioning militia forces to aid in suppressing the rebellion. It provides for the appointment of a commissioner to ascertain the amount so expended since Aug. 24, 1861.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A merchant of many years standing, and a citizen of unimpeachable character, (MICHAEL L. DOYLE, Esq., of No. 267 Grand-street,) having purchased in good faith a bill of silks, afterward alleged to have been stolen, was, notwithstanding his character, his position, and his exhibition of his bill and receipt, compelled by Justice DOWLING to give bail on Monday. Feb. 5. to answer to a charge of larceny.

The Health Bill has passed the Assembly, as amended there, appointing five Commissioners-three of whom shall be physicians and two laymen-all to be chosen by the Governor. The Police, if we are not misinformed, are to be excluded altogether.

GOV. PEIBPOINT sent a communication to the Legislature to-day, recommending three Judges of the Court of Appeals and fifteen Circuit Judges. The nominations are generally approved by the conservative members of the Legislature, but a decided opposition to one or two names was anticipated.

SKATING ON THE FIFTH-AVENUE POND.--Maj. OATMAN announces that to-day that the Fifth-avenue Pond is in excellent order for skating. For the accommodation of all who desire to spend the day or part of it on the ice, the pond will be open, and the gallant Major ready to welcome guests to any extent. As the season is fast drawing toward an end, opportunities like that offered to-day are, of course, becoming less frequent.
The House of Assembly, late last night, after a stubborn fight, passed the bill ratifying the lease of the Morris and Essex Railroad to the Great Western Railroad.

A heavy snow storm prevailed yesterday and last night all over the northwest. The weather is Cohler than it has been any time this Winter, the thermometer ranging from 15 to 30 degrees below zero. All the railroads in Wisconsin and Minnesota are more or less blocked up by snow, and it will take a day or two for the trains to go running again. go running again.

By Mr. Low-To regulate the construction of the Metropolitan Railroad, in Brooklyn. By Mr. FOLGER-To amend the charter of the United States Watch Company; also, in case of Judge SMITH, of Oneida County, that the complainant and accused be present with counsel, and that an investigation be conducted before the Judiciary Committee of the Senate; which was agreed to.

The announcement made by the French Emperor in his speech of the 22d ult., as to the policy he proposes to adopt in regard to the case of Mexico, does not detract from the value or interest of the diplomatic dispatches of DROUYN DE LHUYS, which we received from Europe yesterday, and which are published in our present issue.

Mardi-Gras was celebrated here, last evening, in a style not surpassed in many years, in the number and splendor of the balls and other kinds of public amusements, and the hosts of people who attended them or filled the streets to watch the merry maskers.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--AUBER'S delightful opera of "Fra Diavolo" will be given here to-night for the first time this season. The cast is in every way effieient and admirable.

CAMPBELL.--On Thursday, Feb.15, after a short illness, THOMAS N. CAMPBELL, In the 64th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, No. 82 West 14th--st., Saturday, afternoon at 3 o'clock. day, afternoon at 3 o'clock.

THE NEWARK AND NEW-YORK RAILROAD.Monopolies and Copperheads seem to have gone down together in New-Jersey. The battle over the Newark and New-York Railroad charter ended yesterday in the lower house of the State Legislature, with the concession of the grant desired,
We print on another page extended reports of the operations of the Government steamers Winooski and Algonquin, during their recent experiments as to speed, use of fuel, , in Long Island Sound.

No intelligent man has ventured to deny the importance of the interests involved in the question of reciprocity. On the contrary, everybody who has approached the question, whether from the protectionist or free trade standpoint, has conceded its magnitude, and the necessity of according to it careful and candid consideration.
The Union members of the Senate and Assembly held a joint caucus this evening to nominate a candidate for Police Commissioner to succeed Mr. McMURRAY. Senator FOLGER was called to the chair.

The readers of the Spirit will bear in mind that our columns have repeatedly, within the last two years, urged upon Congress the adoption of a name for this country, which should be sui generis, like the names of France, Austria, Russia, England, and not a copy of the names of several other countries, with but a slight modification of their titles.

In the Legislature to-day the Committee on Federal Relations reported a series of resolutions deolaring that the safety of the Government depends upon adherence to the cardinal principle that all men are created free and equal. While rejoicing over the restoration of the Union, we earnestly protest against any policy of reconstruction which disregards these vital principles and admits the enemies of the Government to participate in its administration.
Incorporating the Manor House Hotel Company of Westchester County; extending the charter of the New-York Female Assistance Society.

Mr. BOWLES, in his very clever book, descriptive of California and Colorado, makes somewhere the remark that it is doubtful if the majority of the individuals engaged in mining in California and Nevada have made more profits than if they had been employed in agriculture.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--AUBER'S sparkling opera of "Fra Diavolo" was given here, last night, to an exceedingly good and fashionable audience. The cast was the same as heretofore. Miss KELLOGG was in admirable voice, and sang and acted with equal brilliancy.
A meeting of the Commissioners of Health was held yesterday at noon. Present--His Honor the Mayor, Messrs. BRICE and GREEN, and Drs. SAYRE and MORRIS.

In the House, this morning, Mr. JENKINS, of New-York, moved that the Assembly insist upon its amendments to the Metropolitan Health Bill, and that a committee of conference be appointed. The motion was carried without any division, and subsequently Speaker TREMAIN appointed Messrs. JENKINS, of New-York; HISCOOK, of Onondaga; PITTS, of Orleans;

Major-Gen. W. R. CHALMERS has addressed the following card to the Memphis Avalanche: "I'had occasion to go to my former State (Mississippi) on business a few days since, and found on my return your city full of a rumor that I had left the country to avoid arrest by the United States government. As this report is calculated to do me much injury I ask you to correct it.

ZENO BURNHAM, THE MOCK ACOTIONEER IN SING SING.--Deputy Sheriff RYNDERS, who conveyed ZENO BURNFAM, the mock auctioneer, to Sing Sing, says that ZENO took his fate "very hard," and that he charged conspiracy against the parties who had secured his conviction. s Understood that Mr.

The Board met pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--Councilman Keenan, Stacom, Robinson, O'Brien, Kenney, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, White, Mackay, Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Roberts, Pullman, Hettrick, Imlay-20.

Houses and Lots For Sale EverywhereBrisk Trade in the Exchange Salesroom-Property Sold and For Sale. In no previous February were so many dwellings in and near the City offered for sale, and never before were prices so high as now. At the ferry gates and on the dead walls, in every place of public resort, the conspicuous advertisement is almost invariably headed "For Sale."

The Spanish war steamer, Dona Isabella la Catolica, arrived at this port yesterday from Havana. The Isabella la Catolica is commanded by Capt. JoACKIM POSADIL, and is a paddle-wheel steamer of 500horse power, carrying 16 guns, with a crew of about 160 men.

GRANT'S NEXT RECEPTION.--A Boston paper belabors the "muscular heathen" of this City who getup receptions to Gen. GRANT, and who, it says, have already " wrung his hand and trodden on his toes to an extent to gratify the most ambitious mortal."

The iceboats Minnehaha, Snowflake and Icicle, carrying twelve to fourteen gentlemen, left here this morning for Albany. The river between here and that city is covered with one continuous sheet of smooth ice, and the wind blowing fresh from the westward the speed of the boats will surpass that of the cars on the Hudson River Railroad.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. DIXON introduoed a bill to prevent a fraudulent use of the mail. It authorizes the non-delivery of packages or letters sent to fictitious addresses, and imposes a fine for mailing handbills and circulars to invite investments in lotteries or gift enterprises.

A MORMON DIFFCULTY.--Congress has not yet taken action upon any of the numerous bills that have been introduced for abolishing the system of polygamy in Utah. The fact is, the question is one more difficult to deal with practically than some had supposed. The passage of an act would of course-or rather should of course-imply its enforcement;

THE FREEDMEN'S BUREAU. There is a great deal of speculation, especially in Congress, as to the President's intended action on the Freedmen's Bureau Bill. The general feeling of the more moderate men of the Union Party is, that his refusal to approve it would be productive of bad results in confirming the distrust of his sentiments and purposes which have been so generally excited.
THE SOUTHERN PRESS--A great deal of bad spirit seems to be developing itself in the Southern Press. The Richmond Examiner, which has just been suspended by Gen. TERRY,

The following is a brief synopsis of this report, showing the condition and working of the Common Schools of the State for the school year ending Sept. 30, 1865: The number of school districts is 11,780, showing an increase over those reported the preceding year of 63.
The House has passed a bill submitting the question of establishing a Penitentiary to a vote of the people.

The funeral of Bishop FITZPATRICK took place this forenoon, and was of the most solemn and imposing character. The exercises took place in the Cathedral Chapel of the Holy Cross, on Washington-street, where the body of the deceased Bishop, in full canonicals, lay open to view in the central aisle.

A NEW FIRM IN THE BOOK-TRADE.--ROBERT M. STREBEIGH, for several years prominently connected with the publishing department of the New-York Tribune, has formed a copartnership with GEORGE A. and WILLIAM R. LEAVITT, book auctioneers, and the firm will hereafter be known as LEAVITT, STREBEIGH Co.

ILLEGAL USE OF THE MAILS. Mr. DIXON introduced a bill to prevent the perversion of the mails to iraudulent and illegal purposes. It authorizes the Postmaster-General to prevents the delivery of packages or letters sent to fictitions addresses. Whenever he is that a fraud or deception is intended, such letters shall be sent to the Dead-letter office, and thence to the writers.
The United States flag-ship Lancaster arrived here this morning from Honolulu. The steamer Ajaz reached Honolulu from this port on the 27th ult., having had an exceedingly stormy passage.
SUPREME COURT -- GENERAL TERM.
The internal revenue of the National Treasury averaged $6,830,828 in each of the past two weeks, and will amount to about five million dollars in the week now closing.

THE CATTLE DISEASE--VACCINATION.--We observe that Mr. JENNER, whose father assisted Dr. JENNER in the discovery of vaccination for small-pox, has written to the English newspapers on the subject of vaccination of cattle as a preventive of the rinderpest.

Among the multitude of Constitutional Amendments offered in Congress there is one which the reporters seem to have overlooked or passed by without attention. It is that offered on the 5th inst. by Mr. ANDERSON, of Missouri, to establish a positive name for our country and Government, in place of the awkward sentence "The United States of America."
BARKER.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Feb. 14, at the residence of her son, Dr. John Barker, Mrs. ELIZABETH BARKER, aged 71 years. The remains will be taken to Wallingford, Conn., for interment.

BORING THE PRESIDENT.--For several weeks after Mr. JOHNSON'S accession to the Presidency he was beset with delegations of various kinds, colors and sizes, some wishing to say one thing and some another, but all desirous of compelling him to make a speech, whether he had anything in particular to say or not.
OSCAR DERBY, charged with altering postal currency from "five" to "fifty" cents, who was put under $2,000 bonds to answer the charge, absconded this morning, and his bail has been declared forfeited.

About 7:30 o'clock last evening, the Sergeant in charge at the Twenty-second Precinct Station-house was informed that a terrible tragedy had taken place in Forty-seventh-street, between Eighth-avenue and Broadway, a mother having murdered her three little children, and then attempted to commit suicide.

It was near this place that the discovery of gold in 1858 was made. The discoverers, for lack of other name, called the locality "Pike's Peak." The Peak is distant from Denver at least seventy-five miles, but in plain view, and, to all appearances, not more than twenty miles away. The gold first discovered was of the scale formation, and is still found in quautities too small to pay for working.

A messenger of the United States Express Company, while delivering a package in the upper part of a building on Third-street, about 10 o'clock this morning, was robbed of $40,000, nearly all the contents of his satchel.

The City of London from Liverpool Jan. 31 and Queenstown Feb. 1, arrived here yesterday morning. Her dates are one day later than those by the Bremen. MASRID, Tuesday, Jan. 30-Evening. Two Chilian prrvateers have been seen off the coast of Spain. The frigate Isabel has received orders to pursue them.

BOYD.--On Friday, Feb. 16, MARIA ANN BOYD, widow of James Boyd, in the 78th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, No. 409 West 21st-st., on Monday afternoon at 3 1/2 o'clock. BARTON.--at Buffalo, on Friday, Feb. 16, PHINEAS BARTON, in the 71st year of his age, former of Leicester, Miss.

The last reported events of Gen. PRIM'S undertaking are that he has retired to Portugal, and that his army had disbanded. We regard the intelligence on these points as not wholly free from exaggeration and doubt. But if it be strictly true, and if the whole revolt be actually crushed, the causes which induced it still remain, and the whole matter cannot be said to have received its final settlement.

Truman," in his letter of Jan. 20, published Feb. 4, is good as far as it goes, but there are some important facts which he has omitted to state.

New-Zealand dates of the 29th of January are received. Sixteen Wakatler murderers had been sentenced to be executed. The Maori war continued. The native forces were defeated by the English with heavy loss, on the 30th of November, at Poverly Bay. Koohan had been evacuated by the rebels, after a severe engagement.

A DAY OP SPEECIH-MAKlNG. This day was devoted to spooch-making. Mr. KETCHUM presented the remonstrance of P. S. WYNKOOP and others, raper and envelope manufacturers and dealers and stationers, of Dutchess and Columbia Counties, N. Y., against the passage of the bill to authorize the Postmaster-General to sell .stamped envelopes at the value of the stamps thereon. Referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Postroads.

A passage-at-arms occurred to-day in the Tennessee House of Representatives between the Speaker, Mr. HASKELL, and Mr. MULLENS, a Roprosentative. The discussion arose about the power of the Speaker to compel members to vote, when Mr. HASKELL called Mr. MULLENS "a demand old liar" and "a lying scoundrel,"

This city is, nominally at least, the seat of the Government of Canada. The circumstance, however, by no means prevents its ordinary Winter condition being as lifeless as any place can possibly be. In Summer, it is far otherwise, the utmost activity then prevailing, Ottawa being the principal emporium of the greatest of Canadian staples-the produce of her boundless forests.

One great fundamental principle inherent in a democratic form of government is that those living beneath its sway are accorded perfect liberty of speech. Any orator, professional or temporarily inspired, may exhaust his lungs upon 'any topic, and before any gathering, in as wild and ferocious a manner as the temper of his audience will allow.

Mr. RAYMOND'S speech on the proposed apportienment amendment to the Conetitution contains the only gleam of comfort to lighten the gloom which has settled down on everybody with regard to the action of Congress toward the Southern States.

On Friday and yesterday more ice made its appearance in the Bay and the North and East Rivers Lan has been seen there for years past, causing great inconvenience to the residents of Brooklyn, Jersey City and Hoboken, by delaying the regular trips of the ferry-boats.

While sojourning here to take note of the proceedings at the trial of the dapper young gentlemen who found their way into the treasure chests of Adams Express Company, on their way from New-York to Boston, I have enjoyed the opportunities offered during brief recesses of court to see the improvements of this fast-growing town.

No city in the world is so like Paris as NewYork. Many of the unique features of that gayest of capitals are reflected and reproduced only here. Paris represents the essence and intensity and variety of the Continent, as New-York does the feverish and many-sided forms of life in America.

Monday last was a somewhat notable day in this city, The new City Hall- rather dumpy, twostory building of stone,-60 feet square-was "dedicated." The ceremonies were singing, prayer, speeches, supper, and dancing all night, an uncommon mixture in most localities, but not so here.

Yesterday the Conference Committee of the two Houses of the Legislature settled the differences upon the Health Bill, and it was reported as amended. The Senate adopted it, 23 to 22; the Assembly did not vote, their copy not being perfected, but will undoubtedly concur.

THE ELECTION OF HON. A. H. STEPHENS TO THE UNITED STATES SENATE.--A largo number of both branches of the Georgia Legislature have issued an address coutroverting some statements made by Hon. JOSHUA HILL. They say that Mr. STEPHENS was not privy to the plan inaugurated for his election, and the determination to run him was based upon the idea first, that he was the choice of the people;

The steamship City of London arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her dates are one day later than those by the Bremen. The political news is unimportant, A fancy fair and a concert, in aid of the Fenian prisoners, had been prohibited in Dubiln. There are no signs of the Canada at Ha ifax or the Balgian at Portland. Both steamers are overdue.

UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE. Before Commissioner Osbom. Yesterday John Hartman was taken before Commissioner Osborn, charged with having in his possession large quantities of counterfeit United States currency of various denominations. From the testimony of Thomas Bowles, a detective in the employ of the Solicitor of the United States Treasury, it appears that he having tracked the prisoner, caused him to be arrested by a sergeant of police;

The Oregon Union State Convention meets on, the 29th of March next. The United States sloof-of-war Cyane has arrived here. The steamer Pacific, from Oregon, with $140,000 in treasure, has also arrived.

Right Rev. JOHN B. FITZPATIRCK, Catholic Bishop of Boston, departed this life at his residence, on Washington-street, at 20 minutes before 7 o'clock this morning. JOHN BERNARD FITZPATRICK was born in Boston on the first day of November, 1812, and received his early training in the public schools of this city, of which he was a model scholar.

Philanthropy, considered as merely a sentiment, is often unwise, short-sighted and suicidal-unwise as to the means adopted to secure its ends, short-sighted as to possible results, and suicidal because in its blind jostlings in the midst of facts which it cannot appreciate it stumbles and is trodden under foot.

Seward, Secretary of Sidle : SIR: Permit one who feels a deep interest in the success of the Paris Universal Exposition for 1867, to address you a few lines relative to that Exposition from a Western stand-point. Missouri just emerging from the sufferings of a four years' war, is feeling her way slowly but surely amid the great changes through which she has passed and is passing.

We have had frequent occasion to record, and always with deprecation, the course of many of the newspapers in the Southern States since their resumption of publication. The Press ought to be a reflex of popular sentiment; yet in the case of a great number of the most influential journals in the lately rebel States, we are afraid that the reverse is the fact;

Gen. GRANT has issued a circular letter, addressed to Department Commanders, requiring them to report to head-quarters newspapers that contain sentiments of disloyalty and hostility to the Government in any of Its branches. The inquiry is made with a view to their suppression, which is to be done by his order from head-quarters only.

The prominent feature in the Health Bill, as it passed the Senate, was, that it put a very positive power in the hands of certain men well known as honest, intelligent, and fearless-a power which would be strong and active enough to coerce sanitary reform.

We notice a bill before our Legislature of a really alarming character--one that will do more to drive our citizens from the City than any yet proposed. Nothing less it than to prevent any person who is a "non-resident of the State from selling any provisions in our markets." This will oblige all the New-Jersey people to sell their provisions in bulk to the middlemen.

The City Council yesterday passed resolutions asking the Legislature for authority to issue bonds for the purchase of gas works. The amount is not specifled. They also ask for anthority-to issue bonds to the amount of $500,000 for the construction of a new hospital, and to levy a tax of one mill on a dollar for sewerage purposes.

WHAT DOES IT MEAN ?--The Columbus, Ga., Sun publishes the following notice, dated at the office of the Assistant Special Agent of the United States Treasury Department, in that place, and signed by G. J. A. ALEXANDER:

The church and congregation which worship in the Fifth-avenue Baptist Church, on Forty-sixthstreet, yesterday commemorated the twenty-fifth anniversary of their existence with most interesting and appropriate services. The commodious edifice was crowded at the morning service, which commenced at 10:30 o'clock.

ASSAULTED BY ROWDIES.--Two young men, named DAVID VAN COTT and HENRY C. BROOKS, were arrested by the Forty-third Precinct Police on Saturday night, on the complaint of Mr. SAMUEL PARKER, of No. 180 Degraw-street, who charges that while on his way home, and near his residence, he was violently assaulted by the accused, one of whom struck him on the head with a sand-bag.

HIGWAY ROBBERY. PATRICK KEARNS, a resident of Alleghany County, in this State, while passing the corker of Seventh-avenue and Eighteenth-street, during Saturday evening, inquired the way: to Sullivan-street. A crowd of roughs who were standing on the corner gathered round KEARNS, and one of them put an arm round his neck, when the others took from his person an overcoat, a dress, coat, and $37 in United States Treasury notes from his pantaloons pocket.

Dr. MASSEY, long a resident of Mexico, is to lecture on the subject of the past and present history of that country, at Cooper Institute, on Tuesday evening. The Lecturer is thoroughly familiar with men and things in Mexico, and those who can find it convenient to be present on Tuesday evening will be entertained as well as instructed.

OUR NATIONAL CREDIT.--It is a week or more since we were informed by telegraph of a "great conspiracy against American credit" which had been organized in Canada. Its object was declared to be the breaking down of the finances of our Government by some wonderful means.

This is the commercial capital of the Lone Star dominions, and the city where they shoot cross-eyed men and red-headed women at sight, where they used to draw and quarter a Dutchmen, scheme for emigration, and eat pork until you can feel the bristles.

The long-talked-of and much-thought-of iceboat expedition to Albany from Poughkeepsie has been accomplished, and it was in every way a satisfactory one, if we may, perhaps, except speed. Iceboats have of late years become numerous, there being over one hundred of them on the Hudson River at the present time.

The annual report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction contains, as usual, some valuable and suggestive statements. The subject of education is the most important one that can come before our community. With a good system of schools for our masses, we may be able to resist all the evil effects of a poor immigration, as well as the concentration of social evils in our large cities.

The Times' Brownsville letter reports a fight between CANAILES and CORTINAS, in which the latter was worsted. Murder and robbery are the order of the day on the Rio Grande. Much terror prevails. All persons now cross from Matamoras to Brownsville without horses.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: More than a year ago, in the Pathological Institute of Berlin, after having examined, at the instigation of Prof. REED VIRCHOU, its head, several samples of food, sausage and wurst of pork, which contained Trichinae, I wrote and transmitted to this country an account of the disease the use of such food had caused in Germany.

SUPPRESSION OF THE RICHMOND EXAMINER. The history of the suppression of the Richmond Examiner has not been heretofore given to the public. We are now enabled to present a brief statement of the whole matter as it occurred. The special articles to which exception was taken appeared in the Examiner respectively of the dates of Jan. 26 and Feb. 5 and 6.

BARCLAY.--On Friday night, Feb. 16, Mrs. AUGUSTA, wife of Dr. Barclay, and daughter of Jos. Baldwin, of Newark, in the 36th year of her age. Funeral at 11 o'clock on Tuesday, 20th inst. from the Episcopal Church in Freehold, N. J. Friends, of the family are invited to attend. BORROWE.--At Stamford, Conn., on Saturday morning, Feb. 17, SARAH, widow of William Borrowe, and daughter of the late James Barrow, of New-York.

SOUTH CAROLINA.--Mr. PERRY, recently the Provisional Governor of South Carolina, but who is now waiting in Washington for admission to Congress as Senator from that State, has written a long letter upon national restoration, and in behalf of the State he was elected to represent.

Looking to the returns of internal revenue for the past three years, it may be ascertained with tolerable certainty to what great sources we shall henceforth have to look for meeting the fiscal exigencies of the Government. From tobacco (including cigars) we got, in the year ending June last, over eleven million dollars, against about one-fourth that amount in 1863.

To deprecate the endless manufacture of propositions purporting to be amendments of the Constitution, is not necessarily to affirm the divine origin or unchangeable character of that instrument. We are not required to make the infallibility of its authors a saving article of faith, or to forswear all modification or enlargement of its terms.

Yesterday morning, people in Richmond anxiously expectant for an Examiner-ical description of the officers' hop were disappointed, as Gen. GRANT, Secretary STANTON, or Gen: TERRY--some fearful military power at any rate--considering that treason had been ventilated under his or their noses long enough, closed the Examiner office, and prohibited the further issue of the paper at present.
Early yesterday morning a fire broke out in the staten Island Journal office, in the top story of the building known as Van Riper's corner Bay and Canal streets, Stapleton.

The steamer Manhattan arrived yesterday from Vera Cruz. She brings no news of interest. The French steam transport Jura arrived here on the 8th inst., with troops on their way to France. Yesterday was the first day of the carnival, the festivities of which have been declining from year to year.

DUNN--PRICK.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday evening, Feb. 15, at the residence of Lieut, W.P. Buckner, U.S. N., by Rev. H. A. Spafard, JOHN DUNN of Brooklyn, and JOSEPHINE A. PRICE, of Baltimore. Nocards. Hon Henry J. Raymond, House of Representatives: DEAR SIR: While listening to your able argument, last week, in regard to the continuancy of a State, I was struck by the idea that the "Sonderbund" rebellion of 1847, in Switzerland, was a strong case in point. On examining the question, I find it to be so.

The Peculiar and mysterious tragedy in Forty-seventh-street, a full report of which was given in yesterday's TIMES, caused intense excitement in the immediate neighborhood during the whole of yesterday. A crowd was almost constantly congregated in the street near the shanty which was the scene of the sad occurrence,

To the Editor of the Albany Evening Journal: In Your journal of yesterday Mr. TREMAIN is reported as having said: "Mr. TREMAIN was not satisfied with the explanations. He wanted more proof that ACTON and BERGEN were true to their party fealty. But he wished that while Mr. LITTLEJOHN was defending them, he had also defended THURLOW WEED from suspicion of contributing to that defeat.

The steamship Europa arrived yesterday at Halifax, with three days' later intelligence. The Mexican question was still under discussion in France. It was reported that a bearer of dispatches had been sent to this country, demanding a categorical answer to the question whether the continued occupation of Mexico by the French Would be treated as a casus belli.

The Royal mail steamship Europa, which left Liverpool at 11 A. M. on the 3d, and Queenstown on the 4th inst., has arrived at this port, with three passengers for Halifax and 25 passengers for Boston. The Europa had heavy weather the first part of the voyage; the last part weather was fair. She sails at midnight for Boston.

About 10:45 o'clock last night a fire was discovered by Officer FLEMING, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, on the third door of premises No. 186 West Houston-street, occupied by JOHN WEIR as a block manufactory. Owing to the inflammable character of the contents, the flames spread rapidly through the entire floor of the building, Nos. 180, 182, 184 and 186.

BREVET MAJOR-GENERALS, VOLUNTEERS. To the Senate of the United States: I nominate the officers named in the accompanying communication for appointment by brevet in the volunteer force, as proposed by the Secretary of War. WASHINGTON, Jan. 13, 1866. ANDREW JOHNSON.

Mr. MARETZEK'S operatic matinee was, as usual, well attended on Saturday afternoon. "Ernani" was fairly sung by all the artists--Mme. ZUCCHI being in very good voice. The role of Don Carlos was Interpreted by Signor BRANDINI, a recent addition to the troupe. Signor BRANDINI has a high baritone voice of fair quality which he uses discreetly.

Next Thursday being the one hundred and thirty-fourth anniversary of the birth of WASHINGTON, and the occasion being one on which our citizen soldiery are wont to parade, the inquiry naturally suggests itself as to what preparations are being made on the part of the National Guard for the proper observance of the day.

Yesterday morning, at the Church or the Holy Trinity, Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street, Rev. Deacon VAN WAGNER and Rev. WILLIAM DIMOND were ordained to the priesthood of the Protestant Episcopal Church. The house was well filled by the congregation which worships at the Holy Trinity, and within the chancel were several distinguished clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal faith;

A large and enthusiastic Fenian meeting was held ?? night and addressed by GEORGE FRANCIS TRAIN, Maj. TOOLEY, B. DORAN KILLIAN and Hon. Messrs. ?? of New-Jersey. and HOGAN, of Missouri. Letters were read from MICHAEL BOYLE and Capt. CAFFERTY, dated at the jail, in which they were confined on charges against Her Majesty's Government, from which it appears that United States Consul EASTMAN and Minister ADAMS declined to interfere in their behalf.

ANOTHER DANCE-HOUSE Row.--Shortly before 1 o'clock yesterday morning, a disturbance took place in the dance-house situated on the corner of Washington and Rector streets, among a number of the regular habitues of the place. During the fight, which was the ultimate result of the difficulty, one of the combatants, named PATRICK DUGAN, residing at No. 19 Morrie street, was shot with a pistol.

ANDERSON.-On Monday, Feb. 19 MARY J., relief of Joshua Anderson, in the 74th year of her age. Funeral from the residence of her son, Cornelius V. Anderson, at Rye, Westchester County, on Wednesday next at 10 1/2 A M. Her remains will reach Greenwood Cemetery for interment near 3 P. M.

A New LIGHT IN SOUTH CAROLIA.-In a message transmitted to the South Carolina Legislature recently, Gov. ORR used this language: "So long as the African was a slave, though his moral training was not neglected, it was our policy to prohibit him from learning to read and write.

STABP, a native of England, aged 21 years. The City Inspector's Report shows that 417 deaths occurred in this City during the past week103 men. 85 women, 119 boys and 110 girls-being an increase of 23 as compared with the previous week, and decreease of 80 as compared with the corresponding period of 1865.

At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen ?? evening, Ald. BLISS,. the President, in the chair, tLe Committee on Lamps, and Gas presented a repart recommending that the Street Commissioner be authorized to advertise for proposals for lighting the street lamps with gas or other material from dark till daylight the year round, and that the estimates state the price for one year and also for ten years.
Present--John Brice, Esq., President, in the chair: Aldermen Moore, Coman, Norton, Flynn, Shannon. Gedney, Fly, Reilly, Loew, Masterson, Varnum. Jr., O'Brien McGinnis, Van Voorhis.

In a recent letter to the TIMES I gave on authority that I deemed entirely reliable, an account of an alleged interview between GOV. FENTON and a Senator, wherein the former attempted to influence the latter's vote on the disagreement of the two Houses over the Health Bill.

The Legislature ought to enact as follows: Every ferry company shall have at the extreme outer end of their bridges a portcullis, divided into two equal parts, and each rising by weights, and shutting off all communication with their boats.

The Journal of Commerce has published a letter from Secrotary AMOY, dated Santa F6, Feb. 3, which says the Legislature of New-Mexico has just adjourned. A large number of laws were passed during the session.

A NEW PAPER AT ALBANY.-The Tiunesays: "There is, we hear, a movement on foot to establish a new Republican paper at Albany. Ample capital. it is said, is ready to be embarked in such an enterprise, and it is thought it can be made highly remunerative and specially satisfactory to the Republican Party of this State."

The country will not be taken by surprise in reading the announcement of the President's veto of the Freedmen's Bureau Bill. That veto implies no essential difference of opinion between the Executive and the majority in Congress on the primary object of the bill.

The steamship Moravian, from Liverpool Feb. 8, via Londonderry 9th inst., has arrived. The steamship City of New-York, from New-York, arrived at Queenstwon on the 7th. The steamship Hansa, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the 8th. The steamship St. David, from Fortland, arrived at Londonderry on the 7th.

"Hon. BENJ. F. MANIEHRE, of our City, has been nominated for Police Commissioner by the Union members of the Legislature. We presume there is no doubt of his election. He will prove a faithful and efficient officer."-Tribune. In 1863, when the Executive Department was Democratic and the Legislature Republican,

The growth of this City within the present century is one of the marvels of our country. The little town in which many of our older residents were born, has before their death taken rank among the great capitals of the world, with but a few ahead of it.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -The " African" was given last night to a brilliant audience. To-night RICCI'S delicious opera of "Crispino la Comare." The preparations for the grand Ball d'Opera are progressing rapidly, and we notice that the subscribers' tickets will be ready for delivery on Wednesday next. We saw six imps of darkness, commonly called printers' devils, carrying a proof to the Academy on Saturday.

The report of Fire-Marshal BAKER for the six months ending Nov. 30th, 1866, was presented to the Common Council yesterday. From this document it appears that the total number of fires for the half-year was 171, or twelve less than occurred during the same period of 1864. The aggregate losses for the half-year were unprecedently heavy.

THE PRESS.--We have frequently warned those Southern newspapers which have of late been attempting to stir up bitter feeling between the North and South, that their course was doing infinite danger to Southern interests. It has now proved a damaging one for themselves as well as for their section. Gen.

Is the Senate yesterday Mr. NYE presented a bill providing for extending the area of Nevada. Mr. BANKS introduced a bill proposing to increase the capital of certain National Banks. Mr. WILSON introduced a joint resolution to disband the military forces of the States lately in rebellion.

To the Senate of the United States: I have examined with care the bill, which originated in the Senate and has been passed by the two Houses of Congress, to amend an act entitled " An Act to establish a Bureau for the Relief of Freedmen and Refugees, and for other purposes."

The Tribule misrepresents Hon. Mr. LITTLEJOHN for the purpose of justifying, or attempting to justify, its own inconsistencies. Mr. LITTLEJOHN only objected to partisan Commissions. Non -partisan Commissions Lave reformed many and gross municipal abuses.

Files of the Pajara Verde, a newspaper published in the City of Mexico, have been received here, with news to Jan. 30. The adhesion of Papantla to the Empire is announced. The place is held by Gen. THUN with an Austrian garrison.

A MAN CRUSHED TO DEATH.--Coroner AVERY, of Hoboken, held an inquest, yesterday afternoon, on tho body of a young man named JAMES BROWN, whose death was caused the night previous by being crushed between the ferry-boat Pauerson and the Hoboken ferry bridge.

We receive, in one way and another, two or three hundred communications in each week. Of these we print perhaps a dozen. Necessarily, a great many well-meaning friends are disappointed in not finding their contributions in our columns.

BURGLARS SURPRISED WHILE AT WORK.--About 4 o'clock yesterday morning, Mr. RICHARDSON, residing on the corner of Fifty-ninth-street and Tenth-avenue, was awakened by seeing the gas lighted in a room adjoining his sleeping chamber.

The mystery attending the deaths of the three young children who were found dead in a shanty last Saturday evening by their father on his return from work, and who are supposed to have been murdered by their mother, ANASTINA SHOTZ, who was at the time of the discovery laboring under the effects of some unknown poison, still continues a profound and perplexing enigma.

GAS COMPANIES TAKE NOTICE.-A bill is now before the State Legislature, the passage of which would cause that body to be held in grateful remembrance to the last generation of suffering New-Yorkers. Substantially it puts the great gas monopolies on the same footing as the Insurance Companies.

CREDENTIALS. Mr. WADE presented the credentials of Mr. SHERMAN, Senator elect from Ohio. MEMORIALS AND PETITIONS. Mr. SUMNER presented a memorial from the officers of a Convention of colored men of Florida, praying for a remedy for the refusal of landholders to lease lands to them, and for a grant of homesteads and civil rights, including the right of suffrage.

The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Association of Sunday-School Teachers was held in the Madison-avenue Baptist Church, last evening, RALPH WELLS, Esq., in the chair. The meeting was set apart for prayer in behalf of fellow-teachers, coworkers, and scholars in the Sabbath-schools connected with the various churches;

A meeting was hold last evening, at the lecture-room of Clinton Hall, by the friends of the Orphan Patriot Home. At 8:30 o'clock about two hundred persons had assembled, and as no speaker had arrived except Rev. Mr. BOOLE, the Tremaine Brothers gave several of their peculiar and patriotic songs, after which Rev. Mr. BOOLE was introduced,

Virginia City papers contain a report that two hundred men on their way to the mines in Montana perished in a snow-storm. Communication with that Territory is cut off, and it is feared that great suffering has been experienced there. Gen. STEEL left here yesterday to take command of the Department of Columbia.

BEARDSLEY.--At his residence in Brooklyn, on Monday morning, Feb. 19, Dr. H. G. BEARDSLEY, formerly of Hamilton, N. Y., aged 60 years. Funeral services Wednesday at 2 o'clock, at the Church of the Messiah, Green-av., corner of Clermont-av. BROWEB,--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday morning, Feb. 20 after a brief illness, EUPHEMIA D. MATHESON, wife of Rem. Lefferts Brower, in the 34th year of her age.

One hundred guns were fired here to-night in honor of the President's veto of the Freedmen's Bureau Bill. TRENTON, Tuesday, Feb. 20. In the House to-day, Mr. PRICE, of Essex, (Dem.,) offered a series of resolutions approving of the President's veto of the Freedmen's Bureau Bill, and of the principles set forth in his veto message.

REPORT OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE.--From the report of Hon, ISAAC NEWTON, Commissioner of the Bureau of Agriculture, for January, we learn that the decrease of importations of foreign wool for 1865 was 22,541,674 lbs., which the Commissioner notes as a gratifying fact, because it shows the progress that is made in supplying the domestic wants of the country in a commodity so essential to its wants and comfort.

So long as he refused admission to Tennessee, in common with other States, on the ground that its rights had been forfeited by rebellion, there was an appearance of principle in the refusal. We might not accept it, but at least we were inclined to respect it.

The expectation was for the time disappointed, and after the suspense of about a minute, Peers and Peeresses, Judges and Bishops.

The following call for a meeting of Citizens, who are in favor of the President's policy and views, is inviting signatures. It will, we hope, be extensively circulated: PUBLIC MEETING OF THE CITIZENS.--The citizens of New-York, who sustained the national authority in the war against the rebellion,

The final victory of the Health Bill is an event not to be passed over without public notice. For ten years, philanthropic individuals, medical authorities and interested place-hunters have come each Winter before the Legislature, and urged a reform of our notoriously inefficient and corrupt sanitary administration.

We understand that the Ninety-ninth Regiment New-York National Guard, Col. JOHN O'MAHONEY commanding, have made application to the Inspector-General's Department for the necessary certificate to enable them to make requisition on the Quartermaster's Department for new uniforms.

A bill has been reported in the Assembly prohibiting railroad officers from granting free passes on their roads to any person except certain employes of the Company. We trust there may be sufficient independence and good sense in the Legislature to secure the enactment of this bill into a law. The issue of passes has grown into a monstrous abuse, alike oppressive to shareholders and corrupting to the recipients of railroad bounty.

FIRE IN CEDAR-STREET.--At 3:30 P. M. yesterday a fire broke out in the fourth floor of premises No. 13 Cedar-street, among some loose cotton, the fourth floor and attic story being consumed by the ??. The third and fourth were occupied by MICHAEL KERWAN, repacker of cotton. Loss $10,000, Insured for $18,000, in the New-England, Indemnity and Morris Insurance Companies. .

The following papers were omitted from our report of the proceedings of the Board of Aldermen of Monday: RESOLUTIONS. By Alderman Flynn-- Resolved, That the Committee on Streets be directed to inquire into the expediency of continuing Sixth-avenue in the southerly direction, to connect with West Broadway at the junction of that street with Walker-street,

PETITIONS AND MEMORIALS. Mr. HENDERSON presented the petition of citizens of Missouri on the subject of reconstruction, asking Congress to annul the acts of the President in establishing civil Governments in the South, and to secure equal rights to all without distinction on account of color. Referred to the Special Committee of Fifteen.

THE GRAND QUESTION IN THE SENATE. The intense excitement produced yesterday by the President's veto was only partially lulled by the lapse of the hours of rest. All over the city, up to hours that bordered upon the dawn, knots and companies of gentlemen were excitedly discussing the matter. Since the famous war of Gen. JACKSON upon the Bank nothing like the present excitement over a veto has been known.

ANN BARRY, charged with the murder of her child, five weeks old, in July last, by drowning it in the canal, is on trial in the Court of Oyer and Termiser at Rochester. Attorney-General MARTINDALE conducts the prosecution. A replevin suit, involving $20,000, between ISAAC BUTTS and the Bank of Montreal, has been on trial at Rochester since last Friday, before the Supreme Court.

GAS MONOPOLIES.--The gas companies, not content with the monopoly of supply, are availing themselves of every opportunity for extortion. In London a similar grievance obtains, but there, we learn, a movement is on foot which will doubtless result in the formation of a protective company, with Commissioners chosen from the people.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--The performance last evening of "Crispice la Comare" was in every way delightful. We have never listened to a more even, perfect and delicious representation of this truly enjoyable work. Signor BELLINI, on whom much depends, was in admirable mood, and Miss KELLOGG was, as she always is, thoroughtly exquisite.

STREET AND SIDEWALK INCUMBRANCES.--The Common Council, after tedious deliberation, have adopted an ordinance vesting the power of granting permits for the exhibition of showcases, delivery of goods, erection of sidewalk stands, hoistways, , in the Mayor. The Common Council have hitherto exercised this power exclusively.

THE HEALTH BILL.--The action of Mr. BERRYMAN, of the Assembly, upon the Health Bill, has been misrepresented. He was consistent and firm in his support of the Senate bill. When the resolution to strike out the Police Commissioners was made in caucus an amendment adhering to the Senate bill was offered, for which Mr. BERRYMAN voted, but which was rejected.

The Senate yesterday refused to pass the Freedmen's Bureau Bill, by the necessary constitutional vote, over the President's veto. Several of the Senators who supported the bill on its original passage through that body, changed their position after the reading of the Veto Message, and voted to support the President.

The Texas State Convention is still engaged in making out business, but is doing very little. Mr. JONES, of Baxter Countw, offered a proposition to divide Texas into three States for the purpose of effecting a balance of power in the Union.

At a caucus of the Legislature this evening, the following resolution, offered by Hon. LEWIS BAKER, of the Senate, was adopted: Resolved, That this Legislature cordially approve and indorsen the action o Senators of this State in voting to pass the Freedmen's Bureau Bill, notwithstanding the President's veto, as being in accordance with the sentiments of their constituents, and the principles upon the support of which alone this Government can be sustained.

The Canadian delegates recently at Washington are assailed on their return home with a bitterness which is almost incomprehensible to those who judge of Provincial polities from a distant point. Their proposition to the Committee of Ways and Means is denounced as a surrender of Provincial interests;

Gen. GRANT, his family, and his staff are in the City. They came by rail from Washington, reached the depot at 6 o'clock in the morning, and went direct to the Metropolitan Hotel, where, without fuss or parade, they were cordially welcomed. Quite likely some people would be glad to know how the General spent his hour before breakfast.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S opera of " II Poliuto " was given here last evening with much effect, the artists being all in excellent voice. The orchestra and chorus were also good. " Don Pasquale," which was to have been played, has been temporarily withdrawn. On Friday " Don Sebastian" will be given for the last time, and on Saturday, at 11 o'clock, there will be a matinee performance of "Ione,"

About thirty Government horses were sold here to-day at an average price of $167 apiece, and a lot of mules at an average of $143. The steamer Fanny, from Baltimore for Savannah, put in yesterday, the weather outside being stormy. She sailed again last night.

GASTRONOMIC HORRORS.--There have been numerous and vivid descriptions of a malady under which pork-eaters in some parts of Germany have succumbed. The ghosts of trichinse have in consequence haunted the imagination of many who had before revelled, after the enthusiastic fashion of CHARLES LAMB, in the succulent delights of roast pig and other swinish diet.

The news received from Mexico becomes scarcer and scarcer by each arrival, and as there is nothing to prove that a diminution of events has taken place in that unfortunate country, one is led to surmise that the aspect of things is not in the most favorable condition for MAXIMILIAN and the Imperial Government.

AMENDMENTS.--We notice that several Senators and Representatives have grossly neglected the first duty of a member of the Thirty-ninth Congress. At least fifteen or twenty of them have as yet failed to introduce an amendment to the Constitution W?? will their constituents say to Representatives of such small inventive faculty as to be confessedly unable to tinker the organic law?

We publish a call for a meeting to sustain the President. Only brief time was given to obtain signatures, and it received thousands. Few, indeed, even hesitated, and scarcely any one refused. The unanimity of sentiment in favor of the President is equally a surprise and a gratification, nor does it come too soon.

BELLOWS, arrived yesterday. 18th inst., lat. 27.28, long. 80.14, passed a bark bound north, showing a signal, white square on blue ground. 20th, lat. 36.27, long. 74.32, passed a brig showing signal white with red diagonal stripe, with letters O. T. in it.

At a meeting of the Academy of Medicine last evening, Dr. JAMES ANDERSON presiding, papers were read by Dr. DAVID NUTTING and Dr. GRISCOM on the cholera. Dr. NUTTING detailed the symptoms of cholera, already sufficiently well known, and said that all human efforts to prevent its appearance appeared to be unavailing. At the same time, however,

TAXATION.--Delegations representing nearly all the industrial and mercantile interests of the country are now continually making their appearance in Washington, and attempting to induce Congress to make reductions of the taxation upon this, that and the other business.

If it were possible at the present time to find an intelligent observer, unbiased in either way by contending partisans, he would be constrained to bear testimony to the forbearance, the moderation, the consistent devotion to the Constitution and the Union, by which ANDREW JOHNSON has been distinguished from the first moment of his elevation to power.

BROADWAY.--The irreparable damage which the rent-raisers proposed to inflict upon Broadway and the business of the City is already beginning to be felt. We hear of many superb houses, which now enhance its splendor and give it variety and importance, making definite arrangements to move out of it.

The one hundred and thirty-fourth anniversary of the birth of WASHINGTON will be duly celebrated on the 22d inst. Business will be generally suspended, the day having been designated by the Legislature as a legal holiday.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON offered a resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee. setting forth the duty of expressing through Congress the national gratitude to the officers, soldiers and sailors of our army and navy. A petition in favor of extending the right of suffrage to women was presented by Mr. HENDERSON.

VEHICLES IN THE CITY.--The Common Council have passed an ordinance requiring railroad and car companies to have conspicuous lights placed in front of their vehicles, so that persons shall be warned of their approach. The ordinance is ??rmed one for the better protection of life and property.

Study and reflection strengthens, in the public mind, the force of the President's objections to the Freedmen's Bureau Bill. The first feeling, which was one of regret that the President was constrained to withhold his approval, is succeeded by a sense of obligation that he has saved the country from evils that its passage would have entailed upon us.

THANKS TO OUR SOLDIERS AND SAILORS. Mr. WILSON introduced the following joint resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee: Resolved, That it is the duty and privilege of Congress to express the gratitude of the nation to the officers, soldiers and seamen of the United States, by whose valor and endurance on the land and on the sea,...

The bill amending the Usury Laws was again rejected in the House to-day. The Senate passed the Valley Railroad Bill, with a proviso that the road shall not connect with the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad until the Covington Railroad is completed.

WASHINGTON'S DAY.--The lapse of time, however long-the march of events, however great--dims not the glory of the name of WASHINGTON. Some have fancied that as generations passed away his memory would fade;

The working men in different manufacturing establishments throughout the country, are circulating, for subscription by mechanics, the following petition for such an alteration of the tariff as will protect their labor against the efforts of British capitalists and manufacturers to drive them out of the American market:

From all sides we hear confirmed what I stated to you in my last letter, to the effect that an understanding had boon come to on the Mexican question. The understanding here appears to be based on a promise of non-intervention on the part of the United States; that is to say, France is to withdraw her troops this year, and the United States are to observe a neutrality between MAXIMILIAN and the Mexican people.

PITTSBURGH, Penn., Wednesday, Feb. 21. At the afternoon session of the Fenian Congress today, the report of Gen. SWEENEY, the Secretary of War, was made the special order for 10 o'clock, to-morrow morning. All the delegates present pledged themselves to sustain the Constitution adopted at Philadelphia.

The House of Commons, to-day, passed to a second reading the bill relating to Indians and negroes, with amendments. The eleventh section of the bill, providing that negroes shall testify in all cases where they are concerned in person or property, was amended as follows:

WASHINGTON'S Birthday will be celebrated in this city with more than usual spirit. Business will be suspended, and a number of military organizations will parade during the day, including the Old National Guard. The MIilitary Order of the Loyal League of the United States will hold a meeting at noon at the Academy of Music.

Great interest is felt here in the meeting called tomorrow night in New-York to sustain the President. Secretary SEWARD left here in the 4 o'clock train for Philadelphia, where he will stay to-night and go to New-York in the morning.

OLD ENGLAND.--In our latest London newspapers we read of some curious incidents which show the strange hold that old customs and laws havee upon the English mind. One of these is the custom of searching in the Houses of Parliament for a Guy Faux, Which always takes place previous to the opening of Parliament by the Queen in person, and which was repeated about two or three weeks ago.

CONANT.--ON Tuesday evening. Feb. 20, Mrs. MARY W. CONANT, wife of the late Dr. D. S. Conant, of New-York. Notice of funeral hereafter. DRAYTON.--In Jersey City, N. J., on Tuesday, Feb. 20, JOHN DRAYTON, a native of Barrington, Somesetshire, England, in the 79th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from Grace Church, Jersey City, on Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

The Senate to-day passed the Patterson and Neward Railroad Bill. This bill has now passed both Houses. Mr. TRUESDALE (Dem.) presented a concurrent resolution, that we have full faith in the ability, patriotism and fidelity of ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United States, and that we have confidence in him as the Executive of the National Government.

Files of Valparaiso and Santiago papers have been received here up to the 16th of January. The news of the rumored mediation of France and England in the Spanish-Chilian war has not been regarded with much favor in Chili, or doomed of great importance. It is not expected that Spain will voluntarily relinquish her pretensions.

Parliament met to-day. Lieut.--Gov. WILLIAMS made a speech, which congratulates the members upon the condition of the Province. The revival of this fine opera has given much satisfaction to the public and the subscribers. It is withdrawn only because other novelties are in readiness, and the shortness of the Spring season does not admit of many repetitions.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Gordian knot, to untie which had baffied the wisest, has been cut by the sword. Slavery is no more. From three to four millions of dependent beings-dependent on a master's care and provision-have suddenly been thrown upon their own resources. They are free, and must accept the boon, with its advantages on the one hand and its drawbacks on; the other.

GRANT.

DRAYTON-In Jersey City N. J., on Tuesday, Feb. 20, JOHN DRAYTON, a native of Barrington, Somersetshire, England, in the 79th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from Grace Church, Jersey City, on Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

The case of ROBERT M. MARTIN, who has been held some time by the military and civil authorities of the United States, on a charge of being implicated in the plot of the rebels to burn this City, has been brought to a close by the discharge of the prisoner, on a habeas corpus issued by Judge SHIPMAN, sitting in the United States Circuit Court in this District.
The Cunard mail steamer Cuba, Capt. STONE, which left Liverpool at 2:30 on the afternoon of the 10th and Queenstown on the 11th of February, arrived here yesterday morning.

The Daily Advertiser of to-morrow will contain the following: One of the neatest and most successful detective operations we have heard of in some time, culminated in our city to-day in the arrest of the perpetrators of the systematic robberies of the Erie Railroad Company. Much of the freight over the road known as timc freight has been stolen for some two years past.

MR. SEWARD ON THE SITUATION. The following dispatch has been received in Washington from Secretary SEWARD: "NEW YORK, Fe. 23, 1866. It is all right and safe. The Union is restored and the country safe. The President's speech is triumphant, and the country will be happy. *** (Signed) W. H. SEWARD." THE UNION CAUCUS.

The French Lighthouse Board has taken an important step in giving a fair trial to the system of lighting by electricity, and has been rewarded by an encouraging success. At the southern lighthouse of Cape La Heve, the machine invented by FRESNEL has been under trial since December, 1863, but has been superseded by the electric light of the Alliance Company of Paris.

As a friend to tobacco, RALEIGH would have been better pleased than King JAMES to foresee the result of a case lately tried in the English Court of the Exchequer, where a dealer suing a minor for a couple of hundred dollars' worth of pipes and cavendish, pursuaded a jury to satisfy his hopes of recovering half the claim.

The steamer Colorado, from New-York, with dates to the 1st, has arrived. Mazatlan dates to the 15th are received. That port was opened by an Imperial decree. Advices indicate that MAXIMlLIAN'S prospects are still depreciating. The Consul of the Mexican Republic has received advices from JUAREZ at El Paso, to the 20th of January, representing affairs as very promising.

HENERY WARD BEECHER.--Mr. BEECHER is suffering severely for his recent course, as well as the President. We do not know that it is exactly correct to say that he is suffering; for a man who is attacked is not always a sufferer. But he is assailed with a bitterness and fury only less vindictive than that directed upon the President.

The bridge across the Hudson at Albany is now near enough completed to allow the passage of trains over it. It is a structure which for size is equaled by few in this country. For several years past the various railroad companies now interested in this bridge saw the necessity of constructing it, but lacked the nerve to undertake the job.

The day was celebrated here by a procession of the Second United States Infantry, the Turners' Society, and Soldiers' and Sailors' Union League. A large and enthusiastic meeting was held to-night, in honor of President JOHNSON's veto of the Freedmen's Bureau Bill.

The highest court in the State of Mississippi has declared the Stay Law passed by the Legislature of that State to be unconstitutional. The same result is inevitable whenever the question shall be brought to a final test in the States which have by similar enactments sought to impair the obligations of contracts and enable their citizens to repudiate their just debts.

The birthday of WASHINGTON was fittingly chosen for popular demonstrations in favor of the Union. That in this City was triumphant. That at Washington, equally enthusiastic, was even more significant, for there the President himself uttered "thoughts that breathe and words that burn."

The Complete Art of Letter-Writing is the title of a popular book which one can buy at any book-stall for fifty cents. The art of letter-writing is therefore cheap and accessible. But the gift of letter-writing comes from nature, and cannot be purchased. The letter is a universal form of composition; but how few letter-writers make what the dramatic critics call "a hit."

The Democrats and Conservatives held a meeting at Mercantile Library Hall, last night, at which resolutions were adopted to the following effect: That the Democracy of St. Louis are determined to restore to the citizens of Missouri all their constitutional rights; that the Federal Constitution defines the qualifications of Members of Congress,and all men possessing such qualifications are eligible to seats in either House of Congress;

THE SOUTHERN EMIGRATION.--It seems that the amusing and affecting appeal of certain residents of Alabama to be permitted to emigrate to "foreign shores," and to procure the rescinding of Gen. SHERIDAN'S order prohibiting emigration, has had its effect. For we find in the papers of Mobile an advertisement announcing the sailing from that port, on the 1st proximo, of a steamer with emigrants to Para, Brazil.

THE GREAT QUESTION.--Mr. STEPHENS of Georgia treats briefly of the negro question in his speech before the Legislature. He is quite philosophical upon it, accepting, as is proper, the actual condition of things, and urging the people and their representatives to make the best of it.

Since the last mail, a fortnight ago, no battles have occurred, but events have progressed toward issues near and certain. The report I gave you of the reinvasion of Corrientes by LOPEZ'S troops has been contradicted, but the possession of seventeen prison ors taken in their expulsion is good evidence of the fact.

The luxury of having speeches, delivered in the heart of Georgia, reported by telegraph, verbatim, for the NEW-YORK TIMES, is not one that may be every day indulged in. But the elaborate, temperate and judicious discourse of Mr. A. H. STEPHENS before the Legislature of Georgia, which we publish in full in other columns to-day, seems to us to justify the prominence we give it.

The colored population of this city celebrated the anniversary of the emancipation Proclamation to-day, by a large procession, consisting of-two regiments of colored soldiers and two thousand colored people. Telegrams of this character were freely circulated in the meeting at Cooper Institute and at Gen. GRANTS reception at the Loyal League Club, on Union-square.

The Legislature of Georgia, some weeks ago, elected ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, late Vice President of the Southern Confederacy, to represent them in the United States Senate. Mr. STEPHENS peremptorily declined, believing his prominent connection with the Davis Rebellion to be an insuperable objection to his presence at Washington as a Senator.

The demonstration on Thursday in support of the President's policy, was, perhaps, the most notable political assemblage since the opening of the sectional conflict five years ago. There was a remarkable fitness in the coincidence of WASHINGION'S birthday having been designated for such a demonstration.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The matinee to-day commences at 11 o'clock, instead of 1. This arrangement will enable country visitors to attend not only to their business, but their pleasure. The opera is "Ione," in which there is much to see and to hear. The work will be given entire, and with the full strength of its superb caste. WINTER GARDEN.--There will be a matinee here to-day for a charitable purpose.

JOHN S. PEARSON, who on the night of the 24th of September last killed WALTER GREGORY, an aged farmer at Van Burenville, town of Wallkill, Orange County, expiated his crime on the gallows, at Goshen, yesterday. The solemn scene took place in the Courthouse, almost in the some spot where he sat during his trial.

We had the important intelligence yesterday that President JOHNSON, in reply to inquiries of Gen. HOWARD, said on Wednesday last that his interpretation of the original act of Congress passed at last session, establishing the Freedmen's Bureau, authorized the continuance of the Bureau for one year from the date of a proclamation of peace-which proclamation he proposed to issue.

SINGULAR CASUALTY.--We learn from the Bridgeport Farmer that a serious accident happened to JOHN D. HURLBURT, Esq., of Ridgefield, a tow days since. He was in Danbury, and accepted an invitation to look at BAILEY'S wild animals, which are wintering in that town.

It is reported that Earl RUSSELL will not introduce his reform bill until after Easter. What sort of a bill he will bring in then I doubt if he knows. The House, and both Houses, must be canvassed, to see how strong or how weak a measure they will bear, or whether they will agree upon any.

The new circumstances under which the British Parliament has just opened, have invested the proceedings of that body with unusual interest. The anxiety widely felt and generally expressed that Her Majesty should attend in person was set at rest by her appearance.

The Senate does not yet see its way clear to the adoption of the Constitutional Amendment as it passed the House, or of any other form of words by which the object in view shall be attained. No one can deny but that some change in the Constitution is needed, to remedy the inequality in representation which the abolition of slavery has brought upon the country.

That there should be a well-founded desire on the part of consumers to see lower prices is natural, and that producers should be quite willing to see them higher is not surprising. But sudden and violent changes are to be deprecated-neither party is really benefited, but in the end both are injured.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We are under great obligations to the Press for t e help afforded us in creating a demand for the labor of the destitute unemployed men who have been supported by the House of Industry since the commencement of the year. Hardly a day passes without applications for them.

The extraordinary speech of President JOHNSON, on Thursday, has been attributed to a weakness to which it is universally understood he is occasionally addicted. Dispatches from Washington affirm that the speech was made under no such influence.

Yesterday the General, accompanied by Gen. BUTTERFIELD, J. H. BAILEY and JACKSON S. SCBULTZ, visited the "swamp," and was received by a large gathering of the leather merchants. The reception took place in the store of M. ARMSTRONG SONS. Speeches of welcome were made by Mr. BAILEY, Gen. BUTTERFIELD and others, to which Gen. GRANT replied with his usual brevity.

Capt. CLIFFORD, formerly of those 48th Kentucky, Volunteers, but better known as the "Bloody 48th," has for several months past been the teacher of a very large school two miles south of this place. Everything was progressing finely until last Friday, between the hours of 3 and 4 o'clock P. M., when the professor noticed a disturbance, and, on investigating it, found it necessary to inflict a punishment on some one of his pupils;

Mojor-Gen. T. J. WOOD some time since directed Col. SAMUEL THOMAS, Assistant Commissioner of the Freedmen's Bureau for Mississippi, to make a tour of inspection through the State, for the purpose of ascortaining the condition and prospects of the freedmen and feelings of the people generally. Col. THOMAS visited Jackson, Meridian, Macon, Lauderdale, Columbus, Aberdeen, Okolona, Holly Springs, Corinth, Grenada, and Canton, visiting and conversing with magistrates and leading citizens at each place.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT-SOUTHERN DISTRICT. Before Judge Shipman. Judzeri C. Fiero, convicted of having in his possession a quantity of counterfeit stamps, with intent to pass the same, was sentenced to be imprisoned at hard labor, in the Albany Penitentiary for a year and six months, and to pay a fine of six cents. Fiero was formerly a keeper in the institution to which he is now consigned as a convict.
The steamer Hillman collided with the steamer annie Byers at 2:30 o'clock this morning, near Madison, Ind., sinking the latter vessel almost instantly. Thirty lives are reported lost.
The Senate is not in session to-day. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. MR. CLARK ON RECONSTRUCTION. The House went into Committee of the Whole. Mr. CLARK submitted his views on the subject of reconstruction.

SIGISMUND WAITZ, a former member of Company E. Second Regiment New-Jersey Volunteers, applied on Thursday evening at the Grant House, No. 48 New Bowery, for a lodging, when his request was complied with. On Friday morning WAITZ was found lying insensible in the bed, and an empty, vial, labeled "Landanum," standing on the table, indicated that the unfortunate man had attempted suicide.

ALLEGED RUM POISONING CASE.--Coroner KIRSTEN, of Jersey City; yesterday received intelligence of the death of a young man, which occurred about a week since, under circumstances which seem to demand legal investigation, and which he has decided to institute.

TROUBLES IN WAYNE COUNTY, TENN.-We have recently received information to the effect that one evening last week a party of unknown armed men entered Clifton, in Wayne County, and rode up to the house of a Mr. HUGHES, late an officer in the rebel army, and sent a messenger in and demanded that dither he should appear at the door or send out his coat which he had worn in the rebel service.

A CARD BY MR. POLLARD. The Richmond Examiner of Friday contains the following card: To the readers of the Examiner: I arrived in Richmond only last evening. After the allusion made in yesterday's Examiner to the suppression of the paper, I had hoped that it would not have been necessary for me to refer again to the subject.

The Royal Commission appointed to inquire into the cause, nature and suppression of the recent rebellion in the eastern district of this island, are prosecuting their important work with great energy and ability. They sit daily from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M., and get through a large quantity of evidence, as Messrs, GURNEY and MAUL are experienced in the examination of witnesses.

Last evening Mr. WM. ANDERSON delivered a lecture on "The Choice of Matrimonial Companions," in the Seventh--street M. E. Church. The audience was large and appreciative. The lecturer began by alluding to the tie which bound the States of the Union, and glided into the discussion of an institution older human government--the institution of marriage.

When the Secretary of War announced, in his Annual Report, that he should be able to bring our army down from 1,000,000 to 50,000--at which latter point it would permanently gravitate-some anxiety was manifested to know the reason on which so hopeful a reduction of expenses rested.

Mr. PLANTS considered the subject of constitutional amendments.
