The Methodist Church North offers to take the negro churches of Texas under its protection.

The Tribune plunges, with its accustomed zest, into the new crusade against President JOHNSON. It. brings to the task with cheerful alacrity all its resources, of invention, recklessness and insinuation, and is evidently determined to win fresh laurels in this new field. Here is one of its earliest and choicest efforts:

The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the residence of Isaac Bates, No, 582 Pacific-st, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, 27th, at 2 P.M. BENSON.-On Snnday, Feb. 25, EGUERT BENSON, in the 77th year of his age. Nntice of funeral hereafter.

The Academy of Medicine commenced what it intended to be an exhaustive discussion of the subject of Cholera. At the last meeting, Dr. METCALE and Dr. GRISCOM each read extended papers. To the careful listener one underlying thought controlled both arguments.

The stories put in circulation by various radical prints, here and elsewhere, as to the transmission of the President's speech, are shown, in our special Washington dispatch, to be utterly mendacious. The report that tho speech was ordered to be suppressed by the Government censor was the invention of a singularly courageous fabricator.

Two RUFFIANS COMMIT A DARING ROBBERY.--About 10 o'clock on Saturday night, two men named CORNELIUS MADDEN and HENRY FARMER, members of Hose Company No. 10, visited the grocery store of CLAUS J. PEPER, corner of Sixth-street and Fillmoreplace, Eastern District, and remained, against the wishes of the proprietor, until 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

Last evening, the Rev. E. R. CRAVEN, D. D., preached a sermon on "Christian Union," at the Protestant Episcopal Church, (Rev. JOHN COTTON SMITH), corner of Tenth-street and Fifth-avenue, After the sermon a collection was taken up for the

A RELIC OF THE REVOLUTION.--There is on exhibition at a jewelry store in Baltimore a relic of the revolutionary war of exquisite manufacture, as well as of great value. It is a gold snuff-box, presented by Louis XYI., King of France, to Col. JOHN LAURENS, of South Carolina, Aid-de-Camp to Gen. WASHINGTON, on the .occasion of that Officer's visit to France by order of the American Congress, to negotiate a loan for his Government.

FIRE IN CHERRY-STREET.--Last evening, at about 101/2 o'clock, Officer OATES, of the Fourth Precinct, discovered a fire bursting out through the window of the second floor of the two-story frame building No. 59 Cherry-street, formerly enjoying the ages name of "The Dirty Spoon," but latterly occupied by TIERNAN Co., dealer in cottons, who had a stock of baled and loose cottons on hand.

THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH. The failure of certain journals to receive the Presideat's speech in time for publication, has given rise to the charge that the speech was at first suppressed by the Government Censor. I am personally cogninant of the acts which transpired on that occasion, and can, therefore, state them correctly. Let the public first understand that there is no longer such a person as the "Government Censor."

From the Harrisburgh Telegraph. A terrible accident occurred on Wednesday evening, near Larimer's Station, on the Penneylvani Railroad, about 21 miles this this of Pittsburgh. We learn that a stock and oil train coming east was detained on the track while some cars of a forward train were being shifted.

In steamship Fah-Kee, from st. Jago.--Dr. C. Dunham, wife and child, Walter Douglass, A. D. Timmins, M. Namino, L. de la Tone. FEB. 25--In steamship St. Lawrence, from London.--Samuel, Holly and lady. In steamship Evening Star. From New-Orleans.--Lieut.-Col. W. P. Cowie, E. P. Thompson, C. F. Gardner, T. J. Rogers, F. T. Learned, Col. Emerson, John Menta, P. J.

President JOHNSON'S contemptuous allusion to Col. J. W. FORNEY as a "dead duck," has solved a problem which has sorely puzzled that conspicuous political acrobat for some months past. It has decided which side he will take in the impending contest between the Constitution and the Radicals of the country.

THE SOUTHERN PRESS.--Gen. GRANT'S warning to the Southern Press a fortnight ago seems to have had an excellent effect. They have discovered that they cannot safely indulge in treasonable language, or in language that smacks of treason, and they promptly ?? that discretion is the better part of ??.

Considerable excitement was caused yesterday morning in the Twentieth Ward, by a deliberate attempt at murder by an ex-patrolman, of the Twentieth Precinct, who endeavored to kill Roundsman McCULLOUGH, of the same precinct,by shooting him with a pistol.

The educational movement in India has become remarkably active; indeed, suprisingly active when compared with the indifference to intellectual culture that prevailed among the natives but a few years ago. Year by year the numbers of students in school and college increase, and the fact forms a prin- it cipal subject of conversation with the civil and military functionaries who come home on leave.

Dr. HUGHES, while standing on the scaffold, with the rope about his neck, declared that he should be with the earthly community as much after death as before, and he scems determined to keep his word. Among the many persons who called to see HUGHES in his cell before the execution, was an honest butcher of the Teutonic persuasion.

The third as yet arrived, of the United States and Brazil Mail Steamship Line of steamers, the South America, sails for New-York to-day. As the party whose adventures are chiefly my theme returns to the states, in the prosecution of his mission, by this steamer, and as I have been with him during the whole course of his travels, and "know the points"...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Is the old official regulation, making it obligatory on policemen to extend civilities to reporters of the Press, a dead letter? The writer was refused admission to the reporters' table at the Cooper Union on Thursday evening last by the officers at the rear entrance of the building, though he as fully armed with the proper credentials.

The murrain among cattle in Great Britain has reached an alarming extent. Since July last, 130,000 head have been attacked, of which only 15,000 have recovered. The pecuniary loss is estimated at about $7,000,000 in our present currency.

The little steamer Kate sunk yesterday morning, six miles above Leavenworth, Ind. She will be raised. No lives were lost. It is reported that TOM HENRY, the guerilla, sen tenced to the New-Hampshire Penitentiary, will be released soon. A rumor prevails here that cannot be verified tonight, that the steamer Stephen Decatur blew up above Memphis.

It is altogether unnecessary in these enlightened days to urge upon any sensible man the importance and necessity of life insurance. It is a safeguard against the contingencies of the future that every one with a family or dependent friends resorts to as a matter of course. The only room for debate is as to the company in which a policy shall be taken out;

A TEXT-BOOK OF ANATOMY, PHYSIOLOGY AND HYOIENSE for the use of Schools and Families. By JOHN C. DRAPER, Professor of Natural History and Physiology in the New-York Froe Academy, Svo. New-York: HARPER BROS. This handsomely-printed and illustrated volume possesses special adaptation for purposes of general tuition that gives it a marked superiority over the books intended for strictly professional use.

Cape Town advices to Jan. 13, have been received. The Basuto war continued. The army of the Free State was melting away by desertion, and the prospects of the new State was dismal enough. The results of a year's hostilities was that the Basutos had learned to fortify themselves in impregnable possessions unassailable without trained troops. Every important mountain in their country was be ing fortified.

A LOST ARCHIVE.--In the report of the proceedings of the Senate it will be found that a joint resolution has passed the Assembly authorizing the City o Williamsbureh to send to London for a certicopy copy of its lost charter. The original one was granted by their gracious Majesties King WILLIAM and MARY, and bore their royal seal.

The Supreme Court is an appellate court, and does not execute its own judgments, but having decided the cause, the Court issues a mandate to the Court below, directing that Court to enter the proper Judgment, which is to be enforced by the inferior Court.

If the war upon President JOHNSON is carried on in the style in which it has been opened by his adversaries, they will at the same time indicate their own want of judgment in the conduct of a political struggle, and will fail to injure him who is the object of assault.

A work of art, unique and most curious, is now to be seen at the jewelry store of Mr. Z. M. QUIMBY, Broadway, near Twenty-sixth-street. In fact, it is so far out of the common line of inventive undertakings that it is difficult to oven give it a name. It may, perhaps, be called a "Dual Mortuary Memorial," being a miniature monument to those two Presidents of the United States,
NATIONAL STEAM NAVIGATION COMPANY.--The new steamship England, of this Company's line, arrived her last Thursday from Liverpool. This vessel is one of the finest specimens of naval architecture

RUFFIANISM IN THE EASTERN DISTRIOT.--About noon, yesterday, while Truant Officer CARR, in charge of a truant boy, was passing through Tenth-street, E. D., he was assailed with eggs and stones by a crowd of roughs, at the corner of North First-street, in so furious a manner that he was compelled to abandon the boy in his charge, and seek personal safety in flight.

IOWA AND CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS. Mr. GRIMES presented the memorial of citizens of Iowa, asking for such an amendment to the Constitution as will recognize the existence of God and the divinity of Christ.

The following is among a series of resolutions introduced in the lower branch of the Legislature to. day, and referred to the Committee on Federal Relations: Resolved, That the recent public attack upon one of the honored and beloved Senators of Massachusetts by the President of the United States in a public speech in the City of Washington, is an insult to the commonwealth.

[OFFICIAL.] BOARD OF ALDERMEN. STATED SESSION...MONDAY, Feb. 26, 1866. Present--Aldermen Moore, Coman, Norton, Flynn, Shannon, Gedney, Ely, Ryers, Reilly, Brice. Loew, Masterson, Varnum, O'Brien, McGinnis, Van Voorhis. The minutes of February twenty-one were read and approved.

The Wheeling Intelligencer of Saturday gives this account of the burning of the steamer Winchester, on the Ohio River: At 3:30 o'clock one of the firemen threw a shovelful of hot ashes out in a careless manner. Some of the live embers were blown into a bundle of hay, which was part of a lot that had been taken at the mouth of Yellow Creek.

On Saturday morning last it was discovered that the house of Rev. A. MITCHELL, of Morristown, N. J., had been entered and robbed of property to the amount of $300, and that the thief, whoever he might be, had been so adroit and successful as to do it without alarming any of the household, and gone, nobody could guess where.

The steamship Hermann, from Southampton, arrived at this port last night with three days' later intelligence. Her advices are unimportant. The prospects and probable character of the Reform Bill to be presented to Parliament occupy public attention in England; but every one seems to be in the dark about it.

The Tribune quotes a single paragraph from President JOHNSON's speech--hat in which he refers to three men by name as "hostile to the fundamental principles of this Government"-and then denounces sundry journals in this City for trying to "commend and bolster up the speech by the most extraordinary plaudits."

A GOOD TIME COMING FOR TRAVELERS ON THE CITY CARS.--The millennium approaches for City railroad travelers, and these comprise the entire community. The Common Council n have appointed a City Railroad Inspector at an annual stipend of $2,500.

GEN. WM. DE LACY.--This gallant officer, late Colonel of the One Hundred and Sixty-fourth Regiment N. Y. V., has been, alter four years' service, promoted a Brevet Brigadier-General of Volunteers, to rank from March 13,1865.

The bill incorporating the Covington and Ohio Railroad passed both Houses to-day. The House passed the Senate Bill amending the Usury Law, so as to authorize contracts for the payment of eight per cent. interest.
The Canadian gazette contains a proclamation warning American fishermen that they cannot use the Canadian shore fisheries after the 17th March next.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL--RESOLUTIONS IN FAVOR OF A PUBLIC MEETING TO SUSTAIN PRESIDENT JOHNSON.--The Board held a regular meeting yesterday afternoon, and there being considerabie business, extended the session to a late hour in the evening.

THE PRESIDENT IN CONNECTICUT.-There is to be a meeting on Wednesday evening in New-Haven in support of the Union and the President's policy. The call is broad and liberal, and meets the warm approval of many of the foremost citizens of the State, among them Rev. Dr. BACON, who, in giving his name, says:

The general discussion on the future of the great Union party, in view of recent events, has been exceedingly vigorous here for the past few days, and has thus far produced most encouraging and harmonizing results. Comparing the feeling of last Thursday night with that of to-day, we cannot but feel elated over the aspect.

A very common sort of a scoundrel answering to the name of ZENO BURNHAM, was convicted, the other day, of common swindling. He kept a "Peter Funk" shop in one of the upper wards of the City-" brown-stone front." He was known to the public, for years, as a cheat and scoundrel.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The debut last evening of Senorita CARMELINA POCH-a Spanish prima-donna who has recently been added to Mr. MARETZEK'S troupe-was in every way successful. The lady possesses a voice of unusual power, and uses it with skill. It is a soprano of excellent quality; clear, ringing, free alike from harshness and trembling, and just and absolute in intonation.

RETAILERS AND PRICES.--While there is a general tendency to a considerable reduction in the wholesale price of almost every commodity, the retail dealers of this and adjacent cities have continued to demand nearly the same prices for their goods as they did when everything was at an enormously high rate.

President WARNER sent his Annual Message to the Liberian Congress Dec. 11. We make these extracts: "The ratifications of the treaty between Liberia and Haiti and that between Liberia and Denmark have been duly exchanged.

Rev. Dr. MORGAN, Rector of St. Thomas' Church, preached a sermon in behalf of this institution of mercy on Sunday evening, in Zion Church, Madison-avenue, corner of East Thirty-eighth-street. The church was crowded. The steamship Hermann, from Southampton on the 14th of February, arrived here last night. The Asia and Erin arrived out on Feb. 10. The Steamship Caroline from New-Orleans and Havana arrived at Queenstown Feb. 11.

We have among us journals whose peculiar pleasure it is to give prominence to every word and every incident calculated to convey the impression that the Southern States cherish a spirit at variance with that which is attributed to them by those who claim their restoration to power and position in the Union.

BUNNER.--At Harlem, on Monday, Feb. 26, MARY LBUNNER, eldest daughter of C. A. and Catharine Bunner, aged 15 years and 11 months. The triends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock, in 125th-st., between 6th and 7th avs.

THE RIGHT TO CARRY ARMS.--In a large number of assaults by burglars and highwaymen recourse is being had more and more by the thieves to firearms and other deadly weapons. Not only so, but the systematic carrying of arms appears to be a matter of course among a large class of turbulent persons in this City.

Last evening Gen. GRANT was received at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the members of the Twenty-third Regiment, N. G. S. N. Y., on behalf of the citizens of Brooklyn. The interior of the Academy was beautifully decorated with the national colors and the banners of the Twenty-third Regiment.

Mayor HOFFMAN two weeks since returned to the Board of Aldermen, without his approval, a resolution adopted by that body, which appropriated $3,500 to Mr. D. T. VALENTINE, the venerable Clerk of the Common Council, for his services in compiling the Manual of the Common Council for the current year.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--BELLINI'S beautiful opera of "La Somnambula" will be played here to-night, with Miss KELLOGG as Amina. It was in this role that the lady won one of her earliest successes. The opera is so seldom played, that its occasional representation is as good a novelty as anything else in the repertoire.

The Commissioners of Health met at the Mayor's Office yesterday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock. Dr. SAYRE presented the following letter: SENATE CHAMBER, WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 1866. Dr. Sayre, Resident Physician:

DEGREE, CONFERRED.--On Thursday last, President, ANDREW JOHNSON, of the Union College, Washington City, conferred the honorary title of "D. D." upon JOHN W. FORNEY, Esq. This exaltation creates some surprise, since it is not known that the recipient was ever in holy orders, and some go so far as to say that the President is making game of him;

PRAYER FOR COLLEGES.--On Thursday the following services will be held: In the chapel of the New-York University, at 11 A. M. Sermon by Rev. T. D. W. TALMAGE, of Philadelphia. In Madisonsquare Presbyterian Church, Rev. Dr. ADAMS, pastor, at 3 1/2 o'clock. Addresses are expected from Rev. J. T. DURYEA, Rev. A. E. KITTREDGE and T. R. SMITH.

The agitation concerning the prices of food, the greenback and gold bother, the proposition to introduce a new system of numeration, and the general upheaval of society in anticipation of the first of May, are current realities of life in New-York. It is gratifying to know that the prices of some prime necessaries are going down, although the retailers have not received the news.

The late storm damaged the bridges on the Nashville and Decatur Railroad. The shipment of freight, temporarily interrupted in consequence, will be resumed on Thursday. The two great billiard champions, KAVANAGH of America, and ROBERTS of England, gave an exhibition of billiard playing at the new theatre to-day.

THE MILITIA BILL. Mr. WILSON reported from the Committee on Military Affairs the Militia Bill with amendments, many of them of minor importance, one of which strikes out drunkards and vagabonds from the exempted persons, Another includes the Executive and Judicial officers of the States and Territories among the exempt-but the States are not allowed to make exemptions. The companies may consist of 60 to 100 privates, in addition to officers.

A terrific explosion occurred last evening at the furnace of J. H. J. REILLY, in Middletown, resulting in the complete destruction of the furnace, the death of five men and the wounding of six other. Eight boilers were in the furnace.

THE DECISION AGAINST THE ATLANTIC AND GREAT WESTERN ROAD,.--Yesterday the long-expected decision in the case in which the Philadelphia and Erie and the Pennsylvania Railroad Companies were complainants, and the Catawihsa and the Great Western Railroad Companies were defendants, was rendered by Judge READ, of the State Supreme Court.

THE VACANT RECORDERSHIP.--There was an attempt, yesterday, on the part of the Board of Supervisors to fill the vacant Recordership of the City, an office left without an incumbent by the election of Mr. HOFFMAN to the Mayor's chair.

FLOUR moderately active. WHEAT advanced 2c., closing firm at $1 23 3/4@$1 24. CORN dull. OATS firm. HIGHWINES firm. PROVISIONS firm. MESS PORK $26 50@$27. SWEET PICKLED HAMS in good request at 15 1/2c.@17 1/2c. English Meats quiet, but firm, Cumberland Middles, 13 1/2c.@18 3/4c.; Short Ribbed, 14 1/2c.@15c.

The funeral of Hon. GEO. W. SMYTHE was at-t tended by the members of the State Convention enmasse, previous to which resolutions of respect to his memory and condolence and sympathy with his family were adopted.

The Superior Court, Judge PUTNAM on the Bench, has been occupied yesterday and to-day with the case of F. O. J. SMITH, recently convicted of subornation of perjury, in his application for a now trial. The defendant's counsel occupied all of yesterday and a portion of to-day in presenting his case. District-Attorney SANGER, for the Commonwealth, replied this afternoon.

ARNOUX.--Suddenly, on Tuesday, Feb. ?? ELLA KENNETT, daughter of Anthony and Clementine W. Arnoux, in the 4th year of her age. The friends of the family, and of her grandfather, John s. Woodward, are invited to attend the funeral services, to be held at the house of her parents, No. 03 East 17th-st., at 2 P. M. of Thursday, March 1.

Petitions were presented for a ship canal from Cayuga Lake to Lake Ontario; for an appropriation to the Now-York Society for the Protection of Destitute Catholic Children; and to equalize the fare on the East New-York and Jamaica Railroad.

A LIQUOR CASE.--Those who use spirituous liquors may be reasonably soared by a curious case just reported at the United States District Court at Albany. Some casks were seized as smuggled, which were filled with an imitation of brandy, manufactured of neutral spirits, flavored with oil of cognac, and colored with burnt sugar-in fact, miserable stuff.

The loss by the steamboat fire last night, including the cargoes of the Dictator and Luna, and freight burned on the levee, is estimated at about $750,000. Insurance on the Dictator, $112,000. The other vessels were not insured.

The Commercial Advertiser quotes from the TIMES' columns, (politely calling us "a Republican morning contemporary" ) remarks of ours that there are journals which "give prominence to every word and every incident calculated to convey the impression that the Southern States cherish a spirit at variance with that which is attributed to them by those who claim their restoration to power and position in the Union."

THE CONCURRENT RESOLUTIONS. Upon the resumption of the discussion of the concurrent resolution in the Senate to-day, Mr. DIXON got the floor and made a forcible speech in advocacy of the President's policy. He argued that the only mode to save the Union and restore harmony was to pursue the policy adopted by the Administration.

Both Houses of the Legislature reassembled this morning, the members refreshed by a week's recess, invigorated by breathing a purer atmosphere than the stifling gases of the Assembly Chamber, and their back-bones stiffened by learning the will of their constituents.

MR. TRUMBULL'S SPEECH.--We are asked by the Tribune to copy from its columns a synopsis (taken from another paper) of Senator TRUMBULL'S speech on the Freedmen's Bureau bill. Very happy, indeed, to oblige,

If Marshal FOREY'S speech in the Senate on Mexican affairs was prepared with the cognizance, if not the approval of the Emperor, as some pretend to believe, the return of the French army may not tale place so soon as expected. Marshal FOREY knows the subject well-no man better;

This Board met at 1 P. M. yesterday, for the first time since the 9th of January, President SMITH in the chair. Mr. TWKED said he bad been served with a number of papers relative to the claims of banks against the City for taxes collected in error. He moved that they be referred to the special Committee having the matter in charge, and the motion was adopted.

THE NEW COURT-HOUSE AND CHARGES OF CORRUPTION.--There is a well-settled conviction in the public mind that the magnificent new Court-house now in process of erection in the City Hall Park, is the channel through which flows a heavy volume of the public money into the pockets of the Municipal "ring."

A Democratic Convention assembled at Sacramento, a few evenings since, in large numbers to sustain the President's veto and policy generally. Ex-Gov. BIGLER addressed them in approval of the President's veto and reconstruction policy.

A certain class of individuals, including a number of old women and a very few sensible but short-sighted persons, are greatly perturbed over the fact that " the Copperheads indorse President JOHNSON."

The steamer Oceanus, which went ashore on Fisher's Island, on Friday night. was hauled off early this morning and started for Now-York, in tow of a steamer. The cargo had previously been taken out in good condition.

MEAN, BUT CHARACTERISTIC.--The Tribune calls our statement that there are four persons who disapprove the President's speech a piece of " effrontery," and proceeds, not to show that these four persons or any of them are misrepresented, but that five or six Legislatures have repudiated the veto message.

ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, Vice-President of the defunct Southern Confederacy, made an excellent and most timely speech before the Georgia Legislature on WASHINGTON'S birthday. It makes four or five columns in the New-York TIMEq, to which paper it was specially telegraphed and published on Saturday--an enterprise in journalism noticeable even in these days, so often marked by enterprising journalistic feats.

A fire oceurred here to-day, destroying three small buildings. Loss $1,000. The Petroleum Board met this afternoon, and resolved to form a permanent board, and publish a weekly newspaper devoted to petroleum and mining interests. KAVANAGH and ROBERTS will play a game at billiards to-night; the French carom game--5OO points.

National topics, in spite of all attempts to keep them in the background, pressed upon the attention of both Houses this morning. It has become evident that we are doomed to suffer not a little speechmaking over the position of President JOHNSON relative to the lately rebellious States, and that many members will take occasion to define their views.

The increase of the National Treasury, from Customs duties at the Port of New-York, thus far, this week, has averaged $626,370 a day, as follows: Monday, $969,839; Tuesday, $446,271; Wednesday, $463,000; making the total for the month of February $12,018,659, against only $4,823,214 same month last year. This shows an increase in the month just closed of $7,195,445.

The Reconstruction Committee was appointed by Congress "to inquire into the condition of the late so-called Confederate States, and report whether they or any of them are entitled to representation in either House of Congress, with leave to report by bill or otherwise."

The postponement of yesterday in the House of Representatives, by an immense majority, of the proposed amendment to the Constitution, is looked upon as an admission on the part of the Radicals that a direct fight with the President is not in order.

COAL CHEAPENING RAPIDLY.--It will gratify the mass of our readers to learn that fuel, if not food, is steadily declining to remunerative, though not extortionate rates. At the regular auction sale of Scranton coal yesterday, twenty thousand tons were disposed of at prices which show a fall,

Advices from Galveston state that the Texas State Convention adopted the new article to the Constitution, abolishing involuntary servitude, except for crime, protecting African descendants in their rights of property, and allowing them to testify in tile courts by a vote of 56 against 26, and ordered it to be engrossed.

Never before in the experience of the esteemed Commissioner who retired on Wednesday, were trials so dreary as to incident and so few in number, There were but sixty complaints; and of the sixty not more than ten held sufficient water to wash more than one day's pay from the monthly pay-rolls. So much the better for the officers of the force.

BERRIAN--HOWLAND.--At Hyde Park, N. Y., on Wednesday, Feb. 23, by Rev. Henry Dater, GEO, W. BERRIAN, of Rye, and ELIZABETH A., daughter of Chas. J. Howland. of the former place. GRIFFITH--DANIELL.--At Springfield, Mass., on Tuesday, Feb. 27, by Rev. S. G. Buckingham, WALTER S. GRIFFITH, of Brooklyn. N. Y., and HENRIETTA S. DANIELL, of Springfield.

Official news from El Paso, the seat of the National Government of Mexico, has been received here up to the 2d inst. The French column which had started from Chihuahua to El Paso returned to Chihuahua, and it was understood that all the French troops at the City of Chihuahua were about leaving that State, of which they hold only the capital.

To enable the Atlantic Yacht Club to appoint Trustees. Providing for the restoration of securities deposited with the Insurance Department by the Life Insurance Companies of other States. Authorizing the District-Attorney of Kings County to appoint a clerk.

About 4 o'clock this morning, a bottle filled with explosive fluid was thrown through the window of a house in Lafayette-street, occupied by Capt. BOLLEYN, constable of the Third Ward. The Captain was sleeping in the room, which was suddenly enveloped in flames. He escaped alive, though somewhat burned, but the house was quickly destroyed.

On Monday last, Judge M. F. CONWAY, formerly a Representative in Congress from Kansas, was offered the use of the Chamber of the House of Delegates for this evening, in order that the he might address the citizens of Richmond and vicinity on the subject of the policy of the Administration.

ALLEN.--On Tuesday, Feb. 27, MATTHEW ALLEN, in the 49th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the M. E. Church, corner of Lexington-av. and 52d-st., on Friday afternoon at 1 o'clock. Carriages will be in attendance for those who wish to accompany the remains to Greenwood Cemetery.

There was a large attendance in the Superior Court-room to-day to hear F. O. J. SMITH on his ap. peal to have the verdict convicting him of subordination Of perjury set aside, and a new trial granted.

AN APT PUPIL.--The Washington correspondent of the Springfield Republican says: "Sometimes the mob is right. I suppose, for instanoe, that if JOHN DIXON, on his return to Connecticut, should be tarred and feathered, everybody would say he was rightly served."

The bill to regulate trade with the British North American Provinces, printed at length in our columns yesterday, affords ground for hoping that the Committee of Ways and Means are not unmindful of the embarrassment with which the country is threatened as a consequence of the sudden breaking off of the Reciprocity negotiation.

The noisiest brawler for what he calls liberty is, proverbially, the greatest tyrant in his own practice. In the same way, 'the pharisaical stickler for propriety in speech and action is apt to be most unmindful of his duties in regard to both when they interfere with his own particular pleasure.

A large, influential and enthusiastic meeting of the people of this city was held in Brewster Hall this evening in support of the policy of President JOHNSON. A series of resolutions was adopted, setting forth that no good reason existed for the disruption of the Union Party which had carried the country through the peril of civil war;

THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT POSTPONED. The backbone of the Constitutional Amendment movement was broken in the House to-day. The last amendment was to have been carried through upon the broad shoulders of Mr. BINGHAM, but he broke down with the burden, mainly in censequence of a parliamentary checkmate moved by Judge HALE, of New-York.

CREAMER--CONGER.--On Wednesday evening, Feb. 28, by Rev. Stephen H. Tyng, Jr., JAMES S. CREAMER and EMMA FIELD, daughter of the late Ellison Conger, of Newark, N. J. CROWTHER--SISSON.--On Wednesday, Feb. 21, in Chillicothe, Ohio, by Rev. Mr. Biggs, HENRY CROWTHER, of Leeds, England, and Miss CORNELIA A. SISSON, daughter, of the late Dr. Sisson, of Columbus, Ohio.

THE NEW-YORK SHIP NEWS.--The first member of a new weekly newspaper of this, name is printed. It gives forty-eight finely-printed pages of matter concerning the great interests of commerce, with espacial reference to the shipping business. It seems to be a very comprehensive journal and, if kept up to the rather ambitious standard of this specimen, will be a valuable addition to the class literature of the day.

EUGENE KELLY. banker, of New-York, and FREDERICK BILLINGS, were among the passengers on the steamer yesterday. The Alta California, the largest and oldest paper in the State, (Independent Union) supports President JOHNSON'S administration. Large shipments of grain and breadstuffs are going to Australia in consequence of the closing of the Chilian ports by Spain.

This town has been in a great flutter from an early hour this morning till late this afternoon. Carriages driven by men having on their breasts white rosettes admonished the people that something out of the ordinary line of Bridgeport life was on foot. So many carriages were never seen in the place before; hence the inquiry on all hands: "What is it?"

The steamship Asia, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 17th ??, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her dates are four days later than these already received. The Asia has 23 passengers for this port and 43 for session.

According to accounts received at Santiago de Cuba from the French West ladies, the cholera still continued at Guadeloupe, committing great ravages, the number of deaths up to Dec. 31 was as follows: Pointe-a-Pitre, 1,200; Basse-Terre, 2,000. In thirteen communes of Qnadeloupe the number of deaths was 6,500. In Grand-Terre, in twelve communes, included Marie Galante, 12,200.

A WOMAN WANTS A DIVORCE AFTER HER HUSBAND'S DEATH.--The Supreme Court of Tennessee has decided an interesting case. Mrs. SWAN has filed a bill by J. M. SWAN, defendant, who also filed a cross bill Owing to the Chancellor's ill health the matter was ?? to three prominent members of the bar.

Church, corner of Lexington-av. and 52d-st., on Friday afternoon at 1 o'clock. Carriages will be in attendance for those who wish to accompany the remains to Greenwood Cemetery. DICK.--On Thursday. March 1, Mrs. MARY DICK, widow of the late Samuel Dick, aged 72 years.

There is but one serious side to the Fenian movement. We have pointed out its ludicrous features, perhaps as broadly as was expedient. There is, however, one view of the question which no true friend of "justice to Ireland" should overlook. The movement thus far has compassed two striking objects, and two only, for Ireland and Irish Liberals.

SANDY COTTON.--Five bales of cotton were opened on the premises of the Suffolk Manufacturing company in this city yesterday, the bales containing ?? the hundred and eighty-seven pounds of sand. Each bale had a bag of sand in the centre, extending near to the end. Two of them had two bags in each one. There were 216 pounds of sand in one bale.

THE HORRORS OF SALISBURY PRISON.--The trial by military commission of Maj. JOHN H. GEE, formerly the rebel commandant of the Salisbury Prison, was begun at Raleigh, N. C., on Wednesday morning. GEE was commander of the Confederate prison at that place previous to its capture by Gen. STONEMAN, and it is alleged that the prisoners were subjected to the same outrages and indignities which rendered the name of Andersonville so odious.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber was held at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Alexander Delmar, Howard L. Parmelee, D. S. Moore, Francis R. Goodrich, N. W. Stuyvesant Catlin, Joseph A. Drefous and Alexander Forman were elected members of the Chamber.

THE NEW--JERSEY MARSHES AGAIN.--We understand that a mass meeting of musquitoes is to be held early in June, at Snake Hill, on the Jersey flats, to take into consideration the prospective trespasses upon the domains which they have held undisturbed from time immemorial.

The meeting called to sustain the reconstruction policy of Congress was held in the Front-street Theatre, where LINCOLN and JOHNSON were nominated. The spacious building was densely packed, and great enthusiasm was manifested.

THE STRIKE SYSTEM.--Accounts from Pittsburgh, Penn., say that the strikes continue among the mills there; that the workmen, Ending that the employers will not yield, are seeking other occupations. This was to be expected. There is no other way of exit from the difficulties of the ease, so long as both sides are determined on victory.

The following is an exttract from a letter written by a veteran Republican of St. Lawrence, who has occupied responsible places in the Government, and whose wisdom and patriotism are proverbial: OGDENSBURGH, Monday, Feb. 26, 1866. Another reason for my writing is to say to you that I fully indorse the course of our good President.

The steamship Asia, from Liverpool, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her dates are four days later than those received by the Hermann. The steamship Edinburg also arrived yesterday. The Fenian excitement in Ireland was on the increase. The royal assent had been given to the bill suspending the writ of habeas corpus in Ireland.

UNDEVOUT ASTRONOMERS.--Much good ink has been wasted in sentences and paragraphs of astonishment that a whole month (February) has passed over to the credit side of Old Time's ledger without having had a full moon. Our business being more with the stars on the American flag than with the "glitteringg generalities" of the sky, we have paid no spocial attention to the matter, for we do not usually follow the changes of the moon;

ACADEMY OF MUSIC DONIZETTI'S opers of " "La Favoriat" will be repeated here to-night for ?? second and last time. The new prima donna, ?? CARMELINA POCH, is the Leonore. We had occasion on the first performance of the opera to speak in high terms of the lady's cpacities. It is seldom that we have heard a voice of such purity and power.

GENTLY.--At the rate at which the temporary followers of the radical leader are deserting his standard, the party promises to assume proportions exceedingly small before the week shall have closed. The belligerent organ here has retired from active and open warfare, and betaken itself as formerly to the feblest kind of innuende.

ORPHANS' HOME OF THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI.--Rev. Dr. TEASDALE, General Superintendent of this institution is now in New-York asking aid for the suffering orphans of Mississippi, of whom it is supposed there are at least 10,000 in the State. To meet the ex-agencies of this suffering class, the Orphans' Home has been inaugurated. The Lauderdal Springs property has been purchased for the objects of the institution.

Mr. SHERMAN submitted a communication from the Commissioner of Agriculture to the Senate Committee on Agriculture, relating to dyers' madder, which was ordered to be printed. It contains the statistics of its consumption in this country on account of experiments in its culture here, with their results, and a reference to the causes of its non-production.

The sober second thought is evidently doing its work among the politicians. The majority of the Union Party in Congress begin to evince a gratifying unwillingness to play the game of the few reckless men who have arrogated the authority of leaders. There is a manifest tendency in the direction of prudence, if not of absolute conservatism.

The New-Orleans newspapers inform us that Gen. SHERIDAN recently stopped a boat-load of Southern " chivalry " on their way to the imperial dominions of MAXIMILIAN. Why he stopped them we are totally at a loss to imagine, as up to this time Gen. SHERIDAN has borne the reputation of great practical sense.

FOUND DROWNED.--We suggest to the Police authorities that they adopt the English method of making public the description of unknown persons found drowned. It is there the rule to keep a board suspended outside every Police station, on which is posted from time to time, and for a stated period, printed forms with blanks, for inserting the descriptions of the persons, dress, contents of pockets, , of sch unfortnates.

An immense meeting was held on Wednesday evening by the friends of protection to home Industry. It was a meeting of the masses, who came together to consider the grave questions which have recently been forced upon the attention of the public by the formation of Free-Trade Leagues. Some excellent speeches were made, and the resolutions adopted were of the right character.

The inhabitants of Tampico, in Mexico, who were lately congratulating themselves on having been relieved by their French defenders from the inland blockade to which their town was subjected by the Republicans, have had their short-lived joy suddenly turned into mourning.

A DELEGATION FROM MARYLAND VISIT THE PRESIDENT. This morning a committee waited upon the President to present the resolution adopted at a meeting held at Baltimore on the 26th ult. Mr.COX addressed the President as follows: Mr.PRESIDENT: At an overwhelming meeting of loyal citizens of Baltimore on Monday last, it was determined that a committee should present to you, in person, the resolution adopted, with unexampled unanimity, on that occasion.

HALF, of the Essex District, in this State, upon the amendment proposed to the Constitution, by which Congress is empowered to secure by law to all the citizens of the several States "equal protection in the enjoyment of life, liberty and property."

THE SKY BRIGHTENS.--The political fegrises, leaving an atmosphere all the brighter for its transient obscurity. In the Legislature sensible resolutions have succeeded, and will supersede intemperate ones. The Union Press opens its eyes and its columns. The Fulton County Republican, an able and reliable journal, sustains the President firmly.

Journeying across the Plains in midwinter is a cold proceeding; ours was frozen one. By the most direct route from the "States," and, in fact, the only Santa Feroute, it is a fifteen days journey. A portion of this travel, too, is through a country so infested by Indians that stations cannot be built and kept.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you allow me a place in your valueble columns to say a word in defence of my Southern brethren from the false conclusion which is generally arrived at by our Northern fellow-citizens upon the question of their loyalty.

The meeting hold in Brewster Hall, in this city, last night, was large, respectable and intelligent, including representatives of all classes of the community. Music Hall, which is much larger, would have been engaged for the occasion, but that it was preoccupied by other parties. As it was, however, the spirit of the meeting was one of which the Union Party of the country may speak with pleasure, and without fear.

The Southern States want capital and labor. Under their propitious skies there are leagues and leagues of fruitful lands, of which we may say, in the Hibernian simile, "Tickle them with a hoe, and they will laugh with a harvest." The collapse of the rebellion has left a sad state of society over most of that fair territory.

Maj.-Gen. POPE has issued a general order detailing a plan for the safety of travelers when cross ing the Western Plains. Forts Ridgley and Abercromble are designated as posts of rendezvous for all trains from the Minnesota for the Upper Missouri, Yellow Stone, or Block Hills, and Powder River regions. Fort Kearny is designated as the frendezvous for trains to Denver City or Fort Laramie, via the Platte River route;

Y., on Tuesday night, by Detective BAKER, of this city, who reached here this morning with his prisoner. The arrest was made on the charge of stealing two bales of goods from KNOWLES LELAND, on Devonshirestreet, valued at $3,500.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT-EASTERN DISTRICT. Before Judge Benedict. The Union Ferry Company vs. The steamship Favorita.-This was a case of collision. The libelants were the owners of the ferry-boat Manhasset, which, on the 14th of April, 1865, was run into by the Favorita, which was coming up the East River, returning from a trial trip, about 3 or 4 o'clock P. M.

THE CONCURRENT RESOLUTION PASSED BY THE SENATE. One of the vexed questions that have agitated Congress for the past ten days or so, was finally disposed of in the Senate this evening at 7 o'clock. The concurrent resolution which passed the House early last week, and which has since almost wholly occupied the Senate, came to a vote in the last-named body, and was passed by yeas 28 to 18 nays,

THE DEAD LEVEL--It has been suggested that the attempt of the Independent to stretch the month of February beyond its natural limit was only a logical expression of that paper's theory of absolute equality.

The Special Committee of the Board of Supervisors appointed to inquire into the charges of corruption brought by Mr. ELY against the Committee of the New County Court-house, met in session last evening at 5 o'clock, Mr. Fox in the Chair. A letter had been received from Mr. JOSEPH F. DALY, attorney of the Citizens' Association, offering his services, as the representative of that body, to the committee in aid of the investigation.

BENNETT--At Fort Hamilton, Friday, March 2, RICHARD R. BENNETT, aged 56 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from his late residence, on Monday, the 5th inst., at 2 1/2 o'clock. Carriages will be in waiting at the terminus of the railroad.

A special meeting of several Fenian Circles was held to-night at Fenlan Hall. Resolutions were adopted recognizing the crisis as having arrived, and promising all aid to their brethren struggling in Ireland. A grand mass meeting will be held on Tuesday night, in front of Independence Hall.

The business people of Houston, Texas, have acquired sufficient practical acquaintance with the new order of things, to have found the necessary ways and means to establish a National Bank. In some points of political intelligence, however, the Texan people are rather lagging behind their neighbors.

The Texas State Convention referred to the Finance Committee the whole subject of the public debt of the State. The Committee on Indian Affairs reported in favor of making a treaty with the Creeks and Chickasaws, permitting them to hunt on the frontier if they will assist in protecting the settlers; also, in favor of sending Commissioners to Washington to lay the condition of the frontiers before the Gonvernment.

SUICIDE OF A RETURNED SOLDIER--REMOESE AND INTEMPERANCE--AFFECTING LETTER.--About 9 o'clock on Friday night, I returned soldier named WILLIAM H. FOSTER was found dead on a lounge in his apartments, corner of Franklin and Noble streets, Greenpoint, with two small phials, emptied and marked "laudanum," on a table beside him. Deceased had been living alone for some time, his wife and three children having abandoned him in consequence of his intemperate habits.

The dispatches from Pesth which reached us by the last steamer show an unalterable determination on the part of the Liberal Party to insist on constitutional reforms and the administrative independence of Hungary in the new order of things. The people of Rochester have "been and gone and done it," and here is the proof of the fact. The Demnocrat of Friday makes this startling announcement: "The Republicans of Rochester assembled in City Convention, last evening, to nominate municipal officare, closed their work by the spontaneous and unanimous: nomination, by acclamation, of Licut.- Gen. GRANT as their candidate for the Presidency it the election of 1868."

JASON H. TUTTLE, formerly connected with the Post-office at Tuttlesville, N. J., and who is alleged to have been operating a jewelry gift enterprise, lately became alarmed and fled to Canada. On reaching Detroit he forwarded his trunk by the American Express Company to Toronto, to the address of R. J. WALE.B, In due time TUTTLE appeared in Toronto, represented himself to be R. J. WALKER, and claimed the trunk.

The Spanish authorities congratulated themselves when they succeeded in inducing the United Slates authorities to libel the steamer Meteor, alleged to have been fitted out for privateering purposes. Since that event two Spanish war-vessels have arrived here to watch suspected vessels and parties, but thus far their presence has been of little avail. The South American allies are too cunning for the Spaniards.

Since the subsidence of the flurry to which the ROBERTS and O'MAHONEY fiasco give rise, the Fenian element has been comparatively quiet. However energetic the Brotherhood may have been in their arduous labors, there was but little noise aboveground, and the bulk of the population slept soundly over the mines which the highly imaginative minority supposed to honey-comb Manhattan.

Yesterday afternoon Presidents SCHULTZ and Registrar HARRIS, of the Health Commission, accompanied by Inspector CAUPENTER, of the Metropolitan Police, visited the late City Inspector's office, intending to demand the books, papers, and other public property belonging to the City Inspector's Department; but Mr. BOOLE was absent, and the gentlemen found only a raft of old books and Coroner's inquest papers. These were not removed, yesterday, but are to be taken away to-morrow.

So many "missions" have already been assigned to America, that it will not surprise anybody if one more contribution seem to be added to the list. Our country of late has undertaken the task of disproving old proverbs, and exposing ancient laws to ridicule. The present "mission" of America, according to some people, appears to be to show that a house divided against itself can stand.

KILLED BY A FALL FROM A WINDOW.-Shortly before midnight of Friday, information was lodged at the Sixteenth Precinct Station-house to the effect that the dead body of a man was lying in the vacant lot adjoining the residence of Mr. DAVID SAMSON, No. 205 West Fourteenth-street. Capt. HEDDEN proceeded thither, and found that the dead man was Mr. SAMSON himself, the body being yet warm, but lifeless.

Capt. W. DUNCAN, an officer of the rebel Commissary Department at Anderaonville, was arraigned before the Military Commisssion yesterday on charges of murder, robbery and cruel treatment of Union prisoners. The prisoner made an affidavit denying the charges. His witnesses will be sent for.

A SEA CAPTAIN CHARGED WITH STEALING CARGO. In December last, WASHINGTON LIBBEY, a resident of Boston, chartered the schooner Iren Pecker, Capt. J. H. PHINNEY, to sail from this port to Brazos, Texas, for a cargo of wool. Capt. PHINNEY proceeded on his voyage, and received 375 bales of wool at Brazos, and set sail for New-York.

Not the least interesting of the various movements toward a greater freedom of thought in the Old World is that which makes itself visible from time to time within the pale of the English Established Church. Most of our readers are familiar with the attitude of Bishop COLENSO and others, who, ...

The Assembly, this morning, ordered to a third reading a bill appropriating seventy thousand dollars to the Soldiers' Home in Albany. This institution is located at the former Ira Harris United States General Hospital, and is furnished throughout with every convenience for receiving patients. It is now under the charge of that eminent physician, and thorough gentleman, Surgeon-General J. E. POMFRET.

The Aldermanic Committee having this matter under consideration, consisting of Messrs. LOEW, MCGONNIS and GEDNEY, met at 1 P. M. yesterday, Mr. LOEW in the chair. A considerable number of persons were present, who appeared to take great interest in the proceedinns of the Committee.

Last evening the members of the Twentysecond Regiment cave their ninth grand promenade concert, at the Regimental Armory, in Fourteenth. street. These agreeable and fashionable concerts are always a success, being quite the vogue among those residing on the West side of town. Last night,

THE AGE OF BRASS. -Figuratively speaking, and without any reference to a metallic currency, this is surely the age of brass. By order of one of the Treasury Clerks, and on that individual's own responsibility, the vignette of WASHINGTON was recently removed from the five-cent currency notes, and there was substitututed in place thereof the figure and counterfeit of the modest clerk himself.

On motion of Mr. Attorney-General Speed, Orlando M. Barnes, Esq., of Michigan, was admitted an attorney and counselor of this Court. No. 243-The Merced Mining Company, appellant, vs. Biddle Boggs. The motion to dismiss this cause was argued by Mr. Field in support thereof, and by Mr. Reverdy Johnson in opposition thereto.

The Academy of Music was well attended on Saturday, but the usual crowd was of course modified by the weather. Those who were present enjoyed an exceedingly agreeable performance of the charming comic opera "Don Pasquale." Mlle. BOSISIO was the Norma, and sang and acted much better than she has yet done.

A large gathering of Fenians, representing the Shawmut District, was held at headquarters in Hanover-street, Saturday evening, at which $.36,000 in bonds were taken. The meeting, in view of the aspect of affairs in Ireland, reconsidered the motion where by it was voted at a late meeting that the Brotherhood parade in a body on St. Patrick's Day, the money which would be expended on that occasion being required by the "men in the gap."

Among the many excellent recommendations in the Report of the Commissioners on the Internal Revenue, was one which has been almost passed over by the public: That the Secretary of the Treasury should on certain occasions present himself to the House of Representatives, and report in person, or answer such questions as may be put to him for any reasonable information in regard to his Bureau.

Interesting services were held in the Fifth-avenue Presbyterian Church, (Rev. Dr. RICE'S), last evening, on behalf of the New York City Mission and Tract Society. Rev. Dr. DEWITT opened the exercises. The opening prayer was offered by the Rev. Dr. DYER.

THE FENIANS.--The sagacity of the Fenian leaders of the O'MAHONEY faction was fully attested yesterday by the response to their call for what they termed an "aggregate" meeting on the Christian Sabbath at Jones' Woods. These shrewd gentlemen doubtless had well considered that the mass of Irish enthusiasts are so fully occupied on secular days in honest toil,

Notwithstanding the circular which the Archbishop of New-York sent to the clergy of the Roman Catholic Church on Saturday, and caused to be read in all the churches yesterday, admonishing Catholics, and counseling them to regard the mass meeting at Jones' Wood as " an open profanation of the Lord's day, an act of public scandal to religion, and an outrage to the feelings of all good Catholics, especially in this holy season of Lent,"

We are happy to inform our readers that the panic about houses and shops is over-for the present. A bill here and there appears now on some modest mansion bearing those almost forgotten words-" To Let." There is to be sure about the bill a timid air, as though it were a very shabby thing-in such a dreadful minority-but there the words are--" To Let ;"

Col. W. A. BROWNING, late Private Secretary to the President, died on Thursday last at Washington. Col. BROWNING was a native of Washington, and after spending several years in the West he returned as Secretary to Mr. JOHNSON when the latter was a Senator from Tennessee. He also held a position upon Mr. JOHNSON'S staff when the latter was Military Governor of Tennessee, accompanied him when he came to Washington as Vice-President, ...

The desirableness of a governmental deadlock is not affirmed in any quarter. They who most applaud the attitude of the Radicals, and most strenuously aid them by attacks upon the President, are constrained to acknowledge the difficulties which such an attitude entails, and the expediency of averting them if possible.

The annual meeting of the Board of Managers of the Nursery and Child's Hospital took place on Thursday morning at the Institution in Lexington. avenue. The Chair was occupied by Rev. Dr. JOHN COTTON SMITH, and addresses were delivered by that gentleman, and by Rev. Dr. WASHBURNE and Hon ERATUS BROOKS. The Secretary's report was read by Dr ELLIOTT, and the Treasurer's by Mrs. SALTUS..

A COLORED WOMAN STABBED.-SARAH ANN DESMOND, a colored woman, was stabbed in the side and wrist, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, while passing through Thomas-street. The assailant was not recognized. The injured woman was taken to the Filth Precinet Station-house, and her wounds were dressed by a surgeon, after which she returned home.

ADAMS.--On Sunday, March 4. GRACE ALLEN, oldest daughter of Walter W. and Cecelia C. K. Adams, in her 6th year. Funeral to take place from the residence of her parents. No. 196 Varick-st., on Thursday morning. March 6. at 11 o'clock. ?? New-Redford and Fall River papers please copy. BERRY.--In Brooklyn on Friday morning, March 2, MARTIN R. BERRY, in the 65th year of his age.

ALLEGED NOMINATION OF GEN. MEADE FOR GOVERNOR OF PENNSYLVANIA. The Copperhead organ of this city, TOM. FLORENCE'S Constitutional, Union, announces that Gen. MEADE has agreed to accept the Democratic nomination for Governor of Pennsylvania, and that he will be nominated by acclamation by that Convention which meets at Harrisburgh to-morrow.

The French brig St. Louis brings Yokohama dates of Jan. 31st and Hong Kong dates of Jan. 17th The Japanese steamer Fusiyama built in New-York had arrived at Yokohama. The supply of silk in Japan was inferior in quality and quantity. A great fire occurred in the suburbs of Yeddo on the 28th of January. Thirty persons perished in the flames.

MYSTERIOUS AFFAIR--A MAN FOUND BLEEDING AND INSENSIBLE IN HIS OWN STORE.--Between 6 and 7 o'clock on Saturday evening, a gentleman named GRAHAM, residing at No. 301 South Third-street, E. D., called at the jewelry store of WILLIAM COLLINS, No. 98 Fourth-street, and found that gentleman sitting down in a chair, bleeding from the mouth and ears, and quite insensible.

NAT. TYLER has withdrawn from his connecttion with the Richmond Enquirer. Possibly the newspaper world and the public in general will not agree with Mr. TYLER in their estimates of the importance of this event, and the reasons that he assigns for his action may not therefore be looked for so eagerly as he anticipates.

FIRE IN PEARL-STREET.-About 7 o'clock on Saturday evening a fire was discovered on the fifth floor of premises No. 328 Pearl-street, occupied as tenement building by some twenty-six families. The flames originated from a defect in a chimney five The building, owned by A. BLOODOOOD, is damaged to the extent of $1,600-insured. JOHN ORGANIOccupied the first floor as a liquor-store, and his family reside on the second floor. Loss $400.

In this part of the State everything is profoundly quiet Everyone has gone to work earnestly. All of the freed people have made contracts, and are now busy at work. I have employed between forty and fifty and have settled them off upon small places, ten or twelve upon a place--each place separate and distinct from the other.

Our special correspondent in Texas gives us, this morning, a plain, unvarnished and exceedingly minute history of the proceedings attending the organization of the Constitutional Convention of that State. It is most advisable that all the facts bearing upon the temper and the personnel of these Southern conventions should be thoroughly and frankly stated.

A Correspondent in Florence sends us the following description of a new group by BALL, the Sculptor, representing LINCOLN emancipating the slaves. "The idea is beautiful, and it is finely carried out.

The case of the Philadelphia and Eric and Pennsylvania Railroad Companies against the Atlantic and Great Western, the Westert Central and the Calawissa Railroad Companies, was decided yesterday by Justice READ, the Supreme Court., sitting in equity-all the chiet points at issue being determined against the defendants, and effectually stopping their operations looking to the opening of a new and more direct route from New-York to the West, through the interior of Ponnsylvania.

The steamship Costa Rica, Capt. BRADBURY, from Aspinwall Feb. 23, arrived at 2 o'clock this morning bringing important advices from central and South America. The Costa Rica brings 200 passedgers and the following amount of Specie:

The Tribune has thrown off the mask under which it has for some time assailed the President, and openly arraigns him on a charge of disloyalty to the Union Party, by whom he was elected. We fancy that our City cotemporary has discovered the futility and unprofitableness of its recent tactics.

The Committee on Lands and Places of the Board of Aldermen were yesterday directed to consider the advisability of changing the City Hall Park into an open, paved plaza. If this project should be decided upon, it would doubtless afford an opportunity for expending a large amount of the tax-payers' money;

Present-John Brice, Esq., President: Aldermen Norton McBrion, Flynn, Shannon, Gedney, Ely, Ryers, Reilly, toow, Masterson, Varnum, O'Brien, McGinnis. The minutes of February twenty-six were read and approved. PETITIONS. By Alderman Shannon Bill of Manahan's Band for one hundred and forty-four dollars, for music on Fourth of July. Which was referred to the Committee on Finance.

COL. J. H. SIMPSON.--The Omaha Herald, in speaking of the President of the Board of Commissioners in the Union Pacific Railroad Company, pays the following compliment to Col. SIMPSON, an old and highly respected officer of the regular service: He served in Florida during the Seminole war, and in Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee during the Creek and Cherokee removals.

The robberies and murderous outrages which were so frequent in and around Brownsville previous to and at the time of my arrival, have perceptibly abated, the military have come to the aid of the civil authorities, and the town being now patrolled nightly.

JOHN WASPOM, President, and A. T. SMITH, Secretary, of the Southern Pacific Railroad, are expected here from Texas during the week, and a general meeting of the stockholders of the road will take place during the present month. Direct railroad communication between here and Memphis will be rapidly completed, the Louisville and Nashville Railroad having loaned the Memphis, Clarksville and Louisville Railroad $300,000 for that purpose.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. MORGAN introduced a resolution of inquiry into the alleged kidnapping of colored persons and their sale as slaves. The bill relative to the new site for the New-York City Post-office was reported back with an amendment, adding to the Commission the names of CHARLES N. RUSSELL and MOSES TAYLOR.

The recent mild weather, although there was a cold change yesterday, which, however, cannot last long, has had its effect on the ice in the Hudson. Dense fogs, a muggy atmosphere and southerly winds have so cut the ice that even the present cold snap cannot delay the speedy opening of navigation.

The other day, when the President made an informal speech to some of his neighbors, New-York was flooded with Washington telegrams, announcing a terrible party earthquake. Sensible men had met here on that occasion (the 22d of February) to give a formal public expression to their thorough confidence in the President and his policy.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, President BRICE in the Chair. Mr. ELY offered a resolution, which was adopted, requesting the Committee on Lands and Places to report on the advisability of paving the entire area of the City Hall Park and making it an open plaza.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--" II Trovatore" was given last evening to a good, but not crowded attendance. To-night Signor MAZZOLENI, an artist who is esteemed highly, and rightly so, by the public, will take his benefit. The opera is MEYERBEER'S "African," in which this fine singer and actor is heard and seen to the best advantage. We trust that the atiendance will be all that Signor MAZZOLENI could degire.

Brief mention was made in yesterday's TIMES of an extensive conflagration in Bridge-street, but the lateness of the hour at which the fire occurred did not permit of any extended account. The fire originated in the large storage warehouse of EDWARD C. JOHNSTON Co. at No. 4 Bridge-street, and ran through the block to Pearl-street, at No. 7.

WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.--We have to apologize to at least one of the Inspectors of weights and measures in this city for having assumed that these officials were not sufficiently active in the discharge of their duties. A singular case came to our knowledge, which leads us to a contrary belief.

In the municipal election to-day all the wards except one gave 737 Republican majority, against 578 on the annual vote last year, showing a Republican gain of about 200. A. E. STEVENS is the Mayor-elect. SECOND DISPATCH. PORTLAND, Monday, March 5. At the Charter election to-day AUGUSTUS E. STEVENS was elected Mayor.

ALLEN.-In Brooklyn, on Monday, March 5, R. JOSEPHINE, wife of Frank H. Allen. The funeral will take place on Thursday, the 8th inst., at 2 P. M., from the residence of deceased's father, Thos. Cornwell, Hanson-place, fifth door above Ethott-place, Brooklyn. ADAMS.--On Sunday, March 4, GRACE ALLEN, oldest daughter of Walter W. and Cecelia C. K. Adamus, in her 6th year.

To the Etitor of the New-York Times: Being a reader of your valuable and independent paper for twelve years, I would take the liberty of requesting a few lines in regard to the New Courthouse now in process of erection in the City Hall Park.

Mr. LABAU gave notice of a bill to incorporate the Thirty-fourth-street Metropolitan Market Association. Mr. BENNETT introduced a bill to release the Female Institute of Buffalo from taxation; also, to incorporate the Buffalo Franciscan Hospital.

Of the unnumbered plans for a passenger railroad of some kind in Broadway which have boon committed to paper since the present Legislaturo organized, that of HOH. MARCUS D. MOORE, of Kings County, is conspicuous, aspresenting many advantages superior to other projects, in the opinion of many Broadway landlords and storekeepers, on grounds of cheapness, ornament and utility.

LETTERS OF LIFE. By Mrs. L. H. SIGOURNEY. Post Svo. New-York: D. APPLETON Co. This handsome volume is an autobiography of the authoress addressed in the form of letters to her cherished friend, Mrs. CAROLINE WASHBURN, at whose suggestion they were commenced, and to whom the work, completed by a sketch of Mrs. SIGOURNEY'S last days, is dedicated by her daughter.

He said:

EDWARD NEWMEISTER and E. H. JONNSTON, two of the five thieves who robbed the U. S. Express messenger here two weeks ago, have been arrested, and $19,214 recovered. The remainder of the $49,000 stolen is supposed to be in the possession of the other three robbers, who are still at large.

The Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, President GREEN in the Chair. Mr. WATTS offered a resolution to the effect that hereafter eight hours should constitute a day's labor for all mechanics and laborers employed by the Corporation. It was referred to the Committee on Salaries and Offices.

The Democratic State Convention met this afternoon. Hon. W. HOPKINS, of Washington County, was elected permanent President. He spoke of the favorable prospects of the Democratic Party in influencing a speedy restoration of the Union, and opposing the doctrine of negro equality, which had become a characteristic feature of the Republican Party.

THE FARE ON THE CITY CARS.--Judge DALY, of the Court of Common Pleas, decided yesterday that the charge of six cents by the city railroads, imposed ostensibly to cover the government tax, is illegal. If this decision should be sustained, on. appeal, the railroad companies will suffer badly.

The Vice-President laid before the Senate the petition of a citizen of Columbia, S. C., 98 years ot age, who sets forth that his entire property, valued at $10,000, was destroyed by fire by Federal troops last Winter; that he has always been a loyal man, and asking indemnity from Congress. Referred to the Committee on Claims.

The steamer Crusader, from Jamaica, Port-auPrince and Turks Island, arrived here this morning. Jamaica papers of Feb. 19 are received. A deputation of prominent mon waited on Gen. O'CONNER and expressed their thanks for his energetic measures In aid of Gov. EYEE in suppressing the late rebellion. Admiral HOPE would remain on the Jamaica station as long as the Royal Commission of Investigation should sit.

TENNESSEE. The report and joint resolution in relation to the admission of Tennessee from the Committee on Reconstruction to-day, were accompanied by various papers, including the memorial of Representatives elect COOPER, LEFTWICE, STOKES and MAYNARD, of that State, addressed to the Senate and House of Representatives, in which they say the government of Tennessee is republican in form,

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. RAMSAY introduced a joint resolution for the establishment of quarantine regulations to prevent the spread of cholera. Mr. MORRILL reported a bill to establish telegraphic communication between Now-York and the West Indies. The bill to reimburse the State of Missouri for expenses in equipping and paying the militia of that State was passed.

Col. BOWERS, Adjutant-General on Gen. GRANT'S Staff, was killed instantly by falling between the cars while attempting to get on the train just as it was starting from this station, of the Hudson River Railroad, this afternoon. Gen. GRANT has ordered his remains to be sent to West Point, in care of Major HILL.

The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Present--Councilman Keenan, Long, Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, O'Brien, Kenney, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Koech, White, Mackay, Kellogg. Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Roberts, Pullman, Hettrick, Finlay-24.

FIRE IN BANK-STREET.--At 11:50 last evening Officer CHESTERFIELD, of the Ninth Precinct, discovered a fire in the rear of the kindling-wood yard of JOHN H. HESSMAN, in Bank-street, near West, which, though quickly extinguished, resulted in a loss of $1,500 on the buildings and stock.

ALLEN.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, March 5, R. JOSEPHINE, wife of Frank H. Allen. aged 21 years, 1 month and 4 days. The funeral will take place on Thursday, the 8th inst., at 2. P. M., from the residence of deceased's father. Thos. Cornwell. Hanson--place, fifth door above Elliott-place, Brooklyn.

The Canadian Minister of Finance has availed himself of a political banquet to explain and vindicate to his countrymen the course which he and his co-delegates pursued in the recent negotiations at Washington. Some of his remarks possess an interest beyond the Province, as serving to indicate the grounds on which the proposition submitted

The Tribune quotes conspicuously the testimony of Major-Gen. THOMAS before the Reconstruction Committee, so far as it refers to the alleged disposition of the "rebels of the South" to "embarrass the Government in its administration, as much as they can, so as to gain as many advantages for themselves a possible ;"

GOV. FLETCHER has signed the bill which recently passed the Missouri Legislature providing for the consolidation and payment of the bonded debt of the State. By the provisions of this bill all over due interest is to be funded and incorporated with the principal in new bonds, and the payment of the interest is to be resumed on the 1st of January, 1868. The bonded debt of Missouri, including unpaid interest, amounts to $30,000,000.

He must take his stand with one or the other, helping to fight its battles and sharing its prosperous or adverse fortunes. If his heart is with the Union Party,

SHALL AND WILL.--Is it not about time that orators and writers who maltreat the unfortunate words "shall" and "will" took some pity upon then? The public oontinrally hear such phrases as "I will be" doing this, that or the other, or "I will be" happy, miserable, or what not else, when the meaning sought to be conveyed is that he or she " shall" be.

"THE MISSIONARY LINK."--A little magazine with this title lies on our table. The name has all the charm of brevity; but can anybody enlighten us as to its significance? A trifling philologist suggests that it is an abbreviated reference to the name, and in honor of " our late lamented President "

A NEW PARTY.--Colorado JEWETT is out in a Cincinnati paper in support of President JOHNSON, his veto, and his policy, though believing that it will be necessary, in the end, to admit the blacks to equal rights with other poople.-Tribune.

The Navy Register for 1866, just published, gives the following particulars of the reduction of our naval force: Since the close of the war 255 vessels have been disposed of by sale, and 13 have been lost. The number of vessels retained in the service is 318, of which 73 are laid up in ordinary, 63 are building at the different navy-yards, 14 are fitting out for sea service, 35 are under repair,

THE MYSTERIOUS ASSAULT IN BROOKLYN.-The attack made upon a Brooklyn jeweler. who was struck down in his own store, which was afterward found to have been robbed, and all in broad daylight, is a fearful comment upon the desperate character of the thieves in our midst. The facts at present known warrant the inference that murder was intended.

THOSE STATUES AGAIN.--The Aldermen of our City seem determined to patronize the arts. They have again considered and referred to their Committee of Arts and Sciences the proposition, vetoed by the Mayor last December, to set apart two pieces of ground in Thirty-second and Thirty-fifth streets for statues of FULTON and MORSE.

At the charter election to-day, FOWLER, Republican, was elected Mayor by about 400 majority. UTICA, Tuesday, March 6. At the Charter election to-day, Col. JAMES McQUADE, Republican, was elected Mayor by 46 majority. The rest of the Democratic city ticket was elected. Four Republicans and three Democratic Aldermen were also elected.

In the Senate to-night Mr. FOLGER reported from the Judiciary Committee, that Judge GEORGE W. SMITH, of Oneida County, against whom charges of official corruption have been made, had elected to be tried by the whole Senate. The Committee was therefore discharged. The Judge will be tried before the Senate in a few days. The trial is likely to occupy a considerable time,

HEAVY COTTON MOVEMENTS.--The exports of Cotton from the Port of New-York, during the week ending last evening, reached the unusual quantity of 17,442 bales, valued at $3,678,371, or equal to about two hundred and eleven dollars per bale. Included in the exports were 12.039 bales, valued at $2,462,659. to the single port of Liverpool.

The steamer Lockwood blew up and was burned last night about eighteen miles below here. There were twenty killed and twenty-five injured. She is valued at $60,000, and not insured. The names of the killed and wounded are not known yet.

THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY.--A stated meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held in the hall of the Society last evening. Mr. GEORGE MOORE read a very interesting paper on "North American Rock Writing and other Aboriginal Inscriptions," prepared by the Hon. THOMAS EWBANK, late Commissioner of Patents.

Brownsville dates of the 28th ult. are received. Major-Gen. GETTY had assumed command of the Rio Grande District, vice Col. BROWS. Military matters remained quiet on the Rio Grande. CORTINAS is lurking about some twelve miles above Matamoras on the Mexican side. The death of the Liberal Chief MENDEZ, from wounds in taking the Rancho de Tanquito, is confirmed.

The overland mail, with New-York dates to Feb. 8, has arrived. Mining stocks are still improving. Ophir, $600; Savage, $995. Chollar Potosi, $372 50; Imperial, $137; Crown Point, $1,240; Yellow Jacket, $455. Legal tenders, 731/2@74.

PROVISIONAL GOVERNORS-MESSAGE FROM THE PRESIDENT. The following message was received by the House to-day: To the House of Representatives: In answer to the resolution of the House of Representatives of the 12th of January last,
The steamer Diamond, laden with 820 bales of cotton, was burned at Gulf Landing, on the Tombigbee River, on last Thursday. The cotton was insured. The boat was valued at $20,000, and not insured.

There seems to be considerable misapprehension in the public mind growing out of the late decision of Judge DALY on the right of the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company to add one cent to the rate of fare fixed in its charter, as granted by the Common Council.

BILLS REPORTED. Authorizing the construction of a basin at Wallabout Bay, Brooklyn. To incorporate the San Souci Building Association. To discontinue Ninety. ninth, One Hundredth and One Hundred and First streets, between Third and Fourth avenues, Authorizing the Comptroller of New-York to borrow money for the Fire Department purposes.

The Texas State Convention still continues in session. The Committee on the condition of the State reported adversely on the ordinance for the protection and encouragement of manufacturers, declaring that it was a proper subject for the action of the Legislature.

The steamer City of New-York, from Southampton via Queenstown, arrived at this port last evening, with four days later advices. The suspension of habeas corpus in Ireland caused the greatest consternation among the Fenians, and a grand stampede for England at once took place, especially among the American sympathizers and abettors of the agitation.

We venture to think that if the labors of the Reconstruction Committee, thus far, have not given very general satisfaction at home, they have been estimated at their just value abroad. There has not been a single step taken by that Committee, hitherto, that has not afforded supreme gratification to the GREGORYS, the ROEBUCKS and the LAIRDS of the House of Commons.

The accounts received here from Mexico are to the 18th and 22d ult., the former being the latest date from the Capital, Mexico City, and the latter from Vera Cruz. According to these, the Liberals had been defeated at Tehuantepec by Gen. PRIETO. They amounted to 2,000 in number, and had more than 100 killed, besides losing a large number of muskets.

In addition to the brief dispatch from the Agent of the Associated Press at Poughkeepsie, we this morning give the particulars of the deplorable accident to Gen. T. S. BOWERS, Assistant AdjutantGeneral to Gen. GRANT.

The Union members of the Senate and Assmbly held a joint cauous to-night to consider the policy to be pursued in reference to the passage of resolutions on national affairs. Senator GODDARD was called to the chair. Sixteen Senators and sixty-six members of Assembly wore present. Mr. Low said the time bad arrived for an expression of opinion on the affairs of the nation.
