The Inman steamer City of New-York, which left Liverpool at noon on the 21st, and Queenstown on the 22d February, arrived here last evening. The Tarifa arrived at Liverpool on the evening of the 20th February. The Hiberman arrived off Londonderry at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 21st.
PETITIONS. Mr. SUMNER introduced a petition for an International Copy-right Law, which was referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

The Board met in their chamber, No. 17 City Hall, pursuant to the following call: Present--Henry Smith, Esq., President, and the following members: Supervisors Blunt, Bleakley. Ely, Fox, Hayes, Roche, Shook, Stewart, Tw ed and Willmann--11.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S delightful comic opera of "Don Pasquale" was given here last evening. The house was but poorly attended, owing, we suppose, to the almost unbearable state of the weather. Those who braved the gale were rewarded with a fine performance of a seldom-heard, but moat enjoyable work.
The river here has been rising all day. The water this evening is eight feet deep on Harpeth Shoals. A negro named NELSON WRIGHT was arrested to-day on the charge of murder.
The Fomento newspaper, of Porto Rico, copies a report from the Panama Star Herald, to the following effect:

ALLEN.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, March 5, R. JOSEPHINE, wife of Frank H. Allen aged 21 years, 1 month and 4 days. The funeral will take place on Thursday, the 8th inst., at 2 P.M., from the residence of deceased's father, Thos. Cornwell, Hanson-place, fifth door above Elliott-place. Brooklyn.

THE AMENDMENT--MR. SUMNER'S SPEECH. At 1 o'clock to-day the Senate resumed the consideration of the Reconstruction Committee's constitutional amendment as to representation, Mr. SUMNER having the floor. The speech of the Senator from Massachusetts was a literary production fully up to his own standard.

The Republican State Convention assembled in the House of Representatives at 12 o'clock noon, and was called to order by Hon. JOHN CESSNA, Chairman of the State Central Committee. LEWIS W. HALL, of Huntington, was declared elected temporary Chairman.

The Flag has advices from Fort Masda, NewMexico, stating that the Imperial 'Commander at Magdalena, Lonora, with a band of Indians, seized a freight train belonging to American citizens, and prohibited further transportation by American citizens.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. GREEN in the chair. A resolution was presented by Mr. ROBINSON, authorizing the Comptroller to sell at public auction, for a term of ten years, the lease of the right to run a ferry from the toot of Spring-street to Hoboken. It was laid over.

At the third session of the Board of Health, President SCHULTZ in the chair, the following amendment of the Health Act was ordered to be engrossed and forwarded to the Legislature, with a recommendation that it pass: "Any action brought by authority of the Metropolitan Health Act may be brought in any Court in said district having jurisdiction in any civil action to any amount as large as is demanded in such action:

Present--Henry Smith, Esq., President, and the following members: Supervisors Blunt. Bleakly, Ely, Fox, Hayes, Roche, Stewart, Tweed, Willmenn-10. The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, No. 17 /City Hall. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

In the absence of President McLEAN, the Clerk of the Board called the Commissioners to order, and Mr. S. B. H. VANCE was chosen President for the time. Communications were received from the Trustees of several Wards, on matters relating to school edifices, repairs, releasing, and the like.

That arrangements are under contemplation for the withdrawal of the Emperor NAPOLEON'S Expeditionary and Interventional Corps from this country, is very apparent. How the troops are going, when will be their time of departure, what will be their conduct on leaving, or who shall assume governmental power, has not in a single instance, to the writer's knowledge, been the subject of discussion.

INCENDIARY FIRES.--On Tuesday night two frame dwellings, in course of erection by HARVEY BRUNDAGE, in Lorimer-street, between Ainslie and Power, E. D., were red and damaged to the extent of about $1,600; insured in the Williamsburgh City Insurance Company.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S grand romantic opera of "L'Etolle du Nord" will be revived here to-night. It has not been played since 1856, when it made a tremendous success. We anticipate for it a similar reception. In general variety of the action and pecular coloring of the music, it is, we think, the best work of the maestro. The caste tonight is unexceptionable, and the rehearsals warrant the prediction that the opera will be given unexceptionably.

An effort was made in the Texas State Convention to-day to base representation in the Legislature on the number of free persons in the State, but it failed. The Committee on Legislative Department expressed unqualified opposition to negro suffrage. Provision was made for the election of State officers shot as soon as practicable.

DEWEY--BROOK.--On Wednesday, March 7, at the Church of the Intercession, by Rev. J. Howard Smith, HENRY DEWEY of Bennington, Vt., and M. ELIZABETH BROCK, of New-York. DE HART--SPEIR.--On Thursday, March 8, by Rev. J. S. Holme. W. H. DE HART, U. S. N., and AGNES A., daughter of John Speir, Esq., of Brooklyn.

The steamships Java and Borussia arrived at this port yesterday, bringing European advices to the 25th ult. Important debates took place in the British House of Commons on the 23d ult. on the neutrality question and the subject of Fenianism in America.

SANITARY MEASURES FOR HUDSON COUNTY.-Since the passage of the Metropolitan Health Bill, the enforcement of which will cause to be banished from its purlieus such establishments as may be deemed detrimental to health, the people of Hudson County have become fearful that many of the slaughter-pens, bone-boiling and other establishments may be removed to localities within the county, and thus imperil the health of its inhabitants.

The Royal mail steamer Java, Capt. MOODIE which left Liverpool at 2:30 on the afternoon of the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th February, arrived here yesterday morning. The steamship Borussia, from Southampton on the 20th of February, also arrived yesterday. The Mexican, from Mobile, arrived at Liverpool Feb. 18. The New-York arrived at Southampton on the morning of the 22d.

The free exhibition of French and Flemish paintings in the old Dusseldorf Gallery during the past two weeks, attracted many visitors. who lingered amongst the unusually choice collection with much pleasure. The works of one hundred and thirty-five artosts. each of more than passing merit and some of them world. famous.

About 7 o'clock on the evening of Wednesday the dead body of an unknown man was found, by the Twenty-third Precinct Police, lying in a small creek near the corner of One Hundredth-street and Secondavenue. When discovered, the body was quite lifeless, and the deceased had evidently been shot through the head with a pistol.

In the Senate, this evening, able speeches on national affairs were made by Messrs. GIBSON and ANDREWS. The House witnessed a most exciting political debate on the Senate resolutions which were substituted for those previously offered by Mr. TREMAINE. Messrs. ANDERSON and MILLSPAUGH made spirited Democratic speeches in opposition to the resolutions.

Last evening an attempt was made to burn the house of Mrs. HYZER on Atwater-street. During the absence of Mrs. HYZER from the house, the clothes in a cradle in which a child three years old was sleeping, were set on fire. The house had previously been ransacked by some person who evidently expected to obtain a considerable amount of money which Mrs. HYZER was known to have received within a day or two.

Representative BOUTWELL, of Massachusetts, to-day made a report from the Committee on Reconstruction, signed by himself and Representative WASHBURNE, of Illinois, in which they state that the colored people of Tennessee are undoubtedly loyal, and one-half of the white people disloyal. East Tennessee is strongly loyal, and Middle and Western Tennessee disloyal.

AN UNNECESSARY AND CRUEL HARDSHIP.--The public sensibility has been outraged for several days past by the evidence of official neglect of a shameful and inexcusable character. The semi-annual pension to crippled soldiers and to the widows and orphans of the dead is now being paid in one of the small rooms in the Custom House.

Our usually dull city is all at once wide awake, and the centres of news, around Place d'Armes and Great St. James-street, are in a great bustle. The principal hotels are as lively as any of your Broadway caravanseries, and for once the sleepy old capital of Canada is tolerably well aroused.

The fact that Congress has, ever since this session commenced, been almost exclusively occupied in the discussion of the varied phases of the various questions appertaining to political reconstruction, has unquestionably saved us from much other foolish, irritating and perilous talk upon other subjects that it is very important should not be foolishly agitated-especially at the present time.

The following States were represented at the meeting of the Antietam National Cemetery, held at Baltimore to-day: AUGUSTIN BRIGGS, President; Thomas A. Boult, Secretary; Charles C. Fulton, Trustee for Maryland; Gen. E. Shriver, Trustee for Maryland; Hon. James G. Blaine, Trustee for Maine; Henry Edwards, for Massachusetts; M. Yates Selleck, for Wisconsin; G. L. Cramner, for West Virginia.

Concerning the Revenue agency of the Internal Revenue Department in this City there is but little general knowledge, and yet its workings have benefitted the Government and hence the country during the year and a half of its existence to an extent bepend computation.

The Senate did not come to a vote upon the joint resolution to amend the Constitution as to representation, as was expected this afternoon, but it was arranged that at 3 o'clock P. M. to-morrow, the vote shall be taken. The discussion to-day did not develop any new phase.

A difficulty occurred about 2 o'clock yesterday morning in the bar-room of a drinking-saloon at No. 9 James-slip, familiarly known as Slaughterhouse Point, between a barkeep named PETER O'NEILL and RICHARD O'SULLIVAN, a customer of the house.

The funeral of CoL J. T. BOWERS, late Adjutant-General on the staff of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, who was killed by falling off the down train on the Hudson River Railroad at Garrison's Station, on last Tuesday evening, took place at the Military Academy at West Point yesterday afternoon.

Mr. VAN WINKLE introduced the joint resolution of the West Virginia Legislature, asking Congress to make an appropriation to reimburse that State for expenses incurred in equipping and paying the militia during the war. It was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Officer BENDON, of the Fifteenth Precinct, arrested ELLEN LAUGHLIN yesterday morning for violating a City ordinance, in throwing into Clintonplace a pail of garbage, thereby endangering the health of the neighborhood. The arrest was made in accordance with instructions from the Metropolitan Board of Health, The accused was committed to answer the charge at the Court of Special Sessions, in default of $200 bail.

The Boston Herald has a long account of the discovery of the murderer of the two JOYCE children, ISABELLA N. and JOHN S. JOYCE, in Bussey's woods, West Roxbury, on the 12th of June, 1865. He was found to be a convict in the State Prison who had been Bent there for a burglary committed in Worcester County shortly after the murder.

The inquest on the body of the unknown man, which was found in a creek near One Hundred and Tenth-street. was held, yesterday, by Coroner COLLIN. THE APPROACH OF CHOLERA.--We observe a statement that a quarantine of twenty-five days has been established, by military order, at New-Orleans, in respect to all vessels from the West Indies. A quarantine has also been established at the Texan ports. We see no reason to doubt the necessity for the action.

THE CIVIL RIGHTS BILL. The House proceedings to-day were confined to the consideration of the Civil Rights Bill and the Reciprocity Bill, the first being recommitted to the Judiciary Committee and the latter going over for future debate. The discussion upon the Civil Rights Bill was of unusual interest, and was participated in by those among the most learned and talented members of the House, Messrs.

WILLIAM H. CANNON, aged 18, who was for some time in the employ of Messrs. JONES, SMITH SHEPPARD, of No. 11 Murray-St., as errand boy, was discharged recently. Soon after he and others arranged a plan ?? the firm, whose employ he had but just left.

Mr. GIDEON J. TUCKER this morning introduced a bill for the better protection of sick and infirm indigent passengers arriving at the port of NewYork, which is in response to resolutions of the Common Council of the City of New-York. It provides that it shall be the duty of all captains, owners, agents and consignees of vessels arriving at said port, having as a passenger any lunatic. idiot, deaf, dumb,

BEL--DENNISTON.--On Monday, March 5, at Bethlehem Orange County, by Rev. R. H. Beattie, CLARENOE H. BELL, of Boston. Mass., and SARA E., daughter of John W. Denniston, Esq. of Bethlehem. DAVIS--PEARCE--On Wednesday, March 7, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Augustus Woodbury, ALEX. H. DAVIs, of Syracuse, N. Y., and JULIA B., daughter of Edward Pearce, of Providence. R. I.

On Thursday morning last the hotel of Mr. JOHN FORREST, corner of Pacific and Boerum street, Brooklyn, was burglariously entered by some villains of the most desperate character. They entered by scaling a very high board fence and springing open one of the windows of the cellar. Having succeeded in effecting an entrance, they went up into the bar-room-robbed the till of the small change left in it, not exceeding $5.

A telegram sent by Capt. HUNTER, from Granada, Missouri, to Gov. BROWNLOW, urging the latter to beware of assassination, is believed to be a canard for political purposes. EDWARD RYAN,.formerly of La Salle, Illinois, committed suicideto-day by shooting himself, near the Chattanooga Depot.

ARMSTRONG.--At North hempstead, Queens County. on Friday, March 9, DEBORAH AEMSTRONG, aged 69 years and 5 months, The friends and relatives of the deceased are invited to attend her funeral on Sunday. the 11th inst., at 1 P. M., from her late residence, and at 2 P. M. from the Presbyterian Church Hempstead. BULL.--Suddenly on Thursday evening, March 8, ALICE. daughter of the late Frederick G. Bull.

In the Senate Mr. TRUMBULL offered a resolution of inquiry in regard to the Rock Island Arsenal. The bill extending the time for the withdrawal of goods from publicstores was taken up and opposed by Mr. SPRAGUE. The consideration of the Constitutional Amendment on representation being resumed, Mr. FESSENDEN addressed the Senate in support of the bill. Mr. SUMNER replied to Mr. FESSENDEN,

Since the adoption of the law creating a new Board of Health we have been literally deluged with communications touching its functions and duties, and more than half these documents have been formal complaints against the new Commissioners for neglect.

Spotted Tail, chief of the Beulah band of Sioux, came here to-day, and was received by Col. MAYNADIER with great ceremony. Spotted Tail came here to bring the dead body of his daughter, which was interred at the cemetery at this point with Christian rites, the Chaplain performing the burial service.

UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT. John A. Blanchard, Appellant vs. Nathaniel J. Brown, Administrator, , et al.--It is claimed in this case that in August, 1845, Nathaniel J. Brown was the owner in fee of a portion of block 12, in the "School section addition" to Chicago, in Cook County, III.: that various judgments were recovered against him in 1846, and became liens upon the premises.

THE ROCK ISLAND ARSENAL. Mr. TRUMBULL offered the following resolution, which was adopted: Resolved That the Secretary of War be directed to inform the Senate what legislation is necessary to fix and establish the position of the Chicago and Rook Island Railroad and bridges at Rook Island Arsenal, so as to accord with the purposes of the Government in its occupancy of said island for military purposes;

COLUMBIA COLLEGE LAW SCHOOL.--The graduating lass' of the Columbia College Law School have made choice, after a spirited canvass, of Mr. E. B. CONVERSE, of Zaneaville, to be valedictorian, and Mr.-- RICHARDS to be alumni orator. These class elections are usually rather excited affairs, and this one probably not the least so of any that have been made in the institution designated.

Up here in the woods we begin to feel the tea-pot tempest that seems to be disturbing your mercurial people. You already know that the Government has ordered out a large force to defend, if need be, the New-York and Michigan borders-that arms are glistening in the pale March sun, and bright uniforms are astounding the urchins of all our great towns.

The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: PCouncilmen Keenan, Long. Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, O'Brien, Kenney, Cosiello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Koech, Mackay, Kellogg. Thomas, Halloran, Roberts, Pullman, Hettrick, Finlay--22.

On Tuesday afternoon last, the brig Catharine Rogers, Capt. SEATON, for Providence, R. I, with 290 tons of coal, from Elizabethport, N. J., went ashore in a gale on the Cornfield Point Shoals, of Westbrook, and sunk. The captain and crew were saved by heroic efforts on the part of Capt. MANWARRING and his men, of the Government light-boat, stationed on the shoals above-named.

The demurrer of Col. THOMASTON of the Freedmen's Bureau, in the case of MARTH and HEPWELL, two Lieutenants of the Police, has been sustained: that in the case of MILLS has been overruled. J udgment was reserved until the next term. A party of eight discharged colored soldiers went aboard the steamer Arcola for St. Louis, and claimed cabin passage, which the clerk refused.

A large mass meeting was held at Norfolk night before last; for the purpose of giving the citizens, and especially those who have been in the rebel service, an opportunity of expressing their sentiments relative to the important questions of the day. The meeting was addressed by Mayor TABB and several prominent citizens, and a series of resolutions unanimously adopted.

Our Northern neighbors are apparently enoying the unusual luxury of a sensation in their dull Winter months. It is nearly thirty years since they had anything like it. They evidently imagine that the Fenians, in a body, are after them with sharp sticks; and twenty or thirty of their stalwart yeomanry have been put under arms to meet any possible emergency.

ANOTHER CASE OF INFANTICIDE.-A domestic named ANNA KIERNAN, in the employ of Mrs. MARY BOYD, residing at No. 190 East Tenth-street, discovered, yesterday morning, the remains of an infant male child, wrapped up in a blanket, and lying in the water-closet attached to the dwelling. Officer LONG, of the Seventeenth Precinct, was called in, and he removed the remains to the station-house.

BURR.--On Saturday, March 10, at St. James Hotel, EDWIN BURR, Esq., counseller-at-law, aged 58 years. The funeral services will take place at the University place Church, corner of 10th-st., (Rev. Dr. Kellogg,) on Tuesday at 1 o'clock P.M. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend without further notice. HARRISON.--Suddenly, on Saturday, March 10, EDWARD C. HARRISON, in the 70th year of his age.

The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House the day was given up to speeches, and those of no particular moment. Mr. STEVENS occupied a large portion of the time in an effort to be unusually sarcastic and amusing, with what success may be gathered from a perusal of our usual report,

ODD.-ROEBUCK, as we learn by our foreign advices, lately asserted, from his seat in the House of Commons, that there was as yet no reunion between the North and South, and he amiably expressed the wish that complete reconciliation might never take place.

The Thirty-second Collection District has been web named the Metropolitan District of the country. Embracing the First, Second and Fourth Wards of the City, it has within its borders the great moneyed institutions of the land, the many hundred brokers and bankers who deal in gold and silver and precious bonds, the newspaper Press, over whose hundreds of thousands of impressions it has no control,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Political reconstruction is one thing, and a very important one. The South having yielded to their destiny and acknowledged their allegiance to the Government, are knocking at the door for readmission to their former privileges as constituent parts of the great whole.

BEFORE COMMISSIONERS ACTON AND MANIERRE. Commissioner B. F. MANIERRE took his seat in Trial Chamber on Wednesday. The trials, of which there were sixty-two, were refreshing in a reportorial point of view, there having been several cases which were highly sensational; several that had manifestly been arranged in advance with a view to creating an impression on the Commissioners' minds;...

A GOOD CHANCE FOR ASSAULT.-A Western paper makes what it evidently considers a strong point against the President, in saying that a delegation of "leading Democrats recently went to Washington to assure him of their support." Unfortunately, however, for its point, it gives the names of the "leading Democrats " whom it accuses of this rascality-foremost among which is that of Gen.

Tile House sat to-day as in Committee of the Whole, nothing being in order but general debate on the President's message. The attendance of members was small, but the galleries were well filled. Mr. ORTH, of Indiana, addressed the House. He defended Congress from the charge of dilatoriness in legislation.

RESOLUTIONS ADOPTED. The following are the resolutions adopted by the Pennsylvania Union State Convention: Resolved, That this Convention, representing the Union-loving and loyal people of Pennsylvania, who never despaired of the Republic, and who poured out millions of treasure, and devoted yet more precious blood for the rescue of their country from the felonions attacks of a wicked and causeless rebellion;

Mr. HOSKINS, from the Committee on Federal Relations, reported against the resolution offered by Mr. LYONS, instructing our Senators and Representatives in Congress to pass a law restricting the hours of labor of Government employees to eight hours a day. Messrs. CUBTISS and MILLSPAUGH dissented from the report.

At the mass meeting of the Fouian Brotherhood, on Friday evening, it given unanimously resolved that no patronage should be given by members of the Order to any tradesman or other person who omits to purchase the bonds of the Irish Republic. Of course this is a matter of private option, and concerns only those merchants who may elect to procure or retain their customers in this way.

The debates in the British House of Commons upon the inefficiency of the neutrality laws and the relations of this country toward the Fenians have a certain significance when considered together. In the early period of our war many farseeing English statesmen predicted that the course taken by their Government in respect to the fitting out of privateers was sure to cause future trouble.

While a party of boys were playing, during Wednesday afternoon, on the low ground near the creek where the body of the unknown man was found on Wednesday night last, near One Hundredth-street and Second-avenue, one of them, named HENRY HALLETT, son of the Superintendent of the House of Refuge, found a large Colt's revolver, navy size, lying in the water near the spot where the body was discovered lying.

THE RIGHTS OF ANIMALS. -We do not suppose there can be any opposition to the passage through the Legislature of the bill now pending for the incorporation of the " Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals." Every one is aware of the beneficent labors of the London association which has this character and name;

The ante--equinoctial gale of the past four days has been an especially unwelcome visitor in this Lenten season. The supply of fish this week has been much below the average, and some confusion and considerable increase in prices have been the result. Dealers are prompt to take advantage of all changes of the weather favorable to high prices--the philanthrysic fishmongers of Fulton and Washington markets not excepted.

The Trustees of the Rutgers College, NewBrunswick, N. J., have established a department of the College under the name of the Rutgers Scientific School, for the education of a certain number of young men, gratuitously, who live in the State of New-Jersey, and such students as are desirous to pursue the three years' course of study marked out in this institution.

DEATH OF ALEXANDER CAMPBELL. The famous ALEXANDER CAMBELL, of West Virginia, died at his home in Bethany on Sunday night, March 4, aged 78. He was a native of Scotland, but came early to this country, and was originally a Presbyterian minister until 1812, when he became a Baptist.

THE OHIO PRESS AND THE PRESIDENT.--A Cleveland Radical organ makes out a list of little rural sheets published at various blacksmith's shops in Ohio, which oppose the policy of the President, and over against this makes out a shorter list of Republican journals in the same State which sustain the President.

The San Autonio Herald says: "A scouting party of fitty men of the Eighteenth New-York Cavalry, which left San Antonio on the 20th January, had just returned, after traversing all the section of country between the Leas and Leona Rivers. They report the Indians divided small parties. An old man named BUCKLEW was shot and killed by the Indians while traveling in his wagon:

IN BROADWAY. About 10:30 o'clock last night a fire was discovered on the fourth story of No. 262 Broadway, near the corner of Warren-street, in the premises occupied by SAMUEL FRIEND, manufacturing jewe1er, and resulted in burning out nearly the entire four floors and a portion of the roof. The firemen were quite prompt in answering the alarm, and by flooding the building they succeeded in checking the flames.

I left the South on the night succeeding the disastrous battle of Bull Run, the eventful 21st of July, 1861. I revisited it during the months of November, December, January and February just passed. With the history of that section of the United States during the four years and three months which intervened between these dates, the whole world is now sufficiently familiar.

FATAL RESULT OF SCALDS.--ANNA DORETTA WERSLIK, daughter of RUDOLF WERSLIK, of South Seventh-street, E. D., died on Friday night from the effects of scalds received the night previous, while her father, mother and a stranger were engaged in a melee in the lager beer saloon "WERSLIK." A kettle of boiling water was spilled over the person of the deceased during the disturbance.

O Willow, why forever weep, As one who mourns an endless wrong ? What hidden woe can lie so deep ? What utter grief can last so long ? The Spring makes haste with step elate Your life and beauty to renew ? She even bids the roses wait, And gives her first sweet care to you.

The sale of the collection of oil and watercolor paintings by French, Flemish, Dutch and American artists, closed on Friday evening. The attendance was quite as large as on the evening preceding, but the bidding was much less spiritedat the opening many fine paintings going at comparatively low figures. As the evening advanced bidding became more brisk, and active competition continued till the close of the sale.

In one of my late letters I promised you a little account of the gamblers and their operations. In this you shall have the story. First, I should tell you that the gambling houses are licensed, and all games, with the exception of " Three-Card Monte," and the "Strap," are permitted by law.

THE PEACH CROP IN NEW-JERSEY.--Dr. I. P. TRIMBLE continues to receive from his fellow-members of the Legislature twigs from peach trees in all parts of the State. He says there is no chance for a crop in New-Jersey this year; that in the peach districts of Mercer, Hunterdon, Somerset and Morris Counties the destruction of the buds appears to have been total,

President JOHNSON, Of the United States Senate, and Mr. MLYNARD, of the House of Representatives, remained in their seats as loyal Representatives from the State of Tennessee, after the ordinaoe of secession was adopted by that State.

The Inman steamer City of Boston, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at 10:30 on the morning of the 28th February, and Queenstown on the 1st March, arrived here yesterday. The steamer Queen, of the National Line, left Liver. simultaneously with the City of Boston. The Africa reached Liverpool at 7 A. M. on the 26th ult. The city of Washington reached Queenstown early on the morning of the 28th February.

Something entirely new for wear at the opera is the hooded jacket. This jacket is made of white merino, and finished at the edge with a broad binding of blue silk, with blue cord heading. Down the front are large round blue silk buttons. The jacket fits the figure, falling below the waistband. The back is pointed, the sides round up and fall in two points in front. The hood is cut the capuchin pattern,...

PERNIE.--On Saturday, March 10, JUDITH, wife of M. Bernie, in the 66th year of her age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, No. 145 Norfolk-st., on Tuesday, 13th inst., at 11/2 o'clock P. M. BROWER--On Sunday, March 11, RACHEL BROWER. wife of Abraham Brower, in the 68th year of her age.

By the European mail which arrived yesterday, we have news which indicates the possibility of a party crisis being near at hand. Lord RUSSELL made some heavy bids for popularity in weeding out several of the more unpopular members of the Cabinet as it existed under Lord PALMTRSTON.

BEEF vs. PORK.-Those who have been disturbed by the stories of the ravages of the trichina spiralis generated in pork, will either have their fears entirely set at rest, or possibly they will be still more alarmed at the statement which the Journal of Science for March reproduces, from a paper read before the British Association,

It is over five years since foreign intervention began its work in Mexico, and nearly three years since the Archduke MAXIMILIAN of Austria was proclaimed Emperor by the "Assembly of Notables" convened at the City of Mexico. Three years is a very long time for a Mexican Government of any sort to sustain itself in any fashion.

ABODES OF FILTH--We have numerous communications describing the filthy condition of the waiting-room of the Staten Island Ferry, and asking that the attention of the Health Commissioners be drawn thereto.

The Virginia Legislature has adjourned after a session of ninety days, leaving but little undone that should have been done, but it did many things in a bungling way. However, it proved itself a more than ordinary body, for its members escaped to confront their constituents without any offensive taint being attached to their names for having damaged the interests of the State.

RAYMOND, of New-York, said: Mr. Speaker, I have no intention of following the gentleman who has just taken his seat (Mr. BROOMALL) in his discursive remarks upon the general question of reconstruction,...

To the Editor of the New York Ttmes. We have heard of the French savants who listening with delight to the " Book of Ruth," desired to learn the source of such a charming pastoral, and feel inclined to place the facetious inquirer concerning the "Missionary Link " under the same category of seek. ers after truth.

Despite the schemes of adventurers on the Mexican frontier, the parade and noise of Fenian fillibusters on our Northern borders, and the steady prediction by the opponents of reconstruction, that repudiation will follow reunion, the advance of our national securities abroad continues to be steady and unchecked--fully answering to the appreciation of the national currency at home.

The steamer City of Boston arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, with Queenstown dates to the 1st inst. The news from England is interesting and important. A rumor was current that Earl RUSSELLELL had tendered his resignation, and had recommended Her Majesty to send for the Duke of Somerset to form a new Ministry.

HOUSE PROCEEDINGS--MR. STEVENS' SPEECH. Saturday is by custom of the House devoted to speech-making, and generally on that day the galleries are nearly empty, and but few members attend the session, save those who propose to read a speech. There was a departure from this custom yesterday.

Holt, Mr. Clements, H. Arrington, wife and child, Mr. Higgins and wife, Mrs. Jackson and daughter, Mr. Cohen, Mr. Schroeder, Mr. and Mrs. Livingstone.

The ice on the Hudson, which about one week since had been so worded upon by the mild weather as to be ready to move out, thus opening the through navigation of that stream, has been greatly strengthenad by six days of stinging cold weather, accompanied by furious westerly gales.

The following private letter from a wellknown gentleman of Alabama to Hon. H. T. BLOW, member of Congress from Missouri, has been handed to us for publication. It contains information of general public interest: FLORENCE, Ala., Feb. 28, 1866. Hon. Henry T. Blow: DEAR SIR: * * I see you have got in a wonderful muss about the admission of our Southern members.

The news last Semmr that the greatest living thinker and philosopher on political economy had been requested to stand for Parliament, was received by the thinking public of this country with the deepest interest.

AN EXTRAORDINARY DECISION.--At Chambers, on Saturday, Judge BARNARD is reported to have rendered the following extraordinary decision: In the matter of JOHN DOE for discharge, I order his discharge, on the ground that the commitment is not legal.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The opera of "L'Etoile du Nord" was introduced ten years ago to our public by Mr. MARETZEK, who now revives it in obedience to a general desire for more of MEYERBEER'S music. It was then a novelty, and had only boon played in two or three of the principal opera houses of the old World. Like other works of the same unflagging maestro, it had enjoyed a prefatory fame.

THE RECIPROCITY BILL KILLED. The Reciprocity Bill was killed in the House tonight thus eminently distinguishing the first night session. The bill had been discussed for nearly a week, and all its provisions had been very thoroughly handled; but the fate of the bill was determined almost entirely by the animus of members toward Canada. The State Logislalure adjourned this morning. The bill allowing negroes to testify in all cases where they are concerned in person or property, when jurisdiction shall be restored to the Courts in the State, was passed.

MEETING OF THE BUTCHERS' HIDE AND MELTING ASSOCIATION. The Butchers' Hide and Melting Association were invited to assemble in their hall, on the north-east corner of First-avenue and Fifth-street, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon; but at that hour the sole occupants of the hall were Mr. WILLIAM LALOR'S Broabdignagian steers "Union" and "General Washington."

Advices from El Paso, Mexico, have been reReceived. The Repulican Government was still located at El Paso. JUAREZ had learned that the French would soon leave Chihuahua in the hands of the Mexican garrison, when the Republicans will have no trouble in recapturing the city.

We suppose that nobody doubts the earnestness of purpose of the Radical leaders in Congress. They are probably as pure in motive as the general run of politicians.

We said a few days ago, in commenting on the statements of our correspondent in Texas, that the discussions in the Constitutional Convention of that State, while exhibiting a bitter and unreconciled rebel sentiment on the part of those who opposed the motion of Judge PASCHAL, showed also a decidedly combative Union majority in the Convention, which speedily brought Mr. ROBERTS and his brother rebels to terms.

In the Supreme Court to-day, JOHN WOOD, alias Jack Sheppard, Jr., was sentenced to five years in the State Prison for larceny, He has also four years of an unfinished term to serve in Sing. Sing, from which prison he recently escaped.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. BRICE in the Chair. The resolution granting the City Inspector the use of the dffices in Chatham-street in order to settle up the business of his Department, was adopted.

The English steamer Conway arrived this morning from Vera Cruz. Letters from Guaymas give gloomy details of the occupation of Alamas by dissenting troops under MARTINEZ and CORBEA, said to be to the number of 1,300 men. Not a head of cattle remains in Alamas or its vicinity.

SMYTH, republican, and it may run up to nearly six thousand, the majority of last year, when the Democrats made but little effort. The Republicans are jubilant, and the opposition astonished. The Republican majority in the Legislature will be very large.

The Tribune says: JOHN T. MONROE, the "National Democratic" candidate, whom we stated some days ago was chosen Mayor of New-Orleans, was the rebel Mayor when BUTLER and FARRAGUT took that city.

AN ACKNOWLEDGMENT FROM THE KING OF ITALY TO AN AMERICAN CITIZEN. Mr. SUMNER, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, reported a joint resolution authorizing Commodore WILLIAM HADFORD to accept the decoration of the Order of St. Maurice and Lazzaro from the King of Italy, as a reward for the assistance rendered by him to the Italian frigate Re D'Italia, when ashore on Long Branch.

FLORIDA.--Florida joins the other Southern States in attempts to secure immigration. A Florida paper now before us says that labor is in great demand on the plantations and farms, and the cities offer advantages to mechanics.

THE LOYALISTS OF TEXAS.--Our special correspondent in Texas has made mention of the present and past bearing of the loyal men of that State. He happens to have inadvertently confounded Judge J. A. PASCHAL with his brother, Judge GEORGE W. PASCHAL--both loyal men. The latter is now in this City.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your paper, in its Washington correspondence, has repeatedly charged Mr. S. M. CLARK with having placed his likeness on the five-cent currency without authority, and this charge has been made the test of a most unkind editorial.

The Scottish-American Journal, in the new dress in which it appears, is certainly the handsomest weekly sheet in America. The selections show good taste, and if the editor dealt more gently with radicalism he might possibly please his Scottish patrons better.

AS ALARMING FACT.--Intelligence was received yesterday at the rooms of the American Seamen's Friend Society, that a few days since a vessel on which they had placed one of their sailors' libraries, had been boarded in an Irish port by an English detective, who insisted upon examining the craft. Coming upon this library,

The wealthy benefactor of the poor in London--Mr. GEORGE PEABODY--not satisfied with his princely gift of $750,000 (gold) in 1862, to found lodging-houses, has appropriated another $500,000 for a similar object.

M. LANGLAIS, financial Minister and Secretary of the Treasury of Mexico, died very suddenly, last Friday evening. He was attended by the Emperor's physician, Dr. SHULTZ. The funeral obsequies took place at the Cathedral yesterday.

THE BUTCHERS AND THE BOARD OF HEALTH.-A delegation, composed of representative men in the butchering business, met yesterday in consultation with the President of the Board of Health, concerning the necessity of removing slaughter-houses from the centres of dense population.

The Oceanport Steam Mill and four buildings adjoining were burned last evening. A large quantity of sash blinds in the mill, belonging to T. R. JACKSON, Architect of the Astor House Hotel Company was burned, which was insured for $10,000. .
Few people, we suppose, pretend to comprehend the whole of the speeches, or the half of the theories that have been elaborated in Congress during its present session.

The Southern Express Company, which runs in connection with the Adams Express Company, paid yesterday, through its President, H. B. FLAT, $200,000 to the First National Bank of Memphis for money lost on the W. R. Carter, which exploded near Vicksburgh, Miss.

The failure of the Whipple File Manufacturing Company was announced to-day heavy liabilities. The capital stock of the company was seven hundred thousand dollars, and it recently petitioned for a further increase.

The London Times and the largest English newspapers are printed by HOE'S presses. American reapers, and other agricultural implements, take the lead in England, and our sewing-machines may now be found in every well-ordered British household.
Great indifference was shown here yesterday as to the result of the municipal election. A large number of voters did not go to the polls, and especially was this the case with business men.
At 2 o'clock this morning the steamer Adelaide from Norfolk, while off Sharp's Island, was run into by a schooner, demolishing the cook-room of the steamer.

THE ARMY BILL. Save the action upon the Army bill, the proceedings in the Senate to-day were not of remarkable interest. The bill as passed was substantially to same is that introduced by the Senate Military Committee and published in the TIMES Congressional report some days ago. It will also be recollected that we...
The Orton murder remains a mystery. The Coroner's jury found that the deceased was killed by some person to the jury unknown. PADDOCK, who was arrested, proved an alibi, and was discharged..

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The third performance of "L'Etoile du Nord" attracted a fashionable attendance last evening, and the work was given with the rarest spirit. It is certainly a delightful opera, and it has been placed on the stage with a care which leaves nothing to be desired.

POTRID MEAT.--The numerous seizures of putrid meat at various markets of this City disclose a state of things before comparatively unknown to the public, though we presume not to the Market Superintendents. There are some dealers who occupy regular stands who are implicated in this nefarious and reckless business.

Pursuant to notice the National Convention of Iron Founders assembled in this city at the Board Trade rooms at noon to-day. Between 80 and 100 delegates were in attendance, from nearly all the Northern, Eastern and Western States, as also from Canada.

The schooner Sunny South, from New-York 5th, bound to Jacksonville, struck on the Cumberland Island Shoals on the evening of the 10th inst., and run ashore on the Island and is leaking badly. On the morning of the 11th the tide ebbed and flowed in her. A small part of the cargo was discharged.

A SUCCESSFUL EXPERIMENT.--We note an entirely successful establishment of a cooperative store at Trenton, N. J. This was only recently incorporated by the Legislature of New-Jersey, and has been in operation but a few months.

In the Senate to-day Mr. LENT introduced a bill to incorporate the New-York Storage and Lighter-age Company, which provides that Henry M. McDorkie, Henry Green, Hayner Lord, Franklin Johnson, Samuel Brownell, and all others who may be come stockholders in the Company, shall be body corporate and politic for the purpose of owning leasing, holding, crecting and maintaining lands, docks, bulkheads, piers, basins and warehouses,

The excitement in regard to the Fenian foray is still at fever heat. Indeed, public credulity is ready to swallow any rumor, however wild. Business, of which we never have much, is now at a stand-still, and nobody cares to buy or sell.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. BRICE in the chair. A communication was received from the Comptroller of Greenwood Cemetery, stating that in accordance with the request of the Common Council, a plot of ground has been set apart in the Cemetery, for the erection of a monument to the soldiers killed in the late war.

On Monday, the Committee of the Board of Supervisors, appointed to investigate the charges of corruption brought against the Committee on the construction of the new Court-house, met at 3 o'clock, Mr. Fox in the chair.

A POLICEMAN SHOOTS A THIEF.--Some two or three weeks ago MARTIN FURLONG, residing at No. 159 Cherry-street, was garroted and robbed of a watch in Water-street. Subsequently the timekeeper was found in the possession of a young man, who stated that he had purchased it from JOHN SHELLY, a man well known to the Police as a garroter.

BILLS REPORTED. Amending the charter of the United States Warehouse Company. Incorporating the National Warehouse and Security Company. Defecting the removal of the railroad track in Thompson-street, and to change the route of the Broadway and Seventh-avenue Railroad Company.

THE FITNESS OF THINGS.--We dare say there was some portion of the Congressional audience that listened to Mr. BANKS' eloquent speech on Tuesday, whose judgment would have been better satisfied if the speaker had been less belligerent in tone and bearing.

JARED SPARKS, the intelligence of whose decease will be found in another column, was born at Willington, Conn., on May 10, 1789, and graduated at Harvard in 1815. The earlier years of his life had been devoted to agriculture and mechanical pursuits, but the bent of his mind was toward the acquisition and imparting of knowledge.

CITY RENTS.--We hear from many of the cities of the country of a heavy decline in the rates of rent that were demanded a few weeks ago. Even in Washington they have been greatly lowered, and still untenanted houses there are frequent.

DEATH FROM BURNS. An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY, on the body of ROSE KELLY, at the residence of Mr. BROWN, in One Hundred and Twentieth-street, near Second-avenue, where the deceased had been employed as a domestic.

Charles H. Daniels, by Thompson, his next Friend vs. The Chicago and Rock Island Railroad Company.--On the trial of this case in the Northern District of Illinois, it was proven that the defendant was a common carrier of passengers and freight,

A DETECTIVE ASSAULTED IN A PORTER-HOUSE. Several men became involved in a quarrel, about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, in the porter-house kept by CHARLES NICHOLS, corner of Grand and Orchard streets. During the fight which ensued, PATRICK PURCELL was severely beaten about the head. Officer SLOWEY, of the Detective Squad, happening to be in the vicinity, entered the promises and endeavored to quell the row.

The Clarksville correspondent of the Houston Telegraph charges that the Treasury agents there have seized 1,700 bales of cotton, which it was well and generally known did not belong to the late Confederacy.
The managers of the Fenian movement are smart men. They have contrived to keep up for many months a paying excitement upon most insignificant capital.

In the Senate Mr. SUMNER reported a joint resolution authorizing Commodoro RADFORD to receive from the king of Italy a decoration of honor for assistance rendered to an Italian frigate, ashore on Long Island. The bill appropriating $2,600 to the sufferers of the late Arsenal explosion at Washington, was passed.

The Court-house Investigating Committee, consisting of Supervisors FOX, BLAKELY and HAYES, resumed their labors at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Ex-Mayer OPDYEE, Comptroller BRENNAN and Mr. JOHN KELLUM, the architect of the new Court-house, were present in obedience to the Sheriff's mandate.

The steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 3d, via Queenstown on the 4th instant, has arrived at this port. Her dates are two days later than those already published. The steamships Helvetia, Damascus, Fulton and Peruvian arrived out on the 2d, and the Bavaria, City of Cork and Australasian on the 3d instant.

As a sequel to the late Tournament of the New-York Chess Club, a match has at length been definitely arranged between Capt. G. H. MACKENZIE, of the New-York clubs, and Mr. REICHELEN, champion of the Philadelphia chess-players. The conditions of the encounter are that the first winner of seven games is to be declared the conqueror;....

THOMAS MURPHY--To incorporate the NewYork City Sunday School Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Also, to incorporate a company to keep valuables secure from fires, burglars and mobs.

Ex-parle Milligan, Bowles and Horsey.--Hon. Henry Stanbery, of Ohio, on the part ot the Government, made an oral argument in these cases, in substance as follows, which has not been stated: This Court has not jurisdiction in the case. It has no original jurisdiction, for it is not within any of the provisions of the Constitution or the laws of the United States which vest original jurisdiction in the Supreme Court.

BALL--STONE.--On Thursday, March 15, at the residence of the bride, by Rev. Dr. J. H. Price, Dr. A. BRAYTON BALL, of this city, and HELEN S., daughter of Edward Stone, Esq., of Kingsbridge.

The steamship Africa, with Queenstown dates to the 4th inst., arrived yesterday morning, at Halifax. Her dates are two days later than those received already. Memorial Diplomatique states that Mr. SEWARD's reply to the French dispatch on Mexico had been received. It contained, says the Memorial, an assurance of neutrality on the part of the United States toward Mexico, in view of the promised evacuation ot that country by the French troops.

The British steamer Cadmus, eight days from Vera Cruz, arrived here to-day and fired a salute of twenty-one guns, which was returned by the flagship, then by the forts, and then by the Spanish Admiral.

A sale of a large number of pictures by modern French, Flemish and English artists, took place at the Studio Building in Tenth-st., last night. Messrs. H. H. LEEDS MINER Offciated as auctioneers. The attendance at the sale was quite large, and fair prices were realized. The first pictures disposed of were by NOEL, THOM, GIRSCHER, LASSALLE and LAMBINET, which brought from $50 to $95 each.

THE CIVIL RIGHTS BILL PASSED. The important event of the Senate session to-day, was the passage of the Civil Rights Bill in the form it came from the House. Each of the House amendments was adopted separately, upon demand from Mr. DAVIS for a separate vote, though the Senate was inclined to dispose of the whole matter in lump, and make a five minutes' affair of it.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VEEDI'S opera of "UnBallo in Maschera" will be given to-night by Mr. MARETZEK. The distribution includes the names of several of the best-known members of the Company. At the matinee to-morrow, MEYERUEER'S superb spectacular opera of the "Star of the North" is the special attraction. It begins at 1 o'clock. In the evening the Company plays at the Brooklyn Academy of Musci for the benefit of Mine. CAROZZI-ZUCCHI. MEYERBEER'S "African" is the opera.

Hagerty, Esq., Clerk of the Board of Councilmen You will please convene the Board of Councilmen on Thursday, the fifteenth instant, at two o'clock P.M., for the purpose of transacting such business as may come before them.

J. A. Cummings vs. The State of Missouri.--Hon. Reverdy Johnson having concluded the reargument in the Arkansas and Louisiana test-oath cases, under the act of Congress, (which cases were reported in the TIMES on the former argument), the Missouri test-oath cases were taken up.

The public history of the occupation of Rome by French troops has received an important addition in the shape of a dispatch addressed by Cardinal ANTONELLI to the Pontifical Numcios, in which he reviews the situation of affairs in the Pope's dominions, and anticipates the dangers which may arise by their withdrawal.

The steamer America, of the Nicaragan line, sailed to-day with a large number of passengers. Two steamers sailed to-day for Portland, Oregon, carrying a large load of passengers and freight destined for the Montana and Idaho mines.

The Indiana Democratic State Convention assembled here to-day, and was largely attended. The following nominations were made: For Secretary of State--Gen. Moblon D. Manson, of Montgomery. Auditor--Christian G. Badger, of Clark. Treasurer--James Bryon, of Marion.

A very pleasant festival and social ball were given last night on board the National Steam Navigation Company's ship the Queen, lying at her dock, Pier No. 47. North River. Nearly one hundred and fifty ladies and gentlemen were present, and the affair was a complete success.

FORTS DISMANTLED. The dismantling of Forts Carroll, Stanton, Baker Mahan, Lincoln, Totten, Slocum, Stevens, Reno and Sumner, north of the Potomac, reduces the defence of Washington to a peace footing, and leaves of them only the powerful water battery on the Maryland shore, above Fort Foote, which is armed with the heaviest and most improved artillery,and commands the Potomac River for miles below and above.

HIGHWAY ROHBERY. RICHARD T. PARMLEE, of No. 173 Forsyth street, while passing through Willett-street at the hour on Saturday night, on his way home, was assaulted by three men, who knocked him down and rifled his pockets of a watch, a pocket-book aand an eye-glass, of the aggregate value of $12 50.

The programme of the French Exposition is now published, and dates have been assigned for the various operations of the Commission, for the information of the workmen and exhibitors: Before Dec. 1, 1866--The Palace and buildings in the park are to be finished. Before Jan. 1, 1867--French artists are to be notified of their admission.

The last advices from England convey the intelligence of the death, on the 6th instant, of the distinguished Professor and scholar, Dr. WHEWELL, Master of Trinity College. Dr. WHEWELL was born in Lancaster, of humble parentage. and, it is said, his father intended to devote him to his own handicraft, but the superiority of his intellectual powers were so apparent when a pupil in the Free Grammar School.

THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH COMPANY.--The Atlantic Telegraph Company, it will be seen by the news from Europe this morning, is undergoing the process of reorganization. It is to be under new management--which every one will be willing to hope may likewise prove more successful management.

Mention was made in yesterday's TIMES of a stabbing affray in a drinking-saloon at No. 53 Park-street, the parties to whichy were MICHAEL MANNING and ANTHONY LONG. It appears that LONG, who is a Frenchman, quarreled with WILLIAM MULHOLLAND, alias Stone, alias "Billy Bottles," and a fight was the result.

GOLD AND GOVERNMENTS.--Gold was offered for sale with unusual eagerness yesterday, on a steadily declining market-the currency rate falling as low as 127 3/4, without eliciting any remarkable inquiry from any source. This is the lowest point reached by the precious metal in nearly three years, or since the early Autumn of 1863, when sales were made as low as 122.

A dispatch from Portland to-day says GEORGE BADUE, a noted guerrilla, was shot dead yesterday morning, it is supposed by MICHAEL GALLAGHER, who is now under arrest. Tho Oregon Herald, a new Democratic daily, has just appeared.

A PORTRAIT GALLERY.--Included in the extremely curious and interesting museum of antiquarian matters, rare books, engravings, autographs, , which BANGS, MERWIN co., bring to the hammer tomorrow (Wednesday) evening, as will be seen by an advertisement elsewhere, is a mass of copper and steel engravings of celebrated persons, numbering some 5,000 different subjects, and embracing many very rure and some unique exemplars.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"Ione" was given here last evening for the benefit of Mile. BOSISIO. The house was not well attended, but the lady appeared to be warmly regarded by her friends, who bestowed on her many beautiful floral tokens of their appreciation. A couple of brilliant trifles from PETRELLA'S new opera, "II Folieto di Gresly," was sung by the lady and Signor BRANDINI with spirit.

PETITIONS. Mr. SUMNER presented the petition of citizens of New-York, earnestly asking that no State that rebelled shall be admitted as a governing, partner into the Union without adequate security for the future. Referred to the Committee on Reconstruction.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The apathy of the merchants and others on Broadway, in view of the different projects at Albauy for its destruction as a business street, is amazing. Some four or five elevated plans are before the Railroad Committees, which are scarcely lose absurd than imprudent, and yet I am told they are being seriously considered.

In the House this evening, Mr. LITTLEJOHN, from Committee on Appointments, prepared a bill apportioning members of the Assembly to the respective counties under the census of 1866. New-York gains under this bill four members, Kings two, and Erie one. The following counties lose one member each, viz.: Alleghany, Chenango, Herkimer, Jefferson, Livingston, Steuben and Suffolk. Other counties remain unchanged.

Some two years ago an eccentric gentleman of this City published a grand plan for the payment of our national debt by voluntary subscriptions of the people. The project was subsequently taken up and advocated with great intensity by one of our City cotemporaries.
The latest report from the Texas Convention indicates steady, if not rapid, progress on the part of that body toward a conformity with the Executive policy of restoration.

The Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. BRICE in the Chair. The Tax Levy was returned from the Board of Councilmen, who refused to concur in adopting the item of $200,000, for Belgian pavement, which they reduced to $100,000. The Board, on motion of Mr. NORTON, adhered to its former action.

RENTS AND REASON.-A correspondent, who has taken our advice in regard to patience on the rent extortion question, tells us that, having read an article on the subject in the TIMES, he withdrew his "early application" for a house near this City about three weeks since.

The distance of 1,000 miles from the army, with no telegraphs, makes news a rare commodity. We seldom have advices here at the National Capital less than four days old, and then six days elapse before we hear again. With such a distance, and with the liability of false rumors acquiring the value of news, we are often incommoded.

THE EQUALIZATION OF BOUNTIES. The proposition to equalize countiess of soldiers, which has been receiving the grave attention of members of Congress from the beginning of the session, has at length taken form in both branches of the National Legislature simultaneously.

NEW SOUTHERN RAILROAD PROJECTS.--We notice that among the new and progressive projects new being mooted in the South, is that of a railroad connecting Memphis with Central Alabama. To effect this it only requires the stretching of a line to Selma from some point on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad.

Cold water is a wonderful alleviator of nervous irritation. I remember to have seen, some eighteen years ago, a band of determined revolutionists in open air demonstration suddenly subside into the littleness of ordinary mortals by what the authorities no doubt supposed to be the judicious application of a shower-bath, unexpectedly administered from a neighboring by ?? by a hose and handful of policemen.

The house was poorly attended, notwithstanding the attraction of MEYERBEER'S "African.." It did not indeed represent the seats sold previous to the change.

MARY ELLEN KEARNEY was shot dead last evening in the doorway of her father's house in Roxbury, by JOHN MORAN. The parties had been keeping company; but MORAN'S character being reported bad, the father of the young woman had forbidden him the house. The alleged murderer surrendered himself to the police this morning.

The friends of the Mexican Republic have printed and are circulating a statement of the aspect of the question, based on the comparative financial condition of the country under republican and monarchical rules. It shows the total foreign debt, as recognized in 1862, to be near $82,000,000, less than $3,000,000 of which is due to French, nearly $9,500,000 to Spanish, and the remainder to English subjects.

DEATH OF AN OLD CITIZEN.--Another vacancy occurs in the ranks of our useful and benevolent men, occasioned by the death of ISRAEL RUSSELL, one of our oldest. Most useful and philanthropic citizens. He died of paralysis at his residence in this city on Monday morning. He was born in Morristown. New-Jersey, in 1790, and was consequently 76 years of age.

Traveling in the South now-a-days is anything but pleasant, if confined to railroads. In the first place the fastest trains do not make more than fifteen miles per hour, and the majority of them do not average twelve, while the fare averages six and a halt cents per mile, and the cars are far from comfortable.
STERLING KING, who confesses himself guilty of attempting to assassinate Secretary SEWARD, undertook to commit suicide this morning by severing a blood vessel of his arm. His recovery is doubtful.

The sheep disease had reached its customary point. Sixteen thousand sheep had been infected up to Nov. 1.

The Democratic State Convention was held in this city to-day. THOMAS STEENE, of Smithfield, presided, WM. J. MILLER and GEORGE N. BLISS Secretaries. No nominations for State officers were made. A Committee was raised to bring forward a ticket here after if deemed expedient.

Smith, No. 57 West Warren- St., Brooklyn, this day. (Thursday,) at 2 o'clock P.M. BOYD--On Tuesday, March 20. LIZZIE, youngest daughter of Peter J, and Elizabeth Boyd, in the 6th year of her age.

The construction of the immense iron-clad ram, the Dunderberq, fast progresses toward completion, and as she assumes the appearance of a perfected work, the visitors to the yard of Mr. W. H. WEBB, where she is being built, are numerous, and enthusiastic in their admiration of this wonder of construction.

We reproduce in the TIMES this morning the comments of leading English journals on President JOHNSON'S 22d of February speech. It will be seen that the tone of these comments is extremely laudatory of the President's position and views, and that the praise comes from journals representing every shade of political opinion.

ROBBED ON THE CARS.--It is probable that not one-half the robberies which take place on the City railroad cars are ever made public; but occasionally a gross case comes to light. Last Wednesday night Mr. C. H. WyMAN of the firm of JOHNSON WYMAN while riding down in one of the fourth-avenue line of cars with a party of ladies, was robbed of a valuable gold watch and his pocket book.

The bill here with reported is for the construction of a subterranean railway from the Battery, in the City of New-York, to run from thence northerly, under Broadway, to Madison-square, and from thence by alternative routes, either Broadway or Fifth-avenue to the Central Park, with branches connecting with the Hudson River and New-York and Harlem Railroads.

THE PORK SENSATION.--We are constrained to protest against the sensational stories which are circulated, evidently by interested parties, on the subject of disease in pork. The flesh of hogs is not now more liable to or infected by disease than it has been for any time during this generation; and when the rumors set about are investigated, it is found that they are entirely baseless.

The Royal Mail steamer Australasian, Capt. COOK, which sailed from Liverpool at 1 P. M. on the 10th and Queenstown on the 11th of March, arrived here yesterday morning. The City of Baltimore reached Liverpool about noon on the 9th inst. The Scotland arrived at Queenstown at midnight on the 9th.

President SCHULTZ, Commissioner ACTON and Dr. STONE, in their early visit to Washington Market on Wednesday morning, discovered a small city which is not laid down on the maps, and of which few NewYorkers outside the retail grocery and huckstering circles have any knowledge. It is the City of Shanties. The common charts have an entire block, bound.

We learn that subscriptions to the stock of this Company are vgery liberal in this City and throughout the country. A LITTLE GIRL BURNT TO DEATH IN WEST FORTYSIXTH-STREET. About 4 o'clock on Wedndsday afternoon, a fire was discovered in premises No. 161 West Forty-sixth street, occupied as a dwelling by VALENTINE KBAUSE, which resulted in the death of CATHARINE KRAUSE, aged five years.

My last letter to the Times was from a point considerably further down toward the " Metropolis" that the present. This township, as you well know, lies directly in the line of the Harlem Railroad, and at the junction of the border lines of three States--New-York, Massachusetts and Connecticut--a fact which has made it sometimes a favorite resort of prizefighters and gentry of that ilk.

The steamship Australasian, which sailed from Liverpool March 10, and from Queenstown March 11, reached this port yesterday morning. The speech of President JOHNSON at the meeting in Washington on the 22d of February attracted much attention in England, and met with very general approbation. The London Times warmly applauds it and says it would not have been unworthy of the great founder of the American Republic.

The storm of Tuesday night was very severe and damaging to property in the neighborhood of Connessville, Ind. Several buildings were blown down, and one of the piers of the bridge of the Cincinnati and Indianapolis Junction Railroad was destroyed. A freight-train ran into the chasm, and the engineer and firemen were severely injured.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There will be no performance hero to-night, all tile artists being needed for tomorrow's matinie, when "Don Giovanni" will be given. This grand work requires three prima-donnas, and is rarely performed except at the end of the seasons owing to this circumstance. Our lady friends are in good luck to have it at their own special performance.

GRAND LARCENY.--A young woman named BRIDGET CAREY was arrested a couple of days since, on suspicion of having stolen about $80 from Mrs. CHRISTOPHER MATTHEWS, of Hudson City. Yesterday, Officer MANN, who made the arrest, recovered the money, it having been thrown into the street by the accused after she was arrested, and was picked up by a young lady, who gave information which led to its recovery. overy.

Notwithstanding the rejection of Mr. MORRILL'S Bill, it is evident that the question of reciprocal trade with the British Provinces will not be allowed to rest in its present shape. During the few days which have elapsed since the expiration of the treaty, the question has occupied the attention of several of our cotemporaries, whose remarks indicate the dissatisfaction with which intelligent business men contemplate the inevitable disturbance of an important trade.

By order of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, twenty thousand tons of Scranton coal were disposed of yesterday at public auction, Mr. SIMEON DRAPER officiating as auctioneer. The coal is delivered at Elizabethport, N. J., during the month of April, on the usual terms and conditions, the freight thence to this City being 70 cents per ton.

THE LATE WM. WRIGHT.--With characteristic liberality the citizens of Paterson, N. J., have initiated a movemnent to raise a fund for the benefit of the family of the late WILLIAM WRIGHT, whose death was announced a few days since. Mr. WRIGHT was connected with various journals during his newspaper life, among them the Commercial Advertiser, the Evening Post, the Railroad Journal and the TIMES of this city, and also with the Paterson Guardian and Press.

BLEECKER, Assessor. This is the largest income district in the country, requiring more careful assessment, more diligent searching, more official examination than any other, unless it be the Thirty-second, where it will be remembered congregate our dissatisfied friends, the brokers.

Messrs. LEAVITT, STREBEIGH Co., open their first regular Spring trade sale of books, stereotype plates and stationery on the 3d prexime, at their new Trade Sale Rooms, No. 498 Broadway. The catalogue before us, covering nearly 400 pages promises one of the most extensive Spring sales we have had for years.

We suppose the people of the country in general were considerably astonished on learning, by the statement just communicated to Congress by the Secretary of War, that there are still in the service and pay of the United States over one hundred and fifty thousand troops! It is all but a year since LEE surrendered, and the Work for which our army was raised was finished.

The following are the reasons assigned by EDWARD W. GREEN, the Malden murderer, in his petition to the Supreme Court, asking for a writ of error: First--That the Court had no power to enter judgmont and award sentence of death against the defendant upon his plea, without the intervention of a Jury.

THE PRESIDENT ON THE CONNECTICUT ELECTION. The President assured Gen. HAWLEY at the interview yesterday, that all reports to the effect that he ad agreed to support the Democratic candidate for Governor of Connecticut were fats. He had made and intended to make no such piedges. He also said that though he did not design to interfere with the local elections of any State yet it would satisfy him to see his political friends successful.

MR. EDWIN BOOTH AND THE DESTITUTE CHILDREN OF OUR SOLDIERS AND SAILORS.--On Saturday next, March 24, Mr. EDWIN BOOTH will give a performance at Winter Garden for the benefit of the institution in Fifty-eight-street, which has been doing such noble service in providing for the children of our soldiers and sailors who have been made destitute by the war.

EXEMPTING DISABLED SOLDIERS FROM PAYMENT OF LICENSE FEES. Mr. SUMNER introduced a resomtion instructing the Committee on Finance to inquire into the expediency of amending the Internal Revenue Act so as to Permit disabled soldiers of the Union Army to peddle without paying the license now required by law. The resolution was adopted.

The ?? is of trespass, in centermity with the Texas ?? to try title to a lot of land containing about ?? in San Antenio.

THE BUTTER TRADE.--The extraordinary prices of butter have for sonic time attracted the attention of housekeepers, and with good reason. The causes assigned are that there has been a large inquiry, for foreign use, for the prime and fancy sorts, and that the supply has not been equal to its demands.

While temporarily sojourning at this interesting little town, finding myself within four miles of Brandy Station-tho scene of so many conflicts during 1864--I rode over there the other morning, and while there I called upon Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS, whose extensive and valuable plantation forms so large a portion of the cultivated tract surrounding the station.

The Board of Trustees of the New-Jersey State Normal School,of which Prof. J. S. HART, L.L. D., is Principal, have just made their report to the State Legislature. From this document it appears that the whole number of pupils under instruction in the Normal school during the past year has been one hundred anti twenty-five, oi whom eleven were males and one hundred and fourteen females;

ANOTHER TUMBLE IN COAL.--At the regular monthly sale of Scranton Coal yesterday, on account of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, 20,000 tons were disposed of at prices indicative of a further fall of from 521/2c.@ $1 65 per ton of 2,240 pounds, as compared with the rates realized at the preceding sale, Stove having receded 921/2c.@$1 65; Chestnut, $1 55@$1 571/2;

DEATH OF AN OLD PRINTER.--ULYSSES F. DOUBLEDAY, who died at Bloomington, Ill., recently, was a native of the County of Otsego, where, in 1809, he was appronticed to H. E. PHINNEY, of whom he learned his trade. In 1813 he was journeyman printer at Utica, in the office of Messrs. SEWARD WILLIAMS.

AN INTERPOLATION WHICH OUGHT TO BE EXPUNGED.--Since the Board of Education, at its last December session resolved that it would pay no journal for publishing accounts of its proceedings, the ring organ in this City has continued its reports as of old, omitting only the seal of the Board and the word "official."

The State Senate has passed resolutions indorsing the action of the majority in Congress, as against that of the President, by a vote of 21 to 23. Mining stocks are firmer: Ophir, $640; Yellow Jacket, $790; Belcher, $300; Savage, $1,000; Imperial, $130; Croton Point, $1,375. Legal tenders, 78 1/2.

THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES. The Vice-President laid before the Senate the report of the Vice-President of the National Academy of sciences. SALE OF REVENUE CUTTERS AND HOSPITALS. Mr. CHANDLER moved that the Senate insist on its amendments to the bill authorizing the sale of revenue cutters and marine hospitals, and appoint a committee of conference.

Mr. CALVIN PEPPER, who was arrested here yesterday, left this morning for Richmond. An investigation is to be immediately made into his colonization scheme by Maj.-Gen. TERRY, at Richmond, and the result will in a few days be made public.
Pike's Opera House is in ruins. Portions of the front wall of the building have fallen into Fourthstreet, and the entire rear and side walls are a mass of rubbish.

BASSFORD.--On Friday morning, March 23, the infant son of Geo. W. and Amanda T. Bassford, aged 1 month and 3 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Sunday afternoon. 25th inst., at 1 o'clock from the residence of his parents, No. 173 10th-av.

In the Senate, yesterday, a Committee of Con ference was appointed on the amendments to the civil Appropriation bill. Mr. WILSON introduced a joint resolution securing bounties to colored soldiers in certain cases. Mr. CHANDLER introduced a bill to prevent smuggling.

The House has been in session till near midnight, amid the greatest excitement, over the new Capitol bill. Powerful speeches have been made by Speaker TREMAINE in favor of, and by D. P. WOOD against the bill.

KEEPING IT UP.--The Fenian newspapers have already given notice that Mr. STEPHENS, the Chief Executive of their "Government," has escaped from his great Republic, and is on his way to America.

IN READE-STREET. At 9 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered on the fifth floor of No. 143 Reade-street, occupied by DAVID T. DUNN as a paper-bag manufactory. The flames were promptly extinguished. Damage to stock, $1,000.

Planting is going on rapidly in Louisiana. Sugar and corn are all planted. The Louisiana and Texas District Courts are easy upon debtors, and prosecutions are few. Important cases of prosecution for non-inscription of mortgages during the late war are being argued.

WOOD'S GYMNASIUM.--The fourth reception of the season took place at Wood's Gymnasium, in East Twenty-eighth-stroot, last evening. A very large number of spectators assembled, among whom were sovoral hundred ladies.

DEAF MUTE KILLED BY A RAILROAD TRAIN. Coroner WILUEY held an inquest yesterday at the Thirty-second Precinct Station-house, on the body of NORMAN AMBROSE, a deaf mate, who was struck by the locomotive of an express train on the Hudson River Railroad, at the Fort Washington depot, on the 21st inst., as already reported in the TIMES.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The "Don Giovanni" matinee, it must be remembered, begins to-day at 11 o'clock, and the doors open at 10. Of the cast, we have already spoken. It includes the best artists of Mr. MARETZEK'S company. The work itself is of course the finest attraction that could be offered.
There was a public exhibition (yesterday afternoon) near the corner of Fifty-fifth-street and Ninth-avenue, of what is known as the Sweeney Rotary Boring Machine.
There is little of public interest to report today. In the Texas State Convention a Committee of nine has been appointed to prepare an address to President JOHNSON.

CHRISTIAN UNION.--Conferences on this theme will be held this afternoon at three o'clock, in Dr. ARMITAGE'S church, corner Forty-sixth-street and Fifth-avenue; Drs. YERMILYE, KREBS, and others, will speak. The supposed exclusiveness of certain denominations will be the subject of thought.

SUICIDE BY DROWNING.--Yesterday afternoon about 2 o'clock the body of MARGARET MAHER was found floating in a pond at the corner of Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Fiftieth-street. An inquest was held by Coroner WILDEY on the body, when it was shown in evidence that deceased had been deranged since October inst. and had lived with her brother, THOMAS MAHER, at the corner of Tenth-avenue. The United States consul at Port Mahon, Minorca Island, under date of February 28, informs the Department of State that the United States merchant vessels are eagerly sought after about the Mediterranean, and are preferred by freighters to vessels of any other nation. Ho says that within a very short time past American vessels could have been chartered to great advantage.

The Senate of the United States has passed a bill intended to remedy that defect in our legislation in relation to the places ceded to the United States, which was brought to the attention of the public by the decision of Judge SHIPMAN in the case of Mr. BARNEY a short time since.

There is a wide-spread belief that wealth insures ease; ease, health; health, happiness. But wealth-what we now call wealth-is rarely accumulated by industry, by daily labor. One man, with brain and hands, may earn two dollars, three dollars, five dollars, ten dollars per day; rarely more than that.

DEATH OF PROF. CHARLES BECK.--We regret to announce the death of Prof. BECK, for many years Professor at Harvard College, which took place Monday evening, at his residence in Cambridge. In the afternoon he was riding on horseback, accompanied by his daughter, when he was taken in a fit, and Mr. THUOLT, who was present, supported him and conveyed him home, where he lingered a few hours.

Gen. FISK has sent to the Froodmon's Buroan a most unfavorable account of the condition of affairs In Kentucky. On the part of a large majority of the whites, he believes that there is an honest desire to adjust on a lair basis the new relations arising from the abolition of slavery, but the Bureau is not a popular institution among them.

FIRE IN SECOND-AVENUE.--About 5:30 O'ClOCK last evening a fire br oko out on the third floor of the four-story building corner of Thirty-fourth-street and Second-avenue, occupied as a paper-hanging manufactory, by J. DECKER. The flames spread with such rapidity that the entire third and fourth floors wore burnt out, and about $1,500 worth of paper stock consumed. Loss covered by insurance.

The Picayune has the following: The steamer Sonora, from Vera Cruz on the 12th, via Tampico on the 15th, and Bagdad on the 18th inst. has arrived here. The weather at Vera Cruz is already quite warm, but the city is quite healthy. The population is large compared to what it was former years. Business is lively.
