The rumors from Washington gain strength that the President will veto the bill to secure an equality of civil rights to the freedmen of the South. We have hoped this result might be avoided. There is, however, as all know who have examined it, one feature of the bill open to the most serious objection.
A reference by one of our correspondents to the proposed charter of the Intornational Telegraph Company, as n measture to establish a dangerous monopoly, has called forth several rejoinders.

The decision of Judge BETTS on denying the application of the owners of the Meteor for leave to bond her pending the litigation, involves the following points: 1. The Judge decides that it is within the ordinary usage of the United States Courts to bail personal property, seized under process in rem. issued out of courts of civil and admiralty jurisdiction.

Mr. Secretary MCCULLOCH does not exaggerate when he declares that it will be "a national calamity if Congress shall fail to grant additional powers to the Secretary." The whole tenor of his letter to the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee shows that these additional powers are sought, not to magnify his office or enable him to carry out a policy of the principles of which the country is ignorant,

OUR LARGE NEGRO ARMY.--It appears by the recent official statement of Secretary STANTON that there are at this time more black than white troops in the volunteer service of the United States. Of negro soldiers (privates) we have no less than 63,373, while the white volunteers now left number but 55,326 men.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your article suggesting the immediate reduction of ur present army, reminds me of a corollary provision coming under it, which our Generals commanding departments have been culpable in neglecting. The various clerks and commissioned orderlies, known as additional Aids-d-camp, who swell the staffs of military leaders, were ordered some months age to be mustered out of the United States service.

The bill making appropriations to commence building a new capitol continues to be an excapitol subject of legislation here. The Al. baniens display a wonderful zeal in putting the measure through, and members are importuned everywhere by all sorts of people, in the House, at their boarding places, wherever they go, to vote for the bill.

Cotton weak and unsettled; sales 1300 bales; receipts to-day 1350 bales. Low middling at 37 1/2c. Gold 224; Sterling Exchange 33 3/4c. Checks on NewYork 1/2 discount. The business of the week closed lively. The high water has broken through the levees in Upper Louisiana, and work is suspended.

There is one position in the United States Navy which the writer thinks should be filled by persons appointed by the Government, instead of which they are appointed by the paymaster, with the approval of the Captain. I refer to paymasters' clerks, This rather savors of a civil appointment, and the clerk cannot feel that he stands in the same relation toward the Government that those do, who are appointed by it.

Thousands of enterprising and industrious Northern people, as you are doubles aware, have been deterred from emigrating to the South the prevent season, by fears of ill-treatment, or at least hostile feeling, on the part of the resident population. The has resulted in a damage to both parties.

GOLD AND BUSINESS.--The fall of gold as low as 25 has taken everybody by surprise. Some think it indicates a steady return to special payments, and others think it portends a grand commercial and business collapse. We never pay much attention to the hopes of very sanguine people, nor to the fears of very despondent people;

THE CIVIL RIGHTS BILL. Prominent members of Congress say the President will to-morrow return to the Senate the Civil Rights Bill, with his objections, while others assert that the message is already prepared. THE SECRETARY AND THE LOAN BILL. In the face and eyes of the fact that a letter was read from the Secretary of the Treasury, just previous to the passage of the amended loan bill in the House.

AMERMAN.--In Brooklyn, on Sunday, March 25, HENRY V., son of John D. Amerman, aged 18 years and 4 days. The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend the funeral service this (Monday) afternoon at 4 o'clock, from No. 395 Hudson-av. The remains will be taken to Sommerville, N. J., Tuesday morning, for interment.

Officer HYDE, of the Sixth Precinct, arrested FREDERICK FRAZIER, a Scotchman, on a charge of having effected a burglarious entry into Room No. 21 of the hotel situated at No. 02 Chatham-street, and stealing a quantity of bed-clothing and other fittings valued at $32. The accused was met by the proprietor, CHARLES WATERMAN, in the corridor, having the stolen properly in his possession.

The United States receiving ship Constellation, Commander CLARY, stationed at Norfolk, will be relieved in a few days by the line-of-battle ship New Hampshire, Lieut.-Commander LAW. The Constellation has been ordered to the Philadelphia Navy-yard.

Please correct the statement in Saturday's World that Hon. N. D. SPERRY will vote for Mr. ENGLISH for Governor. He will for Gen. HAWLEY. The New-Haven Palladium denounces the World's falsehood, and says:

The United States vs. The Steamship Victor and Cargo, and Steamship Victor, Master and others vs. United States.--These are cross appeals in prize from the District Court of the United States for the Southern district of Florida, in which port the steamship and her cargo were libelled as prize of war, and subsequently acquitted and ordered to be restored to the owners, by the judgment of that Court ;

MAJOR-GEN. SETH WILLIAMS. The country has heard, with much sorrow, of the death of Brevet Major-Gon. SETH WILLIAMS, so long and so well known in connection with the Army of the Potomac. He graduated at West Point in the class of 1842, and among his classmates were Gen. W. S. ROSECRANS, Gen. JOHN NEWTON, Gen. GEORGE SYKES, Gen. JOHN POPE, Maj. BENTON, of the Ordnance Department and others, distinguished for their services in the war.

Mr. COOKE has made an interesting book. His pen is lively, spirited sad dashing, almost to recklessness; and in this work it treats of a character around which clustered innumoraide incidents, that could not fail to attract and Listen the attention of the reader, if they were well told, as they certainly are in this case.

Hon. John V. L. Prayn: DEAR SIR: My work last term left me no leisure to look into the history of the Income Tax, and verify the views which I had propounded in the conversation to which your letter refers. And term had scarcely ended when I was unexpectedly but unavoidably called away from Oxford to a place out of the way of political books and information.

The new residence of JAY COOKE, the banker, is situated on Chelton Hills, eight miles from Philadelphia, and is built in the French style, with steep slate roofs and massive plastered chimneys. It is now spite finished, exteriorly, and will contain fifty bed chambers, a chapel, a gymnasium, a library, and all accessories to the palatial home of a Christian banker.

CAUTION.--There have been served very large robberies of bonds and money in this City of late; and in each of the cases the robbers have eluded all attempts at detection or capture. The cases, however, are being "wrought up" with all the skill of the proper branch of the police force;

The following telegram from President JOHNSON to the lately elected Mayor of New-Orleans appears in the Journals of that city: WAR DEPARTMENT, March 17, 1866. To John T. Monroe: Your telegrams of to-day just received. In answer the ??to I send you a copy of the telegram sent by me to Mayor KENNEDY, in regard to the Mayoralty of New-Orleans.

At the meeting of theo Charles S. Spencer Club of the Sixteenth Ward, last evening, in Washington Hall, Eighth-avenue and Eighteenth-street, Mr. WILLIAM TERHUNE, President, Dr. HENRY F. RANNEY, in a telling opening speech, introduced Mr. HORACE GREELEY. Mr. GREELEY said: The war has happily shown the world that the country is not a confederacy, not a mere alliance, but a compact nation, a nation to which our first allegiance is due.

BRIDDON.--On Sunday, March 25, aged 7 years and 8 months, BLANCHE, the second daughter of Charles K. and Martha Briddon. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend the funeral from the residence of her father, Dr. Briddon, No. 33 Amity-St., on Wednesday, the 28th inst., at 1 o'clock. BARLOW.--At Elizabeth, N. J., on Monday, March 26, GRACE, wife of Charles Barlow, aged 36 years.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Miss KELLOGG'S benefit last evening, when "L' Etoile du Nord" was played, exceeded even the best expectations of her friends. The house was crowded, not only in those better places which friendship might be expected to occupy, but in the upper regions where the masses utter their verdict.

Two engagements have taken place at Paras, Northern Mexico. The Liberals under MARANGO were defeated by Gen. DOUAY. The Liberals, reinforced by Gen. TREVANO, afterward attacked the French under Baron Du BRIAR, who was killed, with 100 men, except four who were captured.

PROTECTION AGAINST THE SAVAGES.--The Spring migration Westward over the Great Plains is commencing; and notwithstanding the attractions and invitations of the various Southern States, from Virginia to Texas, it is quite certain that a vast body of people from different parts of the country will wend their way to the Missouri River, and thence across the Plains to the Rocky Mountains or the Pacific Coast.

The Committee of Investigation into the charges of fraud brought by Supervisor ELY against the New County Court-House Committee, met yesterday at 3 1/2 P. The "Rescript" or reply of the Emperor of Austria given to the Hungarian Parliament in the beginning of March is another act in the great drama passing now in the Austrian Empire. Constitutionalism is struggling with Imperialism, and each step taken by either party is a historical event.

THE WEATHER.--At 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning the mercury stood at 14 deg. and at 8:30 it marked 20 deg. At noon it had risen above the freezing point, but the wind was piercingly cold. According to DELATOUR's record the weather has not been so cold at this period of the year for ten years past.

Mails for Europe, rid Boston and Liverpool, per steamer Africa, close here to-day at 5:30 P. M. Mails for Havana and the West Indies,por steamer Eagle, close Wednesday at 2 P. M. Mails for St. Thomas, the West Indies and Brazil, per steamer Havana, close Thursday at 2 P. M. The Havana calls al Rio, Para, Pernambuco and Bahia.

QUARRELS AMONG OFFICERS.--We observe that Gen. FRANKLIN has published some severe strictures upon Gen. BURNSIDE'S recently published report of his military operations. We understand, also, that Gen. BUTLER has all ready for publication a self-defensive, quasiofficial volume, in which GRANT and not a few other high personages are sharply handled.

It had been expected that the Reconstruction Committee would this afternoon report the testimony of Gen. LEE and others as to the States of Virginia and North and South Carolina, but Senator HOWARD had not concluded his examination of the report prepared in his absence, and consequently the evidence was not presented to Congress. It may be looked for tomorrow.

THE CANADIANS.--The Canadian volunteers will go back to their homes very much disappointed that they have not had the opportunity of measuring either swords or legs with the Fenians. They have been brim fill of fight for a month past, and have been in daily expectation of seeing the enemy make his appearance over the border.

The new and elegant steamship Arizona, of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, J. MAURY, commanding, has just arrived on her first passage, having left New-York on the lst inst. The city government is still disorganized. The Governor refuse to recognize the elected Recorders. There have been heavy rains on the Upper Red River, and navigation is excellent. Continued reports are received of damage to the levee by high floods from the Upper Mississippi.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER moved to amend the journal by striking out the vote of Mr. STOCKTON on the question of his seat in the Senate. After a long debate Mr. SUMNER offered in lieu of the pending motion a resolution declaring that the vote of Mr. STOCKTON be not received in determining the question of his seat in the Senate.

If we had true, able, and well-known statesmen at Washington in this crisis, to speak authoritatively in our behalf, their presence would be invaluable. They could counteract the effort now being made to hoodwink the North as to the true position of the South. But since they are not, there, we deem it our bounden duty to speak out so that there may be no misapurehension on this vital question.
Mr. SESSIONS introduced a bill incorporating the Fire-Proof Iron Tank Petroleum Company. The bill authorizing the trustees of the village of ?? to purchase a steam fire-engine was passed.

Some of the latest reports of the Assistant Commissioners of the Freedmen's Bureau have been laid before the United States Sonate, agreeably to a resolution of that body. Twenty-two different papers are included in the return. And the officers making these reports rank from Colonels to Brevet MajorGenerals.

The following letter was found on a person captured in the Department of Washington in the early, part of 1864. He turned out to be a messenger from the rebel emissaries in Canada to the Richmond authorities, trying to make his way through our lines into Virginia.

MR. STOCKTON'S VOTE ON THE CONTESTED ELECTION CASE. Mr. SUMNER rose to a question of privilege. He moved to amend the journal by striking out the vote of Mr. STOCKTON, in the question of his seat. As the motion was of some importance he had reduced it to writing.

A small boat belonging to the schooner Thomas Jefferson, lying in the Roads, from Chesapeake Bay, bound to New-Haven with oysters, capsized with four men in it, while coming ashore. Three of the men were rescued by a boat from the schooner Typhoon, but the fourth, whose name is unknown, drowned before assistance could reach him.

Every day complicates the Connecticut election. The nominations for Governor of men equally true to the country in her hour of peril was sufficiently embarrassing. But the efforts of both parties to draw the President into the canvass adds to the excitement. He evidently felt that he ought not to be drawn into the vortex, and while each claimed to be the friend of his administration, he kept aloof.

The Italians, excepting COLYTAGO MONTALBA, engaged in the sale of counterfeit fractional currency, were bound over by the United States Commissioner to-day. B. B. In the Texas Convention an ordinance has been adopted providing for the appointment of a Commission by the Government to proceed to Washington to represent definitely the condition of the inhabitants along the Mexican frontier. The Kiclapoos are particularly complained of. Five companies of seventy men each (mounted) are to be organized for present service.

The Inquirer Newspaper Company have purchased all the property on Vine-street, between the Gas-office and Mozart Gardens, on which they will erect a magnificent opera-house, with printing offices in the rear.

The rejection of Hon. JOHN P. STOCKTON has set the Legislature busily at work preparing to fill the vacancy. This will protract the session beyond the expected day of adjournment. The name of A. G. CATTELL, of Camden, is whispered among the members likely to be appointed.

At a meeting held here yesterday to raise funds to provide for the families of the Montreal volunteers on duty, there were about fifty persons present, who subscribed twenty-five thousand dollars, and it is supposed there will be no difficulty in raising fifty thousand.

During the interval between Saturday night and Monday morning, the United States Bonded Warehouse, No. 116 Washington-street, corner on Carlisle, occupied by JOHN B. HOBBY, was entered by a gang of burglars, who opened five or six cases of hatter's silks, and stripping of the wrappers, numbers and marks, packed up and carried off nearly $5,000 worth of that description of goods.

The residents of Bloomfield, N. J., were startled on Monday by the announcement that Mr. JOHN M. BIDDULPH, one of the most respected citizens of the town, had committed suicide byhanging. Shortly before noon on the day named he left the house, remarking to his daughters that he was tired of life, but no thought that he meditated violence to himself was suggested to them by his manner.

LUCY RUSHTON'S THEATRE.--The old story of "Valentine and Orson" has been used by Mr. JAMES SCHONDERO in the construction of his new burlesque called "Valiant Valentine." It has served many other writers, and, in most cases. satisfactorily. the legendary groundwork admits of any quantity of superstructure, and is favorable to the contrasts of this style of piece.

CHANGE OF STEAMERS.--The New-York Mail Steamship Company have substituted the Merrimac for the morning Star for New-Orleans, to leave on Saturday next, the 31st inst. The Merrimac had been refitted, an upper cabin added and her saloons are furnished with great elegance and comfort.

BILLS REPORTED. Authorizing selection of a site for another State prison. Providing for the equitable distribution of the Safety Fund. Amending the charter of the Dime Savings Bank of Now-York. Incorporating the Blank Book Binders' Benevolent Union of New-York. For the relief of the Seamens' Fund and Retreat. For the relief of the Butternut Woolen and Cotton Manufacturing Company.

BRADLEY T. JOHNSON, who left Maryland at the outbreak of the rebellion and subsequently returned during the invasion of the State as a General, commanding a rebel brogade, was arrested yesterday by United States Marshal BONIFANT, on a warrant issued on an indictment for treason, found by the Grand Jury in August last.

Whatever be the result of the contest in Connectiout, the provoking spectacle witnessed there will not be without its use, if it lead the Union Party to study the consequences which the action of the Radicals in Congress must inevitably produce.
THE COAST SURVEY REPORT. The Coast Survey report for the year ending November, 1885, was laid before the Senate, and on motion of Mr. SHERMAN, was referred to the Committee on Printing.

The late Imperial disaster at Parras is confirmed. The French Gen. DUVAY, with 1,500 men, coming up from Saltillo to protect the Imperial garrison at Parras, had his retreat cut off, and one-fifth of the Liberals attacked him, capturing the whole force and some munitions of war. The Liberal loss was trifling.

A WARNING TO HOUSEKEEPERS AND THE POLICE.--Within a few weeks a system of robbery has boon practiced, chiefly in the central portion of the City, between Eighth and Twentyeighth-street, which should keep both housekeepers and the Police on the alert.

THE VETO AND ITS RECEPTION. The Veto Message did not cause much surprise, for it has been anticipated for several days. It is very full and very able. Mr. BINGHAM, who is probably the ablest lawyer in the House, says that its legal objections to the bill are unanswerable;

The steamer Pacific has arrived from Portland, Oregon, with $100,000 in treasure. The Republicans called a meeting at Portland to indorse President JOHNSON, when Gov. GIBBS, who was present, arose and denounced the meeting as a meeting of Copperheads. He with others then left the meeting.

A very large and enthuslaslic Union meeting was held here this evening. Hon. N. D. SPERRY, Postmaster of this city, whom the Copperheads have falsely accused of supporting ENGLISH, presided, and on taking the chair, made a most telling speech, indorsing HAWLEY and the Union platform. Gen. GARFIELD delivered one of the best speeches of the campaign.

BOLAND.--On Monday evening, March 26, WM. BOLAND, in the 60th year of his age. His friends are invited to attend his funeral this (Wednesday) morning at 9 o'clock, from St. Peter's Church, Barclay-st., without further notice. BOYD.--On Tuesday, March 27, LOUISE, daughter of Peter J. and Elizabeth Boyd, in the 9th year of his age.

The Message of the President announcing his veto of the Civil Rights Bill, which we publish in full in other columns, may not command universal assent. But we venture to think that few state papers have ever been given to the world that will so thoroughly compel the attention of thinking men of whatever creed, or kindred, or party.

Near Cambridge, Mass., a company of gipsies has located one hundred in number. They obtain their livelihood chiefly by trafficking in horses, although some of the women are said to gather considerable money from the credulous by telling fortunes. The band is governed by a queen. She is married and has one child, and lives in great luxury compared with the style of her subordinates.

LARGE COTTON SHIPMENT.-- Extensive shipments of cotton were made from this port during the week ending last evening, the aggregate having been 16,609 bales, valued at ?3,111,335, of which to Liverpool there were exported 13,257 bales, valued at $2,484,442; to Havre 2,151 bales, valued at $403,776; and to Bremen 1,099 bales,

The steamer Connecticut ran high and dry on the coal bed, in the vicinity of Bristol, last night. She will probably be got off this morning. The water in the Hudson was lower yesterday than has been known before for a number of years.

Cornelius F. Buck, plaintiff in error, vs. Horace N. Colbatk, defendant in error.--The defendant in error brought two actions of trespass in the Minnesota State Court against Duck, plaintiff in error, in August and September, 1861, for taking and carrying away goods belonging to him, on attachment against other parties.

An evening paper, some days ago, complained of ruffianism on the Staten Island Ferry-boats. It is high time something was done. For years, in the Summer season, and especially on Sundays, these boats have been the stamping-ground of low ruffians and pickpockets.

FROM DOVER TO CALAIS.--The Emperor of the French is doubtless one of the master spirits of the age. He has already nearly accomplished what Hannibal would have been thankful for, and what Mon Oncle would have hailed with delight, in his great tunnel through the Alps. But a larger scheme of his is it seems in embryo.

We understand that the American News Company will soon issue, as agents for the proprietor-a gentleman of means and reputation-the first numbr of a new fortnightly magazine, to be called the Galaxy. The design is to furnish, in a cheap and elegant form, the bet serial stories now appearing in Eagland by the most famous novelists,

EXPORT TAX ON OOTTON. Another joint resolution to amend the Constitution was born to-day in the House. It came from Mr. STEVENS, who had been busily engaged in a conferenee with Mr. BINGHAM, and was to the effect that it should be legal after its adoption to levy an export duty on cetton of five cents per pound.

The other day a telegraphic item informed us of the fitting out of national vessels to protect the interests of American fishermen on the coasts of British North America. A cotemporary enumerates seven vessels, carrying eighty-six guns, as in course of preparation for service in this "flying squadron."

The investigations into the condition of Washington Market have revealed a more shocking state of things than the public had even supposed. There can be no question, if ever there was any, that the whole affair ought to be swept away.

ANNOUNCEMENT OF THE DEATH OF SENATOR FOOT. After the reading of the journal, Mr. SUMNER rose and said: Mr. PRESIDENT: A great bereavement has fallen upon the Senate. Mr. FOOT, a Senator of Vermont, one of our most honored associates, and the oldest among us in continuous service, died this morning, at 8 o'clock.

The Tribune has chosen, with a singular infelicity, to bring up again for public consideration the recent contest between a large majority of our citizens and the conductors of that journal, in regard to the Health Bill. It is a record which will always tell most strongly with all fair-minded men against the public spirit and the supposed desire for the public good of the journal in question.

Rev. Dr. CLARK, of the Reformed Dutch Church, who made the opening prayer in the Assembly this morning, thanked God that the principles of "civil rights" were planted deep in the hearts of the people: prayed that the Lord would sustain Congress in its efforts to maintain liberty and justice, but omitted to include the President in his invocation.

A PLAIN STATEMENT OF FACTS. While offering my celebrated medicines to the afflicted, I fool that I present to the public nothing novel or strange. The success of my medicines in the cure of Pulmonory Complaints is too well established to admit of skepticism; their effect is too certain to require any combat with that prejudice which usually assails the introduction of a new article to the public.

THE PENIONS OF DISABLED SOLDIERS.--Our remarks the other day on the case of the poverty-smitten and helpless soldier, "JOHN RABUS, from Gotha," who committed suicide because, as he alleged in a note written immediately previous to his last act, he could not get any response to his application for the small 'pension to which he considered himself entitled as a soldier disabled in the service,

HASTY WRITING.--The World would not weaken its political arguments by a little more care as to its facts. In speaking of the veto of the Civil Rights Bill, the editor says: "Mr. DUOLITTLE and Mr. RAYMOND voted for the Civil Rights Bill, as well as Mr. SUMNER and Mr. STEVENS."

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Although the doors of the Academy are temporarily closed to the public, there is no lack of industry within them. The forces are engaged from morning till night in the rehearsal of MEYERBERR'S greatest work. "Les Huguenots," which will be produced on Monday with a caste better in almost every leading respect that we have yet had in this City.

William Young Brown, plaintiff in error, vs. William C. Tarkington et al., defendants in error.This was an action of assumpsit, brought by the plaintiff against the defendants, upon four promissory notes, signed by S. L. Campbell, President of the Bank of Tekama, payable to plaintiff, and amounting to $12,877 50. Also to recover $2,500 upon bank bills, issued by that bank--a bank doing business in Burt County, Nebraska Territory.

THE POLICE AND THE FERRIES.--A consideration arising out of the outrages upon ferryboats committed by rowdies during the excursion season, seems worth notice. Why cannot police be detailed for permanent duty on each ferry-boat at all seasons of the year. A ferry-boat is, to all intents and purposes, in the same category as a street or road,

The steamer Tonawanda, Capt. TEAL, from New-Orleans, bound to New.York, with a cargo of erdy nce stores, old muskets, , arrived here yesterd by disabled, in tow of the steamer Marmion. The Tonawanda left New-Orleans on last Sunday morning, and had good weather until Thursday, when a gale sprung up from southeast to south.

A DISHONDEST SERVANT.--Mr. EDWARD E. KENDRICK, of No. 20 East Seventeenth-street, caused the arrest of WM. KENNY, yesterday, by Officer DUNLAP, of the Seventeenth Precinct, whom he charged with having, on the 18th inst., stolen a lady's gold watch valued at $100, a revolver, valued at $15, and a silver dollar, and on the 25th inst., a $100 United States 3-20 bond.

After the announcement of the death of Senator FOOT, of Vermont, the Senate adjourned. In the House, Mr. WILSON, of Iowa, from the Judiciary Committce, reported back a bill providing that all moneys raised in the United States for the support of refugees or freedmen, and received by any officer of the United States Army, shall be charged against such officer. The bill was passed.

A CRIME WITHOUT A PUNISHMENT.--We think it is time some of those individuals who commit murder accidentally by the careless use of firearms were taken hold of by the law and punished, either for the murder or the carelessness. Only last week a youth in Brooklyn, while carelessly handling firearms, accidentally killed his mother;

The Metropolitan Board of Health held a special session yesterday afternoon, and hastened to the reading, by Counselor EATON, of a code of laws which he had framed under the orders of the Board. The new code, which may be considerably modified, covers all those corporation ordinances in the remotest degree touching the public health which have hitherto been a dead letter, as well as all other laws con.

A SHIP OF THE "OLD SCHOOL."--Last week there sailed from Hull, amid the cheers of a great multitude, the bark Truclore, the only vessel dispatched this year from Hull to the Davis Strails' whale fisheries. The Truelore is under the command of Captain WELLS, a name associated with the most successful period of the whale fisheries. The True love is one of the oldest vessels afloat.

BOYD.--On Tuesday, March 27, LOUISE, daughter of Peter J. and Elizabeth Boyd, in the 9th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Thursday, the 29th inst., at 9 A. M., from the residence of her parents, No. 61 Bond-st. The remains will be taken to White Plains for interment in the 11 A. M. train from 26th-st.

The Judiciary Committee of the Senate have reported favorably upon Senator HA?? bill for the reorganization of the Federal Judicial system, and the bill, amended in some respects in Committee, is now before the Senate for discussion. We have before pointed out some of the objections to the bill, and we see no reason to withdraw those objections.

SOLOMON FOOT, of VERMONT. The death of this distinguished and honored United States Senator and citizen of Vermont involves the loss by that State and the country at large, of one of the noblest men to whom the terms patriot and statesman lave ever been applied.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It seems to me that your paper, in one or two issues, has unintentionally misrepresented the position of Gen. HAWLEY and the Union Party of Connecticut. Neither Gon. HAWLEY nor the Union Party make any issue with the President or Congress in this canvass. We are endeavoring to elect the Union ticket, composed of true and loyal men who have sustained the Government during the war,

FIRE IN FULTON-STREET.--At 6:15 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out on the fifth floor of the building No. 142 Fulton-street, occupied by E. LAW, tailor. LOSS, $300. Insured for $1,000 in the Indemnity Insurance Company. The fire originated from a furnace used by Mr. LAW to heat his irons. The fourth floor is occupied by HUNTINGTON, LORETZ Co., electrotypers.

The Senatorial question begins to be exciting. The House to-day passed a resolution to go into join meeting to elect a United States Senator on Wednesday next, but when it came to the Senate it was lost by a vote of 8 yeas to 10 nays. Mr. SCOVEL said he opposed the resolution until he know the man. He wanted a radical man, and no more conservatism, which had cursed and cost the country enough.

THE EIGHT HOURS' SYSTEM.--The bill establishing eight hours' labor as a legal day's work in this State, was defeated yesterday in the Assembly, and a subsequent motion to reconsider was lost by a still more decisive vote than the original measure.

THE POLICE AND THE FERRIES ONCE MORE.-The suggestion of the TIMES in favor of detailing policemen to preserve order on the ferry-boats and protect passengers from the lawlessness of organized gangs of ruffians, has brought out an expression from the Board of Police Commissioners.

GIFT ENTERPRISES.--Notwithstanding the frequent exposures which these swindles have received in the public press, they appear to flourish as heretofore, bearing out the old adage that " as long there are fools in the world there will always be knaves." Scarcely a day passes that Mayor HOFFMAN does not receive communications complaining of the swindlers who operate these " enterprises."

THE FUNERAL OF SENATOR FOOT. The funeral services over the remains of Senator FOOT in the Senate Chamber to-day were of the most column, impressive and affecting character. Strong hearts were moved to tears, and weeping was almost universal during the touching recital of the noble Senator's beautiful religious experience, and his farewell moments with those he loved.

This is Fast Day throughout the State, a fast day appointed by the authorities as an occasion for penitence and prayer for the good and bad people of this greatly distracted Commonwealth. Surely, if ever people needed to repent, the Democrats here and hereabouts are in the category, especially such of them as edit and control "Opposition" newspapers, whose columns teem now-a-days with falsehoods as malignant as they are unavailing.

INCENDIARY FIRE.--About 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the old starch factory in the upper part of Wayne-street, Jersey City. The firemen repaired to the scene soon after the alarm was given, but owing to the fact that a high wind prevailed at the time, the building was entirely gutted out.

The canvass in Connecticut is spirited and exciting. The persistent efforts of the friends of both candidates to extract or screw from the President an expression of preference, has confused and bothered both parties. The President, with quite enough to occupy his time and thoughts legitmately, endeavored to keep out of Connecticut, leaving her electors to act upon their own convictions.

MUTINY ON SHIP BOARD.-A mutiny occurred yesterday on board the American ship Constellation, of New-York, Capt. HOXIE, bound to Liverpool, while lying off Bedloe's Island, ready for sea. The crew refused toobey the orders of the Captain, who then called to his assistance the Harbor Police Boat, but as her officers could not force the men to do their duty, Capt. HOXIE was obliged to seek other assistance.

About 7 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the banking office of Messrs. DUNCAN, SHERMAN Co. , by the porter who has charge of the office. The flames were subdued without much difficulty, and the total loss, it is supposed, will not exceed $2,000. The fire originated beneath, or near, an alcove in which was a coil of hot-water pipes for heating the office.

To-day an event transpired so novel in its character, and so remarkably calculated to affect the relations of the Indians to our Government, that I am induced to give you a brief account of it. A daughter of SPOTTED TAIL, one of the chiefs among the Sioux, died two weeks age, at their rendezvous on Powder River, some 260 miles from this fort. She was an interesting girl of 18 sears of age.

To Gov. A. J. Hamilton, Austin, Texas: I was highly gratified to receive your dispatch, and to hear that your Convention was organized. I hope all will end well. It is of the utmost importance that the proceedings of your Convention be prudent and of the most temperate character, vindicating loyalty, and of the entire willingness to acknowledge the supremacy of the Constitution and of the obedience to the laws of the United States.

A NEW ANESTHETIC PROCESS.--A new process for producing what is technically called "local anesthesia," but which we know by the humbler and less jaw-breaking name of "a deadened sensation," has been discovered and brought into practice by Dr. RICHARDSON. It consists in direction on the part of the body to be operated upon perfectly pure ether in the form of infinitely minute subdivision of fine spray.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The statement of Mr. KIMBALL, in your issue of this morning, seems to call for a few words in reply, that my position in the matter of Christian Union may be properly understood. The Union Association was originated for the purpose of uniting Christians of different denominations, and Mr. KIMBALL pressed me most importunately to identify myself with the movement.

STORMY MARCH.--We do not remember for many years a March so blustering, cold and uncomfortable generally as that which passed into eternity last night. The fairest, loveliest day of its thirty-one was Good Friday, the solemn anniversary of the grandest event that has marked the course of time.

APPLETON Co., to be followed by other smaller ones, and a very largo and valuable one from J. E. TILTON Co., of Boston.

THE SOLDIERS' DEPOT CLOSED.--The New-York Soldiers' Depot, Nos, 50 and 52 Howard-street, was closed on Saturday last, and the employes, were discharged. After a successful career for over four years, the depot goes out of existence, full, of honor, and thus another landmark of the secess war disappears. Nearly 150,000 soldiers have been hospitably received at the Home since its first establishment,

THEFT OF A GOLD WATCH. JOHN M. EMERSON, residing at the Empire Hotel, on the corner of Third-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street, caused the arrest of GEORGE LAWDON alias JOHN DACKER, by Officer MURPHY, of the Fifteenth Precinct, on a charge of having stolen a gold watch and silk chain, valued at $125.

ANSER.--At Sing Sing, Saturday, March 3, of consumption PURDY A. ANSER, aged 48 years, 5 months and 16 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Tuesday, April 3, at 10 o'clock P. M., from his late residence. Friends taking the 10 A. M. train arrive in time to attend the funeral, and return by the 4:14 P. M. train.

GORMAN, Acting Sergeant-at-Arms, with his assistants, to. gether with the friends of the deceased Senator, arrived on Saturday at 4 o'clock. They were joined at Salem by a committee from this place. The following card appears in the Anti-Slavery Standard: The Thirty-third Annual Meeting of the American Anti-Slavery Society will be held in the City of New-York, at the Church of the Puritans, on Union-square, on Tuesday, May 8, at 10 o'clock. In the evening there will be another public meeting at 7 1/2 o'clock. The names of speakers for these meetings will be duly announced.

THE VOTE ON THE VETO DELAYED. A dispatch was received this evening from Senator DOOLITTLE, stating that the funeral of the late Senator FOOT had been postponed until Tuesday, and consequently the Senators who have charge of the remains of the deceased cannot be hero until next Thursday. The vote on the veto will not, therefore, be taken in the Senate before Thursday or Friday;

THE RENEWED MARCH OF THE OHOLERA.-The cholera is said to have made its appearance in several districts of Germany--a warning to us we can hardly hope to escape the scourge. The large tide of emigration from German ports alone presents a source of danger which warns us to be vigilant.

From all accounts, there is a reasonable prospect that by the vote which will be cast to-day in Connecticut, Gen. HAWLEY will be elected Governor by a small majority. This result, we venture to think, will be primarily due to the patriotic record of the candidate during the war.

A meeting of the Republican citizens of Camden County, N. J., was held at the Court-house, in Camden, on Saturday evening. The meeting was large. Resolutions censuring the course of Senator SCOVEL, and urging the election of A. G. CATTELL, were passed unanimously. The meeting was not presided over by, nor were any of the officers, politicians.

THE CITY RAILROAD PROJECTS.--We print elsewhere one of the most prominent of the many plans for railroads in this City now before the Legislature. This bill proposes an underground, a surface, and an elevated track from the Battery to Central. Park, to be built not upon existing streets, but upon property bought for the purpose in the centre of blocks adjoining Broadway.

SINGULAR AND SUDDEN DEATH.--A German named EDWARD RUSSEKAMMER, died very suddenly about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at his residence, No. 16 Coles-street, Jersey City. Tile deceased, who was a jeweler by trade, and about forty years of age, went out to the barber-shop, returning home about 9:30 A. M., apparently in good health.

MATTERS OF INTEREST IN CONGRESS. Both Houses of Congress were largely attended by visitors to-day in the expectation of hearing the Civil Rights Bill and the veto discussed in the Senate, and the Dodge-Brooks election case in the House; but there was disappointment in both instances. By general consent the veto was postponed, and Mr. DAWES, the Chairman of the Election Committee, did not call up the contested seat case in the House.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S opera of "Les Huguenots" was revived last evening by Mr. MARETZEK. Having been carefully rehearsed and liberally put on the stage, its success was, of course, insured. It would have attracted large and enthusiastic audiences at any period of the season. An additional point in its favor just now is the existence of a sort of MEYERBEER fanaticism.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. Before Recorder Hackett. The Court of General Sessions organized for the business of the April term yesterday. Owing to the fact that Recorder HACKETT was to make his debut in a charge to the Grand Jury, there was a large attendance of members of the Bar.

The property in the Parish of Plaquemine, belonging to the late LUCIEN BONAPARTE, sold recently for $30,000. The Company sent two months ago to look into the reported guerrilla depredations in Morehouse and Cowall Parishes, has returned, having found all quiet in those localities. Red River navigation is excellent. Cotton-boats are actively bringing down cotton.

Yesterday was opening day of the regular Spring trade sale of books under the hammer of Messrs. LEAVITT, STREBEIGH CO., successors to J. E. COOLEY. At 9:30 o'clock some forty to fifty representatives of the trade were present, quite a number of these being from the Western States, and two or three from Canada. The Eastern cities were also well represented, as were Philadelphia and Kentucky.

Y., from whence, in 1812, he went into the Army. Soon after his marriage,

To-morrow night the Opera Ball, which was announced before Lent, and which for a long time has been impatiently expected, is to take place. The tickets of admission, which are limited in number, have for some time past been sought at an advance upon their first cost, but it has become next to impossible to fund them.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER called up his resolution, offered yesterday, calling upon the Postmaster-General and the Secretary of the Treasury to report to the Senate whether persons have been employed in their Departments since December last, without taking the oath required by law, which was passed-yeas 25, Days 8.

[OFFICIAL.] BOARD OF COUNCILMEN. STATED SESSION, MONDAY, April 2, 1866--2 o'clock P.M. The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the Chair, and the following members:

ANNIVERSARY OF THE OCCUPATION OF RICHMOND.-Instend of moralizing on the occurrence of the anniversary of the entrance of our army into Richmond, we will merely indulge in an expression of gratification that a brief year has done so much to rebuild the ruins of the war.

The political atmosphere of Europe grows more and more excited upon the question of peace or war. It is thought by the majority of observers that the latter solution is theo only one that will be attempted, and that the contest will soon be commenced by a coup-de-main upon Holstein by King WILLIAM.

Since Wednesday night there has been a report of negro insurrections on OVIEDO'S plantations, and also on an estate of MARTIN HERNANDEZ, and on two others near Bolondron. The government sent this morning cavalry, and infantry are now preparing to go to the scene of trouble. There is little danger to be apprehended of a general insurrection at press. ent, but many feel that it will come sooner or later.

The Texas Convention is drawing near its end. Five men have been appointed to convey the ordinances it has passed to Washington for inspection. Gen. HOUSTON'S widow is to have paid to her the full salary of her husband's term as Governor, of which she was despoiled by his untimely taking, off in 1861 by the Secession Convention.

BENEDICT.--At Bethel, Conn., on Tuesday, April 3 FANNY, widow of the late Elizur Benedict, in the 61st year of her age. Her funeral will take place from her late residence, on Thursday, April 5, late 11/3 o'clock P. M. BRIGGS.--At Philadelphia on Sunday, April 1, PHEBE BRIGGS, in the 78th year of her age.

It is difficult to conceive of any rational and just ground upon which objection may be urged to the decisive step just taken by the President. In formally, declaring the insurrection at an end, and proclaiming the reconstruction of the Southern States, and their title to the rights and immunities belonging to integral parts of the Union, he has simply exercised the authority belonging to his office under the Constitution.

THE NEGRO CELEBRATION IN RICHMOND.--We fear that the Southern people will be compelled to boar for the future, with the best grace they can, very many such episodes as the negro commomoration of their emanicipation.

The last news from England is not consoling to those who looked hopefully to the stability of Lord RUSSELL'S Ministry. Ten years ago the late Mr. EDWARD ELLICE-the most sagacious Englishman of his time, and the relative, by marriage, of two of the most powerful Whig families in England-caused the defeat of the Reform Bill, then introduced, by simply announcing that nobody seemed to care about it.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT--SOUTHERN DISTRICT. Before Judge Benediet John Yeaton, et al., vs. Cornelius Vanderbill. This was a libel for collision filed by the owners of the brig Mechanic, which was run into by the steamer Ariel, of which the respondent was owner on the night of Jan. 3, 1866. The brig had anchored in the after. noon about a mile astern of the steamer, which was also at anchor.

We have had another day of uproar, of ma??cuvering, or wire-pulling, and of excitement. The Democrats, who knew, of course, of Senator WRIGHT'S perilous trip to Washington, are in constant communication with friends at the National Capital, who sent bulletins of the Senator's health. and indicated the improbability of his surviving the terrible rush of blood to the heart.

From the Tribune. This victory has been won against a combination of adverse influences such as cannot occur twice in twenty years. Mrs ENGLISH was a very popular candidate; the outside official influences told heavily against Gen. HAWLEY; but the main discouragement was the fatal, treacherous failure of the Republicans of Connecticut to place their State squarely on the platform of Equal Rights and Impartial Freedom in the Suffrage Election last September.

Mr. GREELEY (for he chooses to be personal) is strangely oblivious. His article of Saturday turns truth inside out. Indeed, one rarely witnesses such a lamentably detective memory: "The TIMES bears false witness in asserting that 'the Tribune had its reason for advocating a separation from tho Slave States.'

THE NEW-YOUR COLLECTORSHIP. The political atmosphere has been in a continual buzz to-day over the New-York Collectorship. That somebody had been or was soon to be appointed everybody asserted very positively, and a list of seven or eight names was mentioned during the day, each of whom was said to be the man. The supporters of DAVIS, particularly the mathematical Professor, were sanguine that the contest had been narrowed down to DAVIS and SMYTHE.

The heaviest losers by the disastrous fire which occurred on the Hyde and Egbert farm on Saturday morning are the following: W. H. HALDEMAN, 4,000 barrels of oil in tanks and barrels, and 2,000 empty barrels.

BILLS REPORTED. Incorporating the Ladies Christian Union. Ordered to a third reading. To prevent the introduction and spread of the rhinderpeet. Incorporating the Newburgh Female Seminary. Ordered to a third reading. To provide for the equitable distribution of the Safety Fund. Ordered to a third reading.

The members of the New-York State Associated Press met here to-day and elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President-A. M. CLAPP; Secretary and Treasurer-ELLIS H. ROBERTS; Executive Committee-GEORGE G. COOPER, of the Roohester Union, Dr. HALSTEAD, of the Syracuse , Courier, JOHN FRANCIS, of the Troy Times.

Mr. LITTLEJOHN this morning introduced a bill to incorporate the North American Mail Steamship Company, and obtained unanimous consent to refer the same to the Committee on Judiciary, with power to report complete. The bill names the following corporators, viz.: Wm. H. Webb, Marshall 0. Roberts, David Dows, Wm. Butler Duncan, Solon Humphreys, Pickering Clark, Robert L. Taylor, Wm. H. Guion, John C. Bancroft Davis and their associates. The capital stock is to be $3,000,000,

Mme. Pock appeared as the heroine and fully justified the expectations of her admirers.

The State election to-day passed off very quietly, and Gen. BURNSIDE was elected Governor with so little opposition that the vote was very light. The Journal has returns from all the towns in the State except three, showing for BURNSIDE, (National Union,) 7,749: for LYMAN PIERCE, (Democrat,) 2,456 and scattering 142. The remaining towns will not materially change the relative result.

Yesterday, sixteen thousand tons of Seranton coal were sold by Mr. JOHN H. DRAPER at auction, by order of the Delaware, Lackawana and Western Railroad Company. The attendance at the sale was unusually large, and the bidding spirited. A slight advance on the prices obtained at the March sale was realized.

The minority in Congress becomes alarmingly small. The opponents of the President are welcome to make all out of the admission they please. In times of peril, in the crisis of revolution, in the hour when mena re clutching--not for party triumph or permanent party ascendency--but for national extence, overwhelming majorities supply the only hope for national unity.

The steamship Damascus, Capt. WATTS, which loft Liverpool at 2 P. M. of the 22d, and Londonderry 23d ult., arrived here at 9:45 this evening. The Damascus passed the steamer Delta yesterday, bound East. The steamship City of Manchester, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool on the 22d.

THE RAPACITY OF LANDLORDS.--There is no limit to the greed and rapacity of the so-called landlord class on this Island. A person of the name of WALKER bought the house i Eighty-third-street, of which a gentleman well known to us has a lease, and in which he lives.

The water at Sacramento is five inches higher than before this season. The country for hundreds of miles is again overflowed. Mining stocks are firm-Ophir, $732; YellowJacket, $1,005; Belcher, $355; Choller Potosi, $392 50. Arrived, ship Good Hope. MILLER, from New-York.

A curious case has just been decided in the English Divorce Court, which bears rather hardly upon the matrimonial dispensations of Utah--at least the denizens of that patriarchal Territory will think so. One HYDE married a wife in Utah, both parties being Mormons. The husband became converted and left.

The announcement in the morning papers that the veto message would be discussed in the Senate to-day, attracted a large audience, and during the delivery of Senator TRUMBULL'S speech all parts of the Senate chamber were literally crowded with spectators.

There has been within the last year or two an enormous increase in the number of eating saloons in New-York, and a corresponding increase in the number of people who live, or rather who eat, in these saloons. As recently as 1850, one might count of his fingers all the dining saloons there were in the City.

IN ELIZABETH-STREET. About 9:30 o'clock last night, a fire was disCovered in the fifth floor of building situate in rear of Nos. 53 and 55 Elizabeth-street, occupied by FREDERICK WAGNER as a cabinet shop. Owing to the inflammable nature of the contents, the flames spread through the floor with great rapidity, causing a bright light.

The facts in the case are these. After the arrest on the 27th ult., and release upon bail entered under protest, Mr. JOHNSON went to Washington and exhibited his parole and pass to Gen. GRANT. The Senatorial tompest is still raging. In the language of one of the excited Senators, the "war goes bravely on." The caucus hold last evening, at which the choice of the Republicans was shown to be Mr. CATTELL has been the theme of conversation among all of the cliques that are here engaged in the pleasant labor of wire-pulling.

MUTINY ON SHIPBORAD.--Capt. HARTT, of the Harbor Police, yesterday arrested two men named WM. DAVIS and MICHAEL DONALD, seamen on board the ship Geo. Peabody, on complaint of the first officer, GEO. N. ARMSTRONG, charging them with assault and battery. The ship arrived at this port yesterday,

The steamer Bristol, of the Merchants' Steamship Line of Bristol, R. I., was handsomely launched yesterday morning, from the ship-yard of Mr, WM. H. WEBB, at the foot of East Sixth-street. A concourse of 3,000 persons witnessed the interesting event.

The steamship Damascus arrived last evening at Portland, bringing one day's later news from Europe. The bill to abolish certain restrictions in dissenters in the University of Oxford had been ordered to a second reading in the British House of Commons. The Reform Bill was under discussion in the English journals, and anothe amendment had been offered by a Liberal member of Parliament.

One of the reforms contemplated by the new Health Commission is the rigid enforcement of the existing laws for the registration of births, marriages and deaths. The principal object of the law was the accumulation of reliable vital statisties; but a hardly less important object to be gained is the establishment of a Bureau of Record, which shall be a legal and authoritative source of proof in most questions of legitimacy and heriship.

The unfitness of Mr. THADDEUS STEVENS for the position he occupies in Congress, the hindrance he imposes upon the work of peaceful reconstruction, and the discredit brought upon the Union Party by his tone and tactics, are points upon which the intelligence and conservatism of thecountry have long been agreed.

This morning, as the 1:20 o'clock through train for Washington was passing along on the Pennsylvania Railroad track, on the west side of the Schuylkill, a small iron bridge which crosses the road, near the wrie bridge, broke down, precipitating the engine and tender into the road below.

The Officers and crew of the U. S. Iron-clad Weehawken, , Appellants, vs. The Steamer Atlanta.-This vessel, an iron-clad war steamer, taken from the rebels in battle, has been condemned as lawful prize, and the question now is on the distribution. The main and difficult question is whether the entire value is to go to the captors, or half to them and half to the Government. The act of 1862 prescribes the rule thus:

STREET BEGGIN.--The order issued yesterday to the Police demanding that the laws and ordinances against street begging and vagrancy, which have been disregarded almost entirely during the past few years in this City, should be again enforced, at least as far as arresting the offenders is concerned, will generally be regarded with favor.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, A. A. Low, Esq., President, in the Chair. The following-named gentleman were elected members: ALFRED DOUGLAS, RICHARD DOUGLAS, JOHN DOUGLAS, JOHN H. PRENTICE, J. W. DOW, W. C. THOMPSON and ABRAM WAKEMAN.

Arrived, steamship St. Louis, with New-York dates to March 11. The steamship Sierra Nevada has arrived from Portland with $83,000 in treasure. Late Manila dates report a fair quantity of last year's sugar crop left for shipment. The coming crop is likely to be an average one. Arrived brig Lubra, HOWES, from Shanghao,

FATAL CITY CAR ACCIDENT.--Yesterday morning LOUISA OTTO, aged 4 years, residing with her parents at No. 11 Avenue A, was run over near her residence by Car No. 18 of the Avenue A line. Soon after being removed from the scene of the accident death ensued. Coroner GOVER was notified to hold an inquest.

DAVID HENDERSON, of this city, has been arrested on the charge of being implicated in heavy frauds against the Government, occurring in the management of the horse and mule corrals in this vicinity. HENDERSON gave bail in the sum of $38,000. Mr. PHILLIPS and GREEN DEERLING were afterward arrested on charges of defrauding the Government. The latter was held for want of ball.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. 14th-st., corner of Irving-place. THIS EVENING, April 6, commencing at 8 o'clock, FRA DIAVOLO. Brilliant cast, including Miss Clara Louise Kellogg, Miss Fanny Stockton, Sig. Mazzoleni, Sig. Bellini, Sig. Dubreul; conductor, Carl Bergmann.

At a meeting of the principal creditors or UULVER, PENN Co., held this day, at the McHenry House, resolutions were passed unanimously, expressing entire confidence in the ability and integrity of the firm, and recommending that the assignment be canceled, and an extension granted of six, twelve, eighteen and twenty-four months. TAPLEY IS JOLLY.--The World thinks (or says, rather,) that the Connecticut election shows a great decline in the Republican Party strength. Decidedly we do not see it in that light.

DEBATE ON THE VETO--EXTRAORDINARY SPEECH OF SENATOR WADE. A few minutes before 5 o'clock P. M. the discussion in the Senate upon the Veto, unexpectedly to some, came to a conclusion. Senators DIXON and WRIGHT who have been ill, had deemed it imprudent to sit out the long session upon the mere possibility that a vote would be taken this afternoon, and beside it was not expected that a vote would be taken until to-morrow.

The latest dispatches show as yet no action by the House of Commons on Mr. GLADSTONE'S great measure, the Reform Bill. A scheme of legislation so radical as this, and so vitally important, ought to require time in its discussion.

By the arrival of the Cuba at this port yesterday, we have two days' later news from Europe. Military preparations were still going on in Austria and Prussia, but the tone of the German papers is still pacific. The rumor that England had offered her mediation in the quarrel was repeated by the Berlin correspondent of the London Times.

John A. Hosbach and Richard Wiggin, appellants, vs. John A. Porter and wife, appellees.--This is an appeal from a decree of the Supreme Court of Nebraska. In 1857 Hosbach Preempted a quarter section of land, in Douglas County, in the Territory of Nebraska, and entered thereon afterward, receiving the usual certificate of entry from the proper department.

In the United States Circuit Court this morning, there was filed by Assistant District-Attorney A. M. ROGERS, Esq., papers consisting of copies of a letter from Liout.-Gen. GRANT to President JOHNSON, and one written, in accordance with the instructions of the latter, by Attorney-General SPEED to WM. J. JONES, Esq., District-Attorney of the United States Court.

The Royal mail steamer Cuba, Capt. STONE, which left Liverpool at 1 o'clock, on the afternoon of the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th of March, arrived here yesterday morning. The City of Manchester arrived at Queenstown on the afternoon of the 22d, and reached Liverpool on the evening of the 23d of March.

ARMSTRONG.--On Thursday, April 5, HAMILTON, youngest child of Hamilton and Dorinda Armstrong, aged 6 months and 20 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his parents. No. 32 Bethune-st., this afternoon at 2 o'clock. BRINKERHOFF.--On Thursday morning, April 5, JACOB G. BRINKERHOFF, in the 77th year of his age.

Brig Avondale, DIX, from Georgetown, S. C., for Boston, with lumber and naval stores, was dismantled and waterlogged in a gale March A. The captain and crew were taken from the wreck, on the 19th, in latitude 41, longitude 71, by the schooner Winter Bird, HILTON, master, from Boston, for Jeremie, and landed at Turks Island on the 20th, thence by the brig Fearless. bound to Porto Rico.

The President, in the exercise of his constitutional power, returned to the Senate, without his approval, a measure called the Civil Rights Bill. The Senate, in turn, yesterday exercised its constitutional prerogative in voting by the requisite majority that the measure should become law, independently. of the Executive Veto.

The bank panic in this city continues. A. KARNES, a private banker, who was not doing a large business in deposits, suspended to-day for want of currency. His friends are confident that he will again soon resume payment. A run has been made all day upon POWERS' banking office, but has made no impression.

There is a crevasse at Baton Rouge three hundred feet in length, and many others are feared below. The whole country down to Bayou Plaquemine it is expected will be flooded, and it is feared that the Bayou Plaquemine cannot carry off the food, and that it will extend down to the Bayou Lafouche, comprising the richest sugar and cotton lands in Louisiana.

NEW-JERSEY.--The quarrel in New-Jersey costs the Union Party a Senator in Congress, for New-Jersey will relapse into its normal political condition. The substantial advantages of last Fall's triumph are thus sacrificed. Mr. SCOVEL, whose recusancy defeated the joint ballot, will of course be wiped out; but there is small consolation in that.

The river here is four feet deep on the shoals, and falling. There is considerable excitement in the city to-day consequent upon the arrest of several persons, formerly in the employ of the Quartermaster's Department, under Col. CHAS. H. TRAVIS. M. H. BRUNES, formerly Superintendent of the mule corrals, is shortly to be tried for alleged frands on the Government.

The third day's sale opened on Thursday with a larger attendance than that of either the two preceeding days. English books sold well up to the expectations of publishers, but there was no marked improvement in the prices obtained for home publications. On the whole, however yesterday's sale was by far the most satisfactory throughout.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-- " Fra Diavolo" was given last evening for the last time this season. The attendance was not overwhelming, partly in consequence of the weather, and partly the result of last evening's festivities. There was an expression, however, of the usual amount of applause and satisfaction. To-day there will be a matinee commencing at 11 o'clock-doors open at 10.

Both Imperialists and Liberals say that Gen. OGAJON left hero in January last, after four months stay under an assumed name. Before leaving he signed a document concurring in the extension of JUAREZ' Presidency. He started from Hualiacan March 20 to consult with JUAREZ about the campaign in Jalisco.

This has been a day of " big things " in the Assembly. On motion of Mr. VEEDER, of Kings, an "omnibus" was formed, by a resolution requiring certain bills to be read the third time out of their order. Among them were the Quarantine Bill, Niagara Ship Canal Bill, Central Railroad Fare Bill, and divers bills for street-railroads in New-York.

The Territory of Nebraska ex rel. Eleazer Wakeley, plaintiff in error, vs. William F. Lockwood, defendant in error.--This was an information in the nature of a quo warrant, filed in the District Court of the Territory of Nebraska, for the County of Douglas, by the Territorial District Attorney for the Judicial District. under the Code of 1867, and the act of October, 29, 1868.

Mails for Europe via Havre, per steamship Washington, close to-day at 10:30 A. M.; via Southampton and Bremen, per steamship Bremen, and via Queenstown per steamship City of Baltimore, at the same hour. Mails for Santiago De Cuba and Bermuda, per steamship Fah Kee, close to-day at 2 P. M.

About 4:15 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the rear basement of the five-story building of No. 231 Broadway, occupied by H. J. BANGS, as a restaurant and dwelling. Before the alarm was given the entire building was filled with a dense vollume of smoke, creating great confusion among the inmates who were sleeping on the upper floors.

The Cattle market opened dull this week, at a decline of 1/2c.@3/4c. from the lowest prices paid last week. There were not as many buyers in from New-York as usual, and those present bought carefully. Ordinary light stock sold at 6c.@61/2c.; for fair to good 7c.@8c,; for extra 8c.@9c.; some were held at the outside figure,

FATAL ACCIDENT.--Coroner KIRSTEN held an inquest yesterday afternoon, on the body of PETER KEENAN, eight years of age, residing at No. 25 Prospect-street, Jersey City, who was run over, on Thursday afternoon, by a locomotive on the New-Jersey Railroad. near the Grove-street crossing.

THE CIVIL RIGHTS BILL. At about 3 o'clock the Civil Rights Bill was called as, and Mr. DOOLITTLE, in a forcible speech of some length, gave his views. During the progress of this speech, it was whispered around that Senator MORGAN, who had been generally counted upon as one of those who would sustain the veto, had stated that he should vote for the bill.

Before the vote of the President's Veto was taken yesterday in the Senate, it was announced that an immense edition of Senator TRUMBUL'S speech would be issued, for use as an electioneering document against the President. The Radicals profess to be delighted with the Senator's effort, and confident of the effect of his reported oratory upon the people.

In the Senate Mr. LANE, of Kansas, offered a joint resolution for the admission of the States lately in rebellion to representation in Congress, on condition of their repudiating the rebel debt, indorsing the Federal debt, annulling all ordinances of secession, and granting the right of suffrage to such colored people as can read, or who own and pay taxes on $250 worth of property.

SWINDLING VERDANT GERMANS.--A young German, 23 years of age, named FRANCIS KALLMEYER alias Alfred Lux, was arraigned before Justice WALTER yesterday on a charge of swindling preferred by WILLIAM GEYER, a recently arrived emigrant from Germany.

Mr. GEORGE W. WASHINGTON, aged about 54 years, and a native of this City, who was formerly employed in a down-town United States Bonded Warehouse, committed suicide yesterday morning at the Putnam House, on the corner of Twenty-sixthstreet and Fourth-avenue, by cutting his throat, during a temporary aberration of mind.

In the realm of abstract or speculative thought, outside of the domain of morals, there are few inquiries that can find their response in a direct affirmation or a direct negation. There are few fixed points, few settied laws, few definite conclusions. We sweep around and around a truth; we advance toward it; but it is rare that we are able to seize it, and demonstrate that we hold it.

The last rail between Kansas City, Mo., and Wyandotte, Kansas, joining the Missouri, Pacific, and the Union Pacific Railroad, was laid on Monday last by the principal officer of each road. Amending the act relative to the Croton Aqueduct and certain streets in New-York. To facilitate the construction of the Ithaca and Tonawanda Railroad. Lost.

The Senate assembled at 10 o'clock this morning, all the members being present. After the reading of the journal President SCOVEL called Mr. REEVES to the chair, and rising to a question of privilege said: The organ of the Republican Party says I gave my written pledge to go into Joint meeting when I was elected President of the Senate. This falsehood has been twice repeated. I never gave such a pledge.

The teamer Eliza Hancox arrived nere this morning from Galveston, Texas, having touched at Key West and Charleston, S. C., to obtain a supply of coal. She encountered a heavy blow in the Gulf, and reports having passed, on the 28th ult., a large propeller steamship, supposed to be one of the steamers running from New-York to New-Orleans, ashore, about five miles below Carrysfort Light, with her foremast gone and the wreckers making toward her.

The wheat grown in different parts of the United States cannot be screcned by the same grades of bolting-cloth. The grain from Southern Ohio and Illinois requires a mesh of one size, from Wisconsin and Minhesota another, and other sections still others. The shape of the mesh is also different for different kinds of grain.

One of the most singular uses in the practical arts now is the method of taking an impression in a hard substance of an object made of a much softer material Thus the most delicate leaf will leave every line of its skeleton plainly impressed in lead if the two are pressed together. Advantage is taken of this in a proposed method of printing from a photograph.

The bank panic is over. The run upon Mr. POWERS' bank has ceased. He paid out $80,000, and took in from depositors $40,000. He received $10,000 more in currency from New-York this morning. Mr. KARNES has resumed business, the assistance tendered him having enabled him to go on as before and to meet all demands, which he now proposes to do.

There is a groat crevasse at Chennes Levee, West Baton Rouge. The whole pariah is overflowed. Extensive damage is feared. The crevasse below this city is being repaired. rear of the city is flooded. The British Steamship Company and merchants of this city are drawing up a memorial for the deepening of the ocean passes.

ANDREWS.--On Saturday, April 7, GEORGE H. ANDREWS, aged 68 years. The funeral will take place on Monday at 2 P. M., at St. Thomas' Church. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. Boston papers please copy. BAILEY.--On Thursday, April 5, at East Jama ice, L. I. JOHN H. BAILEY, in the 87th year of his age.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Prof. CREASY, some years since, wrote a book which he entitled The Fifteen Decisive Battles of the World. As philosophical military analysis it is very curious and interesting, whatever may be the opinions of martial critical experts as to the justness of his conclusions. This article is prepared on the same basis of consideration.

The sarcophagus in the great Pyramid, which has been held to furnish the source of our measures as the "quarter," has lately been measured by an Englishman, in order to settle a dispute about its dimensions. Measuring rods were arranged around it, and by the aid of the magnesium light photographs of the whole were taken, so that the dispute could not possibly be continued.

A TRIBUTE TO THE LAMENTED PRESIDENT.--The following tribute to our lamented President and the American people, appears in the British Colonist, published in the far-off town of Victoria, Vancouver's Island: The Southern rebellion, If it sowed the dragon's teeth to bring forth the enemies to freedom, produced on the other hand the highest order of humanity as a counteracter.

The Assembly has been occupied to-day in perfecting the Annual Supply Bill. The Committee on Ways and Means seem to have exercised great care to keep the appropriations within a proper limit, and have rejected many bogus claim against the State.

MAURY'S report of the defence of Mobile narrates the eventful history of a torpedo boat as follows: It was built of boiler iron, was about thirty-five feet long, and was manned by a crew of nine men, eight of whom worked the propeller by hand. The ninth steered the boat and regulated her movements below the surface of the water.

NECESSITY OF A PUBLIC HOSPITAL DOWN TOWN.--A WORD OF WARNING.--With reference to the demolition of the City Hospital in Broadway, and the removal of the institution somewhere on the upper end of the island, we would say that we trust it will not be done until provision is made for the establishment of some sort of a public hospital in the lower part of the City.
DANGEROUS WALLS.--There is instant and imminent danger that the walls of the American Hotel building, on the corner of Broadway and Barclay-street, will topple down.

Another Veteran of 1812 Gone. EBENEZER T. ANDREWS, a votoran soldier of 1812, and a most esteemed citizen of Massachusetts, died yesterday at his residence in Charlestown, at the advanced age of 77 years.

A GALLANT SOLDIER'S TESTIMONY. Among tho latest arrivals from the South is Major I. WALKER, of the Fifth United States Cavalry, regular army, who has just returned from South Carolina on leave of absence, having suffered a painful fracture of the leg, caused by being thrown from an ambulance at Columbia, S. C., some three weeks since.
FAST-DAY PROCLAMATIONS.--Gov. CRAPO, of Michigan, has issued a proclamation appointing Thursday, of next week, as a day of "Fasting, Humiliation and Prayer" for the people of that State.

Last evening, at the Madison-avenue Presbyterian Church, Rev. LOWELL SMITH, D. D., of Honolulu, gave some account of his experience as a missionary in the Sandwich Islands. he said that during the year past, clergymen everywhere whom he had visited had besought him to preach; but he had invariably declined, saying that after preaching thirty-two years in the Hawaiian language, he had come home to rest.

BILLS PASSED. To amend the Insurance Department Act. To amend the charter of the United States Accident Insurance Company of Syracuse. To incorporate the New-York Women's Medical Coltege. To incorporate the Cortland Savings Bank. To provide for laying out a new road in Newtown, Queens County.

A daring escape from the Fortress of a prisoner, named MICHAEL FOLLEY, a private of Company H, Fifth United States Artillery-under sentence in the main guard-house for mutiny and other misdemeanors-was made the night before last; and so far he has succeeded in eluding the precautions adopted by the officers to effect his capture. The manner of the escape is somewhat involved in mystery.

We trust that the telegraphic statement that "there is a proposition under consideration by some Senators to urge the expulsion of Hon. GARRETT DAVIS from the United States Senate for the sentiments he uttered in his speech on Friday last," will not be borne out by events. If such a proposition really be " under consideration," it cannot be discarded and forgotton too soon.

FIRE IN SECOND-AVENUE.--A fire broke out, about 9 o'clock last evening, in the building No. 883 Second-avenue, occupied by F. H. FEIL as a bakery. The flames soon extended to No. 885, occupied as a crockery-store by CATHARINE RALPH, and also to No. 163 Forty-seventh-street, occupied as a tenement-house. All of this property was destroyed by the flames. It belonged to JOHN MOORE. Loss on buildings, $5,000.

DUTIES ON PRODUCE SENT THROUGH CANADA. Mr. SHERMAN introduced a bill to remit and refund certain duties, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce. It is designed to free from duties the produce of the United States, sent from one port in this country to another via Canada. THE NATIONAL CURRENCY.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. 14th- st. ,corner of Irving-place. THIS EVENING, April 10, commencing at 8 o'clock, MARTHA. A great case, including Miss Clara Louise Kellogg. Miss Adelaide Phillips, Signor Irate, Signor Antonucci. Conductor, Carl Bergmann.

The steamship Hansa, from Southampton on the 28th of March, arrived at this port last evening. The National Steam Navigation Company's steamship England arrived yesterday morning at Halifax, to which port she had changed her course, instead of continuing her voyage to New-York, for the purpose of obtaining medical aid.

M. W. Gardner, City Treasurer, , plaintiff in error, vs. Anna R Babcock, by defendant in error by reason of the non-repair and unsafe condition of a sidewalk in one of the public highways of that city.

On the evening of the 17th of January last, the three children of ERNESTINA SCHOTZ were found dead in their bed, attired in their beat and laid out, their mother, seemingly a corpse, kneeling at the bedside. Mrs. SCHOTZ, however, was yet alive, and after some exertion physicians were enabled to declare her out of danger.

The steamship Tonawanda, Capt. BERRY, from Boston, March 10, for Havana, went ashore at 2 A. M. on the 28th ult., on Grecian Shocals, coast of Florida, the weather being thick and squally at the time. At 3 A. M. the steamer commenced leaking: at 6 o'clock she was full of water and shortly afterward bilged, broke in two and became a total loss. Wrecking vess ?? in saving cargo.

We quoted yesterday some remarks from a Boston periodical, pronouncing republican institutions a failure, because "first-class men," such as PHILLIPS, EMERSON, WHITTIER, LOWELL, SUMNER, STEVENS, WADE and SCHURZ, did not succeed in getting at the head of the Government as our rulers.

The Senate is not in session to-day, that slow-going and dignified body having, as usual, adjourned till evening. The House proceedings, like grocers' accounts and certain Albany letters in Metropolitan journals, have been "without interest." From this remark, however, I should make an exception or two.

"HIGH ART" IN NEW-YORK.--The frauds that are carried on at our popular picture auctions are far greater than those which used to be carried on in jewelry by the Peter Funks. The two sorts of knavery are very much alike. The old style of Peter Funks sold brass jewelry for jewelry of "real genuine gold, eighteen carats fine;"

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"Les Huguenots" was given last evening for the final time to a splendid house. The performance was good, and therefore requires no further mention. To-night (Tuesday) FLOWTOW's agreeable opera of " Martha" will be rendered, with KELLOGG, PHILLIPS, IRFRE and ANTONUCOT in the cast. On Wednesday "Norma," for the last appearance of Mme. CAROZZI-ZUCCHI. Mile. STELLA will on this occasion mako her debut as Adalgisa.

By the Hansa at this port, and the England at Halifax, we have Southampton dates to the 28th ult. The England put in at Halifax for medical assistance, having had one hundred and sixty cases of cholera and fifty deaths during her voyage. She has 1,200 passengers, mostly Irish and German emigrants. The principal topic in England is the Reform Bill, and its friends are giving it active

Warnings of an Unwelcome Visitor. It would be as unwise to treat lightly as it would be to exaggerate the report which comes to us from Nova Scotia this morning. The steamer England, of the National Steam Navigation Company's line, put into the harbor of Halifax yesterday for medical assistance.

About two hundred Fomans sailed for Eastport, Me., (on the British frontier) in the steames New-Brunswick this afternoon. The boat was unable to take the arms this trip, and a schooner was chartered for the purpose.

We have dates from Callao and Lima to the 22d March. The only item of importance is a report that reached Callao, just before the sailing of the steamer, that the Chilian steamer Paquete de Maule had been attacked by the Spaniards, and after a severe engagement was captured, with 250 soldiers on board.

BRAINARD--In Brooklyn, on Sunday April 8, EVELINE 1? daughter of John A, and Eveline A. Brainard, aged 13 months and 25 days. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Tuesday, April 10, at 31/2 P.M. from the residence of her grandparents, No. 230 Washington-av. CATLIN--At Staten Island, on Sunday, April 8, GEORGE CATLIN, in the 57th year of his age.
