FRANKLIN BABBITT, Rector of Grace Church, Nyaok, and EMILY, oldest daughter of Francis Tillou, Esq., of this City.

PRESENTATION TO A CLERGYMAN.--The congregation of the First Presbyterian Church, corner of Remsen and Clinton streets, presented their Pastor, Rev. Dr. H. J. VANDYKE, on Sunday last, with a check for $7000 as a substantial token of their esteem. The money was contributed in order to enable the Reverend gentleman to purchase a residence.

The Board of Aldermen mot at 2 P. M. yesterday, President BRICE in the chair. The majority of the Committee on Ferries presented a report adverse to permitting the Astoria Ferry Company to change the terminus of the ferry from Eightysixth to Ninety-second-street. The report states that the slip at Eighty-sixth-street has been used for many years, and that there is no special reason why the terminus should be now changed.

The feeling which led to the passage of the Civil Rights Bill was doubtless that in matters which related to the two races at the South it would not be safe to leave the colored men to the local laws and courts; that the nation was pledged to see to it that they received justice, and to that end would have questions which involved their rights determined

CHAMBERLAIN--BURROUGHS.--At Boundbrook, N. J., on Tuesday, April 10, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Samuel M. Haskins, D. D., assisted by Long Island, and ANNA M., only daughter of Joseph Burroughs, of Boundbrook, N. J. No cards. Sag Harbor. L. I., papers please copy.

NEW-YORK CONTESTED ELECTION. The morning hour having expired, the House resumed the consideration of the regular order of business after the morning hour, being the following resolutions reported from the Committee of Elections: Resolved, That Hon. JAMES BROOKS is not entitled to a seat in this house as a Representative in the Thirtyninth Congress from the Eighth District in New-York.

The Tribune, following tho example of THE TIMES, has enlarged its borders, and now appears upon a sheet the size of our own. Last evening the beginning of the twenty-fifth volume was celebrated by a dinner at DELMONICO'S where were gathered about sixty of the former and present employes in the leading departments' of the paper.

BOLD ATTEMPT AT ROBBERY.--On Monday evening Mr. GEORGE C. WEED, Cashier and General Superintendent of the Etna Iron Works, was assaulted by three men in Rivington-street near Norfolk, who knocked him down with a club. Mr. WEED had during the day drawn $12,000 from the bank to pay off the hands in the Iron Works, and it is supposed that his assailants were aware that he had the money in his possession.

THE NEW-YORK CONTESTED ELECTION CASE.-- We give elsewhere the very able and exhaustive speech delivered in the House of Representatives, April 6, by Hon. Mr. DAWES, Chairman of the Committee on Elections, upon the case of DODGE vs. BROOKS.

Some time during the interval between Saturday night and Monday morning, the bonded warehouse No. 13 Greenwich-street, occupied by DEVOE BEECHEE, was entered by burglars and nearly $3,000 worth of valuable silks were carried away. It appears that the thieves gained an entrance into the premises. through a rear window, whence they crawled in over some bags, and gained the third floor,

The charter election hold in this city yesterday resulted in the election of the Democratic candidate for Mayor, GEORGE H. THACHER, by between 700 and 800 majority, and the election of the Democratic city ticket, except Police Justice, by majorities ranging from 350 to 700. S. H. H. PARSONS, Republican,

The steamship Belgian, with one day's later news from Europe, arrived yesterday morning at Portland. The Austro-Prussian difficulty was still the main theme of discussion in the English and Continental journals.

RANDOLPH; Vice-President--JOHN HILTON; Secretary--A. G. GILKYSON: Treasurer--GEORGE E. CUTTER; Trustees--Samuel Stevens, Marcus Higgenbotham, George H. Williamson, Jacob Ringle, William H. Page, John W. Cossad and Alex. Wilson.

Brevet Brig.-Gen. ROBERT E. CLAY, Deputy Quartermaster-General, has been assigned to duty here as Chief of the ?? ster's Department of Tennessee, relieving Capt. A. F. EDDY. A fire occurred last night on the corner of Church and Vine streets, destroying a number of wooden buildings. Loss $15,000.

In the House, last evening, in Committee of the Whole, a bill was considered, reported from the Committee on Militia and Public Defence, appropriating $500,000 to arm and equip the National Guard, of this State.

The President announced the following special committees: On the Senate and Assembly apportionments--Messrs. Andrews, Hoyt, H. C. Murphy, E. Cornell; on Docks and Piers within the Metropolitan District-Messrs. Pierson, Low, Gibson, La Bau and Thomas Murphy. The Assembly amendments to the Brooklyn Metropolitan Railway Bill were concurred in.

The Loan Bill, as finally passed, falls far short of what it should have been to do justice to the Secretary of the Treasury or to meet the views of those who, like him, earnestly desire a speedy return to specie payments.

HORSE THIEVES.--Officer LYONS, of the Tenth Precinct, arrested THOMAS GALVIN, on a charge of larceny, preferred against him by HORACE A. FULLER, residing at No. 193 Bowery, who stated in the Essex Market Police Court, when the prisoner was arraigned, that he had stolen five horses and a light wagon, valued at $1,100, from GEO. METCALF, of Louisville, Ky., where he was hired to take charge of the animals. The accused was hold for examination.

It will be seen from the brief statement of the fishery question, and the accompanyingresolutions in Congress, yesterday, that our Government has not receded, and does not intend to recede, one step from the position taken by Mr. WEBSTER fifteen years ago, in regard to the fair and honest interpretation of the Convention of 1818.

IN NASSAU-STREET. About 9 o'clock last night a fire broke out on the third floor of No. 66 Nassau-street, occupied by E. THOMA, manufacturing jeweler. The flames originated from the forge. Damage to stock, $200. Damage to building, $125.

THE SOUTHERN COTTON CROP.--We near from different parts of the South that though the cotton crop this year will be respectably large, the breadth planted will not equal the estimates of the more sanguine made some months ago. The emigration from the North during the last six months has been limited;

At the meeting of theo Metropolitan Board of Health yesterday afternoon, the Code of Health Ordinances, which had been prepared by Counsellor EATON, was taken up section by section, after much discussion and a few necessary amendments, adopted, and it was ordered that 2,500 copies be printed. The code requires every practising physician within the Metropolitan District

Present--John Brice, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen Moore, Coman, McBrien, Shannon, Godney, Ely, Reilly, Loew, Varnum, O'Brien, Van Voorhis--12. The minutes of the proceeding meeting were read and approved. PETITIONS. By Alderman Van Voorhis--

THE FENIANS.--The late abatement in the Fenian fever bids fair to be followed by a renewal of excitement on the arrival of JAMES STEPHENS. This skillful and lucky man will presently be among us, and we shall doubtless have very enthusiastic demonstrations in his honor by our Irish fellow-citizens.

Miss BATEMAN To-NIGHT.--On Monday night MISS BATEMAN played Pauline to a very fair house in Brooklyn. She was well supported, and the entertainment was a success. To-night she plays Bianca, in the "Italian Wife," with the same company. This will be her last appearance in Brooklyn for a long time, and affords an excellent opportunity for those who have enjoyed her Leah to judge of her ability in other lines.

A grand anniversary celebration of the Fire Department off Mobile occurred yesterday, and passed off splendidly. The enthusiasm was unbounded. After the ovation, the members of the Fire De. partment, the City authorities and a few invited guests partook of a collation. Among the toasts was the following:

The British war ship Pylades arrived here yesterday, and went to St. Andrews. The British Consul and the United States Marshal are at Maybee's Hotel, also prominent Fenians. Communication between St. John and the Western towns on the British side, was destroyed last night by the Fenians.

The steamship Belgian, Capt. BROWN, from Liverpool on the 29th, vid Londonderry on the 30th of March, arrived here at 6:30 o'clock this morning. The steamships City of New-York and Bospherus, both from New-York, arrived at Liverpool on the evening of the 28th of March.

The Fashion Course, Long Island, was visited yesterday by a fair attendance of the lovers of trotting and those interested in fast horses to witness a trot for a stake of $1,500, mile heats, best three in five, in harness. It was the first contest of the season, al though not regarded as the legitimate opening of the Spring campaign,

VAIN REGRETS.--There are still men in England who, looking at the present power and prospects of this country, indulge in maledictions against Earl RUSSELL'S Government for its policy of non-interference in our war. One of this class declares that if England had made an alliance with LOUIS NAPOLEON for recognition aid support of the Confederacy,

Arrived, steamers George Cromwell and Merrimac, from New-York. Attacks in this city by slung-shot and the robbing of citizens is becoming of daily occurrence. Many lunatics and robbers are abroad, who were released from asylums and prisons during the war,. and who come bore from all parts of the country.

BILLS PASSED. Amending the charter of Brooklyn. It relates to the cleaning and improvement of the streets. For the improvement of the Gowanus Canal, Brooklyn. To extend the boundaries of Prospect Park, Brooklyn. To provide for a parade ground in Kings County. Authorizing the sale of certain lands in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

A LANDLORDS' SCARE.--We have all along asserted, and properly owners have denied, that the short supply of house accommodation did not justify the enormous increase of rents demanded this Spring. Our anticipations of the final results of the action of landlords begin to be justified. Not only have rents fallen below the figures of a month ago,

The canvas was concluded in Jersey City at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon. ORESTES CLEVELAND (Dem.) was reelected Mayor by 366 majority, against 516 majority one year ago. Joseph McCoy (Dem.) was reelected School Superintendent by 829 majority. Cornelius C. Martindale (Dem.) was reelected City Recorder by 550 majority over Tilden (Rep.) and Cutter, (Ind. Dem.)

A terrible crime, in the lower section of the city, was discovered this afternoon. A family of seven persons had been murdered: CHRISTOPHER DEERING, his wife, niece and four children, on Mr. DEERING'S farm, at Point House road and James Lane. It is supposed the murders were committed last Fri. day by a German laborer on the farm.

The one hundred days during which members of the legislature are allowed to draw $3 per diem expire to-day, and the balance of the session must be carried on at the expense of the honorable members--or the lobby, which latter body, by the way, is exceedingly large and savagely clamorous as time passes, The House has pretty nearly disposed of its business, but the Senate is far behind.

PETITIONS. Mr. SUMNER presented a petition asking for Congressional aid for the building of a European and North American Railroad, to connect Halifax with the United States. The petition was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr. SHERMAN presented sections for protection to

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"La Favorita" attracted a good but not overflowing audience last evening. The performance exhibited Mme. POCH'S fine dramatic powers, and the truly great quality of her voice. The lady has not had many chances this season, but the remembrances of her two efforts are entirely pleasant. Her voice and her style are alike large.
SUPPOSED POISONING OF A YOUNG GIRL.--A young girl named MARGARET McCORMACK, about 13 years of age, residing with here parents at the corner of M??-avenue and Essex-street, E. D.,

We have news this morning from Europe to the 1st inst., which would seem to be portentous of an actual rupture between the despoilers of Denmark. It has been apparent for some time that Austria was carefully measuring her resources and moving large masses of troops as rapidly as possible from one part of the Empire to another.

THE CHOLERA.--We hear that among the less-informed classes of the City, the announcement that cholera was on board the steamer England, off Halifiax, has been transmogrifled into the most fearful shapes, They have had the epidemic located in town, and not a few deaths from other maladies during the last few days,

THE NEW-YORK COLLECTORSHIP. The New-York Collectorship is again the subject uppermost in the minds of New-York politicians. Positive statements are made by certain parties to-day that the appointment of a prominent bank President has been determined on; but the developments of the past thirty days on this subject do not render it safe to believe anything as certain until the appointment is signed.
Cotton stiffer; sales 1,300 bales; receipts today 720 bales; low middlings 811/2c.@35c. Molasses nominal. Sugar unchanged. Gold 125; Sterling 32. New-York bank checks 3/8 ?? cent. discount.

The steamship Asia arrived yesterday at Halifax, the North American at Portland, and the Pereire at this port, the first bringing two days' later news from Europe. The German difficulties were still increasing, and the actual occurrence of hostilities was looked forward to as merely a question of days.

The Methodist Conference is still discussing the Episcopal veto, A communication from the Baltimore Conference in relation to the extension of business relations was received with much favor. The discussion of Federal politics is entirely ignored. Grand preparations are being made for the Louisiana races to-morrow. The track is dry, but rather rough.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, from Liverpool on Saturday, March 31, via Queenstown, April 1, arrived at this port this afternoon. All the Markets were closed, and there is no later commercial news than that taken out by steamers leaving on the 29th and 30th. The steamship Hibernia, from New-York, arrived out 31st.

THE CRUELTY TO ANIMAIS BILL.--The bill for the prevention of cruelty to animals has at length passed both branches of the State Legislature, and will speedily become a law. This action is late in the day, but not the less welcome. In the first notice of the necessity for some action on the subject, and which appeared in these columns,

GRANT, who has not a few newspaper backers already in the North, to Professor LEE, who is regarded as the fittest man by one or two Southern newspapers. We have to labor ceaselessly,

THE TROUBLES OF MAXIMILIAN.--The news from Mexico of late has been exceedingly flat. But for the enlivenment given to affairs by a fight with banditti now and then, here and there, we should hardly have an item of history. It is now evident to all that the Republicans have given up all hope of effecting anything whatever by military effort.

THE CAR-DRIVER'S STRIKE,--The drivers on tho Third and Sixth-avenue railroads resorted yesterday to the ill-advised proceeding of a strike, and, as was perhaps to be expected, the proprietors at once commenced endeavoring to supply their places-the drivers in the end giving in. The action of both parties in tho contest is much to be regretted.

Yesterday morning the drivers of the street cars on the Third and Sixth avenue lines struck for an increase of wages. On the Third-avenue line the drivers have been paid two dollars per day for ordinary trips, and two dollars and twenty cents per day for running through trips to Harlem. On the Sixth avenue line they were receiving two dollars per day.

Charles Comstock et al. plaintiffs in error vs. Jefferson Crawford, defendant in error.-In this case the plaintiffs in error brought an action of ejectment to oust the defendant of an undivided three-tenths of 680 acres of land, situate in Grant County, Wisconsin. They proved title on the trial (in the district for Wisconsin) as heirs-at-law of Matthias C. Comstock, who died in 1838,

The well-known colored caterer and cysterman, THOMAS DOWNING, died on Tuesday last, at his residence in this City. The deceased was in the 75th year of his age, having been born in Accomac County, Va., in 1791. His mother, a slave, was a woman of great piety and much respected by her owners, the DOWNINGS.

Quicksilver has advanced 10 cents a pound in consequence of troubles at New-Almaden. Six of the rioters there have been arrested, and the rest will be shortly. SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, April 11. Mining stocks are firm. Crown Point, $1,400; Ophir, $765; Belcher, $377; Empire Mills, $200; Yellow Jacket, $940; Chollar Potosi, $380; Savage, $1,085.

Hod. ANNIS, the party recently arrested for the great Lord rebbery in New-York, has been released by Judge CHAPMAN, of the Supreme Court, on a writ of habeas corpus. ANNIS has been under the charge of Chief of Police KURTZ, but without any legal document for holding him.

We had the pleasure yesterday of an introduction to the Sphynx--an unfortunate creature of whose original entity nothing now remains save a very intelligent head and a remarkably rotund voice. He, she or it was in a box, resting upon a table on Barnum's stage, surrounded by sacred fires, and invested with all the pomp and circumstance of scenic display.

Full reports of the DEERING family murder show it to have been one of the most horrible butcheries of the age. The Press reporters say that the body of the mother and those of her four children were found in one corner of the barn, near a small outhouse, which communicated together by a hole, through which the remains of the murdered victims were brought to view.

AIRMAN.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday evening April 12, JULIA MARION, youngest daughter of Walter M. and Julia Aikman, aged 4 years and 6 months. The funeral will take place on Saturday, the 14th inst., at 3 o'clock, from No. 13 Tompkins-place, Brooklyn. BELL.--On Wednesday morning, April II, at Green-point, L I., MARGARET BELL, in the 77th year of her age.

THE NEW STEAMSHIP CITY OF PARIS.--The new screw steamship City of Paris, of the Inman line, which arrived here a few days ago,. was thrown open to public inspection yesterday. The vessel was built at Glasgow. She is three hundred and seventy-three feet long; forty feet in width: twenty-seven feet in depth, and of two thousand eight hundred tons burden.

The lottery case, in which Sinclair Webb is charged with selling lottery tickets without a license, on the complaint of John W. Leggett, Collector of Internal Revenue, was up before the Commissioner for examination, yesterday, but owing to the absence of Mr. Donohue, counsel for defendant, it was adjourned. The witnesses on the part of the Government were present.

The entertainment accompanying the distribution of degrees at Grammar School No. 10, Female Department, yesterday, was of a highly interesting character. In all, one hundred and twenty-seven certificates were conferred, sixty-four of these being of the first class, thirty-four of the second, and twentynine of the third. This is said to be, comparatively. the highest number of certificates ever conferred at an examination.

In the races to-day, the first race, for a purse of $500-mile heats for two-year olds-was won by Lewis Smith in two straight heats. Time, two miles: 2min. 43/4sec. The second race, for a purse of $1,000--two-mile heats-was won by Beacon in two straight heats, Time: 3:15, 3:46.

Gov. HAMILTON, of Texas, made a speech at Austin recently, in which he opposed some ordinances passed by the Convention as not being republican or meeting the necessary demand made. They had passed but one ordinance which accorded fully with the President's policy, and that was declaring the war debt null and void. He appealed from the action of the Convention to the people.

The strike among the car drivers on our city lines, inaugurated on Wednesday, was very much extended yesterday, and at this time threatens to become general. On Wednesday the drivers of the Third and Sixth avenue lines, heretofore receiving two dollars per day, struck because the companies reiused to pay them two dollars and a half.

From the Newark Advertiser. The annual catalogue of the College of NowJersey, at Princoton, has just been issued, and shows a degree of prosperity which must be highly gratifying to the friends of that time-honored institution. The students number altogether 238, of whom 85 are from New-Jersey, 45 from Pennsylvania, 33 from Marylaud, 17 from Delaware, and the remainder are from fourteen other States-also one from India and one from the West Indies.

A company of 200 gentlemen, representing the newspaper and book publishers of New-York, Hoston and this city, paid a visit to the Manayunk Wood Paper Pulp Works, and witnessed the entire process of converting cord wood into paper pulp, and its manufacture into paper.

In the Senate the bill to reimburse the State of Missouri for war expenses was called up, and the House amendments concurred in. The bill authorizing the remission of duties on produce shipped from one port of the United States to another via Canada, was passed and goes to the House. Mr. STEWART introduced a constitutional amendment, a substitute for the joint resolution previously introduced by him.

The ex-rebel Vice-President, Mr. A. H. STEPHENS, entertains views in reference to the duty of the Southern people which differ widely from those inculcated by the ultra Democratic journals of the North.

A partial revelation of the mystery attendant upon the robbery of $164,000 worth of United States Government bonds and railroad securities from the residence of Mr. Joan P. MOORE, No. 110 Madisonavenue, was made yesterday, through the exertions of Capt. JOHN S. YOUNG and his assistant detectives.

NATURAL SCIENCE,-A course of lectures on this subject will be delivered by Prof. R. OGDEN DOREMUS at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, commencng Tuesday, April 17. The lectures will be given under the auspices of the Brooklyn Mercantile Library Association, and will be illustrated by experiments which have rarely been exhibited in public on account of the expense attending them.

The Committee of Conference on the bill regulating the pay of the Metropolitan Police, have, I understand, substanially agreed, although their report has not yet been submitted. The committee consists of Messrs. Pierson. T. Murphy and Lent on the part of the Senate, and Creamer, Buckman, Brandreth, Seebacher and Congdon on the part of the Assembly.

We trust that the railroad corporations of this City will not affect to misunderstand what we have said in sympathy with the claims of their employes, the car-drivers. That the public are almost unanimous as to the justice of giving them additional compensation, we have, after full opportunities of judgment, not the slightest doubt.

There was much excitement yesterday and last night at St. Stephens, New-Brunswick, opposite this city. The fears of a Fenian raid somewhere on the frontier have been strengthening for several days past, but the precise point of attack is not yet known. Reports from Eastport yesterday indicated that Fentans were leaving there in squads, supposed for Calais-but up to this hour have not shown themselves here.

THE GLOBE MUTUAL LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY.--This Company has insured lives during the year to the amount of more than eight millions of dollars. It has received in premiums over five hundred thousand, and issued two thousand eight hundred policies. This success in its first fiscal year is unprecedented, and is due to its popular feature of its policies being non-forfeiture.

A painful accident occurred near Williston, on the Central Railroad, early this morning, occasioned by the burning of a bridge, twenty feet in length, which spanned a carriage-way. The fire took place in the night, and the night express going north, due there about 4:30, having no knowledge of it, was moving at full speed. The engine leaped the chasm,...

PREPARING AGAINST THE PESTILENCE.--Drs. PARKER, STONE and CRANE, of the Board of Health, have acted with commendable promptitude in reporting, as they did yesterday, the imminence of the public peril; and the Board are entitled to credit for at once appealing, without quibble, to Gov. FENTON for those extraordinary powers which he may authorize them to exercise in time of peril. The Board ask,

The Metropolitan Board of Health assembled yesterdayy afternoon, President SCHULTZ in the chair, and Dr. SWINDURNE absent. Commissioner MANIERRE, from the Finance Committee, reported that an additional $50,000 had been inserted in the tax levy, thus making $250,000 which the Board is to have at its disposal this year,

To the Editor of the Newark Daily Advertiser: After a storm comes a calm, as well on the political arena as at sea. Having been present at Trenton, I was cognizant of the unjust imputation cast upon Hon, J. M. SCOVEL of insincerity in his offers to go into joint meeting if Mr. CATTEL was withdrawn, and take any one of certain named candidates, or even to extend the list.

EDWARD W. GREEN, the murderer of young CONVERSE, at the Malden Bank, about two years ago, was executed this forenoon in the jail yard at East Cambridge, in the presence of the authorities and citizens designated by law, to whom tickets of admission were issued by the Sheriff, Between two and three hundred persons were present within the walls, and perhaps an equal number outside.

CONGRESS. The Senate agreed to the report of the Committee of Conference on the Naval Appropriation Bill. It strikes out the appropriation for the purchase of OAKMAN and ELDRIDGE'S wbart at Charlestown, Mass. A bill to authorize the distribution of a copy of the Congressional Globe to each of the District and Territorial Judges of the United States, was called up, and on motion postponed.

The following autograph letter from Donator D. L. YULEE, of Florida, to Gov. F. W. PICKENS, of South Carolina, came into the possession of Mr. B. F. SUCH, of this City, in 1862, while he was acting as correspondent for THE NEW-YORK TIMES in the Military Department of the South. It is interesting as a fragment of the history of the rebellion:

BERRY--HALL.--In Jersey City, on Thursday, April 12, at St. Mathew's Church, by Rev. S. M. Rice, SAMUEL J. BERRY, Jr., and CHARLOTTE L., daughter of Andrew Hall, Esq., of Jersey City. BARRY--HENDRICKSON.--At the 13th-st. Presbyterian Church, on Tuesday, April 10, by Rev. S. D. Burchard, D. D., R. A. BARRY, M. D., and JENNIE, daughter of J. B. Hendrickson, all of this city.
A large number of Fenians have just arrived in the steamer from New-York. KILLIAN returned last night with thirty or forty. They are perfectly quiet, having no arms. No disturbance has yet occurred.

The steamboat financier, bound from Pittsburgh to New-Orleans, was burned last night at Remington, 20 miles below this city. Ten lives were lost. The boat and the cargo, consisting of agricultural implements, iron, nails and glass, wore totally destroyed. The insurance on tho boat was $265,000, on tho cargo $50,000, mostly in Pittsburgh offices.

INCENDIARY FIRE.--The Common Council have before them a proposition to offer a reward for the detection of incendiaries. The motive is good, though the method proposed for diminishing the fearful crime of incendiarism may be open to question.

Hon. DANIEL STEVENS DICKINSON, United States District-Attorney, died at the residence of Mr. COURTNEY, his son in-law, No. 129 East Thirty-fourth-street, on Thursday evening, at 8:30 o'clock. He was in his office on Monday attending to business, and went home afterward complaining of an illness the nature of which was not then understood.

BILLS PASSED. Amending the name of the National Life and Travelers' Insurance Company of New-York. For the relief of the Flatbush and Coney Island Railroad Company, To amend the act relative to the transfer of female convicts from Buffalo and Rochester to Sing Sing.

A man was arrested at the corner of Twentythird and Market streets this morning, who confesses to having committed tile murder of the Deering family, He states that he was assisted by a company ion, whom he has described minutely to the authorties.

The burdens of taxation are hard on the people and hard on industry. No business man can pass a day without groaning under them, and no man whatever, except the rich, can live without suffering severely from them. The complexity of the taxes, as well as their magnitude, troubles us all.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC. 14th-st., Corner of Irving-place. THIS AFTERNOON, commencing at 1 o'clock, THE HUGHENOTS.

AIKMAN.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday evening, April 12, JULIA MARION, youngest daughter of Walter M. and Julia Aikman, aged 4 years and 6 months. The funeral will take place on Saturday, the 14th inst., at 3 o'clock, from No. 13 Tomokins-place, Brooklyn. BARING.--On Wednesday, April 11, at No. 109 West 11th-st., ROBERT BOWNE MINTURN, younger son of T. C. and S. C. Baring, in his 3d year.

The Assembly to-night had a stormy and exciting session over the New-York County Tax Levy. The proceedings were diversified by a sharp passage-at-arms between D. P. WOOD, of Onondaga, and Mr. BRANDRETH, of Westchester, in which the former charged the latter with having inserted items in the bill on his own responsibility not asked for by the Comptroller or Supervisors, and without a meeting of the Committee on Cities, of which Mr. BRANDRETH is Chairman.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"L'Etoile du Nord" was given here last evening to a brilliant and even an everflowing audience. The performance terminated Mr. MARETZEK's regular season--the most regular and the most successful on record. To-day there will be a matinee, when MEYERBEER's greatest opera, "Les Huguenots," will be repeated, also for the last time.

THE NAVEL APPROPRIATION BILL. Mr. GRIMES from the Committee of Conference on the Naval Appropriation Bill, made a report, Mr. GRIMES stated that the bill, as agreed to by the Committee of Conference was, substantially, that passed by the Senate.

Before Justice Hockes and a Jury. Michael Kidney vs. The Bleecker-street and Fulton Ferry Railroad Company.--The plaintiff in this action sought to recover the sum of $20,000 of the above-named Company for alleged personal injuries sustained in consequence of having been knocked down on the 27th of September last in Beckman-street, near Water, by the horses attached to Car No. 24,

A quorum has at length been obtained in the House by the reception of the report of the Committee on Credentials, and the consequent admission of members. The franchise law was passed by an overwhelming majority.

ARREST OF SUPPOSED BURGLARS.--Two young men giving their names as ROBERT REYNOLDS and GEORGE BROWN, were taken into custody at 12 o'clock on Thursday night, near the Jersey City Ferry, by Officer CARROLL, on suspicion of having stolen some wearing apparel which they had in their possession.

Considerable tumult was caused here this evening by the conduct of a theatrical company from New-York, STUART and TAYLOR, managers, who announced the play of the "Merry Wives of Windsor," with HACKETT as Falstaff, at the Academy of Music.

There is one part of the Civil Rights bill, in the practical working of which we anticipate that very great difficulty will be found, and we desire to call attention to it, that such difficulty many, if it exists, be possibly in some way remedied.

THE LAWS OF TRADE.--It has come out in the course of a legal trial now in progress in Cincinnati, that the butchers there have been charging twenty-five cents per pound for slop-fed beef that they only paid five or six cents for.

ST. STEPHEN'S CHURCH.--A grand concert in aid of the building fund of this Church will be given to-night by the artists of the Italian opera company. Miss ADELAIDE PHILLIPS, Mme. DE LUSSAN, Mlle. STELLA BONHEUR, Signor MAZZOLENI, Signor BELLINI, signor ANTONUCCI and Mr. APPY will take part in the entertainment.

Had Macbeth, the doughty Scottish chieftain, lived in these days of high civilization and abounding Knowledge, he scarcely would have hurled his sublime defiance at Macduff in the full faith that he should escape all unharmed by man's relentless anger "till Birnam woods do come to Dunsinane."

The lower part of this City may be said to be regularly rebuilt in every twenty years. There are but few buildings in the first, second and third wards to-day that ate older than that. Time was when the most elegant of our private residences were in the vicinity of the Battery and Bowling Green, and the time is within the memory, too, of young gentlemen whose beards are not yet grown.

The chief and almost solo topic of conversation in the South at present is the resident's Proclamation, which very naturally gives unqualified sailsfaction to the people in this section. Though they had ardently longed for some such measure, they had not dared to expect it at so early a day;

The whaling ship Congress arrived at Hilo from the Line, March 9. She had done nothing. The following vessels were at Margueretta Bay. Dec. 24: Barks Fanny Hunter, 100 barrels of oil; Hunchback, Nile and Richmond, clean; ship Reindeer, clean; bark Martha Thomas arrived clean, March 13:

Mining Stocks are firm; Ophir, $865; Savago, $1,095; Belcher, $360; Yellow Jacket, $830; Choliar Potosi, $355; Crown Point, $1,375. Legal-Tenders 97c. Sailed--Opposition steamer Moses Taylor, for San Juan del Sur.

Travel was to a great extent resumed on nearly all the City roads yesterday, but as soon as darkness set in the cars were withdrawn, as during the two previous evenings. On the Third-avenue line about 45 cars were running. All were crowded to excess.

BILLS PASSED. For the relief of the Brooklyn City and New-town Railroad Company. Incorporating the Brooklyn Masonic Hall Association. Relative to the College of the City of New-York, Incorporating the New-York Steam Transit Company.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We see by the New-York papers that we have had several cases of yellow-fever, cholera, , on this Island. I assure you there is no truth in the report. Key West has been for several months unusually healthy, and I do not believe there is a serious case of sickness on the Island.

The speech delivered by Mr. BRIGHT at Manchester on the 27th ult., seems to indicate the point at which the real agitation for new reforms in the representative system in England actually begins. There have for years been meetings held and speeches listened to, but no very strenuous efforts have been made by the mass of the people since 1832, to secure the further exercise of the franchise.

In the Chittenden County Court this evening the Jury returned a verdict of "Guilty" against JOHN WARD, alias Jerome Tavigue, of New-York City, for the murder of Mrs. SALLY GRISWOLD, of Williston, on the 28th of August last, and "Not guilty" for CHAS. H. POTTER, of Williston, for the same offence.

HENRY GARDINER, member of the Twelfth United States Infantry, and formerly a resident of Cleveland, Ohio, where he has a father, sister and two brothers living at present, was on Wednesday convicted of murder in the first degree, and today was sentenced by Judge BALOOM to be hung on Friday,

Gen, SHERIDAN has issued orders to the effect that all persons embarking from New-Orleans for VeraCruz, Tampico or Matamoras,, Mexico,,must obtain passports from the Provost.Marshal. This order causes much remark. The morning vapors say that the order is directed against Confederate colonization schemes.

The cargo of the Schoolier Satita, which arrived at Norfolk direct from the West Indies, was sold at auction here yesterday. The old line of steamers on the Chesapeake Bay have reduced their fares to $3,. in consequence of the competition for the travel introduced by the Leary line of steamers.

Tile annual report of our CitySuperintendent of Schools furnishes many suggestions and facts of value to the public. Every American understands the immense importance to our Republic of "education at the bottom," We feel it is for the highest public interest to afford every reasonable advantage to the poorest individual for a common education, and even for a considerable progress in knoweldge.

Pursuant to a call for a preliminary meeting of the Bar, to take measures for the formal meeting to be held in reference to the death of Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, the members of the Bar collected in the Law Library yesterday.

The man arrested at Cornwall yesterday turned out to be a person named WHEELER, an ex-confederate officer, and now a Lieutenant-Colonel in the Fenian army. On being searched his commission was found upon him, and authority given by Gen. SWEENEY to recruit a Fenian battalion in Canada.

The appointment of a new Postmastor for this city has been long expected, the "Gentiles " hereabout having for a considerable time been working to bring about such a consummation. Not that there was any special offence chargeable to the present incumbent, as pertaining to the duties of his office--the reasons being party reasons only, so far as I have heard.

On Monday evening the Fourth Regiment, Veteran Zouaves, assembled at the State Arsenal, corner of Thirty-fifth-street and Seventh-avenue, for battalion drill. The attendance was fair, but not as full as it ought to have been. One reason for this apparent lack of members was the illness of at least two of the officers commanding companies, Capts, WEBSTER and MORRIS.

THE ANNIVERSARY OF THE ASSASSINATION. In respect to the memory of the late President LIN. COLN, the public offices were to-day closed, including those of the Executive Mansion, The President did not receive visitors.

A SUSPICIOUS CHARACTER AT YORKVILLE.--The terrible family massacre that occurred in Philadelphia lately has awakened almost as much interest here as it has done in the vicinity of its occurrence. On Friday night a man answering the appearance of one of the murderers entered a liquor saloon near the corner of Ninety-second-street and Third-avenue, Yorkville.

No more gratifying news could be presented to the reader, this morning, than that of the arrest of the hired man ANTOINE, who, either with his own hands murdered the DEARING family, or aided in the fiendish work. He was captured by Officer DORSEY, of the Sixth Police District, who, in company with Officers ATKINSON and WELDON, of the same District, were on patrol duty, on Thursday night, in West Market-street.

DEATH OF PHILIP KENJOCKETY.--The aged Indian SKY-DYOE-GWA-DEH, or, as he was more familiarly known, PHILIP KENJOCKETY, died last Sunday afternoon at Newtown, on the Cattaraugus Reservation. KENJOCKETY was the oldest resident of this region. He came to "Buffalo Creek" with the Senecas, soon after the Revolutionary war,

DEATH OF OLE BULL. The Montreal Gazelle reports the death of OLE BULL, the celebrated violinist, at Quebec, on the 10th inst. This distinguished musical genius was born at Bergen, In Norway, Feb. 5, 1810, His early passion for music was repressed by his father, who placed him, at the ago of eighteen, at the University of Christina.

The following are among the bills passed by the Senate yesterday: For the relief of Brooklyn City and Newtown Railroad Company. Relative to the college of the City of New-York. Relative to exemption from jury duty in Kings county, Authorizing construction of a permanent quarantine establishment in the lower bay. Authorizing the taxation of stockholders in banks and banking associations.

BURTIS.--On Friday evening, April 13, CATHARINE, wife of Divine Burtis, aged 52 years. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend the funeral on Monday afternoon at 3 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 82 Summit-st., South Brooklyn, without further notice.

So crowded with mighty events was the April of a year ago, that the nation could not now, if it would do, more than note the brilliant record. Yesterday was memorable alike as the anniversary of the fall of Sumter, and of the dastardly murder of President LINCOLN--two events pregnant with national grief and indignation.

The bill taxing stockholders in National Banks passed the senate to-day by the decisive vote of 28 to 3, the dissenting Senators being Mossrs. KLINE, T. MURPHY and WOOD. The House will undoubtedly concur in the passage of the bill.

The hot days and sultry nights are drawing night when all animate creation longs for pure air, fresh breezes and cold water; when the un lever incapacistates the residents of cities to work, makes the blood sluggish and the brain heavy.

Although the eight hour movement has received its quietus in the Legislature for this session, the recent demonstration of workingmen at Union-square shows conclusively that the project is not abandoned. The indications are that an attempt will be made in the great cities by "strikes" to coerce the employers into adopting eight hours as a labor-day.

The New Almaden Quicksilver Company has on hand thlrty-four thousand flasks of quicksilver euough to supply the world for ninety days. The steamer Sacramento, from Panama, arrived here this morning with New-York dates of March 21.

The warlike attitude of Austria and Prussia promises to soon resolve itself into open hostilities, and any arrival from Europe may bring the news of the opening of a war which may involve the whole of Europe. In view of these facts we present our readers with some interesting data concerning the naval power of these two countries upon which the eyes of the world are at the present time turned.

From Le Follel, The law of fashion with regard to the make of dress seems now established in a very decided manner. It is quite inadmissible for nay dress to be made with plaits all round the waist; the front and sides, at any rate, must be plain. There are, however, two styles in vogue--the "Princesse" and the "Fourreau."

To-morrow the Military Court-martial assembles to investigate the frauds in the Quartermaster's Department. Brig.-Gen. A. C. GILLEN is President, and Capt. S. P. VOIS, Judge Advocate, assisted by Lieut.-Col. W. H. COYLE, Judge Advocate of the Department of Kentucky. HENRY BRUNER's case will be tried first. Maj. H. C. BLAKEMAN is counsel for the defence.

The pleasant little church (Episcopal) on Thirty-first-street, near Second-avenue, was well filled yesterday by a large and interested congregation, gathered to hear a few words of respect to the memory of the late DANIEL S. DICKINSON. Mr. DICKINSON was not noted for his devotion to the external forms of any denomination during his lifetime,...

Cotton is irregular; sales 1,600 bales; receipts to-day, 2,370 bales. Corn 88c. @90c. Sterling Exchange 33 1/2. Gold 125 1/4. Freights unaltered. Sugar, flour, oats, pork, bacon, hay and tobacco unchanged.

A NEW STEAMER.--The now sidewheel steamboat Henry Smith, Capt. W. H. KNAPP, went on her trial trip on Saturday. She is a handsomely-finished boat, 120 feet long, and 24 feet beam, named in honor of the President of the Board of Supervisors. A pleasant party of about fifty, including Mr. SMITH and friends, ladies, steamboatmen, and a brass band,

We observe in some quarters an inclination to discuss the question of the fisheries in a more warlike temper than existing circumstances appear to warrant. "Shall we have war for the fisheries?" is the suggestive interrogatory with which an influential contemporary starts upon the discussion.

Before judge Benedict. Edward Rowe vs. The Steamship City of Dublin, action is brought to recover damages for undue delay in delivering a case of merchandise shipped in the steamer City of Dublin, consigned to the libelant.

ALLATRE.--At Farmingdale, N. J. Monday, April 9, SARAH L., widow of Throckmorton A. Allaire. Her remains were taken to Shrewsbury for interment. BLACK.--On Saturday evening, April 14, ELLWOOD ASTEN, infant son of William T. and Josephine H. Black, aged 10 months and 26 days.

The almost total stoppage of the cars on the twelve lines of City railroad, which ordinarily furnish the facilities of daily travel from point to point on this island for over three hundred thousand of our citizens, has produced an amount of annoyance, suffering and loss to the public beyond any computation.

ROBBERY OF WATCHES AND JEWELRY.--A jeweler named BEAKS, doing business in Grove-street, near Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, was robbed about 12 o'clock, on Saturday night, of a number of watches and some jewelry, in all valued at about $500. It appears that Mr. BEAKS was in the habit of carrying home the most valnahla nart of his goods every night in a ??

The spirit and manner in which the Daily News and the World respectively respond to the charge that they are endeavoring to keep alive disaffection, and to sow the seed for another rebellion, are essentially characteristic, The World cries peccavi, and protests that its rhetorical thunder and its parade of Latin scraps were merely a display of editorial capacity, signifying nothing.

The closing obsequies of the late DANIEL S. DICKINSON were concluded hero this afternoon, He was buried in accordance to the rites of the Episcopal The funeral took place at the home of the deceased known as "The Orchard," and was witnessed by over 6,000 people.

The Saxonia brings dates to the 4th inclusive. The news is not especially important, but has some interesting features. The Prussian and Austrlan quarrel is still the main subject of anxiety on the continent, and opinions are very greatly varied. As for actual facts, they are few and inconsequential; thus far the quarrel is altogether one of words.

The New-Orleans Times of a recent date has the following interesting account of the wonderful deposits of salt on Petite Anse Island: Perhaps the purest and most important natural deposit of salt in the world is that found on, our coast, at Petito Anse Island, This deposit was referred to In FRENCH'S "Historical Recollections of Louisiana."

THE NEW-YORK COLLECTORSHIP. It is reported upon reliable authority that the President has appointed HENRY A. SMYTHE, Esq., President of the Central National Bank, Collector of New-York. I have no doubt his name will be ?? to the Senate to-morrow for confirmation.

The seventh anniversary of the Sunday-school and Juvenile Missionary Society of the Sixth-avonue Union reformed Dutch Church was celebrated last evening. The exercises, which consisted mainly of singing by the children of the Sabbath-school, were diversified by the distribution of prizes to the pupils and the presentation of life-memberships to their teachers.

The Senate has been in session till a late hour to night, engaged in an animated debate ver the bill to incorporate the Niagara Ship Canal Company, upon which more than half the Senators in the circle have taken occasion to express themselves, many of them displaying an amazing igaorance of the laws of commerce and trade.

GERMAN OPERA.--Mr. GROVER returns to the charge this evening, and with a fair chance of carrying his point. The company is neither stronger nor better than last season, but the repertoire is interesting. In what fashion nine grand operas can be presented on eight evenings we are at a loss to imagine, but his is Mr. GROVER's affair, not ours.

It is a matter of mercantile curiosity and interest to notice the amount of sales the last ten months by some of our largest houses, as taken from the official record and reported in the daily papers.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. 14th-st., corner of Irving-place. THIS EVENING, commencing at 8 o'clock, GERMAN OPERA--FAUST. Cast including Joseph Hermans, Franz Himmer, Mme. Johanna Rotter Mlle. Sophia Dziuba, Heinrich Steinecke, Wagner, Lehman, Marta, Mme. Berger.

A COLLECTOR FOR NEW-YORK APPOINTED. As indicated in my dispatch of last night, the Presdent sent to the Senate to-day the nomination of HENRY A. SMYTHE to be Collector of the Port of NewYork. Mr. SMYTHE is well and favorably known in business circles; was formerly a leading dry goods merchant, and is now a Director in the Bank of Commerce, and President of the Central National Bank.

On the heights of the west bank of the Harlem River stands a fine old mansion, dating back long before the days of the Revolution; a house in which WASHINGTON, LAFAYETTE and their cotemporaries wrote their dispatches during that dark period when the British landed and occupied the City;

The United States steamor Winooski arrived hero yesterday. She is supposed to have been sent here to observe noutrality on the border. A party of five men, supposed to be Fenians, went across to Indian Island, on Saturdry night, and presented their revolvers at the head of the Deputy Collector, demanded his flag, (Brittish), which he was compelled to give up to them.

President SCHULTZ is to meet the street-cleaning contractors again at 9 o'clock this morning, and the contractors are probably to decide whether they will retain or surrender their contract. They will, of course, retain it, notwithstanding the action of the Board of Health threatens to reduce their profits below $250.000 a year;

The Collector of the Port yesterday received the following important dispatch from our Conusl at Halifax: HALIFAX, April 16. To the Collector of Customs of the Port of New-York: The city physicians on board the emigrant ship England, after further developments of the disease and fuller consultations last evening, concur in pronouncing it Asistic cholera.

BILLS PASSED. incorporating the Now-York Board of Fire Underwriters; to improve Grand-street, Brooklyn; to lose a portion of Lefferts-street, Brooklyn; for the Improvement of Third-street, Brooklyn; authorizing the draining of low lands in Fishkill; authorizing the formation of the Rockaway Beach Land Improvement Company; amending the charter of the Southwestern Mining and Land Company-lost.

The Mexican question seems to have passed Into a new phase. The French Emperor has promised to withdraw his troops from the support of MAXIMILIAN, and to remain entirely neutral in his struggle with the Mexican Republic, upon the understanding that the United States shall remain neutral also.

The supposed accomplice in the sevenfold Philadelphia murderer has been arrested here. He gives his name as CHARLES MCCUTCHEON. When arrested he turned pale and nearly fainted. The only discrepancy between the description of the murderer and the appearance of the prisoner is, that instead of having lost a thumb his forefinger is gone.

BLACK.--On Saturday evening, April 14, ELLWOOD ASTEN, infant son of William T, and Josephine H. Black, aged 10 months and 26 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his parents, No, 101 East 33d-st., on Tuesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

WHERE, OH WHERE?--Where in the world is that Fenian ship which left the northeastern coast of Maine a week ago on a secret "expedition?" It cannot possibly have landed its load at any point on the island of Campo Bello, nor of Newfoundland or Nova Scotia, nor on Prince Edward Island or NewBrunswick. The question, therefore, arises.

After a series of announcement and many dis. appointments the name of a New-Yorker has boon sent for confirmation as Collector of this port to the Senate, The fortunate individual, whose days will henceforth be a continuous scene of turmoil, whose nights will belong rather to his political friends than to his family, is Mr, HENRY A. SMYTHE.

To the Editors of the National Intelligence: GENTLEMEN : In your paper of this morning I observe a very incorrect and perverted report of one of my recent opinions in a habeas corpus case. In that opinion I did not express a doubt of the legality of the late Peace Proclamation,

Present--John Brice, Esq., President. Aldermon Moore, Coman, Norton, McBrien, Flynn, Shannon, Godney, Ely, Reilly, Loew, Masterson, O'Brien, Varnum, McGinnis. The minutes of April ninth and twelfth were read.

The steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 4th, via Queenstown on the 5th inst., at. rived at this port yesterday morning, bringing one day's later news from Europe. The steamship Hibernian, from Portland, arrived at Londonderry on the 5th inst.

The City of New-York brings one day's later news. There is no material change in the aspects of the Austro-Prussian misunderstanding. It is said that the French troops in Mexico will be withdrawn in three detachments, in November, March and November, 1867.

COLLINS, a clerk, what purported to be a check on the City Bank, of Hartford, Conn., for $289 39, and drawn by "JOHN HENNESSY, Treasurer of the Traders' Insurance Company, of Hartford,"
THE NATIONAL SOLDIERS ASYLUM. Mr. WILSON reported, without amendment, from the Committee on Military Affairs, a joint reso1ution appointing managers for a national asylum for disabled volunteers.

A terrible explosion of what was supposed to be nitra glicerine, occurred at a 1:15 o'clock to-day, near WELLS, FARGO Co.'s building. The explosion hook the earth like an earthquake for a circle of a quarter of a mile.

The friends of Rev. SAMUEL L. TUTTLE will be surprised and pained to hear of his death, which took place at Madison, N, J., yesterday morning, Mr. TUTTLE was about 50 years of ago, and was well known throughout the central part of New-Jersey as a faith. ful pastor.

The testimony reported to-day from the Committee on Reconstruction, embraces the examination of a dozen witnesses, relating to the condition of Arkansas, Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia. It is conflicting in its character in respect to all the States excepting the former, about which all the witnesses so far examined, agree in testifying favorably.

THE CHOLERA AT HALIFAX.--The medical men at Halifax agree that the disease which has committed such ravages among the passengers by the steamship England is Asiatic cholera. The United States Consul telegraphs to that effect,

In company with several thousand (more or less) follow sufferers we attended theo Private View" afforded the press and friends of the members of the National Academy of Design last evening. I take the last hour of an open supplemental mail to give you later news from the seat of war. Admiral LAMANDARE arrived on the 23d of February at the fleet, and infused the first signs of life noticed for the last four months. Orders are issued for all things to be in readiness for an important move on the 10th of March.

Yesterday the prayers of the old drivers were answered so far as they referred to the weather, for it was a wet, rainy, sloppy, slippery disagreeable day. This state of things conduced to the confusion of the new drivers, to the damaging of the property of the various companies, and to the exultation of the strikers.

The "grand advance guard" of the O'Mahony Fenians, under the generalship of the redoubtable KILLIAN, are making comic history in a style of which GILBERT A'BECKETT never dreamed. A quiet vein of the grotesque, verging on the ludicrous, and rising now and then to the laughable, was all of which that funniest of funny historians was capable.

In a criticism of the last Brooklyn Philharmonic Concert, which appeared in your issue of Monday, there are misstatements reflecting upon CHICKERING SONS, which we trust you will have the fairness to correct. The following is the paragraph containing the misstatement. Speaking of Mile. POCH, it says:

To the Editor of the New- York Times: There has been a great deal of sympathy expressed by the City Press for the drivers who have refused to work at the wages offered and heretofore paid by the City Railroads. But is not that sympathy based more on the general hostility to the companies than any real attempt at oppression on their part?

An incorrect copy of the new license law having been published in this City, the TIMES publishes the following, which is a copy of the law bearing Gov. FENTON's signature: AN ACT TO REGULATE THE SALE OF INTOXICAING LIQUORS WITHIN THE METROPOLITAN POLICE DISTRICT OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK.

ARRIVAL OF THE FIFTY-FOURTH NEW-YORK VETERAN VOLUNTEERS.-This regiment arrived in the City yesterday by the steamer Gen. Barne, from Charleston. It was formed in this City in September, 1861, since which time it has seen much service. It served with distinction on Morris, Folly, and James Islands, and at the taking of Charleston. The following is the list of its field and staff officers: E. A. Kozlay,

The Senate get into a sanguinary mood this afternoon, and after considerable debate, slaughtered two New-York City railroad bills. The Christopher street Cross-town Road, which was reported favorably by a majority of the Railroad Committee, was defeated on the motion to order the bill to a third reading by the following vote:

NOYES--GARNDER.--On Tuesday, April 17, St. Bartholmew's Church by Rev. Samuel Cooke, D. D., BENJAMIN NOYES, of New-Haven, Conn., and Miss MARYLAND VIRGINIA GARNDER of this City. WILSON--HOWE.--On Tuesday, April 17, by Rev. Mr. A. J. Canfield, Mr. B. D. WILSON, of Brooklyn, E. D., and Miss KATE L. HOWE, of New-York.

The steamship Manhattan, Capt. SUMNER, from Vera Cruz April 8 and Havana 13th, arrived here last night. Among the passengers by the Manhattan are M. BLONDEL DE BOLDENDROCK, Minister from Belgium to Mexico, and Count DE LA JOUR, Minister from Italy to Mexico. Also Count DE PODENAS.

Consul GODEY has received a letter from JUAREZ dated El Paso, March 9, stating that the troops sent to chihuahua would occupy that place, and in eight days from that date the Liberal Government would be established there. A letter from Gen. ALVAREDO fully confirms the defeat of MENDEZ by the Liberals at Urdapan.

The Board met pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number seventeen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President in the Chair, and the following members; Councilment Keenan, Long. Stacom, Flynn. Robinson, O'Brien, Kenney, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, White, Mackay, Kellogg, Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Roberts, Pullman, Bettrick, Imlay--24. The minutes of the previous meeting were read the approved.

The car drivers, who have been on a strike for an increase of wages since Wednesday of last week, are apparently as far from the fulfillment of their desires as they were before quitting their work. They demand two dollars and fifty cents per day for their labor, and the Directors of the various roads refuse to pay it, alleging that they cannot afford to do so.

The new Collector, Mr. SMYTHE, came on from Washington Monday night, to prepare for an early entrance upon his new duties. On the train were the friends of various candidates, and two of his unsuccessful competitors; but it would have been difficult to inter from aught that was said, looked or done, which were the "ins" and which the "oats."

THE SCHUYLKILL ARSENAL. Mr. WILSON introduced a joint resolution to provide for the erection of fire-proof buildings at the Schuylkill Arsenal, near Philadelphia, which appropriates $46,000 for the erection of storehouses for the storage of Government property. Referred to the Military Committee.

The Legislature met to-day. A violent attack was made by two members upon two daily papers, the Gazelle and the Banner of this city. The Knoxville Whig was also assailed by Mr. WILLIAMS, a member of the House. The military court-martial for the trial of H. BRUNER, met this morning.

THE NEW EXCISE LAW OF NEW-YORK.--This measure, constituting, as it may be made to constitute, a powerful engine for reforming very much that has been wretchedly and defiantly vile in our City, has passed the Legislature, and the Police are at once proceeding to at upon it.

Advices from Brownsville say it was reported there that the Liberals had captured a wagon train between Paros and Monteroy with $20,000, and killed and captured about 200 French soldiers. The train, consisting of 150 wagons, left Monterey about the 1st of April, with supplies and money for Matamoras, escorted by 1,400 Imperialists, Gen.

The following comprehensive and important order has just been issued from Police Headquarters, in relation to the inspection of all places where liquor is sold or drank, with a view to determine the licensing of the same: OFFICE OF THE SUPT. OF METROPOLITAN POLICE, NO. 300 MULBERRY-STREET, NEW-YORK, April 17, 1866.}

BILLS PASSED. Incorporating the Traders' Exchange. Incorporating the Bond Deposit Company of New-York. To facilitate the construction of the Whitehall and Plattsburgh Railroad. It appropriates $50,000 per mile for ninety miles. Passed by 24 to 8.

Mr. ALEX. H. STEPHENS' testimony before the Reconstruction Committee is described in the Washington correspondence of a cotemporary as " the most damaging to the South yet brought out." Wo have looked through the evidence, as reported by the Committee, without finding anything in the tone, form or substance of his statements to sustain such an impression.

There is much alarm about the levees on account of the high water above. It is feared that the whole Lower Mississippi will be overflowed. Heavy rains have injured the cotton seed, which was poor, and much land must be replanted.

THE STRIKE--THE COMPANIES' DEFENCE.The strike continues. The Railway Companies still refuse the advance asked by the drivers. A momentary truce, yesterday, between the Third-avenue managers and a portion of their employes, is all the indication we have, as yet, that a compromise is any longer possible.

THE COLLECTOR.--The appointment of Mr. HENRY A. SMYITHE as Collector of the port of New-York not only ends " a long agony," but seems to have ended it auspiciously. Mr. SMYTHE'S appointment is well received by the Press and by our citizens generally.

Yesterday was regarded as the legitimate commencement of the trotting season on Long Island, the first of the series of purses given by the new proprietor of the Fashion Course being then contended for. It is true that a trot had come off on this track the week previous; but as it was more of a private than a public character, few of the regular habitues of the course attended it.

AN INTERESTING MATTER FOR INQUIRY,--Hon. WM. L. SHARKEY, of Mississippi, who, having occupied-the highest judicial position in the State of Mississippi, having acted as Provisional Governor, and being now Senator-elect, may be supposed to be at once thoroughly informed as to that of which he testifies, and anxious to give his testimony honestly and in good faith,

In the County Court in this city to-day WM. H. STEVENS, one of the crew of the four-cared shell-boat, which was matched against a New-York boat, in a race opposite Poughkeepsie, in July last, and who got into a difficulty with a man named THOMAS MCDERMOTT, on the evening of the day of the race, which difficulty resulted in MCDERMOTT'S death,

PRESIDENT JOHNSON TO THE SOLDIERS AND SAILORS. The Soldiers' and Sailor' Union having called a mass meeting of their friends for this evening, invited the President to be present. Mr. JOHNSON sends this reply: Wm. S. Morse, Esq., Chairman Committee of Arrangements,

The following note comes from a responsible source: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Rev. J. WEST begs to earnestly present the case of the bearer JACOB ANCONA--who lost his hand on the battle-field, his father being also a soldier--to present it for the purpose of soliciting an advertisement of his want of something to do--or for any work for him.

BULLEY.--In this City, on Monday, April 16, JOHN BULLEY, Jr., in the 34th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectively invited to attend his funeral from his late residence, No. 313 West 22d-st., this (Wednesday) afternoon at 3 o'clock, His remains will be taken to Poughkeepsie for interment.

BIG BUSINESS IN COTTON.--The shipments of Cotton from this port, exclusively, during the week ending last evening, were to the unusually heavy amount of 21,100 bales, of the currency value of $3,697,518; including, to Liverpool, 18,586 bales, valued at $3,299,482; to Hamburg, 1,101 bales, valued at $184,314 ; to Bremen, 920 bales, valued at $139,506;

The judgment of all sensible people will approve the course of the Government in making no more than is necessary of the farcical proceedings on the Maine frontier, at and around Eastport. Madmen and ordinary law-breakers are taken care of by the police. Military service involves a higher range and a broader scope of duty.

There was a passage at arms in the House today, between M. WOODRUFF, editor of the Union, and Gen. J. P. BROWNLOW, the latter denouncing WOODRUFF in the strongest sterms. Pistols were drawn, but the parties were finally separated. The trial of BRUNER has been resumed.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. Wilson introluced a bill to prevent and punish the issue of false stamps, brands and stencils, which was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. Mr. GRIMES inproduced a bill regulating the appointment of officers in the navy. It provides for 1 Vice-Admiral, 11 RearAdmirals, 25 Commodores, 50 Captains, 90 Commanders, 108 Lieutenants, 160 Ensigns, and in other trades tile number now allowed.

At a meeting of the Board of Fire Commissioners, held at Firemen's Hall yesterday afternoon, the following appointments and promotions were made: Assistant Foreman, MICHAEL KELLY, of Metropolitian Engine Company No. 3, promoted Foreman of same Company; private JAMES HORN to be Assisstant Foreman of same Company.

The annual meeting of the officers and patrons of the New-York Lying-In Asylum was held yesterday afternoon at that institution. Mrs. JOHN W. SCHMIDT, the First Directress, prosided, and the proceedings were opened with prayer by the Rev. Dr. BURCHARD, of the Twelfth-street Presbyterian Church, who continued the religious exercises by reading a selection of Scripture.

RAID ON NEW-YORK PEDDLERS.--For several days past a number of the Jersey City Policemen have been paying particular attention to the peddlers from New-York who cross over to Jersey City for the purpose of supplying their customers with crackers, candy, pies, cured fish, mustards,

The steamer City of Norwich, of the New-London and New-York line of steamers, came in collision with the schooner Gen. S. Van Vlict in Long Island Sound, cif Huntington Light, about 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning. The schooner struck the City of Norwich just lerward of the paddic-house, crushing in her side, and allowing the water to rush in on her lower deck.

Within a circuit of thirty miles of New-York are located all the principal training quarters of racing thoroughbreds in the Northern States. As the turf campaign is soon to be inaugurated, a descriptive account of our reporter's visits to them, and of the horses in active training preparation for their Summer and Fall racing engagements may not prove uninteresting.

FLYING FROM THE CHOLERA.--It is said that numerous persons of weak nerves are contemplating a flight from the City, in hope of being spared the chance of attacks of cholera, Such persons may as well be assured that their intentions are founded entirely in error. There is no calculating the exact spots which will be reached by the disease, nor its violence as respects locality.

The cars upon the various City roads were running quite regularly yesterday, and the public experienced less inconvenience from the strike than on any previous day since the trouble began. No arrangement has been made with the old drivers, but the companies are employing new men to take their, places.

The bill allowing an increase of half a cent per milo passenger faro on fast trains of the New-York Central Railroad passed the Senate, as was expected, this afternoon. Various amendments wore offered and voted down. Among these was one limiting the operation o the bill to three years;

PAY DEPARTMENT IN THE NAVY. Mr. GRIMES, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported the bill passed by the House to provide for the better organization of the pay department of the navy, with an amendment in the first section relative to assistant and passed assistant paymasters.

ARCHER.--On Wedneday, April 18, DEBORAH ARCHER, aged 75 years. Her relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at the Memorial Church, corner of Hammond-st. and Waverley-place, on Friday morning, 20th inst., at 9 A. M. Her remains will be taken to Yonkers for interment.

It is now rendered certain that nitro-glycorine caused yesterday's explosion. No marks on the box containing it indicated its character. The bodies of eight persons killed by yesterday's explosion have boon identified. Seven or eight others are missing, who were probably blown to atoms.

THE RAILWAY COMPANIES AND THEIR GUARDIANS.--We are not accustomed to find fault with the Police administration. As a rule, it is exceedingly efficient, and, as a rule, fault finding would be altogether unjustifiable. But the public do complain that so many of the Police force should be taken from their duties proper to enable the Railroad Companies to break in a new set of drivers,

In the Senate yesterday Mr. GRIMES reported the bill passed by the House to provide for the better organization of the Pay Department of the Navy. The resolution appropriating $127,785 for fulfilling certain treaties with Indian tribes was passed. The resolution of thanks to Gen. HANCOCK was also passed. The House resolution appointing managers for the National Soldiers' Asylum was passed.

President McLEAN resumed his chair at the meeting of the Boardof Education last evening. After routine business a communication was received from the School Trustees of the Fifth Ward, recommending that Colored School No. 5 be closed on the 25th instant, and that the pupils be removed to such suitable place as the Board's officers may designate. Tho subject was referred to the Building Committee, with power.

The Grand Jury this morning found a true bill of indictment against ANTOINE PROBST, for the murder of the DEARING family. The prisoner was brought into Court and arraigned at 1 o'clock this afternoon. After much legal delay, the prisoner having no counsel, the Court assigned him Messrs. JOHN P. O'NEILL and J. C. WOLBERT.

The pressure upon our advertising columns precludes the publication of a detailed report of the interesting and impressive proceedings in the United States Court-room yesterday afternoon. A meeting was hold of the members of the Bar, presided over by Judge BETTS, at which the prominent members of the Judiciary and Bar assembled to testify their appreciation of the virtues and accomplishments of the late DANIEL S. DICKINSON, and their regret at his deceased.

The same philosophical characteristics that distinguished the speeches of Mr. STEPHENS, of Georgia, appear in his testimony, recently given before the Committee on Reconstruction. It differs very strikingly in several respects, and in none more than in its vein of philosophy, from the testimony of Gen. LEE. LEE declined to indulge in speculative fancies;

This now fortnightly magazine has made its appearance. Externally and internally it possesses some novel features which will attract attention and secure it a wide popularity. The cover is chocolate colored, with the design and lettering in gold.
