Hassey, J. Cl. Movwatt Mr. Blondel de Boldenbrook and valet, Count de la Tour and valet, Dr. and Mrs. Prevost, 18 children and 2servants Dr. Davis, Dr. Hough, C. Covert, Mrs. Lyona, 2 children and nurse, and 4 in the stearage.

AN EXTRAORDINARY TRIAL.--The English papers give quite a long report of the trial before one of the Assize Courts of a child ten years old, named EMILY BALLARD, on a charge preferred by Rev. G. R. GRAY, of stealing a penny from a schoolmate named SARAH JANE GOUGH.

BRITISH-AMERICAN CONFEDERATION.--A telegram from Halifax announces that both Houses of the Nova Scotian Parliament have passed resolutions in favor of a Confederation of the Provinces. This insures the carrying out of the scheme. In a few weeks the question will go before the Imperial Parliament.

The following interesting letter was recently received by the Secretary of State from a volunteer soldier of the Sixth Michigan Cavalry. It has been handed to us for publication: HONORABLE SIR: I take this privilege of addressing to you a few lines from Texas.

The trial of HENRY BRUNER was resumed this morning. Capt. SAMUEL P. VOORHEES of the Thirtyeighth Illinois Volunteers, Judge Advocate, made application for an adjournment of the case, on the ground that an application has been made to the General commanding tile milltary division to send for counsel to assist in the prosocution of the case.

The steamship Virginia, from Liverpool April 4, vid Queenstown on the 5th, arrived at this port yesterday. Thirty-eight deaths occurred on board during her passage, of which two were among the crow. The disease is said to be the same as that with which the steamship England is infected.

The necessity for legislation in reference to the mineral lands of the country has long been felt by all concerned in their occupation and development. In the absence of a national law upon the subject, Territories and States have made provision for the protection of private rights and interests, though this provision has usually gone little further than the empowering of the miners themselves to make regulations binding upon their particular districts.

The congregation known as "Adas Jeshurun" was organized in July, 1804, and now number some eighty members. Since then they have been unprovided with a fitting place for worship. Yesterday their Rabbi, Rev. Dr, ADLER, laid the corner stone of a new synagegue now in process of erection in Thirty-ninth-street, between Seventh and Eighth-avenues.

This corporation, which was originally chartered by the Legislaturo in 1824, has been reorganized, and the capital stock increased from $200,000 to $800,000. Under its present charter, the Company is anthorized to insure against lose or damage by inland navigation and transportation, as well as against fire.

FOR THE BOARD OF HEALTH.--We venture to call the attention of the Health Commissionere to certain pools of stagnant water in the upper wards of the City. Several exceedingly noxious pools may be seen by the Inspectors close to Eightieth, Eighty-first and Eighty-second streets, and Fourth-avenue.

A stallion trot for $600, mile heats, best three in five, came off on the Fashion Course, Long Island, yesterday afternoon, between two horses owned in Fulton Market, and known on the road by the names of Indian Chief and Hornflower; the former in harness and the latter to a 350-pound wagon. The race excited very little interest beyond the immediale friends of the respective owners of the horses,

MILK AND WATER.--It is amusing, in view of the indignant denials with which our last year's statements that milkmen watered their milk were met by dealers, to notice that the Police report the names of about forty worthies who "usually" attenuate their lacteal merchandise at the hydrant between Forty-eighthstreet and Lerington-avenue.

In steamship Virginia, from Liverpool--Miss Wilkinson, Col. Wilkinson, Mr. Harding, Mme, A. Miller, Miss W. Miller, Miss L. Miller, Capt. Clang, Mrs. McCard, Mrs. J. Secley, Mr. Hall, A, Habersach, F. Habersach, A. Henderthan, A. E. Hastings, and 1,029 in the steerage.

BILLS PASSED. Amending the charier of St. Stephen's College. For the better protection of sick and infirm immigrants arriving at the port of New-York. Increasing the compensation for the care and education of deaf mutes. Confirming the title of the citizens of this State to lands derived through the conveyance of aliens.

COMMERCE IN THE ORIENT.--Rev. D. STUART DODGE delivered an interesting familiar lecture on "Commerce in the Orient," at the Free Reading-room of the Young Men's Christian Association, No.76 Varick-street, last evening, to a large and attentive audience. He glanced at the past and briefly stated the present condition of Eastern commerce

Adam Van Allen, , et al., plaintiff's in error, vs. Michael A. Nolan, et al,, defendants in error; and two other cases.--The facts and points of law involved in these cases were stated in the TIMES at the time of the argument, and will be remembered, The Supreme Court and the Court of Appeals of this State had held that the Acts of Congress authorized the tax, and judgment was rendered accordingly.

THE FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES AND THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--The advance in fire insurance yesterday, resolved upon by the Board of Underwriters, is, we regret to say, not only a new tax upon every property-owner on the Island, but is also practically a vote of nonconfidence in the present organization of the Fire Department.

The inclosures on the levee of the New-York Mail Steamship Company, and of the Atlantic and Mississippi Steamboat Company, were torn down to-day, amidst great excitement. It was done by the City Surveyor by order of the Council, on the Ground that the inclosures were illegal.

The steamer Barcelona arrived yesterday from St. Thomas, Puerto Rico and St. Domingo, from the latter we get no news, neither is any published in the papers of Santiago de Cuba. No cause is yet assigned for this. From Puerto Rico we have dates to the 3d. A subscription has been started at Nagriabo to aid Spain in the war declared against her by Chili and Peru.

GERMAN OPERA.--Mr. GROVER is certaiinly not fortunate in finding himself sandwiched between two Italian opera companies--Mr. MARETZEK'S the gone, and Mr. GRAU'S the coming. But it is perhaps on indication of his pluck that he is willing to occupy so tight a position. Better times, mayhap, are in store for him. At all events he does the best with his opportunity.

Last evening the Union Hall of the Cooper Institute was filled with enthusiastic Fenians of the Sweeny denomination. A band was in attendance, which, prior to the formal opening of the meeting, played national and Irish airs alternately.

GRAY--DUFF.--On Wednesday, April 18, by Rev. Jas. Mcdougall, Jr., HENRY T. GRAY and EMMA J., eldest daughther of the late J. T. Duff, Esq., all of Brooklyn. GWYNNE--PARKER.--At Grace Church, Jersey City, on Wednesday, April 18, by Right Rev. W. H. Odenhefiner, assisted by Rev. S. M. Rice, Wat. GWYNNE. of New-York, and MARY E., daughter of Robert R. Parker, of Jersey City.

The last accounts received from Mexico mention a victory obtained by the French contra-guerrilla chief, Col. DUPIN, over the brother of tile nowlyelected Liberal Coommander, GAIZA, at Orcasitas. It appears that Col. DUPIN left Tula on the 5th of last month for Tampico, and on the 11th came up with some of the enemy's dragoons, ambuscaded along the side of the road that the Imperialists were following.

IMPROVEMENTS--THE "OLD STEAMBOAT" TO BE REMODELED.--For the past 25 years a piece of ground forming an angle, bounded by Fulton-avenue, Willoughby and Pearl streets, has been occupied by a collection of old wooden buildings called Linden-row,but from the peculiar shape of the plot upon which they stand, was more familiarly known as "The Old Steamboat."

SERENADE TO THE PRESIDENT. At 6 o'clock this evening a procession of soldiers and sailors, and such of their friends as sympathize with them in their grateful acknowledgments to the President for his order lately issued directing the Heads of Departments to give preference in appointments and promotions in the subordinate offices

The steamship Persia arrived at this port last evening, with three days later advices. There had "been no material change in the relations between Prussia and Austria; both Powers continued to make warlike preparations and there was little hope o maintaining peace. Great agitation prevailed in Franco and Italy on the subject and both countries were preparing to concentrate armies of observation on their German frontiers.
The volunteers who were sent to the Lower Canada frontier have been recalled, Fenian raids being no longer feared. The examination of the Fenian prisoners at Cornwall continues with closed doors.

BROMLEY--CARPENTER.--At St. John's Church, New Haven, on Tuesday, April 17, by Rev. Dr. Benjamin Stone, Miss MARGARETTA CARPENTER and EDWARD BROMLEY. BROWER--BECKLEY.--On Wednesday, April 18, at the Reformed Dutch Church, Lafayette-place, by Rev. Thomas De Witt, D. D., JOHN BROWER and SARAH L., daughter of Samuel M. Beckley, Esq., of this City.

"VALLANDIGHAM called on THAD, STEVENS to-day, and in course of conversation stated that if the President did not immediately begin to appoint Democrats to office he could not retain the adherence of a single Democrat three weeks longer."--Tribune.

The Board of Health held a special meeting, yesterday afternoon, to take measures in relation to the cholera on board the steamship Virginia. A committee was appointed to visit the ship and report this afternoon. Registrar HARRIS sent in a series of blank forms which he had prepared for physicians, clergymen and others.

Paper pipes possess great advantages over others for many purposes. They are highly glazed inside, and thus diminish firetion, are impregnated with bitumen, and therefore not attacked by insects or asides. Besides these points of superiority, they are sufilcieutly elastic to permit water to freeze in them without bursting, and pipes of 3, 4, and 5 inches diameter and a half inch thickness, have withstood a pressure of 500 pounds to the square inch.

FATAL CITY CAR ACCIDENT.--About 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, HENRY SUNKEL, aged 9 years, and residing with his parents at No. 57 Forsyth-street, was run over in the Bowery near Spring-street, by Car No. 26, of the Fourth-avenue line, being almost instantly killed by the wheels passing over his neck.

NATIONAL MILITIA SYSTEM--The extent to which the General Government should regulate and enforce militia laws throughout the States of the Union is deserving of consideration in connection with the military bill now before Congress.

President JOHNSON'S experience of the an noyances incident to his every official act, as briefly told to the soldiers and sailors of the Union on Wednesday evening, does not widely differ, we fancy, from the experience of every one who strives to do his duty. When he does anything, howsoever meritorious, the motives that have prompted him are impugned and abused.

The Cunard steamship Persia, Capt. LOTT, which left Liverpool at noon on the 7th, and Queenstown on the 8th inst., arrived at this port last evening. The Hibernian reached Liverpool on the evening of the 5th inst. The New-York arrived at Southampton on the 5th.

AN APOLOGY FROM SENATOR M'DOUGAL. Mr. McDOUGAL rose and said: A few days ago I made some remarks of a personal nature. It is believed by my personal friends that these remarks were a violation of the decorum of the Senate. After their advice, and on careful consideration, I now acknowledge the wrong, and ask the pardon of the Senate.

A GREAT BLUNDER OR A SHREWD TRICK--THE NEW JERSEY CITY POLICE LAW A DEAD LETTER.--The discovery was made, yesterday afternoon, that the new Police Law for Jersey City, creating a Board of Commissioners, was a dead letter, through informality. The City Clerk, Mr. SCOTT, sent to Trenton for a certified copy of the Police Bill, and upon looking it over, discovered that some of the Senate amendments were not contained therein.

Dispatches, dated March 23, received to-day from Mazatian, state that the French army, 1,100 strong, reinforced from Tepic, attacked Gens. CORONA and RUBY, three miles from Mazatlan. After a severe battle the French were entirely defeated, with the loss of 700 killed and wounded, 350 scattered, and the remainder returned to Mazatlan.

Notwithstanding the assurances of the Vienna press that Austria is not arming, the advices from Paris and other political centres, by the Persia last night, show that there is a prodigious massing of troops near the old battle grounds of the former wars between the two German Powers.

From the Mount Sterling, (Ky.,) Sentinel. Below we publish a letter of Gen. JACKSON'S, written to CUTHBERT BANKS, Esq., introducing to him the celebrated AARON BURR. This letter bears date Aug. 13, 1805, and carries the mind far back to the memorable days of our past history; the days of JEFFERSON, MADISON and MONROE.

The steamer Moniezuma, from Kingston, arrived here yesterday, with Jamaica advices tothe 7th instant. The Royal Commission closed its sittings on the 4th inst., and it was expected that Mr. RUSSELL GURNEY, M. P. and Mr. MAULE would return to England in the stamer leavingt Kingston on the 9th of the present month for Southampton.

THE FINE ARTS.--We have on several occasions been moved to praise the very delicately perfected chrome-lithographic prints published by L. PRANG Co., of Boston. and again we are admiring a little gem--a group of chickens contending for a fly which two of them are pulling at.

ARCHER.--On Wednesday, April 18, DEBORAH ARCHER, aged 75 years. Her relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at the Memorial Church, corner of Hammond-st. and Waverley-place, on Friday morning, 28th inst., at 9 A. M. Her remains will be taken to Yonkers for interment. BRITTEN.--At his late residence, Communipaw, N. J., on Wednesday, April 18, ABRAHAM BRITTEN, aged 63 years and 1 month.

As was announced by yesterday morning's TIMES, the National Steam Navigation Company's steamship Virginia arrived at Quarantine on Wednesday evening, with 14 cabin and 1,029 steerage passengers, and with Aslatic cholera on board. The facts were communicated to Dr. SWINBURNE immediately on the arrival of the ship, and the Doctor and Assistance Health Officer BURDETT lost no time in boarding the vessel and making a through investigation.

FRANCE AND MEXICO.--Few Well-informed persons will bo disposed to credit the report of a London journal, brought last night by the Persia--that the Emperor of the French, after withdrawing his troops from the interior of Mexico, intends to keep possession of Vera Cruz and other commercial ports as security for the expenses of the invasion.

An altercation took place to-day at the Custom-house between Gen. BURBRIDGE and a cotton planter from Shreveport, about some cotton transactions. BURBRIDGE fired three times. No blood was shed. Gen. MCINTOSH reports the Indian Territory has been desolated by the war, and will not recover for years. The people are very destitute.

A PAINFUL ACCIDENT.--A correspondent asks special attention to a painful occurence. He says: A sad, and not unfrequent accident, occurred to-day on one of the City cars, which calls for a word of caution. A passenger sat with his elbow out of the window, when the stake of an empty cart struck it.

LETTER-BOXES ON THE CITY CARS--The Postoffice Department has authorized the attachmont of an Iron letter-box to each car of the Union Passenger Railway Company of Phildelphia with a wide mouth in the exterior panel of the car, enabling persons on the line of the road to drop letters into the box as the car moves along.

GERMAN OPERA.--"La Dame Blanche" was given here last evening in a very effective and satisfactory manner. the audience--like the popularity of the opera--was "wide spread." It was inadequate to the occasion, and teaches us that opera, after all, is but a fashion with the masses, not a social necessity. There are but few serio-comic operas in the world, and this is one of the best.

For the purpose of more fully supplying the wants of the public, and in order to prevent unscrupulous dealers from palming off inferior and worthless goods as the MORTON GOLD PENS, I shall hereafter SELL NO GOODS AT WHOLESALE excepting only to duty Appointed and Authorized Agents, to whom a Certificate of such Agency will be given, and who alone shall be able to sell the MORTON PRESS in that city or village.

THE LATE RAILWAY STRIKE.--As we all know, the car-drivors' strike-which is now at an end-has been prolific of immense inconvenience to the public, great suffering to the strikers and their families, and no small loss in money to the railroad companies.

BILLS REPORTED. Relative to dividends of Life Insurance Companies. To enable the Board of Supervisors of New-York to raise money. Regulating hours of labor of drivers in New-York. Incorporating the New-York Northern Railroad Company.

A correspondent of the American Messenger estimates the number of Norwegians settled in the Northwest at two hundred thousand, one-third of them in Wisconsin. They are a rural people, having farms of moderate size, and living quiet and industrious lives. Few of them can read English, and their supply of native literature is very meagre.

Gov. FENTON'S vote of the Oneida Lake Canal Hill has created a great sensation here with the numerous friends of the bill, among whom are some of the most prominent men and influential politicians of the State. Indignation meetings have been held in the ante-chambers of the Capitol, and much feeling is exhibited.

THE ENORMOUS PRICE OF UNIMPROVED PROP ERTY IN NEW-YORK.--Some idea of the rise in the price of unimproved property in NewYork may be gathered from the report of the great up-town sale which took place yesterday. A lot on Eighth-avenue and Seventy-secondstreet, 25 feet 8 inches by 100 foot, sold for the enormous sum of eighteen thousand eight hundred dollars.

THE FREEDMEN'S CELEBRATION. The celebration of the anniversary of the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia by the colored people here to-day was a very creditable and successful observance of that first step in the work of emancipation.

A fire broke out at 9 o'clock in the fourth story of the Inquirer building, on Chestnut-street, above Third-street. The compositors in the room were forced to leave, on account of the smoke. The fire so far is confined to the room in which it originated, and the firemen will probably save the building.

The Fenian prisoners at Cornwall have been remanded till Wednesday next, awaiting important evidence. A most complete detective system is in operation, and further arrests will be made unless the suspected parties succeed in escaping.

BUTCHER--In Brooklyn, E.D., on Wednesday, April is, ROBERT BUTCHICI, of the American Treat Society, aged 51 years. The friends and acquaintances, also the members of Ark Lodge No.28, I.O. of O.F. are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Sunday, 22d inst., at 1 1/2 o'clock, from the H.P. Church, Attorney-st. COBLINGTON.--On Friday incruing, April 20, Miss HELERNA COLDIROTOR.

A fire broke out in Geneseo last evening, about 7:30 o'clock, in the store of S. P. BIERGES, and before It was checked proved very destructive. A clerk went into the cellar to draw kerosene. The faucet not working readily he held his light near it to ascertain the reason, when fire was communicated to the liquid and the collar was immediately in flames.

Mr. FOLGER introduced by unanimous consent, a bill to extend the time of completing the assessment roll in New-York till the 30th of June. Mr. FOLGER said the subject was reached by the bill passed last night for the taxing of bank shares, but iw would be impossible to complete the rolls under that act in the time now limited by law. The bill was passed.

When the fever which just now inflames the public mind against President JOHNSON shall have subsided, as it certainly will, candid people will have no difficulty in seeing that it has been largely duo to studied and malicious misrepresentation of his position on various questions of public importance.

At a meeting held by the saloon passengers, Col. S. WILKINSON, of Buffalo, in the chair, it war resolved and unanimously agreed to, that the following letter of thanks be presented to Capt. PROWSE and his officers, and that the same be published in the daily papers:

THE PACIFIC RAILROAD. Mr. HOWARD asked that the Committee on the Pacific Railroad be discharged from the further consideration of a bill to aid in the construction of the Southern branch of the Pacific Railroad, on the ground that the Committee are of opinion that no further pecuniary obligations ought to be assumed by the Government to aid in the construction of the branches of the Union Pacific Railroad.

THE FFNIANS vs. OUR GOVERNMENT.--It is not England that the Fenians are making war upon thus far, but the United States. It is our neutrality laws, primarily, that they are engaged in violating, and in threatening still further to violate. It is our interests and our peaceful relations that they are attempting to interrupt.

From the Tribune. Mr. W. L. SHARKEY is certainly a candid witness at all sides. In his remarks before the Reconstruction Committee, he gives a high character to the Mississippi freedmen, and testifies that they are ambitious to own real estate; but concludes, " My expectation concerning them is that they are destined to extinction beyond a doubt."

Messrs. JACKSON S. SOHULTZ, THOMAS O. ACTON, BENJAMIN F. MANIERRE and JOHN G. BERGEN, Drs. WILLARD PARKER, JOHN SWINBURNE, JOHN O. STONE and JAMES CRANE, and Judge JOSEPH S. BOSWORTH, organized yesterday as the Metropolitan Board of Excise. Mr. SCHULTZ was chosen President; Col. EMMONS CLARK, Secretary; Mr. MANIERRE, Treasurer; Mr. D. B. EATON, Counsel;

In the Senate yesterday the bill providing three gold medals, one to be presented to Capt. CREIGHTON, of the ship Three Bells, of Glasgow; one to Capt. Low, of the bark Kilby, of Boston, and one to Capt. STOUDLER, of the ship Antartic, as testimonials of national gratitude, for their gallant conduct in rescuing about five hundred Americans from the wreck of the steamship San Francisco was passed;

Passengers who lett San Francisco March 30, state that on their arrival at Acapuleo, April 6, they learned that a collision had occurred between the Liberal forces, under CORONA, and the French troops occupying Mazatlan. It appears that CORONA had for some time closely invested the place, but finally withdrew, when the French marehed out, with the intention, it is presumed, of giving CORONA battle if he could be overtaken.

The steamer Rapidan sailed to-day for New-York. The first race to-day for $5, 000, mile heats, was won by Lewis E. Smith ; time 1:52 1/4. 1:53 1/2. The second race for $300, mile heats, was won by Small Boy, Filly ; time 1:55 3/4. 1:58 3/4. Rains have injured cotton badly in Texas, replanting is general, and seed bad.
The steamsho Arizona, Capt. MAURY, from Aspinwall 18th inst., wiht passengers and treasure to Pacific Mail Steamship Company, arrived yesterday morning.

The Colton Dental Association, No. 19 Cooper Institute, have extracted teeth for 11,485 patients with the laughing gas, all of whom by their signature certify that it was done without pain, and that the effect of the gas was pleasant. The list embraces a large number of our most distinguished citizens--ladies and gentlemen.

The Legislature of 1866 has departed. It was not divided, whatever else may be said of it; it will certainly go down to history as the most industrious and hard-working body that ever assembled at the State Capital. Its dilligence in the discharge of the unprecedented amount of business throuwn upon it has been most extradinary.

THE TRAFFIC IN LIQUOR--A GREAT REFORM.--We have for many years been so accustomed in this City to the disgrace of having the excise laws openly defied by the liquor dealers, or at best loosely administered by the authorities, that it seems almost too much to believe that a change for the better will be made.

The Board met pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number seventeen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President in the Chair, and the following members: Councilmen Keenan, Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, O'Brien, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keoch, White, Mackay, Kellogg, Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Roberts, Pullman, Hettrick, Imlay-21.

Before Commissioner Osborn. Wallace Dyckman was before the Commissioner yesterday on the charge of passing a counterfeit $50 U. S. Treasury note. Several Witnesses were examined for the defence, their testimony uniting in establishing a most excellent previous character for the young man accused of the offence referred to.

EJECTION OF THE TROCLODYTES.--If cholera is to be our scourge, its first victims doubtless will be from among the dwellers in the subterranean caverns of our poorer wards, who breathe an atmosphere at night which does not furnish enough oxygen to keep a candle burning.
STREET MURDER.--On the return of the pilgrims from Mecca, LANE tells us that the devotees in Cairo are in the habit of lying down in the road and allowing the SOHEIK'S horse to trample over them.

M. PAUL ANNASOFF, Commissioner of the Russlan Government to the Western Union Telegraph Company arrived in the Persia. After delivering his dispatches to the Russian Minister at Washington and spending a few days at the Telegraph Company's head quarters Rochester, he will proceed to San Francisco by the steamer of May 1. and there join the expedition under Col. BULKLEY,

MEANS OF KNOWLEDGE.--We perceive that Sir MORTON PETO is about to publish a book in London on the "Resources and Prospects of America, ascertained during a visit to the States in the Autumn of 1865." There is no doubt that Sir MORTON will do ample justice to his subject and to this country.

SUICIDE IN FOURTEENTH-STREET,--Mrs. CAROLINE S. SCHENCK, who has kept a boarding-house for some years at no. 71 West Fourteenth-street, was missed from her residence of Friday evening and despite diligent search, was not found till 5 o'clock yesterday morning, when her dead body was discovered the yard attached to the premises.

DA CUNHA--COLE.--On Wednesday, April 18. by Rev. Thomas street, LOUIS A. DA GUNHA and Miss SUSIE M. COLE, all of this City. SCUDDER--WILLARD.--In Troy, on Thursday morning April 19, by Rev. Dr. Coit, HENRY J. SCUDDER, Esq., of New-York and Miss EMMA, daughter of John H. Willard Esq., of Troy.

The following communications explain themselves: NEW-YORK, March 24, 1866. E. Kingsland, Chief-Engineer Metropolitan Fire Department: SIR: On Monday evening last an alarm of fire proceeded from the house of Mr. AUSBACHER, in Fifth street, I was summoned to attend his little daughter suffering from severe burns, which afterward proved fatal. The members of Hook and Ladder Company No. 11 were present,

The Senate is not in session to-day, having adjourned over until Monday. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. The proceedings of this day's session were, by order, confined to general debate on the President's annual message. Mr. NICHOLSON, of Delaware, was the first speaker.

A meeting of prominent members of the Republican or Union Party friendly to the national policy as developed by President JOHNSON, was held in this city yesterday, for the purpose of consultation and expression of opinion.

THE FREEDMEN. The Assistant Commissioner of the Freedmen's Buweau in the State of Florida has transmitted a report to the Bureau. He states that he has labored to provent any collision, as far as possible, between the military and civil authorities of the State. He called the attention of Gov. WALKER

The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House, the proccedings were confined, by order, to general debate on the President's annual message. Mr. NICHOLSON, of Delaware, spoke against the constitutional amendment in regard to representtion. He was followed by Mr. PERHAM, who took the opposite view.

A MONOMANIAC.--The following singular affidavit was made before a Justice of the Peace for Hoboken a few days since, for the purpose of allaying the fears of a man-perfectly sane on every other subject-but who imagines that he is persecuted by fiends:

We present our usual resume of National Guard movements and gossip for the information of the members: DRILLS DURING THE WEEK. On Monday evening, the 16th inst., the right wing of the Eighty-fourth Regiment assembled for battalion drill at the State Arsenal in Seventh-avenue.

THE WHEAT CROP IN VIRGINIA.--We hear from all sections of the State that there has recently been a great improvement in the condition of the growing wheat, Fields in which six weeks age there was not believed to be a living spire, and which the owners contemplated ploughing up and planting in corn, now look green and give promise of a partial crop.

Mr. GLADSTONE'S hasty conclusion as to the strength and permanence of the late Confederacy, suggested grave doubts of the soundness of his judgment, oven among those who sincerely admired his noble advocacy of Italian liberty.

Very many complaints have been made by members of the Metropolitan Police force at the treatment they received from the different railroad companies during the continuance of the recent strike. They state that they were compelled, time and again, to pay car fare while proceeding up town for duty at the railroad depots, and while returning from suet extra duty.

THE PROPOSED MASONIC TEMPLE.--The fourth meeting of the Masonic fraternity of Brooklyn was held at Joppa Lodge-rooms, corner of Court and Joralemon streets, last evening. P.M. N. P. WARING occupied the chair. On organizing the chairman stated that the act incorporating the Masonic Temple had been passed by the Legislature and signed by the Governor, and was now therefore a law.

A good deal of ferment has recently been made, in literary and dramatic circles, over a new comedy, by M. EMILE AUGIER, entitled "Contagion," now on the bills of the Odgen Theatre, one of the places of amusement enjoying a subvention from the Imperial Government.
FRANCE IN MEXICO.--The first effect in Paris of the news that the arrangement for the return of the French troops from Mexico had been concluded,

The following case. which cam off at the April Term of Sumier Superior Court, Before His Honor ALEX. M. SPEER, will be read with unusual interest. The points decided are such as effect thousands of our citizens, and gives, on that account, a prominence to this decision beyond that which usually attaches to a decision of the Circuit Coruts. We understand that the case will go up to the Supreme Court:

CHAPTER I. "I never saw such rain in my life." "My dear, it always rains at Genoa." "Then why does 'Murray' say the Genoa is a dry place, with sharp, cutting winds?" "My dear, 'Murray' makes a mistake. I have been here--let me see--six times; and every time it has been just like this, close, muggy weather, and raining warm water."

By an act of the Legislature passed on the 21st of last month, entitled "An act for the better protection of seamen in the port and harbor of New-York," the keeping of a sailors' boarding-house or hotel in this City or Brooklyn without a license is rendered illegal.

NEW MILITARY IDEAS--OUR COAST DEFENCES.--The Pall Mall Gazelle, in discussing the subject of the "Next War," throws out some rather curious remarks as to the possibility of the introduction of new military conditions, and the effect that these might have upon the fate of one or other of the combatants.

The occurrence of what is probably cholera on a ship arriving in this port, and now in the Lower Bay, ought to occasion no anxiety or alarm in our community. Even if the disease should reach the shore, it is not the time of year as yet for it to begin its ravages, and we probably shall have some weeks to prepare.

It would be extremely gratifying for Mr. SMYTHE, the nominee for Collector, to know that the statement of a morning journal concerning the full in applications for office is correct. Unfortunately for him it is simply false, the converse of the assertion being patent to any one who will take the pains to observe or inquire.

A large procession of the negro population of Hampton Roads and the surrounding country took place to-day, in honor of the passage of the Civil Rights Bill, The negroes, after marching through the principal streets of Hampton, were addressed by MaJ..Gen. MILES, commanding the district; Brig.-Gen, ARMSTRONG, Superintendent of the Freedmen's Bureau; Col. D. B. WHITE and others.

The last act of the Pennsylvania Legislature prior to the adjournment was the passage unanimously of joint resolutions of thanks to Gov. CURTIN. The members of each political party voted "aye" with great enthusiasm. The following are the resolutions, proposed in the House by Mr. RUDIMAN and in the Senate by Mr. WALLACE, the Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee:

We have all read of the humane and wise Yankee who conceived the plan of saving the fur and the lives too of his beaver--by catching and shearing their fur once a year instead of killing and stripping their skins from their bodies--and we have supposed it a good conceit but in no way true or possible.

THE ENGLAND AND THE VIRGINIA--OVER-CROWDING.--If the epidemic which raged with such terrible effect on board the England and the Virginia was not primarily caused, it was at least most seriously aggravated, by over-crowding.

SIDEWALK THIEVES. On Saturday Mr. AUSTIN KELLY, of No. 51 Walker-street, saw SAMUEL FERNEY, a man nearly 50 years of age, and GEORGE VALENTINE, only 10 years of age, attempt to remove a case of hoop-skirts from the sidewalk in front of his store. Mr. KELLY called upon Officer WOOLSEY, of the Broadway Squad, who arrested the supposed thieves.

AGED GRADUATES OF HARVARD UNIVERSITY.--By the recent death at Georgetown, in this State, of Mr. THOMAS JEWETT of the class of 1707, the number of the survivors of the graduates who took their first degree before the beginning of this century in 1801, is reduced to ten only, of whom four are resklents of this city, viz.: Dr. JAMES JACKSON, 1796; Rev. Dr. JENKS, 1707; S. D. PARKER, Esq., 1799; Col. SAMUEL SWEET, 1800.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts vs. John McGuire, Plaintiff in error.--The plaintiff in error was indicted for maintaining a nuisance in the keeping of a house for the sale of intoxicating liquors, under the following provisions of the Prohibitory Liquor Law of Massachusetts: SECTION 6. All buildings, places or tenements, resorted to for prostitution, lewdness or illegal gaming, or used for the illegal keeping of sale of intoxicating liquors, shall be declined common nuisances.

At Brandenburgh, on Friday afternoon, in an altercation between two brothers, KENDRICK and ALLEN STANFORD, respecting an old partnership, the latter having drawn a pistol, was killed instantly by the other.

THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH--THE NEXT ATTEMPT TO LAY THE CABLE.--The more active promoters of the Atlantic Telegraph enterprise are profuse in their promises to recommence the great task of laying the cable in early Summer. The first part of June is the time fixed for the sailing of the Great Eastern with her precious and precarious freight.

THE CITY RAILROADS AND THEIR DRIVERS.-Now that the strike of Railroad drivers is over, we have a word of advice for the managers of these companies. Let them pay their drivers decent wages, or require of them only a just amount of work per day, and they will have the public sympathy on their side in any difficulty that may occur hereafter.

We record to-day the death of the distinguished and learned physician, and dprominent citizen, Dr. JOSEPH M. SMITH. He has long stood among the heads of his profession in this country. He was born at New-Rochelle, Westchester County, N. Y., March 14, 1789, and was the son of the eminent Dr. WATSON SMITH.

Among the many evidences that have come to light, showing that the present Secretary of the Interior. (Mr. HABLEN,) has rendered the public very great services by his management of affairs, is his rapid publication of the Census Returns. He has accomplished in a few months, what formerly occupied as many years.

GERMAN OPERA.--We have had a good deal of MEYERBEER lately, and, making allowance for the many "cuts" which were rendered necessary by the early habits of our public, the works of that eminent composer have been rendered with marked dramatic and musical ability. The sales have been entrusted to competent hands.

BREVET BRIG - GEN. THOS. B. VAN BUREN. -- Among the worthy officers who have been confirmed by the Senate as Brevet Brigadier-Generals we notice the name of THOMAS B. VAN BUREN, late Colonel of the One Hundred and Second Regiment New-York Volunteers. This regiment was raised by his strong personal efforts and influence, and was one of the best equipped and disciplined in the army.

[OFFICIAL.] BOARD OF ALDERMEN. STATED SESSION....MONDAY, April 23, 1866. President--John Brice, Esq., President. Aldermen Moore, Coman, Norton, McBrion, Flynn, Shannon, Godney, Ely, Ryers, Reilly, Brice, Loow, Masterson, Varnum. O'Brien, McGinnils, Van Voorhis. The President being absent at roll call, on motion of Aldermen Norton, Alderman Varnum was called to the chair. The minutes of April sixteen were read and approved.

This usually quiet city is to-day the theatre of a regular Fenian excitement, consequent upon the seizure last night by the United States Deputy Marshal, STEPHEN RIED, of about 140 Springfield rifles, which were secreted in a barn near the city, and destined for the use of the Fenians. These arms wee brought here by railroad in boxes marked "machinery," and directed to PATRICK REGAN, a prominent Fenian.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--The Board met last evening, the President, Alderman BLISS, in the chair. A communication was received from ROBERT FUREY Co., asking the privilege to use the city docks at the foot of Fulton and Gold streets, and offering $700 per year rent therefor. The subject was referred to a Special Committee.

We had a fine illustration yesterday of the, style in which Congress has abdicated its constitutional functions in regard to the admission of its members. It is now six or eight weeks since Mr. BINGHAM, on behalf of the Reconstruction Committee, reported a resolution providing for the admission of Tennessee into the Union.

The Washington Correspondent of the Utica Herald says that President JOHNSON is evidently determined to submit to the people the question of restoration, and adds: "He has no hesitation in his policy, but the Republicans in Congress, for the most part, are reticent,, and do not fight back.

The Legislature adjourned without authourizing the construction of other of the various railways, "Underground," "Elevated," or Surface", which had been proposed for expediting and cheapening communication between the upper and lower portions of our great and rapidly growing metropolis.

Rio Grande advices of the 15th inst. state that Gen. MEJIA had returned to Matamoras, leaving a portion of his forces with Gen. JEANINGRO, who was charged with the operations against the Liberals. On his return, MEJIA foll into an ambuscade during the night, commanded by CANALEZ and CORTINA, which he penetrated losing six killed and wounded.

UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE. Before Commissioner Betts. The case of Otto Burstenbinder, of the United States Blasting Oil Company, came up for examination, by adjournment, yesterday. Joseph H. Prentice, the first witness called for the defence, testified that Mr. Burstenbinder was absent from the City about five weeks, and returned about the 1st of April; he sold no oil before leaving.

JUMPED OVERBOARD FROM A FERRY-BOAT.--At one o'clock yesterday afternoon, as the Jersey City ferry-boat Newark was crossing from New-York to connect with the train, an unknown man attempted to commit suicide by jumping off the bow when near the middle of the stream. The boat passed entirely over him, and when next seen he had divested himself of his coat and was swimming vigorously toward the shore.

BERGEN--HAGEMAN.--At New-Brunswick, N. J., on Wednesday, April 18, by Rev. R. H. Steele, SAMUEL J. BERGEN, OF Cranberry, and MAGGIE E. HAGEMAN, daughter of J. V. Hageman, of the former place. PENNOCK--HARDCASTLE.--In West Philadelphia, on Thursday, April 19, by Rev. Charles Brown, Mr. HOMER PENNOCK and Miss ANNIE HARDCASTLE, third daughter of the late Thomas M. Hardcastle, all of New-York, No cards.

SMALL SLANDERS ON THE PRESIDENT.--It would be amusing, if it were not disgusting, to note the shifts resorted to by letter-writers and newsmongers of the radical stripe, to excite public hatred and distrust of the President. A Washington correspondent of the Worcester Spy is especially zealous in this labor of love.

The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number seventeen City Hall. Present--J. Wilson Green, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Councilmen Keenan, Long, Stacom, Flynn, Robinson, O'Brien, Costello, Hartman, Brinkman, Koster, Watts, Keech, White, Mackay, Kellogg, Tyng, Thomas, Halloran, Roberts, Pullman, Hettrick, Imlay--23. The minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved.

The steamship America, from Southampton on the 11th of April, arrived here yesterday morning with three days later news from Europe. The Afrira arrived at Queenstown at 10:30 A. M. on Monday, April 9. The United States corvette Canandaigua arrived at Southampton April 9.

THE CATTLE PLAGUE. The Chair laid before the Senate a communication ?? Dr. HENRY OAES, on the subject of the rinderpest, its cause and cure, which was referred to the committee on Agriculture. Mr. COWAN presented the petition of Pennsylvania wool-growers for an increase of the duty on foreign wool, which was referred to the Committee on Finance.

GRAND LARCENY. WILLIAM H. PHILLIPS, of No. 84 Wooster-street, had a complete set of table knives, forks and spoons, valued at $54, stolen from his residence yesterday morning. Subsequently the greater portion of the stolen property was found in the possession of JOHN JONES, (colored,) who waits arrested by Officer ALLASON, of the Eighth Precinct.

The former election in Portsmouth for municipal officers having been contested by the Radical Party, a new election took place last Saturday. On the former occasion it is asserted that the Commissioners, or a portion of them, deserted their posts before the legal hours of the election had expired. The "Citizens' ticket," as It is called, approving the President's policy, was elected by a large majority.

The steamship America, from Southampton on the 11th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning, with three days later intelligence from Europe. The Austro-Prussian complication was still unsettled, and preparations for war on either side were carried on with unremitted vigor. The belief in an alliance be. tween Italy and Prussia was 'gaining strength;

At the meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health, yesterday, Judge BOSWORTH presented the Proclamation of Peril, which was recently adopted by umns of the Times. The Governor has signed the Proclamation, and the Board is now clothed with all those extraordinary powers which the law contemplated in time of immiaent peril.

BLACK.--On Tuesday, April 24, IDA LOUISE, youngest daughter of George M. and Mary Annie Black. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her grandmother. Mrs. Lockwood, No. 130 6th-av., this (Wednesday) afternoon at 1 o'clock. COBB.--Suddenly, on Tuesday evening, April 24, ABRAHAM LEGGETT, son of Joseph L. and Isabella A. Cobb, aged 1 year, 9 months and 4 days.

The steamer John L. Stephens, from Mazatlan, has arrived, with $45,500 in treasure, On her down trip the steamer was seized at Cape St. Lucas, by order of Gen. CORONA, and an effort was made to send her to Altata, but she was finally ordered to La Paz.

NAVY-YARDS.--The proposition for a naval station below the Palisades, on the Hudson River, is doubtless entitled to due weight and consideration. There are numerous good sites along our northern shores which, in process of time, will be availed of for the further protection of the coast and inland waters.

THE INTERNAL REVENUE BILL. The Internal Revenue Bill will probably be reported to-morrow. Since the bill passed through the hands of the Committee, the following changes have been made on a second consideration of its items: The tax on stock and bullion brokers was fixed at two cents on the hundred dollars; the tax on merchandise brokers remains as heretofore, but are put in under the same stamp law as others;...

We fail to discover in the news from Europe received yesterday that the situation in Germany is changed in any material degree, or that actual hostilities are more imminent than they were a month go. There is so much of rumor mixed up with the statement of facts that it is difficult to. draw any accurate distinction between what is positive and what is simply conjectural.

THE COLLECTORSHIP.--We give no credence whatever to the rumors so industriously circulated of special efforts being made to defeat the confirmation of Mr. SMYTHE as Collector at this port. Undoubtedly some who are perfectly satisfied with things they are, would like to prevent anything likely to disturb them.

Our correspondent "Veteran Observer" availed himself of the privilege we cheerfully give him, of expressing his own sentiments, in Monday's TIMES, by saying: "I don't believe it is at all necessary that the rebel States should govern this country. I don't mean myself to help them to that result.

Yesterday the leases of the following property belonging to the Corporation were disposed of at public action. The attendance at the sale was quite large and the bidding spirited, a large advance on the present rentals being realized. Mr. CHARLES F. LOEW, Collector of the City Revenue, officiated as auctioneer. He called particular attention to the following among the conditions of the sale:

We regret that Mr. STEVENS did not bring before the House for its action on Monday, his resolution concerning Col. FORNEY'S Chronicle. If consolation is to be administered to the Colonel for the griefs he sustains at the hands of the Administration, it ought to be done soon. Delays are dangerous.

THE BOARD OF EDUCATION AND A CHANCE FOR ECONOMY.--The Finance Committee of the Board of Education, at the last meeting of that body, reported that they had resolved upon strict economy during the current year, in order to close the twelvemonth without incurring debt.

ENORMOUS COTTON MOVEMENTS.--The exports of Cotton from this port ran ahead of all precedent during the week ending last evening, having reached 22,277 bales, of the currency value of $3,882,769, or an average of about one hundred and seventy-five dollars a bale.

A SILLY BUSINESS.--The World indulges in some very ill-judged criticisms upon the Board of Health, such as the following: * * * "Our Board of Health is working off its enthusiasm by passing daily a series of very vigorous resolutions. But there is a woeful difference between its programmes and its performance.

GERMAN OPERA.--BEETHOVEN'S only opera--and his chef d' ocuvre--"Fidello," will be brought out to-night at the Academy of Music. It is a favorite work with the Germans, and indeed with all others who regard a high purpose in art. The distributions includes the best artists of Mr. GROVER'S troupe, and the ensembles will be given, we have no doubt, with the brilliant effect which was so enjoyable in "William Tell."

Within the past week or ten days there has been an unusually, and, in the regular course of trade, we might add, an unprecedentedly heavy business transacted in all classes of the national stocks, at steadily advancing prices At the outset of the movement, the currency obligations of the Government met with most favor, especially the Compound-Interest notes and Seven-thirties.

The patriotic Mexicans yesterday celebrated the splendid victories said to have been achieved over the French at Presidio and San Sebastian. Col, RAIG, who commanded the French at Presidio, gives all official account of the battle, in which he states his small expeditionary force was attacked by 3200 Liberals, who were repulsed after four hours' hard fighting, with a loss of two pieces of artillery, 300 killed and 200 wounded.

There was an immense crowd around the Court-house this morning awaiting the arrival of ANTOINE PROBST, the murderer of the Deering family. He was adroitly admitted through a side door, disappointing most of the spectators. After the usual preliminaries, the bill of indictment for the murder of CHRISTOPHER DEARING was read, and the prisoner pleaded "Not guilty."

The Collector of this port has taken measures to stop the introduction of cattle via the Isthmus, and has notified officers of the customs along the coast to prevent cattle and hides coming in from foreign ports.

In the Senato to-day a bill passed its first roading, tendering the mansion house at the Hermitage, JACKSON'S residence, and 200 across of ground adjoining, on condition that the United States Government will establish upon it a branch of the West Point Military Academy, or some other public institution.

THE RECONSTRUCTION COMMITTEE. A rumor is current around the Capitol that the Committee on Reconstruction, at their meeting today, failed to agree upon a report, there being a wide disagreement among the members. An effort will, however, be made to reconcile conflicting views.

Considerable excitement exists here about a murder committed by a negro. The Sheriff arrested the murderer, when a mob attempted to rescue him from his custody and hang him, A few soldiers stationed here came to the assist. ance of the Sheriff. and are now repelling the mob, who are falling back, but gather in strength,

JUST THE THING. -- Chicago is just now doing a beautiful thing and witnessing a most deserved success. Last Summer ALFRED L . SEWELL, of this City, slarted The Little Corporal, a first-class paper for children, which is charming the whole country from Maine to Oregon.

BOLD AND SUCCESSFUL HOUSE ROBBERY.--The residence of Mr. ABRAHAM KAUFMAN, No. 57 South Fourth-street, E. D., was entered about 4 o'clock yesterday morning by two burglars, through a rear window, and robbed of $1,030 in money.

The Inman steamer City of Boston, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at 3 P.M. on the 11th, and Queestown on the 12th of April, arrived here yesterday morning, with one day Inter intelligence from Europe. The Erin left Liverpoo; for New-York simultaneously with the City of Boston.

Co., owners of ship, appellants vs. The United States.--This is an appeal from the Circuit Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The facts in the case have been heretofore stated in the TIMES, and the opinion of the Court will sufficiently ?? them.

Tho gale which sot in on Monday continued up to this morning, and several disasters have occurred to vessels on Lake Ontario, The schooner Bahama, bound from this port to Chicago, with coal, is ashore near Oak Orchard Creek.

Yesterday the regular monthly sale of Seranton coal by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company took place. Mr. JOHN H. DRAPER officiated as auctioneer, The attendance at the sale was quite large and the bidding spirited. The lump and steamer coal was sold in large lots, and a slight advance was realized on the prices obtained at the last sale.

A Memphis dispatch to the Gazette says that the steamer John Raymond exploded her boiler and took fire, when near Island No. 40, at 10 o'clock yes. terday morning. The First Engineer was blown overboard and lost, The Second Engineer was badly scalded.

Assistant Health-Officer BISSELL'S report on Tuesday shows that the whole number of patients received from the Virginia on board the hospital-ship Falcon was ninety-five. Twenty-nine had died, one had returned, ten had been received from the Illinois, and one of these had died, and seventy six were remaining in hospital.

We have had several rows here lately. A soi disant tenor named RAY undertook to sing in the opera of "Lucrezia Borgia" last Tuesday, and was hissed. The Spaniards choose to make it a question of nationality, and tried to drown by excessive applause the disapprobation, which led to words, a general fight in front of the theatre, and some five or six duels.

PETITIONS. Mr. GRIMES presented a petition asking Congress to enact just and equal laws for Inter-State insurance, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce. Mr. WILSON presented a petition of the loyal citizens of Florida, for compensation for property confiscated by the rebels, which was referred to the Committee on Claims.

A regatta came off in our harbor to-day, for prizes given by the grand fair for the benefit of soldiers' widows and orphans. The first race, for single sculls, distance two miles, was won by WALTER BROWN. Time, 20 minutes. The second race, for working boats, without outriggers, distance three miles, was won by the Bessy. Time, 29 minutes.

The steamship City of Boston arrived at this port yesterday morning, with one day's later intelligence from Europe. The position of affairs in Germany remained unchanged; but it was asserted that Prussia had decidedly refused to accede to Austria's request that she should withdraw the order for the mobilization of her corps d'armee. Mr. GEORGE PEABODY's letter to Queen VICTORIA is published in the English journals.

Mr. GROVER was rewarded last evening with a fine and fashionable audience. The opera--as we here previously announced--was "Fidelio." To speak of this work in any terms of criticism or praise would be presumptious. It has taken the highest place in music, and rightly or wrongly is accepted is the culmination of all that is great in emotion or mind. The story is certainly interesting, and the music old fashioned, but beautiful.

This afternoon Judge BALLARD, of the United States District Court, issued an order for the arrest of Gen. J. C. DAVIE, for interfering with the course of public justice in disobeying the writ of habeas corpus in the case of HAMILTON. Marshal MERRY WETHER was resisted by DAVIS while attempting to enforce the order. An allas attachment was awarded against DAVIS returnable in May.

GERMAN OPERA.--WAGNER'S opera of the "Tannhauser" will be produced here to-night for the first time in several years. The merits of the work have been often discussed. An important case of broach of trust was made public in this city yesterday. The facts of the case, as we have learned them, are as follows: A man named D. A. CLARK has for some time past been doing business in St, Louis, as a cotton broker. His dealings with his customers had always been of the most honorable character, and implicit confidence was placed in him by them,

ACTION OF THE NEW-YORK DELEGATION. The meeting and action of the New-York Congressional Delegation last evening, with reference to the question of reconstruction, has been the subject of much comment to-day, and has created considerable surprise among the extreme men, who counted on the majority of that delegation as sure to favor forced negro suffrage in any event.
The American Missionary Association will hold anniversary meetings in New-York and Boston. The meeting in this City will occur May 8, at 10 o'clock A. M., in Cooper Institute.

BOGGS.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, April 25, of Bright's disease, WILLIAM BOGGS, in the 53d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from him late residence, No. 102 Clinton-st., Brooklyn, this day, (Friday) at 1 o'clock P.M. His remains will be taken to Leicester, Mass. for intermont.

Arrived, steamers Monterey and Star of the Union, from New-York. Sailed, steamer Montgomery, for New-York. Fifteen thousand dollars was realized by the Washington Artillery Ball last night for the disabled members of the regiment.

A large party of distinguished officers of the Navy and Marine Corps were yesterday assembled at the residence of Admiral BAILEY for the purpose of celebrating the fourth anniversary of the triumphs achieved by our naval forces in the series of battles which culminated in the capture of the "Crescent City."

The steamer De Soto, the flagship of the Eastern Squadren, arrived here to-day. Gen. B. DORAN KILLIAN and a number of the Fenians are in town this morning. Some artillery arrived to-day from Treat's Island, and it is being stored in FRENCH SONS' storehouses.

DESTITUTION IN THE SOUTH.--Exceedingly painful accounts continue to reach us of distress and starvation in tho State of Alabama. Of the two Montgomery papers that reached us last night, one has an editorial headed, "Alarming Destitution in Randolph County--An Appeal ;" the other has an editorial headed, "Destitution in Autuga."

The steamship Nova Scolian, from Liverpool on the 12th, via Londonderry on the 13th inst, ar. rived at Portland at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The steamship Peruvian arrived at Londonderry on the night of the 12th.

The Newburyport Herald publishes a statement of CHAS. H. GOLDEN, in jail there on charges of burglary, in which he claims to have been very intimate with Mrs. CUNNINGHAM and her family, and knew all about the projected murder of Dr. BURDELL, in Bond-street, several years ago.

A year ago yesterday the pleasant little City of Elizabeth, New-Jersey, was excited by the report that a well-known and generally respected employe of the New-Jersey Railway, had murdered his wife, the mother of his two children. His name was JAMES GLENNAN, a hard-working, industrious, well-built American, who some time previous had moved to the city, marrying one of Elizabeth's daughters, and settling quietly as if for a life-long work.

To the President and the Secretary of State of the United States: I congratulate you on the completion of the telegraph line connecting Vancouver's Island with the United States, effected by American enterprise. It is my earnest hope that it may prove an enduring link to bind the United States of America and Great Britain in the bonds of peace and progression.

The largest sale of Government property ever held here takes place May 2, at Camp Hamilton, ruler the direction of Col. A. P. BLUNT, Assistant Quartermaster. The list of articles comprises a large amount of transportation material, such as hospital, army and spring wagons, carls, , and carpenters' and blacksmiths' tools, office desks, anchors, and all kinds of quartermasters' stores.

A letter from Constantinople gives the following news of Mr. IRA ALDRIDGE, the celebrated negro comedian: We have a tragedian celebrity here at the present moment, in the person of IRA ALDRIDGE, a native of New York. He has acted with great success in the French theatre as Othello, all the other actors reciting their parts in the French translation of Shakespeare.
The receipts of the Internal Revenue from the First District of California, show an increase of 35 per cent. during the past quarter over the corresponding quarter of last year.

Messrs. CHARLES LANE Co. sold out their entire stock of wool, amounting to about 300,000 pounds, this forenoon. The auctioneer was J. B. OSGOOD. The attendance was large and the bidding spirited.

THE ELECTRIC GIRDLE EXTENDING.--A New-York company by charter, and consumption in design, has undertaken the work of introducing the electric telegraph into China. Dr. MACGOWAN has been appointed by that Company--the East India Telegraph--to proceed to China forthwith as its Commissioner and engineer, to connect Pekin with Canton.

We had occasion to State in our issue of yesterday, that any further indemnity for the expenses of the war than we have already received, is out of the question. Security for the future is the subject now uppermost before Congress and the country.

RENTS AND HOUSES IN THE CITY.--As we approach nearer and nearer to the first of May, there seems to be more and more houses in different parts of the city to let. All the villages and localities around appear also to be inviting people to leave the city, by offering houses at quite reasonable rents.

THE NEW TEXAS CONSTITUTION.--This document came on to us yesterday. The Governor's term of office is made four years instead of two salary $4,000 instead of $3,000. Section 36 is all new, and is important, as it gives the Legislature the power to guarantee the bonds of railroads for the purchase of iron.

Gen. GRANT, in a recent conversation with Rev. GEORGE HEDWORTH, of Boston, said of Gen. SHERMAN: "SHERMAN is a man to be proud of. He is impetuous, he is faulty, but he knows his own fault as soon as any man," And of SHERIDAN he said: "He is the best man in America. He has no peer. He can wield any force.

The morning was taken up with the consideration of the report from the Committee on Missions. They propose to substitute the chapter on missions now in the discipline by a new chapter. It condenses the mission field into two classes, Foreign and Domestic, instead of the China, Indian, Colored, German and Home Missions, which have hitherto stood upon the Statues. The whole subject was laid over.

Two hundred years ago a PETER BARING was living at Groningen, in the Dutch Provinces of Overyssel. His son or grandson, FRANCIS, was a Lutheran minister at Bremen, until the accession of WILLIAM of Orange to the English throne opened the way for him to greater influence as pastor of a Lutheran church in London.

The recent railroad strike in this City, and the indications that if successful, it would have been followed by others in various directions, render a few words on the relations of labor and capital not wholly inappropriate. These relations are continually misunderstood and misstated.

A trip from Washington to Lynchburgh is a serious undertaking. Not that there is any danger, but that the traveling conveniences are exceedingly uncomfortable. However, the interesting points along the route are of sufficient attraction to balance the account of discomforts; and while you have to pay well from your pocket, the trip pays well, all things considered.

SENATOR LENT.--Senator LENT, after devoting himself with untiring zeal and inflexible integrity to the interests of his constituents and the welfare of the State, is rewarded by abuse in the Tribune. This is the penalty that all public men pay who decline to walk in the narrow political groove that journal marks out for them.

REPORT OF THE RECONSTRUCTION COMMITTEE. The Joint Committee on Reconstruction, after a session of some four hours on Saturday, at which all the members of the Committee were present, agreed to report on Monday the following propositions: A joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

The trial of ISHAM HENDERSON was continued to-day. His counsel denied the jurisdiction of the Court. The Court overruled the plea, declining to give their reasons at the request of the counsel, and then adjourned until the 30th inst. The Secretary of War, in a telegram to Gen. THOMAS dated the 27th inst., says that the President sustains him and the Court in the HENDERSON matter.

GLAD TIDINGS FOR THE POLICE.--Commissioner MANIERRE received a telegram, yesterday afternoon, notifying him that the Governor had signed the bill giving Metropolitan Policemen $1,200 annually. An hour later the intelligence had spread to the remote at corners of the Metropolitan District, and last evening the patrolmen on the streets wore consequently, the most cheerful of men.

The trial of ISHAM HENDERSON will be continued to-day at Nashville, the President having approved of the proceedings of Gen. THOMAS and directed HENDERSON to be tried by court-martial. NASHVILLE, Monday, April 30. The court-martial case of BRUNER has been postponed the May 7.

The best contested trot of the season up to the present time came off yesterday, on the Fashion Course, L. I. It was a purse of $100, mile heats, best three is five, to wagons, for horses that at the time of entry had never trotted in public.

An agreeable experiment in electro-magnetism maybe made by placing a magnet in the circuit of a galvanic pile; then break the circuit at any point, and place the two ends in a box containing iron-filings; then very carefully and gently raise one wire and draw it from the box, and it will draw away the filings in a long chain.

This evening a serious riot occurred in the southern portion of the city, between policemen and negro soldiers, growing out of an attempt of the po lice officers to arrest t a white man whom the negroes determined to protect. Twenty to thirty policemen assembled and kept up a fight for a couple of hours with about one hundredand fifty negroes.
Gens. ALMONTE, HERON and BRINCOURT, together with 400 French troops, have sailed for Europe. Gen. GALVEZ has been arrested and confined at Puebla.

The American Medical Association met again this morning at Concordia Hall. Dr. C. The Spanish steamer Maisi, which arrived yesterday morning from St. Domingo, brings news from the Dominician Republic to the l9th inst. Ac cording to these, the military operations of the Gov ernment along the southern frontier were going on prosperously. The Government troops had occupied San Juan and Neyba, the inhabitants of those two places, who had sought refuge in the mountains, having returned and joined the army as volunteers.

The Board of Excise are very busy, and although their work is quite monotonous, it is exceedingly popular, Col. BARTRAM has received in all about 1,500 applications for license, of which the Board have considered 356, to whom they have agreed to issue licenses as follows:

BOYLE--NELSON.--In New-York, on Monday, April 30, by Rev. G. Campbell, Mr. JAMES BOYLE and Miss MARGARET NELSON, both of this City. DAUGHADAY--COLTON.--On Wednesday, May 2, at the Trinity Church, Toledo, Ohio, by Rev. Dr. Walbridge, H. DAUGHADAY, of New-York, and ANNIE S., daughter of Carlos Colton, Esq., of the former place. No cards.

There was a large meeting of merchants in this city last evening to encourage trade with the City of Baltimore. Rev. Mr. PAYSOL was present, representing 300 Baltimore houses, and gave most encouraging statements and facts. The brokers of New-Orleans met last night and organized a regular board for the transaction of business.

Tho steamer Washington Irving which es caped from Norfolk yesterday and proceeded to sea, was overtaken about nine miles out by the steamer in pursuit. But her Captain refused to return, and after a guard was put on board, she was allowed to proceed northward. Her owners claim that she was free from arrest, as they paid the Government claimof $1,100 on the morning of her departure.

The Brig Herold, Cargo and Claimants, Appellants, vs. The United States.--The brig Herold took a clearance at Boston for Turk's island on the 22d of May , 1861, while her real destination, which was concealed from the Custom-house officers and from her crew, was Beaufort, N. O.

The newly elected State officers wore duly installed in their respective offices to-day with appro priate ceremonies. The morning opened inaus piciously, with a high wind and heavy rain; but be fore noon the clouds broke away, and the day was all that could be desired for the celebration of the occasion. Soon after noon the parade commenced,

According to the debt statement, just given to the public by Secretary McCULLOCH, the net aggregate is $2,689,689,842, or nearly sixteen millions less than the not total a month ago, Then the gross amount of the recognized debt was $2,827,793,897, less $122,147,381 cash in the Treasury, making the not indebtedness $2,705,646,516. Tho United States sloop-of-war Kearsarge ar rived hero yesterday morning, twenty days from Sierra Leone, coast of Africa, Before leaving that place the yellow fever broke out on board in its most fearful form, causing Commander HARROLD to put to sea with several sick on board. Before reaching this place seven officers and seven men died, and wereburied at sea.

A Custom-house officer, just arrived from Quebec, reports that some armed Fenians left there in a small fishing vessel this morning, but were put on board a large schooner back of Grand Menan, N. B. SECOND DIPATOH, EASTPORT, Me,, Wednesday, May 2, Theo United States steamer Winooski has just left the harbor in pursuit of a Fenian privateer.

The Trilnine of Tuesday says: "One lamentable fact connected with the members, as a body, who are sent to the Senate and the Assembly from the City of New-York, is that, for various reasons, they cannot be induced to advocate the measures calculated to produce reform in our Municipal Government.

The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend here funeral on Friday, May 5, at 2 o'clock, at No. 427 Hudson-st. Her remains will be taken to Rochester for interment.

Mr. GEORGE PEABODY, who arrived in the Scotia yesterday, is lodged at the Brevoort IIouse. He is in fine health and spirits, grateful, after scattering blessings and boun ties among the poor of London, for the privi lege of again pressing the soil and breathing the atmosphere of "his own-his nativeland,"

Each new mail from Europe changes mate rially in some degree the aspect of the Ger man question. The strength of the Prussian position lies in the Kingdom being led by an ambitious and most able statesman, who is not accused, oven by his enemies, of letting "I dare not" waitupon "I would."

The testimony to-day reported by Mr. WASH BURNE, of Illinois, from the Committee on Reconstruction, relative to the States of Florida, Texas and Louisiana, presents no now facts of importance, and is mainly commentative of the various views heretofore expressed by other witnesses.

The Health Officers received tidings of another case of cholera in the City, yesterday afternoon. As the physicians of the Board had predicted, the disease was found in one of the tenement dwellings of the Sixth Ward--a building which shelters a hundred families.
