To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have for many years lived, or rather procured my meals at a restaurant in Broadway. The keeper tells me that hereafter he will be compelled to " shutup " on Sunday, Can you tell me, Mr. Editor,

A very large Convention of the Democracy of this State assembled in the Court-house here to-day. Most of the counties in the State were represented. Ex-Gov. WICKLIFFE was chosen temporary Chair man. The resolutions adopted are as follows;

FIGHTING THE DEVIL WITH FIRE.--The Com mon Council of 1865 signalized the last days of its corrupt existence by surreptitiously au thorizing a scheme, which was indorsed by Mayor GUNTHER, for the widening and ex tending of,Ann and Fulton streets. This in iquitous measure justly awakened the indig nation of the public and the Press, and its projectors were stigmatized in the severestterms.

BILL FOR THE CONSOLIDATION OF THE NATIONAL DEBT. Mr. SHERMAN introduced the following: An act to reduce the rate of interest on the national debt, and for funding the same. Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United Stales in Congress assembled.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: While cordially indorsing theo views in theo TIMES' loader to-day, headed "Our Army--Tho Army Bill," as to the importance of an early adjustment of this question, perhaps from age, 1 am disposed on this, as on most important questions, to adopt Sir WILLIAM CECIL's tavorite maxim: "Lot us go onslowly, that we may get on the faster."

Cotton unchanged; sales 1,000 bales at 33c.@34c. for middling; to-day's receipts, 476 bales, Sterling Exchange, 39. New-York checks 3/4 premium, Freights very dull and unchanged. By instruction of the President, Gen. CANBY has released the cotton held by the military and turned it over to the United States Marshal.

THE EXCISE BOARD AND THE "CLUBS."-The decision of the Board of Excise respecting the various social, artistic, literary and political clubs in the City naturally excites considerable attention. Most of the clubs believe the decision to be unjust, and, we learn, have determined to contest its legality.

THE NATIONAL LINE OF STEAMERS.--The Erin, of this line, Capt. CUTTING, will sail for Liverpool on Saturday. It is worthy of note that this ship following the England and the Virginia, brought over nearly 1,300 people, and had only four deaths during the voyage--three of these were very young children, (two of scarlet fever,) and one was an adult, who died of consumption.

A SWINDLER ABROAD.--We have before us a handsomely-engraved card, reading, "JOHN HOCK, Reporter N. Y. TIMES, No. 94 Sixth-street." We have no knowledge of any such person, except that we hear of sundry applications for free passes and other favors in his name, and have now with his card an application for a pass on a certain steamboat line.

The city remains quiet at nine o'clock to-night. The negro soldiers recently mustered out, were paid off at Fort Pickering to-day. They threaten to burn the city to-night. Great uneasiness is felt. They are kept in the fort by a portion of the Sixteenth Regulars.

The Chanargo Bridge Company, Plaintiff's in Error vs. The Binghamton Bridge Company, Defendants in Error.--In 1805 the Legislature of the State of New-York, by an act creating a number of corporations, in-corporated "the President and Directors of the Delaware Bridge Company," and the "Susquehanna Bridge Company," the latter for the purpose of erecting a bridge across the Susquehanna River at Oquaga,

THE ADMISSION OF COLORADO. Colorado was put through the House to-day under whip and spur, the athletic and am brosial Mr. ASHLEY, Chairman of the Committee on Territories, holding the reins. It is the feather in his cap which the Executive shears will clip, and then the whole thing will collapse, for there are not votes enough to give it the required two-thirds.

The telegraph has already given us an abstract of Gov. HAWLEY'S Message to the Connecticut Legislature. We give the following extract: FINANCIAL CONDITION. Naturally, and in consequence of the prolonged contest, the debts and resources of the State claim our early attention.

My window looks out on as quiet, rural, picturesque a scene, as this world can anywhere present. There may be a brighter, a busier and a more sublime scene, but none more suggestive of rest, and quiet, and rural beauty.

BRODIE.--On Wednesday. May 2, after a protracted Illness, GEORGE BRODIE, in the 48th year of his age. His friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Saturday afternoon at 1 o'clock, from his late residence at No. 300 Canal-st. BURLEY.--JULEAINE BURLEY, wife of John H. Burley, aged 60 years.

ANDERSON--FREEMAN.--On Thursday, May 3, at the residence of the bride's parents, Woodbridge, N. J., by Rev. Geo. C. Lueas, JOHN ANDERSON and MARTHA E., daughter of Dr. Ellis B. Freeman. BATS--BENNETT.--At Dresden, Saxony, on Wednesday, March 28 by Rev. Charles H. H. Wright, M. A., chaplain to the English, Embassy. JOSEPH WILLIAM BATES, of Philadelphia, and MARY EMILY BENNETT, of New-York.

THE WAR UPON THE PRESIDENT.--The war of words which Congress has waged from the commencement against the President, is tak ing another form. The Senate has so amend ed the Post-office Bill as to deprive all officers appointed by the President from compensa tion ! This aggression, it is well to remember,was wholly unprovoked.

If you are not satisfied with your wages, respectfully ask for more. If your employer refuses to advance, give him reasonable notice that you must quit. Go, when the time ex pires. If any man takes your place at less than you demanded, let him do it-perhapshe can afford it.

Although the testimony of Major-Gen. SHERIDAN communicated to the Secret Committee of Fifteen omits many points in regard to which the country would have been glad to have his views, it is full enough to show that, in the main, he agrees with the other distinguished soldiers whose opinions upon the reconstruction question had been previously reported.

THE ARMY BILL.--Several schemes for reorganizing and increasing the Regular Army have been considered by Congress during its present session. The Senate Military Committee, some weeks since, reported a bill to that body, complete in all its details, to which but slight objection could be found.

There was a grand reception last evening to Governor-General, Lord MONCK, on the occasion of his arriving here to take permanent residence. It was a public holiday. Triumphal arches were erected, and the volunteers, firemen and citizens turned out to meet him.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, Mr. A. A. Low, President, in the Chair. Mr. BRADFORD, of the Arbitration Committee, presented a report in response to the question as to whether goods consigned to the Port of New-York can be delivered in Brooklyn without first having obtained a written consent of all the consignees.

On motion of Mr. FEAR-- Resolved, That the Metropolitan Gas Light Company be required to report to this House, within ten days from this date, the amount of their capital stock at the time the said company went into operation, and the amount of their said capital on the first day of January in each and every year to the present time;
VALPARAISO.--We see a great many papers are indignant at the destruction of the City of

OUR CITY THIEVES.--The late extraordinary robberies from the houses and business places of this city give warning to those of our town residents who are about leaving the city for the country. Nobody, of course, leaves jewelry or diamond articles behind at such seasons, everything in that line being needed for personal display and adornment at the watering-places.

FACTIOUS ABUSE OF SENATOR LENT.--The Tribune persists in its causeless and vindictive abuse of Senator LENT, who provoked all this by his manly, independent action as a Representative. He is not assailed for any wrong thing, nor is he abused for any neglect of duty. The motive of his assailant is this revealed:

The steamer Washington Irving has proceeded to New-York. The United States Marshal states that the Government claim against her had been paid by her owners, and he did not consider himself obliged to detain her on account of any other claims due theCity of Norfolk.

Great epidemics are not an unmixed evil, if they are instrumental in calling attention, by a sudden and sharp lesson, to the sanitary dangers by which we are constantly surround ed. There is perpetually in cities an amount of disease and mortality which might beavoided.

LIQUOR LICENSES. --It is evident even from the operations of the Excise Board thus far, that a very handsome revenue to the City can be derived from liquor licenses. We do not think the Board need to stretch their power in unauthorized directions, or apply it to doubt ful cases, to realize a much larger sum thanthe catimate of a million dollars.

THE DRESSMAKERS. The Chair laid before the Senate a memorial of the dressmakers of the United States for a modification of the tax laws affecting their business which was referred to the Finance Committee.

Commissioner MANIERRE, Treasurer of the Board of Excise, received the first license fee yesterday under the new law. The happy recipient of license is Mr. GEORGE F. HANFORD, of No. 815 Eighth-avenue, hotel-keeper. The Board have thus far passed upon four hundred and four applications, forty-eight of which are of the second class.

It is believed that the issue of the Bank of Brazil will be increased, the Government guaranteeing it, and that the ten millions of dollars of gold in the vaults will be withdrawn to meet the expenses of the war.

The opening debate in the Senate upon the report of the " Directory" is alike significant in what it disclosed and in what it concealed. Mr. FESSENDEN showed " no stomach" for the debate, and but slight confidence in a scheme, the only purpose of which is to keep the Union disrupted until after another Presidential election.
BOGUS CURRENCY ADVERTISING.--There is a practice extant in this City, and probably else-where, of manufacturing imitations of fractional and other currency for advertising purposes.

HOMEOPATH.--We are glad to see that the Sanitary Committee of the Board of Health have reported favorably upon the request made by the homoeopathic physicians of this City to be assigned to hospitals in case of avisitation of the cholera.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. CHANDLER, from the Conference Committee on the Cuban Telegraph Bill, made a ??, which was agreed to. The bill now awaits ?? signature of the President. A bill to pay JOHN ELICSION $13,900 for services in planning the war steamer Princeton, was called up by Mr. ANTHONY and passed.

B. LIPPINCOTT Mr. JONES has succeded in giving a very accurate and comprehensive description of this work upon its title-page, which we have quoted above. It is a "Robel War Clerk's Diary,"

In the House of Representatives here this afternoon, the bill to equalize the bounties of the Massachusetts soldiers was passed to be engrossed, by 110 yeas to 85 nays. Speaker STONE ruled that the members of the House who had served in the army as soldiers, and would be entitled to receive-bounties if the bill became a law, would not be permitted to vote;

The stated meeting of the Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, JAMES LENOX, Esq., in the chair. Communications were received from Rev. S. B. BERGNE, Secretary British and Foreign Bible Society, with pleasing expressions of thanks for the consent of the Board to make duplicate plates of the Arabic Bible for that Society;

THE UNITED STATES COURTS AND THE POST OFFICE.-The United States District Court, which heretolore occupied rooms in the Kings County Court house, and in the Hamilton Buildings in Court-street, opposite the City Hall, has been removed to Nos. 137 and 139 Moutague-street, immediately opposite the Academy of Music. One of the buildings has recent.ly been occupied as a dancing academy.

The termination of tile Reciprocity Treaty has produced none of the depression, none of the uncasi ness, which was by many anticipated as its immediate consequence. This is in part attributable to the fact that a great effort was made last Fall and during the Winter to clear out the leading agricultural staples of the Province; so that in regard to these no inconventence will be felt during the present year.

The President sent a message to the House of Representatives in answer to a resolution requesting the names of persons worth more than $20,000 to whom special pardons have been issued, and a statement of the amount of property which has been seized as belonging to the enemies of the Government, or as abandoned property, and returned to those who claimed to be the original owners.

With some little trepidation we yesterday accepted an invitation from Prof. NOEBEL to attend a gathering of scientific gentlemen on the rocky slope between Eighth and Ninth avenues, near Eighty-third-street, for the purpose of witnessing a series of experiments with that cheerful compound ordinarily recognized as nitro-glycerine.

From the days of SOLOMON to those of Dr. DARWIN, the Garden has been one of the purest and most salubrious of human enjoyments; and now that the costly life of cities and the physical welfare of children induce so many of our citizens to turn their thoughts toward rural life, whatever tends wisely to embellish or worthily to occupy that life, deserves special attention.

GONE UNDER.--We rather think that when Head-Centre STEVENS arrives bore from Ire land he will find Fenianism dead and alto gether beyond resurrection, Not only does it exhibit no signs of life, but its renewed vital ity would be against the established nature of things, and the fixed laws of humbug.

At 7 o'clock yesterday morning, JOSHUA JENKINS, a child of seven months, son of Mrs. JENKINS, who died of cholera in Ninety-third-street, near Third-avenue, died of the disease which took off his mother. Mrs. COYLE, of Mulberry-street, was more comfortable, and the physicians had hopes of her recovery.

THE BOMBARDMENT OF VALPARAISO.---If it were right for Commodore ROGERS to pro pose intervention to the British Admiral for the protection of neutrals at Valparaiso, it could not have been far wrong to have done so " on his own hook." Itwould have been a strain upon International Law, but one in. regard to which his and other Governments would have been charitable in their constructions.

A SYMPTOM.--Gleams of light force their way into that dark Chamber where Senators, during the rebellion, ruled and reveled; where Mr. LINCOLN was traduced; where a Committee was appointed to demand the dis missal of the Secretary of State from the Cabinet. Senator POLAD, of Vermont, moved yesterday that the bill encroaching upon the Executive prerogative be recalled from the House.

In steamship William Penn, from London, Cannon, C. Cannon, L. Pickard, Mr. Burgeman, Mr. Peacock, Mr. McCall, Mr. Hyde and lady, Mrs. Pickard, Mrs. Beebe, Miss Franck, Miss Peacock, Miss Hyde, G. Schneider, H. Bacherach. A. Bacherach, H. Sachs, T. Baker, D. Loen., Y. Sillibourne, G. Prevest, N. M. Henry, J. H. Bowen, C. Anturn, G. Hoffman, J. Woodhaus. .

ATROCIOUS ASSAULT BY A MAN OF HIS WIFE.--A man named JOSEPH LENNOX was brought before Recorder AVERY, at Hoboken, yesterday, on a charge of brutally beating and attempting to take the life of his wife.

The Senate has passed the Franchise Bill thirteen against six. It is now a law, and distranchi ses over nine-tenths of the people of Tennessee. At the trial of HENDERSON to-day the cross-examina tion of HAYES elicited the fact that a letter was sent to HENDERSON threatening exposure, and demanding twenty thousand dollars, which the witness said was written by the instruction and sanction of CaptainVOORHIS.

The Merchants' National Bank of Washington, failed to-day. The amount of its notes in circulation is $180,000, which, however, are secured by United States bonds. The Bank was also a Government depository. Crowds of private depositors where on the premises to-day lamenting their supposed irretrievable loss. Some of them had confided in the Bank to the extent of $20,000.

On the 1st instant the Superintendent of Police sent out a circular to every Police Captain within the Metropolitan district, excluding the County of Westchester, bidding him notify all liquor-dealers in his precinct to whom, for any reason, he might declins to deliver blank applications for liconse, that he could be heard by the Board of Excise Committee on Applications.

SOUTHERN INDUSTRY.--On the ever-interest ing question of the forthcoming cotton crop the appearances now are, from all we can learn, that on this, as on so many other things, those of moderate judgment will comenearest the realized truth.

Gen. SHERMAN, accompanied by Col. McCoy, of his staff, left here yesterday morning on an extensive tour along the eastern termini of the Pacific Railroads, He proceeds first through. Wisconsin, ?? to Fort Leavenworth, where he will organize a military corps, guards, engineers, .

At the meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Excise yesterday, Commissioner ACTON presented six hundred and ninety-six applications for license, which had been considered and approved by the Committee on Applications, and the Board ordered that the desired licenses be granted, thus making the total number of licenses, down to last night, precisely eleven hundred. Not one of these is for Brooklyn.

The radius of twelve leagues from Las Tres Bocas (the three mouths) of the river Paraguay still holds the gathered forces of four nations. No abate ment of claim or of purpose has modified their rela tions. Preparations are making to force the Pass do Is Patria by the army, under shelter of the gunboats, When there will begin, as everybody believes, a series of closely-contested engagements, such as this country has never yet seen.

About 100 emigrants, of all classes, ages and sexes, from the interior of North Carolina, passed by hero last night on the steamer Adelaide, going West in search of employment. They were in oh rge of philanthropists from that election of the country. The movement was undertaken on account of the compe tition being introduced in their native State by the superabundance of negro labor, furnished under theministrations of the Freedmen's Bureau.

BERTINE.--At Mount Vernon, on Thursday, May 3, SEAMAN W., son of Samuel E. and Mary A. Bertino, aged 10 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his parents, on Sunday, at 2 P. M. BLACKWELL--At Janesville, Wis., on Sunday, April 29, CHARLES G., son of J. P. Blackwell, of this City, in the 24th year of his age.

THE INDUSTRIES OF NEW-YORK.--"A fair day's wages for a fair day's work," is something that everybody should struggle for until everybody achieves it. But the continual breaking up of one and another branch of industry by strikes, and the exorbitant demands that are sometimes made by workers, operate very disadvantageously to the interests of this City.

GOOD ADVICE TO BLACK MEN AND WHITES.--The unfortunate fact that the great mass of the Southern negroes are unable to read is not without a certain countervailing advan tage, especially when their present circum stances are taken into account. They are left in blissful ignorance of much of the bad ad vice that is attempted to be given them, and know nothing of many of the intolerablewrongs under which they still labor.

Capt. WM. H. GRACE, who claims to be one of the oldest Feniann in New-England, publishes a com munication in the Post, of this city, detailing the re cent abortive attempt to invade the Eastern BritishProvinces.

ITALIAN OPERA.--Mr. GRAU'S short season of Italian opera, disturbed by the non-arrival of the Havana steamer, will commence on Monday next with "La Traviata." The impresario and the artists are here and in fine condition. VERDI's work will enjoy the advantage of an almost entirely new caste. Mile, LEONILDA BOSCHETTI is the Violetta, Signor ANASTASY the Alfredo, Signor ORLANDINI the Germoni,

The Board of Health have under consider ation a very important measure, the removing bodily the cellar population of New-York from their habitations. They are enabled to do this, probably, by their general powers with reference to removing nuisances, and from the particular powers conferred on them in thenear approach of a pestilence.

BAKER--WAKEMAN.--On Wednesday, May 2, at the residence of the bride's parents, by Rev. Dr. Rice, DWIGHT BAKER and DELIA M., daughter of Wm. W. Wakeman, Esq., both of this City. BARDUA--LIENAU.--On Thursday, May 3, by Rev. S. M. Rice, at Grace Church, Van Vorst-st., Jersey City, N. J., F. WILHELM BARDUA, of Berlin, Germany, and JACOBINA C. LIENAU, of Jersey City, N. J.

The regular troops lately arrived in Texas are acting very badly, indulging in drunken rows and fights at Galveston. Business at Matamora is dull. The Imperial Aus trian troops are dissatisfied on account of their small pay. Forced loans are driving the merchants away. Cotton easy; sales to-day, 1,200 bales. Week's receipts, 10,888 bales, against 10,303 bales last week.

FIVE HORSES BURNED TO DEATH AT A FIRE IN SEVENTH-AVENUE.--At 12:10 yesterday morning, a fire occurred in a row of frame stables in rear of Nos. 449 and 451 Seventh-avenue. There were eleven horses housed in the stables, six of whom were got out in safety, but the remaining five were burned to death. Two of the horses burned were the property of

The TIMES is well aware that we believe in the Citi zens' Association as a body of upright, intelligent, public-spirited tax-payers, singly Intent on saving our citizens from legislative and municipal thieves Tribune. We cheerfully concede all that is desired for the "Citizens' Association," and as cheerfully add that we should rejoice to see its means and votes much more efficiently and successfully applied.

PERSONAL.--Prof. RAPHAEL PUMPELLY, an American mining geologist, whose recent researches in the economical geology of Japan, China and Mongolia, (now in course of publication by the Smithsonian Institution,) have resulted in important discoveries, is about to set out on a professional tour of the Pacific coast.

THE EIGHT-HOUR SYSTEM. Mr. CONNESS presented a petition from the workingmen of California, asking the enactment of an eight-hour law for the government of the men in the employment of the United States. Mr. CONNESS said he fully believed that labor would be as profitable to the country under the eight-hour system as it is now under the ten-hour system.

Consul GEODEY, Liberal, has official communications, dated El Paso Del Norte, March 30, announcing that the Liberals took the City of Chihuahua March 26, after two days hard fighting, capturing 300 prisoners, among whom was JULIO CARRANCA, the Imperial Mayor of Chihuahua. On the 22d the Liberals captured the City of Hidaljo del Parral by assault.

Honolulu advices state that the steamer Kilsna, supposed, hopelessly wrecked, had arrived comparatively unharmed. Mining stocks continue dull. Ophir, $520: Hale and Norcross, $915; Yellow Jacket, $690; Chollar Petosi, $295; Imperial, $131.

In the Senate yesterday the bill to provide for the payment of Quartermaster's stores and subsistence supplies furnished the army by loyal citizens was read three times, and laid over till Tuesday next. Several petitions were offered and referred, and private claims considered. In the House, on motion of Mr. STEVENS, a joint resolution was unanimously passed congratula ting the Emperor and people of Russia on his recentProvidential escape from the danger of assassination.

PERSONAL.--Mr. WM. MARTIN, so long connected with telegraphic enterprises in Boston, has accepted a responsible position in the office of the American Telegraph Company of this City. Mr. MARTIN has given many years to the doing of his part in the development of that which has grown to the magnitude of a great institution in his time.

Toward the close of the last century TEN NANT had the happy thought to introduce chloride of limo for bleaching purposes. Previous to that time bleaching had been ac complished by the slow process of exposingthe goods upon grass in the sun.

The contest in England over the Reform Bill naturally calls forth it good deal of dis cussion upon the principles of democracy the opponents of the bill urging every fair argument against an extension of the suffrage and not a few unfair ones. Among the latter a controversy which has been going on in Aus tralia has been pressed into the service in themost outrageous way.

The unsettled weather of the past three weeks has somewhat retarded the progress of out-door sports in this vicinity. Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather, the different cricket and base ball clubs have been as busy as beavers in their preparations for the approaching tourney. nearly, of not all, the leading clubs have had their opening days, and in the course of a fortnight the season will be setively inaugurated.

About 8 o'clock this evening a fire broke out in the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum, and in an hour the building was burned to the ground, with a portion of its contents. The building was a large wooden structure, and was the private property of Rev. Father PETER HAVERMANS. There were one hundred and seventy-two orphan boys in theAsylum, all of whom were saved.

Yesterday morning those liquor-dealers to whom Capts. THORNE, PETTY and JOURDAN had not given applications for license, were heard by Commis sioners ACTON and MANIERRE, in the Trial Chamber, at Police IIeadquarters. Their name was legion. They crowded the chamber, peered in over each other's shoulders at the doorways, and followed eachother up in long lines far down the stair-cases.

We learn from reliable sources that steam communication is likely to be soon established between New-Orleans and Vera Cruz direct. This line of steamers will receive an adequate subsidy from the Imperial Government to insure its success. It is intended to make three trips each way every month.

Two Circuit Judges in Virginia, Messrs. SHEF FEY and CHRISTIAN, in recent charges to the Grand Juries of their respective counties, spoke very justly and humanely of the manner in which the freedmen ought to be treated. They both declared that the negroes are, by the Constitution and laws, clothed with certain civil and personal rights which Courtsare in duty bound to recognize and respect.

A special dispatch to the Commercial, from Knoxville, says: "The East Tennessee Convention assembled yesterday, (Friday,) and the proceedings of Thursday were adopted. Resolutions petitioning the Legislature for an act following East Tennessee a separate State Government were adopted, with but four dissenting voices, and a committee of seven was appointed to lay the matter before the Legislature.

INTERNAL REVENUE ACCOUNTS. The clause in the Internal Revenue Bill now before Congress, requiring that Collectors acting as disbursing agents shall be allowed all payments made by them in pursuance of directions from the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, provokes unfavorable comment.

From the New-York Boudoir, It is a singular, and to us not very creditable fact, that foreign art is more popular in this country than native art. We have American-born artists who are in every respects the equals of those of Europe; nor can we import better works from abroad than we can purchase in American studios.

The recent revelations in the TIMES of the do ings and misdoings of the O'Mahonyites have created a sensation in Fenian Arcles greater than they have before experienced. "It was bad enough," say some of the principal men, "to be cheated and bamboozled by the great Head Centre, but to have our verdency exposed and ridicule thrown upon all, because of the weakness of one, is a little morethan we bargained for."

Although the war through which our country has passed differs from others in many essential particulars, the lesson which it and they are meant to teach is common to them all. It is that peace and good-will are neces sary to humanity. The end of all campaigns, for whatever undertaken, is that of conquering a peace.

McKAY HODGE in 1864 as follows: Monday, Aug. 8, $2,600; Tuesday, Aug. 10, $2,500; Wednesday, Aug, 11, he drew out $500; Thursday, Aug. 12, $2,000; Saturday he drew out $13,600. FROM THE LOG-BOOK OF THE STEAMSHIP VIRGINIA. From the Galaxy. Twelve hundred miles and more From the stormy English shore, All aright, the seventh night, On her course our vessel bore. Her lautern shone ahead, And the green Jump and the red To starboard, and to larboard, Shot their light.

The House met for general debate on the President's Annual Message, as if in Committee of the Whole. Mr. PHELPS addressed the House on the subject of reconstruction, supporting the position assumed by the President.

Our Washington dispatches yesterday morning announced the death in that city, of typhoid fever, of Count ADAM DE GUROWSKI. After a life full of remarkable adventures, he died at the age of sixty-one years. Count GUROWSKI was the oldest son of the Polish Count LADISLAS GUROWSKI, who, in 1794, took an active and prominent part in the insurrection of which KOSCIUSKO was the leader.

A simple plan was tried during the former attacks of cholera in some of the English and Scotch towns, which saved more lives, proba bly, than any measure or cure ever inau gurated against this pestilence. It was based on tile common-sense idea that the point on which cholera should be attacked is in the preliminary symptom--the painless diarrhoea-and that it is just here that the poor aremost careless.

SUICIDE BY A CUBAN, BOY.--DOMINGO BATAN, a native of Cuba, only 17 years age, arrived in this City some two weeks ago, when he put up at the Railroad Hotel, No. 8 Broadway. His intention was to endeavor to learn the business of civil engineering, but being almost penniless and a total stranger his efforts did not meet with success, the fact having a depressing effect upon his spirits.

The authorities at Galveston have issue an order granting permits to sailing masters to be their own health officers. Unless they have sickness on board their ships, they may enter the harbor without inspection, but the responsibility of this course willrest upon the masters.

SURPRISE AND CAPTURE OF BURGLARS.--Shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning a private watchman named JAMES HUGHES discovered the rear window of the butcher shop of LAWRENCE Co., No. 60 Grand-street, E. D., open, and hearing a noise within, he entered the place and surprised two burglars, who immediately ran out of a side door.

Thomas Shankland, Esq., New-York City: My DEAR SIR: As I have heard nothing from you since my reply to your letter of the 4th of Janu ary last, I have concluded that, owing to the great derangement of the mails, it has failed to reach you. I therefore write again hoping for better luck this time.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The most philosophical and eloquent of British statesmen, Mr. BURKE, uttered a striking truth in saying that manners influence us more than laws. Laws affect us now and then, here and there, but manners have a powerful influence upon us every day, every hour, everywhere--in every look, utterance and action; and we cannot escape their bias in our estimate of character and conduct.

The Tribune brings its usual self-confuting logic into play in defence of the Trumbull amendment to the Post-office Bill, withholding compensation from officers appointed without the approval of the Senate. COLORADO TO BE A STATE.--Congress is rush ing the Territory of Colorado, with 5,000 electors, into the Union as a State.- The proposition did not at first meet with favor. But now, when Senators are needed to out vote the President, and those from Colorado supposed to be convenient, the "switch" hasbeen changed.

The steamship China, from Liverpool on the 28th, via Queentown on the 29th April, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received. The China has 48 passengers for Halifax and 89 for Boston.

PROBST has made a full confession to his priest of all the murders of the DEARING family, commencing with CORNELIUS CAREY, the hired boy. He had no accomplice in his bloody work. SECOND DISPATCH. The Evening Telegraph publishes the confession of PROBST.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. GRAU opened his season last evening with "La. Traviata," an opera which, notwithstanding the sneers that have been sibillated against it, is yet the best emotional and vocal opera in the Italian or any other repertoire. The interest of such a revival can be fonnd-by wearisome habitues and critics-only in the artists who take part in it. This was understood andamply provided for by Mr. GRAU.

THE BRITISH REFORM BILL.--The Reform Bill, it will be seen, has passed the House of Commons, but by so small a majority that it is probable its enemies will be found strong enough to kill it in Committee, or to mutilate its provisions so that it will prove unacceptable to Ministers and their Liberal supporters.

No arrangement has yet been effected between the employers and their late employes in the ship-building interest. It is now over five weeks since the ship caulkers, joiners and carpenters struck for the eight-hour system, and in the meantime all labor heretofore performed by them is at a stand-still.

Nelson Chase et al. vs. John Howard Smith et al.--The argument on the motion made on behalf of the defendants in this highly important action was continued yesterday in the large room of the Court-house, known as Part I, of the Circuit, and Oyer and Terminer room.

In the Senate yesterday the House joint resolution in relation to the attempted assaseination of the Emperor of Russia was passed. Mr. CHANDLER, from the Committee on Commerce, reported a joint resolution directing the Secretaries of War and Navy to unite in establishing a uniform system of quarantine in the ports of the United Slats.

MODEL FARM-SCHOOLS FOR THE CHIILDREN OF COLORED SOLDIERS.-M. DE MAREIL, editor of the Messager Franco-Americain, has just inaugurated near Washington a benevolent enterprise of some importance. He has bought an estate and erected thereon buildings capable of accommodating several hundred children, with the purpose of organizing, under the auspices of the Freedmen's Bureu,a model farm-school for the benefit of the children of coloredsoldiers. Teachers have already been secured,

In addition to the religious convention called by Dr. BRECKINRIDGE, of Kentucky, which will meet here on the 17th instant, the Presbyterian General Assemblies, of both the Old and the New School, will convene here on the 17th inst. One thousand delegates are expected to be in attendance. Ample provision has been made for all that come.

ANTON PROBST has at last succumbed. He made a full and free confession of his crime, detailing the circumstances of the murders, and the motive that induced him to commit them. Sunday he made the first approach toward a confession, and then he admitted to the priest, Rev. Mr. GUNTHER, that he alone was responsible for the death of the eight persons found dead on the Dearing farm.

THE PRESIDENT'S APPOINTING POWER. The debate in the Senate this afternoon upon the amendment to the Post-office Appropriation Bill, restricting the President in the appointing power, was more lively than any of the previous debates on that subject. The matter will again come up to-morrow, when a final vote will be taken, and doubtless the amendment will be rejected. Should this be the result,...

The following is a schodule of work performed by this department in the abatement and removal of nuisances, for the week ending May 8, 1860: Com plaints of nusances received, 077; notices served for abatement, 1,106; nuisances abated under service of notice, 784; sinks and water-closets cleaned, 432;loads of night-soll removed from City limits, 1,780;

BRIDGES OVER STREETS.--Where are the "light and elegant structures" which it was understood were to span the more dangerous crossings in the streets? There is really a necessity for them. If a number were erected the services might be saved of many of thesquad whose duty it is to protect pedestriaus.

At the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in session in this place, Judge BACON presiding, a bill of indictment was found this morning against AsA FULLER, HIEL DAVIS, IRVING VANCE, CHAS. VANCE and THOS, DUTCHER for murder. The indictment charges them with killing JOHN L. CAMPBELL, at Frankfort Hill, on the 6th of February last. The young men were arraigned and plead not guilty.

The keepers of dram-shops in the Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, Tenth, Thirteenth, and Twenty-eighth Police Precincts were packed in Police Trial Chamber on Monday and Tuesday mornings, even more closely than the inmates of a tenement-house. The majority of the dealers were from the Tenth Ward--a ward which has only thirty-two thousand population and six hundred and twenty-one bars.

We copied from another paper, in our Sunday issue, a statement that a Mr. SCOTT, of New-Jersey, had made affidavit that he had been defrauded of large sums by purchasing lottery tickets, and that warrants had been issued for the arrest of certain parties. The gist of the charge was that the lotteries were not fairly drawn or if so, that the real drawings were altered.

CHOLERA. Mr. MORGAN presented the memorial of the Medical Association, recently assembled at Baltimore, asking Congress to take measures for the prevention of the introduction of Asiatic cholera into this country.

The progress of statistical science in this country must be regarded as eminently satis factory. To this result the Census Bureau has boon the chief contributor. The portly volume just issued by that Bureau compares favorably with any which has been produced by any Government or individual, whether as respects its amplitude of material, or thewith which that material has been arranged.

The great robbery of the Adams Express Company's car in January last is fresh in the public mind. The recent trial of TRISIAM and CLARK, at Bridge port, resulted in their sentence to the state Prison, since when the detectives have been busily at work, with the most favorable consequences.

FIRE IN BROADWAY.--At 6:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in one of the upper floors of the five-story building No. 198 Broadway. The flames gained good headway before the arrival of the firemen, but they went to work with so good a will that the flames were checked before they had extended below the fourth floor.

The fifty-second anniversary of this Society was celebrated last evening at Irving Hall. The attendance was quite large, a number of our most prominent citizens interested in religious and educational movements being present. WILLIAM A. BOOTH, Esq., President of the Society, took the chair.

Gen. BEAUREGARD and W. ADAMS have gone to Europe to negotiate Jackson Railroad bonds. President JOHNSON has modified their paroles so that they can go and return. A tornado, accompanied by hail, has passed over Louisiana and Arkansas, destroying corps.

BANG--BERGETRIN.--On Tuesday, May 8, at St. Francis Church, by Rev. Mr. Pfeiffer, HENRY J. BANG and AUGUSTA BERGSTEIN, daughter of August Bergstein, of this City, No cards. GRANNISS--PRICK.--On Tuesday, May 8, at Zion Church, by Right Rev. Horatio Southgate, D. D., JAMES E. GRANNISS and JANE E. PRICE, all of this City.

The French steamer La France arrived to-day with troops bound to Vera Cruz, One of the boilers of the floating dock in our harbor exploded, killing two persons and scalding seven others, of which three have since died. There was also an explosion of gunpowder on board the Spanish steamer San Pclayo, but it appears thequantity was small, and little damage ensued.

At the annual meeting of the Shipowners' Association of New-York, held at the Rooms No. 50 Pine-street, yesterday, the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President--Geo ge Griswold, First Vice-President--James H. Frothingham, Second Vice-President--Ambrose Snow, Treasurer--William D. Morgan.

The mails by the steamship China reached this city from Boston at an early hour yesterday morning. We give the more striking portions of several of the principal speeches delivered in the British House of Commons during the concluding debate on the Bay form Bill.

SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS--MAY 9. Before Justice Harnard. The argument of this motion, which for several days has elicited much interest in certain circles, was continued yesterday in the room appropriated to the Circuit and Oyer and Terminer. The apartment was crowded to excess long before the hour appointed for the commencement of the proceedings.

FIRE IN GRAND-STREET,--At 5 o'clock Yesterday morning a fire occurred in the building on the corner of Grand and Baxter streets, breaking out on the third floor, occupied by FROELICK Co., manufacturers of photographic shades. The firemen soon succeeded in extinguishing the flames, but the occupants of the lower floors sustained considerable loss by water.

The office of the Treasurer of the Excise Board was besieged from an early yesterday morning, until the close yesterday afternoon, by those dealers whom Col. CLARK had notified to report personally and receive license. Generally the recipients of license were good-tempered and communicative, and the majority of those dealers who made any remark professed their readiness to aid the Board in a rigid enforcement of the law.

The Union Course, L. I, was yesterday visited by a large number of gentlemen interested in trot ting stock, and horsemen generally, to witness the sale by public auction of the famous Hamble tonian gelding, Decker, and other horses hithertojointly owned by Messrs. ALLEY TEAKLE,

BURGLARY IN GRAND-STREET.--During Tuesday night a burglary was committed in the tailoring establishment of F. Leonard, corner of Grand and Allen-streets, when a large quantity of goods were carried off. The thieves effected an entrance to the store by wrenching off the lock on the trap door leading into the cellar, and then cutting a hole through the floor.

A regular meeting of the Board of Fire Commissioners was held yesterday. A Communication was received from residents of Yorkville, commending the conduct of members of Engine Company No. 22 at the late fire in Eighty-fifth-street.

ARRIVALS IN THE CITY. Hon. H. White, Niagra Falls; Hon. N. P. Gordo, Philadelphia; Hon, V. M. Rice, Albany, and Hon, T. P. Pomroy, Rhode Island, are at the Astor House. Hon. Richard Yates, Illinois; Anson Stager, Cleveland; Gen. H. L. Robinson, Washington; Hon. A. C. Brastow, Providence; Hon, B. R. Wood, Albany; Judge Selden and Gov. Church, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

HOWARD.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday, May S. AMANDA, wife of William Howard, and daughter of the late Henry Chichester, of Norwalk. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 160 Fort Green-place, this (Thursday) afternoon at 3 o'clock.

"Lo! THE POOR INDIAN,"--The aboriginal race, receding and polishing as civilization advanced, excited at least public sympathy. Emancipation for the negro is proving a dearly purchased blessing. The race, in passing through its ordeal, encounters dangers as ap palling as those which beset the children ofIsrael on their journey to the promised land.

In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported to incorporate an Academy of Music in the City of Washington. Mr. CHANDLER introduced a bill to regulate the transportation of nitro-glycerine. It forbids such transportation on all conveyances used for passengers, and makes the killing of any person, by the violation of the statute, murder in the first degree.

ORGANIZATION OF THE BOARD OF CHOSEN FREE HOLDERS.--The members of the Chosen Board of Free holders, for Hudson County, met at the Court-house yesterday afternoon and organized by the election of the following officers: Director, James Lyrch; Clerk, Chas. J. Rob; Treasurer, E. W. Kingsland; Counsel, Jacob R. Wortendyke; County Physician, Joseph F. Finn; School Examiners, Wm. L. Dickinson and Joseph E. Culver; Official Papers, Jersey City Standard,

BURNED To DEATH IN A LIME KILN.--Yester day morning as workmen in charge of the lime kiln of WM. HALLIDAY, No. 242 East Eighteenth-street, went to work they found the body of an unknown boy, apparently about 8 years of age, burnt to a crisp. It is supposed that the boy crept into the kiln to sleep and was smothered. The body was dressed in a blackjacket, gray pants, blue army cap and brogans.

The debate on the English Reform Bill has brought out some expressions of opinion in regard to our form of government which are somewhat amusing. A portion of the speechof Mr. LOWE possesses this character.

THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC AT WASHINGTON. Mr. MORRILL, from the Committee on the District of Columbia, reported, with an amendment, the bill to incorporate the Academy of Music in the City of Washington. The amendment strikes out the seventh section, which authorizes the borrowing of money by the issue of bonds of the Association.

As regards the variety of its contents and general literary ability, the second number of the Galaxy--that for May 15--is a decided advance upon the first, Dr. W. H. DRAPER contributesan exceedingly valuable and timely paper on

The official report of the Spanish Admiral NUNEZ of the bombardment of the City of Val paraiso adds little to our knowledge of the event, though it is as admirable a piece of re porting as we have ever seen. He recites the various efforts of KILPATIRICK and ROGERS to negotiate a peace, but shows that there Werepoints in dispute which he could not give up.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--" I Trovatoro" was pro duced hero last evening with several artists new to the public. Of the work itself it is unnecessary to speak. It is sufficiently well known, Mr. GRAU gave it the re current importance of a now cast. In doing so he introduced to us several artists of positive merit. Mine, NOEL-GUIDI, the Leonora, possesses a voice ofgreat purity and extent.

About five hundred shipwrights of this City and vicinity, representing the ship carpenters, caulk ers and joiners, assembled last evening at Clinton Hall, for the purpose of debating matters relative to the strike in which they are now engaged. These mechanics, numbering nearly ten thousand work. men, stopped work over five weeks ago, for the purpose of inaugurating the eight-hour system,

THE MEMPHIS RIOTS.--We observe that some of our Southern and Southwestern exchanges are designating the recent shocking riots in Memphis as a "war of races." We hope there is no terrible "shadow of future events" cast in this phrase.

To those who have followed the journeyings of Mr. TRUMAN in the South, as reported in his correspondence with this journal during the last eight months, the special statement prepared at the instance of the President, and printed in our columns on Tuesday, presentsnothing that is absolutely new.

The death warrant for the execution of ANTOINE PROBST on Friday, the 8th of June, was received by the Sheriff this morning. The Evening Telegraph says that the prisoner received the announcement quietly, seemingly entirely unmoved. He had previously told his confessor that he believed that death was the only expiation for his crimes, and that he was willing to suffer.

While the last Legislature of our State was in session, we refrained as far as possible from commenting upon their doings, only now and then referring to measures which seemed to be of great importance. That Legislature did some good things; and it did some very silly things.
A BAD INVESTMENT--The French people are becoming quite as much disgusted with their Mexican financial experience as they have been with their Mexican military experience.

ADOPTION OF THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON RECONSTRUCTION. The great debate in the House closed to-day, and at 3:45 P. M., the Constitutional Amendments, just as reported by the Reconstruction Committee, were passed by the strong vote of 128 years to 87 Days. The manner in which this result was brought about deserves especial notice.

The Convention of the advocates of woman's rights was held yesterday at the church of Dr. CHEE VER, Union-square. The building was crowded with an audience which for three hours and a half gave undivided attention to the speeches and addressesdelivered.

AKIN.--At Greenbush, N. Y., on Wednesday, May 9, CAROLINE ARIN, wife of the late Burr Akin. Funeral at Greenbush thus day, (Friday,) May 11, at 3 P. M. APPLEBY--On Wednesday, May 9, at Spotswood, N. J. JOHN APPLEBY, aged 71 years.

During the last ten days bookseller have been unusually active, not so much in disposing of their stock, however, as in transferring it from one point to another. The moving mant?? has seized upon them so violently as to suggest the idea that they have been changed in a gigantic game of that amusement so popular with juveniles--"Puss in the corner."

A battalion of the Seventy-first Regiment N. Y. S. N. G., consisting of Companies D and E, Capts. WOLCOTT and SMITH commanding, proceeded to the residence of Mayor HOFFMAN, at the Clarendon Hotel, on Fourth-avenue, last evening, and honored him with a serenade. After performing several airs, Mayor HOFFMAN responded to repeated calls for aspeech in a few remarks.

In the Senate yesterday the House bill to suthorize the Vice-Admiral of the Navy to appoint a Secretary, with the rank and pay of Lieutenant, was passed, A resolution calling upon the Secretary of War for information as to the intention of the Gov ernment with regard to the Government works atHarper's Ferry, was adopted.

THE GRADE OF VICE-ADMIRAL. On motion of Mr. GRIMES, the House bill to amend the act establishing the grade of Vice-Admiral in the Navy was taken up and passed. It authorizes the Vice-Admiral to employ a Secretary, with the rank and pay of Lieutenant.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--An excellent performance of "Faust" was given last evening, to an utterly in adequate audience. What was deficient in numbers, however, was amply made up in enthusiasm; and the enthusiasm, we are glad to add, was deserved: Signor ANASTASI was in good voice.

A special messenger arrived yesterday at Lee Angeles, bringing a dispatch from the commander of Fort Grant to Gen. MASON, announcing that Fort Goodwin, Arizona, had been taken by 2,000 Indians, and the garrison, numbering 124 men, massacred, with one exception, and the fort burned.

A man named JOHN PRICE shot another named CLINTON JAMES last night, in the American Theatre, corner of Baltimore and Calvert streets. JAMES died at midnight. He was a second in the recent prize tight near Washington.
POLICE ON FERRIES.--The passage of the Now-York Excise Law has rendered the neces sity for Police on the ferry lines more apparent than it was when we last alluded to the subject.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of this day it is stated that we were arraigned before Justice DOWLING for violating the recent act of the Legislature in boarding the English ship Cordillera, and pleaded guilty to the charge. We beg respectfully to inform you that such a statement is entirely incorrect. Judge DOWLING dismissed the case.

MULLER, Captain Company B, Fourteenth Infantry, and Acting Assistant Surgeon TAPPAN, U. S. A., were fired upon by Apaches at Cotton Wood Springs, March 22, and the former killed and the latter hadly wounded.

An examination of the list of brevets already confirmed by the Senate will call to the memory of our readers a pungent letter of Gen. SHERMAN'S to the War Department, in which, after protesting against the advance ment of officers who left in the midst of bullets to go to the rear in search of advancement, he says, "if the rear be the post of honor, thenwe had better change front on Washington."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My attention has been called to the speech of Hon. JOHN SHERMAN, of Ohio, at Bridgeport, Conn., in which he assailed me. It was reported for your widely-circulated journal, and published in it. Will you do me the favor to publish my response to that part of it which referred to me personally.

The steamship Agnes, from St. Thomas on the 2d instant, arrived here yesterday. The only news of importance is that the French steamer Slyx left St. Thomas on the 1st instant, with 1,200 French troops for Vera Cruz. A French steamer arrived at St. Thomas on the 27th ultimo, from Vera Cruz, with 700 troops, and sailed on the 29th for France.

FIRE IN GREENE-STREET,-At 6 o'clock yester day morning, a fire broke out on the second floor of the building No. 62 Greence-street, originating in tile dining-room of the French confectionery factory, owned by JAMES RIVERA.Before tho flames were extinguished, they extended to the roof of No. 64, re.suiting in both roofs being destroyed.

SOLON REDIVIUS.-Our last Legislature sol emnly enacted the following points: 1. Liquor selling is a nuisance, a disgrace and a detri ment to the people. 2. But if the seller pays a license, liquor-selling is virtuous-and a legitimate source of profit, therefore, desirableand highly commendable.

In the Senate, yesterday, the joint resolution of the House to provide for carrying into immediate effect the bill for the better organization of the pay Department of the Navy was passed. SUMMER, MORRILL and JOHNSON, until the expiration of the morning hour.

PETITIONS. Mr. GRIMES presented petitions for the passage of a bill the Upper Mississippi, so as not to impede railroad or water travel, which were referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Post Roads. NATIONAL BUREAU OF EDUCATION. Mr. GRIMES presented the joint resolution of the Iowa Legislature for the establishment of a National Bureau of Education, which was ordered to lie on the table.

The Metropolitan Hotel swarmed yesterday with gratified Hibernians, who flocked in crowds to pay their respects to JAMES STEPHENS, Chief Executive of the Irish Republic, and to extend to him a warm welcome to the "Land of the Free." His movements yesterday were somewhat circumscribed, he being in the hands of the Fenian Executive Committee.

Last Sunday we published the substance of an affidavit made by LYMAN 0. SCOTT in regard to al leged frauds in the management of the Kentucky lot teries. Subsequently we were furnished with a copy of a counter afidavit signed by LYMAN B, SCOTT, thematerial portions of which we also published.

The Radical meeting last night in commemoration of the capture of Camp Jackson five years ago, was one of the largest, most enthusiastic gatherings ever assembled in this city. Speeches were made from three stands. Gov. OGLESBY, of Illinois; Gov. FLETCHER, Secretary of State RODMAN, CHAS. D. DRAKE, and several other distinguished persons were among the speakers.

The steamer Constoilution sailed to-day for Panama, with $398,418 in treasure, of which $285,346 are for Now-York. There was sold, yesterday, 660,000 pounds of sugar, refining grade, at 81/8c. Reports indicate that theo crop of cereals will exceed that of any former year,

The unexpectedly small majority by which the British ministers have been sustained on the second reading of their Reform Bill, indi cates either an aversion to the question itself amounting almost to a dread, or a want of tact on the part of those entrusted with its care. Elected with a direct reference to this question, it had been computed that the present House of Oommons would givea ministerial majority of about fifty;

ARREST OF A GARROTER. --A men named MARTIN KILLELAY, residing at No. 79 North First--street, Eastern District, was attacked by two garroters at the corner of Third and North First streets, at a late hour on Monday night. One of the ruffians seized him by the neck while the other attempted to rob him, but Mr. KILLELAY being rather stronger than his jossailant, struggled so effectually as tos cosmpel him to loosen his grip.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Legislature of Florida, at its last session, granted a charter to a New-York Company, incorporating it under the name of the International Ocean Telegraph Company. The object of this Company is to connect our shores with Cuba and the West Indies, and from thence to branch out over all creation in general by telegraph.

The cattle market opened dull with a down ward tendency, owing to the decline in the New-York market last Monday, but the demand to-day was ac tive, both for New-York and the Eastern markets, and at prices nearly up to the ruling rates of last week, a fact not much appreciated by t he Western sellers, however, as they paid more for their stock than they didthen.

The examination of the class of '66 was closed last evening. The Examining Committee were S. B. RUGGLES, Chairman, GOUVENEUR M. OGDEN and GEO, T. STRONG. On the close of the examination, Mr. RUGGLES, the Chairman, rose and spoke as follows: I am happy to announce to you, gentlemen, that your class, numbering 48, have passed the examine.tion without one exception.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--PACINI'S opera of "Saffo" was revived here last evening for the first time in several years. it afforded an excellent opportunity for the rentrie of Mme, GAZZANIGA--an artiste whose merits have not been forgotten by the public. This fact was pleasantly demonstrated. en Mme.

The results of the failure of Messrs. BAYNE Co., of this city, already known to the public as the prime cause of the failure of the Mer chants' National Bank, Washington, proves to have been more disastrous, financially, than at first supposed. Four of our city banks, at least, are sufferers;

The Commercial Advertiser has the following: "The House of Representatives yesterday passed the plan of reconstruction as it was reported from the Committee. The vote was very decisive--128 to 87. The plan seemed to have few friends in or out of Congress, and the third section, which disfranchises the South until 1870, was especially criticised.

UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE. Before Commissioner Belts. The investigation in this matter was continued. Tal. P. Shaffuer testified that he had been largely engaged in scientific pursuits; had been interested in the electric telegraph; his specialty in millitary matters was artillery raining: he had been connected with the military services of both Europe and America;

As usual with occurrences of the kind, this one has been accompanied by exaggeration and misrepresentation. The following are the facts, gathered from personal observation and raliable sources:

The bill to equalize the bounties of the Massachuset's soldiers, which passed the House of Representatives last week by a majority of twenty-five votes, was refused a third reading in the Senate to-day by a vote of 15 year against 22 nays.

The TIMES of the 4th inst. reported the trial of Patrolman JOHN J. CLARE, for delivering to an imposter a valuable bundle of undergarments which Mrs. ANN O'BRIEN had washed and was taking to the owner, the officer being at the time on duty for the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company, and having taken Mrs. O'BRIEN'S bundle out of the car to the front platform.

A curious case of eccentricity is described in the following facts which have lately fallen under our notice. A good many years ago, a gentleman who filled a prominent situation in one of our banks, at a good old age married his servant.

One of the difficulties experienced by the Census Bureau in collecting information on various statistical subjects, has been the care less indifference of local officials in preserv ing records of population. The question of a thorough national system of registration of births, deaths and marriages, almost instantlysuggests itself on learning this fact.

The great topic of conversation among Irish men is the arrival and movements of the Central Or ganizer of the Irish Republic, Mr. JAMES STEPHENS. He is quietly lodged at the Metropolitan Hotel, from the roof of which building waves the national flag ofIreland, so dear to the hearts of her sons.

The weather still continues cold and unseasonable, and everything in the vegetable line is very backward. On Friday night last there was quite a severe frost. Ice formed in the gutters, and it is feared that incipient fruit in this region was seriously damaged. The season is full two weeks behind time, but generally, when such is the case, our Summer crops are all the better for it.

Gov. MORTON,-Some of the Indiana papers express great joy at the probable recovery of Gov. MORTON, since if his health is completely restored he will be an available candidate for the United States Senate. The whole people are interested in the recovery of Gov. MORTON, than whom we have few if any abler, wiser or more devoted statesmen.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Laymen says that according to Burke, who he rightly estimates high in the scale of statesmen and philosophers, "that manners influence us more than laws. Laws affect us now and then, here and there, but manners have a powerful influence upon us every day, every hour, everywhere--in every look, "

The great debate on the extension of the suf frage reopened on Monday night with a long speech from Mr. BRIGHT, which disappointed alike his ene mies and his friends. It was moderate to tamoness; it was, for Mr. BRIGHT, simply weak and unimpressive.

TAKING UP "FREE PASSES."--The Railroad conductors are now having an interesting time taking up the passes by direction of the new act of the Legislature. It is hard work with some persons to part with their free tickets and pay over their fare. Conductor HADCOCK, on the Central down train, was shown a pass yesterday with the name of a leading railroad man attached to it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You have remarked in your columns, on the plans presented to the Board of Health, of a preliminary house-to-house visitation to prevent cholera. It may be interesting to your renders to know more particularly the results of this measure in Great Britain, especially in the cholera epidemic of 1849.
ADAMS.--In Merrisania, on Saturday, May 12, Mrs. SARAH ADAMS, widow of the late Jesso Adams, St., aged 73 years. The funeral will take place on Monday at 2 o'clock,

From the Galaxy. How the stars shine out at sea! Swing me, Tital Faster, girl! I'm a hang-bird in her nest, All with searlot blossoms drest, Swinging where the winds blow free. Ah! how white the moonlight falls, Catch my slipper! there it goes, Where that single fire-fly shines, Tangled in the heavy vines, Creeping by the convent walls.

HUDSON COUNTY COURT--PRISONERS ARRAIGNED.--The Grand Jury of Hudson County, which has just concluded is Session, found seventy hills of indictment, three of which were against parties for maintaining nuisances in the shape of slaughter-houses and been boiling establishments. On Saturday, quite a number of persons were arraigned before Judge Bedle, and associates judges Chambers and Sturges, 29 follows:--Jacob Erwin, ??laughter house nuisance in Jersey-City.

Capt. HEDDEN, of the Sixteenth Precinct, Capt. WALLING, of the Twentieth, and Sergt. GRCS, acting for Capt. SLOTT, of the Twenty-second, appeared before Commissioners ACTION and MANIERRE,Yesterday, and confronted those liquor dealers of their respective precincts whom they, under their instructions from the Police Commissioners, had been unable to recommend.

From the Galaxy, To the northwest of France, hidden in the mystic vapors of the ocean, lies a fortunate archipelago. The gulf stream there brings out a flora worthy of the fairest isles of the Adriaticand Mediterranean.

Hon. W. H. SEWARD--My Dear Sir: I thank you, for myself and for many others, for your recent speech in New-York, which has the ring of the true metal, and is a direct and logical consequence of the policy consistently shaped through the last four years.

GRAU'S TROUPE IN BROOKLYN.--The first appearance of Mr. GRAU'S troupe in Brooklyn was made on Saturday night when the good patrons are at teachers' meeting or singing-school, so a full house was out of the question. "Saffo" was given in admirable style, Mme. GAZZANIGA and Mmc. CASH-POLLINI sharing with ANTONUCCI the continuous favors of the house.

While sitting in the Superintendent's office at Police Headquarters a few evening since, two young men entered, and one of them said to Inspector LEONARD, in a voice tremulous with emotion: "Can you tell us, Sir, if an old lady has been found in the streets to-day, by the Police? "Who was the lady?" said the Inspector.

Record has an account of an adroit transaction: "Two Gipsies, answering to the names of WILLIAM and MARY WALLACE, encamped about seven miles below Drummondtown, succeeded in persuading a Mr. EDWARD WRIGHT, a merchant of the place, that if he would allow them to put any amount of his money in his trunk, the key and trunkboth to be in his (Mr. WRIGHT'S) keeping,

DEADLY ASSAULT BY A WOMAN UPON A MAN AND HIS WIFE.--A deadly and disparate ?? was committed by a woman, on Friday night, in the apartments of PATRICK O'BRIEN, in the rear of No. 422 East Thirteenth-street. It appears that O'BRIEN and his wife were quietly seated in their room, about 10 o'clock, when they were disturbed by the appearance of CATHARINE BURNS, who resided in the neighborhood, armed with a large carving-knife.

The Freeport (Ill.) Journal reports a very large mortgage recorded in the County Court at that place on the 19th ultimo. It was executed by the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Company to SAMUEL J. TILDEN, of the City of New-York, to securethe payment of $2,500,000.

The stocks of Eastorn goods are quite low, and cash orders to replenish were sent yesterday, The shipments of gold, nevertheless, were small, as moat of the trading houses have funds East sufficient for present use,

ROBERT J. TIFFANY, hatter, paid $500 in gold for the first choice of seats on the occasion of the first appearance of EDWIN FORREST. The certificate of the incorporation of the Pacific Rolling Mill Company was field yesterday. The company will run the mill for smelting and manufacturing railroad iron, copper and other metals. Its capital is $1,000,000.

"From sudden death, good Lord deliver us!" Never until now was I impressed with the full significance and import of the above supplication. It had always seemed to me that when the final call came, requesting me to hand in my checks, I should like it to be short and sudden; but the occurrence of Monday last has wrought a complete change in mywishes in that respect.

THE ANNUAL SUNDAY-SCHOOL PARADE.--The thirty-seventh anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday-Schools will take place on Tuesday, the 22nd instant, whether the day be pleasant or stormy; in case of rain the parade will be dispensed with. The schools are to repair to the churches assigned to them--services to commence promptly at 2 o'clock P.M., and continue one hour.

COLLECTOR SMYTHE. The Collector of Customs for New-York is here to-day to file his bonds and make other preparations for entering upon the duties of his office next Monday. INTERNAL REVENUE. The receipts of internal revenue for the week ending to-day are $4,232,376 80.

BALDWIN'S BUSINESS DIRETORY,--Messrs. H. A. BALDWIN CO. have just issued (see advertisement in another column,) a consolidated Business Directory giving the names of firms in New-York, Boston and Philadelphia. Each business is classified by itself, and the names and locations of those engaged in anybranch in the three cities named are given together.

During the week just closed considerable activity has been discernable in the several militia organizations in this City, several drills, inspections, serenades, and parades having taken place, notices which appear below under appropriate headings. We could give several items of gossip in relation to future movements, but omit them, as we cannot trace them to any authentic source, owing to the fact that no official orders have as yet been received.

A NEW-JERSEY CENTENARIAN.--There is now residing in Camden a gentleman named MARTIN BELISLE, who on the 1st of last March was ninety-nine years of age, being now in his one hundredth year. He was born in 1767, nine years before the declaration of Independence.

The last number of the Batavia Spirit of the Times contains an obituary notice of the death of LUCAS SEAVER, Esq., former editor and proprietor of that paper. Mr. SEVER was a man so well known throughout this State and the West, ad was withal a man of so genial and noble nature, as to deserve more than a passing notice.
If, as many suppose, a war will after all break out between Austria and Prussia, it will be characterized by conditions which have not controlled any which have taken place inGermany.

A CHICAGO HEIRESS ELOPES WITH A RAILWAY CONDUCTOR.--The daughter of one of the heavy elevator men of Chicago, while returning from a pleasure trip, some months ago, became acquainted with the conductor of a train on which she was traveling. He was young and of very pleasing address, and the lady was not regardless of his attention.

The steamships Germania and City of Paris arrived at this port yesterday, bringing news to the 3d inst. The Washington correspondent of the Lon don Times gives that paper an interesting account of an interview which he had recently with President JOHNSON. The German question was still unsettled, and in fact more threatening than at any previoustime.

ADAMS.--In Merrisania, on Saturday, May 12, Mrs. SARAH ADAMS, widow of the late Jesse Adams, Sr., aged 73 years. The funeral will take place on Monday at 2 o'clock, from the Methodist Church on Fordham-av. and 6th-st. The relatives and friends are invited to attend. BERTINE.--On Friday, May 11, RODMAN BEETINE, in the 74th year of his age.

WEDDING.--A wedding, noticeable for its elegant display, took place on the 8th, at Newtown, Coun. The parties were ALEX. R. T. NICHOLS, a gentleman well known in this City, and Miss LOTTIE B. BEERS, of Newtown, daughter of the late HENRY BEERS. The ceremony was performed in the oldest Episcopal Church in the State.

From the Congressional Globe. Mr. STEVENS--Mr. Speaker, I rise to conclude the debate, but I will not move the previous question until I finish what I have to say. I am glad, Sir, to see great unanimity among the Union friends in this House on tall the provisions of this joint resolution except the third one.

TRE FUNERAL OF AN ODD FELLOW.--The fune ral of the late Grand Master, JOHN J. DAVIES, of the R.W. G. Lodge of the I. O. of 0. F. of Southern New. York, took place yesterday afternoon from St. Johns Church, corner of Washington and Johnson streets, and was largely attended by members of the Order in New York and Brooklyn, in addition to Stella Lodge of Free Masons to which deceased had also been attached.

The United States, Appellants vs. The Schoaner Reform and claimants of Ship and Cargo,--The facts in this case were stated at length in the TIMES of January last, and they are now sufficiently recapitulated in the opinion of the Court, delivered by Mr. Justice CLIFFORD.

The season wanes steadily to a close. It does not seem possible to revive it. New-Yorkers are bent on leaving the City, and our regular visitors from the country have not yet began to arrive. Under the circumstances, Mr. GRAU has perhaps done as well as could be expected, although the result will be far different to what he deserved.

HOUSE CLEANING. The hall of the House of Representatives, in Sum mer order, will be ready for occupancy to-morrow, but from the number of members out of town thereis some doubt if a quorum be present.

The steamship Germania, from Southampton on the 2d of May, and the City of Paris, from Liver pool on the 2d, and Queenstown on the 3d of May, reached this port yesterday. The news is four dayslater than previous advices.

A fire this morning destroyed four stores in the Emerson Block, Broad-street, occupied for manufacturing purpose. The whole loss is from $25,000 to $30,000. ELMIRA Sunday, May 19. A STREET PREACHER ABRESTED. EDWARD FALCONER, the notorious street-preacher, and EDWARD KILLIP, his assistant, were arrested yesterday morning by Offices McCLOUD and KENNALLY, of the Thirteenth Precinct, on a charge of disturbing the public peace. The prisoners were holding forth to a promiscuous gathering of citizens in East-street, near the East River,

Notwithstanding the fact that the Liquor Dealers' Associations have expressed, during the past week, a determined intention to oppose the new Excise Law and its strict prohibitions tooth and nail, the requirements of the law were very generally observed by the liquor dealers throughout the City yesterday.

THE BRITISH REFORM BILL. -- Lord RUSSELL'S government, it will be seen, have not con cluded either to resign or to go to the country with their Reform Bill. Mr. GLADSTONE, it seems, is not afraid of a working majority offive members.

THE LONDON PRESS ON THE PRESIDENT'S POSITION.--The heat and pressure of the great parliamentary debates in England have caused scarcely a perceptible abatement in the interest and eagerness with which political movements here are watched by al sections of the British Press.

SERMON BY REV. STEPHEN H. TYNG, JR. The anniversary discourse of the Young Men's Christian Association, of the City, was preached by Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG, Jr., Rector of the Church of the Holy Trinity, in the Madison --square Presbyterian Church, last evening, to a large and attentive congregation, He adopted as his text the following:

Great interest still attaches in Irish circles to the movements and actions of their idolized chief, Mr. JAMES STEPHENS. This gentleman's record in Ireland, and his well-known devotion to the cause so dear to Irish hearts, has placed him in a position which gives him the control of all persons and matters pertaining to the Irish Republic.
