We stated on Saturday the manner in which the five amendments reported by the Recon struction Committee were forced through the House in a lump, by a coalition of the ex treme Radicals under Mr. STEVENS, of Penn sylvania, and the extreme Copperheads underMr. HARRIS, of Maryland.

A serious fracas occurred at Hamptor yesterday afternoon, between J. LAKMIER, the Deputy Sheriff, and a merchant doing business in Washington. The latter was stabbed in four different places. The Press of Norfolk are nearly unanimous in condemning the charge made by Judge UNDERWOOD before the Grand Jury, at the opening session of the Court.

MARRIED UNDER PECULIAR CIRCUMSTANCES.--Yesterday afternoon a young man named MONAHAN, of New-York, was married to a young woman named PLUNKET, by Justice AVERY, at the Hoboken Police Station. It appears that the young woman was a servant girl in the employ of a family residing in Bloomfield-street, near Eighth.

We copied, on Thursday last, a summaey of the speech in which Mr. GLADSTONE, the offi cial leader of the House of Commons, closed the debate on the Reform Bill, which had been pending for some weeks in that body. It oc cupied about two hours in the delivery, and was a careful, decorous and most powerful argumentative reply to the speeches that hadbeen made in opposition to the bill.

The editor of the Washington Chronicle de votes himself, with impassioned and unscru pulous zeal, to the work of arousing the pas sions of Congress and the people against those in the Southern States who seek a restorationof peace and order in the Union.

IN SECOND-AVENUE--FOUR PERSONS BURNED. Near 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a back room on the third floor of the tenement house No. 383 Second-avenue, occupied by THOMAS STANTON. The flames originated from the explosion of a kerosene oil lamp, which accidentally upset on a bed. MARY ANN HALEY, aged 14, was terribly burned about the face and body, as she lay asleep. Her injuries are considered fatal in their character.

The following report concerning the opera tions of the Freedmen's Bureau in Virginia and North Carolina has been forwarded to the War Department by Gens. FULLERTON and STEDMAN, who are on a tour of inspection through theSouthern States by order of the Government:

The steamer Del Norte has arrived from Crescent City, with $3,850 in treasure. Also arrived, ship Premier. The local woolen mills are running to the extent of their capacity cotton goods. The product of Oakland Mill, such as heavy brown sheetings, are selling at 25c. LEONARD SONS sperm candles sold to-day as 30c. cash. Market for Refined Sugar weakening.

THE NEW STEAMAR WILLIAM PENN.--The new steamer William Penn, of the London and New-York Steamship Company's Line , was thrown open to pub lic inspection on Saturday. The vessel was built at the Company's yard in Waterford, Ireland, and is 333 feet in length, 40 feet breadth of beam, 27 feet depthof hold, and draws 21 feet when laden.

The Moravian passed Father Point yesterday, with one day later news than brought by the City of Paris. The steamship Helvetia, from Liverpool 2d inst., was sent back from Queenstown, cholera having broken out among her passengers. Only two deaths occurred, but many others were affected. The National Line will take theno more German passengers at present.

The State of Virginia has failed in a good many things during its recent rebellion, but her failure to lose HENRY A. WISE is the most calamitous of her disasters. If she had got rid of him the Old Dominion could havesustained all her other losses.

To the Members of the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States: GENTLEMEN--I feel that if any one, strictly in private life, has a right without presumption to address the loyal representative mean of this nation upon a subject we are all alike interested, that I might venture to do so without offence, and without rendering myself obnoxious to the charge of vanity.

CLARK--On Tuesday morning, May 14, of typhoid fever, SAMUEL G CLARK in the 45th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family, also these of his brother-in-law W. J. Cochran are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late into residence, No. 80 West 12th-inst., on Wednesday next at 2 P. M.

From the Huntsville Independent Mr. CLAY reached home on Sunday morning about 8 A. M. and as soon as it became known, a large number of friends hastened to greet him at the residence of his venerable father; and on yesterday the parlors of the mansion were thronged with gen tlemen from the city and country, who came to greet their respected fellow-citizen and welcome him homoagain.

HORAGE MAYNARD, Senator CRESSWELL, Hon. FRANK THOMAS, Gen. GARFIELD and Hon. JOHN L. THOMAS, Jr., addressed a meeting at Hagerstown, Md., on the issues of the day. Among the resolutions adopted were the following:

We have favored the proposition to consol idate the principal and reduce the interest on the Public Debt, as we doubt not the popular sentiment will favor it as the subject is dis cussed, because we believe this great Govern ment entitled, from its high credit and vast revenues, to place its loans at a cheaper rateof interest in gold than six per cent.

GERMAN EMIGRATION.--The National Steam ship Navigation Company have determined to carry no more German emigrants by their line, Their experience in the case of the Virginia and the England has certainly been exceedingly severe;

CHAPTER 1. There is a very valuable but little-known book entitled the Civil List. It contains the names of all the State and County officers from the establishment of our Colonial Government. In looking it over, as I do very often, it occurred to me that the present citizens of New-York might be interested in knowing who and what manner of men represented the City in theLegislature fifty years ago.

MONITORS FOR THE BRITISH NAVY.--It took the British Board of trade some ten years to arrive at a satisfactory conclusion as to the best method of communicating between the pas sengers in a railway car and the conductoror engineer in charge of the train.

The steamer Golden City, WATKINS, from Panama, has arrived. with New-York dates to April 21. The Western Union Telegraph Company's steamer George S. Wright made a trial trip on Saturday, for the purpose of testing her salling qualities. Sheworked satisfactorily.

But little of interest transpired yesterday yesterday in fenian circles. The rooms of the "Central Organizer of the Irish Republic," Mr. JAMES STEPHENS, continue to attract many visitors, all or whom are eager to welcome to America this representative of Irish freedom.

PETITIONS. Mr. SPRAGUE presented a petition for the exemption of savings bank deposits from taxation, which was referred to the Committee on Finance. THE UNITED STATES COURT IN MISSISSIPPI. Mr. HARRIS, from the Judiciary Committee, reported a bill to change the place of holding the United States District Court of Northern Mississippi to the town of Oxford, which was passed.

On Monday, the 1th inst., the region of Bue nos Ayres was visited by one of the most fearful storms on record, It began about 5 P. M., and in five minutes the whole heavens were obscured by driving clouds of dust, making the day darker than the dark est night ever known. It was quite impossible, indoors or out, to see your hand before your face.

SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS. Before Justice Clerke. A few days since we published the fact that Justice CLERKE, of the Supreme Court, had granted an injunction at the suit of a Society known as the Germania, of the City of Brooklyn vs. The Commissioners of Health, the Police Commissioners, and others.

The Milwaukee Sentinel has the following amiable and rational paragraph: "The NEW-YORK TIMES publishes a long 'report' made to President JOHNSON by BEN. C. The Fenian bubble has substantially burst, but a fresh effort is to be made to inflate it by the old method-a public meeting. The ar rival of the real " Head Centre"--the genuine and only original Jacobs-affords the oppor tune occasion for this necessary ceremony, and a great gathering of the Irish is to beheld to-day at Jones' Wood.

During the night of Aug. 5, 1864, Sergt. FAR RELL, of the Fifth Precinct Police, discovered during his tour of inspection round the ward that the Cro ton pipes in the store No. 373 Broadway,occupied by A. H. ROSENHEIM, had been left open, and that the water was fast flooding the premises. He rapped for assist ance, when Officers RICHARD B. VAN VARICK, ALLEN andCARMAN responded to the call.

The accounts from the Red River are gloomy. Most of the river cotton lands are under water. FLOUR, Superfine, $10 26. CORN, ?? dearer, PORK YORK SIGHT EXCHANGE, 1/4c. premium. The Cotton reports from all the southwest are gloomy. Tornados have made fearful havee with all the crops.

The steamhip Moravian, from Liverpool 8d, via Londonderry 4th inst., has passed this point, route to Quebec. Her advices are one day later than per steamship City of Paris. Steamship Belgam, from Scotland, arrived out of the 4th.

To the Editors of the Montgomery Mail: GENTLEMEN: I observe in your issue this morning an article abstracted from some paper (not designated) in which it is stated that Commodore MAURY, in a letter to the London Morning Herald, estimates Southern losses during the war at the extraordinary total of seven billions of dollars.

It is understood as the result of Secretary McCULLOCH'S visit, that President JOHNSON has directed the surgeon of the post to make in special report of the health of JEFFERSON DAVIS, as it is confidently said that during the past twelve months the unceasing tramping and changing of the guards around his cell has prevented him from enjoying at any one time more than two hours' unbroken sleep;

Gen. HOWARD, as the Head of the Freed men's Bureau, has shown himself an officer of great ability, and thoroughly enlisted in the work which his Bureau was created to perform. He is naturally sensitive to attacks upon its honor and usefulness, but, in his zeal to defend them, it seems to us he goes agood deal further than prudence will sanction.

THE DIVISION ON THE BRITISH REFORM BILL.- The division on the Reform Bill which left Mr. GLADSTONE with a majority of only five, shows how much more tightly the Tory leaders hold the reins of discipline than their Lieral opponents. Only one member deserted from the Tory ranks to vote with the MinisterialParty in favor of reform;

I have it from high authority that JEFF DAVIS will be tried in Richmond in June, upon the indictment recently found by the grand jury at Norfolk, providing Chief-Justice CHASE will consent to preside in the Circuit Court there to be convened.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--"Un Ballo in Maschera" was given here last evening in an exceedingly agreeable manner. The opera require many artists, and it is necessary that they be all good in their separate roles. We have barely become acquainted with Mr. GRAU's company. but its even quality was certainly demonstrated in the representation of this work.

The Tribune announced on Saturday that the habeas corpus bill recently passed by Con gress, intended to prevent Union officers and soldiers from being prosecuted by rebels for arrests or acts done in suppression of the re bellion, would "probably be vetoed about the middle of the week, on the grounds that it is too sweeping in its character, and exemptstoo many persons."

Immediately on the adjournment of the United States Circuit Court in Norfolk, on last Thursday afternoon, Judge UNDERWOOD left for Washington, D. C., and gave particular instructions to the Clerk of the Court to exhibit to no person or persons the indictment brought against JEFFERSON DAVIS.

The following reports has been made to the Chilian Government in reference to the bombardment of Valparaise: INTENDENCIA, VALPARAISE, April 1, 1866. M. SECRETARY: By various telegraphic dispatches, I have had the honor to communicate to your Excellency a knowledge of only the most notable circumstances of the bombardment of this city, committed by the Spanish forces on the 31st of the month just passed.

After the reading of the minutes at the meeting of the Board, yesterday, Attorney BLISS reported that the number of orders for the abatement of nuisances had reached 10,300, and that the code of ordinances, having now been published two weeks has taken effect.

VETO OF THE COLORADO BILL. The "President' acting Private Secretary, Col. COOPER, delivered to the Senate to-day a message in writing, containing the objections of the President to the bill for the admission of Colorado into the Union as a State. This announcement created some little surprise, as an unauthenticated rumor just previously prevailed that the bill had been approved.

THE EDITOR OF THE TRIBUNE IN THE "Lon. BY." The Tribune says; "Once more, we ask the TIMES to justify its charge against Mr. JOHN L. PARKER and a majority of his associated on the Assembly Railroad Committee? Will it do so?"

HOYT--EVANS,--At Strong-place Church, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, May 15, by Rev. C. Evans, assisted by Rev. Edward Lathrop, D. D., of Stamford, Conn, G. H. HOYT, Esq., of Stamford, Conn., and Miss S. S. EVANS, of Brooklyn, daughter of the officiating clergyman. No cards.

A billiard match for the championship of Pennsylvania, between VICTOR ESTEPHE and ROBERT S. RYALL, took place at Philadelphia, on Monday evening, in the presence of a large audience. The match created considerable excitement in this City, where the contestants are well known as two of the most expert players in the country.

We are delighted with Congress. It is getting alive to the proprieties and amenities of debate. It is becoming fastidious And sensitive to imputations upon official purity and integrity. Mr. CHANLER, of New-York, offered a resolution of Monday indorsing the efforts of the President to protect by his veto, the rights of the people ":against the wicked and revolutionary acts of a few malignant and mischievous men."

It ought to be understood that there are two Campaign Clubs in Washington devoted to the support of the President and his policy; and although they both profess support of the same general principles, their Objects andmodes of action are by no means the same.

Yesterday a purse and stake of $300, mile bests, best three in five, in harness, was trotted for on the Union Course, L. I. The day was unfavorable for a good rice, there being a high wind blowing during the afternoon, which materially interfered with the action of the horses trotting, and by raising clouds of dust, obstructed the view of the race at occasional intervals.

For two or three days past there might have been seen flitting out and in through the corridors of the New-York Hotel, a dapper little gentleman, in whose finely cut, thoughtful and somewhat and face, the scrutinizing observer. Perchance, might "read the construction" of no ordinary man, but whose unimposing presence would be little likely to mark him out as a cynosure of public gaze.

A ROUNDABOUT WAY.--The Hibernian Head Centre STEPHENS failed to explain one point in connection with current Irish movements. Among the passengers from Liverpool to this country during the past month of April, there are officially reported to have been 9,277 Irish.

Gens. STEEDMAN and FULLERTON, pursuing their duty of inspecting the operations of the Freedmen's Bureau in the South, reached this place yesterday, having finished their investigations of North Carolina and Virginia and forwarded their report from Wilmington. As it will probably be published very soon, it is not necessary to refer to it at this time.

At the February Term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, ZENO BURNHAM was put on trial on a charge of having defrauded a lady of the sum of the $1,030 by misrepresentations as to a quantity of furniture alleged to have been purchased by her at one of BURNHAM'S mock actions.

DIED IN A CELL.--Officer MOONEY, of the Fifth Precinct, arrested CATHARINE SOUTHERLAND on Monday evening, on a charge of having stolen a silver watch valued at $21, from her employer, CHARLES C. RONALD, residing at No. 2 Desbrosses-street. The prisoner was locked up in a cell in the Leonard-street Station-house, and at 4 o'clock yesterday morning Doorman FEERIS found her in a dying condition.

Mr. HENRY A. SMYTHE our new Collector, returned to the City last evening, and notified Mr. FINCH of his wish to meet the Deputies this morning at 9 o'clock in the Collector's room at the Custom house. At that hour he will swear in the Deputies, and make a brief address of instruction and suggestion.

MONTANA. The Chair laid before the Senate the memorial of the Legislature of Montana for the establishment of a branch mint in that Territory. Which was referred to the Committee on Finance. Also a memorial from the same source, asking for an extension of the southern boundary of that Territory. This was referred to the Committee on Territories.

A fire, attended with shocking loss of life and a heavy loss of properly, occurred at North Royalton, Vt., last night, upon the premises of Mr. LYMAN BURBANK. The house was occupied by Mr. BURBANK, a hired man named BALLOW, an adopted daughter of Mr. BURBANK, and Miss DICKERMAN, of Trowbridge, who was temporarily staying there.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. MORGAN presented the project of the New-York Chamber of Commerce against the proposed tax on cotton. Mr. FESSENDEN gave notice that he would, on Monday next, call up the reconstruction resolution from the House, and press them to a vote as early us possible. Mr. VAN WISKLE introduced a joint resolution to suspend temporarily the collection of the direct tax in West Virginia.

It was announced in the herald and other papers yesterday morning that Collector SMYTHE would not enter upon his duties at the Custom-house for several days to come. The TIMES stated that he would do so at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. He did so, of course, and his presence there created alively stir among the merchants and clerks.

At the meeting of the Board of Police Com missioners, yesterday morning, Treasurer BERGEN was directed to make estimate, as required by the act of April 25, for the support of a police body in Richmond County.

A letter from CHARLES HAMILTON, dated williams Fork, Arizona, April 30, seems to confirm the massacre at Fort Goodwin. He says that the massacre occurred ten days previous, and that of two companies of regulars, Third Battalion, Fourteenth Regiment, consisting of 100 men, only seven escaped.

About 8 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the large building situated on the block bounded by Columbia, Sedgwick, Van Brunt and Irving streets, and occupied by BLANCHARD Co. as a cotton packing establishment.
We published on Monday morning a letter from JOHN M. BOTTS, on the best mode of re storing the States and people lately in rebel lion to their proper relations to the Federal Government.

FIRE IN GREENWICH-STREET.--Shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire was discovered in the building Nos. 363 and 365 Greenwich-street, occupied as the Empire box factory by JAS. MOORE. The flames originated from some shavings taking fire from the furnaces in the engine-room.

ARGALL.--On Wednesday morning, Mrs. HANNAH ARGALL., relict of the late Wm. Argall, in the 79th year of her age. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at her late residence, No. 59 St Mark's-place, at 2 o'clock P. M. Saturday.

The steamship Java reached this port yester day, with two days later advices from Europe. The outbreak of cholera among the German emigrants on board the Liverpool steamers was attracting much at tention in that city, and precautionary measures hadbeen taken against the spread of the disease.

THE VETO MESSAGE. After the reading of the journal, the Chair laid be fore the Senate the Veto Message of the President on the Colorado Bill, which was read by the Chief Clerk. At the conclusion of the reading Mr. FOSTER (in the chair) said the question is upon the reconsideration of the bill. Shall the bill pass, the objections of thePresident notwithstanding?

VETO OF THE COLORADO BILL BY PRESIDENT JOHN SON. The following is the President's veto message of the Colorado Bill: To the Senate of the United States: I return to the Senate, in which House it originated, the bill which has passed both Houses of Congress entitled "An Act for the admission of the State of Colorado into the Union," with my objections to its becoming a law at this time.

Collector SMYTHE entered upon the duties of his office at the Custom-house yesterday morning. He was welcomed in some very appropriate remarks by the acting Collector, Mr. CLINCH, and responded in simple but fitand proper terms.

The newspapers are raising a great hue and cry over Mr. STANTON'S declaration, made in Cabinet meeting, that he is opposed to the Congressional Committee's plan of reconstruc tion and in favor of the general principles heldon this subject by the President.

YALE COLLEGE.--The Faculty have determined to have presentation exercises Wednesday, June 27. They would have set the day one week later but for the fact that the 4th of July comes on that day. Next year presentation is to be the first Wednesday in July. The wooden spoon exhibition will take place June 26. The Beatheven Society will give concerts in New-York and Brooklyn on the 23d and 30th of this month.

SUICIDE BY AN UNKNOWN MAN.--An inquest was held yesterday morning by Coroner WILDEY, at the New-York Hospital, on the remains of an unknown man, apparently about 24 years of age. It appeared from the evidence in tho case that the deceased went Into the restaurant kept by GEO. SCHMIDT, at No. 133 Reade-street, on Saturday, being very much intoxicated.

NEGRO RIOT IN NORTH CAROLINA.--The Salisbury Old North State, of a late date, says: "We learn that a rice took place at Morganton, a few days ago, which resulted in the United States regular troops stationed there driving some returned negro soldiers from the town.

The Charleston Courier, of May 5, contains a very interesting collection of intelligence concerning the growing crops in different Southern States. In these extracts we find accounts, in most respects highly gratifying, of the conduct of the freedmen, and a hopeful statement of the labor question.

A PHILANTHROPIST--WENDELL PHILLIPS has an income of $60,000 a year. He sits under polished mahogany, eats off beautiful china and solid silver, and buries his slippers in the soft pile of velvet carpets fit for the parlor of a prince. He has never been known to deny himself for purposes of charity.

In a brief comment upon a casual remark of mine the Times implies that I am willing to leave a portion of the people unrepresented--for the make of power. Without the least controversy with you, with the President, or with any loyal or patriotic person, I bag leave to say that it is high time, if we wish to preserve the integrity of our country that we understood one another.

The Royal Mail Steamship Java, Capt. Moodte, which left Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 5th, and Queenelown on the afternoon of the 6th of May, arrived here yesterday morning. The Belyian arrived Londonderry on the 4th, at c A. M., and reached Liverpool early on the 5th inst.

At the opening of the session Tuesday afternoon, Mr. MANIERRE asked that counselor TRACY be instructed to report upon the propriety of permitting the transfer of licenses. Mr. ACTON reported favorably upon five hundred applications for license, and the Board ordered that the Licenses be granted.

Senator GWYNN has arrived. He was released on parole without other conditions. He refused to take the oath or to leave the country. He is visiting his friends to-day. The trial of GRUBER'S murderer is progressing. There is a great crowd and much excitement.

Advices received at the Military Headquarters from Arizona state that the recent murder of HUAFA YUMA, Chief of the Hualapi tribe, by a party of whites in revenge for a murder committed by vagrant Indians, is the cause of the taking up of arms by the Huolape tribe against the whites in Colorado Valley.

"La Juive" is an exhaustive opera in more senses than one. It consumed the best inventive powers of the composer, and by its extreme length taxes the patience of an audio co. Few works, however, are so thoroughly filled out. The greatest care has been bestowed on the partition. The orchestra is treated with consummate ability.

The President's reasons for declining to sign the bill admitting Colorado as a State, are cogent and entitled to weight. Under a different aspect of public affairs, they would probably command universal assent.

Yesterday morning, just as the TIMES was ready for press, our steam engine gave out, and we were unable to print the last side of the paper. Our neighbors of the Tribune very generously gave us the use of one of their presses, and we managed, at a very late hour, to present the TIMES to its readers.

Considerable activity has been discernible in the Twenty-second and neighboring Precincts of the Metropolitan Police since the daring robbery in Forty-third-street, on Saturday last, when Mr. JOHN H. HIGGINS, a cashier, was knocked down and robbed of $16,480 in United States Treasury notes and fractional currency, as reported in the Sunday edition of the TIMES.

It is authoritatively understood here, as the result of Secretary McCULLOCH'S late visit, that President JOHNSON has directed the Surgeon of the post to make a special report on the health of JEFFERSON DAVIS, and it is confidently said that during the past twelve months, from the increasing tramping and changing of the guards around his cell, be has been prevented from enjoying more than two hours of unbroken sleep at a time.
The steamer Herces, from Havana on the 12th, is at quarantine. Gen. DULIE had returned from the Isle of Pines, and was preparing to leave via New-York. His successor had already left Spain.

Gun cotton is now made into ropes for storage, and kept under water. When an order is received at the manufactory, a few hours suffices to send the cotton on its way. It has been found that by making the ropes, with many air channels through the mass, the cotton explodes almost instantaneously, and is as violent in action as the strongest fulminates.

In the Soldiers' and Sailors' Convention to-day, several resolutions of a political character were presented, causing a political debate, which was ended by their being referred to the Committee on Resolutions. Gen. PLAISTED, for the Committee, reported a draft of a constitution.

Yesterday the officers of the United States steamers Miantonomo and Augusta dined with Admiral HOPE on the flagsip Duncan. In the evening the American residents met them at Judge JACKSON'S residence, where a happy greeting and splendid dinner was given them.

World. Mr. TERWILLIGER accepted the place of Secretary from Collector KING at the pressing request of numerous friends.

COMMUNICATION FROM LIEUT.-GEN. GRANT. The President sent a message to the House to-day inclosing the following communication from Lieut.-Gen. GRANT: HEADQUARTERS ARMIES OF THE UNITED STATES, WASHINGTON, D. C., May 16, 1866. Hon. E. M. Stanton Secretary of War SIR: In view of the long delay in the lower House of Congress in agreeing upon a plan for the reorganization of the army.

ADVERTISING LETTERS.--There is a section in the Post-office Appropriation Bill which provides that "hereafter all Government advertising in Washington shall be given to the two daily papers having the largest paid circulation, and to no others; that circulation to be determined on the 10th of June annually, and on the bona fide circulation of the regular issue of the paper for the three preceding months."

LECTURE ON DENTISTRY.-LASt evening, Dr. ELEAZAR PARMLY, Emiritus Professor of the Inoti tutes of Dentistry, delivered a lecture on that science at the hall of the New-York Historical society. By a prospectus handed round prior to the giving ot the lecture, the public is informed of the institution of a New-York College of Dentistry, upon which the Legislature conferred a charter in the session of 1865,

Mr. JAMES STEPHENS, the C. 0.1.R., and head of the Irish revolutionary spirit, continues, in a very quiet, unostentatious manner, his labors to effect a union of the opposing elements of the Fenian Broth erhood. He is engaged most of the time in consulta tions with prominent men in the organization, using every argument in his power to conciliate those whoare opposed to him.

TRIAL OF NEW-YORK ROWDIES FOR RIOT.--In the Hudson County Court, yesterday, was commenced the trial of MICHAEL CUNNINGHAM, HUGH MCGOWAN, PATRICK GENETTY, GARRET BALDWIN, JOHN PETERS, and JAMES STACK, of the First Ward, New-York, indicted for riot and assault and battery on citizens, near Greenville, on Sunday afternoon, the 29th of April.

UNIFORM WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.--The report in another column of the proceedings of the Chamber of Commerce of this City, presents statements of interest in respect to the prospect, sooner or later, of extending the "Metric System" throughout the civilized nations of the earth.

Our readers are aware that there is a bill before Congress for the amelioration of the condition of steerage passengers by emigrant vessels, The question has arisen in this shape mainly by reason of the presence and the alarming progress of epidemic disease on board one or two overloaded passenger steamships.

The anxiety which has prevailed throughout Mexico, especially at the capital, over the probable fate of the secamship Vera Cruz, was relieved on the 27th inst., by a telegram forwarded from the port of Vera Cruz, on the arrival of the Spanish mail steamer Barcelona, announcing the loss of the Vera Cruz offthe coast of North Carolina.

BROWN--MCCLENAILAN,--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, May 17, at the residence of the bride's mother, by Rev. N.E. Smith, DE WITT CLINTON BROWN and LIZZIE, eldest daughter of the late John McClenahan. No cards, CLEAVLAND--MCINTOSH.--On Tuesday, May 15, by Rev. Francis Vinton, D. D., TREADWELL CLEAVLAND and EVELYN S., daughter of the late James Mc. McIntosh, Flag-Officer U.S. Navy.

A GREAT WESTERN IDEA.--A novel and gigantic idea is generating itself in the Western head--whether practicable or not, remains to be seen. It is to attempt to render the vast Trans-Missouri Plains fit for the settlement and residence of man by planting their surface with trees.

At about 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon, a fire was discovered in the brewery of BETZ CO., NO. 349 West Forty-fourth-street, which, originating from frictions of the elevator or screw, caused a loss to the stock of $6,000, and to the building of $2,600. Insured as follows on stock: Central Park, Globe, Hoffman,Jefferson, Kings County, Baltic, for $2,500 cash;

In tho Scnate, yesterday, Mr. WADE submit ted an amendment ou reconstruction. The bill to prohibit the carriage, shipping, or transportation of nitro-glycerine on passenger vessels or railroads was passed. The resolution to appoint examiners to ex amine the site for a fresh-water basin for the iron.clad navy, at Portland, Me., was passed,

OUR OVERCROWDED CITY-COMMUTATIONS ON RAIROADS.-During the recent house panic in this City, and, still more recently, since the closing of multitudes of liquor-shops has opened up, in some respect, the question of Sunday oc cupations and amusements, the availability of the various lines of railway for preventing a recurrence of the one and for providing a par. tial solution of the other, has been more andmore apparent.

The Soldiers' Convention in this city is pre sided over by Gen. J. P. CILLEY, and is very fully at-. tended. Among the resolutions adopted was one declaring that the soldiers of Maine watch with solicitude the National Legislature upon all questions bearing onpromotions.

MARYLAND POLITICIANS.--The editor of the Washington Chronicle, speaking of politics and public men in Maryland, says: "Mr. WEBSTER, Collector of the port of Baltimore, who was an active unionist in 1864, is now for JOHNSON, and his example has been followed by a number of other office-holders.

ATTEMPTED BURGLARY. -A grocer named ANSTETT, doing business at tile corner of Morrill and Debcvolso streets, E. D,, heard some one boring through the front door of his store about 11 o'clock on Wednesday night, and on peeping out discovered two men industriously at work in cutting out the panels. ANSTETLT, being deficient in pluck, shouted l,)r help instead of helping himself, and the burglars,becoming alarmed, fled.

FLOUR-Extra State, $9 50; Westorn and Can ada White. $12@$14. WHEAT inactive and nominal at about $1 80 for No. 1 Milwaukies Spring. CORN dull, at 64c. for No. 1. OATS dull. BARLEY, $1 for Canada. RYE, 80c. WHISKY nominal. PORK-Sales at $31 50. LARD, 221/2C. CANAL FBEIGHTS--TO New York, Wheat 13c., Corn 11c., and Oats 7c.; to Albany,What 101/2c., Corn 81/2c., and Oats 51/2c.;

The New Almaden Quicksilvor Mining Com pany has ceased to bo a dealer, and will now attend exclusively to the production of quicksilver. The product of the rnine--50,00 flasks per aunuu--has been sold to BARRON Co. SAN FRANCISCO. Wednesday, May 16.

The day was observed as a day of fasting and prayer, by proclamation of the Mayor, in accordance with the previously published accounts, that the President had ordered the day to be so observed on account of the near approach of cholera. Late in the afternoon it was discovered that no fast day had been thus designated by the President.

NEW-HAMPSHIRE.--The annual session of the New-Hampshire Legislature will convene in Concord on the 6th day of June. The term will be held in the enlarged and remodeled Capital Building, which is now nearly completed.

SECRETARY SEWARD.-The Auburn Advertiser of Wednewsday has the followign paragraph: "Secretary SEWARD arrived last evening to elecbrate the auniversary of is birthday with his family. He is 65 years of age to-day. He is accompanied only by his Secretary, messenger and servant. His health appears to be well established, and he is as confident of an ausnicious future for our country.

ALLEN.--The remains of Mrs. ETHAN A. ALLEN, having arrived from Europe, the funeral will take place from the residence of her father, Dr. Samuel S. Kuypers, No. 142 2d-av , on Sunday next., May 20, at 2 o'clock. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral without further notice. ARGALL.--On Wednesday morning, Mrs. HANNAH ARGALL., relict of the late Wm. Argall, in the 79th year of her age.

The Common Council has got up another "job" which naturally excites a great deal of comment and indignation, It is to widen Fifth-avenue by taking away the stops and stoops in front of the dwellings and carry ing the sidewalks close up to their walls. Nobody seems to have asked for it and everybody protests against it, yet this makes, apparently, not theslightest difference to our City legislators.

It begins to look a little as if Mr. STEVENS, and those in Congress to whom his will is law, did not intend to make any provision whatever for the restoration of the States lately in rebellion to their former relations with the Government.

The Mechanics' and Agrioultural Fair for the Mississippi Valley opens Nov. 20. Exhibitors are solicited from the whole country. A large amount of money has been raised, and the grounds are to be handsomely adorned. Louisianians propose to bring back Ex-Gov. ALLEN'S remains from Mexico.

Europe echoes with the preparations for war from one end to the other. Prussia has put six corps d'armbe on a ware footing; she is buying horses, making ammunition, and transporting artillery by every train toward the southeast.

The Union Convention met this morning, Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS in the Chair, when Mr. HILL offered the following: Resolved, That accepting as the settled policy of this Convention, the resolutions and reports agreed upon, we organize ourselves into a permanent political organization, to be known as the Union Republican Party of Virginia.

FLOUR dull and declined 15c.@25c.; buyers and sellers widely apart in views. WHEAT very unsettled, opening at $1 56, declined to $1 12 1/2, rallied to $1 51 1/2 and closed irregular at $1 53 1/2; sales of No. 2 at $1@$1 05. CORN declined 1c, closing moderately active at 49 1/2c.@50c. for No. 1, and 47c.@47 1/2 c. for No. 2. OATS quiet at 30 1/2c.@31 1/2c.

In the Senate, yesterday, several petitions were offered; among others, one for the trial of JEFFERSON DAVIS by a court-martial. A bill was reported back from the Military Committee to provide for the publication of the official history of the war.

ALLEN.--The remains of Mrs. ETRAN A. ALLEN, having arrived from Europe, the funeral will take place from the residence of her father, Dr. Samuel S. Kaypers, No. 142 2d-av., on Sunday next, May 20, at 2 o'clock. the friend of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral without further notice. AROALL.--On Wednesday morning, Mrs. HANNAH ARGALL, relict of the late Wm. Argall, in the 79th year of her age.

In steamship Manhattan front Vera Cruz, Sisal and Harana --Geo. Drew, Jas. Dinnen, A. Hope, R. Aumada, J. A. Didter, wife and son, A. M. Peet, Mrs. C. Chate and child, Jase Pastor. A. Fibian, Mr. Dutmar, Mrs. Erchier and 3 children, Thos, Hand. S. Levick, M. D. Lane and lady, Mrs. W. H. Stevens, 3 children and maid, Mr. and Mrs. Manual Donde. S. Ireland, Henry Ostermoor.

In steamship Tybee, for Savannah--Mr. T. W. Vaughn and son, Mr. Quinn, Mr. a. Pitcher, Mr. McDaniel, Mr. Brady, Mr. H. Taylor and servant, Mr. Haines, Mr. Boswick, Mr. J. P. Watson, Mr. Baum, Mr. H. T. Nelson, Mr. Jas, Nelson, Mr. M. D. Logan, Mrs. M. G. Ross, Miss Mary Williams, Miss Ellen Sullivan, Mr. J. Sullivan, Mr. M Gready, and 6 in steerage.

The steamer Kalorama, from Charleston for Baltimore, put in here, to-day, under stress of weather. She reports stormy weather outside. It rained hard here yesterday, and the storm continued to-day from the north.

It is reported that at about 10 o'clock this morning, while a construction train, with a number of hands on board, was passing over the railroad bridge at Clarksville, Tenn., one hundred feet high, one of the spans gave way, precipitating the cars into the water. Several lives it is said, were lost.

BURCHARD--HAFF.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, May 17, at the residence of the bride's mother, by Rev. Morgan Dix, D. D., L. J. GREGG BURCHARD, M. D., of New-York, and Miss CARRIE V. HAFF, daughter of the late Jacob Haff, of Newark, N. J. No cards. CATLIN--BRADFORD.--On Wednesday, May 16, by Right Rev. Horatio Potter. D. D., LL.D., Bishop of New-York, WILLIAM H. CATLIN and MARIAN GRAY, only daughter of Alexander W. Bradford. No cards.

Gens. STEADMAN and FULLERTON arrived hero last night. They left Charleston on Sunday last, and have investigated the working of the Freedmen's Bu reau in the Sea Islands. Among the evils that have come to light is the persistent system of overcharge for food and necessaries of life, indulged in by manypersons working the plantations.

The Evening News publishes the following order: HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF ALABAMA, May 17, 1866. In compliance with Instructions from the President of the United States, it is hereby directed that RAPHAEL SEMMES be not permitted to hold or exercise the function of Judge of the Probate Court of Mobile County, or any other civil or political office of trust while he remains unpardoned by the President.

SOLDIERS APPOINTED TO OFFICE. The nominations sent in to-day to the Senate for confirmation go to show the President's determin ation to appoint to office men who served with dis tinctionin the field. Among the nominations were Gen. WM. H. McCARTNEY, as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of Massachusetts.

INTERESTING LETTER FROM A REPUBLICAN JUDGE. Judge H. L. COMSTOCK, of Wyoming County, New-York, who has been a prominent and influential Republican, has published a letter on the political condition of the country. He says the question to be decided is, whether the Union is saved or destroyed.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.---MEYERBEER'S opera of L'Africane" was given last evening with a cast entirely new. It comes to us with a suddenness which courts comparison--and the comparison is not, we think , favorable to Mr. GRAU. Of all the artists who did their beat last evening there was only one who came up to the pleasurable experience of the public --Mmo. GAZZANIGA.

The points urged by Gen. GRANT, in his letter of suggestions to Congress concerning the reorganization of our standing army, are of so obvious a character that they have been put forth again and again by the Press of the country.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Somebody is evidently imposing upon your Staten Island reporter, and making him responsible for frequent statements, which are in some cases wholly false, and in others exaggerated and distorted.

The Ogdensburgh Journal of May 17, says: "The remains of Mr. KING, in charge of PRESTON K. WEBSTER and MARTIN THATCHER, arrived here Wednesday noon, by way of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburgh Railroad. They were met at the depot by a large number of citizens, and conveyed to the late residence of the deceased.

The cattle market opened with unusual activity this week and at prices at least 1/2c. ?? live weight higher than last week, but the supply, 5,900 head, including several hundred stores, proved larger than was expected, to-day holders pressed for sales, and most of the transactions after 10 o' clock were at prices $5@6 head lower than were realized on Tuesday and Wednesday.

After a short stay in Columbia, Gen. STEEDMAN and Gen FULLERTON started for Charleston, arriving here on the 10th inst. Subsequent to my letter from Columbia, it was discovered that brevet Brig-Gen ELY, the Bureau Superintendent for that district of the State, is engaged in the cultivation of five plantation, about which there is considerable doubt, and it is suspected that if they prove profitable the Government will not hear from them.

UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT. Isaac Hogden vs. The Suffolk Manufacturing Company.--On the 11th day of December, 1854, the plaintiff applied to the Commissioner of Patents for a patent for a new and useful improvement made by him in cotton-cleaning.

The following narrative of the late voyage of the steamship England, and the breaking out of the cholera on board, prepared by Rev. AMBROSE MARTIN, may prove of interest at the present time: I was a saloon passenger on board the unfortunate steamship England, which sailed from Liverpool onthe 28th day of March.

DUTY ON FOREIGN WOOL. Mr. POLAND presented a petition for increased duty on foreign wool, which was referred to the Finance Committee. THE TAXATION OF DEPOSITS IN SAVINGS BANKS. Mr. WADE presented a petition for the exemption of Savings Banks' deposits from the Revenue tax,which was referred to the Finance Committee.
COINCIDENCES.--Our Congress is not the only legislative body that ejects members upon an examination of their credentials. The BrItish House of Commons has done quite a

The Red River and the neighboring waters are rising with great floods. There is a crevasse at Gilmore's, above Shreveport, and others are expected. There is untold suffering in the flooded districts, and it is feared the rise of the Red River will increase the deluge, seriously increase the suffering, and rain the crops.

COLUMBIA COLLEGE--A RANDALL'S ISLAND GRADUATE.--Long years ago a bright orphan boy named WM. WASHINGTON SMITH, on Randall's Island, attracted the attention of the Governors, who finding him intelligent and faithful interested themselves in his behalf.

No article has ever appeared in any American paper which has been so thoroughly published and discussed by the Press and people of Mexico as the one recently published in the TIMES. Although we must confess that though no newspaper published in Spanish in the country has as yet made any com ments upon the article 'in any way pleasing to impe rialism, it has exerted a most damaging influence on republicanism.

The Washington correspondent of the Cincin nati Gazette, makes tile following statement, upon his own responsibility, no doubt: It is known that SANTA ANNA came to this country through the influence of Secretary SEWARD. SANTA ANNA was expected last week, Friday, at which time, it will be remembered, it was telegraphed over thecountry that Mr. SEWARD had gone to Auburn;

I don't mean my self to help them to that result. I don't mean to sayanything about it, except this: In my opinion,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you permit one who has never attempted to intrude upon your columns to address you upon a subject which should interest every American? I have frequently noticed articles in the various City papers about this country getting up and sustainingan American line of steamers to a foreign port.

Mails for Europe, (except France) via Queenstown and Liverpool, per steamship City of Paris, close to-day at 10:30 A. M.; mails for France, Italy and Switzerland, per steamship Napoleon III. at 8 A. M.; for Hamburg, per steamship Germania, at 10:30 A. M.

Having noticed in your issue of Saturday, 5th inst. the death of WM. HUTCHINGS, the last Revolutionary soldier of the State of Maine, and as that notice states, the last but three in the United States, I was prompted to write you the following:

In the Old-School Assembly to-day, Dr. McLEAN offered a resolution that until the Assembly shall have examined and decided upon the conduct of the Louisville Presbyterian Commissioners, the Reform shall be excluded from the Assembly; which, under considerable discussion, passed by a vote of 201 yeas 50 nays.

The Episcopal Council to-day adopted to following: Whereas, The conditions which rendered necessary the separate organization of Southern diseases no longer exists, and that organization has ceased by the consent and action of the dioceses concerned;

A dispatch yesterday states that an extensive coal mine had been discovered at Sooke, near Victoria, V. I. At Fort Whipple, on the 198th, the Moqui Indian warriers arrived and surrendered their arms. General markets continue dull. The new crops of grain, wool and wine, of a fine quality, are coming to market in great abundance.

The General Assembly of the Old School Presbyterians met in Dr. NICHOAL'S Church, on the corner of Fifth and Walnut streets, this morning. Dr. LOWRY, of New-York, preached the opening sermon. Three candidates, representing different parties, were nominated for Moderator, with the following result: R. L. STANTON, 158; P. D. GURLEY, 75, and S. R. WILSON, 18, Number of Commissioners present, 259.

Before Judgo Cardozo. Yesterday morning, Mr. James M. Sheehan, counsel for Denis G. Ferguson, charged with the lar. ceny of a bond for $5,000 belonging to Mr. Rufus R. Lord, had his client brought before Judge Cardozo ona writ of certiorari.

AMERICAN EXILES.--The arrival, in Europe, of WIGFALL, of Texas, and TOOMBS, of Georgia, is reported. The whereabouts of WIGFALL, since the fall of the Confederacy, has been a great mystery; but it would seem that he has been all the while in the Lone Star State.

ALLEN.--The remains of Mrs. ETHAN A. ALLEN, having arrived from Europe, the funeral will take place from the residence of her father, Dr. Samuel S. Kuypers, No. 142 2d-av, on Sunday next, May 20, at 2 o'clock. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral without further notice. BABCOCK.--In Brooklyn, at her late residence, No. 75 3d-placed, on Friday, May 18, Mrs. ANN BABCOCK, relict of Dadley Babcock, aged 86 years.

Generals STEEDMAN and FULLERTON had an interview with the African Methodist Episcopal Conference to-day. The information elicited was of a satisfactory character. There was a general concurrence in the opinion that the relations between the two races are friendly and rapidly improving in the States of Georgia, Florida, North Carolina and South Carolina.

As was predicted in the TIMES some weeks since, the present month promises to be one of the busiest and most important of all the preceding months of the year. Already the bugle-note of prepa ration has been sounded, and the incoming week will witness three regimental parades, the long-talked-of inauguration of Col. VOSBURGH'S monument, and ageneral field day of the Fourth Brigade.

Is the Augsburg Gazette safe authority for the future of diplomacy? The editor has been favored with a glimpse at portions of the eighth volume of GERVINUS' "Nineteenth Century," and so he is able to give us a sketch of Prince POLIGNAC'S proposed partition of Europe in 1828. It is a yet wilder scheme than that put forth in LAMARTINE'S name in 1848.

Coroner O' REILLY held an inquest, yesterday, at a house on Jefferson-street, on the body of a young married woman named EMELINE STRAUB, who had been married but five months, and had left her husband on account of his brutal treatment of her. Being poor and friendless, she resolved to destroy the babe in her womb, and in doing so produced her own death.

THE "BUTCHER-CART" ROBBERY.--The examination in the case of REINHART H. T. LIST, the young butcher arrested on suspicion of being one of the gang who assaulted and robbed Mr. JOHN H. HIGGINS of $10,480, in Forty-third-street, on the 11th inst., was hold yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY at the Yorkville Police Court.

A FRIENDLESS RACE.--We do not suppose there is any likelihood of getting a Congressional Committee to investigate the butchery of sixteen friendly Indians, fourteen of them women and children--a report of which has been forwarded to the authorities by the Governor of Idaho.

PATRIOTISM ON STILTS.--It is amusing to see with what Johnsonian grandiloquence the Radical and Copperhead papers announce the very few, and in most instances quite unimportant, changes recently made of office-holders under the Government.

The Cooperstown Freeman's Journal makes, in reference to Gen. PILLSBURY and the Albany Penitentiary, a text for the following story: Last Friday, after reading the above extract in the Argus of that day, we met Gen. PILLSBURY, in company with Judge A. J. PARKER, of Albany, in our streets, they having business before Judge NELSON at chambers.

Hon, JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, is writing letters concerning Southern rights and the re cent war. Nine persons out of ton will be surprised to hear that he is still living, and the other one will not consider it of the slightest consequence whether he is or not, Mr.

Hon. CAVE JOHNSON, as has already boon stated, was recently elected to the Tennessee Legisla ture, but the Senate refused to admit him to a seat. In a letter to the people of his Senatorial District, aftera defence of himself personally, he says:

UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT. Oromel Hough, et al, vs. The Propeller Falcon.--The facts in this case are stated in the opinion of the Court, delivered by Mr. Justice NELSON: This is an appeal from a decree of the Circuit Court of the United states for the Northern District of Illinois.

CLERKS. The Speaker presented a message from the President transmitting, in further response to the House resoultion of the 7th instant, reports from the Secretary of the Navy, Secretary of the Interior and Postmaster-General, as to the clerks and employes of their Departments, and whether any have served in the rebel armies. Laid on the table.

Pardons to the following persons have lately been granted by Gov. FENTON: CHARLES WINROW alias "Little Mickey," convicied at the General Sessions, January 25, 1866, for stealing a watch from Mr. CHARLES F. GAUSS, on the Fourth-avenue Railroad.
The following order has been issued by Super intendent KENNEDY to define the duties of the mem bers of the Metropolitan Police in relation to the newExcise Law:

CHAPTER II. In 1825 a political tornado swept through the State, utterly demolishing the Van Buren, or Democratic Party. The New-York delegation consisted of JAMES BENEDICT. GILBERT COUTANT, GLARKSON CROLIUS, MALTBY GELSTON, SAMUEL L. GOUVERNEUR, JOHN MORSE, JONATHAN E. ROBINSON, DAVID SEAMAN, IRA B. WHEELER and GEORGE ZABRISKIE. Mr. GOUVERNEUR, a son-in-law of President MONROE, was a brilliant, impassioned speaker. He was upright, patriotic;

The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House the Speaker presented a message from the President, transmitting reports from the Secretary of the Navy, Secretary of the Interior and Postmaster-General, as to the clerks and employes of their Department, and whether any have served in the rebel armies.

The Mexican correspondence announces the wreck of the French war steamer Emperor while go ing to Guadalagara. Methuela was assaulted on the morning of the Ist inst. by 1,200 Juarists under Escobedo. The Liberals were permitted to retire losing thirty officers andseventeen men.

The American Baptist Home Missionary Soci ety, in Convention, last evening, adopted a resolution instructing the Executive Board of the Society to continue their work among the Freedmen with every facility in their power, and give such religious in struction to colored preachers as might be deemedconsistent with discretion.

THE TRUE HISTORY OF A LITTLE RAGAMUF FIN. By the author of lieuben Davidger's Adven tures: New-York, HARPER BROTHERS. It seems strange that a writer possessing the power which Mr. GREENWOOD has, should be com pelled to labor for years and then gain recognitionby a lucky hit in a daily journal.

THE WASHINGTON FENIANS, It is stated on the authority of JAMES RYAN, District Centre, that the item published in the distant newspapers, that all the Fenian circles in this city had indorsed JAMES STEPHENS, is utterly untrue, the Roberts-Sweeney Circles having had nothing whatever to do in the matter.

A DOUBTFUL STATEMENT.--Some people suppose that BEAUREGARD, while ostensibly visiting Europe to negotiate railroad bonds, might not, while there, refuse to accept a suitable military position, if it were offered him by one or other of the greater or lesser Powers.

GALVANIZING FENIANISM,-All the attempts to galvanizo Fenianism are failures, Wo hear nothing of it in Ireland-which fact, we sup pose, will be interpreted, on some hands, as very ominous, but which we take to be quiteotherwise.

About 11:30 o'clock on Friday evening a gang of burglars effected a forcible entrance into the boot and shoo store of ARTHUR CAREY, No. 250 Ninth-street. After packing up a quantity of goods valued at $25, the thieves made preparations for departure. As they were emerging from the premises they were noticed by some passing citizens, who immediately gave an alarm.

The St. Paul Pioneer says: "Major NEWSON, the Jason of the Argenautic expedition, which set out last winter in pursuit of the golden fleece at Vermillion Lake, arrived yesterday, and reports a highly flourishing condition of affairs in that hyperborean El Dorado.

"The Code of Health Ordinances," passed by the now Board of Health, took effect on Tuesday. In most respects it is but a re enactment and simplification of existing City ordinances, but the latter have been so long utterly disregarded that, if now enforced, as we are assured they will be, we shall see agreat change in New-York and Brooklyn.

Treasurer MANIERRE'S total receipts from licenses footed up at the close, yesterday, $372,500, The number of indorsed applications for license which Col. BARTRAM had received stood at about 5,300, The Excise Board's Committee on License Appeals listened to applicants from the Forty-fifth, Forty sixth, Forty-seventh and Forty-ninth (Brooklyn) Pre cinets, yesterday morning, and thus closed the hearings for New-York and Brooklyn.

PRESENTATION TO JUSTICE CORNWELL.--Justice JAMES II. CORNWELL was yesterday presented with a fine gold watch and massive chain, and his wife with a beautiful set of silver ware, in all valued at about $800, the girl of the friends and follow-citizens of the Justice, consisting of Messrs. James Edsaill, P. H. Grogan, Wm.Dernard, James Weaver, R. M. Hooley, Hon. S. D. Morris, and others.

Bishop LAY has been rejected, and Dr. WIL MER chosen Bishop of the Diocese of Louisiana. Gen. BAIRD, of the Freedmen's Bureau, and Gov. WELLS, are presiding for the relief of the sufferers by ihe late crevases. The transport Clinton has arrived from Brazos with a regiment of colored troops.

The Academy of Music was crowded to-night to its fullest extent by an enthusiastic audience of ladies and gentlemen, to listen to speeches by Senators COWAN and DOOLITTLE in support of President JOHNSON. HENRY SIMONS, Esq., occupied the Chair. Senator DOOLITTLE, after treating the subject of the rebellion and the present issue before the country, declared that the man who denies the Union of the States, under the Constitution, is himself a disunionist.

In steamship Napoleon III., for Brest, Havre--Count De Faverney, First Secretary of French Legation, Washington ; Countess De Faverney and two servants ; Mr. Louis Guerra de la Vega, Ex-Conaul of Spain at New-York; Col, S. C. Thompson, Mrs. Thompson, M.I. G. R. Schiffelin, Mrs. Richard Alsop and maid, Miss Gaillard, Mew-York; Mr. Kemp, Mrs. Kemp, Miss Kemp, Mr. E. W. Pailket, Miss Martin and Servant.

A rather singular case of robbery came up before Justice HOGAN yesterday, at the Tombs Policecourt. It appears that on Wednesday last, LUTHER W. SHEAR, aged 16 years, and a clerk in the employ of Messrs. BADEAU, LOCKWOOD Co., fruit dealers, at No. 227 Washington-street, filled up a check for $7,050 02 on the Irving National Bank, and coolly Presented it to the cashier, who is also a member of the firm, for signature.

Commissioner MANIERUE, Treasurer of the Metropolitan Board of Health, made a requisition upon the Comptroller, a day or two age, for $20,000 of the supplemental $180,000 which the Legislature inserted in the tax levy, to be extended in payment of necessary expenses of the Board of Health, incurred in this City.

TENNESSEE.--The Nashville Banner learns that on Sunday, the 22d ult., a hail-storm--the heaviest ever known in that section--destroyed a greater part of the corn and cotton crop between Lewisburgh and Cornersville.

Simultaneously with the growth of a large city increases the difficulty of providing outdoor relaxation for those of its inhabitants who, having labored for six days in the midst of crowds and often in ill-ventilated buildings, feel some change to be necessary on the seventh.

The Grant House, in this city, was burned this morning. A lady jumped from a window on the fourth story, and has died of her injuries. Two Servant girls are missing, and it is feared that they perished in the flames. The fire is supposed to have been set for the purpose of plundering the house. The house cost $61,000; insured for $31,000.

Mr. J. C. DERBY, the United States Dispatch Agent at this port, has received, from the United States Consul at Liverpool, J. H. DUDLEY, the following articles, found on board the pirate Shenandoah when she was handed over to him by the British authorities. They have arrived here in the ship Cultivator, Capt. RUSSELL:

Sweet lady mine, the faded rose Is often dearer than the floor Fresh gathered; so each memory grows More precious than the parting hour; And all Love's artist hand can give Of glowing tint and tender shade, is with me, that your face may live In colors that can never fade.

"Rain, rain, rain--pitiless, ceaseless rain,"--has made, and is making, a 'dimnition damp body" of nearly everything hereabouts. As I write, a perfect terrent, like a tropical thunder shower, is falling, making the streets impassable except to ducks and ladies with the new-fashioned trains of orthodox length and hand-sweeping capacity.

From the New-Haren Journal. Thursday evening Telegraphic Convention was held along the American Line all over New-England. Nominations and votes were taken, a constitution and by-laws were passed, by use of the wires. Mr. ROBERTS, of Boston, was made Chairman, and Mr. J.E. WRIGHT, of Boston, Secretary. WM. R.

The Richmond Whig, in commenting on some denunciations by the Chicago Tribune of the ladies of Richmond for strewing flowers on the graves of the Confederate dead, says: " It is the misfortune of the Tribune and kindred sheets to see nothing good in anything that Southern people can do, and it is, therefore, a matter of indifference to us what they think.

On the 16th of the present month convenes the Diocesan Convention of Louisiana for the first time in several years. The pincipal business will be the choice of a Bishop to fill the vacancy made by the death of Bishop POLK. It was our good fortune to be with him much of the times immediately before and after he received a commission in the Confederate army.

The weather in this section continues cool, and all kinds of vegetation are very backward. The ice is not yet all out of the waters North of us, and consequently the wind from that quarter is chilly and unpleasant. Political matters are quiet. The two assemblies of the Presbyterian Church met this morning at 11 o'clock--the New School in Dr. NELSON'S spacious and handsome church, the Old School in the church of Rev. Mr. NICKOLS.

The Senate begins to-day the discussion of the Amendments to the Constitution which have already been passed by the House. The debate will be at once more free and more fair, and the result, whatever it may be, as it will be reached, not by the choking process, but by a distinct vote, will command far moreof public respect.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. Among the witnesses from North Carolina examined before the Committee of Fifteen, was Hon, BEDFORD BROWN, of North Carolina. He said he was opposed to secession, and in favor of the Union all the time, although he served in the State Legislature under Confederate rule. His testimony, Published at length, is in the same vein with that of ALEX.

There was a terrific storm in this city this afternoon, of wind, rain, and hall, accompanied with thunder and lighting. A number of buildings were unroofed, awnings were torn down, and glass was broken to the extent of many thousands of panes.

LLOYD'S MAPS.--J. T. LLOYD, of this City, has Just issued a large and handsome map of North America, compiled from the latest authorities. It is especially full as regards our new territories, all the villages, post stations, roads, and prominent geographical features being noted.

St. Thomas papers (received on Saturday night) contain no news. The Port of Spain Gazette has the following item: The brig Emma, at Port of Spain, Trinidad, from Philadelphia, reports having picked up at sea, in an open boat, Capt. CULLEN and five seamen of the hark Kathleen, which vessel was abandoned in a sinking condition.

The slender Birmingham wire, which we recently traced from its arrival at the gutia percha works in the City--road, through the various processes of manufacture, until. it left Morden--wharf, Greenwich, a compete submarine cable, is now being coiled at the rate of two miles an hour in the vast tanks of the Great Eastern.

The steamer Ironsides, Capt. ED. TURNER, arrived here from Lake Superior at 11:30 o'clock yesterday, being the first arrival of the season. We are indebted to her gentlemanly clerk, JOHN GORDON, for the following particulars of her voyage. The Ironsides left Detroit on her upward trip May 4. The battle of JEFF DAVIS is now reported to be on the mend. About a week since he was attacked by a very serve diarrhea, which has yielded under medical treatment, and he new seems to be in about his usual state of health. A weekly report of the condition of his health is made by the Post Surgeon to Washington.

PASSENGERS FOR EUROPE.--The tide of Sum mer travel to Europe has set in with even greater sweep than that which followed the close of the war. On one steamer alone-the Napoleon III.-323 cabin passengers sailed on Saturday, Two other steamers-the City of Paris and the Germania--cleared the sameday with their full complement.
Simultaneously with the arrival of SANTA ANNA in this country, we have news from Mexico of a great increase of warlike activityon the part of the Mexican Republicans.

THE SARATOGA HIGH ROCK SPRING.--High Rock Spring, Saratoga, which has long been regarded as a great natural curiosity, has recently been investigated during the progress of excavations carried on to induce, if possible, the water to flow over the opening in the rock. The water without doubt originally flowed through the round orifice in the top, during the process of formation of the rock and probably for years subsequent to that.

The weather is clear and warm. The river is falling. Passed down--City of Memphis and Belle St. Louis. Passed up--Baltic, Southerner, Governor Sharkey, Darling. A terrible tornado and hall storm visited Clarke County, Miss., last week, and uprooted trees, leveled houses and barns, entirely destroyed the crops and killed and wounded people and stock.

The Cincinnati Commercial, of the 17th, says: The non-Episcopal Methodist Convention of the United States adjourned after sitting eight days. During that time their proceedings were marked by a spirit of unanimity upon the issues at stake, and upon the whole, great fairness characterized the rulings ofthe body.

A gentleman traveling in Oregon gives the following notice of a barbarous language somewhat in use there: "On our way to Oregon, we were often told that after entering the State, we would hear much of the Chinook jargon, a language originally invented by members of the Hudson's Bay Far Company, in order to facilitate their trade with the Indians.

TRIAL OF DAVIS. Attorney-General SPEED, who returned from the West last week had a lengthy interview with the President on Friday last relative to the trial of JEFF. DAVIS and the indictment found by the Grand Jury at Norfolk. Mr. SPEED gave his opinion as to the legal character of the indictment, which opinion I am not authorized to etate.

The Memphis Post of the 16th inst. says: "A large meeting of the colored people of Helena, Ark,, was recently held to discuss thd importance and bes means of educating their children, It was addressed by Lieut. COLBY, the Superintendent of the colored schools for the State, by lion. JAMES A. BUTLER, and Judge HANLY, who was a member of the rebel Congress.

I was present yesterday at a most interesting and impressive ceremony, which deserves especial notice as illustrative of the feeling of the white for the black race, and of the sincere desire of the former to promote as far as possible the temporal and spiritualwelfare of the hitherto dependent bondsmen.

In this elegantly printed address of nearly one hundred pages, the assiduous President of the New-York Historical Society has elaborated a learned and eloquent argument to show the vast social and scientific results of those great and accessible collections of books, which, of old, in the East, and later in the capitals of Western Europe, enriched and inspired theminds of scholars and the people.

The liquor dealers doing business within the limits of the Metropolitan District, and more especially in this City, seem to have quietly resigned themselves to the regulations and provisions of the new Excise Law. The number of arrests for alleged violations are daily growing less, and those made on each recurring Sunday are also greatly diminished.

COAL IN ENGLAND AND TIMBER IN AMERICA.--Mr. GLADSTONE'S recent speech on the bud got had some rather sensational, though strict ly accurate and scientific statements as to the approaching exhaustion of the coal fields of Great Britain, and the profound effect such a circumstance would produce upon the industry and commerce of the country.

A jet of lava of more stupendous proportions than any ever conceived of, is described by Mr. COAN in the Honolulu Friend of February, in his account of the eruption of Mauna Loa, on the Island of Hawaii: "The eruption commenced near the summit of the mountain, and only five or six miles southeast of the eruption of 1843.

MISSISSIPPI.--The Memphis Bulletin's correspondent in Central Mississippi says that the last two weeks have been wholly lost to planters in that section of the State. Incessant and excessive rains have kept the soil so wet that to work it would have been injurious if not impossible.

The great Washington door for the new Capitol at Washington is being finished at the Ames works in Chicopce, where two entire years have been spent upon it. Many of the panels are already completed, and the work is progressing as fast as it peculiar complexity will allow. Designed by the lamented CRAWFORD, just previous to his death, it was his chef d'oeuvre. Had he survived,

ILLIONIS.--A dispatch of the 18th, from Spring field, III., says: Last night we were again visited by a very refreshing fall or rain. the copious showers which have visited very portion of this section within the last few days have done incalculable good to the crops, and greatly encouraged the farmers.

THE CONNECTICUT SENATOR.--The action of three Republican Senators' in Connecticut in postponing the election of a United States Senator for a week, instead of promptly ratify ing the caucus nomination, is resented withgreat indignation in sundry quarters.

In this class, we believe, may be ranked the gentle man who gives us some very curious facts published to-day in another column-regard ing the Directory of the Brotherhood in thiscountry. OPERATIO AND DRAMATIC-BROOKLYN.--A few years since, the City of Brooklyn had no academy or theatre; operas were undreamed of, theatricals were voted immoral, and entertainments of no kind proved profitable, with the exception of an occasional min strel performance, the Philharmonic concerts, andthe regular lectures of the season.

Newspaper accounts from Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia, Florida, and South and North Carolina represent the growing crop of cotton as seriously impaired by cold weather, heavy rains and overflow of cotton lauds, and stands bad, Detective seed, in a great measure, is the causeof the failure.

On Monday, the 14th inst., the Senior Class of the College of New-Jersey celebrated what is known as Clsss Day, with ceremonies of a very interesting character. This is the day when the toils and privations of college life end, and the dignified Seniors go away from the classic shades of old Nassau, into the busy whirl of independent, responsible manhood's life.

OHIO.--Messrs. BROWN, STEBERBING Co., of Massillon, Ohio, have taken some pains to obtain in telligence as to the condition of the crops, from their agents in various parts of the country. From a con densation which they have made, it appears that ton points in Ohio, well separated so as to represent wheat-growing sections, furnish very sorry accounts, only one of them reporting as much as a quarter of acrop.

In company with some ten thousand festively-inclined Germans and Germane-Americans, we kept the season of Whitsuntide at Jones' Wood, yesterday. The vast majority of the pleasant party were clad in light Summer costume. White trousers were pleasantly conspicuous, and mousselines, calicoes and organdies flourished in extenso.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS.--The Common Council met last evening, the President, Mr. BLISS, in the Chair, A petition from Mr. H. D, WHINEY and others was received in behalf of the New-York, Brooklyn and, Morrisanta Ferry Company, asking permission for their boats to touch at the foot of Fulton and Joralemon streets.

The first cricket match of the season, in this vicinity, will take place to-day at Hoboken, between the Newark Club, of Newark, and the New-York Club. Considerable interest is attached to this game aside from the fact of Its being the inauguration of match-playing. The New-Yorkers will introduce a couple of professionals, of whom report speaks very highly.

BARTON.--At Tempkinsville, Staten Island, on Monday, May 21. Mrs. JANE BARTON, widow of Samuel Barton, in the 66th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral at the Moravian Church, New-Dorp. on Wednesday, May 23, at 2 o'clock P.M. The Westminster Review for April contains an able article entitled "The United States Constitution and the Secessionists." The article is written, in the phraseology of the author, from a Northern and es. sentially "Republican or Free-Soll" point of view, and it clearly sets forth the political connections upon the great national questions which President LINCOLN brought with him into the Executive chair, and de fends his policy throughout the war with great clear.ness of argument,

Mr. ROBERT DALE OWEN has published an other letter on the subject of Reconstruction. Ho waives his original demand that some pro vision should be made for negro suffrage, as impracticable; but insists that the Constitu tion should be amended so as to provide equality of civil rights, a just basis of represensation, and a repudiation of the rebel debt.

In the Old School Presbyterian Assembly, to-day, the memorial of the Convention called by Dr. BRECKENRIDGE, which held a session here last week, was presented and referred to the Committee on Bills and Overtures The memorial review the relations between the Presbyterian Church and the Confederates.

About 12 o'clock last night, flames were discovered in the kitchen attached to the restaurant belonging to the Academy of Music. Discovered, the flames had gained such headway that their further progress could not be arrested, and in a few minutes they spread to the auditorium of the opera-house, and so on to the stage.

Eight-seven cases of arms were seized in this city on Saturday night. They are the property of the Fenian Senate in New-York. They were shipped to this port, consigned to J. F. CRONIN, auctioneer, who is Head Centre of this county, and marked "Hardware and Agricultural Implements." The Provost-Marshal-General will arrive tomorrow to investigate the case.

The damage by the storm here yesterday afternoon was very great. The loss may be estimated by tens of thousands of dollars. Buildings were unroofed, windows destroyed, young trees and plants cut down by the hall, gardens wholly ruined. The nurseries and green-houses suffered much.

RECONSTRUCTION NOT DEBATED. Contrary to general expectation tho debate on the reconstruction amendments to the Constitution was not commenced to-day in the Senate. Mr. FESSEN DEN, who bad charge of the matter, asked that it be postponed until Wednesday, as he was utterly unequal to tho work required of him. By common consentthis arrangement was agreed to.

The steamship Cuba, from Liverpool 12th, via Queenstown 13th inst., arrived here to-day, en route to Boston. The steamship North American, from Portland, arrived at Londonderry on the 10th. The steamship Baltic, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the 10th. The steamship Persia, from New-York, arrived at Queenstown on the 11th.

LAYING THE CORNER-STONE OF THE WOMAN'S HOSPITAL.--we call attention to the notice in our advertising columns of this ceremony, because a most useful and modest charity is about to become available to may more sufferers than before. A discovery in surgery of the utmost value to woman has long been taught and practiced at a small hospital in a hired house in Madison-avenue.

The steamship Cuba arrived yesterday at Halifax, with advices from Europe to the 13th inst. The most important news is the terrible financial panic in England, which is pronounced, on Mr. GLADSTONE'S authority, to be without parallel in the commercial history.

THE GERMAN STRIFE.--The existing German quarrel is nearly as incomprehensible as the merits of the question affecting the right and title to the Danish Principalities, The news this morning by the Cuba does not serve toclear up matters very much.
