The war panic on the Continent and the money panic in England were at their zenith, to all appearances, when the Ouba sailed, on the 12th inst. The latter excited most inter est in business circles in New-York yesterday, though the former is not lost sight of nor deemed less threatening than by the previous annivals.

FIRE COMMISSIONER OF THE WESTERN DISTRICT.--Last evening at a meeting of the delegates from the different Fire Companies, Mr. WALTER BARRE, Jr., was elected Fire Commissioner, in place of JOSEPH H. KETCHUM, resigned. The full term is five years, and Mr. KETCHUM having served one year, Mr. BARRE will occupy the office for the remainder of the term.

Yesterday morning there was quite an inter esting exhibition on the lake in the Central Park, be ing the occasion of the introduction on into this country of the invention of a Danish gentleman named HOHLENBERG, known as the water skates, The title, however, does not well convoy an idea of either the form or mode of progress of this new aquatic, whichoutstrips in speed the fastest boat upon the lake.

WALLACK'S THEATER.--Signor FOSATI'S matinee to-day introduces a new Spanish opera, to which we have already referred. The programme is otherwise interesting, and the attendance will, we hope, be equal to the occasion.

The steamships Bremen and City of New-York, with dates to the 10th inst., arrved yesterday, A. summary of their news was published yesterday morning, but our foreign files furnish us with fullerdetails of recent events of importnece.

Sunday-schools are an institution in this coun try, but in Brooklyn they are a peculiar Institution, in which every family has a highly-prized interest for the sake of the children. Each year it is the pleasant custom of the several "orthodoxy" denominations to celebrate the anniversary of the establishment of schools in the city, by services in the church, paradein the streets, and a collation in the school-room.

Before Judge Cardoia. In the Matter of the Application of D. G. Ferguson to be Admitted to Rail.--A motion was made a day or two since to have D. G. Ferguson admitted to ball. The prisoner was arrested by the police and confined in the Tombs, on the charge of being implicated in the late robbery of bounds, , of Mr. Lord, of this City.

EQUALIZATION OF BOUNTIES. Mr. WILSON, from the Committee on Military Affairs and the Militia, to which was referred Senate Bill No. 207, to provide for the equalization of bounties to the soldiers in the late war of the rebellion, presented a bill and a written report.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON reported bill for the equalization of bounties. It gives every soldier, without distinction of color, $81/3 per month, deducting bounties already paid, and excluding alto gether deserters and those who have sold or barteredaway their claims.

THE HEALTH OF JEFFERSON DAVIS. It will be recollected that, some two weeks ago, Secretary McCOLLOCH, whilst on a visit to Fortress Monroe, had an interview with JEFF. DAVIS, and that the Securetary discovered from observation and the in formation he derived from the surgeon In attendanceat the fort that Mr. DAVIS was in feeble health.

The visits of Sceretary SEWARD to his old home in Auburn, N. Y., are always of public interest. However he may protest and resolve to keep silence, the ardent personal friends of all parties who gather around him always manage to overcome his resolution, and induce him to "give them a speech."

For the third time in the twenty-two years' history of the Peel Act of 1844, the Bank of England has been compelled to ask of the Government a suspension of its terms of incorporation. For the third time the Ministers of the Crown have interposed to save its Charter from legal forfeiture.

SEALERS CRUSHED BY ICEBERGS.--This large picture by BRADFORD has been placed by the artist upon exhibition for the benefit for the support and education of the orphans left by the Union soldiers and sailors.

SAMUEL COOK, the last of the Revolutionary heroes, died, on Sunday night, in Clarendon, Orleans County, at the age of one hundred and two years. He was born in Plymouth, Vermont. At the age of seventeen, he entered the army of the Revolution; first, in the dragoons, and then in the infantry, under COL. SHELDEN, Mr. COOK was three years in the army;

ARRIVALS IN THE CITY.--GOV. Fenton, Albany; S. E. Marvin, Albany, and Senator Dickson, Washington, are at the Fifth-av. Hotel. Ex-Mayor Joseph M. Wightman, Boston; Hon. Amasa J. Parker, Albany; Hon. John H. Reynolds, Albany; Hon. Thomas A. Scott, Philadelphia, and Hon, Geo. M. Cass, Pittsburg, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

THE MOTT MUSEUM.--The greatest loss, in many respects, of the fire that began at the Academy of Music on Monday night, was in he destruction of the Surgical Museum in the Medical College adjoining the Academy. This invaluable scientific collection was the lifetime work of the venerable Dr. VALENTINE MOTT, lately deceased.

The Senate elected to-day Gen. BENJAMIN F. BUTLER, of Lowell, to be Major-General of the Massachusetts State Militia under the new militia organization. The American Baptist Missionary Union commenced its anniversary meetings to-day, Hon. IRA HARRIS, of New-York, President of the Society.

From the Albany Evening Journal. The movement to construct from the rains of the Democracy and the disaffected elements among the Republican, a great personal party--which, with the aid of reconstructed rebels, shall carry the next Presidential election--has already commenced. Meetings are reported almost daily.

At a meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health, yesterday afternoon, President SCHULTZ being engaged with the Commission to select a site for a now Post office, Judge BOSWORTH was called to the chair. Attorney BRISS reported that the number of orders which he has made for the abatement of nuisances has reached the aggregate of 11,250.

From the Brockville (Canada) Monitor. At the present moment the most prominent man--i.e. the man most talked about on this continent--is unquestionably JAMES STEPHENS, C. E. I. R., that is, Chief Executive Irish Republic, who landed in New-York on last Thursday week from France, where he had remained for about a month after his escape from Ireland in a fishing boat.

To the Editor of the New York Times. There exists an erroneous impression that the law requires personal notice as to the returns of in come, , consequently persistent efforts are made to withhold names. Boarding-house keepers profess frequently to be ignorant, not only of the business and place of business, but even of the full names ofthose resident with them.

THE RICHMOND "REPUBLIC."-We are sorry to see that the Richmond Republic has been forced to suspend publication for lack of sup port It has been the ablest, most judicious and most useful of the newspapers in Rich.mond. Its tone was thoroughly loyal,

A temporary ??, erected after the occupation of Macon by the United States forces, as a place of deposit for Confederate ordnance stores, was blown up on Monday afternoon, while several freedmen were engaged in drawing fuses and extracting powder. One of the shells exploded, and was quickly followed by others, resulting finally in a tremendous explosion.

We are pleased to notice the following indorsement, by our able colemporary, the Augusta Constitutionalist, of views recently presented by us concerning what we deemed to be due Lieut-Gen. GRANT by the people and Press of the South. In its issue of the 3d inst. that paper says:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The account of the arrest of Messrs. FAULKNER and KILLIP, on Sunday, the;' 14th inst., is incorrect, in the first place we were not addressing a disorderly crowd, but rather a quiet, respectable congregation, at the close of the service, when Mr. FAULKNER was closing the meeting, two rowdies cried out, "Three cheers for Mr. FAULKNER."

A religious feeling has lately made its appear ance among the negro villages on the Peninsula, and quite a rivalry between the various denominations is kept up as to who shall secure the greatest number of converts. The Baptists at present take the lead, and every Sunday about jive hundred negroes of allages are baptized and join that church.

We understand that in less than two weeks from now the trial of JEFFERSON DAVIS for treason against the United States Government will commence at Richmond. The day actually fixed, we believe, is the first Monday in June. The indictment is simple and specific,

BOLTON.--On Tuesday, May 22, JOHN BOLTON, aged 81 years. Friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend the funeral service this day. (Thursday,) May 24, at 9 o'clock P. M., from the residence of his nephew, A. P. Vandenbergh, No. 439 West 47th-st. The remains will be taken to Albany for interment.

At the second day's session of the GrandLodge of the Independent Order of Good Templars, held to day, officers were elected and installed, Hon. S. D. HASTINGS, of Wisconsin, being called to the chair for the fourth successive year. To-morrow's session ter minates this Convention of the Lodge. Its next meeting is appointed at Detroit, Mich., on the fourth Tuesday in May, 1867. A public demonstration tookplace this afternoon at Music Hall.

The Committee of Congress for the investigation of the riots have organized. The Commissioners are under Gens. STONEMAN and FISK, and have already taken considerable testimony. The Avalanche and Commercial advise the citizens to afford the Committee every facility.

In connection with the disastrous fire in Fourtoonth-stroet, the gratifying announcement was made in our columns yesterday that the looe tures and classes of the Faculty will be continued without interruption. Ample provision is to boemade for the Winter course of instruction,

The editor of the Lewiston Falls Journal, now at Washington, recently spent an hour in the studio of the Maine artist SIMMONS, in conversation with Gen. GREAT, and gives an interesting statement of the opinions expressed by him upon "men and measures"

The brig Carl Ludwig has arrived, with dates from Hong Kong to March 15. Sir RICHARD GRAVES McDONNELL had arrived there, and been inaugurated Governor with great ceremony. The French coolie ship Hong Kong had been seized by the coolies on board of her. When the vessel was recovered from them she was discovered to be covered with blood and dead coolies.

The Emperor's speech at Auxerre has been interpreted as referring primarily to a " reti fication" of the frontier of France, which had been narrowed by the treaties of 1815, He is supposed to mean that the Empire must re include Belgium and the left bank ot the Rhine.

In the Old School Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, to-day, the protest of Dr. VAN DYKE against the action of the Assembly in regard to the exclusion of the Louisville Commissioners was ordered recorded, and a committee, with Dr. WEST as Chairman, was appointed to report an answer in reard to it.

GRANNISS--KING.--On Tuesday, May 22, at the Church on the Heights, by Rev. Dr. Eells, GEORGE HENRY GRANNISS and ANNA A., daughter of the late David P. King. Esq., all of Brooklyn. LEACH--RUGG.--In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, May 23, by Rev. S. H. Hall, D. D., FREDERICK LEACH, Esq., and Mrs. STELLA A. RUGG, both of Owego.

Mr. SEWARD'S speech at Auburn, which we published yesterday morning, was mainly a calm, candid and dispassionate statement of the condition of the country, with especial reference to the differences of opinion that have arisen between the President and Congress.

The largest attendance of the season was as sembled yesterday on the Fashion Course, L. I., to witness the great stallion trot between JAMES L. EOFF's brown horse, George M. Patchen, Jr., and D. MACE'S bay horse, Commodore Vanderbilt, for a purseand stake of $1,500, mile heats, best 3 in 5, in harness.

Cooper Institute was pretty well filled last night to witness the contest between JOHN DEERY, of New-York, and JOSEPH DION, of Montreal, for the champion cue and $1,000. The game was commenced at 8 o'clock, and DION took the lead and turned his first thousand points, when Deery stood at 786.

PETITIONS; Mr. MORGAN presented the petition of stove manufacturers for a reduction of the tax on this business; which was referred to the Finance Committee. Mr. COWAN presented a petition for an increased tariff; which was referred to the Finance Committee. BRIDGING THE MISSISSIPPI. Mr. NORTON called up the bill to authorize the Winona and St.Peter's Railroad Company to construct a bridge across the Mississippi River; which was discussed until 1o'clock.

SENATOR FESSENDEN'S DISOLAIMER.--We are glad to see that Senator FESSENDEN has taken the trouble to repel the accusation' that the failure to road the Colorado veto message in the Senate upon the day on which it was sent in was an intentional discourtesy to the President, on the part of that body.

In the Senate, yesterday, the morning hour was spent in the discussion of a bill to bridge the Mississippi at Winona, Minnesota. The Reconstruc tion resolutions, recently passed by the House, were then taken up. The debate on the report of the Re construction Committee was opened by Mr. HOWARD. Mr. SUMNER desired to postpone the considerationof the report till the last of June.

A WORK OF ART.--An admirably executed bust of the late Mr. Low, of Paterson, by Mr. R. L. SMYTHE, is on view at Messrs. FISHER BIRD'S. The likeness is excellent, and the execution of the work altogether is faultiess. The friends of the deceased gentleman, as well as various artists who have inspected the bust, express themselves charmed with the fidelity and artistic skill with which the design has been carried out.

GOVERNOR FENTON AT BLACKWELL'S ISLAND.--Yesterday Gov. FENTON and daughter, accompanied by Commissioners BELL and BRENNAN, Hon. SAMUEL O. REED, and Commissary-General DOWLING, of the Governor's staff, visited Blackwell's and Randall's Islands. A steamboat chartered for the occasion look the party from the whart at Bellevue.

The mails by the steamship Cuba reached this City last evening. We give from our European files full accounts of the great financial panic in England, and some interesting comments from the French press on the Emperor's recent speech.

In the Chicago correspondence of the Cincin cinnati Gazette, of the 21st inst., occurs this item: "A well authenticated rumor says that the Chicago Republican will change front next week, and come out as a Johnson Administration journal. CHAS. A. DANA, editor-in-chief, and Col. MACK, the business man.aver. will leave the concern.

ANNIVERSARY OF THE EASTERN DISTRICT SUNDAY-SCHOOLS--TEN THOUSAND CHILDREN IN PROCESSION.--The Sunday-Schools connected with the Sabbath-School Teachers' Association of the Eastern District celebrated their anniversary yesterday by a grand parade and exercises in the churches.

A PRESENT TO GEN. LEE.--The Richmond papers some days since alluded to the presentation to Gen. LEE, by the ladies of the centenary Church, of that city, of a beautiful cap, bag and slippers, The Whig contains the following note of thanks from the great chieftain: LEXINGTON, VA., April 18. 1866.

Fifteen thousand Feniana assembled at the People's Park, San Mateo, to express devotion to the cause of Ireland, and to use their influence to heal the dissensions existing among the Fenian Brother hood, The utmost harmony and decorum prevailed. Speeches were made by JOHN HAMIL, State Centre; Col. WALSH, of Gen. SWEENEY'S staff, and others.

Four or five years ago the well-known artist, Mr. THOMAS HICHS, put on exhibition his picture, " The Authors of the United States" me aning thereby not the founders of the Gov ornmmnt, but those who have made themselvesfamiliar mainly by the productions of their pens.

A CHILD TWO YEARS OLD HANGS ITSELF.--Coroner HANLEY, of Hudson City, held an inquest yesterday, at East Newark, on the body of an infant son, two years of age, of JACOB DASCHART, who was found strangled to death by a piece of cord suspended from a door-knob.

The financial excitement in England cannot be said to have occurred unawares. The cul minating point has been reached suddenly, as it always has been in similar circumstances, but for some time past it has been distinctlyindicated.

FORNEY, editor of the Washington Chronicle, thus ventures upon an opinion in the nature of a prediction: "In a very short time, the fourteenth article of the Constitution of the United Stated will here passed both Houses of Congress by constitutional majority, and be presented to the Legislatures of the several States.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON offered a resolution for a special Committee to investigate the condition of the National Banks, which was adopted, The Reconstruction report was then taken up. Mr. STEWART addressed the Senate in favor of universal suffrage and universal amnesty.

Topographical enginers have arrived here to survey the Passes of the Mississippi and improve navigation for the Gulf shipping; also, to search for a bayou or canal outlet to lessen the volume of the water of the river and prevent overflows. Gen. CANBY has gone to Washington, and Gen. BAIRD is commander of the Department.

The public will be gratified by the evidence afforded on Wednesday last of the attitude held by the President's Cabinet toward the policy of his Administration. It is always well to have the views of men holding posts of so much influence and responsibility, upon the leading political questions of the day, dis.tinetly understood.

We hear that Gov. FLNTON pardoned ZENO ?? because he was informed by District-Attorney A. OAKEY HALL that the conviction of BURNHAM was obtained more through prejudice than on evidence. The World this morning, alluding to one of these stories, remarks: "It is reported that BURNHAM has said it cost him $14,000 to get pardoned."

A PETITION WITHDRAWN. Mr. TRUMBULL asked leave to withdraw from the files of the Senate the petition of citizens of Staun ton, Va., praying for military protection as loyal per. sons. He had received a letter, he said, from Staun ton, informing him that the names of the signers of this petition had been procured for the purpose ofpersecution by rebels.

\The latest news from Senator WRIGHT, of New-Jersey, is that he is much better, but whether his recovery is looked for we do not know. It seems that the Senatorial Radicals, putting faith in the "exclusive news" of the Tribune, that Mr. WRIGHT was really no more, busied themselves yesterday morning in arranging over the funeral baked meats for his successor.

The spirit in which the Senate has com menced its discussion of the Constitutional Amendment reported by the Reconstruction Committee justifies the reliance which has been placed upon its disposition to check the unwise action of the other House. The tac tics by which debate is frustrated are no longerpossible.

The case was argued in the Supreme Court to-day on the constitutionality of an Act of Congress denying the right of suffrage to deserters. The case came up from the Franklin County Court, where a judge of election was fined for refusing to receive the vote of HENRY REILLY, who having been drafted neither reported for duty nor furnished a substitute.

The Democratic State Convention, to-day, nominated BENJAMIN LEFEVRE, of Shelby County, Secretary of State; WILLIAM SORWILL, of Ashland County, Chief of the Board of Public Works, and THOMAS K. KEY, of Hamilton County, Judge of the Supreme Court; and adopted the following platform:

A card appeared yesterday morning in the Bulletin, signed by D. H. ROBERTS, charging Gen. RUNKLE, Superintendent of the Freedmen's Bureau, in connection with U. C. SMITH, of the Intelligence Office, with refusing to contract for the employ of freedom without a bonus of fifteen dollars a place. The same statement was telegraphed in advance to papers in several of the Northern cities.

WINTER GARDEN.--Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, who have given so much pleasure to the public during the past few weeks, will take their farewell benefit here to-night. The bill is unusually rich. Three places will be played, "Born to Good Luck," "An Hour in Seville," and the "Fairy Circle."

The Evening Post now announces, in view of the aspect of affairs in Mexico, that MAXI MILIAN'S Empire is near its end, and that the "emissaries of despotism in Mexico, etc., have been checked." It proposes that a pub lic meeting be held "to express our sympathis with the Republicans of Mexico, etc.,

The spirit of the Old School Assembly was nn mistakably manifest on Saturday. The preliminaries to the thorough examination of the rebellious Ken tuckians were ended by an overwhelming vote, pass ing Dr. MAC LEWIS' resolutions of investigation. The rebellious against the Government were arraigned asrebellious against the Church.

Learning that the townsmen of Gen. O. S. FERRY, the Senator elect, proposed to serenade him last night, quite a number of members of the Legislature and other Republican workers went down in the evening train to be present. The delegation was warmly and handsomely entertained, while the bells and a cannon gave voice to the rejoicings of the Republicans of Norwalk over the election.

The revenue cutter Moccasin, which has been stationed at Norfolk and this harbor for the past six months, has been ordered to North Carolina. The revenue cutter Nemaha, now at Baltimore, has been assigned to duty here in her place. Workmen are now engaged in making improvements in the Custom-house.

Hon. John Sherman, U. S. Senate: DEAR SIR,-Like many other citizens and mom bors of the Union Party, I am disturbed at the condition in which we are placed by the differences which have been prominently developed between the President and Congress, A Congresisonal policy appears to be in course of arrangement under which we shall be ex pected to organize, in order to encounter and resistthe Presidential policy.

The United States Customers officers seized at Rouse's Point 1,280 stand of arms on Saturday night. They had come by the lake Champlain boat, in cases marked "machinery" for Ogbensburgh. The cases looked a little suspicious, and one of them was opened. The officers telegraphed to Washington for instructions, and the answer was to seize the arms and prevent their being forwarded.

A man named FRED, ANDERSON was arrested near Peckskill to-day, charged with horse stealing. While being pursued, he turned and fired three shots at his pursuers, none of which took effect. He also made a desperate resistance when overtaken, but was finally secured and brought to the Jail in this city.

Harper's New Monthly, forJune. (New-York: HARPER BROTHERS,) makes a really brilliant opening to the thirty-third volume of this popular periodical. The war, science, art, travel, biography and fiction are all repro sented, and by papers nearly every one of which may justly be ranked as first-class magazine articles.

EXPLANATORY.--The Albany Evening Jour nal objects to our designation of that portion of the Union members of Congress who sym pathize with the sentiments of Mr. STEVENS and Mr. SUMNER, as "radicals." We beg to say that in this we only adopt the term bywhich they themselves prefer to be known.

To even the causal glance of a hurried traveler, the ruling element of the citizens of South Carolina presents a gratifying impression, They are undoubtedly better educated and more intelligent than the controlling classes of many of the other Southern States, and with all their quondam reputation for fire-eating and extreme doctrines, they seem to accept the present condition of affairs with an honest spirit of moderation.

THE LATEST ON FENIANISM.--A11 that remains of the Fenian scheme has assumed a well defined shape; its purpose is made manifest and its duration is defined. Mr. STEPHENS is the expounder of a new method of rescuing Ireland from the grip of the Saxon, and proposes to carry it out.

DALY, Vice-President, an exhibition is now given of BRADFORD'S "Sealers Crushed by Ice bergs," at the Somerville Art Gallery, No. 845 Broad way, In behalf of the Committee, the accompanying circular says that " the scene is off the coast of Labra dor. Against the opalescent background of the ice, the ship, struck by the rays of tile setting sun, outlines herself.

Sailed, steamer Bolivian, for Liverpool. Cotton unchanged; sales 2,300 bales; low middlings 36c. @37c.; to-day's receipts 710 bales; week's receipts 5,210 bales, against 5,460; week's exports, 15,300 bales; stock 147,496 bales. Freights easier, but unchanged. New-York Exchange 3/4c. premium.

FRENCH THEATRE.--This new establishment will be opened to-night, under the well-approved direction of Messrs. JUIGNET and DRIVET. The house is new, and the artists are known; we ma anticipate, therefore, a fine attendance. The pieces are"Nos Allices" and "Les Rendezvous Bourgeois."

In the United States District Court to-day Judge GILES decided a petition for an injunction against a city passenger railway for refusing to allow the petitioner, A. A. BRADLEY (colored) to ride in said cars. The Judge ordered "that the facts stated in the petition do not present a case for equitable action of the Court by way of injunction."

GEO. C. BECK alias HOWE, one of the men concerned in the forgery of certificates on bonded warehouses in this City, was arrested at Rochester on Wednesday. The amount of the forgeries is about three hundred thousand dollars. The case was "worked up" by Mr. GOLDEN, of the detective force.

MEETING OF THE REPUBLICAN SENATORS-RECON STRUCTION. The Republican members of the Senate held a caucus meeting for the purpose of trying to reconcile the various and conflicting opinions in regard to the plan of reconstruction and to settle upon the course to be pursued with reference to the confirmation orrejection of appointments by the President.

The Copperheads are abusing Mr. SEWARD. The Demoeratic World joins Mr. FORNEY'S radical Chronicle and Press in denouncing the Auburn speech and its author. In their efforts to vilify and deery him, they use substantially the same epithets, working from different points, but both evidently having the sameobject in view.

CUBBERLY--STERLING.--In the Reformed Dutch Church, Port Richmond, S. I., on Thursday, May 24, by Rev. James Brownlee, Capt DANIEL D. CUBBERLY, and Miss REBECCA STERLING, both of Staten Island. FULLER--BENEDICT.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday evening, May 24, by Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, at the residence of the bride's father, CORNELIA LUDLOW, eldest daughter of R. S. Benedict, Esq.,

A great many persons think that because the European steamers are filled to overflowing that the entire population of the City of New-York is en route for the continent across the seas. It's a great mistake. The vast millions that remain on this side are as busy as ever in laying plans for the summer rest, vacation or jaunt.

The birthday of Queen VICTORIA was celebrated here with great enthusiasm. Business was laid aside and a general holiday was made of the day. During the afternoon there was a grand military re view, and to-night a monster concert is in progressin aid of the families of the volunteers.

Mr. ROBERT DALE OWEN, in a letter recently published, declared that "the North would renew the war to-morrow" rather than endure the inequality of representation in proportion to voters which the Constitution now gives the Southern States in consequence of the destruction of Slavery.
WINTER GARDEN. Broadway, between Bleecker and Amity sts. THIS EVENING, commencing at 7 1/2 o'clock, B0RN TO GOOD LUCK; or, AN IRISHMAN'S FORTUNE; THE FAIRY CIRCLE, and THE LATEST FROM NEW-YORK.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. MORRILL intro duced a resolution calling upon the President for in formation as to what executive action had taken place under the various bills for the colonization of persons of African descent, which was adopted. Mr. WILSON called up the joint resolutions concerning cad t appointments.

BERLIN.--On Tuesday, May 22, ADELE, LOUISE, only daughter of Charles J. and Hattie L. Berlin, aged 2 years and 8 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Saturday, the 26th inst., at 1 o'clock P.M. , from the residence of her parents, No. 135 Lexington-av.

GAS FROM PETROLEUM.--A Company has been formed in this City for the purpose of supplying the public with gas for lighting and heating purposes manufactured from crude petroleum. It is claimed that gas has nearly three times as much illuminating power as coal gas, that it is entirely free from odor, and can be supplied for 40 per cent, less than coal gas at present prices.

AN IMPERIAL CARICATURE.--An Emperor whose position is so long in dispute as that of MAXIMUJAN, and whose power is so ill con solidated, as his still is, must be said to have a " bad show," viewed in regard to its perman ency. The Empire was set up after the most approved fashion, but its subsequent historyhas not been of the approved imperial kind,

The proceedings of the Old School Assembly of the Presbyterian Church to-day consisted mainly of the presentation of and reading the report of the Committee on the Louisville Presbytery case. The report reviews the declaration and testimony put forth by that body;

We have often had occasion in these col umns to call attention to the excessive specu lation and overtrading of late years in the British market. The vast profits accumulated there in the last ten years have tempted the English public to the wildest speculation andthe most fanciful investments.

Notwithstanding Secretary SEWARD, in his Auburn speech of the 22d, repudiated the necessity of any reconstruction, and declared that the country was reconstructed already, it is palpable that for many practical purposes the Union is not yet restored, and will not be until Congress shall consent that a large part of the country shall no longer be excluded from participation in the national deliberations.

We find in a Southern exchange the following gratifying paragraph: "DISCONTINUED.--We regret to learn that the daily South Carolinian, an outspoken fearless journal published in Charleston, F. G. DE FONTAINE, publisher, and WM. GILLMORE SIMMS, Editor, has been discontinued for the want of support.

The complimentary testimonial to Prof. WM. LAKE at the Cooper Institute, on Thursday afternoon and evening, drew together a small but appreciative audience. The exhibition in the afternoon opened with a trial of skill between GOLDTHWAIT and McDEVITT, American carom game, 400 points up, for a purse of $150, which was won by the latter, the score standing 402 to 206.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In your paper of to-day, under the above startling title, you comment on an article of mine recently published here. "Is the war to be renewed ?" At the present juncture no more important question can be asked or answered, You will then, I trust, allow me a few words in reply.

Dr. ANDREWS' flying ship was cut away from her moorings yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock, ascend ing to a considerable elevation, apparently for a time under the perfect control of the aeronaut, rising but slowly, and going rapidly forward at an angle of less than forty-five degrees in the direction of Westchester County.

THE CHINA MAIL SERVICE. Mr. CONNESS offered a Joint resolution to repeal so much of the act to establish steamship mail service between the United States and China as requires vessels to touch at Honolulu, which was referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Post Roads.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT--SOUTHERN DISTRICT. The United States vs. Seven Certificates of Stock, $4,420 in Gold, is an application made in behalf of Augustus B. Sage, the claimant, for an order directing the delivery to him on bail of $4,420 in gold, $200 in currency, and seven certificates of stock, representing at par a value of $19,250, being the property seized in this action.

Europe has been waiting the past week, in anxious expectation, to hear the sound of the first cannon fired in a war which threatens to surpass all wars of modern times in the numbers of men and of nations engaged in it. But the gun has not been fired, and the question still is, who will fire it? There arescarcely two opinions about the probability of war.

A few minutes before 12 o'clock on Thursday night, a fire broke out among the wooden sheds at tached to the Hudson River Railroad Depot, situated at the foot of Thirty-second-street, North River. Owing to the inflammable nature of the contents of the buildings, the flames spread with great rapidity,and eventually extended to the depot itself, and to a numbers of more standing on the interior tracks.

A fire occurred this morning in a frame build ing known as those Bedstead Factory. It broke out at 7 o'clock, and in twenty minutes the whole building (75 by 200 feet) was in flames, presenting an imposing appearance.. The fire, it is supposed, caught from acotton-drying machine.

JOHN PORTEFIELD has been paroled by the President, to report to Gen. THOMAS. ANDREW JOHNSON, Jr., nephew of the President, has been removed from the agency of the State Peni tentiary by the Commissioners of that institution,and J. S. WAIL has been appointed Warden.

The House has passed another Freedmen's Bureau Bill, which ought to receive careful scrutiny before it becomes a law. All loyal citi zens approve of the organization of the Bureau as a necessity of the war, and they accord it the credit of having rendered the country, and especially the newly liberated race, valuable service.

The most destructive fire that ever took place in the oil regions occurred in Oil City to-day. The whole east side of Oil Creek, comprising half the business portion of the city, is in ashes. Seventy-five stores, eight hotels, forty dwelling-houses, a church and a seminary are a mass of ruins. The loss is $1,000,000, which is insured for only $100,000.

The corner-stone of the new hall to be built in the rear of STEINWAY'S store in Fourteenth-street, near Irving-place, was laid yesterday, Mayor HOFFMAN and a number of managers, artists and reporters assisting in the ceremonies. The hall will be 75 feet wide and 43 feet high.

Our local news is not very important to people not immediately interested. The state Homeopathic Society has been in session here during the past week. Matters of general interest were discussed, confined principally to medes of practice. The cholera very naturally received a large share of attention.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; Some thirty years age the environs London were infested with brutal rowdies, as NEW-Fork is. A gang of these ruflians attended at West Green Fair, on the outskirts of London, where they brutally and without provocation assaulted peaceable citizens: their onslaught resulted in the death of one or same of their victims.

Notwithstanding the warnings that are given by the Press every day, and the continual exposition of frauds that are perpetrated in this City, there are persons verdant enough to allow themselves to be led into traps by the simplest means imaginable. An in stance which shows how truthfully this describes theo gullibility of many persons occurred in this City last week, and was brought to the attention of MayorHOFFMAN yesterday.

Since his arrival in Now-York, on the 15th inst., JOSEPH DION, the Canadian player who defeated JOHN DEERY last Wednesday evening for the Ameri can championship and $1,000, has resided in Brook lyn, at the house of his friend, Mr. GEO. A. COCHRANEa merchant of this City.

THE DEATH OF REV. DR. CHARLES C. PISE.- Rev. Dr. CHARLES C. PISE, pastor of the Church of St. Charles Barromeo, in Sidney-place, was counted among the most influential and distinguished divines of the Roman Catholic faith in this country, The deceased was born in Annapolis, Md., in 1802. Hedied at 12 o'clock yesterday, in the 64th year of his ago.

THE CHOLERA AND THE CITY.--Public opinion changes with groat rapidity, and often on very little ground. Everybody seems now to be getting as fixed in the opinion that we are going to escape the cholera as everybody was certain a month ago that the City was to besubjected to its ravages.

The celebrated French physician, PINEL, relates the case of a watchmaker who was infatuated with the chimera of perpetual motion, and to effect this discovery, he set to work with indefatigable ardor. From unremitting attention to the object of this enthusiasm, coinciding with the influence of revolutionary disturbances, his imagination was greatly heated, his sleep was interrupted, and at length a complete derangement took place.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you allow me a small share in your columns to reply to recent strictures on the course of Commodore RODGERS, in not interfering by force to prevent the bombardment of Valparaiso. It might be a sufficient reply to the censure cast upon him to say his course meets with the full and cordial approbation of the Government,

The following named steamers were sold a Norfolk yesterday afternoon at auction: Warvenock, for $8,500; Gazelle, for $5,500; Bertre, for $2,200. Other vessels were advertised to be sold, but were withdrawn.

From the Washington Intelligencer. The recent references to the trial of Mr. DAVIS have called public attention to this subject, which, very naturally, in a large degree interests the public mind. The indictment in the usual form for treason has been found by the Grand Jury, in the United States Circuit Court, at Norfolk.

At the present moment there is an appropriation pending before the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, involving some $980,000, to supply Indian refugees, Indian Territory. It was but very recently, (at the close of December,) that an appropriation of $500,000 was made out of the negro fund for the same purpose. A year ago just as Congress adjourned, HENRY WINTERS DAVIS purposely talked to death an appropriation of $409,000.

NEW-YORK AND PARIS.--NAPOLEON exercises as great power, comparatively, in the regula tion of the condition of local affairs in Paris, as he exercises over France in the capacity of its Emperor, or over Europe as its practical Dictator. It is to the fact that he possesses this power that many of the great public works and splendid modern improvemeuts of Parisare due.

A SWINDLING GANG BROKEN Up.--The officers belonging to the Merchants' Independent Detective Police, acting under the direction of J. C. KINNER, their Superintendent, succeeded yesterday in arresting THOMAS MEEKER, charged with stealing a piece of cloth valued at $80 from HERMAN , of No. 108 Duane-street;

There are not wanting indications that the British Parliament, now that Fenianism has been squelched, will undertake to deal in ear nest with the trouble which presents itself in the shape of the Established Church of Ire land; called, by a figure of speech, " TheUnited Church of England and Ireland."

A few evenings since a reunion was hold by the chess amateurs of Brooklyn, on occasion of the formal opening of their new subscription rooms at No. 4 1/2 Fulton-avenue. At the hour stated in the in vitations, 8 P. M., no less than fifty visitors must have been present, the Now-York Club being representedby Messrs. THOMPSON, WORRALL, SCHULTZ, Capts.

To the Editor of the New York Times: Will you allow the attention of the Commissioners for locating the new Post-office to be called to some considerations that, it not at this time important in determining the site of the new Post-office, are likely to become controlling with reference to its convenience and adaptability to the public wants, as soon as it will be erected.

UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT. Levi S. Blossmays. The Milwaukee and Chicago Railroad Company.--The plaintiff in this case applied to the Court below to have the sale of the defendants road upon the foreclosure of a certain mortgage confirmed to him--he having been the highest bidder at the sale, (which was not accepted,) and the sale having been subsequently discontinued at the direction of the solicitor for the complainants in the foreclosure proceedings.

The New-Orleans Picayune announces the re lease of Ex-Senator GWIN from Fort Jackson, and says: "Every effort of the Doctor failed to discover or to elicit the faintest intimation of the causes of his imprisonment. Gen. SHERIDAN, who acted toward the Doctor with every kindness and courtesy compati ble with his orders from Washington, appeared to beequally ignorant of the reasons for his imprisonment.

The report of Mr. STEVENS' Committee has the following provision: SEC. 3. Until the 4th day of July, 1870, all persona who voluntarily adhered to the late insurrection, giving it aid and comfort, shall be excluded from the right to vote for members of Congress, and for elec. tort for President and Vice-President of the UnitedStates.

CUNARD.--On Saturday morning, May 26, at No. 124 5th-av., MARY, the wife of E. Cunard. ISAACS.--On Friday, May 25th, at Newtown, Long Island, MARY ANN, daughter of the late I. A. Isaacs. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of 7th-av. and 29th-st., to-day at 2 P. M.

FOREST TREES ON THE PRAIRIES.--We have made reference to an idea which has been originated in the West for encouraging the growth of forest trees on the great treeless Plains between the Missouri River and the Rocky Mountains. The scheme is pro nounced feasible by those best competent to judge;

THE ITALIAN NAVY.--The two most powerful iron-clad vessels which the Italian Govern ment will have for service against the Aus trian Navy in the forthcoming war are of American construction. We refer to the Re d'Italia and Re de Portagalio, built by Mr. WEBB, of this City, for the Italian Government during our late civil war.

The ladies do not understand the new regulation about stopping the cars at the cross streets. Please tell them that if they are bound up town to take the upper cross-walk, and if down town, the lower one. They look daggers at us for not stopping for them until we cross the street, which they would not do,

The Buffalo Commercial quotes a bitter attack upon Secretary SEWARD from the Chicago Tribune, and says: "We do not feel any special call to come to the defence of the Secretary of State, against such ridiculous assaults as the above, for we feel that with the great masses of the loyal people of the North he needs no defence whatever.

ANOTHER INDICTMENT OF DAVIS. There seems to be good authority for denying the correctness of the statement which has been extensively published that a new indictment against JEFFERSON DAVIS has been drawn up in the Attorney General's office since Mr. SPEED'S return to Washington, and that Judge UNDERWOOD'S indictment will be withdrawn and the new one substituted.

EXCELSIOR VP. KNICKERBOCKER. The annual social: union between the Excel sior Club, of Brooklyn, and the Knickerbocker Club, of New-York, took place on the ground of the former at Bedford, on Friday. Various circumstances have pointed out within the last few months that the enlarge ment of the City, whether as regards its popu lation or the number of its buildings, is to be something unprecedented. The architectural adornments of New-York seem likely also tokeep pace with its increase in size.

Sudden death is in many, perhaps the majority of cases ascribed to "heart disease," and persons threatened with that mysterious affection deem them selves incurable and peculiarly the subject of supernatural control. An investigation into the causes of sixty-six sudden deaths in Europe, proves that heart disease, so-called by the physicians, was present in only two of the subjects.

Before Dr. BOARDMAN'S speech on Monday morning, in the Old School, the memorial of "Dr. Bob's" Convention was presented, signed by one hundred and eleven ministers and elders, urging, without defining the precise form, the action which Dr. MAC LEAN'S resolutions have already defined. Dr. VAN DYKE succeeded in getting his paper, declar ing the deliverance of the past five years not obligatory upon the Churches, referred to the Committee.

The steamsips and America, with advices to the 16th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Marnion, from New-Orleans, and the Delaware, from Philadelphia, both arrived at Liverpool May 13. The Laincter, from New-York, arrived at Gravesend May 13.

The Legislature of Montana, before adjourn ing, adopted the following joint resolution: Resolved, by the Council, the House concurring, That we, as a legislative body, return our sincere thanks to Gen. T. F. MEAGHER, Acting-Governor of our Ter. ritory, for the able, prompt and impartial manner in which he has discharged the delicate and responsible duties imcumbent upon him, during our present session.

How many lives, made beautiful and sweet By self-devotion and by self-restraint--Whose pleasure is to run without complaint On unknown errands of the Paraclete-- Wanting the reverence of unshodden feet, Fail of the nimbus which the artists paint Around the shining forchead of the saint, And are in their completeness incomplete.

Almost everybody believes that "an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure," but as a general thing those whose practice conforms the most faithfully to the proverb receives the least credit.

A GRAND INQUEST.--One of the editors of the Gasette, yesterday, had the pleasure of an interview with the members of the Grand Inquest, "in and for the body of the County of Mercer." He found them a very pleasant body of gentlemen, with considerable conversational powers, and a decided inclination to be inquisitiya.

At 8 o'clock last night Contonary Methodist Church was well filled with citizens of both sexes, who had assembled in order to form an association of the young men who desired to cooperate with the ladies belonging to the memorial associations of the city in caring for the graves of the Confederate soldiers in the cemeteries near the city.
BRITISH AMERICAN CONFEDERATION.--Late reports from New-Brunswick indicate, beyond doubt, that the party of Confederation are carrying everything before them in the elections.

The Inman line steamer City of Boston, Capt. BROOKE, which left Liverpool at noon on the 16th, and Queenstown on the 17th of May, arrived here yesterday. The steamship Aleppo, from Southampton, May 15, arrived last evening. The steamer Scotland, of the National line, sailed simultaneously with the City of Boston.

Gen. S. S. ALCORN, United States Senator elect from Mississippi, has made application to Gen. FISKE, of the Freedmen's Bureau, for a teacher of a freedmen's school at Friar's Point, Mississippi. All the Freedmen's Courts were abolished to-day by the Assistant Commissioner, the law of the State making colored persons competent witnesses in all civil courts having gone into operation.

Rev. Dr. HORNBLOWER, of Paterson, N. J., followed Mr. GALLOWAY yesterday in a constitutional argument to prove error in the mode of procedure. He had voted against the resolution sending these Commissioners from their seats, and he maintained, in a clear and earnest argument, delivered in legal style, that the Assembly was impairing its sacred anthority and purity by taking this mode of rendering justice to the accused.

The first game of the season between the Connecticut Clubs belonging to the National Associa Lion, was played here on Thursday, between the Yale College Base-Ball Club of New Haven and the Charterclosely of Hartford. It was closely contested through.

We are informed by Mr. JOHN LOMBARD, a Gross Tete planter, that the distress of the Acadians who resided along Gross Tete and the neighboring bayous, and whose homesteads have been completely overflowed, is of the most heart-rendering character.

At a meeting of the members of the Congregation of St. Charles Borromeo yesterday the following resolutions were adopted : Whereas; In the recent demise of the late Dr. PISE we have all lost a common father, a kind and model Pastor, a great and good man, a distinguished scholar, and a refined gentleman, who, by his kindly qualities, has won the respect of all denominations;

THE TIRADE AGAINST SEOETARY M'OULLOCH. The scene in the House, yesterday afternoon, at the closing of the consideration of the Tax Bill in Com mittee of tile Whole, was exceedingly unfortunate, es. pecially for the irascible Mr. STEVEN, who was the head and front of the onslaught upon the Secretary ofthe Treasury.

CANARD.--On Saturday, May 26, MARY, the wife of Edward Cunard, and daughter of the late Bache McEvers. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral services at Trinity Church, on Tuesday, the 29th inst., at 31/2 o'clock P. M., without furthers invitation.

The excitement of the last seven months, consequent on the disturbances in October, 1865, and the occurrences that followed them, has been succeeded by comparative calm, and all parties are now anxiously awaiting the publication of the report of the Royal Commission, of the conclusion of whose labors in the examination of witnesses you have been already informed.

The novelty of the stringent provisions of the new Excise Law is rapidly wearing off, and there is very little new to say upon the subject. Yesterday was the fourth Sabbath since the Excise Law came into operation, and the arrests for violations have diminished each week in steady ratio, until now the number is scarcely worth recording.

The later news from Europe this morning bears out the comparatively favorable esti mate of the financial and political situation, which was brought by the arrivals on Satur day. The Auxerre speech, as might have been looked for, is found upon closer examination,to admit of a variety of interpretations.

The object of a just plan of reconstruction must be, not vengeance but safety. To protect the nation from harm, or to secure the rights of loyal men, we may take any step that is necessary. To punish the Southern people, or to wreak upon them the revengeful feelings which not unnaturally survive a great conflict, we should do nothing.

Broadway, between Bloocker and Amitysts. THIS EVENING, commencing at 7 1/2 o'clock, THE COLLEEN BAWN. Characters by Messrs, C. Walcot, W. H. Norton, Chas. Peters, Miss Tone Burke, Miss Blanche Grey, Miss Mary Carr.

Dr. COOPER'S report to the Secretary of War touching the health of JEFFERSON DAVIS has met a characteristic reception on the part of the Copperhead press. The World finds in it evidence of "the torture" of the prisoner, and the vilest epithets of the language are heaped upon the Government as the responsible author is his sufferings.

The steamship City of Boston and the Aleppo reached this port yesterday, with one day's later news from Europe. The war question was still un settled, but a general impression was prevailing that the maintenance of peace was somewhat more as sured than at previous advices, Rumors of an approaching Congress continued to circulate;

The total loss by tile ire last evening will prob-. ably reach $220,000. Mr, BLOW'S loss, $150,000; in sured $130,000. STUDLEY Co.'s loss, $20,000; in sured on the building, $3,000; other Insurance unknown.

The Southern Pacific Railroad promises the completion of forty-five miles of road in two months. The Levee Commissioners leave for Washington on Tuesday next to ask for Congressional assistance. They have drawn up a memorial, and will send it through those parts of the Union interested in theMississippi levees.

The Seventh Annual Convention of the Board of Delegates of American Israelites held the Inaugural meeting at the Thirty-fourth-street Synagogue at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The session was well attended, no less than forty-eight congregations being represented, each by two deputies, and the assemblage this even ing will be characterized by a gathering of the repre-. sentatives of no less than seventy-six of the religiousorganizations in the United States.

The stockhade prison at Andersonville still remains intact, with its double walls, its forts, its deadline, a grim and silent memorial of cold-blooded cruelty toward helpless prisoners, which is without parallel either in ancient or modern history.

Here,. for instance, is his Sunday "starvation:"

THE BOMBARDMENT OF VALPARAISO--DISCUSSION IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS.--A lively conversation on the bombardment of Valparaiso took place in the House of Commons on the 15th instant. We give the substance of the discussion in other columns.

Mr. STEVENS made rather a melancholy ex hibition of bad temper in the House on Sat urday. A. clause in the Tax Bill under dis cussion provided for the appointment of a Special Revenue Commissioner by the Secre tary of the Treasury, to fill a bureau in thatDepartment;

UNWHOLESOME, SLEEP,.--Somo of the news papers are sadly exercised because they learn that Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS is unable to sleep soundly-that he is nervous, and that the very slightest, noise disturbs his rest. The main cause of complaint seems. to be that the treadof the sentinels afflicts his sensitive ear.

The Buffalo Express seems disposed, without really being able, to controvert the opinions we recently expressed concerning the possi ability of a modification of existing political parties, to meet new emergencies and neces sities. With reference to what we said of the manner in which the Republican party was subjected to such a charge at the outset of thewar, the Express remarks:

The following is a schedule of meals furnished JEFF. DAVIS for a long time past. The most incredu lous, in reading it over, will see that he has been well cared for, and that It turnishes a palpable contro version of the repeated false assertions of ill-treat. ment, poorly-cooked meals, and their inequality inpoint of delicacy and sustenance.

A terrific tornado swept over the lower portion of this borough last evening. The immense covered bridge spanning the Lackawana River at Sxth-street was bodily lifted a distance of six loot in the air, and fell into the river a mass of ruins. A boy who had just crossed the bridge was carried some fifty feet up the river. Several barns, outhouses, ,were demolished.

The City of Boston brought the intelligence that Lord Lyon won the Derby. This horse is owned by the Duke of BEAUFORT. We shall have further particulars about the race by the Persia, The eighty-seventh Derby had the largest number of nominations ever known, and thisyear's prize was unusually rich.

Messrs. O'CONNOR and SHEA left this morning for New-York, having been in close consultation with JEFERSON DAVIS most of yesterday and to-day. They found him in better health than they anticipated, and though somewhat worn from his long conefinement, still in possession of his keenest faculties and alive to the importance and engrossing nature of the issues involved in his expected trial.

Last evening a meeting of the Association for the Advancement of Science and Art was held at the rooms of that Society in the Cooper Institute. Dr. J. W. RICHARDS occupied the chair. A paper was read by Hon. LORENZO SHERWOOD on " Railroads for carrying freight to and from the City of New-York.

In spite of the anticipations of the Convention the second meeting of the Board ot Delegates of American Israelites was not very largely attended last evening. Still there was a goodly assemblage present, numbering many devines of note and visitors of distinction.

CLRMENT, of Philadelphia, and NELLIE, second daughter of George Chatterley, of Brooklyn. No cards. MILES--CUTHBERT.--In Kingston, C. W., on Tuesday, May 22, by Rev. Mr. Elwell, CHARLES C. MILES, of New-York, and Miss EMILY M., oldest daughter of Rev. W. H. Cuthbert of Barriefield. Township of Pittsburgh.

Before Commissioner Belts. It may be remembered that towards the close of active hostilities Col. Baker made some demonstrations in and about this City by way of arresting bounty-jumpers and other alleged offenders against the laws of the country, which for a time impressed the public with the idea that Col. Baker was a paragon of patriotism and zealous defender of the interests of the Republic.

Dr. JAMES CHRISTIE, the Superintendent of the Battery Barracks, reports that they are not yet cleared of the Government arms which were taken there for storage after the termination of the war. Yet sufficient room has been made for the accommodation of twenty families, and other buildings are soon to be ready for the reception of as many as are likely to offer.

Emigrants tire pouring into this port now in full volume. The arrivals last week num bored ten thousand five hundred, and a sin gle ship yesterday brought over a thousand passengers from Liverpool. They come ofcourse from the old hives of population.

AULD.--On Monday evening, May 28, after a short but severe illness, ELIZA, wife of John R. Auld, in the 31st year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 118 West 23th-st., on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock. A LCOCK.--On Monday, May 28, ADELE., wife of Jas., Alcock of this City.

The appeal and complaint of ROBERT J. BRECKINRIDGE and others against the Synod of Kentucky was before the Old School Assembly to-day, but little progress was made, the time being mainly occupied in deciding who were the real parties in the case, as an attempt had been made to couple the complaint of Mr. McMILLEN against the same Synod with that of Dr. BRECKINRIDGE.

THE COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL BANKS. The Chair appointed the following Committee to investigate the condition of the Naitonal Banks, in accordance with the resolution adopted on Thursday last: Messrs. Wilson, Henderson, Van Winkle, Johnson and Buckalew.

The Keyport Weekly Star states that a great addition to the mineral resources of New-Jersey has been made by the discovery of extensive beds of brown coal in the counties of Middlesex and Mon mouth. This article of fuel is comparatively new in the United States, but it has been long known and used in many paris of Germany, where the beds varyfrom ten to fifty feet in thickness.

Steam Fire Engine Company No. 4, of Boston, are making arrangements to attend the opening of the Industrial Exhibition at Paris, accompanied by their steam fire engine. A public meeting has been called in Faneuil Hall for Thursday noon. in reference to reconstruction.

Ships Adelaide, Cutting, St. John, N. B., Williams Gulon; Elize Ruger, (Brem.,) Schwers, Kanagawa, Merchant Carman. Barks Trinity, Hurtz, Clenfuegos, O. L. wright Co.; Edward, (Pruss.,) Halberston, St. John, N. B., Ruprecht Foster; Viator, (Norw.,) Lorensen, Valenoia, Funch, Meincke Wendt.

Mr. JAMES STEPHENS, the C. O. I. R., on Sunday afternoon attended a Convention of the Fonian Brotherhood at Jersey City. There was a large number of delegates present, and pledged to Mr. STEPHENS the allegiance of their several Circles. A considerable amount of business was transacted, and the meeting was addressed by Mr. STEPHENS.

The Mexican Imperial Consul has received official dispatches from Mazatlan of May 16, stating that the Liberals attacked the garrison of Hermosillo on the 4th inst., and, after a bloody struggle, captured and pillaged the town. Imperial forces subsequently arrived, and, after killing 200 of the Liberals, drovecut the rest and recaptured nearly all their booty.

A heavy rain falling all day yesterday created much apprehension for the wheat crop, as it is thought that unseasonable moisture will produce rust. Whole fields of grain in Santa Clara County are reported to have been prostrated. The steamer Del Norte, from Eureka, has arrived, bringing $10,000 in treasure.

NEW-JERSEY CLASSICAL AND SCIENTIFIC INSTITUTE AT HEIGHTSTOWN.--The corner stone of the brown-stone edifice now building by the Baptist denomination in New-Jersey, will be laid with appropriate ceremonies, at Heightstown, on Thursday, June 14.

In steamship Sheridan, from New-Orleans--Arthur H. Clark, Mrs. and Miss Devon, Mrs. Sarrat, J. Monleym, D. B. Claveril, A. Shorret, A. Vernenil, C. Espenau, Jos. Larue, Mrs. Larue and 2 children, F. Stenwood, wife, 2 children and servant, Mr. Seligny, wife and child, A. Seligny, S. T. Green.

CONGRESS. In the Senate, yesterday, Messrs. WILSON, HENDERSON, VAN WINKLE, JOHNSON and BUCHALEW were appointed a Committee to investigate the condition of the National Banks. The bill to remove land grants to the State of Missouri and Arkansas, to construct a railroad from the Mississippi River to the Texas boundary, was passed.

The entire book-making craft in England, from paper-makers and printers to artists and authors, seem to be exhausting their energies just now in illustrating natural history so as to add to the inherent attractiveness of the studyof this great science.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your paper of this morning contain a letter from some person at Washington on "Indian Appro priations," which would deserve no notice if it had come to the public through a less respectable channel.

WALSH, of the same Company, who perished at the Academy of Music on the night of the 21st inst., was commenced by Coroner GAMBLE yesterday, at the Seventeenth Precinct Station-house. THE REPUBLICAN SENATORIAL CAUCUS. The Repuglican Senators were in caucus again today. The reconstruction plan was under consideration, the object being to harmonize if possible section.

The statement by the Emperor NAPOLEPN that he detested the treaty of 1815, need scarcely have aroused any new suspicions of his sincerity upon the subject of French ag grandizement, Its provisions, while they were intended to assert the principle of legiti macy among European sovereigns, were ex pressly aimed at the extinction of the BONAPARTE family as a ruling power.

Hon. THOMAS B. LAIGHTON, Wheel Name is familiar to everyone who has ever visited the pleasant watering-places on the narrow sea coast of New-Hampshire, died at his residence at the Isles of Shoals, on Friday, May 18, at the age of about 60 years. He was a native of Portsmouth, N. H., and his boyhood and early manhood were passed in that town.

The London Economist and many English journals have commented in a manner not unfriendly, but critical, on the unhappy sep ration between the President and Congress, as showing an inherent defect in our Consti tuition. They speak of the differences as a " dead-look" in our legislative machinery, as an interruption of the whole workings of Government, and as preparing for revolutionand disturbance.

At Newport, R. I., a few days ago, a soldier from the fort, about two-thirds drunk, was playing on the wharf with a largo New foundland dog, noted for his sagaoity and good nature. The animal seemed to like the sport as much as the man, but finally the contest became warm, and the dog raising upon his hind logs, placed his fore paws upon the breast of thesoldier.

COUNTERFEIT CURRENCY.--Counterfeit fifty-cent currency bills seem to be decidedly more plentiful at present than they have been for some time past. Until lately, we have had somewhat of a lull in the business of counter-feiting; but the recent appearance of large volumes of genuine

The World attempts to palliate its virulent attacks upon the Secretary of State byalleg ing that that statesman "took pains in his Auburn speech to traduce the Democratio Party." Ergo, the World is at liberty to traduce Mr. SEWARD.

[OFFICIAL.] BOARD OF ALDERMEN. STATED SESSION.--NEW-YORK, May 28, 1868. Present--John Brice, Esq., President; Aldermen Moore, Coman, Norton, McBrien, Fwnn, Gedney, Ely, Rera, Reilly, Masterson, Varnum, O'Brien, McGiouis, Ven Voorhis. The President being absent at roll-call, on motion of Alderman Van Voorhis Alderman Norton was called to the chair. Minutes of last meeting were read and approved.

It has always seemed to us that the extreme measures urged by what is called the Radical section of the Union Party, in regard to the States lately in rebellion, were certain to de stroy the ascendancy of that party and throw the country back into the hands of the rebelsand Copperheads.

In the midst of the discussions and rumors concerning a general European war it may have escaped attention that Prussia herself is passing through an internal struggle of searcely less significance than that which attaches to the international conflict. Or rather, the crisis has just been passed, and the issue postponed until--or a new one prepared for--next December.

THEATRE FRANCAIS.--The French Theatre was seen to much better advantage last evening than on the occasion of its opening. The house was completely filled, and although, as before, the smell of paint was almost intolerable, it presented a brighter and more finished aspect, and people felt comparatively comfortable. We have omitted to speak of the seating facilities of the house.

THE SOUTH LOOKING UP.-Amid the large number of quite bad papers we daily receive from the Southern States, we are pleased to frequently find one containing an article which enkindles our hopes for their future. Such an one is the Southern Georgian, recentlystarted at the town of Bainbridge.

RELIGION IN BROADWAY.--Broadway seems to be an unfortunate place for churches. Within short time three of the places of worship in that street have met an untimely fate; Dr. OSGOOD'S (formerly Dr. DEWEY'S) was transformed into a theatre, Dr. CHAPIN'S has been converted into a place of business, and the fine old Church of St. Thomas is being torn down to give place to stores.

Mining shares are somewhat firmer. Ophir, 400; Chollar Potosi, 295; Savage, 837; Alpha, 320; Belcher, 210; Yellow Jacket, 615; Imperial 112, Legal-tenders are quoted at 753/4. Arrived--ship Harry Bluff. OLIVER, from New-York. SAN FRANCISCO, Sunday, May 37.

ARRIVALS IN THE CITY,--Maj.-Gen. J. W. Turner, Brig,-Gen. E. N. W. Smith, Maj. H. Jewett, U.S.A.: Lieut. Cox, U.S. N., and Princess Salm Salm, Washington, are at the Hoffman House, Hbn. William Bigler, Pennsylvania; Gen. H. L. Robinson, Washington; Hon. Richard Yates, Minois, and Hon. W. H. Hooper, Utah, are at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

The Rhode Island General Assembly met here to-day to inaugurate the Government for the ensuing year. In honor of Gen. BURNSIDE, the governor elect, there is an universal demonstration. Nearly all the militia of the State are in line. The town is full of visitors, and the ancient election ceremonies are being observed with due pomp.

RECIPROCITY.--The first official statement of the late reciprocity negotiations comes to us in the report of the British Parliamentary debate, received last night, and a portion of which is published in another column thismorning.

IMPRESSIVE MASONIC FUNERAL CEREMONIES.--The obsequies of Mr. WILLIAM F. KEMP. master builder, who died at his residence, corner of Sixth-street and North First, E. E., on Sunday last, were celebrated at the Reformed Dutch Church, Fourth-street, yesterday afternoon, The members of Progressive Lodge, F. and A. M.;

THE STRIKE IN THE SHIP-YARDS.--The very ex tensive combination of carpenters, caulkers and others, so far from subsiding appear to be on the increase, and has become a serious matter for consideration by shipbuilders andowners.

WAR CANARDS IN EUROPE.--They are now daily enjoying the same sort of contradictory sensational dispatches in the capitals of Eu rope that we suffered from in this country in the early days of the late war. All sorts of stories are set afloat hourly, and nobodyknows what to believe about anything.

UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE. Before Commissioner Betts. The examination in the case of James Hughes, charged with defrauding recruits out of their bounty, came up before the Commissioner again yesterday afternoon. James Reilly recalled : When I was in Odd Fellows' Hall, Hughes remained in the mustering-room, assisting in the examination of the men;

THE SOUTHERN PRESS.--If the people of the South knew the damage done them by the rabid newspapers which they support, as we know it here, they would very quickly compel them to change their tone. In a political point of view, these papers are in a large measure responsible for the treatment the Southern States are receiving at the hands ofCongress.

THE SENATOIIIAL CAUCUS. The Republican Senators held another caucus this morning, and finally agreed upon amendments to the Joint resolutions from the Reconstruction Committee as they passed the House. Senator HOWARD reported the result to-day attained, The first amendment is to the first section, and de clares all persons born in the United States, and sub ject to the jurisdiction theroreof, are citizens of theUnited States and the States wherein they reside.

MR. McGEE AND THE FENIANS.--We make the following extract from a letter addressed by Hon. THOMAS D'AROY McGEE, Minister of Agriculture in Canada, to a friend in this City. Mr. McGEE'S opinions on the subject of Fenianism are not unknown to our readers.

In the case of ISHAM HENDERSON, forty-three depositions of prominent citizens of wheeling, Va., as to the reputation for truth and veracity of WM. MCKAY HOGE, one of the witnesses for the prosecution, were introduced. Thirty-two of the deponents agreed that his reputation was bad, and nearly all of them testified they would not believe him under Oath.

The steamship St. David from Liverpool May 17, via Londonderry May 18, passed Father Point yesterday en route to Quebec. The Royal mail steamship Persia, Capt. LOTT, which left Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 19th, and Queenstown on the evening of the 20th May, arrived here last evening.

A PERSONAL EXPLANATION. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, rose to a personal explanation. On Saturday morning last his attention had been called to an imputation made by inuendo and indirection in the Boston Commonwealth, emanating from some one in this city. He immediately telegraphed to the editor of that paper for the name of the author. He had not yet named it.

FRENCH THEATRE.--The second performance of Mr. EICHBERG'S comic opera, "The Doctor of Alcantara," will be given here to-night. The complete success of the first representation leaves no doubt on the subject of the fate of the second. It will, we hope, be witnessed by an anxious crowd, who, we think, will not go away disappointed.

A heavy blow long suspended has fallen at last. WINFIELD SCOTT, renowned and peerless, has gone to his rest. After years of lingering, away from his home, but surrounded by the exponents of the art he loved so well, and attended by all that respectful affec tion could bring to his dying couch, he closed a long and eventful career yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock,at West Point, on the Hudson.

This morning's Commercial contains the fol lowing: "There is a movement of the Fenians now going on, Quite a number of them loft the city yesterday, bound for Canada. Large shipments of arms have been made Northward within a few days.

The many friends, professional and personal, of Dr. HENRY G. Cox, of this City, have been much grieved at his death, which occurred yesterday morn. ing, at his residence, No. 104 West Twenty-sixth-street. Dr. Cox had only reached his 47th year; he was en gaged in a large and excellent practice, and numbers who have profited by his skill or his friendship, nowmourn their loss.

At the meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health, yesterday, Commissioner BERGEN read a let ter from the acting Coroner of Coney Island, detailing the finding of several human bodies which had been sewed up in bed-ticking and undoubtedly cast over board from a ship somewhere near the harbor of New York, and which had been washed ashore on theConey Island beach.

AULD.--On Monday evening, May 28, after a short but severe illness, ELIZA, wife of John r. Auld, in the 31st year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 118 West 28th-st., on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock. ALCOCK.--On Monday, May 28, ADELE A., wife of Jas. Alcock, of this City.

A fire was discovered in the north wing of Congress Hall at 1 o'clock this morning, and now the whole building is in ruins. Loss $200,000. Much of the furniture was saved. The amount of insurance is not yet ascertained. Messrs. HATHORN CO. intended opening the hotel of Wednesday. No other hotel was injured.

When, some two weeks since, a few friends of Gen. SCOTT escorted him to West Point, they felt that they were officiating, if not as pall-bearers, at least as accompanying the illustrious veteran to a bourne from which hewould not return.

THE NEW FENIAN FOOLERY.--The Fenians of the Roberts-Sweeney stripe are again making loud threats of an immediate movement upon Canada. To all this the C. O. F. B. STEPHENS is inflexibly opposed, but the opposite factionwill not listen to his advice.

In the Supreme Court to-day Messrs. DURANT and HUNT, always Union men, argued in favor of the validity of Confederate notes as issued by a bel ligerent Power; and Judge CAMPBELL, late Assistant Confederate Secretary of War, and Mr. MORSE, lateConfederate Judge, argued against them.

WHIST.--The following instructive fact, stated by Mr. LAWRENCE, author of Guy Livingstone, in his recently published novel, Sans Meroi, must, it is believed, be useful to a class of whist-players, for whom, without reformation, the fate of "eleven thousand Englishmen" is reserved.

We regret that the pressure upon our columns precludes the publication of a full report of the Archbishop's sermon preached yesterday at the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, over the remains of his beloved friend and teacher, the late Dr. PISE.

DEATH OF MRS. GEN. CLARKE.--Mrs. CAROLINE E. T. CLARKE, wife of our friend, Gen. DE WITT C. CLARKE, departed this life on Wednesday morning last. An invalid for years, her death put an end to a life in its latter days of most poignant pain and suffering.

A large meeting of ship-owners and business men was held to-day in the Board of Trade Rooms, in reference to the strike of the workmen. WILLIAM ROPES was chosen Chairman, and NATHAN CROWELL and JAMES CURTIS Secretaries, Mr. ROPES, on taking the chair, said that the business before the meeting was most important.

THE SAXONIA.--This steamer, Capt. T. E. MEIER, which arrived in the river at 4 o'clock P. M., on Monday, after a rapid run from Hamburg, came into dock on receiving a clean certificate of health from the Medical Superintendent of Quarantine, and sailed hence yesterday (Tuesday) evening, with a full compliment of passengers, 48,075 francs in specie, and a large cargo.

In the Old School Assembly of the Presbyterian Church the appeal of Dr. R. J. BRECKENBIDGE was laid aside, and the report on the Louisville Presbytery was taken up and debated by Dr. W. L. BRECKIN-RIDGE and Dr. HUMPHREY in opposition, and Hon. A. K. CLARKE in favor, but no action was reached.

PETITIONS. Mr. GRIMES reported from the Naval Committee a number of petitions for an increase of pay of naval officers and asked that the Committee be discharged from the further consideration of the subject. Mr. GRIMES said an order had been issued by the Navy Department, Order No. 27, which to a certain extent met the request of the petitioners. The Committee was discharged from further consideration of the petition.

THE CITY CARS.--The Board of Health would not go amiss in giving a little attention to the condition of some of the City Railroad cars. There are lines upon which they are kept in a degree of filthiness all but intolerable; and these, as is natural, lines on whichh there is a vast amount of travel, and which consequently make most out of the pubic and owe most to it.

The following letter from Dr. BISSELL, of the Hospital-ship Falcon, was sent to the Health-Officer to-day: Dr. SWINBURNE: I have to report the arrival of the steamship Union, Capt. PALMER, from Liverpool May 12, at this station. She sailed with 481/2 passengers, and on her arrival here many of them were down with cholera.

THE PUBLIC DEBT--LETTER FROM THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY. A letter from the Secretary of the Treasury to Hon. JOHN SHERMAN was ordered to be printed by the Sen. ate, together with the accompanying official statements. From the papers it appears that the amount of the public debt redeemable May 1, 1867, is $787,041,420; May 1, 1869, $407,

Several hundred mon arrived hero at an early hour this morning from the West said to be Fenians, though they claim to be laborers en route for Callfor. nia. It is said that they and their brother Fenlans are in secret session here to-day.

His Excellency, Gov. FENTON, arrived home this evening, and was given a public reception. Cannon and fireworks greeted his arrival, and he was escorted with music to Jones' Hall, where he spoke at length on State and National topics to a crowded house.

The Borad met pursuant to the following call: NEW-YORK, May 30, 1866. D T. Valentine, Ewq., Clerk of the Common Council: DEAR SIR: You are hereby requested to notify the members of the Board of Aldermen to meet in special session on Wednesday, the thirtieth instant, at two o'clock P. M., in their Chamber, for the purpose of taking such action as they may deem necessary relative to the demise of Lieutenant General Scott.

At the opening of the Board on Tuesday Commissioner ACTION presented two hundred and seventy indorsed applications, and on his motion the Board granted License, making the total number of venders licensed to date five thousand one hundred and forty-one.

The Supreme Court has decided against MOSES FOX, claimant of $300,000, under the autograph will of JOHN MACDONOUGH. The Cities of Baltimore and New-Orleans were defendants. Judge HYAMS disented from the decision. The majority of the Court say that the proof of the band-writing is not decisive; that the testimony of NATHAN CASE, one of the witnesses, is not credilable,

DUNN--PETERS.--At the residence of the bride's parent, on Tuesday, May 29, by Rev. J. Clement French, ALEXANDER, M. DUNN and Miss OLARA H., daughter of Charles, all of Brooklyn.

LATEST FROM THE MOON.--The Tribune of yesterday, in reiterating its platform of Universal Amnesty and Impartial Suffrage," says: "We do not ask that suffrage shall be absolutely universal, but that no qualifications be exacted, no conditions or restrictions imposed, which do not bear equally on all colors and races.

What purpose Mr. WATKIN may have had in the speech recently delivered in the House of Commons, is not very clear. If it were to elicit information pertaining to the position of the reciprocity question at Washington, he might have learned from the newspapers all that was subsequently stated in behalf of the British Government.

GEN. SWEENEY AND THE FENIANS.--We remarked, yesterday, that no one is better acquainted than Gen. SWEENEY with the knavish, selfish and mercenary character and objects of the men who are associated with him in the Roberts-Fenian movement.

On Tuesday evening the pupils of the Female Art Department gave their seventh annual reception, The rooms were handsomely decorated for the occasion, ana during the evening some fine music was contribute by a band in attendance. Tho exhibition of drawings was especially creditable to both pupils and teachers.

In the Senate yesterday Mr. GRIMES reported adversely on the petitions for an increase of the pay of naval officers. Mr. SPRAGUE called up the joint resolution for the payment of certain Kentucky Home Guards, called into the United States service to repel a rebel invasion under JOHN MORGAN in 1862, which was passed. The reconstruction resolutions were next taken up.
