The Commissioners of Emgration held their regular semi-monthly meeting yesterday afternoon, President VENPLANCK in the chair. At the Democratic Convention to-day, 75 delegates were present. Speeches were made by Gen. WARD, Col. KINNEY, Gen. CRITTENDEN and Ex-Gov. ROBINSON, the President, who characterized the Convention as a mass meeting. A motion to invite every Union man to participate was lost.

Another of the great hotels of Saratoga has been destroyed. Congress Hall, the largest in the place since the United States was burned down, was totally consumed last night. It had just been onlarged and thoroughly renovated, More than $30,000 had been expended in improvements and new furniture, and it was to have been opened for the season to-day.

SUCCESSFUL TRIAL OF A SUBMARINE NOVELTY.--Yesterday afternoon there was a private trial of the Pacific Pearl Company's Submarine Explorer, in the dock foot of North Third-street, Eastern District. The officers of the Company anil a few friends only wore present.

Cotton unchanged; sales 500 bales at 36c.@ 87c. Receipts, to-day, 92 bales. Bank sterling 153. Freights to New-York 1/2c.@3/4c., to Liverpool 3/4d. A tornado swept with destruction over Jackson, Miss., and injured the State House. The Third Michigan Volunteers. 340 strong,

INCENDIARY FIRES.--The Fire Commissioners of this City yesterday considered the propriety of offering a reward of a thousand dollars for the arrest of incendiaries. This measure was stated to be necessary from the great increase and threatened still further increase of the practice of arson.

Since my last letter we have had no later arrivals from Mexico, By the English steamer from St. Thomas we have intelligence from Venezuela. The Grand Citizen, Marshal FALCON, on the 3d assumed his Presidential position and formed his Ministry. Ills predecessor, Gen, BLANCO, has already taken his seat as Representative for the Federal District.

ITALIAN ENTHUSIASM.--There appears to be no lack of national feeling in either of the two principal Powers that are menacing each other with war in Europe; but there is a depth of national feeling and a height of national enthusiasm among the Italian people far greater than in either Austria or Prussia.

There was a large attendance of the owners of fast horses, sporting men, and the lovers of trotting generally,on the Union Course, L. I., yesterday afternoon, to witness the interesting match between Lady Emma and Shark for $2,000, mile heats, best three in five, both going under saddle. Both horses are well known on the trotting turf, Shark being owned by Mr. MARSHALL, of this City,and Lady Emma by Mr. LOUIS PETTEE.

OUR SMALL CURRENCY--The withdrawl of three-cent notes by the Treasury Department has taken them almost entirely out of circultion now-a-days. We are glad of it, for, of all our small currency, they were the poorest and most pitiful, and quickly become the most disgusting and worthless.

A large and highly respectable assemblage of the friends of law and order was gathered into the great hall of the Cooper Institute last evening, The meeting having been called to order by Mr. JOHN FALCONER, Judge SLOSSON was called to the Chair.

Tho New-England Anti-Slavery Society, with GARRISON and QUINCY left out, and WENDELL PHILLITS as its chief helper, held its annual meeting today in the Melodeon. A letter was read from a prominent Salem member, which declared that the South was not yet fit to be reconstructed, coupled the names of JOHNSON and JEFF. DAVIS together,

The Senate on Tuesday made short work of what Mr. STEVENS in the House declared to be the only one of the constitutional amendments reported by the Committee on ReconStruction for which he cared a "snap of his finger."
Gens. STEEDMAN and FULLERTON, who have been investigating the management of the Freedmen's Bureau in Georgia, will report favorably on TILLSON'S administration of affairs.

ATLANTIO VS. HARVARD. Between three and four thousand people assembled at the Capitoline Ground, yesterday, to witness the contest between the champion Atlantics and the Harvard Base Ball Club. The train from Sandusky to-day stopped on account of a broken engine three miles west from here, and was run into by the Day Express train from Toledo. One lady, name unknown, was killed, and four or five other persons seriously and several slightly injured.

THE ORPHEON FESTIVAL--Mr. JEROME HOPKINS' first "Spring-tide Singing Jubilee," on the Plan of the annual festival of the Sons of the Clergy in London, takes place to-day at Cooper institute. The singers are the boys and girls whom Mr. HOPKINS has educated in the art of music.

Another body of men arrived here last night from the West, said to be a Fenian regiment. About one thousand have come altogether, and more are ex pected. Nothing can be learned from the men beyond that they are laborers, bound for California. They have apparently no arms, but it is understood there are plenty secreted here.

EUREKA OF NEWARK VS. HARVARD COLLEGE. The game between these Clubs, played at Newark, yesterday, resulted in the success of the Eurekas by a score of 42 to 39. The Harvard Club showed a decided improvement in their fielding and batting over their game of the day previous with the Atlantics.

The Impartial Suffrage League held a meeting in Fancuil Hall at noon to-day, at which Gov. BUL LOCK presided. The meeting, though not large, was enthusiastic. A series of resolutions were presented, which declare: First-That the same spirit which caused the rebellion still threatens to postpone, and it may, unless conquered,prevent a beneficent and permanent peace.

IN CENTRE-STREET. About 6 o'clock last evening, a fire broke out at No. 41 Centre-street, occupied as a brass finishing shop by BENNETT MOORE. The flames originated from a furnace, setting fire to a work-bench. Officer KAVENEY, of the Sixth Precinct, broke the door open and nut out the flames before they caused any material damage. ARKANSAS.--At the breaking out of the re billion, the State of Arkansas had in her Treasury $800,000 in coin. On the arrival of the Union Army at Little Rock, the rebel Governor and his Cabinet stole the funds, and transported them to the rebel camp of Gen,KIRBY SMITE.

MANHATTAN COLLEGE.--On Wednesday an examination of the higher classes of this institution took place in the presence of some gentlemen desirous of noting the progress of the College. The students were examined in mental philosophy, mathematics and the Greek and Latin Languages. The examination in philosophy, taking in metaphysics, logic and ethics, was conducted in Latin, and the young gentlemen spoke with great case and elegance.

UNITED STATES COMMISSIONERS' OFFICE. Before Commissioner Osborn. Yesterday the Commissioner announced his decision in the case of the United States vs. J. Nelson Luckey. In this case the complainant, Charles Dinning, was a seaman on board the United States steamer Shenandoah at the time of the capture of the prize Ella, and was entitled to a share in the prize money.

ANOTHER REVOLUTION.--The principal fea ture of the Boston Anti-Slavery meetings, just held, was the adoption of the following reso lution-a resolution urging in no indistinct terms the justice and the expediency of an arned uprising of the freed negroes of the South against the constituted authorities andthe white population generally.

Rev., WILLIAM FERGUSON, Commissioner from the Zanesville (Ohio) Presbytery, was expelled from the Old School Assembly to-day, for writing an offensive letter to the Ohio Statesman, and for which he could make no satisfactory explanation. The vote for expulsion was very large. This is the worst case of the kind that has ever occurred. The motion for expulsion was made by Dr. KREBS.

The building on Market-street opposite the Court-house known as Wyman's Hall, recently occu pied as the Metropolitan Theatre, and several adjoin ing stores, were burned to-night. Loss $150,000; partially insured. The loss by the fire of Wednesday night is much larger than was at first supposed. About 2,500 barrels of whisky were burned, The total loss is over $200,000; mostly insured, The Government tax on the whisky was not paid.

NEW WAR TACTICS. Washington has to-day been excessively dull, equal to midsummer stagnation. The only ripple of excitement that we have had was provoked by the Fenian news, giving an account of the novel military tactics and strategy of providing an army with ammunition trains.

THE ORPHEONIST FESTIVAL.--A number of boys and girls--probably 250 in all --took part in, and gave eclat yesterday afternoon to, Mr. JEROME HOPKINS' first "Spring-tide Singing Festival." These represent, inadequately we are informed, the labor of five years of enthusiastic devotion to choir singing, or at least to that branch of it which the young folk can represent.

Fire-Marshal LAWRENCE suspected that the propriotor of the place knew something about the fire, and caused his arrest. The accused was brought before Justice CORNWELL, yesterday, for examination.

The Bulington (Vt,) Free Press announces the death, at Williston, of Hon. WM. H. FRENCH, in the fifty-third year of his age. For a long time he had been a prominent man in State and county. He held various offices in his native town of Williston, and represented it in the Legislature in 1838, 1839, 1846 and 1847.

The marine vivary at Boulogne, erecting under the superintendence of M. EDOUARD BETENCOURT, is intended for the exhibition of adult living fish. The altitude of the rocks will be about 70 feet, and the caverns underneath will have some 12 to 14 feet headway, wherein will be a series of reservoirs, into which sun and air are admitted through fissures.
The U. S. steamer Agawan arrived yesterday from Port Royal. A wreck is reported at Chincoteague, but no particulars. A revenue cutter has been sent to her assistance.

DAVIS' counsel are all in the City, Properatory to proceeding to Richmond, to be present at the opening of the Court there on Monday.

Mr. XAVIER HUELSTAL, proprietor of a restaurant at No. 37 Morcer-street, while closing his premises at 12 o'clock on Friday night, discovered a cigar-box lying in the hallway, As the box had evidently been carefully placed in its position, and were a suspicious look, Mr. HUELSTAL became satisfied that it was of a dangerous character, and he determined to examine it.

About an Hour was used this morning in correcting the minutes of yesterday, in respect to the point whether a reason should be given or not why Dr. ROBERT BRECKINRIDGE declined to argue the case of appeal. The minutes were at last ordered to be corrected by a Committee appointed. As the clerk has written them, it was said that they declare that Dr. BRECKINRIDGE has abandoned the case.

The Montan Post of April 28 has a narrative of an expedition down the Yellowstone. It appears that fifteen men, two women and six children left Virginia City on the 28th of March, traveling with ex teams to the Yellowstone, for the purpose of takingpassage to the States in Mackinaw beats.

EVADING THE LAW.--We understand that those disgraceful places of resort, the "pretty waiter girl" drinking saloons have succeeded in inventing a mode of evading the operations of the Excise Law. The law required them to take a license for the sale of liquor,and to cease its sale altogether at midnight.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In yesterday's (Sunday) issue of the TIMES, in an editorial on forest trees, in which the writer makes a great mistake in supposing that the pollen of maple, elm, or any other forest trees-which he says may now be collected by the bushel-will germinatein the earth and become trees of their kind.

CONDITION OF THE SOUTH.--Our accounts from the South represent the general course of life and industry as on the whole tolerably satisfactory. There is perhaps not as universal activity and prosperity as was promised by sanguine people a year age.

Gen. GRANT's order regarding honors to the memory of Gen. SCOTT, went into effect here to-day. From sunrise to 1 P. M., at intervals of half an hour cannon were fired. At 10 A. M., the troops of the garrison were assembled on parade and the order.

Fire was discovered at 8:80 this morning in Field's Block, destroying that and Rogers' Block. It burst out again at 11 o'clock, destroying Clark's Block and several buildings adjacent, The total loss is estimated at $150,000, which is partly covered by In surance, The sufferers, in addition to the abovenamed, are: J. B. LEIGHT, confectioner: P. G.

All daylong we islanders have been peering out through a driving rain-storm, watching for the Metropolitan Board of Health. But the clouds have been lowery, and we have, therefore, caught only an occasional glimpse of the extremities of our Islandwhen they have lifted.

THE ANTI-EXCISE LAW DEMONSTRATION To DAY,-Our German fellow-citizens have an unqualified right to make the great demon stration which is to come off in Union-square this afternoon, against the Excise Law and its operations in this City. They feel it very hard to be excluded on Sundays from the "Gardens" where they have been accustomedto meet and quaff their lager with their friends;

The condition of things in the Quarantine of New-York to-day is a disgrace and scandal to American civilization and humanity. Let our readers imagine themselves in the place of the poor German and Danish emigrants who have recently arrived here. They leave the European ports perfectly well, looking forward to all the comfort, prosperity and liberty which America holds out to the foreign laborerand farmer.

It is very generally conceded, both here and elsewhere, that there has been a very decided improvement in the political temper of Congress within the past few weeks. The Union majority is far less disposed than it was in February to quarrel with the President, or to insist upon the extreme measures whichit then seemed resolved to pass.

George Smith, appellant, VS. John J. Orion.--The facts in this case have been stated in the TIMES, and they are now sufficiently recapitulated in the opinion of the Court, delivered by Mr. Justice NELSON; This is an appeal from a decree of the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of the State of Wisconsin, held by the District Judge.

THE DAVIS TRIAL. The case of the United States vs. JEFFERSON DAVIS, indicted for treason, which will be called in the United States District Court at Richmond to-morrow, is exciting a great deal of attention and comment here. It is understood that the case will be called pro forma, and postponed by general consent untilthe Fall term.
In this Handsome duodecimo of four hundred and twenty-four pages, we have nine elaborate philosophical and theological essays, by the eminent Professor of Manchester College, London.

The compromise arrived at by the Senate in shaping the Reconstruction Amendment gives evident satisfaction to the great ma jority of the Union Party throughout the Country, The effect of the radical action in the House upon the Fall prospects of theparty has been gradual but unmistakable,

To the Editor of the New York Times: There are few statesmen of our time who are the equals of Mr. SWARD, and there is not one to whom is more justly due the applause of the world. With talents as brilliant as those of METTERNICH, or PALMERSTON, or CAVOUR,he has won greater triumphs. We are acquainted with the history of no publicman which seems to us more worthy of admiration.'

Perhaps in all the history of the Presbyterian Church there never has occurred anything like that which took place in the General Assembly this morning after adopting yesterday's minutes, Hon. Mr, GALLOWAY, of Ohio, road to the Assembly a letter written by Rev. Mr. FERGUSON to the Ohio Stateman, of Colmbus, Ohio, in which there was a most scurrilous attack upon Mr. GALLOWAY and the GeneralAssembly.

A fire was discovered last evening between 7 and 8 o'clock in the grocery-store No. 13 Roosevelt street, kept by CHARLES JEHRING. The door having been forced in, it was found that some shavings were burning beneath the counter. Assistant Fire Marshal H. 0. BAKER made an investigation of the premises, which resulted in finding a quantity of kerosene oilamong tile shavings.

The steamer City of Memphis, from New Orleans to St. Louis, when near Huck's Island, 80 miles below this city, at 7 o'clock this morning ex ploded one or both boilers, which carried away about 60 feet of the cabin and upper works, with the pilot house and the people in that portion of the boat. Thenumber of lives lost is estimated at from 40 to 60.

The Summer season will be inaugurated at several places of amusement to-night, and with attractions which bid fair to make it brilliant and profitable. At which did fair to make it brilliant and profitable. A Niblo's Garden the world-renowned RAVELS commence an engagement. They open in "Robert Macaire," and the "Star of the Rhine." The troupe numbers upward of forty persons, and includes the three RAVELS, GARRIEL, FRANCOIS and ANTOINE.

In steamship Hermann, from Bremen, Newhaus, Miss M. Rute, Mrs. Dickman, C. Riemlin, Miss A. Schneider, L. Morgenthau and family, C. Graydon, C. Thamam, E. Habick and lady, L. Cantador, Mrs. T. Fulton and child, T. Hahnweeller and family, Mr. Wolff, H. Gmelon, Conroy Hutchinson, E. Wiener, W. Shirley and lady, F. Hannauer and family, P. Boshar, F. Meyer, H. Peters, A. Mohrbach, B. Remers and child.

The Spring meeting of the Passaic County As sociation, which commences at Paterson, to-morrow, (Tuesday) has brought together from the Southern and Western States several racing stables to fulfil theirengagements at this and other Northern meetings.

There is a premature, and, we must say, an unsatisfactory ending to the Fenian ex pedition on the Niagara frontier, Of course the pretended invasion turns out to be what we have steadily Characterized it-a more con spiracy of lawless ruffians to create interna tional disturbance and secure plunder, underthe guise and pretence of a patriotic uprising.

The following new cases have occurred since last report : Michael Lutz, Denmark ; Michael Guinness, aged 62 years, Ireland ; Amanda Innerstaden, 31, Sweden; Inger Parson, 52, Sweden; Child, 2, Sweden ; Gusta Olsen, 17, Norway; Martha Longlete, 3 months, Sweden; Ida Monson, 2 years.

The Fenians evacuated Fort Erie last night, and most of them attempted to reach this shore, but only a small number succeeded. About 700 were gobbled by the United States boats guarding the river, and are now prisoners under the United States steamer Michigan's guns at Black Rock. The English forces under Col. PEACOCK are now in possession of Fort Erie without a skirmish.

An adjourned session of the United States Court for the District of Virginia will commence in this city tomorrow. Judge UNDERWOOD has not yet arrived, but is expected in the morning, J. T. BRADY, of New York, WM. B. REED, of Phildelphia, GEO, V. BROWN, of Baltimore, associate counsel for JEFF DAVIS, arrived this morning, and are stopping at the Exchange Hotel, O. O'CONON and GEO. SHEA will ar.rive in a day or two.

I am a planter, and was formerly a lave. holder to some extent, and I fully and cordially acquiesce in the action of the Government which gave freedom to the slaves, and now I conceive it to be the duty and the Interest of the country, and of the Gov ernment, to adopt such measures as will beet pro. mote the material, intellectual and religious interestof the race.

Cotton dull; sales 200 bales; 35c.@36c. for middlings: to-day's receipts 428 bales. Sterling 56. The levee at Alexandria has given way, and the town is flooded, The entire Red River Country is devastated. Sailed on the 30th, Zeuobia for Boston; to-day, George Washington and Fund Shuey, for New-York; St. Louis, for Boston.

Gene. STEEDMAN and FULLERTON hold an in teresting conference this afternoon with the Freed men in the Springfield Church, A number of promi nent citizens were present, The Commissioners stated the object of the interview, and asked thefreedmen to give their views, pro and con. The freed.

The steamship Marathon, from Liverpool May 22, and the Hermann, from Southampton May 23, arrived at this port yesterday. The European crisis remained unchanged. A state ment that all the Powers had consented to a Congress is said to be premature, but it is confirmed that theinvitations had been sent out.

The steamships Maralhon and Hermann reached this port last evening, with three days later newsfromEurope. The German question was still unsettled, nor was anything definite known concern ing the proposed Congress. Meanwhile, peace dem onstrations on a large scale were taking place in Prus sia, and serious disturbances were reported, occasioned by calling out the reserves.

BOGERT.--At Utica, on Sunday, June 3, in his 80th year, THOMAS L. ROGERT, formerly of White Stone, Long Island. BREWSTER.--On Sunday, June 3, CHARLOTTE, wife of Henry Brewster, of this City, and daughter of W.W. Draper, of Greenfield, Mass. Funeral services at Calvary Church, on 4th-av on Tuesday, 5th inst., at 101/2 A.M.

ITALIAN SCHOOL AT THE FIVE POINTS.--The day sessions of this school, as before stated, commenced on the 1st inst., at their rooms, No. 110 Centre-street, with an attendance of sixty-nine, Doubtless this number will be increased, but as if stands, it gives the assurance that at least so many are for the time removed from the temptations to early corruption, sin and crime which are the characteristics of the Five Points.

There is so manifest a plausibility about negotiation as a means of reconciling antago nisms and removing difficulties, that first im pressions are almost 'always in its flavor. What more commendable than an effort to avert war? And what more likely to avert war than a conference of Powers involved in trouble, with Powers having a common interest in thepreservation of peace?

It is always pleasant to record the successes of our neighbors. Three successes were made last evening at three of our best houses of amusement. At Niblo's the RAVELS--the RAVELS, strong in brotherhood and in the knowledge of what can be done among themselves--appeared to an overflowing audience. At the Winter Garden Mr. BROUGHAM made his ventree in "Playing with Fire."

Among the acts of special legislation passed during the last session at Albany, we notice the "Concurrent Resolution", requesting and authorizing the Governor of this State to confer the brevet rank of Major-General on a gentleman of this City, well known by his nom de plume of "Anchor", who has contributed largely during the war to the support of the Administration, and written much in connection with military movements.

During the past week the city has been ?? or teams-mostly ox teams--on their way to the Missouri River, to fetch along the Mormon poor immigration. These teams are contributed by all the settlements in the Territory, and number about rive hundred, mostly ??-yoke teams, Accompanying them are afew mule teams.

The steamer Montana, from the Columbia River, brings $6,500 in treasure. Our markets are generally dull. Sales of Grant's Candles at 23c., and 1,800 boxes Macy's Adamantine at 22 1/2c. Nearly 300,000 lbs. of American shipping grade wool have been sold at from 18c. to 22c. Choice Dry Hides sell freely at 13 1/2c.

The naval receiving-ship New-Hampshire, in tow of the supply-ship Newbern, arrived this forenoon. The former vessel anchored in the stream, where the will remain until Monday next, when she goes to Gosport Navy-yard to relieve the Constellation. The Newbern sailed directly for New-York. The double-ender naval steamer Winnepec, which for several weeks past has been undergoing repairs at the Navy-yard, sailed to-day.

The warm weather of which I spoke in my last was of brief duration, and now I am shivering over an inadequate fire in the grate. May has been emphatically a cold month, with two or three frosts of sufficient severity to injury tender vegetation. Yesterday we were visited by a cold northeast storm,the wind blowing a gale.

In steamship City of London, from Liverpool--Mrs. Read, Miss Kate Read Miss Sinclair, C. Read, Mrs. E. Graham, R. Graham, Mrs. Daley, 3 children and nurse, Mrs. M. Hotehkiss, Miss Lizzie Campbell, Mrs. and Master Barbour, Miss Flora Harbour, Miss McCrer, Mrs. and Miss Daloch, Mr. and Mrs. Ekowell, John Gillespie, F. Williams, C. St. John, E. Scott, J. Campbell, A. Cox, J. Tear. G. Harding, J. Coveny, Mr. and Mrs.

When a New-Yorker looks to the country for a safe and pleasant Summer retreat for his family, and himself on Sundays, why does he naturally turn only northward? The Saco Valley, with Mount Washington in the distance, the Berkshire Hills by the lovely Housatonic, the Highlands overhanging the noble Hudson, carry music in their names, but why not also this beautiful Blue Ridge and the graceful Valley of the Delaware? Why look askance at New-Jersey?

This Board mot at 2 o'clock P. M,, yesterday, Mr, BRICE in the chair. A resolution was adopted directing the Comptroller to furnish the Common Council with semi-monthly reports of the condition of each appropriation, with the balances. A report in favor of directing the Street Commis sioner to cause the removal of the rails laid by the Harlem Railroad Company in Franklin-street, between Centre and Elm, was laid over.

The Inman steamer City of London, Capt. MIREHOUSE, which left Liverpool at 3 P. M. on the 23rd, and Queenstown on the 24th of May, arrived here yesterday morning. The steamship Nova Scotia, from Liverpool May 24, vid Londonderry May 25, passed Father Point yesterday, en route to Quebec.

Yesterday afternoon, the Committees of the Board of Health, the Commissioners of Emigration and the Quarantine Commission embarked at Whitehall on the United States steam cutter Uno, under command of Lieut. PHILLIPS, and went on a voyage of inspection, with a view of selecting a fit spot on which to land the thousand immigrants who are imprisoned on the six pest-ships in the Lower Bay.

Large posters announce the arrival of the great tragedian. "FORREST has arrived!" in large typo, all over town, and close on his heels follows "The Great Circassian Magician." I believe they both came on the same steamer. FORREST everybodyknows, but the Circassian nobody does.

S. P. MULLIGAN, of Indiana, has again come to grief. This individual, it will be remembered, was at the head of the Sons of Liberty in that State. He was arrested, tried and convicted for treason, and sentenced to be hanged. Having been pardoned by President JOHNSON, he returned to his State, a few days since, and addressed the Democrats at Bluffton.

Present--John Brice, Esq., President; Aldermen Moore, Coman, Norton, McBrien, Flynn, Shannon, Gedney, Ely, Ryers, Reilly, Masterson, Varnum, O'Brien, McGinnis, Van Voorhis. The minutes of May twenty-eight and thirty were read and approved.

In response to tho call for a grand demonstration in opposition to the present action of the Board of Excise, the German populace turned out in great strength early yesterday afternoon, wending their way in the direction of Union square, the placenamed for their meeting.

The steamship City of London at this port, and the Nora Scotian at Father Point, bring two days' later news from Europe. The German war question remains unchanged, and there is nothing new with regard to the proposed conference. There had been several additional failures in England, and the financial prospects were said to be very gloomy.

There does not appear to be much change in the warlike situation on the frontier during the last twenty-four hours. Col. O'NEILL, of Andersonville, and his men, are still, we be lieve, under guard of the United States steam er Michigan, in the Niagara River, above the Falls, and the remainder of the Fenian army are stationed at various indefinite points southof the St. Lawrence and the Lakes.

Yesterday was the first day of the regular June term in many of our civil courts. Two circuits, two superior Court trial terms, and two common Pleas trial terms, are advised to be held this month,, common, commencing yesterday. By law 104 jurors should have been summoned for each of the Superior Count: 104 for each branch of the Common Pleas; and 100 for each Circute total, 616.

It appears, says the Wheeling intelligencer, that a clerk of the Virginia Direct Tax Commission has been attempting to collect this tax in Hampshire and other border counties of this State, on the ground that when the direct tax was laid they wore a part ofthe State of Virginia.

I had scarcely closed my articles on " Gold" when we hear of a commercial shock in England, which is as startling as if caused by electricity. The London Times talks of a groat " panic" as if, people got into debt and failed for many millionsbecause of a panic. No doubt there was a panic.

Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON has addressed the following letter to JOHN HOGAN: WASHINGTON, D.C. SENATE CHAMBER, May 90, 1866. DEAR SIR: Your note of the 28th inst, is received. The inquiry you make I answer briefly. The main question in the cases of GARESCHE and CUMMINGS, to which you refer, was whether the test oath required by the Constitution of Missouri was Constitutional.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your editorial of this morning " on the hor rors of Quarantine," I most heartily concur. But if you had headed it "Horrors of No Quarantine," it would have been more appropriate, For the six years that I held the office of Resident Physician my constant effort was to urge the State to locale and organize a properQuarentine. Being unsuccessful,

THE NATIONAL TELEGRAPH. The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Postmaster-General in response to a resolution adopted some months ago, calling for information as to the cost, practicability, , of establishing a national system of telegraphing in connection with the Post-office Department. Referred to the special Committee on the subject of the national telegraph system.

BIGELOW--BLEECKER.--At Newark, on Tuesday, May 29, by Rev. J. S. B. Hodges, FREDERIC BIGELOW and HARRIET VAN RENSSELAER, daughter of the late Alexander N. Bleecker, of this City. BUTTRICK--ROMEYN.--At Detroit, Mich., on Thursday, May 31, by Rev. William Hogarth, D. D., FRANK BUTTRICK, of Milwaukee, Wis., and SUSAN VAN VRANKEN daughter of Theodore Romeyn. Esq.

The Fenian excitement here is rapidly subsiding, the so-called invasion having proved so ridiculous a failure. It was popularly believed last night that the majority of the Fenian Prisoners now in custody of Capt. BENSON would be permitted to escape under cover of the night, It is scarcely necessary for me to say that not one has escaped so far.

The details of the overflow of Alexandria are heart-rending. The people were driven to rafts for protection, and an immense amount of property was destroyed. No relief is possible till the floods subside. The floods in Texas have overflowed and devastated all the bottoms, and the injury to the crops is extensive.

By the returns made to the Commissioners of Emigration by Mr. CASSERLY, General Agent, it ap pears that the number of alien emigrants who arrived at this port, mostly from Europe, during last month, was 40,049. In no corresponding month in several years has the number of these arrivals been so large. The following are the returns of aliens only who have been landed hero since the 1st of January,1866;

CASEY--THORNTON.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, June 5, by Rev. Dr. John McViear, Brovet Major JAMES S. CASEY, Fifth U. S. Infantry, and ADELIA, daughter of the late Brevet Brig.-Gen. W. H. Thornton, U.S.A. DRESSER--OLMSTED.--At Yonkers, on Tuesday, June 5, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. D. M. Seward, D. D., HORACE E. DRESSER, of Nov-York, and CECILIA M., daughter of John Olmsted, Esq.

GEN. SCOTT.--Mr. BRADY, corner of Broadway and Tenth-street, has the last great picture that was taken of SCOTT and his Staff or military family. The old here sits proud and defiant, surrounded by the historic names of HAMILTON, CULLUM, TOWSEND, VAN RENSSALAER, WRIGHT and WILLIAMS. A finer group it would be difficult to conceive; a more interesting picture does not exist.

Major F. L. POPE, Asistant-Engineer of tho Russian-American Telegraph, has reported to Col. BULKLEY, Engineer-in-Chief, that he has surveyed the country from Lake Tatla to the head waters of Seeking River, British Columbia, a distance of 300 miles, and found an excellent route for building atelegraph line the entire distance.

ALLEGED MALFEASANCE IN OFFICE.--Two or three years since the Legislature passed an act creating a new office for Kings County, known as the "Commissioner of Jurors," whose duty it was to take the names of citizens from the tax lists, and summon a sufficient number to serve in the various Courts during trial terms.

The Paterson Spring Race Meeting commenced yesterday under auspices of the most flattering character, with the single exception of the weather. The horses lineage of blood and performances out he turf; the prize run for were rich and liberal, and the attendance for larger and more select than was ever before seen on the opening day of the meeting, on which the memorable "Jersey Derby" was to be run.

NITAL PENSION FUND. Mr. GRIMES Called up the following resolution, which on motion of Mr. FESSENDEN, was laid upon the table: Joint resolution amendatory of a resolution regulating the investment of the Naval Pension Fund, approved July 1, 1864.

Yesterday morning's TIMES contained an account of the visit of the Board of Health, the Quarantine Commission, and the Commissioners of Emigration to the Shores of the Lower Bay, in quest of a few acres of dry land whereon to disembark the thousand uninfected immigrants who now crowd the decks of the six cholera ships in Quarantine.

THE SOCIETY FOR THE PREVENTION OF CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.--It is earnestly to be hoped that this most beneficent association will not injure its usefulness, and bring itself into public contempt, by carrying before the Courts cases which are trivial and foolish. There is enough of actual, indisputable and out rageous cruelty to beasts to be looked after, without flying after dubious eases or casesthat do not deserve notice at all.

The following is a complete list of the prisoners now in the hands of the Fenians at this point. They were captured in the fight at LEWIS'S house in the village of Fort Eric this afternoon. All are well treated and appear to be very comfortable: Lieut. Scofield, Isaac Pew, Robert Offspring, Wm. Black, Gideon Griswold, Robert Armstrong, Wm.Brown, Jacob Garner. Jno. Waters, ...

We spoke some days since of the extradition proceedings in the case of CARL NOELTE, and the prospect that in its further prosecution some important questions in the law of extra dition might be brought before the Court for determination, Of the importance of one ofthese questions there can be no doubt.

One hundred miles of the Union Pacific Railroad were completed yesterday, giving 383 miles of continuous rail west of St. Louis. This Company is now running 126 miles of road, including the Lawrence and Leavenworth branch, and will reach Fort Riley in the latter part of July.

For several years Mr. LOSSING has been diligently engaged in collecting and arranging the material for a history of the late war. He is still occupied in the prosecution of this work, and as the immediate result of his labors we have this large and handsome volume, which covers the period from the inception of the rebellion to the battle of Ball Run.

At the meeting of the Metropolitan Board of Health yesterday afternoon, Dr. DALTON transmitted the following, which is DR. HARRIS' WEEKLY LETTER, The death records for the week ending last Satur day are herewith submitted. They teach important lessons, some of the most practical of which can best be studied in connection with your Sanitary Inspectors' daily returns, your own official order book and Capt,LORD'S returns of nuisances abated.

Cotton nominal ; sales 100 bales ; low middlings, 53c.@35c.; receipts of four days, 3,726 bales, against 2,219 same time last week; exports, 19,480 bales ; stock, 124,423 bales. Bank sterling, 58. New-York bank checks, 5/0 premium. In the McDONOUGH autographic will case, PIERRE SOULE presented a petition for releasing.

THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR. Secretary HARLAN left here this evening for Indiana, were he proposes to spend ten days or two weeks among relatives. The proposed temporary ?? sence of Mr. HARLAN has been magnified by the curbstone gossips into withdrawal from the Cabinet,

From the Chicago Republican. There is no mistaking the temper of the country. It wants the business of reconstruction closed up with as little delay as possible. Gentlemen in Congress must remember that the settlement of this question does not rest with them alone. Every proposition to amend the Constitution has to be ratified by the Legislatures of twenty-seven States.

Piracies in the Chinese waters still continue. Six hundred and fifty Chinese emigrants on the ship Napoleon Canavars mutinied and set fire to the vessel, The captain and crew escaped in small boat. Pirates attacked the ship Mahee on the 18th of March, but after a vigorous fight they were driven off.

THE FISHERIES.--It is gratifying to know that the suggestion which has more than once been alluded to in these columns for avoiding difficulty on the provincial fishing-grounds, has been acted upon by the Government ofCanada.

The bill before Congress to encourage the planting of forest trees upon the Great Plains of the Far West, is one which deserves prompt sand favorable consideration. We spoke of the idea the other day as one of those vast Western conceptions which, with all their magnitude, are yet of a sufficiently practical character to merit attention and encouragement.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. EDMUNDS reported the House bill for the protection of the lives of passengers traveling on steamboats on the Western rivers. Mr. POMEROY introduced a bill to authorize the Secretary of the Interior to lease and preserve the public lands of the United States which contain mineral springs.

STOPPING A PRIZE FIGHT.--Information was received at the West Philadelphia Station-house, on Saturday afternoon, that a prize mill would be fought on Sunday. Lieut. TOLBERT, with twenty-policemen, watched the outskirts of the ward until 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Then they ascertained that the fight was in progress at Gray's Works, on the Darby road, near the Media Railroad intersection. The detachment reached the grove just as the mill was commencing. It was hurriedly postponed.

The TIMES has the good fortune to enjoy in about equal proportions the polite attentions of Radicals and Copperhends. It does not please either of them. It is denounced by both as in the wrong, although in the argu ment each contrives to contradict the other; and so, between the two, our course is justified.

The court-martial adjourned till Monday. Gen, DAVIS has been instructed to obey the writ of habeas corpus served upon him on the petition of HENDERSON. The adjournment prevented the presentation of testimonials relative to the good character of Mr. HOGE, from influential citizens of Wheeling, Va., and several members of Congress.

Judge UNDERWOOD, not being the most learned of lawyers nor the ablest of men, has naturally enough, perhaps, so tangled tile legal threads as to make a Gordian knot of the Davis trial, which will require much patience and ingenuity to unravel, and unraveled it must be before things can proceed decently and in order.

It may not be generally known that all along Prussia, under the lead of BISMAROK, has had other objects in view beside mere ter ritorial aggrandizement by the absorption of the Elbe Duohies-Schleswig-Holstein, Prussia has what may almost be called ahereditary plan for the future.

THE END AT HAND.--President JOHNSON has, through the Attorney-General, issued orders to all United. States District-Attorneys and Marshals, requiring them to arrest the leaders of the "men called Fenians" whenever they (Attorneys or Marshals) have rea son to believe that such leaders have violated or may be intending to violate thelaws of neutrality.

A mooting of colored people, Rev. JOHN PETER SON presiding, was held last evening, at their church in Bulllvan-stroot, for the purpose of discussing the best means to be employed to secure to the colored people the right of suffrage. A great number of rose lutions were offered, which elicited much discussion, Messrs. RAY, PEPPER, DOWNING and others participat ing. The following preamble and resolutions werefinally adopted:

NEUTRALITY.--That narrow-minded section of the Canadian people whose sympathies were so freely extended to the Confederate thieves and assassins during the late rebellion, will probably see, by this time, what sort of thing real neutrality is. The patrons of SANDERS and WILKES BOOTH are exceedingly clamorous at this crisis for the observance ofneutral obligations.

The Ville do Parts, from Brest, on Saturday, 26th of May, at 4 P.M., arrived off Sandy Hood at an early hour yesterday morning, where she was detained seven hours by fog. Her actual running time was nine days and six hours.
PRESERVATION OF NEUTRALITY. The Attorney-General has issued the following circular to the District-Attorneys and Marshals of the United States: ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S OFFICE, WASHINGTON, June 5, 1866.

"The die is east." The resolutions presented by Rev. Dr. GURLEY, appended to the Committee's report, were adopted by the Assembly this morning at 11 o'clock, which was the time agreed upon yester day by the Assembly. As I wrote you, yesterday, the majority good-naturedly agreed to restrict their speak era to fifteen minutes each, and to give unlimitedtime to the defendants.

THE HUMAN TIDES.--Forty thousands and forty-nine elien-born immigrants arrived at this port during the last month. This is nearly double the arrivals in the corresponding month of last year, and those of the first five months of this year are nearly double thoseof the same period last year.

The Soldiers' State Convention assembled at the Academy of Music to-day. Gen. JOSHUA T. OWEN was chosen President, with a largo number of Vice Presidents and Secretaries. Resolutions were adopted denouncing the appoint ment to office of men who embarrassed the operationsof the Government;

At length our suspense is over. Gen. DULCE is relieved, by the arrival of his successor, from the task which latterly weighed so heavily on his broken health. Den FRANCISCO LERSUNDI arrived on Wednesday morning in the frigate Navas de Toloso, and was rowed ashore in the State barge of the Admiral, by fifteen Captains of Biscayan vessels.

The steamship Africa, from Liverpool May 25 vid Queenstown May 27, reached Halifax yesterday morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received. It is confirmed that the three neutral powers had sent identical notes to Berlin, Vienna, Frankfort and Florence, inviting all the Powers to a conference.

The testimony favorable to HOGE will not be received in Court, it not being sworn to, and being simple letters of recommendation. A grand festival for disabled Confederates in Edge field was held to-night. A terrible hurricane passed over Pulaski. Trees were prostrated and other damage dons,

From Vern Cruz we have new up to the 19th ultimo, and it is rather interesting. CORTINA has been completely defeated by OLVERA, who, leaving Matamoras during the night, marched to where CORTINA was encamped. The force of the latter was not great--about 150 pr 200 men, of whom 30 were killed and 50 made prisoners. Their leader lost his watoh,

The Supreme Court of the of Missouri, at its March session, 1866, has just reversed the ruling of the Court below in the case of JOHN WANN vs. The Western Union Telegraph Company," and has rendered a decision of great importance not only to telegraph companies, but to the commercial community in general.

There was quite a large attendance of spectators in the court room this morning, including nearly all the members of the Richmond Bar. Messrs. REED, BRADY and BROWN, counsel for Mr. DAVIS, entered the Court-room about 10 o'clock, and awaited the opening of the Court.
We find, a very noteworthy indication of the temper which animates a large number of professed Union newspapers, in the following paragraph from an article in the Cleveland,Ohio, Leader:

A HOTEL ATTACKED AND ROBBED BY BUR GLARS.--About 3 o'clock yesterday morning a party of burglars drove up to Stroebel's Hotel, situated at the corner of Myrtle-avenue and Cypress Hills Plank Road, and, leaving their wagon, forced an entranceby prying open the front door.

BURGLARY BY DAYLIGHT.--On Friday last the store of EUGENE EBENHART. No. 474 Broadway, was entered by burglars and robbed of lace goods and silk necklles of the value of $1 500. The store had had been closed in the afternoon on the occasion of Gen. SCOTT'S funeral, and the proprietor had gone hone.

A NOVEL ENTERPRISE.--We saw, yesterday, upon the river near the gas-works, the keels of a novel grist-mill, which we understand Capt. M OALLISTER is building. It is to be a boating mill, moored in the river, where the current is swiit and strong, and the motive power is to be the water in its natural course, without full or artificial race.

The pending treaty with the Indians at Fort Laramie promises to be an interesting affair. Passengers in from there to-day say about twenty-five thousand of the Indians are now there, and though their condition is that of exposure and destitution, the Chiefs of the Cheyennes and Arappahoes exhibit their traditionary independence and insist that their buffalo herding grounds must be conceded to them, or they will not stipulate for peace.

The Gazette's Memphis special gives a gloomy account of affairs in Mississippi and Louisiana, from the destructive floods, the cold weather, He predicts there will be famine in the South before another season. Planters have neglected planting grain, hoping for an immense yield of cotton and big prices.

The steamer Winchester, Capt. GREGORY, six days from Havana, short of coal, has arrived, bound to New-York. She encountered on Sunday a heavy southwest gale, lasting twenty-four hours. The day before she sailed the crew mutinied, and three were put in irons by the United States Consul, to be delivered to the United States District-Attorney for trial.

GRAND MASONIC MEETING.--The large hall of the Cooper Institute was well filled yesterday evening, in spite of the untimely thunder-shower, with the members of the Masonic Fraternity, their families and friends. The object of the meeting was to inaugurate the Fair in aid of the Ball and Asylum Fund, to be held shortly. Grand Master ROBERT HOLMES occupied the chair.

The Fenian "war" now assumes a new form, It is an insurrection against the power, authority and majesty of the Government of the United States. It has of course had this character from the beginning, and the orders of Gen. GRANT as well as the action of Gen. MEADE have shown that as soon as it assumed a tangible shape, it would be treated in thisway-as indeed it could be treated in no other.

The steamship Africa, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 4 P. M. on the 26th, via Queenstown 27th ult., arrived at Halifax this morning en route to Boston. She has 43 passengers for Halifax and 77 for Boston. The political situation on the Continent was not materially changed.

CHEAP BREAD.--At this time, when all the provisions and necessaries of life are so high, and when most of us have to resort, or ought to resort, to every possible economy, it is astonishing that there is not a more extensive employment of maize or Indian corn forbread.

THE FINAL REPORT OF THE RECONSTRUCTION COMMITTEE. Senator FESSENDEN, at the meeting of the Reconstruction Committee this morning, presented the Committee's final report, which was accepted. It reviews the whole matter of reconstruction, giving the reasons which influenced the members of the Committee in adopting the measures recommended by them, heretofore reported to Congress.

HUNGARY AND AUSTRIA.--There is reason to doubt the statement that comes to us from Europe that Louis KOSSUTH is endeavoring to cripple the military movements of Austria byexciting revolution in Hungary.

A correspondent of the BOSTON Advertiser of the 4th inst. says: "Very agreeable letters, dated May 3d and 4th, were received in this city to-day (Saturday) from Prof. AGASSIZ. They were written at Rio de Janeiro, where he had arrived a few days earlier from his eminently successful expedition up the Amazon, and while he was making his arrangements to return home.

The Convention of Freemasons resumed its sessions yesterday morning, the Grand Master, ROBERT HOLMES, presiding. The report of the Grand Treasurer was received, by which It appeared that the total amount of receipts were $40,400 44; expenditures, $37,320 98; totalamount of assets now in Treasurer's bands. $8.073 46.

The Fenian "mass meeting" in the City Hall Park, last evening-advertised to take place at the hour when the working-people are returning from their day's labor-numbered about one hundred and fifty persons, one-third of them urchins, who would have been found romping in the Park had there been no Fenian demonstration and no Fenian orator on the ground.

ENGLISH OPERA IN BROOKLYN.--The appearance of the English opera troupe in Brooklyn has created an enthusiasm in musical and general circles unprecedented since the palmists days of MARETZEK'S subscription season. On Tuesday night the second performance of Mr. EICHBERG'S opera, "The Doctor of Alcantara," drew a crowded house at the Academy of Music.

I have visited the celebrated Bituminous Mountains, particularly that range which here lies off the coast, extending from Point Conception to Los Angeles a distance of 190 miles or more. Throughout this range there runs an outcrop of a thick strata of shaly sandstone, charged with sulphur, asphaltum and similar combustible products.

The Journal's Constitutional Union Convention, reported to represent some fifty counties, has harmoniously dispatched and finished its business today. Its five platform resolutions condemo the heresies of sucession and rebellion, ?? fanaticism and extremeism, all assumption of judicial powers by the Freedmen's Bureau, and all efforts, from whatever quarter, to change, undermine or destroy the Constitutional Union of the States;

The movement on the part of the Board of health on Tuesday night, toward the occupation of ground on Seguine's Point for a temporary resting place for healthy passengers who may arrive at our port in ships from Europe, while said ships are un dergoing the process of disinfection and cleansing,was one of a very peculiar character.

The bark Francis, Palmer brings Hong Kong lates to April 13. Some Chinese at New-Changwee took ??orcible possession of a boy in the service of the American Consul, and his companions, who attempted a rescue, were fired upon. The next day the Counsul, with 40 or 50 persons, pulled down the houses of the Chinamen concerned in the outrage, killing three in the affray.

OUR MILITIA.--Those who saw the large military display in the City yesterday must have noticed certain points in which the in fluence of the practical military training of the war made its appearance. A good many of our old soldiers have joined the ranks of the militia regiments, and a large number ofthe former are now officers in the latter.

The regular term of the United States Court of the Judicial District of Utah was held at Provo City, commencing on Tuesday, 24th inst., and ending on Thursday, 26th inst., Associate Judge DRAKE being the presiding officer. The question of the right said power of the Probate Courts of Utah to issue naturalization papers to persons desiring to become citizens of the United States, was brought before the Court for decision.

As briefly told in the TIMES in the TIMES of yesterday, the flying ship of Professor ANDREWS made her second experimental trip on Tuesday afternoon, taking with her the intrepid Acroneant and his coadjutor, Mr. PLUMB. These gentlemen arrived safely with their apparatus in New-York yesterday morning, and the story of their journey of 30 miles in air is sufficiently interesting to deserve narration.

The public will be startled and many highly respectable families pained to learn that Dr. STEPHEN GRIGGS, of this city, has seriously involved himself with the United States authorities, being now under heavy bonds to appear for trial upon a charge of smuggling.

If that wise philosopher and deep-sighted theologlan, EMANUEL SWEDNBORG, were to return from his last and final journey to the spirit world and visit Boston to-day, he would be hardly more gratified than surprised to find himself jostied about semblage of his followers as is here gathered together.

THE TAX ON COTTON. A petition was presented in the Senate to-day by Senator MORGAN, signed by a number of ex-officers of the Federak Arnt new in Alabama. The petitioners say they are from the Northern States, many of them ex-officers of the Union Army, and always loyal to the Government of the United States. That 3, 000 out of 5, 000 at their class are engaged in the cultivation of cotton.

The inauguration of Gov. SMYTHE to-day was attended with an imposing military and civic display. Among those present were Govs. BULLOCK, of Mas sachusetts, and DILLINGHAM, of Vermont. The Governor's message is devoted to local affairs. The State debt is about $4,161,000. The question of providing suitable homes for working people, is one which interests country and town alike. It is not in our great cities alone that the poor are crowded into small, in convenient, ill-ventilated houses; on a smallerscale, this evil exists in almost all our villages.

The charge to the Grand Jury, recently de livered by Judge UNDERWOOD in the United States Circuit Court at Richmond, has at tracted a good deal of attention, as well it might. It may be divided into two parts, the ono calling the attention of the jury to a cer tain statute of the United States, and the other a violent attack upon the City of Richmond, its people and its Press.

ANTOINE PROBST.--The murderer of the Dearing family will underge the penalty of the law tomorrow, between the hours of 10 and 2 o'clock, As the day approaches no changes whatever is perceptible in PROBST, He eats as heartily and converses as unconcernedly as when first received into the prison.

Whether the meeting of the Great Powers can effect a settlement of the European question is as doubtful as ever, according to the latest intelligence. The original grounds of dispute have somewhat changed, and the Schleswig-Holstein question has become complicated by a revival of the steady and unyielding desire of the Italians to possess Venetia, and the determination of Austria to retain it.

In estimating the situation in Europe some of our journals look no further than to a partitioning of Provinces between the sev eral Powers, so that what Prussia may lose by ceding Silesia to Austria she may gain by the annexation of the Duchies, and Austria may be recompensed for the cession of Venetia to Italy by Silesia, and, as some think, by anaccession of territory on the lower Danube.

FENIANS AT ONE CENT A MlLE.-Gen. MEADE finds a few hundred asses at Malone, who have gone up to "take Canada" with six-shooters and bottled ale. With sarcastic cruelty he suggests that our Government ought to tote these deluded fools back to their former residences at the rate of one cent a mile.

One hundred and fifty Feniana left for Canada this morning, without arms. The rifts and waters everywhere are receding, and there are no-fears of any further floods this year. The people in the submerged country are terribly dis creassed, and relief is daily going out from thiscity.

Having exhausted the delights of Albany, and the beat and mosquitoes having nearly exhausted me, I took advantage of the kindness of a friend who asked me to take a ride through Baker County and see how his fleecy majesty is getting along in one of the most thoroughly loyal counties which acknowledge his dominion.

HENRY GRAVES, conductor on the Poughkeepsic way-freight and passenger train on the Hudson River Railroad, was killed at Hastings to-day by being crushed between two cars, which he was endeavoring to couple. He was a married man and resided at Peekskill. He had been in the employ of the Company nearly fourteen years.

Everything at Seguino's Point was reported quiet yesterday. CONCORDAT BETWEEN ROME AND HONDURAS.-- Senor Don CAROLS GUTIERNE, the Minister at the Court of St. James for the Central American Republic of Honduras, and who had been specially charged some time ago to negotiate a Concordat with the Papal See, has exchanged ratifications with Cardinal ANTONELLI, adjusting, at the same time a variety of differences, respecting ecclasinstical jurisdiction, which had hitherto impaired the friendly relations between the two Governments.

Notwithstanding the President's proclamation and Gen. MEADE'S order, Fenian movements continue in this direction. Two car-loads of men supposed to be Fenians went east from Potsdam Junction this morning. Gen. MEADE and Staff left for the East this morning. The TIMES has again been the cause of universal discussion in Mexican circles. The L'Edafille, French organ here, in referring to the editorial of a late number for the TIMES, declares that now the whole cause of the antagonism of the people and press of the United States to the French occupation of Mexico is a jealous fear that the United Statee will lose the grasp on Mexico that its statesmen havesecretly entertained.

CHICKEN-DUTCHERS AND THE ANTI--CRUELTY SOCIETY.--We trust that the Society which has undertaken to alleviate the sufferings of the horses, cows, chickens, , of this City will not be discouraged although they have failed to prove that a fowl does mind an iron instrument being driven into its head.

Private dispatches received last evening by prominent Fenians announce that the invasion of Canada has met with that result which the TIMES pre dicted from its first inception. The Fenians, dis banded, sick, sore, tired, hungry, disappointed anddemoralized, are on their way home.

In the Senate, yesterday, all other business was postponed and the reconstruction resolution taken up. Mr. JOHNSON addressed the Senate in op position to the amendment, being a substitute for the second section. Alter further debate the joint reso lution was finally put upon its passage and carried bymore than a two-thirds vote-yeas 33, nays 11.

EMPTY THREATS.--Certain foolish men among the foolish Fenians have taken to writing foolish letters threatening those, both native and foreign-born, who have been determined in their opposition to the movement. Of all the silly and ridiculous things connected with Fenianism, this is the most ridiculous and silly, and any attempt at the execution ofthese threats would be more preposterous still.

The Committee appointed ten days ago, at a meeting of the ship-owners and builders of this city, in relation to the strike of caulkers and others, made their report to-day, at an adjourned meeting. The Committee have met with entire success in obtaining signatures to the resolutions adopted at the meeting, and the opinion is universal that there should be no wavering or receding from the positiontaken by the ship-owners,

WILLIAM B. READ, counsel for JEFF DAVIS, ar rived yesterday from Richmond, and by permission of the Government was in close consultation with him last night and to-day. He went North to-night on the steamer Thomas Kelso. He gave no definite information respecting his interview with JEFF DAVIS, either as to being admitted to bail by the Government as many anticipated or his release from imprisonment in any manner whatever.

PROBST the murderer is dead. EDUCATIONAL BUREAU BILL DEFEATED. The House to-day, after full and deliberate discus sion, defeated the Educational Bureau Bill by the close vote of 59 to 61. It was defeated by the votes of the New-England men, who believe in permitting the States and communities to perform the educational functions of the nation.

The regatta of the Yale boats yesterday was largely attended, the shore in front of the Pavilion being crowded with spectators. The boats entered for the shell race were the Varuna and Glyuna, They took their places a few moments after 5 o'clock, the Varuna having the inside, and got the word to go. They rowed down the harbor in fine style, the Glyunaslowly gaining on her competitor.

The Steamship Allemannia, from Southampton on the 30th of May, arrived here early this morning. The steamship William Penn, thirteen days from New-York, for London, put into Plymouth on the 28th, short of coals. The Palmyra, steamer, from New-York, arrived off the Fastret.

PETERSON and WELLS, two of the sailors en gaged in the affray on the ship Semimole, were before the Police Court yesterday. The depositions of wit nesses who desired to leave on the vessel wore taken. The second and third mates, who were reported to bein a critical condition, are improving.
We have read with great astonishment the speech recently delivered by Mr. WILSON, of Iowa, the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the House, on the Reconstruction Bill.

Mr. B. C. TRUMAN, special correspondent of the TIMES, is with us investigating tho proceedings of the Direct Tax Commissioners for this State. The President could not have selected a better man for this duty. He is disposed to deal justly, and surelyno honest man can complain of such an officer.

The New-Haven, Hartford and Springfield Railroad Company made an experimental trip from Hartford to Springfield on Saturday, using peat of their own manufacture. The New-Haven Journal reports that "the whole distance to Springfield and return consumed but about 1,200 weight of peat.

"The Popo," says the Moniteur, "lately visited the works in progress by the orders of His Holiness on the Mount Palatine to excavate the site of the ancient palace of the Caesars. His Holiness, who was accompanied by the Minister of Public Works, expressed his desire to form a large museum of all the objects of art of curiosities which might be secured from the remains of this principal residence of Roman majesty.

Advices from the interior of Georgia and South Carolina represent that heavy rains are playing sad have with the crops. The thermometer to-day, at 2 P. M., was 960 in the shade. Heavy rain is now falling. The British ship Milton, Capt. LOCKHAR, cleared from Savannah on Friday, for Liverpool, with 1,982bales of cotton.

The steamship New-York, Capt. GRAY, from Aspinwall May 1, with merchandise and passengers to Pacific Mail steamship Company, arrived yesterday morning. On the 4th inst., lat. 24 deg., on. 74 deg. 95 mini., passed schooner Valeria, bound North. June5, passed steamship Arizona, hence for Aspinwall.

The preparations for the coming season at the White Mountains are on a much larger scale than usual. Two wings have been added to the Profile House, doubling its capacity for guest, The Flume House will remain closed, as usual, this and the Pro file House being owned by one Company, who find it more profitable to make additions to the latter, andlet the former remain unoccupied.

THE PEACH CROP.-At a meeting of the Phila delphia Agricultural Society, Mr. FISHER stated that the peach crop in Delaware, Maryland and New-Jersey was almost a total failure. On his own place in Mary land he had seventy acres In peach trees; twenty acres of these trees had no peaches on them, and onthe others be would not get one-third of a crop.

There were two incendiary fires in this city last night, involving no large amount of loss. A band of five desperadoes, supposed to be from Buffalo, came here last night and made raids upon the houses of ill-fame here. They succeeded, in one case, in compelling the inmates to surrender up all their valuables at the muzzle of their pistols.

The New-Brunswick Anti-Union organs are very despondent about the elections, though they insist that the Government selected those constituencies most favorable to confederation for opening the campaign. The telegram announces the return of four Union men for Northumberland adds: "This settles the matter in New-Brunswick."

A case of considerable interest has recently occurred in Mississippi, in which an opinion was given as to the nature, on the part of the South, of the recent controversy, viz., whether it was a rebel lion or a civil war. It came up on a suit to enforce the delivery of a certain amount of cotton, for which payment was made in advance, some time before theclose of the war.

The prisoners confined in the jail at Mobile made an attempt to escape lately, but were discovered in time to prevent any of them getting off. The two ringleaders, HUDSON and BOONE, were put in irons. Capt. BETTY, Chief of the Mobile Police, and the reporter of the Register, paid the jail a visit, on learning that BOONE could not be kept ironed. The Register thus tells the story:

MILEAGE AND SALARIES OF CONGRESSMEN. The Speaker presented a letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, transmitting a statement of the amount paid for Salary and mileage to the members of the Thirty-Eighth Congress, which was referred to the Committee on Appropriations.

Capt. FISK, who is to commend the large party of emigrants soon to start for Montans, recently made application to Gov. MARSHALL for one of the howitzers belonging to the State, to be used in case of an emergency for the protection of the emigrants on their way across the plains.
With the leaves and flowers and blue skies of Summer come once more longings for the peaceful country, and for sweet companion ship with cool wood and verdant mead andrippling stream.

If we closely compare some particular fashion of those remote days with the fashion of our own time, we shall be surprised to notice the slightness of the difference in taste. Take, for instance, the mode of arranging the hair. But before all, take the hair itself. Yes, take it, touch it, handle it, look at it long, till you make sure of its color.
To the editor of the New-York Times: Expecting the letter below, of Gen. Dix to me, will be interesting in some way to the public. I am confident you will permit it to be inserted in yourpaper.

On Saturday, in the United States Circuit Court, the case of CHARLES PLATT, indicted for passing counterfeit Treasury notes, was tried by a Jury, and resulted in a verdict of guilty. Sentence, two years in the Northern State Prison. This convict is a son of WILLIAM PLATT, once a Justice of the Peace on the coast of New-Jersey.

The following transcript of a letter received yesterday by the California mail tells its own story: OFFICE OF WELLS, FARGO , SAN FRANCISCO, May 19, 1866. San Juan and Nevada state robbed at 4 A. M. of $3,000; reward offered at 7 A. M.: robbers shot and all the money recovered 2 P. M.; Coroner's inquest 3 P. M.; funeral of the thieves 6 P. M.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You very justly discriminate as between tho Fenian adventurers, on the one hand, and the Irish race, both at home and abroad, on the other. Fenian ism is manifestly a lawless thing in its origin, agencies and objects. It is about as really Irish or Irish.

We noticed in this paper a few days since such facts as had then come to light concerning the murder of JOHN SHALE, a farmer of Cook Township. Westmoreland County. It will be recollected Mr. SHALE left his house on Monday morning before breakfast, and nothing more was heard of him until the Tuesday afternoon following, when his dead body was found in the field on his own farm.

STEEPLES.--Our recent remarks upon the fact that all the churches which have come to a bad end in Broadway have been without steeples, and that the three churches yet left are gilted with steeples, have attracted some discussion upon the question of steeples in their moral aspects.

Some thirteen years since, one HENRY WITKOUSKI, living in the suburbs of Warsaw, Poland, deserted his wife and two infant children, and came to this Country, taking up his residence at first in New-York City, and proceeding thence to St. Louis.

BAILIE.--At Port Chester, on Saturday, June 9, JAMES BAILIE, aged 78 years. The relatives and friends ot the family are requested to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of his son, Samuel Bailie, at Port Chester, onMonday. June 11, at 3 o'clock P. M.

Come, Isabel, come to the soirce Where Flora is placed in the chair; Should you miss it, I'm sure you'd be sorry, For all the beau monde will be there. Only think that for four days together Rare people, plants equally rare, Midst an odor of greenhouse and heather, We gather is plaire et se plaire.

Hon, J. STANTON GOULD, President, and Col. P. B. JOHNSON, Secretary of the New-York State Agri cultural Society, have prepared a most important cir cular, from which the following extract is taken: "We do hereby make known the existence of the rinderpest or pleuro-pneumonia, among the cows in the stables of New-York and Brooklyn, and earnestly advise all purchasers of stock to examine those whichare offered for sale, with reference to this disease.

The steamer Lavacoa arrived from New-Or loans this morning with a detachment of four com panies of 300 men of the Tenth United States Colored troops, commanded by Major WM. F. BAKER, en route to City Point, to be mustered out ot the service. The steamer Norwich is hourly expected with the balanceof the regiment.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you permit me to ask a question? I have been waiting for some one else to ask it, but it seems no one is inclined to do so. What can Dr.PARKER mean when he says cholera is only transmissible by clothing? Do clothes get it? Do they produce it?

I hasten to announce to the readers of the TIMES that the great Fenian raid and invasion is over. The right wing of the Fenian army has retreated from Pigeon Hill to this place, and the members are now preparing for their homeward march.

One of the greatest ornaments of a cosmopolitan city like New-York, as well as one of its necessities, are good public libraries. There ought to be places, retired from the bustle and hurry of the streets, where that important class of every community who mine for treasures unseen, and who lay up the wealth of mind silently and laboriously for other generations, can carry on their quietand useful labors.

Rev. Dr. WESTCOTT, Pastor of the Blooming dale Baptist Church, in Forty-second-street, near Seventh-avenue, delivered a discourse last evening upon the life and public services of Gen. SCOTT. The reverend speaker was long a personal friend and ardent admirer of the renowned soldier. The Church was crowded to its utmost capacity with attentive andinterested listeners.

THE CRISIS IN EUROPE--TIME FOR THOUGHT.--The formal acceptance of the proposal for a Conference, by the three European Powers most intent upon war, revives the hopes of those who pray for peace. There is now timeat least allowed for some further reflection.

Information which I have received since mid night on Saturday, has put a new and important phase on Fenian matters in this vicinity, and I am now fully impressed with the conviction that we shall have more exciting times than ever before thisbusiness is ended.

The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on Thursday, May 31, rid Londonderry, June 1, passed Further Point at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, in route to Quebee. The steamships Malta and Edinburgh arrived at this port yesterday. It is asserted that Austria, Prussia, and Italy have definitely accepted the invitation to the Conference, and communications were being interchanged for arranging a day to meet.

The Edingurgh Review, in the number just issued, and from which we publish an extract in other columns, discusses the problem of "the Reconstruction of the American Union" with candor and friendliness, and an intelligence rarely observable in English periodicals when handling purely American questions.

ARMED NEUTRALITY IN EUROPE--By last night's European arrivals we learn that the latest proposal the Emperor of the French has made to his ally, is to adopt' a policy-of armed neutrality, so that if the Conference should prove refractory, France and Eng land might assume a warlike attitude, and force an acceptance of the decisions which a majority of the mediating Powersmay come to.
The Medina Tribune gives the particulars of a shooking casualty in that village on the night of Thursday, May 31. The dwelling-house of Mrs. MARY RYAN was burned,

THE FREEDMEN'S BUREAU. Senator WILSON will tomorrow report the Freed men's Bureau Bill which passed the House a few days since. He has added several new sections, the de sign of which is to finally settle the disputed land title questions of the sea islands, and of the lands set apart for the freedmen by the well-known order of Gen.SUERMAN.

My last letter having boon devoted to the gent oral aspects and importance of this country, I pro pose in this to refer to the coal regions and endeavor to show their vast importance, not only to the Cape Bretonians and Nova Scotians particularly, but to thepeople of this continent at large.

About 12 o'clock this morning a young man, named JOHN DALE left here in a wagon, to be married to a Miss HATTIE MATHISON, living about six miles north of hare. When about two miles on the road, he received a rifle ball through his body. He fell from the wagon, and turned the horse loose, thinking by this meansto call assistance.

One of a party of laborers, who were walking on the track of the Hudson River railroad, just south of Hudson, on Saturday evening last, fell through a bridge and was drowned. His body has not yet been recovered. The body of DANIEL LEROY was found in the Hud son, three miles south of this city, on Saturday. Nomarks of violence were visible on It.

The following extract from a long article in the April number of the Edinburgh Review, on the "Re construction of the American Union," will be read with interest: It is a little more than nine years since Mr. BUCHAN AN made his Inauguration Address as President of theUnited States, It was a high day for slavery.

"Completely and effectually closed" is the language of the law, and throughout the Metropolitan District, excluding the Countries of Westchester and Richmond, the law was observed, yesterday, almost to the letter. Here and there a vonturesome vendor underlook to sell "on the sly," but the police were not long in discovering the offender and putting him under arrest.

THE DOG LAW.--The Mayor's Marshal announces that the law forbidding dogs to run unmuzzled through the streets will be enforced on and after the 18th instant. All dogs caught in the streets and taken to the Pound in Twenty-fifth street, will be paid for at the rate of fifty-cents per dog. No dog will be received from boys.

Believing a few lines from a Bostonian, now on a tour throughout the Southern States, would be intersting to your many readers, I will try and give you details of what was seen and heard in Florence, S.C.

All the paragraphs afloat about an application being made and now pending before the President for the nail and parole of JEFF. DAVIS are without the slightest foundation in truth. The President would have nothing to do in the disposition of thematter of ball under the indictment.

The announcements to-night are as follows: At Wallack's Theatre Mr. DAN. BRYANT 'commences his regular summer engagement, playing in the pieces "Born to Good Luck," and "Handy Andy;" at the Winter Garden Mr. JOHN BROUGHAM offers his friends an entire change of bill, namely: "Flies in the Web," altered from the "Game of Love," and "His LastLegs."

Count RESSIGUIER, who recently visited this City, is a member of MAXIMILLIAN'S household, and Assistant Secretary of the Navy, although a great portion of his time has been spent in the United States as MAXIMILIAN'S confidential and chief agent.

Henry Miller et al. vs. The Steamer Saronia; James McCarthy et al. vs. The same.--These were cases of collision brought by the owners of the schooner Village Bridge and of her cargo to recover the damage occasioned by the sinking of the schooner in a collision with the steamer in this port on the 4th of March, 1865.

A special train from St. Albans arrived late last night, and another this afternoon, bringing altogether about 1,500 Fenians home from the Vermont border all of whom had crossed the Canadian line, except a few strugglers, are included in these arrivals. Transportation was furnished by the United States Government. The Fenian war is ended in that direction for the present.

A most destructive fire broke out shortly be fore 12 o'clock last night In the building on Main street, in Charleston, used as a furniture manufac tory, and as there was a lack of water from repairs being made in the pipes, all the buildings on the square on what is called the "Old Mill Property" were burned, rendering houseless 61 families, embracing some 500 persons,principally Irish. Several firemen were injured,

Yesterday morning Mr. BEECHER, who has for some time past been unusually silent on public af fairs, seemed to be moved by the conjunction of bor der-raids on our late neutral friends and retaliatory reconstruction reports in Congress, to mingle some public instruction with his parochial admonitions. His text was the well-known precept of St. Paul,"Overcome evil with good."

An autopsy of the body of the executed murderer PROBST was made in the clinic room of Jefferson Medical College on Saturday afternoon, in the presence of as many persons as the apartment would contain, all of whom were present by invitation, and most of whom wore members of the medical profession.

In the Senote yesterday the House Bill providing for the ??-steeping of public money intrusted to disbursing officers, was reported and passed. The House Bill pro??ing for the safety of passengers on steam vessels was discussed and laid ever until today.

ACCIDENT ON THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD.--A most miraculous escape was made on the Pennsylvania Railroad on Friday evening by the passengers in a sleeping car, which, in consequence of the breaking of one of the wheels and the snapping of the coupling, went over an embankment forty feet high, completely wrecking it, but, strange to say, not seriously injuring any of the passengers, though some were much bruised.
