The Transcript sketches him thus : "He was a Captain in the Second Regiment of Massachusetts Volunteers, and at the Conclusion of the war he was promoted to be Major.

THE STEAMER WESTERN METROPOLIS.--This vessel, which belongs to the " North American Lloyds," has just been refitted, strengthened and put in complete order. Her machinery has also been overhauled, and she has been supplied with new bollers and water-wheels. She now ranks A 1,

GOLD IN NEW-JERSEY.--Gold has been discovered at Canisteer, in the township of Vernon, Sussex County, and at Wynockie, in Passaic County. A ton of ore, taken from the mine of Mr. S. D. BROWN, in the Canisteer, about five feet below the surface, and apparently of the average quality, has been worked in New-York, and the yield was $88 in gold and $16 91 in silver, or $104 91 in all.

It is quite true, as the TIMES assumes, that the political tone here has greatly improved within the past few weeks. The opposition between Congress and the President is less "pronounced," and there is a more openly avowed desire on both sides for harmony of action, or, if that cannot be had, for the avoidance of needless and useless conflicts.

The Summer season commenced last evening at several places and in many ways. It is difficult, now, to know where or when any season ends. A few years since the lines were more clearly defined. From the middle of May until the first week of September there was nothing that the critic or the public needregard.

BOGERT.--In Brooklyn, on Monday, June 11, RUDOLPHUS BOGERT, in the 56th year of his age. The friends of the family and respectfully invited to attend his funeral from his late residence, No. 215 Bergenat, on Wednesday, the 13th inst., at 3 P.M., without further invitation.

The bark Woodlaader, of and from Liverpool, was wrecked recently near the North Breakers. The deck and rail are under water. Some portions of the cargo, tackle and apparel were saved in a damagedcondition.

CULMNATION OF THE FENIAN WAR.--The wild, Quixotic Fonian demonstration upon the Canadas has terminated, as every sensible per son know it would terminate, in failure and disgrace, but most happily with little loss of life. For this both the Canadians and the Fenians are indebted to the seasonable andefficient "intervention" of our Government.

SIMON SON, from the hospital-ship, landed in the floating hearse, and made their first daylight interment yes terday, and so long as the Police hold the State prop erty on Staten Island there are to be no more midnight burials. Only two bodies were taken ashore,

The now and extensive woolen factory of JOHN C. Ross KENNEDY, and the Evansville and Crawfordsville freight-house were totally destroyed by fire at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The loss of ROSS KENNEDY is $75,000, and they are insured for $21,500, as follows: In the Home, $5,000; in the Security, $5,000;in the Manhattan, $3,000--all New-York companies;...

The demolition of St. Thomas' Church, at the corner of Broadway and Houston-street, which was commenced a few weeks ago, is now nearly com pleted, and scarcely one stone of the edifice remains upon another. St. Thomas was built in 1825, and was once classed among the fashionable churches, but as many of its members moved up town, the clergy and trus tees resolved to sell the edifice and erectanother in a more convenient location.

Connecticut polities is seldom comprehended by outsiders. If, therefore, this epistle should err in any conclusions concerning the recent invitation to the Connecticut Senate to visit the New-York Central Park, let the hospitable people of Bridgeport set the TIMES right.

THE LINCOLN MONUMENT.--We are pleased to find that the interest originally expressed in the erection of a statue of President LINCOLN, is still active and earnest. Born of no casual polit ical enthusiasm, but inspired by genuine public sentiment, time has only deepened the motives and made more clear the propriety of such atribute.

A large and attentive congregation was gath ere in the Bedford-street M. E. Church last evening. in the interest of the Sunday-school cause. Rev. J. H. VINCENT, Sunday-school Agent, delivered a prac tical address on "The Sunday-school as a ValuableAgency in Work in which the Church was engaged."

A fire occurred on Saturday evening in Broad-street, consuming the stores of C. D. NICHOLS Co.; loss, $20,000; insurance, $12,000; CHAS, MACES Co.: loss, $10,000; D. G. MYERHALL Co.; loss, $2,000, and other buildings. The total loss is about $50,000, on which the insurance is small.

The few remaining Fonians loitering about the village left for parts unknown this morning. The Officers and View of the United States Iran-clad Wechawken, Appellants, vs. The steamer Al lanta.-The rebel steamer Atlanta was captured and condemned as prize, and the question now is on the distribution of the prize-moneys. The main and dif ficult question is whether the entire value is to go to the captors, or whether half only is to go to them, andhalf to the Government.

Yesterday the consulting counsel at Albany, Mr. JOHN H. REYNOLDS, telegraphed to Judge MORRIS, the Kings County District-Attorney, that the Court of Appeals had reversed the decision of the General Term, sustaining the convictions and the ruling of the Supreme Court. At the session of the Synod yesterday an ad dross was made by Dr. TAYLOR on the importance of issuing in Arabian version of the Scriptures. He stated that the Spanish version was meeting with an immense demand in Mexico, and the Italian version was being circulated by thousands among the Italian soldiers. Gen GARADALDI, who is a Protestant,favors the introduction of the Scriptures among his followers.

UNION VS. EUREKA-A BRILLIANT GAME AT MORRIS ANIA-ANOTHER VICTORY FOR THE UNIONS. The Union Club, of Morrisania, added another trophy to their list yesterday. Their opponents were the noted Eureka Club, of Newark, and the game, which was played at Morrisania, attracted a large concourse of spectators, who were well repaid for their journey, by witnessing the best and most excitingmatch of the season.

A fearful accident occurred to the down mail train on the Danville Railroad, near Coalfield, this afternoon, caused by the breaking of a switch-rod. The ladies' car was precipitated over an embank ment, making three revolutions, and smashing thecar in the descent.

SUICIDE OF A COLORED SAILOR.--HENRY A. LEWIS, a colored seaman, 54 years of age, committed suicide at the house of MARGARET SENETER, No. 24 First-street, yesterday forenoon, by swallowing about an ounce and a half of laudanum. It appears, from the account of the woman at whose house he boarded, that LEWIS came home on Saturday somewhat in liquor, and with a bottle of medicine, which, discovering to be laudanum, she took away from him.

The English mail Steamer from Vera Cruz, which arrived here on the 4th, brings news from Mexico to the 28th ult., which, although not important, is still of some interest, as showing the disorganized state of the country, and the obstinacy with which the Republicans dispute the authority of MAXMILIAN to be their Emperor.

Tourists and Summer loungers who have not yet made up their minds as to what their routes and resting-places are to be during the present season, would do well to make some inquiry respecting the merits of a trip through the Connecticut valley to the white Mountains and Lake Memphremagog. From our experience last year we do not hesitate to pronounce it as delightful an excursion as can be taken.

The new steamer Grampus was launched from the ship-yard of JEREMIAH SIMONSON, Esq., at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning, in the presence of a large concourse of spectators. The Grampus is a side-wheel steamer of about 1,500 tons burden, and is one of four new vessels now being constructed by Mr. SIMONSON for a new line to Philadelphia. The other vessels are the Norfolk, Richmond and New-York, all perfectly alike.

ITALY.-The most difficult force now to be dealt with, in securing the continuance of peace in Europe, is the belligerent feeling of Italy. The outbreak of war or the continu ance of peace between Austria and Prussia is very much matter of diplomacy and negotiation.

THE STRIKE.-There is reason to believe that justice and reason are resuming their in fluence over men and minds so strangely deluded as, by bringing the great industrial enterprises of our City to a stand-still, to deprive themselves of that employment needful to the health and happiness of their families. Some of the ship-arpenters have gone to work, and others are preparing to follow asensible example.

After a long and most painful illness, the Hon, MOSES F. ODELL, Naval Officer at the port of New-York, died yesterday at his residence in Brooklyn. Mr. ODELL, who, on the 1st of September last, assumed control of the Naval Office, was not an Irishman, as an enterprising contemporary asserts, nor was he a recent convert to the Republican doctriues.

ADOPTION OF THE RECONSTRUCTION RESOLUTIONS BY THE HOUSE-A STRICT PARTY VOTE. The constitutional amendments were promptly called up to-day by Mr. STEVENS, at the expiration of the morning hour, who announced that he should move the previous question at 8 or 3:30 o'clock. Fifteen-minute speeches were then decided upon, and half of the time given to the Democrats, who parceled it out to suitthemselves, It was divided among Messrs, ROGERS.

IMMIGRATION TO THE SOUTH.--Some of the Southern papers are attempting to secure the adoption of practical measures to encourage European immigration to the Southern States--a subject to which we have more than once directed public attention.

Miss SARAH KELLY, a servant employed in Thirty-fifty-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, died on Tuesday night, after thirty-six hours sickness, of cholera. The house in which she dwelt and died is a model of cleanliness and hygienic care. She went on Sunday to visit her sister, who lives in an insalubrious neighborhood in Willett-street, and there she spent the day and part of the evening, returning to Thirty-fifth-street at 9 P.M.

By arrival at this Port yesterday morning of the brig Veteran, from Pence, P. R., we learn that a fire broke out May 29, at Mayague, P. R., destroying a great part of the town. An American man-of-war lying in port sent 150 men ashore to assist in extinguishing the flames. Loss not ascertained.

THE BANKRUPT LAW. Mr. MORGAN presented the memorial of the New-York Chamber of Commerce in favor of the Bankrupt Law. Mr. MORGAN said he hoped the Bankrupt Bill would be reported favorably from the Judiciary Committee at an early day, so as to enable the Senate to pass it.

BERTINE--STUBBINGS--At Mount Vernon, Westchester County, N. Y., on Tuesday, June 12. by Rev. Henry Gidman, Pastor of the Methodist Epise opal Church of Eastchester, Mr. J. h. BERTINE, of New-York, and Miss SARAH, JENNIE, daughter of Mr. Thomas F. Stubbings, of Mount Vernon. No Cards.

WINTER GARDEN. Broadway, between Bleecker and Amitysts. THIS EVENING, commencing at 7 1/2 o'clock, FLIES IN THE WEB and ON HIS LAST LEGS. Characters by John Brougham, Miss Prentice, Miss Mary Carr, Mrs. C. Walcot, Jr., C. Walcot, J. G. Burnett, W. S. Andrews.

FATAL ACCIDENT.-Coroner GOVER held an in quest yesterday at No. 172 Forsyth-street, on the body of PATRICK McCABE, an engineer in the stove polish manufactory of JOHN C. CORELL. It appeared in evi. dence that for some time the hoist-rope of the ele ator has been in an unsafe condition. On Wednes day the deceased was ascending to an upper floor, when the rope parted, and precipitated McCABE tothe basement, causing instant death.

The information in regard to the trade of the United States with British America, pre pared in compliance with a resolution of the House of Representatives, may surprise those who have not hitherto bestowed attentionupon the subject.
The adoption by the House of the proposed Constitutional Amendment, as modified by the Senate, will, we trust, terminate for the time all irritating discussion on the question of reconstruction.

This Board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Presi dent GREEN in the chair. A resolution from the Board of Aldermen, author izing the Street Commissioner to contract for lighting all the public lamps in the City, the contract to be given to the lowest bidder, was concurred in. An ordinance was presented regulating City railroad cars.

Before Judge Cardezo. George W. Hott vs. Jackson S. Shultz and the other members of the Metropolitan Police Commission, Superintendent Kennedy and others.--This case is regarded as a highly important one, for the reason that it has been brought to test the validity and constitutionality of the law passed by the Legislature of this State on the 14th of April last, commonly known as the Excise Law.

In the Senate yesterday a bill was passed authorizing the appointments in the Pay Department of the Navy to be selected from acting Assistant Paymasters who have served two years. Mr. MORGAN presented the credentials of the Chamber of Commerce of New York in favor of the passage of the Bankrupt Bill, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

AMES.--In Middletown, Conn., on Tuesday, June 12, Rev. J. W. H. AMES, in the 29th year of his age. The funeral will take place Friday afternoon. COCKS.--On Thursday, June 14, Miss MARY JANE COCKS, piece of the late Samuel Dodge, Esq. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Saturday, at 2 P. M., from No. 291 West 4th-st.

The American and Western Union Telegraph Companies are about concluding an agreement of union which amounts to a consolidation of interests. The public demand for prompt and uninterrupted transmission of messages renders it indispensable to get rid of all delays in checking and booking from oneline to another.

THE FIRE COMMISSIONERS AND THE FIRE AP PARATUS.--The Board of Fire Commissioners paused resolutions, at their last meeting, prohibiting any fire apparatus from running down any grade on any rail road track in the City, and called upon all magistrates to see that any violation of the ordinance in reference thereto be promptly punished.

It contained the following liberal bequests: To the Treasurer of the yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, on Arch-street, between Third and Fourth streets $10,000; to monthly meeting of same society for the instruction of people of color in Philadelphia, $4,000;to the Tract Association of Friends. $2,000;

The New-Orleans and Liverpool Steamship Company is in trouble. The steamer Florida has been seized. They are on the grandest scale. The Association have $200,000 to pay expenses.

ENGLISH OPERA IN BROOKLYN.--To-night, at Brooklyn Academy of Music, a peculiar version of the "Rose of Castile" will be given by the English Opera Troupe. Miss RICHINGS, Miss ZELDA HARRISON, and Messrs. CASTLE, CAMPBELL and SEGUIN are in the cast.

To-day has been laid the corner-stone of the Westminster Presbyterian Church of this city. The clouds of the morning, which portended rain, cleared away in good time for the public services, and the sunsmiled on the undertaking.

A posse of men to-day attempted to bring into the city two men, named S. A. BOYETT and FRANK WINGATE, arrested for the murder of a man named PAYNE, on Tuesday night. It seems the guilty par ties were informed of by E. N. BANK, an accomplice,who hunted them out near this city this morning.

Since my last the political and military world of Mexico have been in about the same state of perplexity. No new features seem to have announced a more definite settlement of the question. Imperial victories continue to be reported in the official and semi-official papers, but these seem to be well balanced by a painful list of the points abandoned.

Mexico is the political riddle of the world. Outside Governments now confess that they have failed as completely in their dealings with it during the last five years as the Mexicans themselves had failed during the previous forty.

Gen. MEADE arrived here last night, and is at Gen. BARRY'S headquarters this morning. About 2,000 Fenians left here last night for their homes, mostly in the West and Southwest. There are about 400 Fenians loft in town, but they will get off soon. The challenge of the Fenian Gen. BURNS to Col. LOWERY, the British Commandant at Fort Erie, to fight him with an equal number of men, was a pieceof ridiculous bombast.

This morning the woolen and cotton mills of RICHARD GASED. on Fraukford, above Harrison street, were entirely destroyed by fire. Loss, $125, 000; insurance, $72,000. FOSTER Co.'s cotton mill, adjoining, was also burned. Loss, $25,000; insurance, $13,000.

The Senate to-day, in the case of Judge SMITH, of Oneida County, resolved to deny the motion of the respondents counsel to dismiss the charges and discontinue the case; also, that the Senate has jurisdiction over the subject matter involved, and over the respondent's person, and that the trial shall proceed on the message as just sent to the Senate by the Governor.

FUNERAL OF A FENIAN SOLDIER.--EUGENE CORCORAN, who was killed in the recent Canadian raid, will be buried at Calvary Cemetery to-day. The funeral cortege will leave his father's residence, No. 443 First-street, E. D., at 2 P. M. Several military companies, Fenian Circles and Father Matthew Temperance Societies will take part in the funeral procession, which is under the direction of the Graitan Circle. to which to deceased belonged.

BENJAMIN MIFFLIN, who was yesterday consigned to the grave, was a gentleman well known to thousands or our citizens, and especially to the members connected with the newspaper press in Philadelphia. Early in life he was associated with Hon. SIMON CAMERON in publishing the Dolylestown ?? crat.

The citizens of Petersburgh, celebrated June 9, by decorating the graves of the soldiers burled in that vicinity. The Indew says: In a square occupied densely by Confederate dead, repose the remains of Capt. J. A. SMITH, Fourth New-York Volunteers. His grave was very handsome ly decorated-none more liberally so-and the United States flag in miniature waved from amidst the floralhonors.

In the Police Courts on Saturday, the follow ing cases were disposed of; SARAH FORREST, a milli ner, was held for trial on a charge of having forged a cheek. HERMANN F. W. STUCHER, a Prussian, was also committed for trial on a charge of bigamy, preferred againt him by both wives.

Kings County, while paying its last triqute of respect to the remains of her honored son, ODELL, is again called to look upon the face of death, to mourn the loss of a beloved, respected and useful citizen. The Hon. JAMES HUMPHREY, Member of Congress from the Third District, reached his home on Columbia-street, Brooklyn, at 6 o'clock, Thursdayevening, and died of an acute attack of rheumatism.

The intelligence received yesterday by the City of Paris justifies the belief that hostili ties have already commenced in Europe. As we anticipated, the projected meeting of the plenipotentiaries of the Great Powers was abandoned, the .plan of Austria containing reservations which were regarded by France and England as tantamount to a re fusal to join in the deliberationsof the Conference.

DEATH OF COL. SEATON. Col. W. W. SEATON, well known in connection with the National Inteligencer, died to-day, of cancer, with which disease he had been afflicted for some months. He was aged about 81 years. THE ROSSEAU-GRINNELL AFFAIR.

The affairs of the Petroleum Bank, Titusville, Crawford County, and the Venango Bank of Franklin, Venango County, have employed counsel in this city for the purpose of bringing suit against Ex Auditor-General ISAAC SLENKER, and through him against the State of Pennsylvania, for the recovery of a million and a quarter of United States securities deposited with the Auditor-General as security for circulating medium by these banks.

At a meeting of Union-Republican citizens of Penn Yan, the county town of Yates County, in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District of the State of New-York, held at Sheldon's Hall, on the evening of the 18th June 1866, on motion, EDWAR J. FOWLER, was chosen Chairman, and JOHN c. BABOUCK Secretary.

Rev. Mr. FREDOUX, son-in-law of Rev. Mr. MOFFAT, and an agent of the French Missionary Society, has been killed in the far interior of Africa, by a trader, under very remarkable circumstances. A trader, named NELSON, had committed a crime for which he was a fugitive from justice, and followed the track of Mr. FREDOUX, who was on a pastoral journey to Morokwain.

ACTIVE vs. UNA. The game between the Active Club, of New York, and Una Club, of Mount Vernon, which was played yesterday at Hoboken, was won by the Actives, by a score of 23 to 17. The Actives butted very well, but fielded poorly, while the units did very well in the field, but not so well at the bat.

The Chamber of Commerce of this port publishes the proceedings of a special meeting recommending that Congress pass an act to relieve the steam line to China and Japan from stopping at Honolula, as five days would be lost in each passage, or ten days on the round voyage. They also suggest the passage of a bill to subsidize a line of small steamers between the Sandwich Islands and San Francisco.

We are rejoiced to see a greater attention paid continually by the " reformers " of socie ty to the moral appliances against intemper ance; that is, to those cultivating those higher tastes, or satisfying those legitimate desires, whose gratification, with the majority of man kind, seem to take the place of the pleasuresfrom excessive alcoholic stimulants.

It is beginning to be perceived in England that some steps must be taken which will do something more than repress the hopes of lib eral and intelligent Irishmen. Many writers are coincident in the opinion that the method of legislation must undergo a change, and that it must in future be framed with regardto the feelings of the Irish people.

The body of GEORGE GOODALL, who was drowned several days ago, was found washed up on the beach this morning. The deceased was a native of Vermont. The body will be interred here by the authorities until they can be made acquainted with the wishes of his relatives.

ST. STEPHEN'S COLLEGE.--The corner-stone of the Ludlow and Willink Hall of St. Stephen's College, at Annandale, Dutchess County, in this State, was laid on Wednesday last with appropriate ceremonies. Service was held in the college chapel at 2:30 P. M., after which a procession was formed and marched to the site selected for the building in the following order: Students, people, invited guests, trustees, clergy, officiating clergy.

The occurrence of sporadic cases of cholera here and there over the City, though happen ing every season, should this year be a sharp warning to all our citizens to attend to sanitary precautions. Most of the recent cases seem to have been stimulated, if not caused, by the filth and bad ventilation and poisoned atmosphere of our lowest Wards.

The news from Europe by the City of Paris is of the highest importance. The Peace Conference has been abandoned, and all hope of averting war has vanished. The responsibility of this failure is thrown upon Austria, that Power having made demands that rendered it useless to hold a conference. When the City of Paris left Liverpool, it was supposed that hastilities might break out immediately.

Various effort have been made to introduce cooking apparatus--heated by petroleum, naptha and by coal-gas--into general favor, but the objections to all of these were so many as to exclude them from general use.

ANNA DICKINSON, in a Woman's Rights meeting at Boston lately, gave some reminiscences of her early life. She had done hard manual labor, had sewed, taught, copied letters, stood in a store, worked in the mint, before she chose the platform as a profession.

STABBING AFFRAY.--About 8 o'clock last evening, PETER VALENTINE and PATRICK CRAIG quarrelled in East Thirty-third-street, which resulted in a fight. During the meleo CRAIG drew a knife and stabbed his opponent in the back, causing a severe and dangerous wound. As soon as the act was committed CRAIG proceeded to the East Thirty-fifth-street Stationhouse and surrendered himself to the Twenty-first Precinet Police.

CHOLERA IN SCHENECTADY.--The real Asiati cholera has made its appearance in Schenectady, twenty-two miles north of Troy, and three victims have already been claimed by the pestilence. The first victim was JAMES LADER, who was taken sick on Monday night and died Tuesday morning. He had been troubled with diarrhoe for several weeks, but not so much as to incapacitate him for business.

A SAD SIGHT.--A raving lunatic was brought to this city yesterday for treatment in the asylum. He was formerly a soldier, a member of the Forty. first Regiment. His name is GEORGH W. BASSETT, He was one of the Andersonville prisoners, and the terrible privations which he then suffered so shattered his constitution that he never fully recovered, and was finally reduced to his present pitiable conditions.

CHANDOS: A novel by Onida, author of "Strathmore," , Philadelphia: J. B. LIPPINCOTT CO. Chandos is assuredly a novel--there can be no doubt of that fact, and more than this it is in some respects a remarkable novel--curious would perhaps be a more appropriate adjective did it not involve tantology to apply it to a novel. Impossibilities are the staple of the book.

FENIAN FUNERAL--AN IMPOSING DEMONSTRATION.--The funeral of EUGENE CORCORAN, the young Irish soldier recently killed on the Canadian frontier, took place from the residence of his father, No. 343 First-street. Eastern District, yesterday afternoon. It had been arranged that the funeral take place from the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, of which Father MULLANE is Pastor, but Bishop LOUGHLIN refused permission to have the body taken there.

The following was issued this morning: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, June 18, 1866. The President directs the undersigned to perform the painful duty of announcing to the people of the United States that LEWIS CASS, distinguished not more by faithful services in varied public trusts, than by exalted patriotism at a recent period of political disorder, departed this life at 4 o'clock yesterdaymorning.

The John-street Mothodist Episcopal Church withstands the up-town current of church-going, and still invites sinners to, "come in and see the wonders God hath wrought" in the only re maining down-town sanctuary. It was fitting that one of the centenary meetings. of Methodism should have been held there.

A committee of the various Gorman organize tions of this City was appointed some time ago to make preparations for an excursion to Landman's Park, the proceeds to be devoted to the aid of the sick and wounded veterans of the late war in destitute circumstances.

The funeral of the late Col. W. W. SEATON, this afternoon, was attended by a very large number of persons, including Secretary SEWARD and others of public prominence. His remains were followed to the Congressional Cemetery by the Mayor of Washington, Ex-Mayors WEIGHTMAN and FORCE, the City Councils, the Association of Old Inhabitants and the Society of Defenders of Washington in the war of 1812, of which Col. SEATON was an honored member.

An important meeting of the advocates of early closing was held last evening at Clinton Hall. The hall was well filled with ladies and gentlemen, the representatives of the employes, who claim a partial release from the onerous duties and long hours of their labor, in obtaining the concession from their employers of a few hours' relaxation in the week.

The ship-carpenters and joiners having concluded to resume the labor which they had refused for ten weeks, business in the several ship-yards is being prosecuted again with the usual vigor and zeal which characterizes our ship builders. A Fatal Case of Cholera occurred here yesterday afternoon, that of a gentleman who arrived from New-York by Saturday night's train. He died about 4 o'clock in the afternoon at one of our infirmaries. The disease was no doubt contracted in New-York. The name of the deceased was WM. HOWARD, and he was 44 years of age. His father resides in the western part of the city.

William Y. Brown vs. William C. Larkingtontal.--the plaintiff brought this action to make the stockholders of the Bank of Tekama, chartered and organized under an act of the Territorial Legislature of Nebraska, personally liable for the issues of the bank held by him and also upon certain promissory notes made by the President of the bank, in the settlement of his account with the concern.

THE BRITISH REFORM BILL.--The Govern ment of Lord RUSSELL has, for the time at least, escaped defeat on the Reform. Bill. Elated with their previous successes,, the Tories and one or two renegade Whigs attempted a sur prise in Committee of the House of Commons, by moving a postponement of the Franchiseclause of the Bill.

NEW BOWERY THEATRE.--The BUISLEY family, concerning whom much has been said and written, and of whom much was therefore expected, made their first appearance last night at this exclusive and well-proportioned establishment. The piece selected for the occasion was "La Pied de Monten," or the "Sheep's Foot."

The steamer North Point, firm Savannah, bound to Baltimore with cotton, became disabled at 4 o'clock. this morning, twelve miles north of Hatteras. She was spoken shortly afterward by the steamer Fannis, from Baltimore for Savannah, taken in tow, and arrived here this morning. She was towel to Baltimore by the steamer State of Maryland this afternoon.

The Freedmen's Convention meets here in July. The delegates have been elected from all parts of the State. THE ATLANTIC FERRY.--Nearly all the great Atlantic steamship lines are this year outstrip ping their efforts in previous years as to re gularity and speed. The keenest contest this season appears to be between the Scotia, of the Cunard Line, and the beautiful new steamshipOily of Paris, of the Inman Line.

Willets., all of Brooklyn.

FRENCH THEATRE.--BALFE'S opera of the "Rose of Castile" is far beyond the capacity of the company now playing at this establishment. It was a mistake to produce it. The theatre possesses no scenery, and the stage no discipline. The orchestra is mediocre; utterly incapable of presenting the ideas which the composer intends to present, and unable from lack of members to contribute even to the polyphosy of a finale.

Between 5 and 6 o'clock last evening, JERRY O'BRlEN, a well-known Eighth-Ward loafer, murdered his mistress, KATE SMITH, In her boarding-house, at No. 189 Prince-street. The girl, who was about 21 years of age, come to this City from Boston about a year ago, and was not long in making herself known to the Eighth Precinct Police, her first exploit being the stabbing of a thief in Wooster-street.

"Porte Crayon's" recollections of the war is the leading, and almost the only real attraction of Harper's New Monthly, (New-York: HARPER BROTHERS,) for July. This installment covers PATERSON'S famous campaign in the Shenandoah Valley.

RHETORIC ON STILTS.--The Evening Post of yesterday makes game of the rhetoric of an "English Squire"-Sir THOMAS BATESON--who recently said in Parliament that "This new born sympathy for the workingman had been begotten by a lust for power, suckled by the unctuous pap of peripatetic stump orators, and dry nursed by the insolent threats and swaggering bluster of domineering agitators."

ANN CROSDY, a colored women, was taken ill, early yesterday morning, of cholera, at No. 228 Church-street. The case was promptly reported to Dr. DALTON, and one of the Health Board's Sanitary Inspectors was sent to the place: He returned to headquarters yesterday afternoon, and reported that the woman was yet alive, but was not expected to live many hours. The patient died at 7 o'clock last evening.

It is a nile long, takes three or four minutes to pass through, and is dark as Erebus fromone end to the other. Yesterday evening,

The steamship Arago, with European advice to June 7, arrived at this port last evening. The malls by the steamship Peruvian reached this City yesterday afternoon. We find in our Europe an files some additional items of interest respecting the political and military situation in Germany and Italy.

A fire in Lawrence last night destroyed the building in Essex-yard, occupied by LADD Co. as a steam planing mill; WILLIAMS BERRY, sash and blind factory, and for other mechanical purposes.Lose $25,000, of which about one-half is insured.

GEORGE SQUILLS, aged 72 years, and his grand-daughter, aged 11, were brutally murdered on Sunday evening last, near Rossville, in York County, in this State. Mrs. SQUILLS, the grandmother, was also terribly injured, and, at last accounts, was in a dying condition.

Tho annual exhibition of the pupils of the Grammar School of the New-York University took place yesterday morning in the University Chapel. The chair was occupied by the Chancellor, and the exercises were opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. E. R.THOMPSON.

The annual exhibition of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum for Boys was held yesterday after noon at the Asylum, Fifth-avenue and Fifty-first street. The large class-room of the building was gaily decorated with flags and wreaths of flowers, ranged in excellent taste by the good ladies under whose watchful care and management this noble institution succeeds so well.

The Crescent brings an "extra" Rio Grande Courier of the 18th, with the details of the capture by the Liberal forces unper TREVIRIL of a large merchandise train from Matamoras to the interior. The train was conveyed by ten Imperial companies, numbering 850 men, under Capt. HOFFA, 100 guerrillas, made up of Confederates, and 1,500 Mexican Imperialists.

The war is to begin on the 10th of June; so it has been said, To-morrow is the 10th, and the out break of hostilities seems to be close at hand. Count BISMARCK has just sent a dispatch to all the Courts of Europe, so full of gall and gunpowder, that nothingseems to remain but bard blows.

Some of our critical and ever-growling neighbors can find no good in the administration of the finances. They are far from being consistent with each other. A score of funding and contracting crotchets are indulged, as widely differing theoretically from each other as their authors profess to differ from Mr. McCULLOCH practically.

The Union State Convention held to-day in this city comprised 1,060 delegates from all portions of the State. Great interest was manifested in the result, the western section very generally supporting Hon. SAMUEL E. SPRING, of Portland, and the eastern section very generally supporting Gen. J. L. CHAM BERLAIN, of Brunswick. A. G. JEWETT, Esq., ofBelfast, was Chairman of the Convention.

The ship Archer, which occasioned the strike among the caulkers, has been stripped, caulked, sheathed and recoppered by the master mechanics of Boston and their apprentices, and it is expected that the vessel will be ready next week to leave for NewYork and load for San Francisco.

Commodore ROGERS communicates the inform ation that the United States steamer Vanderbill arrived at Acapulco on the 30th of May, with the Monadnock, after a passage of eight days and a half from Panama. The town, he says, is occupied by the French, with a single vessel, the Lucifer, of eight guns, lying atanchor before it.
THE NEW ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--We consider it a fortunate incident that the gale of Sunday last blew down the eastern wall of the Acade my of Music, which was left standing after thegreat fire.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN, from the committee on Agriculture, reported adversely on the bill to establish a National Repertory in Germany. A joint resolution was passed giving fitteen hundred dollars to Mrs. ABBLE GREEN for her services in assisting one hundred and nine Union prisoners to escape from Libby Prison.

The annual exercises connected with this fes tive season have been held during the present week, and, as usual, have awakened great interest, and drawn large crowds of persons into the town. The building of the Schenck Astronomical Observatory has been a marked feature in the progress of the institution during the year.

George W. Holt VS. The Commissioners of Excise, and others.--Yesterday Judge CARDOZO, sitting as a Judge at Special Term, delivered the following opinion in the so-called Holt test case. As will be seen by a perusal of the opinion, the Judge has declared the act of the Legislature, passed April 14, 1866, "unconstitutional and wholly void, and therefore the motion to continue the injunction is granted."
AN AMERICAN REPERTORY IN GERMANY. Mr. SHERMAN, from the Committee on Agriculture, reported adversely on the bill to establish an American Repertory in Germany, recently introduced by Mr. HENDERSON.

On last Friday morning, one of the most re markable and melancholy dispensations of Divine Providence was manifested. in this neighborhood which it has ever been our duty to record, Mr. W. T. SISK, who was a farmer near this town, while out quite early in the morning attending to the feeding of some stock during a severe storm, was stricken bylightning, near his stable, and instantly killed.

The Now-York State Temperance Society has Just closed one of its most interesting sessions in this village, Gen. J. S. SMITH, President. Rev. J. F. FAL WELL was elected Secretary, Many of the earnest friends of the cause were present, Advanced actionon the subject of prohibition was taken.

We are informed that the sale of the Southwest Pacific Railroad to Gen. FREMONT was consummated yesterday by the approval of the contract of sale, and by the execution and delivery of the deed to Gen. FREMONT and of the mortgage by Gen. FREMONT to the State. The first installment of purchase money ($325,000) was paid to the Commissioners, who to-day delivered possession to JAMES TANSSIG, Esq., as attorney in fact of Gen. FREMONT.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT--SOUTHERN DISTRICT. Before Judge Smalley. The United States vs. John M. Kean.--The accused in this case was indicted for embezzling letters containing articles of value from the Post-office in this City when he was a clerk. The testimony showed that on Dec. 31, 1864, about dusk, while he and another clerk were sorting the Erie mail, he was seen to put some letters in his pocket.

THE PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE--HIS OBJECTIONS TO THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT. The President to-day sent the following message to the Senate and House of Representatives: I submit to Congress a report of the Secretary of State, to whom was referred the concurrent resolution of the 18th inst, respecting a submission to the Legislatures of the States of an additional article to the Constitution of the United States.

ROUSSEAU, they adopted the following: Resolved, That LOVELL H. ROUSSEAU has conferred on Hon. J. B. GRINNELL, the highest compliment in his power, by his practical acknowledgment that he cannot cope with the lowa member in debate.

The Union Convention to-day unanimously nominated JAMES G. BLAINE for reelection to Congress from the Third District. A resolution was adopted congratulating the people of the district upon the ability, faithfulness and patriotism of their representative in Congress, who is now nominated for the third time.

THE UNITED STATES COURT -ROOM IN BROOKLYN.-- The United States Court in Brooklyn may be considered now as fairly in their new quarters opposite the Academy of Music. The fitting up of the various offices is not yet completed, and will not be for some time. But the Court room was thrown open for business on Wednesday,

Gov. SWANN, of Maryland, made an able address to a meeting, held in Baltimore, on Thursday evening last, and at which he presided. He said: When this war terminated I felt anxious, with all conservative men, to see this country reestablished upon a permanent and enduring basis.

THE TARIFF. The Ways and Means Committee have concluded the Tariff Bill and will report it to-morrow and move to make it the special order for Wednesday. it is the longest Tariff Bill ever reported, and its consideration in the House to likely to last a whole week, as there are many points which will occasion animated discussion.

TROW'S NEW-YORK CITY DIRECTORY.--The publishers of TROW'S New-York City Directory have just issued their edition for 1866-67. The European news brought last evening by the New-York and Germania is extremely important, Hostiaties had not formally commenced, but had been brought one st nearer by the severance of diplomatic relations between Austria and Prussia, and by the landing of GARBALDI in Italy. The Austrians had completely evaluated Holstein leaving that Duchy to be occupied by Prussian troops.

An inquest was hold yesterday, at the Frank lin-street Station-house, by Coroner WiLDEY, over the remains of JAMES BRENNAN, who was shot dead by CHARLES HEINNER, of No. 114 Centre-street, as was fully reported in yesterday's edition of the TIMES. The evidence elicited during the investigation revealed no new facts, as the affair was a very simple one, permitting no secrecy or prevarication.

A tragedy, rivaling those of Deerfield in this State, and Philadelphia, Penn., where whole families were butchered, occurred at an early hour on Tuesday morning, in the vicinity on West Baden, Orange County, Indiana. From what we have been informed of the case, it appears that shortly after the breaking out of the war, a man named McCRACKEN enlisted in the Union ranks.

AN UNUSUAL STREET SCENE.--About noon yesterday an unusal scene was witnessed on Walnutstreet, above Third. A broker, who has his office in that immediate neighborhood, was met by a young woman, who proceeded to apply a cowhide to him shoulders. Only two or three blows were given before he succeeded in seizing the cowhide and wresting it from her grasp.

ARE CITY EXPRESS COMPANIES A CONVENIENCE OR A NUISANCE?--The carelessness and recklessness of very many of our City express men have long been matters of domestic discussion; also, the impertinence, incivility and disobligingness of many of the drivers.

A FOOLHARDY LEAP.--A man named CONNOLLY a resident of Jersey City, who had been to see some friends off in the Philadelphia train from that city at 6 o'clock last evening, remained in the car in whichhis friends were seated until after the train started.

The Post-office Department have issued an order providing that when the present "quarter" has closed that all policy dealers, bogus lottery ticket swindlers,. gift jewelry houses,. obscene picture deal. era, fancy booksellers, and all known public swin dling operators will no longer be permitted to haveboxes at the General Post-office.

Mr. DARLING--Mr. Speaker, the mournful duty of announcing to this House the decease of JAMES HUMPHRFEY, late Representative from the Third Dis trict of the State of Now-York, has been assigned to me by my colleagues. He was my chosen friend and companion, and my friendship and respect for himled to the most intimate and cherished associations.

THE C. A. ALVORD PIC-NIC.--The employes and patrons of C. A. ALVORD'S printing establishment held their first annual pic-nic on Saturday, at Fort Lee, N. J. They were accompanted by a fine cotillion band, and passed the time in dancing, singing and pic-nicing until 3 o'clock, when they repaired to the Pavilion Hotel for dinner, which was served in the most approved stole by the proprietor, Mr. STROAL,after which the Chairman, Mr. WM. HOBART LUCAS.

The Ways and Means Committee were considerably surprised and chagrined to-day to learn that, not withstanding their assurances of entire secresy regarding the features of the new Tariff, they were nearly all public long before the bill was reported in the House. The Committee own it to themselves now to expose the party who divulged the bill, or else abrogate all injunctions of secresy, which are now so often ululated as to be simply ridiculous.

The Steamship Moravian passed Farther Point on noon yesterday, with two days later news from Europe. The United States gunboats Winnepec, Saco and Marblehead and the yacht America have arrived at Norfolk from Annapolis, Md. The Winnepec became disabled coming down the bay, and is now repairing at the Navy-yard at Ports-mouth.

Head-Centre STEPHENS used terribly severe language toward the Fenian invaders of Canada in his speech in this City on Sunday. No epithets were too strong, no denunciation was too vigorous for him, and "traitor" and "coward" passed out of his mouth with al most every sentence. Mr. STEPHENS' elo quence is not of a high order, but some ofhis general ideas are broad and commendable.

The funeral of Gen. LEWIS CASS took place at Detroit, on Tuesday. During the forenoon the remains were visited at the house by thousands of people. Shortly before two o'clock private religious services were held by Bishop McCLOSKEY, of the Episcopal, and Dr. DUFFIELD, of the Presbyterian Church. The body was then taken to the State-street Presbyterian Church, the family of the deceased and a very large audience being in attendance.

Kennedy touched here this afternoon, and took on board 90 colored men and women for Boston, Mass., where homes in various families in that city have been procured for them, On a previous trip, the Kennedy took a like number, Other installments will be shipped North rapidly. Mr. WILSON, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported the bill to extend section four of an act making appropriations for the support of the army for the year ending June 30, 1866. The fourth section referred to relates to previsions granting three months, pay proper to officers upon final discharges.
